• MN 1:0.1Middle Discourses 1

MN 1:0.2The Root of All Things

MN 1:1.1BJ 10.2PTS-VP-PLI 1.1So I have heard. MN 1:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Ukkaṭṭhā, in the Subhaga Forest at the root of a magnificent sal tree. MN 1:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 1:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 1:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 1:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 1:10.1They perceive Brahmā as Brahmā. MN 1:10.2But then they identify with Brahmā … MN 1:10.3Why is that? MN 1:10.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:100-122.1They directly know water … MN 1:100-122.10the gods of abundant fruit … MN 1:100-122.11the Overlord … MN 1:100-122.12the dimension of infinite space … MN 1:100-122.13the dimension of infinite consciousness … MN 1:100-122.14the dimension of nothingness … MN 1:100-122.15the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception … MN 1:100-122.16the seen … MN 1:100-122.17the heard … MN 1:100-122.18the thought … MN 1:100-122.19the known … MN 1:100-122.2fire … MN 1:100-122.20oneness … MN 1:100-122.21diversity … MN 1:100-122.22all … MN 1:100-122.23They directly know extinguishment as extinguishment. MN 1:100-122.24But they don’t identify with extinguishment, they don’t identify regarding extinguishment, they don’t identify as extinguishment, they don’t identify that ‘extinguishment is mine’, they don’t take pleasure in extinguishment. MN 1:100-122.25Why is that? MN 1:100-122.26Because they’re free of hate due to the ending of hate.

MN 1:100-122.3air … MN 1:100-122.4creatures … MN 1:100-122.5gods … MN 1:100-122.6the Creator … MN 1:100-122.7Brahmā … MN 1:100-122.8the gods of streaming radiance … MN 1:100-122.9the gods replete with glory …

MN 1:11.1BJ 10.6They perceive the gods of streaming radiance as the gods of streaming radiance. MN 1:11.2But then they identify with the gods of streaming radiance … MN 1:11.3Why is that? MN 1:11.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:12.1They perceive the gods replete with glory as the gods replete with glory. MN 1:12.2But then they identify with the gods replete with glory … MN 1:12.3Why is that? MN 1:12.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:123.1BJ 10.16A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—directly knows earth as earth. MN 1:123.2But they don’t identify with earth, they don’t identify regarding earth, they don’t identify as earth, they don’t identify that ‘earth is mine’, they don’t take pleasure in earth. MN 1:123.3Why is that? MN 1:123.4Because they’re free of delusion due to the ending of delusion.

MN 1:124-146.1They directly know water … MN 1:124-146.10the gods of abundant fruit … MN 1:124-146.11the Overlord … MN 1:124-146.12the dimension of infinite space … MN 1:124-146.13the dimension of infinite consciousness … MN 1:124-146.14the dimension of nothingness … MN 1:124-146.15the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception … MN 1:124-146.16the seen … MN 1:124-146.17the heard … MN 1:124-146.18the thought … MN 1:124-146.19the known … MN 1:124-146.2fire … MN 1:124-146.20oneness … MN 1:124-146.21diversity … MN 1:124-146.22all … MN 1:124-146.23They directly know extinguishment as extinguishment. MN 1:124-146.24But they don’t identify with extinguishment, they don’t identify regarding extinguishment, they don’t identify as extinguishment, they don’t identify that ‘extinguishment is mine’, they don’t take pleasure in extinguishment. MN 1:124-146.25Why is that? MN 1:124-146.26Because they’re free of delusion due to the ending of delusion.

MN 1:124-146.3air … MN 1:124-146.4creatures … MN 1:124-146.5gods … MN 1:124-146.6the Creator … MN 1:124-146.7Brahmā … MN 1:124-146.8the gods of streaming radiance … MN 1:124-146.9the gods replete with glory …

MN 1:13.1They perceive the gods of abundant fruit as the gods of abundant fruit. MN 1:13.2But then they identify with the gods of abundant fruit … MN 1:13.3Why is that? MN 1:13.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:14.1They perceive the Overlord as the Overlord. MN 1:14.2But then they identify with the Overlord … MN 1:14.3Why is that? MN 1:14.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:147.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.6The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha directly knows earth as earth. MN 1:147.2But he doesn’t identify with earth, he doesn’t identify regarding earth, he doesn’t identify as earth, he doesn’t identify that ‘earth is mine’, he doesn’t take pleasure in earth. MN 1:147.3Why is that? MN 1:147.4Because the Realized One has completely understood it to the end, I say.

MN 1:148-170.1He directly knows water … MN 1:148-170.10the gods of abundant fruit … MN 1:148-170.11the Overlord … MN 1:148-170.12the dimension of infinite space … MN 1:148-170.13the dimension of infinite consciousness … MN 1:148-170.14the dimension of nothingness … MN 1:148-170.15the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception … MN 1:148-170.16the seen … MN 1:148-170.17the heard … MN 1:148-170.18the thought … MN 1:148-170.19the known … MN 1:148-170.2fire … MN 1:148-170.20oneness … MN 1:148-170.21diversity … MN 1:148-170.22all … MN 1:148-170.23He directly knows extinguishment as extinguishment. MN 1:148-170.24But he doesn’t identify with extinguishment, he doesn’t identify regarding extinguishment, he doesn’t identify as extinguishment, he doesn’t identify that ‘extinguishment is mine’, he doesn’t take pleasure in extinguishment. MN 1:148-170.25Why is that? MN 1:148-170.26Because the Realized One has completely understood it to the end, I say.

MN 1:148-170.3air … MN 1:148-170.4creatures … MN 1:148-170.5gods … MN 1:148-170.6the Creator … MN 1:148-170.7Brahmā … MN 1:148-170.8the gods of streaming radiance … MN 1:148-170.9the gods replete with glory …

MN 1:15.1They perceive the dimension of infinite space as the dimension of infinite space. MN 1:15.2But then they identify with the dimension of infinite space … MN 1:15.3Why is that? MN 1:15.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.3They perceive the dimension of infinite consciousness as the dimension of infinite consciousness. MN 1:16.2But then they identify with the dimension of infinite consciousness … MN 1:16.3Why is that? MN 1:16.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:17.1BJ 10.8They perceive the dimension of nothingness as the dimension of nothingness. MN 1:17.2But then they identify with the dimension of nothingness … MN 1:17.3Why is that? MN 1:17.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:171.1The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha directly knows earth as earth. MN 1:171.2But he doesn’t identify with earth, he doesn’t identify regarding earth, he doesn’t identify as earth, he doesn’t identify that ‘earth is mine’, he doesn’t take pleasure in earth. MN 1:171.3Why is that? MN 1:171.4Because he has understood that relishing is the root of suffering, MN 1:171.5and that rebirth comes from continued existence; whoever has come to be gets old and dies. MN 1:171.6That’s why the Realized One—with the ending, fading away, cessation, giving up, and letting go of all cravings—has awakened to the supreme perfect Awakening, I say.

MN 1:172-194.1BJ 10.18He directly knows water … MN 1:172-194.10the gods of abundant fruit … MN 1:172-194.11the Overlord … MN 1:172-194.12the dimension of infinite space … MN 1:172-194.13the dimension of infinite consciousness … MN 1:172-194.14the dimension of nothingness … MN 1:172-194.15the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception … MN 1:172-194.16the seen … MN 1:172-194.17the heard … MN 1:172-194.18the thought … MN 1:172-194.19the known … MN 1:172-194.2fire … MN 1:172-194.20oneness … MN 1:172-194.21diversity … MN 1:172-194.22all … MN 1:172-194.23He directly knows extinguishment as extinguishment. MN 1:172-194.24But he doesn’t identify with extinguishment, he doesn’t identify regarding extinguishment, he doesn’t identify as extinguishment, he doesn’t identify that ‘extinguishment is mine’, he doesn’t take pleasure in extinguishment. MN 1:172-194.25Why is that? MN 1:172-194.26Because he has understood that relishing is the root of suffering, MN 1:172-194.27and that rebirth comes from continued existence; whoever has come to be gets old and dies. MN 1:172-194.28That’s why the Realized One—with the ending, fading away, cessation, giving up, and letting go of all cravings—has awakened to the supreme perfect Awakening, I say.”

MN 1:172-194.3air …

MN 1:172-194.30That is what the Buddha said. MN 1:172-194.31But the mendicants were not happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 1:172-194.4creatures … MN 1:172-194.5gods … MN 1:172-194.6the Creator … MN 1:172-194.7Brahmā … MN 1:172-194.8the gods of streaming radiance … MN 1:172-194.9the gods replete with glory …

MN 1:18.1They perceive the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception as the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 1:18.2But then they identify with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception … MN 1:18.3Why is that? MN 1:18.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:19.1They perceive the seen as the seen. MN 1:19.2But then they identify with the seen … MN 1:19.3Why is that? MN 1:19.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:2.1“Mendicants, I will teach you the explanation of the root of all things. MN 1:2.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 1:2.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 1:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 1:20.1They perceive the heard as the heard. MN 1:20.2But then they identify with the heard … MN 1:20.3Why is that? MN 1:20.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:21.1They perceive the thought as the thought. MN 1:21.2But then they identify with the thought … MN 1:21.3Why is that? MN 1:21.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:24.1They perceive diversity as diversity. MN 1:24.2But then they identify with diversity … MN 1:24.3Why is that? MN 1:24.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.4They perceive all as all. MN 1:25.2But then they identify with all … MN 1:25.3Why is that? MN 1:25.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:26.1They perceive extinguishment as extinguishment. MN 1:26.2But then they identify with extinguishment, they identify regarding extinguishment, they identify as extinguishment, they identify that ‘extinguishment is mine’, they take pleasure in extinguishment. MN 1:26.3Why is that? MN 1:26.4Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

MN 1:27.1A mendicant who is a trainee, who hasn’t achieved their heart’s desire, but lives aspiring to the supreme sanctuary, directly knows earth as earth. MN 1:27.2But they shouldn’t identify with earth, they shouldn’t identify regarding earth, they shouldn’t identify as earth, they shouldn’t identify that ‘earth is mine’, they shouldn’t take pleasure in earth. MN 1:27.3Why is that? MN 1:27.4So that they may completely understand it, I say.

MN 1:28-49.1BJ 10.12They directly know water … MN 1:28-49.10the gods of abundant fruit … MN 1:28-49.11the Overlord … MN 1:28-49.12the dimension of infinite space … MN 1:28-49.13the dimension of infinite consciousness … MN 1:28-49.14the dimension of nothingness … MN 1:28-49.15the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception … MN 1:28-49.16the seen … MN 1:28-49.17the heard … MN 1:28-49.18the thought … MN 1:28-49.19the known … MN 1:28-49.2fire … MN 1:28-49.20oneness … MN 1:28-49.21diversity … MN 1:28-49.22all … MN 1:28-49.23They directly know extinguishment as extinguishment.   • MN 2:0.1Middle Discourses 2

MN 2:0.2All the Defilements

MN 2:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.7So I have heard. MN 2:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 2:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 2:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 2:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 2:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 2:10.1BJ 10.24And what are the things to which they don’t pay attention and should not? MN 2:10.10These are the things to which they do pay attention and should.

MN 2:10.11Because of not paying attention to what they should not and paying attention to what they should, unarisen defilements don’t arise and arisen defilements are given up.

MN 2:10.2They are the things that, when attention is paid to them, give rise to unarisen defilements and make arisen defilements grow; the defilements of sensual desire, MN 2:10.3desire to be reborn, MN 2:10.4and ignorance. MN 2:10.5These are the things to which they don’t pay attention and should not.

MN 2:10.6And what are the things to which they do pay attention and should? MN 2:10.7They are the things that, when attention is paid to them, do not give rise to unarisen defilements and give up arisen defilements; the defilements of sensual desire, MN 2:10.8desire to be reborn, MN 2:10.9and ignorance.

MN 2:11.1They properly attend: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. MN 2:11.2And as they do so, they give up three fetters: MN 2:11.3identity view, doubt, and misapprehension of precepts and observances. MN 2:11.4These are called the defilements that should be given up by seeing.

MN 2:12.02. Defilements Given Up by Restraint

MN 2:12.1And what are the defilements that should be given up by restraint?

MN 2:12.10PTS-VP-PLI 1.10For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without restraint do not arise when there is such restraint. MN 2:12.11These are called the defilements that should be given up by restraint.

MN 2:12.2Take a mendicant who, reflecting properly, lives restraining the faculty of the eye. MN 2:12.3For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without restraint of the eye faculty do not arise when there is such restraint. MN 2:12.4Reflecting properly, they live restraining the faculty of the ear … MN 2:12.5the nose … MN 2:12.6the tongue … MN 2:12.7the body … MN 2:12.8the mind. MN 2:12.9For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without restraint of the mind faculty do not arise when there is such restraint.

MN 2:13.03. Defilements Given Up by Using

MN 2:13.1BJ 10.26And what are the defilements that should be given up by using? MN 2:13.2Take a mendicant who, reflecting properly, makes use of robes: MN 2:13.3‘Only for the sake of warding off cold and heat; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; and for covering up the private parts.’

MN 2:14.1Reflecting properly, they make use of almsfood: MN 2:14.2‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will live blamelessly and at ease.’

MN 2:15.1Reflecting properly, they make use of lodgings: MN 2:15.2‘Only for the sake of warding off cold and heat; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; to shelter from harsh weather and to enjoy retreat.’

MN 2:16.1Reflecting properly, they make use of medicines and supplies for the sick: MN 2:16.2‘Only for the sake of warding off the pains of illness and to promote good health.’

MN 2:17.1For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without using these things do not arise when they are used. MN 2:17.2These are called the defilements that should be given up by using.

MN 2:18.04. Defilements Given Up by Enduring

MN 2:18.1And what are the defilements that should be given up by enduring? MN 2:18.2Take a mendicant who, reflecting properly, endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst. They endure the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles. They endure rude and unwelcome criticism. And they put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.

MN 2:18.3For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without enduring these things do not arise when they are endured. MN 2:18.4These are called the defilements that should be given up by enduring.

MN 2:19.05. Defilements Given Up by Avoiding

MN 2:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.11And what are the defilements that should be given up by avoiding? MN 2:19.2Take a mendicant who, reflecting properly, avoids a wild elephant, a wild horse, a wild ox, a wild dog, a snake, a stump, thorny ground, a pit, a cliff, a swamp, and a sewer. MN 2:19.3Reflecting properly, they avoid sitting on inappropriate seats, walking in inappropriate neighborhoods, and mixing with bad friends—whatever sensible spiritual companions would believe to be a bad setting.

MN 2:19.4For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without avoiding these things do not arise when they are avoided. MN 2:19.5These are called the defilements that should be given up by avoiding.

MN 2:2.1“Mendicants, I will teach you the explanation of the restraint of all defilements. MN 2:2.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 2:2.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 2:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 2:20.06. Defilements Given Up by Dispelling

MN 2:20.1BJ 10.28And what are the defilements that should be given up by dispelling? MN 2:20.2Take a mendicant who, reflecting properly, doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen, but gives it up, gets rid of it, eliminates it, and obliterates it. They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

MN 2:20.3For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without dispelling these things do not arise when they are dispelled. MN 2:20.4These are called the defilements that should be given up by dispelling.

MN 2:21.07. Defilements Given Up by Developing

MN 2:21.1And what are the defilements that should be given up by developing? MN 2:21.10These are called the defilements that should be given up by developing.

MN 2:21.2It’s when a mendicant, reflecting properly, develops the awakening factors of mindfulness, MN 2:21.3investigation of principles, MN 2:21.4energy, MN 2:21.5rapture, MN 2:21.6tranquility, MN 2:21.7immersion, MN 2:21.8and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

MN 2:21.9For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without developing these things do not arise when they are developed.

MN 2:22.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.12Now, take a mendicant who, by seeing, has given up the defilements that should be given up by seeing. By restraint, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by restraint. By using, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by using. By enduring, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by enduring. By avoiding, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by avoiding. By dispelling, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by dispelling. By developing, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by developing. MN 2:22.2They’re called a mendicant who lives having restrained all defilements, who has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”

MN 2:22.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 2:22.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 2:3.1“Mendicants, I say that the ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know or see. MN 2:3.2For one who knows and sees what? MN 2:3.3Proper attention and improper attention. MN 2:3.4When you pay improper attention, defilements arise, and once arisen they grow. MN 2:3.5When you pay proper attention, defilements don’t arise, and those that have already arisen are given up.

MN 2:4.1BJ 10.20Some defilements should be given up by seeing, some by restraint, some by using, some by enduring, some by avoiding, some by dispelling, and some by developing.

MN 2:5.01. Defilements Given Up by Seeing

MN 2:5.1And what are the defilements that should be given up by seeing? MN 2:5.2Take an uneducated ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 2:5.3They don’t understand to which things they should pay attention and to which things they should not pay attention. MN 2:5.4So they pay attention to things they shouldn’t and don’t pay attention to things they should.

MN 2:6.1And what are the things to which they pay attention but should not? MN 2:6.10These are the things to which they do not pay attention but should.

MN 2:6.2They are the things that, when attention is paid to them, give rise to unarisen defilements and make arisen defilements grow; the defilements of sensual desire, MN 2:6.3desire to be reborn, MN 2:6.4and ignorance. MN 2:6.5These are the things to which they pay attention but should not.

MN 2:6.6And what are the things to which they do not pay attention but should? MN 2:6.7They are the things that, when attention is paid to them, do not give rise to unarisen defilements and give up arisen defilements; the defilements of sensual desire, MN 2:6.8desire to be reborn, MN 2:6.9and ignorance.

MN 2:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.8Because of paying attention to what they should not and not paying attention to what they should, unarisen defilements arise and arisen defilements grow.

MN 2:7.2BJ 10.22This is how they attend improperly: MN 2:7.3‘Did I exist in the past? Did I not exist in the past? What was I in the past? How was I in the past? After being what, what did I become in the past? MN 2:7.4Will I exist in the future? Will I not exist in the future? What will I be in the future? How will I be in the future? After being what, what will I become in the future?’ MN 2:7.5Or they are undecided about the present thus: MN 2:7.6‘Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? This sentient being—where did it come from? And where will it go?’

MN 2:8.1When they attend improperly in this way, one of the following six views arises in them and is taken as a genuine fact. MN 2:8.10An uneducated ordinary person who is fettered by views is not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. MN 2:8.11They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

MN 2:8.2The view: ‘My self exists in an absolute sense.’ MN 2:8.3The view: ‘My self does not exist in an absolute sense.’ MN 2:8.4The view: ‘I perceive the self with the self.’ MN 2:8.5The view: ‘I perceive what is not-self with the self.’ MN 2:8.6The view: ‘I perceive the self with what is not-self.’ MN 2:8.7Or they have such a view: MN 2:8.8‘This self of mine is he who speaks and feels and experiences the results of good and bad deeds in all the different realms. This self is permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’ MN 2:8.9This is called a misconception, the thicket of views, the desert of views, the trick of views, the evasiveness of views, the fetter of views. MN 2:9.2But take an educated noble disciple who has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 2:9.3They understand to which things they should pay attention and to which things they should not pay attention. MN 2:9.4So they pay attention to things they should and don’t pay attention to things they shouldn’t.

  • MN 3:0.1Middle Discourses 3

MN 3:0.2Heirs in the Teaching

MN 3:1.1BJ 10.30So I have heard. MN 3:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 3:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 3:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 3:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 3:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 3:2.1“Mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in material things. MN 3:2.10And they’ll point to me, saying, MN 3:2.11‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in material things.’

MN 3:2.12So, mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in material things. MN 3:2.13Out of compassion for you, I think, MN 3:2.14‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in material things?’

MN 3:2.2Out of compassion for you, I think, MN 3:2.3‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in material things?’

MN 3:2.4If you become heirs in material things, not in the teaching, they’ll point to you, saying, MN 3:2.5‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in material things, not in the teaching.’ MN 3:2.6And they’ll point to me, saying, MN 3:2.7‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in material things, not in the teaching.’

MN 3:2.8If you become heirs in the teaching, not in material things, they’ll point to you, saying, MN 3:2.9‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in material things.’

MN 3:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.13Suppose that I had eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I needed. MN 3:3.10And he has some extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away. MN 3:3.11If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away. MN 3:3.12But the Buddha has also said: MN 3:3.13“Be my heirs in the teaching, not in material things.” MN 3:3.14And almsfood is a kind of material thing. MN 3:3.15Instead of eating this almsfood, why don’t I spend this day and night weak with hunger?’ MN 3:3.16And that’s what they did.

MN 3:3.17BJ 10.32Then the second of those mendicants thought, MN 3:3.18‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food. MN 3:3.19And he has some extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away. MN 3:3.2And there was some extra almsfood that was going to be thrown away. MN 3:3.20If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away. MN 3:3.21Why don’t I eat this almsfood, then spend the day and night having got rid of my hunger and weakness?’ MN 3:3.22And that’s what they did.

MN 3:3.23Even though that mendicant, after eating the almsfood, spent the day and night rid of hunger and weakness, it is the former mendicant who is more worthy of respect and praise. MN 3:3.24Why is that? MN 3:3.25Because for a long time that will conduce to that mendicant being of few wishes, content, self-effacing, unburdensome, and energetic.

MN 3:3.26So, mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in material things. MN 3:3.27Out of compassion for you, I think, MN 3:3.28‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in material things?’”

MN 3:3.3Then two mendicants were to come who were weak with hunger. MN 3:3.4I’d say to them, MN 3:3.5‘Mendicants, I have eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I need. MN 3:3.6And there is this extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away. MN 3:3.7Eat it if you like. Otherwise I’ll throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.’

MN 3:3.8Then one of those mendicants thought, MN 3:3.9‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food.

MN 3:4.1That is what the Buddha said. MN 3:4.2When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

MN 3:4.3PTS-VP-PLI 1.14Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the mendicants, MN 3:4.4“Reverends, mendicants!”

MN 3:4.5“Reverend,” they replied. MN 3:4.6Sāriputta said this:

MN 3:5.1“Reverends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion? And how do they train in seclusion?”

MN 3:5.2“Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta. MN 3:5.3May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this. MN 3:5.4The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

MN 3:5.5“Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 3:5.6“Yes, reverend,” they replied. MN 3:5.7Sāriputta said this:

MN 3:6.1BJ 10.34“Reverends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion? MN 3:6.10‘They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’ MN 3:6.11This is the third ground. MN 3:6.12The senior mendicants should be criticized on these three grounds. MN 3:6.13In this case, the middle mendicants MN 3:6.14and the junior mendicants should be criticized on the same three grounds. MN 3:6.2The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion. MN 3:6.22This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.

MN 3:6.3They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up. MN 3:6.4They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. MN 3:6.5In this case, the senior mendicants should be criticized on three grounds. MN 3:6.6‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.’ MN 3:6.7This is the first ground. MN 3:6.8‘They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’ MN 3:6.9This is the second ground.

MN 3:7.1BJ 10.36PTS-VP-PLI 1.15And how do the disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion? MN 3:7.10‘They’re not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’ MN 3:7.11This is the third ground. MN 3:7.12The senior mendicants should be praised on these three grounds. MN 3:7.13In this case, the middle mendicants MN 3:7.14and the junior mendicants should be praised on the same three grounds. MN 3:7.2The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion. MN 3:7.22This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.

MN 3:7.3They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up. MN 3:7.4They’re not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. MN 3:7.5In this case, the senior mendicants should be praised on three grounds. MN 3:7.6‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.’ MN 3:7.7This is the first ground. MN 3:7.8‘They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’ MN 3:7.9This is the second ground.

MN 3:8.1The bad thing here is greed and hate. MN 3:8.2There is a middle way of practice for giving up greed and hate. It gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment. MN 3:8.3And what is that middle way of practice? MN 3:8.4It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is: MN 3:8.5right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. MN 3:8.6This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.

MN 3:9-15.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.16The bad thing here is anger and hostility. … MN 3:9-15.10It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is: MN 3:9-15.11right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. MN 3:9-15.12This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.”

MN 3:9-15.13This is what Venerable Sāriputta said. MN 3:9-15.14Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Sāriputta said.

MN 3:9-15.2disdain and contempt … MN 3:9-15.3jealousy and stinginess … MN 3:9-15.4deceit and deviousness … MN 3:9-15.5obstinacy and aggression … MN 3:9-15.6conceit and arrogance … MN 3:9-15.7vanity and negligence. MN 3:9-15.8There is a middle way of practice for giving up vanity and negligence. It gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment. MN 3:9-15.9And what is that middle way of practice?
  • MN 4:0.1Middle Discourses 4

MN 4:0.2Fear and Dread

MN 4:1.1BJ 10.38PTS-VP-PLI 1.17So I have heard. MN 4:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 4:10.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins overcome with dullness and drowsiness … MN 4:10.4I am free of dullness and drowsiness …’ MN 4:11.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are restless, with no peace of mind … MN 4:11.4My mind is peaceful …’ MN 4:12.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are doubting and uncertain … MN 4:12.4I’ve gone beyond doubt …’ MN 4:13.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins who glorify themselves and put others down … MN 4:13.4I don’t glorify myself and put others down …’ MN 4:14.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are cowardly and craven … MN 4:14.4I don’t get startled …’ MN 4:15.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy possessions, honor, and popularity … MN 4:15.4I have few wishes …’ MN 4:16.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are lazy and lack energy … MN 4:16.4I am energetic …’ MN 4:17.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are unmindful and lack situational awareness … MN 4:17.4I am mindful …’ MN 4:18.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins who lack immersion, with straying minds … MN 4:18.4I am accomplished in immersion …’ MN 4:19.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are witless and stupid who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. Those ascetics and brahmins summon unskillful fear and dread because of the defects of witlessness and stupidity. MN 4:19.3But I don’t frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest witless and stupid. MN 4:19.4I am accomplished in wisdom. MN 4:19.5I am one of those noble ones who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest accomplished in wisdom.’ MN 4:19.6Seeing this accomplishment of wisdom in myself I felt even more unruffled about staying in the forest.

MN 4:2.1Then the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

MN 4:2.10“That’s so true, brahmin! Everything you say is true, brahmin! MN 4:2.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

MN 4:2.3“Master Gotama, those gentlemen who have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith in Master Gotama have Master Gotama to lead the way, help them out, and give them encouragement. MN 4:2.4And those people follow Master Gotama’s example.”

MN 4:2.5“That’s so true, brahmin! Everything you say is true, brahmin!”

MN 4:2.8“But Master Gotama, remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest are challenging. It’s hard to maintain seclusion and hard to find joy in it. MN 4:2.9Staying alone, the forests seem to rob the mind of a mendicant who isn’t immersed in samādhi.”

MN 4:20.1BJ 10.48PTS-VP-PLI 1.21Then I thought, MN 4:20.10‘Is this that fear and dread coming?’ MN 4:20.11Then I thought, MN 4:20.12‘Why do I always meditate expecting that fear and terror to come? MN 4:20.13Why don’t I get rid of that fear and dread just as it comes, while remaining just as I am?’ MN 4:20.14Then that fear and dread came upon me as I was walking. MN 4:20.15I didn’t stand still or sit down or lie down until I had got rid of that fear and dread while walking. MN 4:20.16Then that fear and dread came upon me as I was standing. MN 4:20.17I didn’t walk or sit down or lie down until I had got rid of that fear and dread while standing. MN 4:20.18Then that fear and dread came upon me as I was sitting. MN 4:20.19I didn’t lie down or stand still or walk until I had got rid of that fear and dread while sitting. MN 4:20.2‘There are certain nights that are recognized as specially portentous: MN 4:20.20Then that fear and dread came upon me as I was lying down. MN 4:20.21I didn’t sit up or stand still or walk until I had got rid of that fear and dread while lying down.

MN 4:20.3the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight. MN 4:20.4On such nights, why don’t I stay in awe-inspiring and hair-raising shrines in parks, forests, and trees? In such lodgings, hopefully I might see that fear and dread.’ MN 4:20.5Some time later, that’s what I did. MN 4:20.8As I was staying there a deer came by, or a peacock snapped a twig, or the wind rustled the leaves. MN 4:20.9Then I thought,

MN 4:21.1There are some ascetics and brahmins who perceive that it’s day when in fact it’s night, or perceive that it’s night when in fact it’s day. MN 4:21.2This meditation of theirs is delusional, I say. MN 4:21.3I perceive that it’s night when in fact it is night, and perceive that it’s day when in fact it is day. MN 4:21.4And if there’s anyone of whom it may be rightly said that MN 4:21.5a being not liable to delusion has arisen in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans, it’s of me that this should be said.

MN 4:22-26.1BJ 10.50PTS-VP-PLI 1.22My energy was roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness was established and lucid, my body was tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind was immersed in samādhi. MN 4:22-26.2Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 4:22-26.3As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 4:22-26.4And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 4:22-26.5With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

MN 4:27.1When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives. I recollected many kinds of past lives. MN 4:27.2That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. I remembered: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

MN 4:28.1This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night. MN 4:28.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

MN 4:29.1BJ 10.52PTS-VP-PLI 1.23When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 4:29.2With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

MN 4:3.1Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too thought, MN 4:3.2‘Remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest are challenging. It’s hard to maintain seclusion, and hard to find joy in it. MN 4:3.3Staying alone, the forests seem to rob the mind of a mendicant who isn’t immersed in samādhi.’

MN 4:30.1This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night. MN 4:30.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

MN 4:31.1When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 4:31.2I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. MN 4:31.3I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

MN 4:32.1Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 4:32.2When it was freed, I knew it was freed.

MN 4:32.3I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 4:33.1This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the final watch of the night. MN 4:33.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

MN 4:34.1BJ 10.54Brahmin, you might think: MN 4:34.2‘Perhaps the Master Gotama is not free of greed, hate, and delusion even today, and that is why he still frequents remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.’ MN 4:34.3But you should not see it like this. MN 4:34.4I see two reasons to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. MN 4:34.5I see a happy life for myself in the present, and I have compassion for future generations.”

MN 4:35.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.24“Indeed, Master Gotama has compassion for future generations, since he is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha. MN 4:35.2Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent, Master Gotama! MN 4:35.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways. MN 4:35.4I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 4:35.5From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

MN 4:4.1Then I thought, MN 4:4.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins with unpurified conduct of body, speech, and mind who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. Those ascetics and brahmins summon unskillful fear and dread because of these defects in their conduct. MN 4:4.3But I don’t frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest with unpurified conduct of body, speech, and mind. MN 4:4.4My conduct is purified. MN 4:4.5I am one of those noble ones who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest with purified conduct of body, speech, and mind.’ MN 4:4.6Seeing this purity of conduct in myself I felt even more unruffled about staying in the forest.

MN 4:5-7.1BJ 10.40Then I thought, MN 4:5-7.4‘There are ascetics and brahmins with unpurified livelihood who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. Those ascetics and brahmins summon unskillful fear and dread because of these defects in their livelihood. MN 4:5-7.5But I don’t frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest with unpurified livelihood. MN 4:5-7.6My livelihood is purified. MN 4:5-7.7I am one of those noble ones who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest with purified livelihood.’ MN 4:5-7.8Seeing this purity of livelihood in myself I felt even more unruffled about staying in the forest.

MN 4:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.18Then I thought, MN 4:8.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins full of desire for sensual pleasures, with acute lust … MN 4:8.4I am not full of desire …’ MN 4:9.2‘There are ascetics and brahmins full of ill will, with malicious intentions … MN 4:9.4I have a heart full of love …’

  • MN 5:0.1Middle Discourses 5

MN 5:0.2Unblemished

MN 5:1.1So I have heard. MN 5:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 5:1.3There Sāriputta addressed the mendicants: MN 5:1.4“Reverends, mendicants!”

MN 5:1.5“Reverend,” they replied. MN 5:1.6Sāriputta said this:

MN 5:10.1It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:10.2‘If I commit an offense, I hope the mendicants don’t find out!’ MN 5:10.3But it’s possible that the mendicants do find out that that mendicant MN 5:10.4has committed an offense. MN 5:10.5Thinking, ‘The mendicants have found out about my offense,’ MN 5:10.6they get angry and bitter. MN 5:10.7And that anger and that bitterness MN 5:10.8are both blemishes.

MN 5:11.1It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:11.2‘If I commit an offense, I hope the mendicants accuse me in private, not in the middle of the Saṅgha.’ MN 5:11.3But it’s possible that the mendicants do accuse that mendicant in the middle of the Saṅgha …

MN 5:12.1It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:12.2‘If I commit an offense, I hope I’m accused by an equal, not by someone who is not an equal.’ MN 5:12.3But it’s possible that someone who is not an equal accuses that mendicant …

MN 5:13.1BJ 10.62PTS-VP-PLI 1.28It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:13.2‘Oh, I hope the Teacher will teach the mendicants by repeatedly questioning me alone, not some other mendicant.’ MN 5:13.3But it’s possible that the Teacher will teach the mendicants by repeatedly questioning some other mendicant …

MN 5:14.1It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:14.2‘Oh, I hope the mendicants will enter the village for the meal putting me at the very front, not some other mendicant.’ MN 5:14.3But it’s possible that the mendicants will enter the village for the meal putting some other mendicant at the very front …

MN 5:15.1It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:15.2‘Oh, I hope that I alone get the best seat, the best drink, and the best almsfood in the refectory, not some other mendicant.’ MN 5:15.3But it’s possible that some other mendicant gets the best seat, the best drink, and the best almsfood in the refectory …

MN 5:16.1BJ 10.64It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:16.2‘I hope that I alone give the verses of gratitude after eating in the refectory, not some other mendicant.’ MN 5:16.3But it’s possible that some other mendicant gives the verses of gratitude after eating in the refectory …

MN 5:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.29It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:17.2‘Oh, I hope that I might teach the Dhamma to the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen in the monastery, not some other mendicant.’ MN 5:18-20.5But it’s possible that some other mendicant teaches the Dhamma …

MN 5:2.1BJ 10.56PTS-VP-PLI 1.25“Mendicants, these four people are found in the world. MN 5:2.10while the one who does understand is better.”

MN 5:2.2What four? MN 5:2.3One person with a blemish doesn’t truly understand: ‘There is a blemish in me.’ MN 5:2.4But another person with a blemish does truly understand: ‘There is a blemish in me.’ MN 5:2.5One person without a blemish doesn’t truly understand: ‘There is no blemish in me.’ MN 5:2.6But another person without a blemish does truly understand: ‘There is no blemish in me.’ MN 5:2.7In this case, of the two persons with a blemish, the one who doesn’t understand is said to be worse, MN 5:2.8while the one who does understand is better. MN 5:2.9And of the two persons without a blemish, the one who doesn’t understand is said to be worse,

MN 5:21.1BJ 10.66It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:21.2‘Oh, I hope that the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen will honor, respect, revere, and venerate me alone, not some other mendicant.’ MN 5:22-24.5But it’s possible that some other mendicant is honored, respected, revered, and venerated …

MN 5:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.30It’s possible that some mendicant might wish: MN 5:25.2‘I hope I get the nicest robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, not some other mendicant.’ MN 5:25.3But it’s possible that some other mendicant gets the nicest robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick … MN 5:26-27.6Thinking, ‘Some other mendicant has got the nicest robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick’, MN 5:26-27.7they get angry and bitter. MN 5:26-27.8And that anger and that bitterness MN 5:26-27.9are both blemishes.

MN 5:28.1‘Blemish’ is a term for these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes.

MN 5:29.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.31Suppose these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by a mendicant. Even though they dwell in the wilderness, in remote lodgings, eat only almsfood, wander indiscriminately for almsfood, wear rag robes, and wear shabby robes, their spiritual companions don’t honor, respect, revere, and venerate them. MN 5:29.10Not even those who were hungry wanted to eat it, let alone those who had eaten.

MN 5:29.11In the same way, when these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by a mendicant … their spiritual companions don’t honor, respect, revere, and venerate them. MN 5:29.12Why is that? MN 5:29.13It’s because these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by that venerable.

MN 5:29.2Why is that? MN 5:29.3It’s because these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by that venerable. MN 5:29.4Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy clean and bright. MN 5:29.5Then the owners were to prepare it with the carcass of a snake, a dog, or a human, cover it with a bronze lid, and parade it through the market-place. MN 5:29.6When people saw it they’d say: MN 5:29.7‘My good man, what is it that you’re carrying like a precious treasure?’ MN 5:29.8So they’d open up the lid for people to look inside. MN 5:29.9But as soon as they saw it they were filled with loathing, revulsion, and disgust.

MN 5:3.1When he said this, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said to him:

MN 5:3.2“What is the cause, Reverend Sāriputta, what is the reason why, of the two persons with a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better? MN 5:3.3And what is the cause, what is the reason why, of the two persons without a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better?”

MN 5:30.1BJ 10.70Suppose these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be given up by a mendicant. Even though they dwell within a village, accept invitations to a meal, and wear robes offered by householders, their spiritual companions honor, respect, revere, and venerate them. MN 5:30.10Even those who had eaten wanted to eat it, let alone those who were hungry.

MN 5:30.11In the same way, when these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be given up by a mendicant … their spiritual companions honor, respect, revere, and venerate them. MN 5:30.12Why is that? MN 5:30.13It’s because these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be given up by that venerable.”

MN 5:30.2Why is that? MN 5:30.3It’s because these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be given up by that venerable. MN 5:30.4Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy clean and bright. MN 5:30.5Then the owners were to prepare it with boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, cover it with a bronze lid, and parade it through the market-place. MN 5:30.6When people saw it they’d say: MN 5:30.7‘My good man, what is it that you’re carrying like a precious treasure?’ MN 5:30.8So they’d open up the lid for people to look inside. MN 5:30.9And as soon as they saw it they were filled with liking, attraction, and relish.

MN 5:31.1BJ 10.72PTS-VP-PLI 1.32When he said this, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said to him, MN 5:31.10And Samīti planed out the flaws in the rim just as Paṇḍuputta thought. MN 5:31.11Then Paṇḍuputta expressed his gladness: MN 5:31.12‘He planes like he knows my heart with his heart!’

MN 5:31.2“Reverend Sāriputta, a simile springs to mind.”

MN 5:31.3“Then speak as you feel inspired,” said Sāriputta.

MN 5:31.4“Reverend, at one time I was staying right here in Rājagaha, the Mountainfold. MN 5:31.5Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms. MN 5:31.6Now at that time Samīti the cartwright was planing the rim of a chariot wheel. MN 5:31.7The Ājīvaka ascetic Paṇḍuputta, who used to be a cartwright, was standing by, MN 5:31.8and this thought came to his mind: MN 5:31.9‘Oh, I hope Samīti the cartwright planes out the crooks, bends, and flaws in this rim. Then the rim will be rid of crooks, bends, and flaws, and consist purely of the essential core.’

MN 5:32.1In the same way, there are those faithless people who went forth from the lay life to homelessness not out of faith but to earn a livelihood. They’re devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They do not guard their sense doors or eat in moderation, and they are not dedicated to wakefulness. They don’t care about the ascetic life, and don’t keenly respect the training. They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, lazy, and lacking energy. They’re unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds, witless and stupid. Venerable Sāriputta planes their faults with this exposition of the teaching as if he knows my heart with his heart!

MN 5:32.2BJ 10.74But there are those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith. They’re not devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re not restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They guard their sense doors and eat in moderation, and they are dedicated to wakefulness. They care about the ascetic life, and keenly respect the training. They’re not indulgent or slack, nor are they leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. They’re energetic and determined. They’re mindful, with situational awareness, immersion, and unified minds; wise, not stupid. Hearing this exposition of the teaching from Venerable Sāriputta, they drink it up and devour it, as it were. And in speech and thought they say: MN 5:32.3‘It’s good, sirs, that he draws his spiritual companions away from the unskillful and establishes them in the skillful.’

MN 5:33.1Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and had bathed their head. After getting a garland of lotuses, jasmine, or liana flowers, they would take them in both hands and place them on the crown of the head. MN 5:33.2In the same way, those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith … say: MN 5:33.3‘It’s good, sirs, that he draws his spiritual companions away from the unskillful and establishes them in the skillful.’” MN 5:33.4And so these two spiritual giants agreed with each others’ fine words.

MN 5:4.1“Reverend, take the case of the person who has a blemish and does not understand it. You can expect that they won’t generate enthusiasm, make an effort, or rouse up energy to give up that blemish. MN 5:4.2And they will die with greed, hate, and delusion, blemished, with a corrupted mind. MN 5:4.3Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy covered with dirt or stains. MN 5:4.4And the owners neither used it or had it cleaned, but kept it in a dirty place. MN 5:4.5Over time, wouldn’t that bronze dish get even dirtier and more stained?”

MN 5:4.6“Yes, reverend.”

MN 5:4.7“In the same way, take the case of the person who has a blemish and does not understand it. You can expect that … MN 5:4.8they will die with a corrupted mind.

MN 5:5.1BJ 10.58PTS-VP-PLI 1.26Take the case of the person who has a blemish and does understand it. You can expect that they will generate enthusiasm, make an effort, and rouse up energy to give up that blemish. MN 5:5.2And they will die without greed, hate, and delusion, unblemished, with an uncorrupted mind. MN 5:5.3Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy covered with dirt or stains. MN 5:5.4But the owners used it and had it cleaned, and didn’t keep it in a dirty place. MN 5:5.5Over time, wouldn’t that bronze dish get cleaner and brighter?”

MN 5:5.6“Yes, reverend.”

MN 5:5.7“In the same way, take the case of the person who has a blemish and does understand it. You can expect that … MN 5:5.8they will die with an uncorrupted mind.

MN 5:6.1Take the case of the person who doesn’t have a blemish but does not understand it. You can expect that they will focus on the feature of beauty, and because of that, lust will infect their mind. MN 5:6.2And they will die with greed, hate, and delusion, blemished, with a corrupted mind. MN 5:6.3Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy clean and bright. MN 5:6.4And the owners neither used it or had it cleaned, but kept it in a dirty place. MN 5:6.5Over time, wouldn’t that bronze dish get dirtier and more stained?”

MN 5:6.6“Yes, reverend.”

MN 5:6.7“In the same way, take the case of the person who has no blemish and does not understand it. You can expect that … MN 5:6.8they will die with a corrupted mind.

MN 5:7.1BJ 10.60Take the case of the person who doesn’t have a blemish and does understand it. You can expect that they won’t focus on the feature of beauty, and because of that, lust won’t infect their mind. MN 5:7.2And they will die without greed, hate, and delusion, unblemished, with an uncorrupted mind. MN 5:7.3Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy clean and bright. MN 5:7.4And the owners used it and had it cleaned, and didn’t keep it in a dirty place. MN 5:7.5Over time, wouldn’t that bronze dish get cleaner and brighter?”

MN 5:7.6“Yes, reverend.”

MN 5:7.7“In the same way, take the case of the person who doesn’t have a blemish and does understand it. You can expect that … MN 5:7.8they will die with an uncorrupted mind.

MN 5:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.27This is the cause, this is the reason why, of the two persons with a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better. MN 5:8.2And this is the cause, this is the reason why, of the two persons without a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better.”

MN 5:9.1“Reverend, the word ‘blemish’ is spoken of. MN 5:9.2But what is ‘blemish’ a term for?”

MN 5:9.3“Reverend, ‘blemish’ is a term for the spheres of bad, unskillful wishes.

MN 6:0.2One Might Wish

MN 6:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.33So I have heard. MN 6:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 6:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 6:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 6:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 6:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 6:10.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May I have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:11.1BJ 10.78PTS-VP-PLI 1.34A mendicant might wish: ‘May I, with the ending of three fetters, become a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:12.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May I, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, become a once-returner, coming back to this world once only, then making an end of suffering.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:13.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May I, with the ending of the five lower fetters, be reborn spontaneously and become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:14.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May I wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying myself and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unimpeded through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with my hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:15.1A mendicant might wish: ‘With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, may I hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:16.1BJ 10.80PTS-VP-PLI 1.35A mendicant might wish: ‘May I understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with my mind.MN 6:16.10expansive mind as “expansive mind”,MN 6:16.11and unexpansive mind as “unexpansive mind”;MN 6:16.12mind that is not supreme as “mind that is not supreme”,MN 6:16.13and mind that is supreme as “mind that is supreme”;MN 6:16.14mind immersed in samādhi as “mind immersed in samādhi”,MN 6:16.15and mind not immersed in samādhi as “mind not immersed in samādhi”;MN 6:16.16freed mind as “freed mind”,MN 6:16.17and unfreed mind as “unfreed mind”.’MN 6:16.18So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:16.2May I understand mind with greed as “mind with greed”,MN 6:16.3and mind without greed as “mind without greed”;MN 6:16.4mind with hate as “mind with hate”,MN 6:16.5and mind without hate as “mind without hate”;MN 6:16.6mind with delusion as “mind with delusion”,MN 6:16.7and mind without delusion as “mind without delusion”;MN 6:16.8constricted mind as “constricted mind”,MN 6:16.9and scattered mind as “scattered mind”;

MN 6:17.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. May I remember: “There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.” May I thus recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.’ MN 6:17.2So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:18.1BJ 10.82A mendicant might wish: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place—and understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: “These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.” And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. And may I understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.’ MN 6:18.2So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.36A mendicant might wish: ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’ MN 6:19.2So let them fulfill their precepts, be committed to inner serenity of the heart, not neglect absorption, be endowed with discernment, and frequent empty huts.

MN 6:2.1“Mendicants, live by the ethical precepts and the monastic code. Live restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.

MN 6:20.1‘Mendicants, live by the ethical precepts and the monastic code. Live restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.’ MN 6:20.2That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

MN 6:20.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 6:20.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 6:3.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May I be liked and approved by my spiritual companions, respected and admired.’ So let them fulfill their precepts, be committed to inner serenity of the heart, not neglect absorption, be endowed with discernment, and frequent empty huts.

MN 6:4.1BJ 10.76A mendicant might wish: ‘May I receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.’ So let them fulfill their precepts, be committed to inner serenity of the heart, not neglect absorption, be endowed with discernment, and frequent empty huts.

MN 6:5.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May the services of those whose robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick I enjoy be very fruitful and beneficial for them.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:6.1A mendicant might wish: ‘When deceased family and relatives who have passed away recollect me with a confident mind, may this be very fruitful and beneficial for them.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:7.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May I prevail over desire and discontent, and may desire and discontent not prevail over me. May I live having mastered desire and discontent whenever they arose.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:8.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May I prevail over fear and dread, and may fear and dread not prevail over me. May I live having mastered fear and dread whenever they arose.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 6:9.1A mendicant might wish: ‘May I get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when I want, without trouble or difficulty.’ So let them fulfill their precepts …

MN 7:0.2The Simile of the Cloth

MN 7:1.1So I have heard. MN 7:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 7:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 7:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 7:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 7:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 7:10.1the Saṅgha,’ they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching. MN 7:11.1Thinking: ‘I have discarded, eliminated, released, given up, and relinquished to this extent,’ they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching. MN 7:11.2When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

MN 7:12.1When a mendicant of such ethics, such qualities, and such wisdom eats boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, that is no obstacle for them. MN 7:12.2Compare with cloth that is dirty and soiled; it can be made pure and clean by pure water. Or unrefined gold, which can be made pure and bright by a forge. MN 7:12.3In the same way, when a mendicant of such ethics, such qualities, and such wisdom eats boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, that is no obstacle for them.

MN 7:13.1They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will. MN 7:14.1They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of compassion to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will. MN 7:15.1They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of rejoicing to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will. MN 7:16.1They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

MN 7:17.1BJ 10.90PTS-VP-PLI 1.39They understand: ‘There is this, there is what is worse than this, there is what is better than this, and there is an escape beyond the scope of perception.’

MN 7:18.1Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 7:18.2When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

MN 7:18.3They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’ MN 7:18.4This is called MN 7:18.5a mendicant who is bathed with the inner bathing.”

MN 7:19.1Now at that time the brahmin Sundarika Bhāradvāja was sitting not far from the Buddha. MN 7:19.2He said to the Buddha, MN 7:19.3“But does Master Gotama go to the river Bāhuka to bathe?”

MN 7:19.4“Brahmin, why go to the river Bāhuka? MN 7:19.5What can the river Bāhuka do?”

MN 7:19.6“Many people agree that the river Bāhuka bestows cleanliness and merit. And many people wash off their bad deeds in the river Bāhuka.”

MN 7:2.1BJ 10.84“Suppose, mendicants, there was a cloth that was dirty and soiled.

MN 7:2.10In the same way, when the mind isn’t corrupt, a good destiny is to be expected.

MN 7:2.2No matter what dye the dyer applied—whether blue or yellow or red or magenta—it would look poorly dyed and impure in color. MN 7:2.3Why is that? MN 7:2.4Because of the impurity of the cloth.

MN 7:2.5In the same way, when the mind is corrupt, a bad destiny is to be expected. MN 7:2.6Suppose there was a cloth that was pure and clean. MN 7:2.7No matter what dye the dyer applied—whether blue or yellow or red or magenta—it would look well dyed and pure in color. MN 7:2.8Why is that? MN 7:2.9Because of the purity of the cloth.

MN 7:20.1Then the Buddha addressed Sundarika in verse:

MN 7:20.10They can’t cleanse a cruel and criminal person MN 7:20.11from their bad deeds.

MN 7:20.12For the pure in heart it’s always MN 7:20.13the spring festival or the sabbath. MN 7:20.14For the pure in heart and clean of deed, MN 7:20.15their vows will always be fulfilled. MN 7:20.16It’s here alone that you should bathe, brahmin, MN 7:20.17making yourself a sanctuary for all creatures.

MN 7:20.18And if you speak no lies, MN 7:20.19nor harm any living creature,

MN 7:20.2“The Bāhuka and the Adhikakka, MN 7:20.20nor steal anything not given, MN 7:20.21and you’re faithful and not stingy: MN 7:20.22what’s the point of going to Gayā? MN 7:20.23For any well may be your Gayā!”

MN 7:20.3the Gayā and the Sundarika too, MN 7:20.4Sarasvatī and Payāga, MN 7:20.5and the river Bāhumati: MN 7:20.6a fool can constantly plunge into them MN 7:20.7but it won’t purify their dark deeds.

MN 7:20.8What can the Sundarika do? MN 7:20.9What the Payāga or the Bāhuka?

MN 7:21.1BJ 10.92PTS-VP-PLI 1.40When he had spoken, the brahmin Sundarika Bhāradvāja said to the Buddha, MN 7:21.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! MN 7:21.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways. MN 7:21.4I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 7:21.5Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

MN 7:22.1And the brahmin Sundarika Bhāradvāja received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence. MN 7:22.2Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

MN 7:22.3He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.” MN 7:22.4And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

MN 7:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.37And what are the corruptions of the mind? MN 7:3.2Covetousness and immoral greed, ill will, anger, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deceit, deviousness, obstinacy, aggression, conceit, arrogance, vanity, and negligence are corruptions of the mind.

MN 7:4.1A mendicant who understands that covetousness and immoral greed are corruptions of the mind gives them up. MN 7:4.2A mendicant who understands that ill will … MN 7:4.30negligence is a corruption of the mind gives it up.

MN 7:5.1BJ 10.86When they have understood these corruptions of the mind MN 7:5.2for what they are, and have given them up, MN 7:5.32they have experiential confidence in the Buddha: MN 7:5.33‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

MN 7:6.1They have experiential confidence in the teaching: MN 7:6.2‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

MN 7:7.1They have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha: MN 7:7.2‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, methodical, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individuals. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

MN 7:8.1BJ 10.88PTS-VP-PLI 1.38When a mendicant has discarded, eliminated, released, given up, and relinquished to this extent, thinking, ‘I have experiential confidence in the Buddha … MN 7:9.1the teaching …
