MN 8:0.2Self-Effacement

MN 8:1.1So I have heard. MN 8:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 8:10.1It’s possible that some mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, might enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness. MN 8:10.2They might think MN 8:10.3they’re practicing self-effacement. MN 8:10.4But in the training of the Noble One these are not called ‘self-effacement’; MN 8:10.5they’re called ‘peaceful meditations’.

MN 8:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.42It’s possible that some mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, might enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 8:11.2They might think MN 8:11.3they’re practicing self-effacement. MN 8:11.4But in the training of the Noble One these are not called ‘self-effacement’; MN 8:11.5they’re called ‘peaceful meditations’.

MN 8:12.01. The Exposition of Self-Effacement

MN 8:12.1Now, Cunda, you should work on self-effacement in each of the following ways.

MN 8:12.10‘Others will be covetous, but here we will not be covetous.’

MN 8:12.11‘Others will have ill will, but here we will not have ill will.’

MN 8:12.12‘Others will have wrong view, but here we will have right view.’

MN 8:12.13‘Others will have wrong thought, but here we will have right thought.’

MN 8:12.14‘Others will have wrong speech, but here we will have right speech.’

MN 8:12.15‘Others will have wrong action, but here we will have right action.’

MN 8:12.16‘Others will have wrong livelihood, but here we will have right livelihood.’

MN 8:12.17‘Others will have wrong effort, but here we will have right effort.’

MN 8:12.18‘Others will have wrong mindfulness, but here we will have right mindfulness.’

MN 8:12.19‘Others will have wrong immersion, but here we will have right immersion.’

MN 8:12.2‘Others will be cruel, but here we will not be cruel.’

MN 8:12.20‘Others will have wrong knowledge, but here we will have right knowledge.’

MN 8:12.21‘Others will have wrong freedom, but here we will have right freedom.’

MN 8:12.22‘Others will be overcome with dullness and drowsiness, but here we will be rid of dullness and drowsiness.’

MN 8:12.23‘Others will be restless, but here we will not be restless.’

MN 8:12.24‘Others will have doubts, but here we will have gone beyond doubt.’

MN 8:12.25BJ 10.100‘Others will be irritable, but here we will be without anger.’

MN 8:12.26‘Others will be hostile, but here we will be without hostility.’

MN 8:12.27PTS-VP-PLI 1.43‘Others will be offensive, but here we will be inoffensive.’

MN 8:12.28‘Others will be contemptuous, but here we will be without contempt.’

MN 8:12.29‘Others will be jealous, but here we will be without jealousy.’

MN 8:12.3‘Others will kill living creatures, but here we will not kill living creatures.’

MN 8:12.30‘Others will be stingy, but here we will be without stinginess.’

MN 8:12.31‘Others will be devious, but here we will not be devious.’

MN 8:12.32‘Others will be deceitful, but here we will not be deceitful.’

MN 8:12.33‘Others will be stubborn, but here we will not be stubborn.’

MN 8:12.34‘Others will be arrogant, but here we will not be arrogant.’

MN 8:12.35‘Others will be hard to admonish, but here we will not be hard to admonish.’

MN 8:12.36‘Others will have bad friends, but here we will have good friends.’

MN 8:12.37‘Others will be negligent, but here we will be diligent.’

MN 8:12.38‘Others will be faithless, but here we will have faith.’

MN 8:12.39‘Others will be conscienceless, but here we will have a sense of conscience.’

MN 8:12.4‘Others will steal, but here we will not steal.’

MN 8:12.40‘Others will be imprudent, but here we will be prudent.’

MN 8:12.41‘Others will be uneducated, but here we will be well educated.’

MN 8:12.42BJ 10.102‘Others will be lazy, but here we will be energetic.’

MN 8:12.43‘Others will be unmindful, but here we will be mindful.’

MN 8:12.44‘Others will be witless, but here we will be accomplished in wisdom.’

MN 8:12.45‘Others will be attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, but here we will not be attached to our own views, not holding them tight, but will let them go easily.’

MN 8:12.5‘Others will be unchaste, but here we will not be unchaste.’

MN 8:12.6‘Others will lie, but here we will not lie.’

MN 8:12.7‘Others will speak divisively, but here we will not speak divisively.’

MN 8:12.8BJ 10.98‘Others will speak harshly, but here we will not speak harshly.’

MN 8:12.9‘Others will talk nonsense, but here we will not talk nonsense.’

MN 8:13.02. Giving Rise to the Thought

MN 8:13.1Cunda, I say that even giving rise to the thought of skillful qualities is very helpful, let alone following that path in body and speech. MN 8:13.2That’s why you should give rise to the following thoughts. ‘Others will be cruel, but here we will not be cruel.’ MN 8:13.3‘Others will kill living creatures, but here we will not kill living creatures.’ … MN 8:13.4‘Others will be attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, but here we will not be attached to our own views, not holding them tight, but will let them go easily.’

MN 8:14.03. A Way Around

MN 8:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.44Cunda, suppose there was a rough path and another smooth path to get around it. MN 8:14.2Or suppose there was a rough ford and another smooth ford to get around it. MN 8:14.3In the same way, a cruel individual gets around it by not being cruel. An individual who kills gets around it by not killing. …

MN 8:14.5An individual who is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, gets around it by not being attached to their own views, not holding them tight, but letting them go easily.

MN 8:15.04. Going Up

MN 8:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.45Cunda, all unskillful qualities lead downwards, while all skillful qualities lead upwards. MN 8:15.2In the same way, a cruel individual is led upwards by not being cruel. An individual who kills is led upwards by not killing … MN 8:15.3An individual who is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, is led upwards by not being attached to their own views, not holding them tight, but letting them go easily.

MN 8:16.05. The Exposition by Extinguishment

MN 8:16.1BJ 10.106Truly, Cunda, if you’re sinking down in the mud you can’t pull out someone else who is also sinking down in the mud. MN 8:16.2But if you’re not sinking down in the mud you can pull out someone else who is sinking down in the mud. MN 8:16.3Truly, if you’re not tamed, trained, and extinguished you can’t tame, train, and extinguish someone else. MN 8:16.4But if you’re tamed, trained, and extinguished you can tame, train, and extinguish someone else.

MN 8:16.47An individual who is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go, extinguishes it by not being attached to their own views, not holding them tight, but letting them go easily.

MN 8:16.5In the same way, a cruel individual extinguishes it by not being cruel. An individual who kills extinguishes it by not killing. …

MN 8:17.1So, Cunda, I’ve taught the expositions by way of self-effacement, giving rise to thought, the way around, going up, and extinguishing. MN 8:17.2Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples. MN 8:17.3Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Cunda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction.”

MN 8:17.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 8:17.5Satisfied, Venerable Mahācunda was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 8:17.6Forty-four items have been stated, MN 8:17.7organized into five sections. MN 8:17.8“Effacement” is the name of this discourse, MN 8:17.9which is deep as the ocean.

MN 8:2.1Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahācunda came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

MN 8:3.1“Sir, there are many different views that arise in the world MN 8:3.2connected with doctrines of the self or with doctrines of the cosmos. MN 8:3.3How does a mendicant who is focusing on the starting point give up and let go of these views?”

MN 8:3.4BJ 10.94“Cunda, there are many different views that arise in the world MN 8:3.5connected with doctrines of the self or with doctrines of the cosmos. MN 8:3.6A mendicant gives up and lets go of these views by truly seeing with right wisdom where they arise, where they settle in, and where they operate as: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

MN 8:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.41It’s possible that a certain mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, might enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 8:4.2They might think MN 8:4.3they’re practicing self-effacement. MN 8:4.4But in the training of the Noble One these are not called ‘self-effacement’; MN 8:4.5they’re called ‘blissful meditations in the present life’.

MN 8:5.1It’s possible that some mendicant, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, might enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 8:5.2They might think MN 8:5.3they’re practicing self-effacement. MN 8:5.4But in the training of the Noble One these are not called ‘self-effacement’; MN 8:5.5they’re called ‘blissful meditations in the present life’.

MN 8:6.1It’s possible that some mendicant, with the fading away of rapture, might enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 8:6.2They might think MN 8:6.3they’re practicing self-effacement. MN 8:6.4But in the training of the Noble One these are not called ‘self-effacement’; MN 8:6.5they’re called ‘blissful meditations in the present life’.

MN 8:7.1It’s possible that some mendicant, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, might enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 8:7.2They might think MN 8:7.3they’re practicing self-effacement. MN 8:7.4But in the training of the Noble One these are not called ‘self-effacement’; MN 8:7.5they’re called ‘blissful meditations in the present life’.

MN 8:8.1BJ 10.96It’s possible that some mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, might enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space. MN 8:8.2They might think MN 8:8.3they’re practicing self-effacement. MN 8:8.4But in the training of the Noble One these are not called ‘self-effacement’; MN 8:8.5they’re called ‘peaceful meditations’.

MN 8:9.1It’s possible that some mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, might enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness. MN 8:9.2They might think MN 8:9.3they’re practicing self-effacement. MN 8:9.4But in the training of the Noble One these are not called ‘self-effacement’; MN 8:9.5they’re called ‘peaceful meditations’.

MN 9:0.2Right View

MN 9:1.1BJ 10.110So I have heard. MN 9:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 9:1.3There Sāriputta addressed the mendicants: MN 9:1.4“Reverends, mendicants!”

MN 9:1.5“Reverend,” they replied. MN 9:1.6Sāriputta said this:

MN 9:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.48“There might, reverends. MN 9:10.2A noble disciple understands fuel, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. MN 9:10.3When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching.

MN 9:11.1But what is fuel? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:11.2There are these four fuels. They maintain sentient beings that have been born and help those that are about to be born. MN 9:11.3What four? MN 9:11.4Solid food, whether coarse or fine; contact is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth. MN 9:11.5Fuel originates from craving. Fuel ceases when craving ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of fuel is simply this noble eightfold path, that is: MN 9:11.6right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

MN 9:12.1BJ 10.114A noble disciple understands in this way fuel, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life. MN 9:12.2When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching.”

MN 9:13.1Saying “Good, sir,” those mendicants … asked another question: MN 9:13.2“But reverend, might there be another way to describe a noble disciple who … has come to the true teaching?”

MN 9:14-18.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.49“There might, reverends. MN 9:14-18.10This is called the origin of suffering. MN 9:14-18.11And what is the cessation of suffering? MN 9:14-18.12It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it. MN 9:14-18.13This is called the cessation of suffering. MN 9:14-18.14And what is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering? MN 9:14-18.15It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is: MN 9:14-18.16right view … right immersion. MN 9:14-18.17This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

MN 9:14-18.2A noble disciple understands suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. MN 9:14-18.3When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who … has come to the true teaching. MN 9:14-18.4But what is suffering? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:14-18.5Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; association with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering. MN 9:14-18.6This is called suffering. MN 9:14-18.7And what is the origin of suffering? MN 9:14-18.8It’s the craving that leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, looking for enjoyment in various different realms. That is, MN 9:14-18.9craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence.

MN 9:19.1BJ 10.116A noble disciple understands in this way suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life. MN 9:19.2When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching.”

MN 9:2.1“Reverends, they speak of this thing called ‘right view’. MN 9:2.2How do you define a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching?”

MN 9:2.3“Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta. MN 9:2.4May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this. MN 9:2.5The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

MN 9:2.6“Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 9:2.7“Yes, reverend,” they replied. MN 9:2.8Sāriputta said this:

MN 9:20.1Saying “Good, sir,” those mendicants … asked another question: MN 9:20.2“But reverend, might there be another way to describe a noble disciple who … has come to the true teaching?”

MN 9:21-22.1“There might, reverends. MN 9:21-22.10Such is old age, and such is death. MN 9:21-22.11This is called old age and death. MN 9:21-22.12Old age and death originate from rebirth. Old age and death cease when rebirth ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of old age and death is simply this noble eightfold path …” MN 9:21-22.2A noble disciple understands old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation … MN 9:21-22.4But what are old age and death? What is their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation? MN 9:21-22.5The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, gray hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings. MN 9:21-22.6This is called old age. MN 9:21-22.7And what is death? MN 9:21-22.8The passing away, perishing, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, laying to rest of the corpse, and cutting off of the life faculty of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings. MN 9:21-22.9This is called death. MN 9:24-26.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:24-26.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:24-26.4A noble disciple understands rebirth, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation … MN 9:24-26.6But what is rebirth? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:24-26.7The rebirth, inception, conception, reincarnation, manifestation of the aggregates, and acquisition of the sense fields of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings. MN 9:24-26.8This is called rebirth. MN 9:24-26.9Rebirth originates from continued existence. Rebirth ceases when continued existence ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of rebirth is simply this noble eightfold path …” MN 9:28-30.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:28-30.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:28-30.4A noble disciple understands continued existence, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. MN 9:28-30.6But what is continued existence? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:28-30.7There are these three states of continued existence. MN 9:28-30.8Existence in the sensual realm, the realm of luminous form, and the formless realm. MN 9:28-30.9Continued existence originates from grasping. Continued existence ceases when grasping ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of continued existence is simply this noble eightfold path …”

MN 9:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.47“A noble disciple understands the unskillful and its root, and the skillful and its root. MN 9:3.2When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching.

MN 9:32-34.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:32-34.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:32-34.4A noble disciple understands grasping, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation … MN 9:32-34.6But what is grasping? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:32-34.7There are these four kinds of grasping. MN 9:32-34.8Grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self. MN 9:32-34.9Grasping originates from craving. Grasping ceases when craving ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of grasping is simply this noble eightfold path …” MN 9:36-38.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:36-38.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:36-38.4A noble disciple understands craving, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation … MN 9:36-38.6But what is craving? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:36-38.7There are these six classes of craving. MN 9:36-38.8Craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts. MN 9:36-38.9Craving originates from feeling. Craving ceases when feeling ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of craving is simply this noble eightfold path …”

MN 9:4.1But what is the unskillful and what is its root? And what is the skillful and what is its root? MN 9:4.2Killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and covetousness, ill will, and wrong view. MN 9:4.3This is called the unskillful.

MN 9:40-42.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:40-42.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:40-42.4A noble disciple understands feeling, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation … MN 9:40-42.6But what is feeling? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:40-42.7There are these six classes of feeling. MN 9:40-42.8Feeling born of contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. MN 9:40-42.9Feeling originates from contact. Feeling ceases when contact ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of feeling is simply this noble eightfold path …” MN 9:44-46.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:44-46.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:44-46.4A noble disciple understands contact, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation … MN 9:44-46.6But what is contact? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:44-46.7There are these six classes of contact. MN 9:44-46.8Contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. MN 9:44-46.9Contact originates from the six sense fields. Contact ceases when the six sense fields cease. The practice that leads to the cessation of contact is simply this noble eightfold path …” MN 9:48-50.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:48-50.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:48-50.4A noble disciple understands the six sense fields, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation … MN 9:48-50.6But what are the six sense fields? What is their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation? MN 9:48-50.7There are these six sense fields. MN 9:48-50.8The sense fields of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. MN 9:48-50.9The six sense fields originate from name and form. The six sense fields cease when name and form cease. The practice that leads to the cessation of the six sense fields is simply this noble eightfold path …”

MN 9:5.1And what is the root of the unskillful? MN 9:5.2Greed, hate, and delusion. MN 9:5.3This is called the root of the unskillful.

MN 9:52-54.10this is called form. MN 9:52-54.11Such is name and such is form. MN 9:52-54.12This is called name and form. MN 9:52-54.13Name and form originate from consciousness. Name and form cease when consciousness ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of name and form is simply this noble eightfold path …” MN 9:52-54.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:52-54.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:52-54.4A noble disciple understands name and form, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation … MN 9:52-54.6But what are name and form? What is their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation? MN 9:52-54.7Feeling, perception, intention, contact, and attention—MN 9:52-54.8this is called name. MN 9:52-54.9The four primary elements, and form derived from the four primary elements—MN 9:56-58.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:56-58.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:56-58.4A noble disciple understands consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation … MN 9:56-58.6But what is consciousness? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:56-58.7There are these six classes of consciousness. MN 9:56-58.8Eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness. MN 9:56-58.9Consciousness originates from choices. Consciousness ceases when choices cease. The practice that leads to the cessation of consciousness is simply this noble eightfold path …”

MN 9:6.1BJ 10.112And what is the skillful? MN 9:6.2Avoiding killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; avoiding speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, good will, and right view. MN 9:6.3This is called the skillful.

MN 9:60-62.10Choices originate from ignorance. Choices cease when ignorance ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of choices is simply this noble eightfold path …” MN 9:60-62.3“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:60-62.4“There might, reverends. MN 9:60-62.5A noble disciple understands choices, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation … MN 9:60-62.7But what are choices? What is their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation? MN 9:60-62.8There are these three kinds of choice. MN 9:60-62.9Choices by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 9:64-66.2“Might there be another way to describe a noble disciple?”

MN 9:64-66.3“There might, reverends. MN 9:64-66.4A noble disciple understands ignorance, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation … MN 9:64-66.6But what is ignorance? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:64-66.7Not knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. MN 9:64-66.8This is called ignorance. MN 9:64-66.9Ignorance originates from defilement. Ignorance ceases when defilement ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of ignorance is simply this noble eightfold path …”

MN 9:68.1BJ 10.132PTS-VP-PLI 1.55Saying “Good, sir,” those mendicants approved and agreed with what Sāriputta said. Then they asked another question: MN 9:68.2“But reverend, might there be another way to describe a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching?”

MN 9:69.1“There might, reverends. MN 9:69.2A noble disciple understands defilement, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. MN 9:69.3When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching.

MN 9:7.1And what is the root of the skillful? MN 9:7.2Contentment, love, and understanding. MN 9:7.3This is called the root of the skillful.

MN 9:70.1But what is defilement? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? MN 9:70.2There are these three defilements. MN 9:70.3The defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 9:70.4Defilement originates from ignorance. Defilement ceases when ignorance ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of defilement is simply this noble eightfold path, that is: MN 9:70.5right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

MN 9:71.1A noble disciple understands in this way defilement, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life. MN 9:71.2When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching.”

MN 9:71.3This is what Venerable Sāriputta said. MN 9:71.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Sāriputta said.

MN 9:8.1A noble disciple understands in this way the unskillful and its root, and the skillful and its root. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life. MN 9:8.2When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching.”

MN 9:9.1Saying “Good, sir,” those mendicants approved and agreed with what Sāriputta said. Then they asked another question: MN 9:9.2“But reverend, might there be another way to describe a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching?”

MN 10:0.2Mindfulness Meditation

MN 10:1.1BJ 10.134So I have heard. MN 10:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma. MN 10:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 10:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 10:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 10:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 10:10.01.4. Focusing on the Repulsive

MN 10:10.1BJ 10.138Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth. MN 10:10.2‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’

MN 10:10.3It’s as if there were a bag with openings at both ends, filled with various kinds of grains, such as fine rice, wheat, mung beans, peas, sesame, and ordinary rice. And someone with good eyesight were to open it and examine the contents: ‘These grains are fine rice, these are wheat, these are mung beans, these are peas, these are sesame, and these are ordinary rice.’

MN 10:11.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

MN 10:11.2That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

MN 10:12.01.5. Focusing on the Elements

MN 10:12.1Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements: MN 10:12.2‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’

MN 10:12.3PTS-VP-PLI 1.58It’s as if a deft butcher or butcher’s apprentice were to kill a cow and sit down at the crossroads with the meat cut into portions.

MN 10:13.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

MN 10:13.2That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

MN 10:14.01.6. The Charnel Ground Contemplations

MN 10:14.1Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering. MN 10:14.2They’d compare it with their own body: MN 10:14.3‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

MN 10:15.2That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

MN 10:16.1BJ 10.140Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures. MN 10:16.2They’d compare it with their own body: MN 10:16.3‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

MN 10:17.2That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

MN 10:18-23.1Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews …

MN 10:18-23.2A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews …

MN 10:18-23.3A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …

MN 10:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.56“Mendicants, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to end the cycle of suffering, and to realize extinguishment.

MN 10:24.1Bones rid of sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here a shin-bone, there a thigh-bone, here a hip-bone, there a rib-bone, here a back-bone, there an arm-bone, here a neck-bone, there a jaw-bone, here a tooth, there the skull …

MN 10:26-28.1BJ 10.142White bones, the color of shells …

MN 10:29.1Decrepit bones, heaped in a pile …

MN 10:3.1What four? MN 10:3.2It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 10:3.3They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 10:3.4They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 10:3.5They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

MN 10:30.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.59Bones rotted and crumbled to powder. MN 10:30.2They’d compare it with their own body: MN 10:30.3‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

MN 10:31.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally. MN 10:31.2They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish. MN 10:31.3Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

MN 10:31.4That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

MN 10:32.02. Observing the Feelings

MN 10:32.1And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of feelings?

MN 10:32.10When they feel a spiritual neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a spiritual neutral feeling.’

MN 10:32.2It’s when a mendicant who feels a pleasant feeling knows: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling.’

MN 10:32.3When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’

MN 10:32.4When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’

MN 10:32.5When they feel a material pleasant feeling, they know: ‘I feel a material pleasant feeling.’

MN 10:32.6When they feel a spiritual pleasant feeling, they know: ‘I feel a spiritual pleasant feeling.’

MN 10:32.7When they feel a material painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a material painful feeling.’

MN 10:32.8When they feel a spiritual painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a spiritual painful feeling.’

MN 10:32.9When they feel a material neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a material neutral feeling.’

MN 10:33.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of the feelings internally, externally, and both internally and externally. MN 10:33.2They meditate observing feelings as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish. MN 10:33.3Or mindfulness is established that feelings exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

MN 10:33.4That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of feelings.

MN 10:34.03. Observing the Mind

MN 10:34.1BJ 10.144And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of the mind?

MN 10:34.10They know expansive mind as ‘expansive mind,’ MN 10:34.11and unexpansive mind as ‘unexpansive mind.’ MN 10:34.12They know mind that is not supreme as ‘mind that is not supreme,’ MN 10:34.13and mind that is supreme as ‘mind that is supreme.’ MN 10:34.14They know mind immersed in samādhi as ‘mind immersed in samādhi,’ MN 10:34.15and mind not immersed in samādhi as ‘mind not immersed in samādhi.’ MN 10:34.16They know freed mind as ‘freed mind,’ MN 10:34.17and unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind.’

MN 10:34.2It’s when a mendicant understands mind with greed as ‘mind with greed,’MN 10:34.3and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed.’ MN 10:34.4They understand mind with hate as ‘mind with hate,’ MN 10:34.5and mind without hate as ‘mind without hate.’ MN 10:34.6They understand mind with delusion as ‘mind with delusion,’ MN 10:34.7and mind without delusion as ‘mind without delusion.’ MN 10:34.8They know constricted mind as ‘constricted mind,’ MN 10:34.9and scattered mind as ‘scattered mind.’

MN 10:35.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.60And so they meditate observing an aspect of the mind internally, externally, and both internally and externally. MN 10:35.2They meditate observing the mind as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish. MN 10:35.3Or mindfulness is established that the mind exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

MN 10:35.4That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the mind.

MN 10:36.0.14. Observing Principles

MN 10:36.0.24.1. The Hindrances

MN 10:36.1And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles?

MN 10:36.2It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances. MN 10:36.3And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances?

MN 10:36.4It’s when a mendicant who has sensual desire in them understands: ‘I have sensual desire in me.’ When they don’t have sensual desire in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have sensual desire in me.’ They understand how sensual desire arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

MN 10:36.5When they have ill will in them, they understand: ‘I have ill will in me.’ When they don’t have ill will in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have ill will in me.’ They understand how ill will arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

MN 10:36.6BJ 10.146When they have dullness and drowsiness in them, they understand: ‘I have dullness and drowsiness in me.’ When they don’t have dullness and drowsiness in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have dullness and drowsiness in me.’ They understand how dullness and drowsiness arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.

MN 10:36.7When they have restlessness and remorse in them, they understand: ‘I have restlessness and remorse in me.’ When they don’t have restlessness and remorse in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have restlessness and remorse in me.’ They understand how restlessness and remorse arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.

MN 10:36.8When they have doubt in them, they understand: ‘I have doubt in me.’ When they don’t have doubt in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have doubt in me.’ They understand how doubt arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

MN 10:37.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally. MN 10:37.2They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish. MN 10:37.3Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

MN 10:37.4That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.

MN 10:38.04.2. The Aggregates

MN 10:38.1BJ 10.148PTS-VP-PLI 1.61Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates. MN 10:38.2And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates? MN 10:38.3It’s when a mendicant contemplates: MN 10:38.4‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form. MN 10:38.5Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling. MN 10:38.6Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception. MN 10:38.7Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices. MN 10:38.8Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

MN 10:39.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …

MN 10:39.4That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates.

MN 10:4.0.11. Observing the Body

MN 10:4.0.21.1. Mindfulness of Breathing

MN 10:4.1And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of the body?

MN 10:4.2It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, with their body straight, and focuses their mindfulness right there. MN 10:4.3Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.

MN 10:4.4When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’

MN 10:4.5When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ When breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’

MN 10:4.6They practice breathing in experiencing the whole body. They practice breathing out experiencing the whole body.

MN 10:4.7They practice breathing in stilling the body’s motion. They practice breathing out stilling the body’s motion.

MN 10:4.8BJ 10.136It’s like a deft carpenter or carpenter’s apprentice. When making a deep cut they know: ‘I’m making a deep cut,’ and when making a shallow cut they know: ‘I’m making a shallow cut.’

MN 10:40.04.3. The Sense Fields

MN 10:40.1Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields. MN 10:40.2And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields?

MN 10:40.3It’s when a mendicant understands the eye, sights, and the fetter that arises dependent on both of these. They understand how the fetter that has not arisen comes to arise; how the arisen fetter comes to be abandoned; and how the abandoned fetter comes to not rise again in the future.

MN 10:40.4They understand the ear, sounds, and the fetter …

MN 10:40.5They understand the nose, smells, and the fetter …

MN 10:40.6They understand the tongue, tastes, and the fetter …

MN 10:40.7They understand the body, touches, and the fetter …

MN 10:40.8They understand the mind, thoughts, and the fetter that arises dependent on both of these. They understand how the fetter that has not arisen comes to arise; how the arisen fetter comes to be abandoned; and how the abandoned fetter comes to not rise again in the future.

MN 10:41.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …

MN 10:41.4That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six internal and external sense fields.

MN 10:42.04.4. The Awakening Factors

MN 10:42.1BJ 10.150PTS-VP-PLI 1.62Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors. MN 10:42.2And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors?

MN 10:42.3It’s when a mendicant who has the awakening factor of mindfulness in them understands: ‘I have the awakening factor of mindfulness in me.’ When they don’t have the awakening factor of mindfulness in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have the awakening factor of mindfulness in me.’ They understand how the awakening factor of mindfulness that has not arisen comes to arise; and how the awakening factor of mindfulness that has arisen becomes fulfilled by development.

MN 10:42.4When they have the awakening factor of investigation of principles … MN 10:42.5energy … MN 10:42.6rapture … MN 10:42.7tranquility … MN 10:42.8immersion … MN 10:42.9equanimity in them, they understand: ‘I have the awakening factor of equanimity in me.’ When they don’t have the awakening factor of equanimity in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have the awakening factor of equanimity in me.’ They understand how the awakening factor of equanimity that has not arisen comes to arise; and how the awakening factor of equanimity that has arisen becomes fulfilled by development.

MN 10:43.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally. MN 10:43.2They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish. MN 10:43.3Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

MN 10:43.4That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors.

MN 10:44.04.5. The Truths

MN 10:44.1BJ 10.152Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths.

MN 10:44.2And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths? MN 10:44.3It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

MN 10:45.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally. MN 10:45.2They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish. MN 10:45.3Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

MN 10:45.4That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths.

MN 10:46.1Anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for seven years can expect one of two results: MN 10:46.11seven months … MN 10:46.14six months … MN 10:46.15five months … MN 10:46.16four months … MN 10:46.17three months … MN 10:46.18two months … MN 10:46.19one month … MN 10:46.2enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.

MN 10:5.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally. MN 10:5.3Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

MN 10:6.01.2. The Postures

MN 10:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.57Furthermore, when a mendicant is walking they know: ‘I am walking.’ When standing they know: ‘I am standing.’ When sitting they know: ‘I am sitting.’ And when lying down they know: ‘I am lying down.’ MN 10:6.2Whatever posture their body is in, they know it.

MN 10:7.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
