MN 10:7.4That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

MN 10:8.01.3. Situational Awareness

MN 10:8.1Furthermore, a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

MN 10:9.1And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

MN 10:9.2That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

  • MN 11:0.1Middle Discourses 11

MN 11:0.2The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

MN 11:1.1So I have heard. MN 11:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 11:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 11:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 11:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 11:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 11:10.1There are some ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping. MN 11:10.2But they don’t correctly describe the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping. MN 11:10.3They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, but not views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self. MN 11:10.4Why is that? MN 11:10.5Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand these three things. MN 11:10.6That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping, MN 11:10.7but they don’t really.

MN 11:11.1There are some other ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping, MN 11:11.2but they don’t really. MN 11:11.3They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures and views, but not precepts and observances, and theories of a self. MN 11:11.4Why is that? MN 11:11.5Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand these two things. MN 11:11.6That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping, MN 11:11.7but they don’t really.

MN 11:12.1There are some other ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping, MN 11:12.2but they don’t really. MN 11:12.3They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, views, and precepts and observances, but not theories of a self. MN 11:12.4Why is that? MN 11:12.5Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand this one thing. MN 11:12.6That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping, MN 11:12.7but they don’t really.

MN 11:13.1BJ 10.162PTS-VP-PLI 1.67In such a teaching and training, confidence in the Teacher is said to be far from ideal. MN 11:13.2Likewise, confidence in the teaching, MN 11:13.3fulfillment of the precepts, MN 11:13.4and love and affection for those sharing the same path are said to be far from ideal. MN 11:13.5Why is that? MN 11:13.6It’s because that teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.

MN 11:14.1The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha claims to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping. MN 11:14.2He describes the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.

MN 11:15.1In such a teaching and training, confidence in the Teacher is said to be ideal. MN 11:15.2Likewise, confidence in the teaching, MN 11:15.3fulfillment of the precepts, MN 11:15.4and love and affection for those sharing the same path are said to be ideal. MN 11:15.5Why is that? MN 11:15.6It’s because that teaching and training is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by a fully awakened Buddha.

MN 11:16.1BJ 10.164What is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of these four kinds of grasping? MN 11:16.10Name and form. MN 11:16.11And what is the source of name and form? MN 11:16.12Consciousness. MN 11:16.13And what is the source of consciousness? MN 11:16.14Choices. MN 11:16.15And what is the source of choices? MN 11:16.16Ignorance.

MN 11:16.2Craving. MN 11:16.3And what is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of craving? MN 11:16.4Feeling. MN 11:16.5And what is the source of feeling? MN 11:16.6Contact. MN 11:16.7And what is the source of contact? MN 11:16.8The six sense fields. MN 11:16.9And what is the source of the six sense fields?

MN 11:17.1When that mendicant has given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, they don’t grasp at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, or theories of a self. MN 11:17.2Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

MN 11:17.3They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”

MN 11:17.4PTS-VP-PLI 1.68That is what the Buddha said. MN 11:17.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 11:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.64“‘Only here is there a true ascetic, here a second ascetic, here a third ascetic, and here a fourth ascetic. MN 11:2.2Other sects are empty of ascetics.’ MN 11:2.3This, mendicants, is how you should rightly roar your lion’s roar.

MN 11:3.1BJ 10.156It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say: MN 11:3.10We have confidence in the Teacher, we have confidence in the teaching, and we have fulfilled the precepts. MN 11:3.11And we have love and affection for those who share our path, MN 11:3.12both laypeople and renunciates. MN 11:3.13These are the four things.’ MN 11:3.2‘But what is the source of the venerables’ self-confidence and forcefulness that they say this?’ MN 11:3.5You should say to them: MN 11:3.6‘There are four things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. Seeing these things in ourselves we say that:

MN 11:3.7“Only here is there a true ascetic, here a second ascetic, here a third ascetic, and here a fourth ascetic. MN 11:3.8Other sects are empty of ascetics.” MN 11:3.9What four?

MN 11:4.1It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say: MN 11:4.2‘We too have confidence in the Teacher—our Teacher; we have confidence in the teaching—our teaching; and we have fulfilled the precepts—our precepts. MN 11:4.3And we have love and affection for those who share our path, MN 11:4.4both laypeople and renunciates. MN 11:4.5What, then, is the difference between you and us?’

MN 11:5.1You should say to them: MN 11:5.10‘It’s for those free of hate.’

MN 11:5.11BJ 10.158‘Is it for the delusional or those free of delusion?’ MN 11:5.13‘It’s for those free of delusion.’

MN 11:5.14PTS-VP-PLI 1.65‘Is it for those who crave or those rid of craving?’ MN 11:5.16‘It’s for those rid of craving.’

MN 11:5.17‘Is it for those who grasp or those who don’t grasp?’ MN 11:5.19‘It’s for those who don’t grasp.’

MN 11:5.2‘Well, reverends, is the goal one or many?’

MN 11:5.20‘Is it for the knowledgeable or the ignorant?’ MN 11:5.22‘It’s for the knowledgeable.’

MN 11:5.23‘Is it for those who favor and oppose or for those who don’t favor and oppose?’ MN 11:5.25‘It’s for those who don’t favor and oppose.’

MN 11:5.26‘But is that goal for those who enjoy proliferation or for those who enjoy non-proliferation?’ MN 11:5.27Answering rightly, the wanderers would say: MN 11:5.28‘It’s for those who enjoy non-proliferation, not for those who enjoy proliferation.’

MN 11:5.3Answering rightly, the wanderers would say: MN 11:5.4‘The goal is one, reverends, not many.’

MN 11:5.5‘But is that goal for the greedy or for those free of greed?’ MN 11:5.6Answering rightly, the wanderers would say: MN 11:5.7‘That goal is for those free of greed, not for the greedy.’

MN 11:5.8‘Is it for the hateful or those free of hate?’

MN 11:6.1BJ 10.160Mendicants, there are these two views: MN 11:6.2views favoring continued existence and views favoring ending existence. MN 11:6.3Any ascetics or brahmins who cling, hold, and attach to a view favoring continued existence will oppose a view favoring ending existence. MN 11:6.4Any ascetics or brahmins who cling, hold, and attach to a view favoring ending existence will oppose a view favoring continued existence.

MN 11:7.1There are some ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these two views’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape. They’re greedy, hateful, delusional, craving, grasping, and ignorant. They favor and oppose, and they enjoy proliferation. MN 11:7.2They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. MN 11:7.3They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

MN 11:8.1There are some ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand these two views’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape. They’re rid of greed, hate, delusion, craving, grasping, and ignorance. They don’t favor and oppose, and they enjoy non-proliferation. MN 11:8.2They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. MN 11:8.3They’re freed from suffering, I say.

MN 11:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.66There are these four kinds of grasping. MN 11:9.2What four? MN 11:9.3Grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.

  • MN 12:0.1Middle Discourses 12

MN 12:0.2The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

MN 12:1.1So I have heard. MN 12:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī in a woodland grove behind the town.

MN 12:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.70Firstly, the Realized One truly understands the possible as possible, and the impossible as impossible. MN 12:10.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.

MN 12:11.1Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of causes and reasons. MN 12:11.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

MN 12:12.1BJ 10.170Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands where all paths of practice lead. MN 12:12.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

MN 12:13.1Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the world with its many and diverse elements. MN 12:13.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

MN 12:14.1Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the diverse attitudes of sentient beings. MN 12:14.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

MN 12:15.1Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the faculties of other sentient beings and other individuals after comprehending them with his mind. MN 12:15.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

MN 12:16.1Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments. MN 12:16.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

MN 12:17.1BJ 10.172Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details. MN 12:17.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

MN 12:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.71Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Realized One sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds. ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, he sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds. MN 12:18.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

MN 12:19.1Furthermore, the Realized One has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements. MN 12:19.2Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.

MN 12:2.1Now at that time Sunakkhatta the Licchavi had recently left this teaching and training. MN 12:2.2He was telling a crowd in Vesālī:

MN 12:2.3“The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones. MN 12:2.4He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective. MN 12:2.5And his teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.”

MN 12:20.1A Realized One possesses these ten powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.

MN 12:21.1BJ 10.174When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this: MN 12:21.2‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones. MN 12:21.3He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective.’ MN 12:21.4Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell. MN 12:21.5Just as a mendicant accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom would reach enlightenment in this very life, such is the consequence, I say. MN 12:21.6Unless they give up that speech and thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.

MN 12:22.1Sāriputta, a Realized One has four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel. MN 12:22.2What four?

MN 12:23.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.72I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or Brahmā, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘You claim to be fully awakened, but you don’t understand these things.’ MN 12:23.2Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

MN 12:24.1I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or Brahmā, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘You claim to have ended all defilements, but these defilements have not ended.’ MN 12:24.2Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

MN 12:25.1I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or Brahmā, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘The acts that you say are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.’ MN 12:25.2Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

MN 12:26.1I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or Brahmā, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘The teaching doesn’t lead those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which you taught it.’ MN 12:26.2Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

MN 12:27.1BJ 10.176A Realized One has these four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.

MN 12:28.1When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this: MN 12:28.2‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones …’ MN 12:28.3Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.

MN 12:29.1Sāriputta, there are these eight assemblies. MN 12:29.2What eight? MN 12:29.3The assemblies of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics. An assembly of the gods under the Four Great Kings. An assembly of the gods under the Thirty-Three. An assembly of Māras. An assembly of Brahmās. MN 12:29.4These are the eight assemblies. MN 12:29.5Possessing these four kinds of self-assurance, the Realized One approaches and enters right into these eight assemblies. MN 12:29.6I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of aristocrats. MN 12:29.7There I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion. MN 12:29.8But I don’t see any reason to feel afraid or insecure. MN 12:29.9Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

MN 12:3.1BJ 10.166Then Venerable Sāriputta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms. MN 12:3.2He heard what Sunakkhatta was saying.

MN 12:3.6Then he wandered for alms in Vesālī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

MN 12:30.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.73I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of brahmins … MN 12:30.10Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

MN 12:30.2householders … MN 12:30.3ascetics … MN 12:30.4the gods under the Four Great Kings … MN 12:30.5the gods under the Thirty-Three … MN 12:30.6Māras … MN 12:30.7Brahmās. MN 12:30.8There too I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion. MN 12:30.9But I don’t see any reason to feel afraid or insecure.

MN 12:31.1When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this: MN 12:31.2‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones …’ MN 12:31.3Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.

MN 12:32.1BJ 10.178Sāriputta, there are these four kinds of reproduction. MN 12:32.2What four? MN 12:32.3Reproduction for creatures born from an egg, from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.

MN 12:33.1And what is reproduction from an egg? MN 12:33.10And what is spontaneous reproduction? MN 12:33.11Gods, hell-beings, certain humans, and certain beings in the lower realms. MN 12:33.12This is called spontaneous reproduction. MN 12:33.13These are the four kinds of reproduction.

MN 12:33.2There are beings who are born by breaking out of an eggshell. MN 12:33.3This is called reproduction from an egg. MN 12:33.4And what is reproduction from a womb? MN 12:33.5There are beings who are born by breaking out of the amniotic sac. MN 12:33.6This is called reproduction from a womb. MN 12:33.7And what is reproduction from moisture? MN 12:33.8There are beings who are born in a rotten fish, in a rotten corpse, in rotten dough, in a cesspool or a sump. MN 12:33.9This is called reproduction from moisture.

MN 12:34.1When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this: MN 12:34.2‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones …’ MN 12:34.3Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.

MN 12:35.1BJ 10.180PTS-VP-PLI 1.74There are these five destinations. MN 12:35.2What five? MN 12:35.3Hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, humanity, and the gods.

MN 12:36.1I understand hell, and the path and practice that leads to hell. MN 12:36.10And I understand how someone practicing that way, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 12:36.11And I understand extinguishment, and the path and practice that leads to extinguishment. MN 12:36.12And I understand how someone practicing that way realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

MN 12:36.2And I understand how someone practicing that way, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 12:36.3I understand the animal realm … MN 12:36.6the ghost realm … MN 12:36.7humanity … MN 12:36.9gods, and the path and practice that leads to the world of the gods.

MN 12:37.1When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand: MN 12:37.2‘This person is practicing in such a way and has entered such a path that when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’ MN 12:37.3Then some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in hell, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe. MN 12:37.4Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, full of glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked. MN 12:37.5Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same pit of coals.MN 12:37.6If a person with good eyesight saw them, they’d say: MN 12:37.7‘This person is proceeding in such a way and has entered such a path that they will arrive at that very pit of coals.’ MN 12:37.8Then some time later they see that they have indeed fallen into that pit of coals, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe. …

MN 12:38.1BJ 10.182PTS-VP-PLI 1.75When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand: MN 12:38.2‘This person … will be reborn in the animal realm.’ MN 12:38.3Then some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in the animal realm, where they suffer painful feelings, sharp and severe. MN 12:38.4Suppose there was a sewer deeper than a man’s height, full to the brim with feces. MN 12:38.5Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same sewer. MN 12:38.6If a person with good eyesight saw them, they’d say: MN 12:38.7‘This person is proceeding in such a way and has entered such a path that they will arrive at that very sewer.’ MN 12:38.8Then some time later they see that they have indeed fallen into that sewer, where they suffer painful feelings, sharp and severe. …

MN 12:39.1When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand: MN 12:39.2‘This person … will be reborn in the ghost realm.’ MN 12:39.3Then some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in the ghost realm, where they experience many painful feelings. MN 12:39.4Suppose there was a tree growing on rugged ground, with thin foliage casting dappled shade. MN 12:39.5Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same tree. MN 12:39.6If a person with good eyesight saw them, they’d say: MN 12:39.7‘This person is proceeding in such a way and has entered such a path that they will arrive at that very tree.’ MN 12:39.8Then some time later they see them sitting or lying under that tree, where they experience many painful feelings. …

MN 12:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.69“Sāriputta, Sunakkhatta, that silly man, is angry. MN 12:4.2His words are spoken out of anger. MN 12:4.3Thinking he criticizes the Realized One, in fact he just praises him. MN 12:4.4For it is praise of the Realized One to say: MN 12:4.5‘His teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.’

MN 12:40.1BJ 10.184When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand: MN 12:40.2‘This person … will be reborn among human beings.’ MN 12:40.3Then some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn among human beings, where they experience many pleasant feelings. MN 12:40.4Suppose there was a tree growing on smooth ground, with abundant foliage casting dense shade. MN 12:40.5Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same tree. MN 12:40.6If a person with good eyesight saw them, they’d say: MN 12:40.7‘This person is proceeding in such a way and has entered such a path that they will arrive at that very tree.’ MN 12:40.8Then some time later they see them sitting or lying under that tree, where they experience many pleasant feelings. …

MN 12:41.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.76When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand: MN 12:41.2‘This person … will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ MN 12:41.3Then some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in a heavenly realm, where they experience exclusively pleasant feelings. MN 12:41.4Suppose there was a stilt longhouse with a peaked roof, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with latches fastened and windows shuttered. MN 12:41.5And it had a couch spread with woolen covers—shag-piled, pure white, or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends. MN 12:41.6Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same stilt longhouse. MN 12:41.7If a person with good eyesight saw them, they’d say: MN 12:41.8‘This person is proceeding in such a way and has entered such a path that they will arrive at that very stilt longhouse.’ MN 12:41.9Then some time later they see them sitting or lying in that stilt longhouse, where they experience exclusively pleasant feelings. …

MN 12:42.1BJ 10.186PTS-VP-PLI 1.77When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand:

MN 12:42.10In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a person, I understand: MN 12:42.11‘This person is practicing in such a way and has entered such a path that they will realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’ MN 12:42.12Then some time later I see that they have indeed realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements, experiencing exclusively pleasant feelings. MN 12:42.13These are the five destinations.

MN 12:42.2‘This person is practicing in such a way and has entered such a path that they will realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’ MN 12:42.3Then some time later I see that they have indeed realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements, experiencing exclusively pleasant feelings. MN 12:42.4Suppose there was a lotus pond with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful. MN 12:42.5And nearby was a dark forest grove. MN 12:42.6Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same lotus pond. MN 12:42.7If a person with good eyesight saw them, they’d say: MN 12:42.8‘This person is proceeding in such a way and has entered such a path that they will arrive at that very lotus pond.’ MN 12:42.9Then some time later they would see that person after they had plunged into that lotus pond, bathed and drunk. When all their stress, weariness, and heat exhaustion had faded away, they emerged and sat or lay down in that woodland thicket, where they experienced exclusively pleasant feelings.

MN 12:43.1When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this: MN 12:43.2‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones. MN 12:43.3He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective.’ MN 12:43.4Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell. MN 12:43.5Just as a mendicant accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom would reach enlightenment in this very life, such is the consequence, I say. MN 12:43.6Unless they give up that speech and thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.

MN 12:44.1BJ 10.188PTS-VP-PLI 1.78Sāriputta, I recall having practiced a spiritual path consisting of four factors. MN 12:44.2I used to be a self-mortifier, the ultimate self-mortifier. I used to live rough, the ultimate rough-liver. I used to live in disgust at sin, the ultimate one living in disgust at sin. I used to be secluded, in ultimate seclusion.

MN 12:45.1And this is what my self-mortification was like. I went naked, ignoring conventions. I licked my hands, and didn’t come or stop when asked. I didn’t consent to food brought to me, or food prepared specially for me, or an invitation for a meal. MN 12:45.10I squatted, committed to the endeavor of squatting. MN 12:45.11I lay on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns my bed. MN 12:45.12I was committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening. MN 12:45.13And so I lived committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body. MN 12:45.14Such was my practice of self-mortification.

MN 12:45.2I didn’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where food for distribution is advertised; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. I accepted no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drank no beer. MN 12:45.3I went to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls. MN 12:45.4I fed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day. MN 12:45.5I ate once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. I lived committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.

MN 12:45.6I ate herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. I survived on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.

MN 12:45.7I wore robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings. MN 12:45.8I tore out hair and beard, committed to this practice. MN 12:45.9I constantly stood, refusing seats.

MN 12:46.1BJ 10.190And this is what my rough living was like. MN 12:46.2The dust and dirt built up on my body over many years until it started flaking off. MN 12:46.3It’s like the trunk of a pale-moon ebony tree, which builds up bark over many years until it starts flaking off. MN 12:46.4But it didn’t occur to me: MN 12:46.5‘Oh, this dust and dirt must be rubbed off by my hand or another’s.’ MN 12:46.6That didn’t occur to me. MN 12:46.7Such was my rough living.

MN 12:47.1And this is what my living in disgust of sin was like. MN 12:47.2I’d step forward or back ever so mindfully. I was full of pity even regarding a drop of water, thinking: MN 12:47.3‘May I not accidentally injure any little creatures that happen to be in the wrong place.’ MN 12:47.4Such was my living in disgust of sin.

MN 12:48.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.79And this is what my seclusion was like. MN 12:48.10Such was my practice of seclusion.

MN 12:48.2I would plunge deep into a wilderness region and stay there. MN 12:48.3When I saw a cowherd or a shepherd, or someone gathering grass or sticks, or a lumberjack, I’d flee from forest to forest, from thicket to thicket, from valley to valley, from uplands to uplands. MN 12:48.4Why is that? MN 12:48.5So that I wouldn’t see them, nor they me. MN 12:48.6I fled like a wild deer seeing a human being.

MN 12:49.1I would go on all fours into the cow-pens after the cattle had left and eat the dung of the young suckling calves. MN 12:49.2As long as my own urine and excrement lasted, I would even eat that. MN 12:49.3Such was my eating of most unnatural things.

MN 12:5.1But there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching: MN 12:5.2‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

MN 12:50.1BJ 10.192I would plunge deep into an awe-inspiring forest grove and stay there. MN 12:50.10the sage still pursues his quest.’

MN 12:50.2It was so awe-inspiring that MN 12:50.3normally it would make your hair stand on end if you weren’t free of greed. MN 12:50.4And on days such as the cold spell when the snow falls in the dead of winter, I stayed in the open by night and in the forest by day.MN 12:50.5But in the last month of summer I’d stay in the open by day and in the forest by night. MN 12:50.6And then these verses, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me:

MN 12:50.7‘Scorched and frozen, MN 12:50.8alone in the awe-inspiring forest. MN 12:50.9Naked, no fire to sit beside,

MN 12:51.1I would make my bed in a charnel ground, with the bones of the dead for a pillow. MN 12:51.2Then the cowboys would come up to me. They’d spit and piss on me, throw mud on me, even poke sticks in my ears. MN 12:51.3But I don’t recall ever having a bad thought about them. MN 12:51.4Such was my abiding in equanimity.

MN 12:52.1BJ 10.194PTS-VP-PLI 1.80There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 12:52.10But you should not see it like this. MN 12:52.11The jujubes then were at most the same size as today. MN 12:52.12Eating so very little, my body became extremely emaciated. MN 12:52.13Due to eating so little, my limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a corpse, MN 12:52.14my bottom became like a camel’s hoof, MN 12:52.15my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string, MN 12:52.16and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn. MN 12:52.17Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well. MN 12:52.18Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun. MN 12:52.19Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly. MN 12:52.2‘Purity comes from food.’ MN 12:52.20Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there. MN 12:52.21Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.

MN 12:52.3They say: MN 12:52.4‘Let’s live on jujubes.’ MN 12:52.5So they eat jujubes and jujube powder, and drink jujube juice. MN 12:52.6And they enjoy many jujube concoctions. MN 12:52.7I recall eating just a single jujube. MN 12:52.8You might think that MN 12:52.9at that time the jujubes must have been very big.

MN 12:53-55.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.81There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 12:53-55.2‘Purity comes from food.’ MN 12:53-55.23Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.

MN 12:53-55.3They say: MN 12:53-55.4‘Let’s live on mung beans.’ … MN 12:53-55.5‘Let’s live on sesame.’ … MN 12:53-55.6‘Let’s live on ordinary rice.’ …

MN 12:56.1BJ 10.196But Sāriputta, I did not achieve any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by that conduct, that practice, that grueling work. MN 12:56.2Why is that? MN 12:56.3Because I didn’t achieve that noble wisdom that’s noble and emancipating, and which leads someone who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.

MN 12:57.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.82There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 12:57.2‘Purity comes from transmigration.’ MN 12:57.3But it’s not easy to find a realm that I haven’t previously transmigrated to in all this long time, except for the gods of the pure abodes. MN 12:57.4For if I had transmigrated to the gods of the pure abodes I would not have returned to this realm again.

MN 12:58.1There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 12:58.2‘Purity comes from rebirth.’ MN 12:58.3But it’s not easy to find any rebirth that I haven’t previously been reborn in …

MN 12:59.1There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 12:59.2‘Purity comes from abode of rebirth.’ MN 12:59.3But it’s not easy to find an abode where I haven’t previously abided …

MN 12:6.1And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching: MN 12:6.2‘That Blessed One wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying himself and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unimpeded through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.’

MN 12:60.1There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 12:60.2‘Purity comes from sacrifice.’ MN 12:60.3But it’s not easy to find a sacrifice that I haven’t previously offered in all this long time, when I was an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.

MN 12:61.1There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 12:61.2‘Purity comes from serving the sacred flame.’ MN 12:61.3But it’s not easy to find a fire that I haven’t previously served in all this long time, when I was an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.

MN 12:62.1BJ 10.198PTS-VP-PLI 1.83There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 12:62.10And they’d pause only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness. But the Realized One would not run out of Dhamma teachings, words and phrases of the teachings, or spontaneous answers. MN 12:62.11And at the end of a hundred years my four disciples would pass away. MN 12:62.12Even if you have to carry me around on a stretcher, there will never be any deterioration in the Realized One’s lucidity of wisdom.

MN 12:62.2‘So long as this gentleman is youthful, young, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life he will be endowed with perfect lucidity of wisdom. MN 12:62.3But when he’s old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—he will lose his lucidity of wisdom.’ MN 12:62.4But you should not see it like this. MN 12:62.5For now I am old, elderly, and senior, I’m advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life. I am eighty years old. MN 12:62.6Suppose I had four disciples with a lifespan of a hundred years. And they each were perfect in memory, range, retention, and perfect lucidity of wisdom. MN 12:62.7Imagine how easily a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow would shoot a light arrow across the shadow of a palm tree. MN 12:62.8That’s how extraordinary they were in memory, range, retention, and perfect lucidity of wisdom. MN 12:62.9They’d bring up questions about the four kinds of mindfulness meditation again and again, and I would answer each question. They’d remember the answers and not ask the same question twice.

MN 12:63.1And if there’s anyone of whom it may be rightly said that MN 12:63.2a being not liable to delusion has arisen in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans, it’s of me that this should be said.”

MN 12:64.1Now at that time Venerable Nāgasamāla was standing behind the Buddha fanning him. MN 12:64.2Then he said to the Buddha:

MN 12:64.3“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! MN 12:64.4While I was listening to this exposition of the teaching my hair stood up! MN 12:64.5What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

MN 12:64.6“Well, Nāgasamāla, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Hair-raising Discourse’.”

MN 12:64.7That is what the Buddha said. MN 12:64.8Satisfied, Venerable Nāgasamāla was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 12:7.1BJ 10.168And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching: MN 12:7.2‘That Blessed One, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, hears both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.’

MN 12:8.1And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching: MN 12:8.10scattered mind …MN 12:8.11expansive mind …MN 12:8.12unexpansive mind …MN 12:8.13mind that is supreme …MN 12:8.14mind that is not supreme …MN 12:8.15mind immersed in samādhi …MN 12:8.16mind not immersed in samādhi …MN 12:8.17freed mind as “freed mind,”MN 12:8.18and unfreed mind as “unfreed mind.”’

MN 12:8.2‘That Blessed One understands the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with his own mind.MN 12:8.3He understands mind with greed as “mind with greed,”MN 12:8.4and mind without greed as “mind without greed.”MN 12:8.5He understands mind with hate …MN 12:8.6mind without hate …MN 12:8.7mind with delusion …MN 12:8.8mind without delusion …MN 12:8.9constricted mind …

MN 12:9.1The Realized One possesses ten powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel. MN 12:9.2What ten?

  • MN 13:0.1Middle Discourses 13

MN 13:0.2The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

MN 13:1.1BJ 10.200PTS-VP-PLI 1.84So I have heard. MN 13:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 13:10.1That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, and succeed in earning money. MN 13:10.2But they experience pain and sadness when they try to protect it, thinking: MN 13:10.3‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’ MN 13:10.4And even though they protect it and ward it, rulers or bandits take it, or fire consumes it, or flood sweeps it away, or unloved heirs take it. MN 13:10.5They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion: MN 13:10.6‘What used to be mine is gone.’ MN 13:10.7This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 13:11.1Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend. MN 13:11.2Once they’ve started quarreling, arguing, and disputing, they attack each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords, MN 13:11.3resulting in death and deadly pain. MN 13:11.4This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 13:12.1BJ 10.206Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and plunge into a battle massed on both sides, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing. MN 13:12.2There they are struck with arrows and spears, and their heads are chopped off, MN 13:12.3resulting in death and deadly pain. MN 13:12.4This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 13:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.87Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and charge wetly plastered bastions, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing. MN 13:13.2There they are struck with arrows and spears, splashed with dung, crushed with spiked blocks, and their heads are chopped off, MN 13:13.3resulting in death and deadly pain. MN 13:13.4This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 13:14.1BJ 10.208Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, and commit adultery. MN 13:14.2The rulers would arrest them and subject them to various punishments—MN 13:14.3whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘demon’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘grass blades’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded. MN 13:14.4These result in death and deadly pain. MN 13:14.5This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 13:15.1Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures, they conduct themselves badly by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 13:15.2When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 13:15.3This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 13:16.1And what is the escape from sensual pleasures? MN 13:16.2Removing and giving up desire and greed for sensual pleasures: this is the escape from sensual pleasures.

MN 13:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.88There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures. MN 13:17.2There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures.

MN 13:18.1And what is the gratification of sights? MN 13:18.2Suppose there was a girl of the brahmins, aristocrats, or householders in her fifteenth or sixteenth year, neither too tall nor too short, neither too thin nor too fat, neither too dark nor too fair. Is she not at the height of her beauty and prettiness?”

MN 13:18.3“Yes, sir.”

MN 13:18.4“The pleasure and happiness that arise from this beauty and prettiness MN 13:18.5is the gratification of sights.

MN 13:19.1BJ 10.210And what is the drawback of sights? MN 13:19.2Suppose that some time later you were to see that same sister—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy.

MN 13:19.3What do you think, mendicants? MN 13:19.4Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”

MN 13:19.5“Yes, sir.”

MN 13:19.6“This is the drawback of sights.

MN 13:2.1Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms. MN 13:2.2Then it occurred to them, MN 13:2.3“It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī. MN 13:2.4Why don’t we go to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths?” MN 13:2.5Then they went to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths, and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there. MN 13:2.6When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. The wanderers said to them:

MN 13:20.1Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in her own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others.

MN 13:20.2What do you think, mendicants? MN 13:20.3Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”

MN 13:20.4“Yes, sir.”

MN 13:20.5“This too is the drawback of sights.

MN 13:21.1Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And she had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.

MN 13:21.3What do you think, mendicants? MN 13:21.4Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”

MN 13:21.5“Yes, sir.”

MN 13:21.6“This too is the drawback of sights.

MN 13:22.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.89Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And she was being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures …

MN 13:23-28.1Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. MN 13:23-28.2And she had been reduced to a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews … a skeleton rid of flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews … a skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews … MN 13:23-28.3bones without sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here a shin-bone, there a thigh-bone, here a hip-bone, there a rib-bone, here a back-bone, there an arm-bone, here a neck-bone, there a jaw-bone, here a tooth, there the skull. …

MN 13:29.1BJ 10.212Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. MN 13:29.2And she had been reduced to white bones, the color of shells … decrepit bones, heaped in a pile … bones rotted and crumbled to powder.

MN 13:29.3What do you think, mendicants? MN 13:29.4Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”

MN 13:29.5“Yes, sir.”

MN 13:29.6“This too is the drawback of sights.

MN 13:3.1“Reverends, the ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, and so do we. MN 13:3.2The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of sights, and so do we. MN 13:3.3The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of feelings, and so do we. MN 13:3.4What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s teaching and instruction and ours?”

MN 13:30.1And what is the escape from sights? MN 13:30.2Removing and giving up desire and greed for sights: this is the escape from sights.

MN 13:31.1There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand sights’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand sights themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sights. MN 13:31.2There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand sights’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand sights themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sights.

MN 13:32.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.90And what is the gratification of feelings? MN 13:32.2It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 13:32.3At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both; MN 13:32.4they feel only feelings that are not hurtful. MN 13:32.5Freedom from being hurt is the ultimate gratification of feelings, I say.

MN 13:33-35.1Furthermore, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption … MN 13:33-35.2third absorption … MN 13:33-35.3fourth absorption. At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both; MN 13:33-35.4they feel only feelings that are not hurtful. MN 13:33-35.5Freedom from being hurt is the ultimate gratification of feelings, I say.

MN 13:36.1BJ 10.214And what is the drawback of feelings? MN 13:36.2That feelings are impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is their drawback.

MN 13:37.1And what is the escape from feelings? MN 13:37.2Removing and giving up desire and greed for feelings: this is the escape from feelings.

MN 13:38.1There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand feelings themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand feelings. MN 13:38.2There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand feelings themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand feelings.”

MN 13:38.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 13:38.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 13:4.1Those mendicants neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the wanderers who follow other paths. MN 13:4.2They got up from their seat, thinking, MN 13:4.3“We will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”

MN 13:5.1BJ 10.202PTS-VP-PLI 1.85Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said:

MN 13:6.1“Mendicants, when wanderers who follow other paths say this, you should say to them: MN 13:6.2‘But reverends, what’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to sensual pleasures? MN 13:6.3What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to sights? MN 13:6.4What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to feelings?’ MN 13:6.5Questioned like this, the wanderers who follow other paths would be stumped, and, in addition, would get frustrated. MN 13:6.6Why is that? MN 13:6.7Because they’re out of their element. MN 13:6.8I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to these questions except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.

MN 13:7.1And what is the gratification of sensual pleasures? MN 13:7.10The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation: this is the gratification of sensual pleasures.

MN 13:7.2There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 13:7.3What five? MN 13:7.4Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 13:7.5Sounds known by the ear … MN 13:7.6Smells known by the nose … MN 13:7.7Tastes known by the tongue … MN 13:7.8Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 13:7.9These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

MN 13:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.86And what is the drawback of sensual pleasures? MN 13:8.2It’s when a gentleman earns a living by means such as MN 13:8.3computing, accounting, calculating, farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions. MN 13:8.4But they must face cold and heat, being hurt by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles, and risking death from hunger and thirst. MN 13:8.5This is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 13:9.1BJ 10.204That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, but fail to earn any money. MN 13:9.2If this happens, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion, saying: MN 13:9.3‘Oh, my hard work is wasted. My efforts are fruitless!’ MN 13:9.4This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 14:0.2The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

MN 14:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.91So I have heard. MN 14:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

MN 14:10.1Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend. MN 14:10.2Once they’ve started quarreling, arguing, and disputing, they attack each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords, MN 14:10.3resulting in death and deadly pain. MN 14:10.4This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 14:11.1Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and plunge into a battle massed on both sides, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing. MN 14:11.2There they are struck with arrows and spears, and their heads are chopped off, MN 14:11.3resulting in death and deadly pain. MN 14:11.4This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 14:12.1Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and charge wetly plastered bastions, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing. MN 14:12.2There they are struck with arrows and spears, splashed with dung, crushed with spiked blocks, and their heads are chopped off, MN 14:12.3resulting in death and deadly pain. MN 14:12.4This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 14:13.1BJ 10.222Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, and commit adultery. MN 14:13.2The rulers would arrest them and subject them to various punishments—MN 14:13.3whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘demon’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘grass blades’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded. MN 14:13.4These result in death and deadly pain. MN 14:13.5This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 14:14.1Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures, they conduct themselves badly by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 14:14.2When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 14:14.3This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 14:15.1BJ 10.224PTS-VP-PLI 1.93Mahānāma, this one time I was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain. MN 14:15.2Now at that time several Jain ascetics on the slopes of Isigili at the Black Rock were constantly standing, refusing seats. And they felt painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion.

MN 14:16.1Then in the late afternoon, I came out of retreat and went to the Black Rock to visit those Jain ascetics. I said to them, MN 14:16.2‘Reverends, why are you constantly standing, refusing seats, so that you suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?’

MN 14:17.1When I said this, those Jain ascetics said to me, MN 14:17.2‘Reverend, the Jain leader Nātaputta claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus: MN 14:17.3“Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”

MN 14:17.4He says, MN 14:17.5“O Jain ascetics, you have done bad deeds in a past life. Wear them away with these severe and grueling austerities. MN 14:17.6And when you refrain from such deeds in the present by way of body, speech, and mind, you’re not doing any bad deeds for the future. MN 14:17.7So, due to eliminating past deeds by mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future. MN 14:17.8With nothing to come up in the future, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.” MN 14:17.9We like and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.’

MN 14:18.1When they said this, I said to them,

MN 14:18.10‘No we don’t, reverend.’

MN 14:18.11‘But reverends, do you know MN 14:18.12that so much suffering has already been worn away? Or that so much suffering still remains to be worn away? Or that when so much suffering is worn away all suffering will have been worn away?’

MN 14:18.13‘No we don’t, reverend.’

MN 14:18.14‘But reverends, do you know MN 14:18.15about giving up unskillful qualities in the present life and embracing skillful qualities?’

MN 14:18.16‘No we don’t, reverend.’

MN 14:18.2‘But reverends, do you know MN 14:18.3for sure that you existed in the past, and it is not the case that you didn’t exist?’

MN 14:18.4‘No we don’t, reverend.’

MN 14:18.5‘But reverends, do you know MN 14:18.6for sure that you did bad deeds in the past?’

MN 14:18.7‘No we don’t, reverend.’

MN 14:18.8‘But reverends, do you know MN 14:18.9that you did such and such bad deeds?’

MN 14:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.94‘So it seems that you don’t know any of these things. MN 14:19.8That being so, when those in the world who are violent and bloody-handed and make their living by cruelty are reborn among humans they go forth as Jain ascetics.’

MN 14:2.1Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, MN 14:2.2“For a long time, sir, I have understood your teaching like this: MN 14:2.3‘Greed, hate, and delusion are corruptions of the mind.’ MN 14:2.6Despite understanding this, sometimes my mind is occupied by thoughts of greed, hate, and delusion. MN 14:2.8I wonder what qualities remain in me that I have such thoughts?”

MN 14:20.1‘Reverend Gotama, pleasure is not gained through pleasure; pleasure is gained through pain. MN 14:20.10But forget about that. Now we ask Venerable Gotama: MN 14:20.11“Who lives in greater pleasure, King Bimbisāra or Venerable Gotama?”'

MN 14:20.2For if pleasure were to be gained through pleasure, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Māgadha would gain pleasure, since he lives in greater pleasure than Venerable Gotama.’

MN 14:20.3BJ 10.226‘Clearly the venerables have spoken rashly, without reflection. MN 14:20.6Rather, I’m the one who should be asked about MN 14:20.7who lives in greater pleasure, King Bimbisāra or Venerable Gotama?’

MN 14:20.8‘Clearly we spoke rashly and without reflection.

MN 14:21.1‘Well then, reverends, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like. MN 14:21.10two days … MN 14:21.11one day?’

MN 14:21.12‘No he is not, reverend.’

MN 14:21.13PTS-VP-PLI 1.95‘But I am capable of experiencing perfect happiness for one day and night without moving my body or speaking. MN 14:21.14I am capable of experiencing perfect happiness for two days … MN 14:21.15three days … MN 14:21.16four days … MN 14:21.17five days … MN 14:21.18six days … MN 14:21.19seven days. MN 14:21.2What do you think, reverends? MN 14:21.20What do you think, reverends? This being so, who lives in greater pleasure, King Bimbisāra or I?’

MN 14:21.21‘This being so, Venerable Gotama lives in greater pleasure than King Bimbisāra.’”

MN 14:21.22That is what the Buddha said. MN 14:21.23Satisfied, Mahānāma the Sakyan was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 14:21.3Is King Bimbisāra capable of experiencing perfect happiness for seven days and nights without moving his body or speaking?’

MN 14:21.4‘No he is not, reverend.’

MN 14:21.5‘What do you think, reverends? MN 14:21.6Is King Bimbisāra capable of experiencing perfect happiness for six days … MN 14:21.7five days … MN 14:21.8four days … MN 14:21.9three days …

MN 14:3.1BJ 10.216“Mahānāma, there is a quality that remains in you that makes you have such thoughts. MN 14:3.2For if you had given up that quality you would not still be living at home and enjoying sensual pleasures. MN 14:3.3But because you haven’t given up that quality you are still living at home and enjoying sensual pleasures.

MN 14:4.1Sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. MN 14:4.2Even though a noble disciple has clearly seen this with right wisdom, so long as they don’t achieve the rapture and bliss that are apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that, MN 14:4.3they might still return to sensual pleasures. MN 14:4.4But when they do achieve that rapture and bliss, or something more peaceful than that, MN 14:4.5they will not return to sensual pleasures.

MN 14:5.1BJ 10.218PTS-VP-PLI 1.92Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too clearly saw with right wisdom that: MN 14:5.2‘Sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’ MN 14:5.3But so long as I didn’t achieve the rapture and bliss that are apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that, MN 14:5.4I didn’t announce that I would not return to sensual pleasures. MN 14:5.5But when I did achieve that rapture and bliss, or something more peaceful than that, MN 14:5.6I announced that I would not return to sensual pleasures.

MN 14:6.1And what is the gratification of sensual pleasures? MN 14:6.10The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation: this is the gratification of sensual pleasures. MN 14:6.2There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 14:6.3What five? MN 14:6.4Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 14:6.5Sounds known by the ear … MN 14:6.6Smells known by the nose … MN 14:6.7Tastes known by the tongue … MN 14:6.8Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 14:6.9These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

MN 14:7.1And what is the drawback of sensual pleasures? MN 14:7.2It’s when a gentleman earns a living by means such as MN 14:7.3computing, accounting, calculating, farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions. MN 14:7.4But they must face cold and heat, being hurt by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles, and risking death from hunger and thirst. MN 14:7.5This is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 14:8.1That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, but fail to earn any money. MN 14:8.2If this happens, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion, saying: ‘Oh, my hard work is wasted. My efforts are fruitless!’ MN 14:8.3This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 14:9.1BJ 10.220That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, and succeed in earning money. MN 14:9.2But they experience pain and sadness when they try to protect it, thinking: MN 14:9.3‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’ MN 14:9.4And even though they protect it and ward it, rulers or bandits take it, or fire consumes it, or flood sweeps it away, or unloved heirs take it. MN 14:9.5They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion: MN 14:9.6‘What used to be mine is gone.’ MN 14:9.7This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

MN 15:0.2Measuring Up

MN 15:1.1BJ 10.228So I have heard. MN 15:1.2At one time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was staying in the land of the Bhaggas on Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood. MN 15:1.3There Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants: MN 15:1.4“Reverends, mendicants!”

MN 15:1.5“Reverend,” they replied. MN 15:1.6Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said this:

MN 15:2.1“Suppose a mendicant invites MN 15:2.2other mendicants to admonish them. But they’re hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They're impatient, and don't take instruction respectfully. So their spiritual companions don’t think it’s worth advising and instructing them, and that person doesn’t gain their trust.

MN 15:3.1And what are the qualities that make them hard to admonish?

MN 15:3.11They’re irritable, and hostile due to anger …

MN 15:3.14They’re irritable, and stubborn due to anger …

MN 15:3.17They’re irritable, and blurt out words bordering on anger … MN 15:3.2Firstly, a mendicant has wicked desires, having fallen under the sway of wicked desires.

MN 15:3.20BJ 10.230When accused, they object to the accuser …

MN 15:3.23When accused, they rebuke the accuser …

MN 15:3.26PTS-VP-PLI 1.96When accused, they retort to the accuser …

MN 15:3.29When accused, they dodge the issue, distract the discussion with irrelevant points, and display annoyance, hate, and bitterness …

MN 15:3.32When accused, they are unable to account for their behavior …

MN 15:3.35They are offensive and contemptuous …

MN 15:3.38They’re jealous and stingy … MN 15:3.4This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.

MN 15:3.41They’re devious and deceitful …

MN 15:3.44They’re obstinate and vain …

MN 15:3.47Furthermore, a mendicant is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go. MN 15:3.49This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.

MN 15:3.5Furthermore, a mendicant glorifies themselves and puts others down. …

MN 15:3.50BJ 10.232These are the qualities that make them hard to admonish.

MN 15:3.8They’re irritable, overcome by anger …

MN 15:4.1Suppose a mendicant doesn’t invite MN 15:4.2other mendicants to admonish them. But they’re easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They're accepting, and take instruction respectfully. So their spiritual companions think it’s worth advising and instructing them, and that person gains their trust.

MN 15:5.1And what are the qualities that make them easy to admonish? MN 15:5.2Firstly, a mendicant doesn’t have wicked desires …

MN 15:5.47BJ 10.236Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t attached to their own views, not holding them tight, but letting them go easily.

MN 15:5.50These are the qualities that make them easy to admonish.

MN 15:6.1In such a case, a mendicant should measure themselves against another like this. MN 15:6.2‘This person has wicked desires, having fallen under the sway of wicked desires. And I don’t like or approve of this person. MN 15:6.3And if I were to fall under the sway of wicked desires, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’ MN 15:6.4A mendicant who knows this should give rise to the thought: ‘I will not fall under the sway of wicked desires.’ …

MN 15:6.47‘This person is attached to their own views, holding them tight and refusing to let go. And I don’t like or approve of this person. MN 15:6.48And if I were to be attached to my own views, holding them tight and refusing to let go, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’ MN 15:6.49A mendicant who knows this should give rise to the thought: ‘I will not be attached to my own views, holding them tight, but will let them go easily.’

MN 15:7.1BJ 10.242In such a case, a mendicant should check themselves like this: MN 15:7.2‘Do I have wicked desires? Have I fallen under the sway of wicked desires?’ MN 15:7.3Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that MN 15:7.4they have fallen under the sway of wicked desires. Then they should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities. MN 15:7.5But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that MN 15:7.6they haven’t fallen under the sway of wicked desires. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities. …

MN 15:7.89Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that MN 15:7.90they are attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go. Then they should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities. MN 15:7.91Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that MN 15:7.92they’re not attached to their own views, holding them tight, but let them go easily. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.

MN 15:8.1Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they haven’t given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should make an effort to give them all up. MN 15:8.2But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they have given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.

MN 15:8.3Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it. MN 15:8.4But if they don’t see any dirt or blemish there, they’re happy, thinking: MN 15:8.5‘How fortunate that I’m clean!’

MN 15:8.6In the same way, suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they haven’t given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should make an effort to give them all up. MN 15:8.7But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they have given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.”

MN 15:8.8This is what Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said. MN 15:8.9Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said.

MN 16:0.2Emotional Barrenness

MN 16:1.1BJ 10.252PTS-VP-PLI 1.101So I have heard. MN 16:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 16:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 16:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 16:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 16:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 16:10.1BJ 10.256PTS-VP-PLI 1.102Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for form … MN 16:10.2This is the third emotional shackle.

MN 16:11.1They eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing … MN 16:11.3This is the fourth emotional shackle.

MN 16:12.1They lead the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods, thinking: ‘By this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’ MN 16:12.2This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving. MN 16:12.3This is the fifth emotional shackle they haven’t cut off. MN 16:12.4These are the five emotional shackles they haven’t cut off.

MN 16:13.1When a mendicant has not given up these five kinds of emotional barrenness and cut off these five emotional shackles, it’s not possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

MN 16:14.1BJ 10.258When a mendicant has given up these five kinds of emotional barrenness and cut off these five emotional shackles, it is possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.

MN 16:15.1What are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they’ve given up? MN 16:15.2Firstly, a mendicant has no doubts about the Teacher. They’re not uncertain, undecided, or lacking confidence. MN 16:15.3This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving. MN 16:15.4This is the first kind of emotional barrenness they’ve given up.

MN 16:16.1Furthermore, a mendicant has no doubts about the teaching …

MN 16:17.1They have no doubts about the Saṅgha …

MN 16:18.1They have no doubts about the training …

MN 16:19.1BJ 10.260PTS-VP-PLI 1.103They’re not angry and upset with their spiritual companions, not resentful or closed off. MN 16:19.2This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving. MN 16:19.3This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness they’ve given up. MN 16:19.4These are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they’ve given up.

MN 16:2.1“Mendicants, when a mendicant has not given up five kinds of emotional barrenness and cut off five emotional shackles, it’s not possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

MN 16:20.1What are the five emotional shackles they’ve cut off? MN 16:20.2Firstly, a mendicant is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures. MN 16:20.3This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving. MN 16:20.4This is the first emotional shackle they’ve cut off.

MN 16:21.1BJ 10.262Furthermore, a mendicant is rid of greed for the body …

MN 16:22.1They’re rid of greed for form …

MN 16:23.1They don’t eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …
