MN 16:24.3This is the fifth emotional shackle they’ve cut off. MN 16:24.4These are the five emotional shackles they’ve cut off.

MN 16:25.1When a mendicant has given up these five kinds of emotional barrenness and cut off these five emotional shackles, it is possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

MN 16:26.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.104They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort … MN 16:26.2the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort … MN 16:26.3the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort … MN 16:26.4the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort. And the fifth is sheer vigor. MN 16:27.1A mendicant who possesses these fifteen factors, including vigor, is capable of breaking out, becoming awakened, and reaching the supreme sanctuary. MN 16:27.2Suppose there was a chicken with eight or ten or twelve eggs. MN 16:27.3And she properly sat on them to keep them warm and incubated. MN 16:27.4Even if that chicken doesn’t wish: MN 16:27.5‘If only my chicks could break out of the eggshell with their claws and beak and hatch safely!’ MN 16:27.6Still they can break out and hatch safely.

MN 16:27.7In the same way, a mendicant who possesses these fifteen factors, including vigor, is capable of breaking out, becoming awakened, and reaching the supreme sanctuary.”

MN 16:27.8That is what the Buddha said. MN 16:27.9Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 16:3.1What are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up? MN 16:3.2Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence. MN 16:3.3This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving. MN 16:3.4This is the first kind of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up.

MN 16:4.1Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching … MN 16:4.2This is the second kind of emotional barrenness.

MN 16:5.1They have doubts about the Saṅgha … MN 16:5.2This is the third kind of emotional barrenness.

MN 16:6.1BJ 10.254They have doubts about the training … MN 16:6.3This is the fourth kind of emotional barrenness.

MN 16:7.1Furthermore, a mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off. MN 16:7.2This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving. MN 16:7.3This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up. MN 16:7.4These are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up.

MN 16:8.1What are the five emotional shackles they haven’t cut off? MN 16:8.2Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures. MN 16:8.3This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving. MN 16:8.4This is the first emotional shackle they haven’t cut off.

MN 16:9.1Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body … MN 16:9.2This is the second emotional shackle.

MN 17:0.2Jungle Thickets

MN 17:1.1BJ 10.264So I have heard. MN 17:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 17:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 17:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 17:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 17:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 17:2.1“Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition about jungle thickets. MN 17:2.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 17:2.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 17:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 17:23.1an individual. MN 17:23.2As they do so, their mindfulness does not become established, their mind does not become immersed in samādhi, their defilements do not come to an end, and they do not arrive at the supreme sanctuary. MN 17:23.3And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by…. MN 17:23.7That mendicant should leave that person at any time of the day or night, without asking. They shouldn’t follow them. …

MN 17:26.1BJ 10.272PTS-VP-PLI 1.108Take another case of a mendicant who lives supported by an individual. MN 17:26.2As they do so, their mindfulness becomes established, their mind becomes immersed in samādhi, their defilements come to an end, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary. MN 17:26.3And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are easy to come by. MN 17:26.4That mendicant should reflect: MN 17:26.5‘While living supported by this person, my mindfulness becomes established … MN 17:26.6And the necessities of life are easy to come by.’ MN 17:26.7That mendicant should follow that person for the rest of their life. They shouldn’t leave them, even if sent away.”

MN 17:26.8That is what the Buddha said. MN 17:26.9Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 17:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.105“Mendicants, take the case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket. MN 17:3.2As they do so, their mindfulness does not become established, their mind does not become immersed in samādhi, their defilements do not come to an end, and they do not arrive at the supreme sanctuary. MN 17:3.3And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by. MN 17:3.4That mendicant should reflect: MN 17:3.5‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness does not become established, my mind does not become immersed in samādhi, my defilements do not come to an end, and I do not arrive at the supreme sanctuary. MN 17:3.6And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.’ MN 17:3.7That mendicant should leave that jungle thicket that very time of night or day; they shouldn’t stay there.

MN 17:4.1BJ 10.266Take another case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket. MN 17:4.2Their mindfulness does not become established … MN 17:4.3But the necessities of life are easy to come by. MN 17:4.4That mendicant should reflect: MN 17:4.5‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness does not become established … MN 17:4.6But the necessities of life are easy to come by. MN 17:4.7But I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe, almsfood, lodgings, or medicines and supplies for the sick. MN 17:4.8Moreover, while living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness does not become established …’ MN 17:4.9After appraisal, that mendicant should leave that jungle thicket; they shouldn’t stay there.

MN 17:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.106Take another case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket. MN 17:5.2As they do so, their mindfulness becomes established, their mind becomes immersed in samādhi, their defilements come to an end, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary. MN 17:5.3But the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by. That mendicant should reflect: MN 17:5.5‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness becomes established … MN 17:5.6But the necessities of life are hard to come by. MN 17:5.7But I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe, almsfood, lodgings, or medicines and supplies for the sick. MN 17:5.8Moreover, while living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness becomes established …’ MN 17:5.9After appraisal, that mendicant should stay in that jungle thicket; they shouldn’t leave.

MN 17:6.1BJ 10.268Take another case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket. MN 17:6.2Their mindfulness becomes established … MN 17:6.3And the necessities of life are easy to come by. MN 17:6.4That mendicant should reflect: MN 17:6.5‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness becomes established … MN 17:6.6And the necessities of life are easy to come by.’ MN 17:6.7That mendicant should stay in that jungle thicket for the rest of their life; they shouldn’t leave.

MN 17:7-22.1Take the case of a mendicant who lives supported by a village … MN 17:7-22.2town … MN 17:7-22.3city … MN 17:7-22.4country …

MN 18:0.2The Honey-Cake

MN 18:1.1BJ 10.274So I have heard. MN 18:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

MN 18:10.1Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered, MN 18:10.10He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha. MN 18:10.11Let’s go to him, and ask him about this matter.”

MN 18:10.2“The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. MN 18:10.7Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha?”

MN 18:10.8Then those mendicants thought, MN 18:10.9“This Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.

MN 18:11.1BJ 10.278PTS-VP-PLI 1.111Then those mendicants went to Mahākaccāna, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 18:11.18“May Venerable Mahākaccāna please explain this.”

MN 18:11.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. They told him what had happened, and said:

MN 18:12.1BJ 10.280“Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But he’d pass over the roots and trunk, imagining that the heartwood should be sought in the branches and leaves. MN 18:12.2Such is the consequence for the venerables. Though you were face to face with the Buddha, you overlooked him, imagining that you should ask me about this matter. MN 18:12.3For he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is holiness. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One. MN 18:12.4That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter. MN 18:12.5You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

MN 18:13.1“Certainly he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is holiness. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One. MN 18:13.2That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter. MN 18:13.3We should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer. MN 18:13.4Still, Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. MN 18:13.5You are capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha. MN 18:13.6Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”

MN 18:14.1“Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 18:14.2“Yes, reverend,” they replied. MN 18:14.3Venerable Mahākaccāna said this:

MN 18:15.1“Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail: MN 18:15.2‘A person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions. MN 18:15.3If they don’t find anything worth approving, welcoming, or getting attached to in the source from which these arise … MN 18:15.4This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.’ This is how I understand the detailed meaning of this passage for recitation.

MN 18:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.112Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. What you feel, you perceive. What you perceive, you think about. What you think about, you proliferate. What you proliferate about is the source from which a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions. This occurs with respect to sights known by the eye in the past, future, and present.

MN 18:16.2Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. …

MN 18:16.3Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. …

MN 18:16.4Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. …

MN 18:16.5Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. …

MN 18:16.6Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. What you feel, you perceive. What you perceive, you think about. What you think about, you proliferate. What you proliferate about is the source from which a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions. This occurs with respect to thoughts known by the mind in the past, future, and present.

MN 18:17.1BJ 10.282When there is the eye, sights, and eye consciousness, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘contact’. MN 18:17.10mind, thoughts, and mind consciousness, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘contact’. … MN 18:17.14When there is what’s known as thought, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘being beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions’.

MN 18:17.2When there is what’s known as contact, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘feeling’. MN 18:17.3When there is what’s known as feeling, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘perception’. MN 18:17.4When there is what’s known as perception, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘thought’. MN 18:17.5When there is what’s known as thought, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘being beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions’.

MN 18:17.6When there is the ear … MN 18:17.7nose … MN 18:17.8tongue … MN 18:17.9body …

MN 18:18.1When there is no eye, no sights, and no eye consciousness, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘contact’. MN 18:18.10mind, no thoughts, and no mind consciousness, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘contact’. … MN 18:18.14When there isn’t what’s known as thought, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘being beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions’.

MN 18:18.2When there isn’t what’s known as contact, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘feeling’. MN 18:18.3When there isn’t what’s known as feeling, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘perception’. MN 18:18.4When there isn’t what’s known as perception, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘thought’. MN 18:18.5When there isn’t what’s known as thought, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘being beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions’.

MN 18:18.6When there is no ear … MN 18:18.7nose … MN 18:18.8tongue … MN 18:18.9body …

MN 18:19.1BJ 10.284PTS-VP-PLI 1.113This is how I understand the detailed meaning of that brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha. MN 18:19.4If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this. MN 18:19.5You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

MN 18:2.1Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms. MN 18:2.2He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Great Wood, MN 18:2.3plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a young wood apple tree for the day’s meditation.

MN 18:20.1“Yes, reverend,” said those mendicants, approving and agreeing with what Mahākaccāna said. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then they said: MN 18:20.17“Mahākaccāna clearly explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”

MN 18:21.1“Mahākaccāna is astute, mendicants, he has great wisdom. MN 18:21.2If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Mahākaccāna. MN 18:21.3That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”

MN 18:22.1When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha, MN 18:22.2“Sir, suppose a person who was weak with hunger was to obtain a honey-cake. Wherever they taste it, they would enjoy a sweet, delicious flavor.

MN 18:22.3In the same way, wherever a sincere, capable mendicant might examine with wisdom the meaning of this exposition of the teaching they would only gain joy and clarity. MN 18:22.4Sir, what is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

MN 18:22.5“Well, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Honey-Cake Discourse’.”

MN 18:22.6That is what the Buddha said. MN 18:22.7Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 18:3.1Daṇḍapāṇi the Sakyan, while going for a walk, MN 18:3.2plunged deep into the Great Wood. He approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him. MN 18:3.3When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side leaning on his staff, and said to the Buddha, MN 18:3.4“What does the ascetic teach? What does he explain?”

MN 18:4.1“Sir, my teaching is such that one does not conflict with anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans. And it is such that perceptions do not underlie the brahmin who lives detached from sensual pleasures, without doubting, stripped of worry, and rid of craving for rebirth in this or that state. MN 18:4.2That’s what I teach, and that’s what I explain.”

MN 18:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.109When he had spoken, Daṇḍapāṇi shook his head, waggled his tongue, raised his eyebrows until his brow puckered in three furrows, and he departed leaning on his staff.

MN 18:6.1Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the Banyan Tree Monastery, sat down on the seat spread out,

MN 18:6.14BJ 10.276PTS-VP-PLI 1.110When he had spoken, one of the mendicants said to him, MN 18:6.2and told the mendicants what had happened. MN 18:7.1“But sir, what is the teaching such that the Buddha does not conflict with anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans? MN 18:7.2And how is it that perceptions do not underlie the Buddha, the brahmin who lives detached from sensual pleasures, without indecision, stripped of worry, and rid of craving for rebirth in this or that state?”

MN 18:8.1“Mendicant, a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions. MN 18:8.2If they don’t find anything worth approving, welcoming, or getting attached to in the source from which these arise, MN 18:8.3just this is the end of the underlying tendencies to desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, the desire to be reborn, and ignorance. This is the end of taking up the rod and the sword, the end of quarrels, arguments, and disputes, of accusations, divisive speech, and lies. MN 18:8.4This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.”

MN 18:9.1That is what the Buddha said. MN 18:9.2When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

  • MN 19:0.1Middle Discourses 19

MN 19:0.2Two Kinds of Thought

MN 19:1.1BJ 10.288So I have heard. MN 19:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 19:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 19:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 19:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 19:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 19:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.117Whatever a mendicant frequently thinks about and considers becomes their heart’s inclination. MN 19:11.2If they often think about and consider thoughts of renunciation, they’ve given up sensual thought to cultivate the thought of renunciation. Their mind inclines to thoughts of renunciation. MN 19:11.3If they often think about and consider thoughts of good will … their mind inclines to thoughts of good will. MN 19:11.4If they often think about and consider thoughts of harmlessness … their mind inclines to thoughts of harmlessness.

MN 19:12.1Suppose it’s the last month of summer, when all the crops have been gathered within a village, and a cowherd must take care of the cattle. While at the root of a tree or in the open he need only be mindful that MN 19:12.2the cattle are there. MN 19:12.3In the same way I needed only to be mindful that MN 19:12.4those things were there.

MN 19:13.1BJ 10.294My energy was roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness was established and lucid, my body was tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind was immersed in samādhi.

MN 19:14.1Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

MN 19:15.1As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

MN 19:16.1And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

MN 19:17.1With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

MN 19:18.1When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives. MN 19:18.2I recollected many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

MN 19:19.1This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night. MN 19:19.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

MN 19:2.1“Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought: MN 19:2.2‘Why don’t I meditate by continually dividing my thoughts into two classes?’ MN 19:2.3So I assigned sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts MN 19:2.4to one class. MN 19:2.5And I assigned thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness MN 19:2.6to the second class.

MN 19:20.1BJ 10.296When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this, I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 19:20.2With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

MN 19:21.1This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night. MN 19:21.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

MN 19:22.1When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this, I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 19:22.2I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.'

MN 19:23.1I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.' MN 19:23.2Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 19:23.3I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 19:24.1This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night. MN 19:24.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

MN 19:25.1BJ 10.298Suppose that in a forested wilderness there was an expanse of low-lying marshes, MN 19:25.2and a large herd of deer lived nearby. MN 19:25.3Then along comes a person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten them. MN 19:25.4They close off the safe, secure path that leads to happiness, and open the wrong path. There they plant domesticated male and female deer as decoys MN 19:25.5so that, in due course, that herd of deer would fall to ruin and disaster. MN 19:25.6Then along comes a person who wants to help keep the herd of deer safe. MN 19:25.7They open up the safe, secure path that leads to happiness, and close off the wrong path. They get rid of the decoys MN 19:25.8so that, in due course, that herd of deer would grow, increase, and mature.

MN 19:26.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.118I’ve made up this simile to make a point. MN 19:26.10‘A person who wants to help keep the herd of deer safe’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. MN 19:26.11‘The safe, secure path that leads to happiness’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is: MN 19:26.12right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

MN 19:26.13So, mendicants, I have opened up the safe, secure path to happiness and closed off the wrong path. And I have got rid of the male and female decoys.

MN 19:26.2And this is what it means. MN 19:26.3‘An expanse of low-lying marshes’ is a term for sensual pleasures. MN 19:26.4‘A large herd of deer’ is a term for sentient beings. MN 19:26.5‘A person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten them’ is a term for Māra the Wicked. MN 19:26.6‘The wrong path’ is a term for the wrong eightfold path, that is, MN 19:26.7wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion. MN 19:26.8‘A domesticated male deer’ is a term for greed and relishing. MN 19:26.9‘A domesticated female deer’ is a term for ignorance.

MN 19:27.1Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples. MN 19:27.2Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”

MN 19:27.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 19:27.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 19:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.115Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a sensual thought arose. MN 19:3.2I understood: MN 19:3.3‘This sensual thought has arisen in me. MN 19:3.4It leads to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both. It blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.’ MN 19:3.5When I reflected that it leads to hurting myself, it went away. MN 19:3.6When I reflected that it leads to hurting others, it went away. MN 19:3.7When I reflected that it leads to hurting both, it went away. MN 19:3.8When I reflected that it blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment, it went away. MN 19:3.9So I gave up, got rid of, and eliminated any sensual thoughts that arose.

MN 19:4-5.1Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a malicious thought arose … MN 19:4-5.10So I gave up, got rid of, and eliminated any cruel thoughts that arose.

MN 19:4-5.2a cruel thought arose. MN 19:4-5.3I understood: MN 19:4-5.4‘This cruel thought has arisen in me. MN 19:4-5.5It leads to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both. It blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.’ MN 19:4-5.6When I reflected that it leads to hurting myself … MN 19:4-5.7hurting others … MN 19:4-5.8hurting both, it went away. MN 19:4-5.9When I reflected that it blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment, it went away.

MN 19:6.1BJ 10.290Whatever a mendicant frequently thinks about and considers becomes their heart’s inclination. MN 19:6.2If they often think about and consider sensual thoughts, they’ve given up the thought of renunciation to cultivate sensual thought. Their mind inclines to sensual thoughts. MN 19:6.3If they often think about and consider malicious thoughts … their mind inclines to malicious thoughts. MN 19:6.4If they often think about and consider cruel thoughts … their mind inclines to cruel thoughts.

MN 19:7.1Suppose it’s the last month of the rainy season, when the crops grow closely together, and a cowherd must take care of the cattle. MN 19:7.2He’d tap and poke them with his staff on this side and that to keep them in check. MN 19:7.3Why is that? MN 19:7.4For he sees that if they wander into the crops he could be executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned.

MN 19:7.5In the same way, I saw that unskillful qualities have the drawbacks of sordidness and corruption, and that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.

MN 19:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.116Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a thought of renunciation arose. MN 19:8.10And when the mind is stressed, it’s far from immersion. MN 19:8.11So I stilled, settled, unified, and immersed my mind internally. MN 19:8.12Why is that? MN 19:8.13So that my mind would not be stressed.

MN 19:8.2I understood: MN 19:8.3‘This thought of renunciation has arisen in me. MN 19:8.4It doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. It nourishes wisdom, it’s on the side of freedom from anguish, and it leads to extinguishment.’ MN 19:8.5If I were to keep on thinking and considering this all night … MN 19:8.6all day … MN 19:8.7all night and day, I see no danger that would come from that. MN 19:8.8Still, thinking and considering for too long would tire my body. MN 19:8.9And when the body is tired, the mind is stressed.

MN 19:9-10.1BJ 10.292Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a thought of good will arose … MN 19:9-10.10And when the body is tired, the mind is stressed. MN 19:9-10.11And when the mind is stressed, it’s far from immersion. MN 19:9-10.12So I stilled, settled, unified, and immersed my mind internally. MN 19:9-10.13Why is that? MN 19:9-10.14So that my mind would not be stressed.

MN 19:9-10.2a thought of harmlessness arose. MN 19:9-10.3I understood: MN 19:9-10.4‘This thought of harmlessness has arisen in me. MN 19:9-10.5It doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. It nourishes wisdom, it’s on the side of freedom from anguish, and it leads to extinguishment.’ MN 19:9-10.6If I were to keep on thinking and considering this all night … MN 19:9-10.7all day … MN 19:9-10.8all night and day, I see no danger that would come from that. MN 19:9-10.9Still, thinking and considering for too long would tire my body.

MN 20:0.2How to Stop Thinking

MN 20:1.1BJ 10.300PTS-VP-PLI 1.119So I have heard. MN 20:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 20:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 20:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 20:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 20:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 20:2.1“Mendicants, a mendicant committed to the higher mind should focus on five foundations of meditation from time to time. MN 20:2.2What five?

MN 20:3.1Take a mendicant who is focusing on some foundation of meditation that gives rise to bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion. That mendicant should focus on some other foundation of meditation connected with the skillful. MN 20:3.2As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end. MN 20:3.3Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 20:3.4It’s like a deft carpenter or their apprentice who’d knock out or extract a large peg with a finer peg. MN 20:3.5In the same way, a mendicant … should focus on some other foundation of meditation connected with the skillful …

MN 20:4.1BJ 10.302PTS-VP-PLI 1.120Now, suppose that mendicant is focusing on some other foundation of meditation connected with the skillful, but bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion keep coming up. They should examine the drawbacks of those thoughts: MN 20:4.2‘So these thoughts are unskillful, they’re blameworthy, and they result in suffering.’ MN 20:4.3As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end. MN 20:4.4Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 20:4.5Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments. If the corpse of a snake or a dog or a human were hung around their neck, they’d be horrified, repelled, and disgusted. MN 20:4.6In the same way, a mendicant … should examine the drawbacks of those thoughts …

MN 20:5.1Now, suppose that mendicant is examining the drawbacks of those thoughts, but bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion keep coming up. They should try to ignore and forget about them. MN 20:5.2As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end. MN 20:5.3Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 20:5.4Suppose there was a person with good eyesight, and some undesirable sights came into their range of vision. MN 20:5.5They’d just close their eyes or look away. MN 20:5.6In the same way, a mendicant … those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end …

MN 20:6.1BJ 10.304Now, suppose that mendicant is ignoring and forgetting about those thoughts, but bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion keep coming up. They should focus on stopping the formation of thoughts. MN 20:6.10‘Why am I walking slowly? MN 20:6.11Why don’t I stand still?’ MN 20:6.12So they’d stand still. MN 20:6.13They’d think: MN 20:6.14‘Why am I standing still? MN 20:6.15Why don’t I sit down?’ MN 20:6.16So they’d sit down. MN 20:6.17They’d think: MN 20:6.18‘Why am I sitting? MN 20:6.19Why don’t I lie down?’ MN 20:6.2As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end. MN 20:6.20So they’d lie down. MN 20:6.21And so that person would reject successively coarser postures and adopt more subtle ones.

MN 20:6.22In the same way, a mendicant … those thoughts are given up and come to an end … MN 20:6.3Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 20:6.4Suppose there was a person walking quickly. MN 20:6.5They’d think: MN 20:6.6‘Why am I walking so quickly? MN 20:6.7Why don’t I slow down?’ MN 20:6.8So they’d slow down. MN 20:6.9They’d think:

MN 20:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.121Now, suppose that mendicant is focusing on stopping the formation of thoughts, but bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion keep coming up. MN 20:7.2With teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of the mouth, they should squeeze, squash, and torture mind with mind. MN 20:7.3As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end. MN 20:7.4Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 20:7.5It’s like a strong man who grabs a weaker man by the head or throat or shoulder and squeezes, squashes, and tortures them. MN 20:7.6In the same way, a mendicant … MN 20:7.7with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of the mouth, should squeeze, squash, and torture mind with mind. MN 20:7.8As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end. MN 20:7.9Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

MN 20:8.1BJ 10.306PTS-VP-PLI 1.122Now, take the mendicant who is focusing on some foundation of meditation that gives rise to bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion. They focus on some other foundation of meditation connected with the skillful … MN 20:8.10Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 20:8.11This is called a mendicant who is a master of the ways of thought. MN 20:8.12They’ll think what they want to think, and they won’t think what they don’t want to think. MN 20:8.13They’ve cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit have made an end of suffering.”

MN 20:8.14That is what the Buddha said. MN 20:8.15Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 20:8.3They examine the drawbacks of those thoughts … MN 20:8.5They try to ignore and forget about those thoughts … MN 20:8.7They focus on stopping the formation of thoughts … MN 20:8.9With teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of the mouth, they squeeze, squash, and torture mind with mind. When they succeed in each of these things, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end.
  • MN 21:0.1Middle Discourses 21

MN 21:0.2The Simile of the Saw

MN 21:1.1So I have heard. MN 21:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 21:10.1In the same way, a mendicant may be the sweetest of the sweet, the most even-tempered of the even-tempered, the calmest of the calm, so long as they don’t encounter any disagreeable criticism. MN 21:10.2But it’s when they encounter disagreeable criticism that you’ll know whether they’re really sweet, even-tempered, and calm. MN 21:10.3I don’t say that a mendicant is easy to admonish if they make themselves easy to admonish only for the sake of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. MN 21:10.4Why is that? MN 21:10.5Because when they don’t get robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, they’re no longer easy to admonish. MN 21:10.6But when a mendicant is easy to admonish purely because they honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching, then I say that they’re easy to admonish. MN 21:10.7So, mendicants, you should train yourselves: ‘We will be easy to admonish purely because we honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching.’ MN 21:10.8That’s how you should train.

MN 21:11.1BJ 10.318PTS-VP-PLI 1.127Mendicants, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you. MN 21:11.12If that happens, you should train like this: MN 21:11.13‘Our minds will remain unaffected. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate. MN 21:11.14We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’ MN 21:11.15That’s how you should train.

MN 21:11.2Their speech may be timely or untimely, MN 21:11.3true or false, MN 21:11.4gentle or harsh, MN 21:11.5beneficial or harmful, MN 21:11.6from a heart of love or from secret hate. MN 21:11.7When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.

MN 21:12.1BJ 10.320Suppose a person was to come along carrying a spade and basket MN 21:12.10Because this great earth is deep and limitless. MN 21:12.11It’s not easy to make it be without earth. MN 21:12.12That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

MN 21:12.2and say, MN 21:12.3‘I shall make this great earth be without earth!’ MN 21:12.4And they’d dig all over, scatter all over, spit all over, and urinate all over, saying, MN 21:12.5‘Be without earth! Be without earth!’

MN 21:12.6What do you think, mendicants? MN 21:12.7Could that person make this great earth be without earth?”

MN 21:12.8“No, sir. MN 21:12.9Why is that?

MN 21:13.1“In the same way, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you. MN 21:13.12If that happens, you should train like this: MN 21:13.13‘Our minds will remain unaffected. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate. MN 21:13.14We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like the earth to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’ MN 21:13.15That’s how you should train.

MN 21:13.2Their speech may be timely or untimely, MN 21:13.3true or false, MN 21:13.4gentle or harsh, MN 21:13.5beneficial or harmful, MN 21:13.6from a heart of love or from secret hate. MN 21:13.7When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.

MN 21:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.128Suppose a person was to come along with dye such as red lac, turmeric, indigo, or rose madder, MN 21:14.10That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

MN 21:14.2and say, MN 21:14.3‘I shall draw pictures on the sky, making pictures appear there.’

MN 21:14.4What do you think, mendicants? MN 21:14.5Could that person draw pictures on the sky?”

MN 21:14.6“No, sir. MN 21:14.7Why is that? MN 21:14.8Because the sky is formless and invisible. MN 21:14.9It’s not easy to draw pictures there.

MN 21:15.1“In the same way, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you …

MN 21:16.1Suppose a person was to come along carrying a blazing grass torch, MN 21:16.10That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

MN 21:16.2and say, MN 21:16.3‘I shall burn and scorch the river Ganges with this blazing grass torch.’

MN 21:16.4What do you think, mendicants? MN 21:16.5Could that person burn and scorch the river Ganges with a blazing grass torch?”

MN 21:16.6“No, sir. MN 21:16.7Why is that? MN 21:16.8Because the river Ganges is deep and limitless. MN 21:16.9It’s not easy to burn and scorch it with a blazing grass torch.

MN 21:17.1“In the same way, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you …

MN 21:18.1BJ 10.322PTS-VP-PLI 1.129Suppose there was a catskin bag that was rubbed, well-rubbed, very well-rubbed, soft, silky, rid of rustling and crackling. MN 21:18.10It’s not easy to make it rustle or crackle with a stick or stone. MN 21:18.11That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

MN 21:18.2Then a person comes along carrying a stick or a stone, MN 21:18.3and says, MN 21:18.4‘I shall make this soft catskin bag rustle and crackle with this stick or stone.’

MN 21:18.5What do you think, mendicants? MN 21:18.6Could that person make that soft catskin bag rustle and crackle with that stick or stone?”

MN 21:18.7“No, sir. MN 21:18.8Why is that? MN 21:18.9Because that catskin bag is rubbed, well-rubbed, very well-rubbed, soft, silky, rid of rustling and crackling.

MN 21:19.1“In the same way, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you. MN 21:19.12If that happens, you should train like this: MN 21:19.13‘Our minds will remain unaffected. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate. MN 21:19.14We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like a catskin bag to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’ MN 21:19.15That’s how you should train.

MN 21:19.2Their speech may be timely or untimely, MN 21:19.3true or false, MN 21:19.4gentle or harsh, MN 21:19.5beneficial or harmful, MN 21:19.6from a heart of love or from secret hate. MN 21:19.7When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.

MN 21:2.1Now at that time, Venerable Phagguna of the Top-Knot was mixing too closely together with the nuns. MN 21:2.2So much so that MN 21:2.3if any mendicant criticized those nuns in his presence, Phagguna of the Top-Knot got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings. MN 21:2.4And if any mendicant criticized Phagguna of the Top-Knot in their presence, those nuns got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings. MN 21:2.5That’s how much Phagguna of the Top-Knot was mixing too closely together with the nuns.

MN 21:20.1Even if low-down bandits were to sever you limb from limb, anyone who had a malevolent thought on that account would not be following my instructions. MN 21:20.2If that happens, you should train like this: MN 21:20.3‘Our minds will remain unaffected. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate. MN 21:20.4We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’ MN 21:20.5That’s how you should train.

MN 21:21.1If you frequently reflect on this advice—the simile of the saw—MN 21:21.2do you see any criticism, large or small, that you could not endure?”

MN 21:21.3“No, sir.”

MN 21:21.4“So, mendicants, you should frequently reflect on this advice, the simile of the saw. MN 21:21.5This will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”

MN 21:21.6That is what the Buddha said. MN 21:21.7Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 21:3.1BJ 10.310Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was going on.

MN 21:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.123So the Buddha addressed a certain monk, MN 21:4.2“Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Phagguna of the Top-Knot that MN 21:4.3the teacher summons him.”

MN 21:4.4“Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Phagguna of the Top-Knot and said to him, MN 21:4.5“Reverend Phagguna, the teacher summons you.”

MN 21:4.6“Yes, reverend,” Phagguna replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

MN 21:5.1“Is it really true, Phagguna, that you’ve been mixing overly closely together with the nuns? MN 21:5.2So much so that MN 21:5.3if any mendicant criticizes those nuns in your presence, you get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings? MN 21:5.4And if any mendicant criticizes you in those nuns’ presence, they get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings? MN 21:5.5Is that how much you’re mixing overly closely together with the nuns?”

MN 21:5.6“Yes, sir.”

MN 21:5.7“Phagguna, are you not a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness?”

MN 21:5.8“Yes, sir.”

MN 21:6.1“As such, it’s not appropriate for you to mix so closely with the nuns.

MN 21:6.10So if anyone criticizes you in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life. MN 21:6.11If that happens, you should train like this: ‘My mind will be unaffected. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’ MN 21:6.12That’s how you should train.

MN 21:6.13PTS-VP-PLI 1.124So Phagguṇa, even if someone strikes you with fists, stones, rods, and swords, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life. MN 21:6.14If that happens, you should train like this: ‘My mind will be unaffected. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’ MN 21:6.15That’s how you should train.”

MN 21:6.2So if anyone criticizes those nuns in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life. MN 21:6.3If that happens, you should train like this: MN 21:6.4‘My mind will be unaffected. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’ MN 21:6.5That’s how you should train.

MN 21:6.6BJ 10.312So even if someone strikes those nuns with fists, stones, rods, and swords in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life. MN 21:6.7If that happens, you should train like this: MN 21:6.8‘My mind will be unaffected. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’ MN 21:6.9That’s how you should train.

MN 21:7.1Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

MN 21:7.10Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready. MN 21:7.11Then a deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.

MN 21:7.12In the same way, I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants; MN 21:7.13I just had to prompt their mindfulness. MN 21:7.14So, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities. MN 21:7.15In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.

MN 21:7.2“Mendicants, I used to be satisfied with the mendicants. MN 21:7.3Once, I addressed them: MN 21:7.4‘I eat my food in one sitting per day. MN 21:7.5Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably. MN 21:7.6You too should eat your food in one sitting per day. MN 21:7.7Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’ MN 21:7.8I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants; MN 21:7.9I just had to prompt their mindfulness.

MN 21:8.1BJ 10.314PTS-VP-PLI 1.125Suppose that not far from a town or village there was a large grove of sal trees MN 21:8.2that was choked with castor-oil weeds. MN 21:8.3Then along comes a person who wants to help protect and nurture that grove. MN 21:8.4They’d cut down the crooked sal saplings that were robbing the sap, and throw them out. They’d clean up the interior of the grove, MN 21:8.5and properly care for the straight, well-formed sal saplings. MN 21:8.6In this way, in due course, that sal grove would grow, increase, and mature.

MN 21:8.7In the same way, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities. MN 21:8.8In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.

MN 21:9.1Once upon a time, mendicants, right here in Sāvatthī there was a housewife named Vedehikā. MN 21:9.10Why don’t I test my mistress?’

MN 21:9.11So Kāḷī got up during the day. MN 21:9.12Vedehikā said to her, MN 21:9.13‘What the hell, Kāḷī!’

MN 21:9.14‘What is it, madam?’

MN 21:9.15‘You’re getting up in the day—what’s up with you, girl?’

MN 21:9.16‘Nothing, madam.’

MN 21:9.17‘Nothing’s up, you bad girl, but you get up in the day!’ Angry and upset, she scowled.

MN 21:9.18Then Kāḷī thought, MN 21:9.19‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger. MN 21:9.2She had this good reputation: MN 21:9.20It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside. MN 21:9.21Why don’t I test my mistress further?’

MN 21:9.22BJ 10.316So Kāḷī got up later in the day. MN 21:9.23Vedehikā said to her, MN 21:9.24‘What the hell, Kāḷī!’

MN 21:9.25‘What is it, madam?’

MN 21:9.26‘You’re getting up later in the day—what’s up with you, girl?’

MN 21:9.27‘Nothing, madam.’

MN 21:9.28‘Nothing’s up, you bad girl, but you get up later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she blurted out angry words.

MN 21:9.29Then Kāḷī thought, MN 21:9.3‘The housewife Vedehikā is sweet, even-tempered, and calm.’ MN 21:9.30‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger. MN 21:9.31It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside. MN 21:9.32Why don’t I test my mistress further?’

MN 21:9.33PTS-VP-PLI 1.126So Kāḷī got up even later in the day. MN 21:9.34Vedehikā said to her, MN 21:9.35‘What the hell, Kāḷī!’

MN 21:9.36‘What is it, madam?’

MN 21:9.37‘You’re getting up even later in the day—what’s up with you, girl?’

MN 21:9.38‘Nothing, madam.’

MN 21:9.39‘Nothing’s up, you bad girl, but you get up even later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she grabbed a rolling-pin and hit Kāḷī on the head, cracking it open.

MN 21:9.4Now, Vedehikā had a bonded maid named Kāḷī who was skilled, tireless, and well-organized in her work.

MN 21:9.40Then Kāḷī, with blood pouring from her cracked skull, denounced her mistress to the neighbors, MN 21:9.41‘See, ladies, what the sweet one did! MN 21:9.42See what the even-tempered one did! See what the calm one did! MN 21:9.43How on earth can she grab a rolling-pin and hit her only maid on the head, cracking it open, just for getting up late?’

MN 21:9.44Then after some time the housewife Vedehikā got this bad reputation: MN 21:9.45‘The housewife Vedehikā is fierce, ill-tempered, and not calm at all.’

MN 21:9.5Then Kāḷī thought, MN 21:9.6‘My mistress has a good reputation as being MN 21:9.7sweet, even-tempered, and calm. MN 21:9.8But does she actually have anger in her and just not show it? Or does she have no anger? MN 21:9.9Or is it just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside?

  • MN 22:0.1Middle Discourses 22

MN 22:0.2The Simile of the Snake

MN 22:1.1BJ 10.324PTS-VP-PLI 1.130So I have heard. MN 22:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 22:10.1BJ 10.334Take a foolish person who memorizes the teaching—

MN 22:10.10PTS-VP-PLI 1.134Suppose there was a person in need of a snake. And while wandering in search of a snake MN 22:10.11they’d see a big snake, MN 22:10.12and grasp it by the coil or the tail. MN 22:10.13But that snake would twist back and bite them on the hand or the arm or limb, MN 22:10.14resulting in death or deadly pain. MN 22:10.15Why is that? MN 22:10.16Because of their wrong grasp of the snake.

MN 22:10.17In the same way, a foolish person memorizes the teaching … MN 22:10.2statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and classifications. MN 22:10.23and those teachings lead to their lasting harm and suffering. MN 22:10.24Why is that? MN 22:10.25Because of their wrong grasp of the teachings.

MN 22:10.3But they don’t examine the meaning of those teachings with wisdom, MN 22:10.4and so don’t come to a considered acceptance of them. MN 22:10.5They just memorize the teaching for the sake of finding fault and winning debates. MN 22:10.6They don’t realize the goal for which they memorized them. MN 22:10.7Because they’re wrongly grasped, those teachings lead to their lasting harm and suffering. MN 22:10.8Why is that? MN 22:10.9Because of their wrong grasp of the teachings.

MN 22:11.1Now, take a gentleman who memorizes the teaching—

MN 22:11.10BJ 10.336Suppose there was a person in need of a snake. And while wandering in search of a snake MN 22:11.11they’d see a big snake, MN 22:11.12and hold it down carefully with a cleft stick. MN 22:11.13Only then would they correctly grasp it by the neck. MN 22:11.14And even though that snake might wrap its coils around that person’s hand or arm or some other limb, that wouldn’t result in death or deadly pain. MN 22:11.15Why is that? MN 22:11.16Because of their correct grasp of the snake.

MN 22:11.17In the same way, a gentleman memorizes the teaching … MN 22:11.2statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and classifications. MN 22:11.23and those teachings lead to his lasting welfare and happiness. MN 22:11.24Why is that? MN 22:11.25Because of his correct grasp of the teachings.

MN 22:11.3And once he’s memorized them, he examines their meaning with wisdom, MN 22:11.4and comes to a considered acceptance of them. MN 22:11.5He doesn’t memorize the teaching for the sake of finding fault and winning debates. MN 22:11.6He realizes the goal for which he memorized them. MN 22:11.7Because they’re correctly grasped, those teachings lead to his lasting welfare and happiness. MN 22:11.8Why is that? MN 22:11.9Because of his correct grasp of the teachings.

MN 22:12.1So, mendicants, when you understand what I’ve said, you should remember it accordingly. MN 22:12.2But if I’ve said anything that you don’t understand, you should ask me about it, or some competent mendicants.

MN 22:13.1Mendicants, I will teach you how the Dhamma is similar to a raft: it’s for crossing over, not for holding on. MN 22:13.11‘Why don’t I gather grass, sticks, branches, and leaves and make a raft? Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I can safely reach the far shore.’ MN 22:13.12And so they’d do exactly that. MN 22:13.13And when they’d crossed over to the far shore, they’d think, MN 22:13.14‘This raft has been very helpful to me. MN 22:13.15Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I have safely crossed over to the far shore. MN 22:13.16Why don’t I hoist it on my head or pick it up on my shoulder and go wherever I want?’

MN 22:13.17What do you think, mendicants? MN 22:13.18Would that person be doing what should be done with that raft?”

MN 22:13.19“No, sir.”

MN 22:13.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 22:13.20“And what, mendicants, should that person do with the raft? MN 22:13.21When they’d crossed over they should think, MN 22:13.22‘This raft has been very helpful to me. … MN 22:13.24Why don’t I beach it on dry land or set it adrift on the water and go wherever I want?’ MN 22:13.25That’s what that person should do with the raft.

MN 22:13.26In the same way, I have taught how the teaching is similar to a raft: it’s for crossing over, not for holding on.

MN 22:13.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 22:13.4The Buddha said this:

MN 22:13.5BJ 10.338PTS-VP-PLI 1.135“Suppose there was a person traveling along the road. MN 22:13.6They’d see a large deluge, whose near shore was dubious and perilous, while the far shore was a sanctuary free of peril. MN 22:13.7But there was no ferryboat or bridge for crossing over. MN 22:13.8They’d think, MN 22:14.1By understanding the simile of the raft, you will even give up the teachings, let alone what is against the teachings.

MN 22:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.136Mendicants, there are these six grounds for views. MN 22:15.10‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’ MN 22:15.11They also regard this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

MN 22:15.2What six? MN 22:15.3Take an uneducated ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 22:15.4They regard form like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’ MN 22:15.5They also regard feeling … MN 22:15.6perception … MN 22:15.7choices … MN 22:15.8whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’ MN 22:15.9And the same for this ground for views:

MN 22:16.1BJ 10.340But an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 22:16.2They regard form like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 22:16.3They also regard feeling … MN 22:16.4perception … MN 22:16.5choices … MN 22:16.6whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 22:16.7And the same for this ground for views: MN 22:16.8‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’ MN 22:16.9They also regard this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

MN 22:17.1Seeing in this way they’re not anxious about what doesn’t exist.”

MN 22:18.1When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha, MN 22:18.2“Sir, can there be anxiety about what doesn’t exist externally?”

MN 22:18.3“There can, mendicant,” said the Buddha. MN 22:18.4“It’s when someone thinks, MN 22:18.5‘Oh, but it used to be mine, and it is mine no more. MN 22:18.6Oh, but it could be mine, and I will get it no more.’ MN 22:18.7They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. MN 22:18.8That’s how there is anxiety about what doesn’t exist externally.”

MN 22:19.1“But can there be no anxiety about what doesn’t exist externally?”

MN 22:19.2“There can, mendicant,” said the Buddha. MN 22:19.3“It’s when someone doesn’t think, MN 22:19.4‘Oh, but it used to be mine, and it is mine no more. MN 22:19.5Oh, but it could be mine, and I will get it no more.’ MN 22:19.6They don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. MN 22:19.7That’s how there is no anxiety about what doesn’t exist externally.”

MN 22:2.1Now at that time a mendicant called Ariṭtha, who had previously been a vulture trapper, had the following harmful misconception: MN 22:2.2“As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”

MN 22:2.3Several mendicants heard about this.

MN 22:20.1BJ 10.342PTS-VP-PLI 1.137“But can there be anxiety about what doesn’t exist internally?”

MN 22:20.2“There can, mendicant,” said the Buddha. MN 22:20.3“It’s when someone has such a view: MN 22:20.4‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’ MN 22:20.5They hear the Realized One or their disciple teaching Dhamma for the uprooting of all grounds, fixations, obsessions, insistences, and underlying tendencies regarding views; for the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment. MN 22:20.6They think, MN 22:20.7‘Whoa, I’m going to be annihilated and destroyed! I won’t exist any more!’ MN 22:20.8They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. MN 22:20.9That’s how there is anxiety about what doesn’t exist internally.”

MN 22:21.1“But can there be no anxiety about what doesn’t exist internally?”

MN 22:21.2“There can,” said the Buddha. MN 22:21.3“It’s when someone doesn’t have such a view: MN 22:21.4‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’ MN 22:21.5They hear the Realized One or their disciple teaching Dhamma for the uprooting of all grounds, fixations, obsessions, insistences, and underlying tendencies regarding views; for the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment. MN 22:21.6It never occurs to them, MN 22:21.7‘Whoa, I’m going to be annihilated and destroyed! I won’t exist any more!’ MN 22:21.8They don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. MN 22:21.9That’s how there is no anxiety about what doesn’t exist internally.

MN 22:22.1Mendicants, it would make sense to be possessive about something that’s permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, and will last forever and ever. MN 22:22.2But do you see any such possession?”

MN 22:22.3“No, sir.”

MN 22:22.4“Good, mendicants! MN 22:22.5I also can’t see any such possession.

MN 22:23.1BJ 10.344It would make sense to grasp at a doctrine of self that didn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. MN 22:23.2But do you see any such doctrine of self?”

MN 22:23.3“No, sir.”

MN 22:23.4“Good, mendicants! MN 22:23.5I also can’t see any such doctrine of self.

MN 22:24.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.138It would make sense to rely on a view that didn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. MN 22:24.2But do you see any such view to rely on?”

MN 22:24.3“No, sir.”

MN 22:24.4“Good, mendicants! MN 22:24.5I also can’t see any such view to rely on.

MN 22:25.1Mendicants, were a self to exist, would there be the thought, ‘Belonging to my self’?”

MN 22:25.2“Yes, sir.”

MN 22:25.3“Were what belongs to a self to exist, would there be the thought, ‘My self’?”

MN 22:25.4“Yes, sir.”

MN 22:25.5“But self and what belongs to a self are not acknowledged as a genuine fact. This being so, is not the following a totally foolish teaching: MN 22:25.6‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, and will last forever and ever’?”

MN 22:25.8“What else could it be, sir? It’s a totally foolish teaching.”

MN 22:26.1“What do you think, mendicants? MN 22:26.10Is feeling … MN 22:26.11perception … MN 22:26.12choices … MN 22:26.13consciousness permanent or impermanent?”

MN 22:26.14“Impermanent, sir.”

MN 22:26.15“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

MN 22:26.16“Suffering, sir.”

MN 22:26.17“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus: MN 22:26.18‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

MN 22:26.19“No, sir.”

MN 22:26.2Is form permanent or impermanent?”

MN 22:26.3“Impermanent, sir.”

MN 22:26.4“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

MN 22:26.5“Suffering, sir.”

MN 22:26.6“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus: MN 22:26.7‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

MN 22:26.8“No, sir.”

MN 22:26.9BJ 10.346“What do you think, mendicants?

MN 22:27.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.139“So, mendicants, you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 22:27.2You should truly see any kind of feeling … MN 22:27.3perception … MN 22:27.4choices … MN 22:27.5consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

MN 22:28.1Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness. MN 22:29.1Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

MN 22:29.2They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 22:3.1They went up to Ariṭṭha and said to him, MN 22:3.10a lump of meat … MN 22:3.11a grass torch … MN 22:3.12a pit of glowing coals … MN 22:3.13a dream … MN 22:3.14borrowed goods … MN 22:3.15fruit on a tree … MN 22:3.16a butcher’s knife and chopping block … MN 22:3.17a staking sword … MN 22:3.18a snake’s head, the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.”

MN 22:3.19But even though the mendicants pursued, pressed, and grilled him in this way, Ariṭṭha obstinately stuck to his misconception and insisted on stating it. MN 22:3.2“Is it really true, Reverend Ariṭṭha, that you have such a harmful misconception:

MN 22:3.21PTS-VP-PLI 1.131When they weren’t able to dissuade Ariṭṭha from his view, the mendicants went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. MN 22:3.3‘As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them’?”

MN 22:3.4“Absolutely, reverends. As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”

MN 22:3.5BJ 10.326Then, wishing to dissuade Ariṭṭha from his view, the mendicants pursued, pressed, and grilled him, MN 22:3.6“Don’t say that, Ariṭṭha! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that. MN 22:3.7In many ways the Buddha has said that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them. MN 22:3.8The Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. MN 22:3.9With the similes of a skeleton …

MN 22:30.1This is called a mendicant who has lifted up the cross-bar, filled in the trench, and pulled up the pillar; who is unbarred, a noble one with banner and burden put down, detached.

MN 22:31.1BJ 10.348And how has a mendicant lifted the cross-bar? MN 22:31.2It’s when a mendicant has given up ignorance, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future. MN 22:31.3That’s how a mendicant has lifted the cross-bar.

MN 22:32.1And how has a mendicant filled in the trench? MN 22:32.2It’s when a mendicant has given up transmigrating through births in future lives, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future. MN 22:32.3That’s how a mendicant has filled in the trench.

MN 22:33.1And how has a mendicant pulled up the pillar? MN 22:33.2It’s when a mendicant has given up craving, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future. MN 22:33.3That’s how a mendicant has pulled up the pillar.

MN 22:34.1And how is a mendicant unbarred? MN 22:34.2It’s when a mendicant has given up the five lower fetters, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future. MN 22:34.3That’s how a mendicant is unbarred.

MN 22:35.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.140And how is a mendicant a noble one with banner and burden put down, detached? MN 22:35.2It’s when a mendicant has given up the conceit ‘I am’, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future. MN 22:35.3That’s how a mendicant is a noble one with banner and burden put down, detached.

MN 22:36.1BJ 10.350When a mendicant’s mind is freed like this, the gods together with Indra, Brahmā, and Pajāpati, search as they may, will not find MN 22:36.2anything that such a Realized One’s consciousness depends on. MN 22:36.3Why is that? MN 22:36.4Because even in the present life the Realized One is undiscoverable, I say.

MN 22:37.1Though I speak and explain like this, certain ascetics and brahmins misrepresent me with the false, hollow, lying, untruthful claim: MN 22:37.2‘The ascetic Gotama is an exterminator. He advocates the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of an existing being.’ MN 22:37.3I have been falsely misrepresented as being what I am not, and saying what I do not say. MN 22:37.5In the past, as today, what I describe is suffering and the cessation of suffering. MN 22:37.6This being so, if others abuse, attack, harass, and trouble the Realized One, he doesn’t get resentful, bitter, and emotionally exasperated.

MN 22:38.1Or if others honor, respect, revere, or venerate him, he doesn’t get thrilled, elated, and emotionally excited. MN 22:38.2He just thinks, MN 22:38.3‘They do such things for what has already been completely understood.’

MN 22:39.1So, mendicants, if others abuse, attack, harass, and trouble you, don’t make yourselves resentful, bitter, and emotionally exasperated. MN 22:39.2Or if others honor, respect, revere, or venerate you, don’t make yourselves thrilled, elated, and emotionally excited. MN 22:39.3Just think, MN 22:39.4‘They do such things for what has already been completely understood.’

MN 22:40.1BJ 10.352PTS-VP-PLI 1.141So, mendicants, give up what isn't yours. MN 22:40.2Giving it up will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.

MN 22:41.1And what isn’t yours? MN 22:41.10consciousness isn’t yours: give it up. MN 22:41.11Giving it up will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.

MN 22:41.12What do you think, mendicants? MN 22:41.13Suppose a person was to carry off the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in this Jeta’s Grove, or burn them, or do what they want with them. MN 22:41.14Would you think, MN 22:41.15‘This person is carrying us off, burning us, or doing what they want with us?’”

MN 22:41.16“No, sir. MN 22:41.17Why is that? MN 22:41.18Because that’s neither self nor belonging to self.”

MN 22:41.19“In the same way, mendicants, give up what isn't yours. MN 22:41.2Form isn’t yours: give it up. MN 22:41.20Giving it up will be for your lasting welfare and happiness. MN 22:41.21And what isn’t yours? MN 22:41.22Form … MN 22:41.24feeling … MN 22:41.25perception … MN 22:41.26choices … MN 22:41.27consciousness isn’t yours: give it up. MN 22:41.28Giving it up will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.

MN 22:41.3Giving it up will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.

MN 22:41.4Feeling … MN 22:41.6perception … MN 22:41.8choices …

MN 22:42.1Thus the teaching has been well explained by me, made clear, opened, illuminated, and stripped of patchwork. MN 22:42.2In this teaching there are mendicants who are perfected, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. For them, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found. …

MN 22:43.2In this teaching there are mendicants who have given up the five lower fetters. All of them are reborn spontaneously. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. …

MN 22:44.2In this teaching there are mendicants who, having given up three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion, are once-returners. All of them come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. …

MN 22:45.2In this teaching there are mendicants who have ended three fetters. All of them are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening. …

MN 22:46.2In this teaching there are mendicants who are followers of principles, or followers by faith. All of them are bound for awakening.

MN 22:47.1Thus the teaching has been well explained by me, made clear, opened, illuminated, and stripped of patchwork. MN 22:47.2In this teaching there are those who have a degree of faith and love for me. All of them are bound for heaven.”

MN 22:47.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 22:47.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 22:5.1BJ 10.330PTS-VP-PLI 1.132So the Buddha addressed a certain monk, MN 22:5.2“Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Ariṭṭha, formerly a vulture trapper, that MN 22:5.3the teacher summons him.”

MN 22:5.4“Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Ariṭṭha and said to him, MN 22:5.5“Reverend Ariṭṭha, the teacher summons you.”

MN 22:5.6“Yes, reverend,” Ariṭṭha replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

MN 22:5.7“Is it really true, Ariṭṭha, that you have such a harmful misconception: MN 22:5.8‘As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them’?”

MN 22:5.9“Absolutely, sir. As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”

MN 22:6.1“Silly man, who on earth have you ever known me to teach in that way? MN 22:6.10fruit on a tree … MN 22:6.11a butcher’s knife and chopping block … MN 22:6.12a staking sword … MN 22:6.13a snake’s head, I’ve said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. MN 22:6.14But still you misrepresent me by your wrong grasp, harm yourself, and make much bad karma. MN 22:6.15This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”

MN 22:6.2Haven’t I said in many ways that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them? MN 22:6.3I’ve said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. MN 22:6.4With the similes of a skeleton … MN 22:6.5a lump of meat … MN 22:6.6a grass torch … MN 22:6.7a pit of glowing coals … MN 22:6.8a dream … MN 22:6.9borrowed goods …

MN 22:7.1BJ 10.332Then the Buddha said to the mendicants, MN 22:7.2“What do you think, mendicants? MN 22:7.3Has this mendicant Ariṭṭha kindled even a spark of wisdom in this teaching and training?”

MN 22:7.4“How could that be, sir? MN 22:7.5No, sir.” MN 22:7.6When this was said, Ariṭṭha sat silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

MN 22:7.7Knowing this, the Buddha said, MN 22:7.8“Silly man, you will be known by your own harmful misconception. MN 22:7.9I’ll question the mendicants about this.”

MN 22:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.133Then the Buddha said to the mendicants, MN 22:8.10For in many ways I have said that obstructive acts are obstructive …

MN 22:8.13I’ve said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. MN 22:8.14But still this Ariṭṭha misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and makes much bad karma. MN 22:8.15This will be for his lasting harm and suffering. MN 22:8.2“Mendicants, do you understand my teachings as Ariṭṭha does, when he misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and makes much bad karma?”

MN 22:8.3“No, sir. MN 22:8.4For in many ways the Buddha has said that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them. MN 22:8.6The Buddha has said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. MN 22:8.7With the similes of a skeleton … MN 22:8.8a snake’s head, the Buddha has said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.”

MN 22:8.9“Good, good, mendicants! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this. MN 22:9.1Truly, mendicants, it’s not possible to perform sensual acts without sensual pleasures, sensual perceptions, and sensual thoughts.
