MN 28:0.2The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

MN 28:1.1BJ 10.448So I have heard. MN 28:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 28:1.3There Sāriputta addressed the mendicants, MN 28:1.4“Reverends, mendicants!”

MN 28:1.5“Reverend,” they replied. MN 28:1.6Sāriputta said this:

MN 28:10.1BJ 10.452PTS-VP-PLI 1.187While recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful may not become stabilized in them. MN 28:10.2In that case they stir up a sense of urgency: MN 28:10.3‘It’s my loss, my misfortune, MN 28:10.4that while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does not become stabilized in me.’ MN 28:10.5They’re like a daughter-in-law who stirs up a sense of urgency when they see their father-in-law. MN 28:10.8But if, while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does become stabilized in them, they’re happy with that. MN 28:10.9At this point, much has been done by that mendicant.

MN 28:11.1And what is the water element? MN 28:11.2The water element may be interior or exterior. MN 28:11.3And what is the interior water element? MN 28:11.4Anything that’s water, watery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes: MN 28:11.5bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine, or anything else that’s water, watery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 28:11.6This is called the interior water element. MN 28:11.7The interior water element and the exterior water element are just the water element. MN 28:11.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 28:11.9When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the water element, detaching the mind from the water element.

MN 28:12.1BJ 10.454PTS-VP-PLI 1.188There comes a time when the exterior water element flares up. MN 28:12.2It sweeps away villages, towns, cities, countries, and regions. MN 28:12.3There comes a time when the water in the ocean sinks down a hundred leagues, or two, three, four, five, six, up to seven hundred leagues. MN 28:12.4There comes a time when the water in the ocean stands just seven palm trees deep, or six, five, four, three, two, or even just one palm tree deep. MN 28:12.5There comes a time when the water in the ocean stands just seven fathoms deep, or six, five, four, three, two, or even just one fathom deep. MN 28:12.6There comes a time when the water in the ocean stands just half a fathom deep, or waist deep, or knee deep, or even just ankle deep. MN 28:12.7There comes a time when there isn’t enough water in the ocean even to wet the tip of your finger. MN 28:12.8So for all its great age, the water element will be revealed as impermanent, liable to end, vanish, and perish. MN 28:13.1What then of this ephemeral body appropriated by craving? Rather than take it to be ‘I’ or ‘mine’ or ‘I am’, they still just consider it to be none of these things. … MN 28:14.1If, while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does become stabilized in them, they’re happy with that. MN 28:15.1At this point, much has been done by that mendicant.

MN 28:16.1And what is the fire element? MN 28:16.2The fire element may be interior or exterior. MN 28:16.3And what is the interior fire element? MN 28:16.4Anything that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes: MN 28:16.5that which warms, that which ages, that which heats you up when feverish, that which properly digests food and drink, or anything else that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 28:16.6This is called the interior fire element. MN 28:16.7The interior fire element and the exterior fire element are just the fire element. MN 28:16.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 28:16.9When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the fire element, detaching the mind from the fire element.

MN 28:17.1BJ 10.456There comes a time when the exterior fire element flares up. MN 28:17.2It burns up villages, towns, cities, countries, and regions until MN 28:17.3it reaches a green field, a roadside, a cliff’s edge, a body of water, or cleared parkland, where it’s extinguished for lack of fuel. MN 28:17.4There comes a time when they go looking for a fire, taking just chicken feathers and strips of sinew as kindling. MN 28:17.5So for all its great age, the fire element will be revealed as impermanent, liable to end, vanish, and perish. MN 28:17.6What then of this ephemeral body appropriated by craving? Rather than take it to be ‘I’ or ‘mine’ or ‘I am’, they still just consider it to be none of these things. …

MN 28:18-20.1If, while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does become stabilized in them, they’re happy with that. MN 28:18-20.2At this point, much has been done by that mendicant.

MN 28:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.185“The footprints of all creatures that walk can fit inside an elephant’s footprint, so an elephant’s footprint is said to be the biggest of them all. MN 28:2.2In the same way, all skillful qualities can be included in the four noble truths. MN 28:2.3What four? MN 28:2.4The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

MN 28:21.1And what is the air element? MN 28:21.2The air element may be interior or exterior. MN 28:21.3And what is the interior air element? MN 28:21.4Anything that’s wind, windy, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes: MN 28:21.5winds that go up or down, winds in the belly or the bowels, winds that flow through the limbs, in-breaths and out-breaths, or anything else that’s wind, windy, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 28:21.6This is called the interior air element. MN 28:21.7The interior air element and the exterior air element are just the air element. MN 28:21.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 28:21.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the air element, detaching the mind from the air element.

MN 28:22.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.189There comes a time when the exterior air element flares up. MN 28:22.2It sweeps away villages, towns, cities, countries, and regions. MN 28:22.3There comes a time, in the last month of summer, when they look for wind by using a palm-leaf or fan, and even the grasses in the drip-fringe of a thatch roof don’t stir. MN 28:22.4So for all its great age, the air element will be revealed as impermanent, liable to end, vanish, and perish. MN 28:22.5What then of this ephemeral body appropriated by craving? Rather than take it to be ‘I’ or ‘mine’ or ‘I am’, they still just consider it to be none of these things. …

MN 28:23.1If others abuse, attack, harass, and trouble that mendicant, they understand: MN 28:23.2‘This painful feeling born of ear contact has arisen in me. MN 28:23.3That’s dependent, not independent. MN 28:23.4Dependent on what? MN 28:23.5Dependent on contact. MN 28:23.6They see that contact, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent. MN 28:23.7Based on that element alone, their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided.

MN 28:24.1BJ 10.458Others might treat that mendicant with disliking, loathing, and detestation, striking them with fists, stones, sticks, and swords. MN 28:24.2They understand: ‘This body is such that fists, stones, sticks, and swords strike it. MN 28:24.3But the Buddha has said in the Simile of the Saw: “Even if low-down bandits were to sever you limb from limb, anyone who had a thought of hate on that account would not be following my instructions.” MN 28:24.4My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness established and lucid, my body tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind immersed in samādhi. MN 28:24.5Gladly now, let fists, stones, sticks, and swords strike this body! For this is how the instructions of the Buddhas are followed.’

MN 28:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.190While recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful may not become stabilized in them. MN 28:25.10But if, while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does become stabilized in them, they’re happy with that. MN 28:25.11At this point, much has been done by that mendicant.

MN 28:25.2In that case they stir up a sense of urgency: MN 28:25.3‘It’s my loss, my misfortune, MN 28:25.4that while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does not become stabilized in me.’ MN 28:25.5They’re like a daughter-in-law who stirs up a sense of urgency when they see their father-in-law.

MN 28:26.1BJ 10.460When a space is enclosed by sticks, creepers, grass, and mud it becomes known as a ‘building’. MN 28:26.2In the same way, when a space is enclosed by bones, sinews, flesh, and skin it becomes known as a ‘form’.

MN 28:27.1Reverends, though the eye is intact internally, so long as exterior sights don’t come into range and there’s no corresponding engagement, there’s no manifestation of the corresponding type of consciousness. MN 28:27.2Though the eye is intact internally and exterior sights come into range, so long as there’s no corresponding engagement, there’s no manifestation of the corresponding type of consciousness. MN 28:27.3But when the eye is intact internally and exterior sights come into range and there is corresponding engagement, there is the manifestation of the corresponding type of consciousness.

MN 28:28.1The form produced in this way is included in the grasping aggregate of form. The feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness produced in this way are each included in the corresponding grasping aggregate.

MN 28:28.10At this point, much has been done by that mendicant.

MN 28:28.2PTS-VP-PLI 1.191They understand: MN 28:28.3‘So this is how there comes to be inclusion, gathering together, and joining together into these five grasping aggregates. MN 28:28.4But the Buddha has said: MN 28:28.5“One who sees dependent origination sees the teaching. MN 28:28.6One who sees the teaching sees dependent origination.” MN 28:28.7And these five grasping aggregates are indeed dependently originated. MN 28:28.8The desire, adherence, attraction, and attachment for these five grasping aggregates is the origin of suffering. MN 28:28.9Giving up and getting rid of desire and greed for these five grasping aggregates is the cessation of suffering.’

MN 28:29-30.1BJ 10.462Though the ear …

MN 28:3.1And what is the noble truth of suffering? MN 28:3.2Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering. MN 28:3.3And what are the five grasping aggregates? MN 28:3.4They are as follows: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

MN 28:31-32.1nose … MN 28:33-34.1tongue … MN 28:35-36.1body … MN 28:37.1mind is intact internally, so long as exterior thoughts don’t come into range and there’s no corresponding engagement, there’s no manifestation of the corresponding type of consciousness.

MN 28:38.1Though the mind is intact internally and exterior thoughts come into range, so long as there’s no corresponding engagement, there’s no manifestation of the corresponding type of consciousness. MN 28:38.10The desire, adherence, attraction, and attachment for these five grasping aggregates is the origin of suffering. MN 28:38.11Giving up and getting rid of desire and greed for these five grasping aggregates is the cessation of suffering.’ MN 28:38.12At this point, much has been done by that mendicant.”

MN 28:38.13That’s what Venerable Sāriputta said. MN 28:38.14Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Sāriputta said.

MN 28:38.2But when the mind is intact internally and exterior thoughts come into range and there is corresponding engagement, there is the manifestation of the corresponding type of consciousness.

MN 28:38.3The form produced in this way is included in the grasping aggregate of form. The feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness produced in this way are each included in the corresponding grasping aggregate. MN 28:38.4They understand: MN 28:38.5‘So this is how there comes to be inclusion, gathering together, and joining together into these five grasping aggregates.

MN 28:38.6But the Buddha has also said: MN 28:38.7“One who sees dependent origination sees the teaching. MN 28:38.8One who sees the teaching sees dependent origination.” MN 28:38.9And these five grasping aggregates are indeed dependently originated.

MN 28:4.1And what is the grasping aggregate of form? MN 28:4.2The four primary elements, and form derived from the four primary elements.

MN 28:5.1And what are the four primary elements? MN 28:5.2The elements of earth, water, fire, and air.

MN 28:6.1BJ 10.450And what is the earth element? MN 28:6.2The earth element may be interior or exterior. MN 28:6.3And what is the interior earth element? MN 28:6.4Anything hard, solid, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes: MN 28:6.5head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, or anything else hard, solid, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 28:6.6This is called the interior earth element. MN 28:6.7The interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element. MN 28:6.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 28:6.9When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.

MN 28:7.1There comes a time when the exterior water element flares up. MN 28:7.2At that time the exterior earth element vanishes. MN 28:7.3So for all its great age, the earth element will be revealed as impermanent, liable to end, vanish, and perish. MN 28:7.4What then of this ephemeral body appropriated by craving? Rather than take it to be ‘I’ or ‘mine’ or ‘I am’, they still just consider it to be none of these things.

MN 28:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.186If others abuse, attack, harass, and trouble that mendicant, they understand: MN 28:8.2‘This painful feeling born of ear contact has arisen in me. MN 28:8.3That’s dependent, not independent. MN 28:8.4Dependent on what? MN 28:8.5Dependent on contact.’ MN 28:8.6They see that contact, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent. MN 28:8.7Based on that element alone, their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided.

MN 28:9.1Others might treat that mendicant with disliking, loathing, and detestation, MN 28:9.2striking them with fists, stones, sticks, and swords. MN 28:9.3They understand: MN 28:9.4‘This body is such that fists, stones, sticks, and swords strike it. MN 28:9.5But the Buddha has said in the Simile of the Saw:

MN 28:9.6“Even if low-down bandits were to sever you limb from limb, anyone who had a malevolent thought on that account would not be following my instructions.” MN 28:9.7My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness established and lucid, my body tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind immersed in samādhi. MN 28:9.8Gladly now, let fists, stones, sticks, and swords strike this body! For this is how the instructions of the Buddhas are followed.’

  • MN 29:0.1Middle Discourses 29

MN 29:0.2The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

MN 29:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.192So I have heard. MN 29:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left. MN 29:1.3There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:

MN 29:2.1BJ 10.464“Mendicants, take the case of a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking, MN 29:2.10If a person with good eyesight saw him they’d say, MN 29:2.11‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are. MN 29:2.12That’s why he passed them over, cut off the branches and leaves, and departed imagining they were heartwood. MN 29:2.13Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …

MN 29:2.2‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. MN 29:2.21This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the branches and leaves of the spiritual life MN 29:2.22and stopped short with that.

MN 29:2.3Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’ MN 29:2.4When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. MN 29:2.5They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for. MN 29:2.6And they glorify themselves and put others down because of that: MN 29:2.7‘I’m the one with possessions, honor, and popularity. These other mendicants are obscure and insignificant.’ MN 29:2.8And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity. And being negligent they live in suffering.

MN 29:2.9BJ 10.466Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, bark, and shoots, he’d cut off the branches and leaves and depart imagining they were heartwood.

MN 29:3.1Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness … MN 29:3.10And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that: MN 29:3.11‘I’m the one who is ethical, of good character. These other mendicants are unethical, of bad character.’ MN 29:3.12And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding their accomplishment in ethics. And being negligent they live in suffering.

MN 29:3.13Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, and bark, he’d cut off the shoots and depart imagining they were heartwood. MN 29:3.14If a person with good eyesight saw him they’d say, MN 29:3.15‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are. MN 29:3.16That’s why he passed them over, cut off the shoots, and departed imagining they were heartwood. MN 29:3.17Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …

MN 29:3.4When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. MN 29:3.5They’re not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for. MN 29:3.6They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that. MN 29:3.7Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity. MN 29:3.8Being diligent, they become accomplished in ethics. MN 29:3.9They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for. MN 29:4.13PTS-VP-PLI 1.194This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the shoots of the spiritual life MN 29:4.14and stopped short with that.

MN 29:4.15BJ 10.468Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness … MN 29:4.18When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. … MN 29:4.25Being diligent, they achieve immersion. MN 29:4.26They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for. MN 29:4.27And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that: MN 29:4.28‘I’m the one with immersion and unified mind. These other mendicants lack immersion, they have straying minds.’ MN 29:4.29And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in immersion. And being negligent they live in suffering.

MN 29:4.30Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood and softwood, he’d cut off the bark and depart imagining it was heartwood. MN 29:4.31If a person with good eyesight saw him they’d say: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are. MN 29:4.32That’s why he passed them over, cut off the bark, and departed imagining it was heartwood. MN 29:4.33Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …

MN 29:4.48This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the bark of the spiritual life MN 29:4.49and stopped short with that.

MN 29:5.1Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness … MN 29:5.14Being diligent, they achieve knowledge and vision. MN 29:5.15They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for. MN 29:5.16And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that, MN 29:5.17‘I’m the one who meditates knowing and seeing. MN 29:5.18These other mendicants meditate without knowing and seeing.’ MN 29:5.19And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that knowledge and vision. And being negligent they live in suffering.

MN 29:5.20BJ 10.472Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, he’d cut out the softwood and depart imagining it was heartwood. MN 29:5.21If a person with good eyesight saw him they’d say, MN 29:5.22‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are. MN 29:5.23That’s why he passed them over, cut out the softwood, and departed imagining it was heartwood. MN 29:5.24Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …

MN 29:5.4When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. … MN 29:5.42This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the softwood of the spiritual life MN 29:5.43and stopped short with that.

MN 29:6.1BJ 10.474Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking, MN 29:6.10Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in ethics. Being diligent, they achieve immersion. MN 29:6.11They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for. MN 29:6.12They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that. MN 29:6.13Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in immersion. Being diligent, they achieve knowledge and vision. MN 29:6.14They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for. MN 29:6.15They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that. MN 29:6.16Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that knowledge and vision. Being diligent, they achieve permanent liberation. MN 29:6.17And it’s impossible for that mendicant to fall away from that irreversible liberation.

MN 29:6.18PTS-VP-PLI 1.197Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. He’d cut out just the heartwood and depart knowing it was heartwood. MN 29:6.19If a person with good eyesight saw him they’d say, MN 29:6.2‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. MN 29:6.20‘This gentleman knows what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, and branches and leaves are. MN 29:6.21That’s why he cut out just the heartwood and departed knowing it was heartwood. MN 29:6.22Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he will succeed.’ …

MN 29:6.3Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’ MN 29:6.39It’s impossible for that mendicant to fall away from that irreversible liberation.

MN 29:6.4When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. MN 29:6.5They’re not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for. MN 29:6.6They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that. MN 29:6.7Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity. Being diligent, they become accomplished in ethics. MN 29:6.8They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for. MN 29:6.9They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.

MN 29:7.1And so, mendicants, this spiritual life is not lived for the sake of possessions, honor, and popularity, or for accomplishment in ethics, or for accomplishment in immersion, or for knowledge and vision. MN 29:7.2Rather, the goal, heartwood, and final end of the spiritual life is the unshakable freedom of heart.”

MN 29:7.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 29:7.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 30:0.2The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

MN 30:1.1BJ 10.478PTS-VP-PLI 1.198So I have heard. MN 30:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 30:10.1BJ 10.486Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness … MN 30:10.16They become lazy and slack regarding their accomplishment in immersion, not generating enthusiasm or trying to realize those things that are better and finer. … MN 30:10.19They’re like the person who mistakes bark for heartwood, I say.

MN 30:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.202Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness … MN 30:11.20They become lazy and slack regarding their knowledge and vision, not generating enthusiasm or trying to realize those things that are better and finer. … MN 30:11.23They’re like the person who mistakes softwood for heartwood, I say.

MN 30:12.1BJ 10.488PTS-VP-PLI 1.203Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking: MN 30:12.10They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that. MN 30:12.11They don’t become lazy and slack regarding their accomplishment in ethics, but generate enthusiasm and try to realize those things that are better and finer. MN 30:12.12They become accomplished in immersion. MN 30:12.13They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for. MN 30:12.14They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that. MN 30:12.15They don’t become lazy and slack regarding their accomplishment in immersion, but generate enthusiasm and try to realize those things that are better and finer. MN 30:12.16They achieve knowledge and vision. MN 30:12.17They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for. MN 30:12.18They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that. MN 30:12.19They don’t become lazy and slack regarding their knowledge and vision, but generate enthusiasm and try to realize those things that are better and finer.

MN 30:12.2‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

MN 30:12.20And what are those things that are better and finer than knowledge and vision?

MN 30:12.3Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’ MN 30:12.4When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. MN 30:12.5They’re not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for. MN 30:12.6They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that. MN 30:12.7They don’t become lazy and slack regarding their possessions, honor, and popularity, but generate enthusiasm and try to realize those things that are better and finer. MN 30:12.8They become accomplished in ethics. MN 30:12.9They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.

MN 30:13.1Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 30:13.2This is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.

MN 30:14.1BJ 10.490Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 30:14.2This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.

MN 30:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.204Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 30:15.2This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.

MN 30:16.1Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 30:16.2This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.

MN 30:17.1Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space. MN 30:17.2This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.

MN 30:18.1Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. MN 30:18.2This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.

MN 30:19.1Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. MN 30:19.2This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.

MN 30:2.1Then the brahmin Piṅgalakoccha went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

MN 30:2.10“Yes sir,” Piṅgalakoccha replied. MN 30:2.11The Buddha said this:

MN 30:2.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

MN 30:2.3“Master Gotama, there are those ascetics and brahmins who lead an order and a community, and teach a community. They’re well-known and famous religious founders, regarded as holy by many people. MN 30:2.4Namely: Pūraṇa Kassapa, Makkhali Gosāla, Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, Pakudha Kaccāyana, and Ajita Kesakambala. MN 30:2.5According to their own claims, did all of them have direct knowledge, or none of them, or only some?”

MN 30:2.6“Enough, brahmin, let this be: MN 30:2.7‘According to their own claims, did all of them have direct knowledge, or none of them, or only some?’ MN 30:2.8I will teach you the Dhamma. MN 30:2.9Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 30:20.1Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 30:20.2This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.

MN 30:21.1BJ 10.492Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end. MN 30:21.2This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision. MN 30:21.3These are the things that are better and finer than knowledge and vision.

MN 30:22.1Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. He’d cut out just the heartwood and depart knowing it was heartwood. MN 30:22.2Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he will succeed. MN 30:22.3That’s what this person is like, I say.

MN 30:23.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.205And so, brahmin, this spiritual life is not lived for the sake of possessions, honor, and popularity, or for accomplishment in ethics, or for accomplishment in immersion, or for knowledge and vision. MN 30:23.2Rather, the goal, heartwood, and final end of the spiritual life is the unshakable freedom of heart.”

MN 30:24.1When he had spoken, the brahmin Piṅgalakoccha said to the Buddha, MN 30:24.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! … MN 30:24.3From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

MN 30:3.1“Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, bark, and shoots, he’d cut off the branches and leaves and depart imagining they were heartwood. MN 30:3.2If a person with good eyesight saw him they’d say: MN 30:3.3‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are. MN 30:3.4That’s why he passed them over, cut off the branches and leaves, and departed imagining they were heartwood. MN 30:3.5Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’

MN 30:4.1BJ 10.480PTS-VP-PLI 1.199Suppose there was another person in need of heartwood … he’d cut off the shoots and depart imagining they were heartwood …

MN 30:5.1Suppose there was another person in need of heartwood … he’d cut off the bark and depart imagining it was heartwood …

MN 30:6.1Suppose there was another person in need of heartwood … he’d cut out the softwood and depart imagining it was heartwood …

MN 30:7.1BJ 10.482PTS-VP-PLI 1.200Suppose there was another person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. He’d cut out just the heartwood and depart knowing it was heartwood. MN 30:7.2If a person with good eyesight saw him they’d say: MN 30:7.3‘This gentleman knows what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are. MN 30:7.4That’s why he cut out just the heartwood and departed knowing it was heartwood. MN 30:7.5Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he will succeed.’

MN 30:8.1In the same way, take a certain person who goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking: MN 30:8.11They’re like the person who mistakes branches and leaves for heartwood, I say.

MN 30:8.2‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. MN 30:8.3Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’ MN 30:8.4When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. MN 30:8.5They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for. These other mendicants are obscure and insignificant.’ MN 30:8.8They become lazy and slack regarding their possessions, honor, and popularity, not generating enthusiasm or trying to realize those things that are better and finer. …

MN 30:9.1BJ 10.484PTS-VP-PLI 1.201Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness … MN 30:9.12They become lazy and slack regarding their accomplishment in ethics, not generating enthusiasm or trying to realize those things that are better and finer. … MN 30:9.15They’re like the person who mistakes shoots for heartwood, I say.
