MN 31:0.2The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

MN 31:1.1BJ 10.494So I have heard. MN 31:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying at Nādika in the brick house.

MN 31:10.1“Good, good, Anuruddha and friends! MN 31:10.2But as you live diligently like this, have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a meditation at ease?”

MN 31:10.3“How could we not, sir? MN 31:10.4Whenever we want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, we enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 31:10.5This is a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a meditation at ease, that we have achieved while living diligent, keen, and resolute.”

MN 31:11-13.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.208“Good, good! MN 31:11-13.2But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

MN 31:11-13.3“How could we not, sir? MN 31:11-13.4Whenever we want, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, we enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 31:11-13.5This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

MN 31:14.1BJ 10.500“Good, good! MN 31:14.2But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

MN 31:14.3“How could we not, sir? MN 31:14.4Whenever we want, with the fading away of rapture, we enter and remain in the third absorption, where we meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 31:14.5This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

MN 31:15.1“Good, good! MN 31:15.2But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

MN 31:15.3“How could we not, sir? MN 31:15.4Whenever we want, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, we enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 31:15.5This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

MN 31:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.209“Good, good! MN 31:16.2But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

MN 31:16.3“How could we not, sir? MN 31:16.4Whenever we want, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, we enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space. MN 31:16.5This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

MN 31:17.1BJ 10.502“Good, good! MN 31:17.2But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

MN 31:17.3“How could we not, sir? MN 31:17.4Whenever we want, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, we enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness. … MN 31:17.5going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, we enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness. … MN 31:17.6going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, we enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 31:17.7This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

MN 31:18.1“Good, good! MN 31:18.2But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

MN 31:18.3“How could we not, sir? MN 31:18.4Whenever we want, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, we enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, our defilements have come to an end. MN 31:18.5This is another superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a meditation at ease, that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation. MN 31:18.6And we don’t see any better or finer way of meditating at ease than this.”

MN 31:18.7“Good, good! MN 31:18.8There is no better or finer way of meditating at ease than this.”

MN 31:19.1BJ 10.504PTS-VP-PLI 1.210Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.

MN 31:2.1Now at that time the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila were staying in the sal forest park at Gosiṅga.

MN 31:20.1The venerables then accompanied the Buddha for a little way before turning back. Nandiya and Kimbila said to Anuruddha, MN 31:20.2“Did we ever tell you that we had MN 31:20.3gained such and such meditations and attainments, up to the ending of defilements, as you revealed to the Buddha?”

MN 31:20.4“The venerables did not tell me that they had MN 31:20.5gained such meditations and attainments. But I discovered it by comprehending your minds, MN 31:20.7and deities also told me. MN 31:20.9I answered when the Buddha directly asked about it.”

MN 31:21.1Then the native spirit Dīgha Parajana went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him, MN 31:21.10the Gods of the Thirty-Three … MN 31:21.11the Gods of Yama … MN 31:21.12the Joyful Gods … MN 31:21.13the Gods Who Love to Create … MN 31:21.14the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others … MN 31:21.15the Gods of Brahmā’s Host raised the cry, MN 31:21.16“The Vajjis are lucky! The Vajjian people are so very lucky MN 31:21.17that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha stays there, as well as these three gentlemen, MN 31:21.18the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila.”

MN 31:21.19And so at that moment, in that instant, those venerables were known as far as the Brahmā realm.

MN 31:21.2“The Vajjis are lucky! The Vajjian people are so very lucky MN 31:21.3that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha stays there, as well as these three gentlemen, MN 31:21.4the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila.”

MN 31:21.5Hearing the cry of Dīgha Parajana, the Earth Gods raised the cry …

MN 31:21.9Hearing the cry of the Earth Gods, the Gods of the Four Great Kings …

MN 31:22.1BJ 10.506PTS-VP-PLI 1.211“That’s so true, Dīgha! That’s so true! MN 31:22.10all the merchants … MN 31:22.11all the workers were to recollect those venerables with confident heart, that would be for all those workers’ lasting welfare and happiness.

MN 31:22.12If the whole world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—were to recollect those venerables with confident heart, that would be for the whole world’s lasting welfare and happiness.

MN 31:22.13See, Dīgha, how those three gentlemen are practicing for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!”

MN 31:22.14That is what the Buddha said. MN 31:22.15Satisfied, the native spirit Dīgha Parajana was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 31:22.2If the family from which those three gentlemen went forth from the lay life to homelessness were to recollect those venerables with confident heart, that would be for that family’s lasting welfare and happiness. MN 31:22.3If the family circle … MN 31:22.4village … MN 31:22.5town … MN 31:22.6city … MN 31:22.7country … MN 31:22.8all the aristocrats … MN 31:22.9all the brahmins …

MN 31:3.1Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to that park. MN 31:3.2The park keeper saw the Buddha coming off in the distance MN 31:3.3and said to him, MN 31:3.4“Don’t come into this park, ascetic. MN 31:3.5There are three gentlemen who love themselves staying here. MN 31:3.6Don’t disturb them.”

MN 31:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.206Anuruddha heard the park keeper conversing with the Buddha, MN 31:4.2and said to him, MN 31:4.3“Don’t keep the Buddha out, good park keeper! MN 31:4.4Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived.” MN 31:4.5Then Anuruddha went to Nandiya and Kimbila, and said to them, MN 31:4.6“Come forth, venerables, come forth! Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived!”

MN 31:5.1Then Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila came out to greet the Buddha. MN 31:5.2One received his bowl and robe, one spread out a seat, and one set out water for washing his feet. MN 31:5.3He sat on the seat spread out MN 31:5.4and washed his feet. MN 31:5.5Those venerables bowed and sat down to one side.

MN 31:5.6The Buddha said to Anuruddha, MN 31:5.7BJ 10.496“I hope you’re keeping well, Anuruddha and friends; I hope you’re alright. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”

MN 31:5.8“Weʼre alright, Blessed One, weʼre getting by. And we have no trouble getting almsfood.”

MN 31:6.1“I hope you’re living in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes?”

MN 31:6.2“Indeed, sir, we live in harmony like this.”

MN 31:6.3“But how do you live this way?”

MN 31:7.1“In this case, sir, I think, MN 31:7.10Though we’re different in body, sir, we’re one in mind, it seems to me.”

MN 31:7.11PTS-VP-PLI 1.207And the venerables Nandiya and Kimbila spoke likewise, and they added: MN 31:7.2‘I’m fortunate, so very fortunate, MN 31:7.23“That’s how we live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.”

MN 31:7.3to live together with spiritual companions such as these.’ MN 31:7.4I consistently treat these venerables with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private. MN 31:7.7I think, MN 31:7.8‘Why don’t I set aside my own ideas and just go along with these venerables’ ideas?’ MN 31:7.9And that’s what I do.

MN 31:8.1BJ 10.498“Good, good, Anuruddha and friends! MN 31:8.2But I hope you’re living diligently, keen, and resolute?”

MN 31:9.1“Indeed, sir, we live diligently.”

MN 31:9.2“But how do you live this way?”

MN 31:9.3“In this case, sir, whoever returns first from almsround prepares the seats, and puts out the drinking water and the rubbish bin. MN 31:9.4If there’s anything left over, whoever returns last eats it if they like. Otherwise they throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures. MN 31:9.5Then they put away the seats, drinking water, and rubbish bin, and sweep the refectory. MN 31:9.6If someone sees that the pot of water for washing, drinking, or the toilet is empty they set it up. MN 31:9.7If he can’t do it, he summons another with a wave of the hand, and they set it up by lifting it with their hands. But we don’t break into speech for that reason. MN 31:9.8And every five days we sit together for the whole night and discuss the teachings. MN 31:9.9That’s how we live diligently, keen, and resolute.”

  • MN 32:0.1Middle Discourses 32

MN 32:0.2The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

MN 32:1.1BJ 10.508PTS-VP-PLI 1.212So I have heard. MN 32:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the sal forest park at Gosiṅga, together with several well-known senior disciples, such as MN 32:1.3the venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, Mahākassapa, Anuruddha, Revata, Ānanda, and others.

MN 32:10.1BJ 10.516PTS-VP-PLI 1.216Then Sāriputta said to those venerables, MN 32:10.2“Each of us has spoken from the heart. MN 32:10.3Come, reverends, let’s go to the Buddha, and inform him about this. MN 32:10.4As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”

MN 32:10.5“Yes, reverend,” they replied. MN 32:10.6Then those venerables went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. Venerable Sāriputta told the Buddha of how the mendicants had come to see him, and how he had asked Ānanda: MN 32:11.11That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”

MN 32:11.12“Good, good, Sāriputta! MN 32:11.13Ānanda answered in the right way for him. MN 32:11.14For Ānanda is very learned …” MN 32:11.6“‘Ānanda, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air. MN 32:11.7What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?’ MN 32:11.8When I had spoken, Ānanda said to me: MN 32:11.9‘Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who is very learned …

MN 32:12.1BJ 10.518“Next I asked Revata the same question. MN 32:12.10Revata answered in the right way for him. MN 32:12.11For Revata enjoys retreat …”

MN 32:12.6He said: MN 32:12.7‘It’s a mendicant who enjoys retreat … MN 32:12.8That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”

MN 32:12.9“Good, good, Sāriputta!

MN 32:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.217“Next I asked Anuruddha the same question. MN 32:13.4He said: MN 32:13.5‘It’s a mendicant who surveys the entire galaxy with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human … MN 32:13.7That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”

MN 32:13.8“Good, good, Sāriputta! Anuruddha answered in the right way for him. MN 32:13.9For Anuruddha surveys the entire galaxy with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human.”

MN 32:14.1BJ 10.520PTS-VP-PLI 1.218“Next I asked Mahākassapa the same question. MN 32:14.10For Kassapa lives in the wilderness … and is accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom; and he praises these things.”

MN 32:14.5He said: MN 32:14.6‘It’s a mendicant who lives in the wilderness … and is accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom; and they praise these things. MN 32:14.7That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”

MN 32:14.8“Good, good, Sāriputta! MN 32:14.9Kassapa answered in the right way for him.

MN 32:15.1BJ 10.522“Next I asked Mahāmoggallāna the same question. MN 32:15.5He said: MN 32:15.6‘It’s when two mendicants engage in discussion about the teaching … MN 32:15.7That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”

MN 32:15.8“Good, good, Sāriputta! Moggallāna answered in the right way for him. MN 32:15.9For Moggallāna is a Dhamma speaker.”

MN 32:16.1BJ 10.524PTS-VP-PLI 1.219When he had spoken, Moggallāna said to the Buddha, MN 32:16.2“Next, I asked Sāriputta: MN 32:16.20That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”

MN 32:16.21“Good, good, Moggallāna! MN 32:16.22Sāriputta answered in the right way for him. MN 32:16.23For Sāriputta masters his mind and is not mastered by it …” MN 32:16.3‘Each of us has spoken from our heart. MN 32:16.4And now we ask you: MN 32:16.5Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air. MN 32:16.6What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?’ MN 32:16.7When I had spoken, Sāriputta said to me: MN 32:16.8‘Reverend Moggallāna, it’s when a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it …

MN 32:17.1When he had spoken, Sāriputta asked the Buddha, MN 32:17.2“Sir, who has spoken well?”

MN 32:17.3“You’ve all spoken well in your own way. MN 32:17.4However, listen to me also as to what kind of mendicant would beautify this sal forest park at Gosiṅga. MN 32:17.5It’s a mendicant who, after the meal, returns from almsround, sits down cross-legged with their body straight, and establishes mindfulness right there, thinking: MN 32:17.6‘I will not break this sitting posture until my mind is freed from the defilements by not grasping!’ MN 32:17.7That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”

MN 32:17.8That is what the Buddha said. MN 32:17.9Satisfied, those venerables were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 32:2.1Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa, and said, MN 32:2.2“Come, Reverend Kassapa, let’s go to Venerable Sāriputta to hear the teaching.”

MN 32:2.3“Yes, reverend,” Mahākassapa replied. MN 32:2.4Then, together with Venerable Anuruddha, they went to Sāriputta to hear the teaching.

MN 32:3.1Seeing them, Venerable Ānanda MN 32:3.2went to Venerable Revata, told him what was happening, MN 32:3.3and invited him also.

MN 32:4.1BJ 10.510PTS-VP-PLI 1.213Sāriputta saw them coming off in the distance MN 32:4.2and said to Ānanda, MN 32:4.3“Come, Venerable Ānanda. MN 32:4.4Welcome to Ānanda, the Buddha’s attendant, who is so close to the Buddha. MN 32:4.5Ānanda, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air. MN 32:4.6What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?”

MN 32:4.7“Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically. MN 32:4.8And they teach the four assemblies in order to uproot the underlying tendencies with well-rounded and systematic words and phrases. MN 32:4.9That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”

MN 32:5.1When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Revata, MN 32:5.2“Reverend Revata, Ānanda has answered by speaking from his heart. MN 32:5.3And now we ask you the same question.”

MN 32:5.6“Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who enjoys retreat and loves retreat. They’re committed to inner serenity of the heart, they don’t neglect absorption, they’re endowed with discernment, and they frequent empty huts. MN 32:5.7That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”

MN 32:6.1When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Anuruddha, MN 32:6.2“Reverend Anuruddha, Revata has answered by speaking from his heart. MN 32:6.3And now we ask you the same question.”

MN 32:6.6“Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who surveys the entire galaxy with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human, MN 32:6.7just as a person with good sight could survey a thousand wheel rims from the upper floor of a stilt longhouse. MN 32:6.9That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”

MN 32:7.1BJ 10.512PTS-VP-PLI 1.214When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Mahākassapa, MN 32:7.2“Reverend Kassapa, Anuruddha has answered by speaking from his heart. MN 32:7.3And now we ask you the same question.”

MN 32:7.6“Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who lives in the wilderness, eats only almsfood, wears rag robes, and owns just three robes; and they praise these things. They are of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praise these things. They are accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom; and they praise these things. MN 32:7.7That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”

MN 32:8.1When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Mahāmoggallāna, MN 32:8.2“Reverend Moggallāna, Mahākassapa has answered by speaking from his heart. MN 32:8.3And now we ask you the same question.”

MN 32:8.6“Reverend Sāriputta, it’s when two mendicants engage in discussion about the teaching. They question each other and answer each other’s questions without faltering, and their discussion on the teaching flows on. MN 32:8.7That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”

MN 32:9.1BJ 10.514PTS-VP-PLI 1.215Then Mahāmoggallāna said to Sāriputta, MN 32:9.10Suppose that a ruler or their minister had a chest full of garments of different colors. MN 32:9.11In the morning, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted. MN 32:9.12At midday, MN 32:9.13and in the evening, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted.

MN 32:9.14In the same way, a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it. MN 32:9.15In the morning, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want. MN 32:9.16At midday, MN 32:9.17and in the evening, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want. MN 32:9.18That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”

MN 32:9.2“Each of us has spoken from our heart. MN 32:9.3And now we ask you: MN 32:9.4Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air. MN 32:9.5What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?”

MN 32:9.6“Reverend Moggallāna, it’s when a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it. MN 32:9.7In the morning, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want. MN 32:9.8At midday, MN 32:9.9and in the evening, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.

  • MN 33:0.1Middle Discourses 33

MN 33:0.2The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

MN 33:1.1BJ 10.526PTS-VP-PLI 1.220So I have heard. MN 33:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 33:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 33:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 33:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 33:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 33:10.1And how does a mendicant not know satisfaction? MN 33:10.2It’s when a mendicant, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, finds no inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds no joy connected with the teaching. MN 33:10.3That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know satisfaction.

MN 33:11.1BJ 10.530And how does a mendicant not know the trail? MN 33:11.2It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the noble eightfold path. MN 33:11.3That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know the trail.

MN 33:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.222And how is a mendicant not skilled in pastures? MN 33:12.2It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. MN 33:12.3That’s how a mendicant is not skilled in pastures.

MN 33:13.1And how does a mendicant milk dry? MN 33:13.2It’s when a mendicant is invited by a householder to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, and that mendicant doesn’t know moderation in accepting. MN 33:13.3That’s how a mendicant milks dry.

MN 33:14.1And how does a mendicant not show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha? MN 33:14.2It’s when a mendicant doesn’t consistently treat senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private. MN 33:14.5That’s how a mendicant doesn’t show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.

MN 33:14.6A mendicant with these eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

MN 33:15.1A cowherd with eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle. MN 33:15.2What eleven? MN 33:15.3It’s when a cowherd knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, smokes out pests, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd. MN 33:15.4A cowherd with these eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.

MN 33:16.1BJ 10.532In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training. MN 33:16.2What eleven? MN 33:16.3It’s when a mendicant knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, smokes out pests, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.

MN 33:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.223And how does a mendicant know form? MN 33:17.2It’s when a mendicant truly understands that all form is the four primary elements, or form derived from the four primary elements. MN 33:17.3That’s how a mendicant knows form.

MN 33:18.1And how is a mendicant skilled in characteristics? MN 33:18.2It’s when a mendicant understands that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds. MN 33:18.3That’s how a mendicant is skilled in characteristics.

MN 33:19.1And how does a mendicant pick out flies’ eggs? MN 33:19.2It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen. They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them. MN 33:19.3That’s how a mendicant picks out flies’ eggs.

MN 33:2.1“Mendicants, a cowherd with eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle. MN 33:2.2What eleven? MN 33:2.3It’s when a cowherd doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t smoke out pests, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in pastures, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd. MN 33:2.4A cowherd with these eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.

MN 33:20.1And how does a mendicant dress wounds? MN 33:20.10That’s how a mendicant dresses wounds.

MN 33:20.2When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 33:20.3If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint. MN 33:20.4When they hear a sound with their ears … MN 33:20.5smell an odor with their nose … MN 33:20.6taste a flavor with their tongue … MN 33:20.7feel a touch with their body … MN 33:20.8know a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 33:20.9If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

MN 33:21.1And how does a mendicant smoke out pests? MN 33:21.2It’s when a mendicant teaches others the Dhamma in detail as they learned and memorized it. MN 33:21.3That’s how a mendicant smokes out pests.

MN 33:22.1BJ 10.534And how does a mendicant know the ford? MN 33:22.2It’s when from time to time a mendicant goes up to those mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—and asks them questions: MN 33:22.3‘Why, sir, does it say this? MN 33:22.4What does that mean?’ MN 33:22.5Those venerables clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters. MN 33:22.6That’s how a mendicant knows the ford.

MN 33:23.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.224And how does a mendicant know satisfaction? MN 33:23.2It’s when a mendicant, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, finds inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds joy connected with the teaching. MN 33:23.3That’s how a mendicant knows satisfaction.

MN 33:24.1And how does a mendicant know the trail? MN 33:24.2It’s when a mendicant truly understands the noble eightfold path. MN 33:24.3That’s how a mendicant knows the trail.

MN 33:25.1And how is a mendicant skilled in pastures? MN 33:25.2It’s when a mendicant truly understands the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. MN 33:25.3That’s how a mendicant is skilled in pastures.

MN 33:26.1And how does a mendicant not milk dry? MN 33:26.2It’s when a mendicant is invited by a householder to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, MN 33:26.3and that mendicant knows moderation in accepting. MN 33:26.4That’s how a mendicant doesn’t milk dry.

MN 33:27.1And how does a mendicant show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha? MN 33:27.2It’s when a mendicant consistently treats senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private. MN 33:27.5That’s how a mendicant shows extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.

MN 33:27.6A mendicant with these eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.”

MN 33:27.7That is what the Buddha said. MN 33:27.8Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 33:3.1In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training. MN 33:3.2What eleven? MN 33:3.3It’s when a mendicant doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t smoke out pests, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in pastures, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.

MN 33:4.1And how does a mendicant not know form? MN 33:4.2It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand that all form is the four primary elements, or form derived from the four primary elements. MN 33:4.3That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know form.

MN 33:5.1And how is a mendicant not skilled in characteristics? MN 33:5.2It’s when a mendicant doesn’t understand that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds. MN 33:5.3That’s how a mendicant isn’t skilled in characteristics.

MN 33:6.1BJ 10.528PTS-VP-PLI 1.221And how does a mendicant not pick out flies’ eggs? MN 33:6.2It’s when a mendicant tolerates a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen. They tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen. They don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them. MN 33:6.3That’s how a mendicant doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs.

MN 33:7.1And how does a mendicant not dress wounds? MN 33:7.10That’s how a mendicant doesn’t dress wounds.

MN 33:7.2When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they get caught up in the features and details. MN 33:7.3Since the faculty of sight is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of sight, and they don’t achieve its restraint. MN 33:7.4When they hear a sound with their ears … MN 33:7.5smell an odor with their nose … MN 33:7.6taste a flavor with their tongue … MN 33:7.7feel a touch with their body … MN 33:7.8know a thought with their mind, they get caught up in the features and details. MN 33:7.9Since the faculty of the mind is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of the mind, and they don’t achieve its restraint.

MN 33:8.1And how does a mendicant not smoke out pests? MN 33:8.2It’s when a mendicant doesn’t teach others the Dhamma in detail as they learned and memorized it. MN 33:8.3That’s how a mendicant doesn’t smoke out pests.

MN 33:9.1And how does a mendicant not know the ford? MN 33:9.2It’s when a mendicant doesn’t from time to time go up to those mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—and ask them questions: MN 33:9.3‘Why, sir, does it say this? MN 33:9.4What does that mean?’ MN 33:9.5Those venerables don’t clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters. MN 33:9.6That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know the ford.

  • MN 34:0.1Middle Discourses 34

MN 34:0.2The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

MN 34:1.1BJ 10.536PTS-VP-PLI 1.225So I have heard. MN 34:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis near Ukkacelā on the bank of the Ganges river. MN 34:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 34:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 34:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 34:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 34:10.1BJ 10.540Just like the baby calf who had just been born, but, urged on by its mother’s lowing, still managed to cross the Ganges to safety MN 34:10.2are the mendicants who are followers of principles, followers by faith. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.

MN 34:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.227Mendicants, I am skilled in this world and the other world, skilled in Māra’s domain and its opposite, and skilled in Death’s domain and its opposite. If anyone thinks I am worth listening to and trusting, it will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

MN 34:12.1That is what the Buddha said. MN 34:12.10for realizing the sanctuary, extinguishment.

MN 34:12.11The Wicked One’s stream has been cut, MN 34:12.12it’s blown away and mown down. MN 34:12.13Be full of joy, mendicants, MN 34:12.14set your heart on the sanctuary!”

MN 34:12.2Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

MN 34:12.3“This world and the other world MN 34:12.4have been clearly explained by one who knows; MN 34:12.5as well as Māra’s reach, MN 34:12.6and what’s out of Death’s reach.

MN 34:12.7Directly knowing the whole world, MN 34:12.8the Buddha who understands MN 34:12.9has flung open the door of the deathless,

MN 34:2.1“Once upon a time, mendicants, there was an unintelligent Magadhan cowherd. In the last month of the rainy season, without inspecting the near shore or the far shore, he drove his cattle across a place with no ford on the Ganges river to the land of the Suvidehans on the northern shore.

MN 34:3.1But the cattle bunched up in mid-stream and came to ruin right there. MN 34:3.2Why is that? MN 34:3.3Because the unintelligent cowherd failed to inspect the shores before driving the cattle across at a place with no ford. MN 34:3.4In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who are unskilled in this world and the other world, unskilled in Māra’s domain and its opposite, and unskilled in Death’s domain and its opposite. If anyone thinks they are worth listening to and trusting, it will be for their lasting harm and suffering.

MN 34:4.1BJ 10.538PTS-VP-PLI 1.226Once upon a time, mendicants, there was an intelligent Magadhan cowherd. In the last month of the rainy season, after inspecting the near shore and the far shore, he drove his cattle across a ford on the Ganges river to the land of the Suvidehans on the northern shore.

MN 34:5.1First he drove across the bulls, the fathers and leaders of the herd. MN 34:5.10Why is that? MN 34:5.11Because the intelligent cowherd inspected both shores before driving the cattle across at a ford.

MN 34:5.12In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who are skilled in this world and the other world, skilled in Māra’s domain and its opposite, and skilled in Death’s domain and its opposite. If anyone thinks they are worth listening to and trusting, it will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.

MN 34:5.2They breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore. MN 34:5.3Then he drove across the strong and tractable cattle. MN 34:5.4They too breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore. MN 34:5.5Then he drove across the bullocks and heifers. MN 34:5.6They too breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore. MN 34:5.7Then he drove across the calves and weak cattle. MN 34:5.8They too breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore. MN 34:5.9Once it happened that a baby calf had just been born. Urged on by its mother’s lowing, even it managed to breast the stream of the Ganges and safely reach the far shore.

MN 34:6.1Just like the bulls, fathers and leaders of the herd, who crossed the Ganges to safety MN 34:6.2are the mendicants who are perfected, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. Having breasted Māra’s stream, they have safely crossed over to the far shore.

MN 34:7.1Just like the strong and tractable cattle who crossed the Ganges to safety MN 34:7.2are the mendicants who, with the ending of the five lower fetters, are reborn spontaneously. They’re extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.

MN 34:8.1Just like the bullocks and heifers who crossed the Ganges to safety MN 34:8.2are the mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, are once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.

MN 34:9.1Just like the calves and weak cattle who crossed the Ganges to safety MN 34:9.2are the mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.

  • MN 35:0.1Middle Discourses 35

MN 35:0.2The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

MN 35:1.1BJ 10.542So I have heard. MN 35:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

MN 35:10.1“A simile strikes me, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:10.2“Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

MN 35:10.3“All the plants and seeds that achieve growth, increase, and maturity do so depending on the earth and grounded on the earth. MN 35:10.5All the hard work that gets done depends on the earth and is grounded on the earth.

MN 35:10.7In the same way, an individual’s self is form. Grounded on form they make good and bad choices. An individual’s self is feeling … perception … choices … consciousness. Grounded on consciousness they make good and bad choices.”

MN 35:11.1“Aggivessana, are you not saying this: MN 35:11.2‘Form is my self, feeling is my self, perception is my self, choices are my self, consciousness is my self’?”

MN 35:11.3“Indeed, Master Gotama, that is what I am saying. MN 35:11.4And this big crowd agrees with me!”

MN 35:11.5“What has this big crowd to do with you? MN 35:11.6Please just explain your own statement.”

MN 35:11.7“Then, Master Gotama, what I am saying is this: MN 35:11.8‘Form is my self, feeling is my self, perception is my self, choices are my self, consciousness is my self’.”

MN 35:12.1BJ 10.548PTS-VP-PLI 1.231“Well then, Aggivessana, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like. MN 35:12.11So of course an anointed king such as Pasenadi or Ajātasattu MN 35:12.12would wield such power, as is their right.”

MN 35:12.2What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:12.3Consider an anointed aristocratic king such as Pasenadi of Kosala or Ajātasattu Vedehiputta of Magadha. MN 35:12.4Would they have the power in their own realm to execute, fine, or banish those who are guilty?”

MN 35:12.5“An anointed king would have such power, Master Gotama. MN 35:12.7Even federations such as the MN 35:12.8Vajjis and Mallas MN 35:12.9have such power in their own realm.

MN 35:13.1“What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:13.10but Saccaka still kept silent. MN 35:13.11So the Buddha said to Saccaka, MN 35:13.12“Answer now, Aggivessana. Now is not the time for silence. MN 35:13.13If someone fails to answer a legitimate question when asked three times by the Buddha, their head explodes into seven pieces there and then.”

MN 35:13.2When you say, MN 35:13.3‘Form is my self,’ do you have power over that form to say: MN 35:13.4‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that’?” MN 35:13.5When he said this, Saccaka kept silent. MN 35:13.6The Buddha asked the question a second time,

MN 35:14.1BJ 10.550PTS-VP-PLI 1.232Now at that time the spirit Vajirapāṇi, taking up a burning iron thunderbolt, blazing and glowing, stood in the sky above Saccaka, thinking, MN 35:14.2“If this Saccaka doesn’t answer when asked a third time, I’ll blow his head into seven pieces there and then!” MN 35:14.3And both the Buddha and Saccaka could see Vajirapāṇi.

MN 35:14.4Saccaka was terrified, shocked, and awestruck. Looking to the Buddha for shelter, protection, and refuge, he said, MN 35:14.5“Ask me, Master Gotama. I will answer.”

MN 35:15.1“What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:15.2When you say, MN 35:15.3‘Form is my self,’ do you have power over that form to say: MN 35:15.4‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that’?”

MN 35:15.5“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:16.1“Think about it, Aggivessana! MN 35:16.2You should think before answering. MN 35:16.3What you said before and what you said after don’t match up. MN 35:16.4What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:16.5When you say, MN 35:16.6‘Feeling is my self,’ do you have power over that feeling to say: MN 35:16.7‘May my feeling be like this! May it not be like that’?”

MN 35:16.8“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:17.1“Think about it, Aggivessana! MN 35:17.2You should think before answering. MN 35:17.3What you said before and what you said after don’t match up. MN 35:17.4What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:17.5When you say, MN 35:17.6‘Perception is my self,’ do you have power over that perception to say: MN 35:17.7‘May my perception be like this! May it not be like that’?”

MN 35:17.8“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:18.1“Think about it, Aggivessana! MN 35:18.2You should think before answering. MN 35:18.3What you said before and what you said after don’t match up. MN 35:18.4What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:18.5When you say, MN 35:18.6‘Choices are my self,’ do you have power over those choices to say: MN 35:18.7‘May my choices be like this! May they not be like that’?”

MN 35:18.8“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:19.1“Think about it, Aggivessana! MN 35:19.2You should think before answering. MN 35:19.3What you said before and what you said after don’t match up. MN 35:19.4What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:19.5When you say, MN 35:19.6‘Consciousness is my self,’ do you have power over that consciousness to say: MN 35:19.7‘May my consciousness be like this! May it not be like that’?”

MN 35:19.8“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:2.1Now at that time Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, was staying in Vesālī. He was a debater and clever speaker regarded as holy by many people. MN 35:2.2He was telling a crowd in Vesālī, MN 35:2.3“If I was to take them on in debate, I don’t see any ascetic or brahmin—leader of an order or a community, or the teacher of a community, even one who claims to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha—who would not shake and rock and tremble, sweating from the armpits. MN 35:2.4Even if I took on an insentient post in debate, it would shake and rock and tremble. MN 35:2.5How much more then a human being!”

MN 35:20.1BJ 10.552PTS-VP-PLI 1.233“Think about it, Aggivessana! MN 35:20.10‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

MN 35:20.11“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:20.12“What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:20.13Is feeling … MN 35:20.14perception … MN 35:20.15choices … MN 35:20.16consciousness permanent or impermanent?”

MN 35:20.17“Impermanent.”

MN 35:20.18“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

MN 35:20.19“Suffering.”

MN 35:20.2You should think before answering.

MN 35:20.20“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus: MN 35:20.21‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

MN 35:20.22“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:20.3What you said before and what you said after don’t match up. MN 35:20.4What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:20.5Is form permanent or impermanent?”

MN 35:20.6“Impermanent.”

MN 35:20.7“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

MN 35:20.8“Suffering.”

MN 35:20.9“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:

MN 35:21.1“What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:21.2Consider someone who clings, holds, and attaches to suffering, regarding it thus: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’ Would such a person be able to completely understand suffering themselves, or live having wiped out suffering?”

MN 35:21.3“How could they? MN 35:21.4No, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:21.5“What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 35:21.6This being so, aren’t you someone who clings, holds, and attaches to suffering, regarding it thus: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

MN 35:21.8“How could I not? MN 35:21.9Yes, Master Gotama.”

MN 35:22.1BJ 10.554PTS-VP-PLI 1.234“Suppose, Aggivessana, there was a person in need of heartwood. Wandering in search of heartwood, they’d take a sharp axe and enter a forest. MN 35:22.10But sweat is pouring from your forehead; it’s soaked through your robe and drips on the ground. MN 35:22.11While I now have no sweat on my body.” MN 35:22.12So the Buddha revealed his golden body to the assembly. MN 35:22.13When this was said, Saccaka sat silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

MN 35:22.2There they’d see a big banana tree, straight and young and grown free of defects. MN 35:22.3They’d cut it down at the base, cut off the top, and unroll the coiled sheaths. MN 35:22.4But they wouldn’t even find sapwood, much less heartwood.

MN 35:22.5In the same way, when pursued, pressed, and grilled by me on your own doctrine, you turn out to be void, hollow, and mistaken. MN 35:22.6But it was you who stated before the assembly of Vesālī: MN 35:22.7‘If I was to take them on in debate, I don’t see any ascetic or brahmin—leader of an order or a community, or the teacher of a community, even one who claims to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha—who would not shake and rock and tremble, sweating from the armpits. MN 35:22.8Even if I took on an insentient post in debate, it would shake and rock and tremble. MN 35:22.9How much more then a human being!’

MN 35:23.1Knowing this, the Licchavi Dummukha said to the Buddha, MN 35:23.10Now he can’t get near the Buddha again looking for a debate.”

MN 35:23.2“A simile strikes me, Blessed One.”

MN 35:23.3“Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

MN 35:23.4“Sir, suppose there was a lotus pond not far from a town or village, MN 35:23.5and a crab lived there. MN 35:23.6Then several boys or girls would leave the town or village and go to the pond, where they’d pull out the crab and put it on dry land. MN 35:23.7Whenever that crab extended a claw, those boys or girls would snap, crack, and break it off with a stick or a stone. MN 35:23.8And when that crab’s claws had all been snapped, cracked, and broken off it wouldn’t be able to return down into that lotus pond. MN 35:23.9In the same way, sir, the Buddha has snapped, cracked, and broken off all Saccaka’s tricks, dodges, and evasions.

MN 35:24.1But Saccaka said to him, MN 35:24.10consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 35:24.11That’s how to define one of my disciples who follows instructions and responds to advice; who has gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, gained assurance, and is independent of others in the Teacher’s instructions.”

MN 35:24.2“Hold on, Dummukha, hold on! I wasn’t talking with you, I was talking with Master Gotama.

MN 35:24.3BJ 10.556PTS-VP-PLI 1.235Master Gotama, leave aside that statement I made—as did various other ascetics and brahmins—MN 35:24.4it was, like, just a bit of nonsense. MN 35:24.5How do you define a disciple of Master Gotama who follows instructions and responds to advice; who has gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, gained assurance, and is independent of others in the Teacher’s instructions?”

MN 35:24.6“It’s when one of my disciples truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 35:24.7They truly see any kind of feeling … MN 35:24.8perception … MN 35:24.9choices …

MN 35:25.1BJ 10.558“But how do you define a mendicant who is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment?”

MN 35:25.2“It’s when one of my disciples truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ And having seen this with right understanding they’re freed by not grasping. MN 35:25.3They truly see any kind of feeling … MN 35:25.4perception … MN 35:25.5choices … MN 35:25.6consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ And having seen this with right understanding they’re freed by not grasping. MN 35:25.7That’s how to define a mendicant who is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.

MN 35:26.1A mendicant whose mind is freed like this has three unsurpassable qualities: MN 35:26.2unsurpassable vision, practice, and freedom. MN 35:26.3They honor, respect, esteem, and venerate only the Realized One: MN 35:26.4‘The Blessed One is awakened, tamed, serene, crossed over, and extinguished. And he teaches Dhamma for awakening, self-control, serenity, crossing over, and extinguishment.’”

MN 35:27.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.236When he had spoken, Saccaka said to him, MN 35:27.2“Master Gotama, it was rude and impudent of me to imagine I could attack you in debate. MN 35:27.3For a person might find safety after attacking a rutting elephant, but not after attacking Master Gotama. MN 35:27.4A person might find safety after attacking a blazing mass of fire, but not after attacking Master Gotama. MN 35:27.5They might find safety after attacking a poisonous viper, but not after attacking Master Gotama. MN 35:27.6It was rude and impudent of me to imagine I could attack you in debate. MN 35:27.7Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?” MN 35:27.8The Buddha consented in silence.

MN 35:28.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.237Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Saccaka addressed those Licchavis, MN 35:28.2“Listen, gentlemen. I have invited the ascetic Gotama together with the Saṅgha of mendicants for tomorrow’s meal. MN 35:28.3You may all bring me what you think is suitable.”

MN 35:29.1Then, when the night had passed, those Licchavis presented Saccaka with an offering of five hundred servings of food. MN 35:29.2And Saccaka had a variety of delicious foods prepared in his own home. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying, MN 35:29.3“Itʼs time, Master Gotama, the meal is ready.”

MN 35:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.228Then Venerable Assaji robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms. MN 35:3.2As Saccaka was going for a walk he saw Assaji coming off in the distance. MN 35:3.3He approached him and exchanged greetings with him.

MN 35:3.4When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Saccaka stood to one side and said to Assaji,

MN 35:30.1Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Saccaka’s park, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants. MN 35:30.2Then Saccaka served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods. MN 35:30.3When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Saccaka took a low seat and sat to one side.

MN 35:30.4Then Saccaka said to the Buddha, MN 35:30.5“Master Gotama, may the merit and the growth of merit in this gift be for the happiness of the donors.”

MN 35:30.6“Aggivessana, whatever comes from giving to a recipient of a religious donation such as yourself—who is not free of greed, hate, and delusion—will accrue to the donors. MN 35:30.7Whatever comes from giving to a recipient of a religious donation such as myself—who is free of greed, hate, and delusion—will accrue to you.”

MN 35:4.1“Master Assaji, how does the ascetic Gotama guide his disciples? And how does instruction to his disciples generally proceed?”

MN 35:4.2“Aggivessana, this is how the ascetic Gotama guides his disciples, and how instruction to his disciples generally proceeds: MN 35:4.3‘Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent. MN 35:4.4Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self. MN 35:4.5All conditions are impermanent. All things are not-self.’ MN 35:4.6This is how the ascetic Gotama guides his disciples, and how instruction to his disciples generally proceeds.”

MN 35:4.7“It’s sad to hear, Master Assaji, that the ascetic Gotama has such a doctrine. MN 35:4.8Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet Master Gotama, and we can have a discussion. And hopefully I can dissuade him from this harmful misconception.”

MN 35:5.1BJ 10.544PTS-VP-PLI 1.229Now at that time around five hundred Licchavis were sitting together at the meeting hall on some business. MN 35:5.10I’ll play a game of ear-washing with the ascetic Gotama, like a sixty-year-old elephant would plunge into a deep lotus pond and play a game of ear-washing! MN 35:5.12Come forth, good Licchavīs, come forth! Today I am going to have a discussion with the ascetic Gotama.”

MN 35:5.2Then Saccaka went up to them and said, MN 35:5.3“Come forth, good Licchavīs, come forth! Today I am going to have a discussion with the ascetic Gotama. MN 35:5.4If he stands by the position stated to me by one of his well-known disciples—a mendicant named Assaji—I’ll take him on in debate and drag him to and fro and round about, like a strong man would drag a fleecy sheep to and fro and round about! MN 35:5.6Taking him on in debate, I’ll drag him to and fro and round about, like a strong brewer’s worker would toss a large brewer’s sieve into a deep lake, grab it by the corners, and drag it to and fro and round about! MN 35:5.8Taking him on in debate, I’ll shake him down and about, and give him a beating, like a strong brewer’s mixer would grab a strainer by the corners and shake it down and about, and give it a beating!

MN 35:6.1At that, some of the Licchavis said, MN 35:6.2“How can the ascetic Gotama refute Saccaka’s doctrine, when it is Saccaka who will refute Gotama’s doctrine?”

MN 35:6.3But some of the Licchavis said, MN 35:6.4“Who is Saccaka to refute the Buddha’s doctrine, when it is the Buddha who will refute Saccaka’s doctrine?”

MN 35:6.5Then Saccaka, escorted by the five hundred Licchavis, went to the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.

MN 35:7.1At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air. MN 35:7.2Then Saccaka went up to them and said, MN 35:7.3“Gentlemen, where is Master Gotama at present? MN 35:7.4For we want to see him.”

MN 35:7.5“Aggivessana, the Buddha has plunged deep into the Great Wood and is sitting at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.”

MN 35:8.1Then Saccaka, together with a large group of Licchavis, went to see the Buddha in the Great Wood, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 35:8.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. MN 35:8.3Before sitting down to one side, some of the Licchavīs bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.

MN 35:9.1BJ 10.546PTS-VP-PLI 1.230Then Saccaka said to the Buddha, MN 35:9.2“I’d like to ask Master Gotama about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”

MN 35:9.3“Ask what you wish, Aggivessana.”

MN 35:9.4“How does the ascetic Gotama guide his disciples? And how does instruction to his disciples generally proceed?”

MN 35:9.5“This is how I guide my disciples, and how instruction to my disciples generally proceeds: MN 35:9.6‘Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent. MN 35:9.7Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self. MN 35:9.8All conditions are impermanent. All things are not-self.’ MN 35:9.9This is how I guide my disciples, and how instruction to my disciples generally proceeds.”

MN 36:0.2The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

MN 36:1.1BJ 10.560So I have heard. MN 36:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

MN 36:10.1BJ 10.566“I am quite confident that Master Gotama MN 36:10.2is developed in physical endurance and in mind.”

MN 36:10.3“Your words are clearly invasive and intrusive, Aggivessana. MN 36:10.4Nevertheless, I will answer you. MN 36:10.5Ever since I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness, it has not been possible for any pleasant or painful feeling to occupy my mind.”

MN 36:11.1“Surely you must have had feelings so pleasant or so painful that they could occupy your mind?”

MN 36:12.1“How could I not, Aggivessana? MN 36:12.2Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought: MN 36:12.3‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open. MN 36:12.4It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell. MN 36:12.5Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

MN 36:13.1Some time later, while still black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

MN 36:13.10‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.” MN 36:13.11Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’

MN 36:13.12BJ 10.568So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him, MN 36:13.13‘Reverend Kālāma, to what extent do you say you’ve realized this teaching with your own insight?’ MN 36:13.14When I said this, he declared the dimension of nothingness.

MN 36:13.15Then it occurred to me, MN 36:13.16‘It’s not just Āḷāra Kālāma who has faith, MN 36:13.17energy, MN 36:13.18mindfulness, MN 36:13.19immersion,

MN 36:13.2Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him, MN 36:13.20and wisdom; I too have these things. MN 36:13.21Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Āḷāra Kālāma says he has realized with his own insight?’ MN 36:13.22I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.

MN 36:13.3‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’

MN 36:13.4Āḷāra Kālāma replied, MN 36:13.5‘Stay, venerable. MN 36:13.6This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’

MN 36:13.7I quickly memorized that teaching. MN 36:13.8So far as lip-recital and oral recitation were concerned, I spoke with knowledge and the authority of the elders. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.

MN 36:13.9Then it occurred to me,

MN 36:14.1So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him, MN 36:14.10I am like you and you are like me. MN 36:14.11Come now, reverend! We should both lead this community together.’ MN 36:14.12And that is how my teacher Āḷāra Kālāma placed me, his student, on the same position as him, and honored me with lofty praise.

MN 36:14.13Then it occurred to me, MN 36:14.14‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of nothingness.’ MN 36:14.15Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.

MN 36:14.2‘Reverend Kālāma, have you realized this teaching with your own insight up to this point, and declare having achieved it?’

MN 36:14.3‘I have, reverend.’

MN 36:14.4‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’

MN 36:14.5‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate MN 36:14.6to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions! MN 36:14.7So the teaching that I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it, you’ve realized with your own insight, and live having achieved it. MN 36:14.8The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and live having achieved it, I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it. MN 36:14.9So the teaching that I know, you know, and the teaching you know, I know.

MN 36:15.1BJ 10.570I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Uddaka, son of Rāma, and said to him, MN 36:15.10Surely he meditated knowing and seeing this teaching.’

MN 36:15.14Then it occurred to me, MN 36:15.15‘It’s not just Rāma who had faith, MN 36:15.16energy, MN 36:15.17mindfulness, MN 36:15.18immersion, MN 36:15.19and wisdom; I too have these things. MN 36:15.2‘Reverend, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’

MN 36:15.33Then it occurred to me, MN 36:15.34‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. MN 36:15.8Then it occurred to me, MN 36:15.9‘It is not solely by mere faith that Rāma declared: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”

MN 36:16.1I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. Traveling stage by stage in the Magadhan lands, I arrived at Senanigama near Uruvelā. MN 36:16.2There I saw a delightful park, a lovely grove with a flowing river that was clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby was a village to go for alms. MN 36:16.3Then it occurred to me, MN 36:16.4‘This park is truly delightful, a lovely grove with a flowing river that’s clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby there’s a village to go for alms. MN 36:16.5This is good enough for a gentleman who wishes to put forth effort in meditation.’ MN 36:16.6So I sat down right there, thinking: MN 36:16.7‘This is good enough for meditation.’

MN 36:17.1BJ 10.574PTS-VP-PLI 1.241And then these three examples, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me. MN 36:17.10That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

MN 36:17.11“In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. They haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening. MN 36:17.13This was the first example that occurred to me.

MN 36:17.2Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying in water. MN 36:17.3Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking MN 36:17.4to light a fire and produce heat. MN 36:17.5What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 36:17.6By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log lying in the water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

MN 36:17.7“No, Master Gotama. MN 36:17.8Why not? MN 36:17.9Because it’s a green, sappy log, and it’s lying in the water.

MN 36:18.1Then a second example occurred to me. MN 36:18.10That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

MN 36:18.11“In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. But they haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening. MN 36:18.12This was the second example that occurred to me.

MN 36:18.2Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water. MN 36:18.3Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking MN 36:18.4to light a fire and produce heat. MN 36:18.5What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 36:18.6By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

MN 36:18.7“No, Master Gotama. MN 36:18.8Why not? MN 36:18.9Because it’s still a green, sappy log, despite the fact that it’s lying on dry land far from water.

MN 36:19.1BJ 10.576PTS-VP-PLI 1.242Then a third example occurred to me.

MN 36:19.10“In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. MN 36:19.11This was the third example that occurred to me. MN 36:19.12These are the three examples, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, that occurred to me.

MN 36:19.2Suppose there was a dried up, withered log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water. MN 36:19.3Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking MN 36:19.4to light a fire and produce heat. MN 36:19.5What do you think, Aggivessana? MN 36:2.1Now at that time in the morning the Buddha, being properly dressed, took his bowl and robe, wishing to enter Vesālī for alms.

MN 36:20.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.243Then it occurred to me, MN 36:20.2‘Why don’t I, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, squeeze, squash, and torture mind with mind.’ MN 36:20.3So that’s what I did, MN 36:20.4until sweat ran from my armpits. MN 36:20.5It was like when a strong man grabs a weaker man by the head or throat or shoulder and squeezes, squashes, and tortures them. MN 36:20.6In the same way, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, I squeezed, squashed, and tortured mind with mind until sweat ran from my armpits. MN 36:20.7My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving. MN 36:20.8But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

MN 36:21.7My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving. MN 36:21.8But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

MN 36:22.4But then strong winds ground my head, MN 36:22.5like a strong man was drilling into my head with a sharp point. MN 36:22.7My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving. MN 36:22.8But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

MN 36:25.1BJ 10.580PTS-VP-PLI 1.245Then it occurred to me, MN 36:25.2‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’ MN 36:25.3So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose and ears. MN 36:25.8But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

MN 36:26.1Then some deities saw me and said, MN 36:26.2‘The ascetic Gotama is dead.’ MN 36:26.3Others said, MN 36:26.4‘He’s not dead, but he’s dying.’ MN 36:26.5Others said, MN 36:26.6‘He’s not dead or dying. The ascetic Gotama is a perfected one, for that is how the perfected ones live.’

MN 36:27.1Then it occurred to me, MN 36:27.2‘Why don’t I practice completely cutting off food?’ MN 36:27.3But deities came to me and said, MN 36:27.4‘Good sir, don’t practice totally cutting off food. MN 36:27.5If you do, we’ll infuse divine nectar into your pores and you will live on that.’ MN 36:27.6Then I thought, MN 36:27.7‘If I claim to be completely fasting while these deities are infusing divine nectar in my pores, that would be a lie on my part.’ MN 36:27.8So I dismissed those deities, saying, ‘There’s no need.’

MN 36:28.1BJ 10.582PTS-VP-PLI 1.246Then it occurred to me, MN 36:28.10Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.

MN 36:28.11Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly. MN 36:28.12Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there. MN 36:28.13Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.

MN 36:28.2‘Why don’t I just take a little bit of food each time, a cup of broth made from mung beans, lentils, chickpeas, or green gram.’ MN 36:28.3So that’s what I did, MN 36:28.4until my body became extremely emaciated. MN 36:28.5Due to eating so little, my limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a corpse, MN 36:28.6my bottom became like a camel’s hoof, MN 36:28.7my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string, MN 36:28.8and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn. MN 36:28.9Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.

MN 36:29.1Then some people saw me and said: ‘The ascetic Gotama is black.’ MN 36:29.2Some said: ‘He’s not black, he’s brown.’ MN 36:29.3Some said: ‘He’s neither black nor brown. The ascetic Gotama has tawny skin.’ MN 36:29.4That’s how far the pure, bright complexion of my skin had been ruined by taking so little food.

MN 36:3.1Then as Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, was going for a walk he approached the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood. MN 36:3.2Venerable Ānanda saw him coming off in the distance, MN 36:3.3and said to the Buddha, MN 36:3.4“Sir, Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, is coming.
