MN 36:3.6Please, sir, sit for a moment out of compassion.” MN 36:3.7The Buddha sat on the seat spread out.

MN 36:3.8Then Saccaka went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

MN 36:30.1BJ 10.584PTS-VP-PLI 1.247Then I thought, MN 36:30.2‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this. MN 36:30.5But I have not achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by this severe, grueling work. MN 36:30.6Could there be another path to awakening?’

MN 36:31.1Then it occurred to me, MN 36:31.2‘I recall sitting in the cool shade of the rose-apple tree while my father the Sakyan was off working. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 36:31.3Could that be the path to awakening?’

MN 36:31.4Stemming from that memory came the realization: MN 36:31.5‘That is the path to awakening!’

MN 36:32.1Then it occurred to me, MN 36:32.2‘Why am I afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities?’ MN 36:32.3Then I thought, MN 36:32.4‘I’m not afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities.’

MN 36:33.1Then I thought, MN 36:33.2‘I can’t achieve that pleasure with a body so excessively emaciated. Why don’t I eat some solid food, some rice and porridge?’ MN 36:33.3So I ate some solid food.

MN 36:33.4Now at that time the five mendicants were attending on me, thinking, MN 36:33.5‘The ascetic Gotama will tell us of any truth that he realizes.’ MN 36:33.6But when I ate some solid food, they left disappointed in me, saying, MN 36:33.7‘The ascetic Gotama has become indulgent; he has strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.’

MN 36:34.1After eating solid food and gathering my strength, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 36:34.2But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

MN 36:35-37.1As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 36:35-37.2But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind. MN 36:35-37.3And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 36:35-37.4But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind. MN 36:35-37.5With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 36:35-37.6But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

MN 36:38.1BJ 10.586PTS-VP-PLI 1.248When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives. MN 36:38.2I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

MN 36:39.1This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night. MN 36:39.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute. MN 36:39.3But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

MN 36:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.238“Master Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who live committed to the practice of developing physical endurance, without developing the mind. MN 36:4.10Their body was subject to the mind, and the mind had power over it. MN 36:4.11Why is that? MN 36:4.12Because their physical endurance was not developed. MN 36:4.13It occurs to me that MN 36:4.14Master Gotama’s disciples must live committed to the practice of developing the mind, without developing physical endurance.”

MN 36:4.2They suffer painful physical feelings. MN 36:4.3This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind. MN 36:4.4Their mind was subject to the body, and the body had power over it. MN 36:4.5Why is that? MN 36:4.6Because their mind was not developed. MN 36:4.7There are some ascetics and brahmins who live committed to the practice of developing the mind, without developing physical endurance. MN 36:4.8They suffer painful mental feelings. MN 36:4.9This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind.

MN 36:40.1When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 36:40.2With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

MN 36:41.1This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night. MN 36:41.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute. MN 36:41.3But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

MN 36:42.1BJ 10.588When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 36:42.2I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ MN 36:42.3I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’

MN 36:43.1Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 36:43.2When it was freed, I knew it was freed.

MN 36:43.3I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 36:44.1This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night. MN 36:44.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute. MN 36:44.3But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

MN 36:45.1Aggivessana, I recall teaching the Dhamma to an assembly of many hundreds, MN 36:45.2and each person thinks MN 36:45.3that I am teaching the Dhamma especially for them. MN 36:45.4But it should not be seen like this. MN 36:45.5The Realized One teaches others only so that they can understand. MN 36:45.6When that talk is finished, I still, settle, unify, and immerse my mind in samādhi internally, using the same meditation subject as a foundation of immersion that I used before, which is my usual meditation.”

MN 36:45.7PTS-VP-PLI 1.250“I’d believe that of Master Gotama, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha. MN 36:45.8But do you ever recall sleeping during the day?”

MN 36:46.1“I do recall that in the last month of the summer, I have spread out my outer robe folded in four and lain down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.”

MN 36:46.2“Some ascetics and brahmins call that a deluded abiding.”

MN 36:46.3“That’s not how to define whether someone is deluded or not. MN 36:46.4But as to how to define whether someone is deluded or not, MN 36:46.5listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 36:46.6“Yes, sir,” replied Saccaka.

MN 36:46.7The Buddha said this:

MN 36:47.1BJ 10.590“Whoever has not given up the defilements—corruptions that lead to future lives and are hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death—is deluded, I say. MN 36:47.2For it’s not giving up the defilements that makes you deluded. MN 36:47.3Whoever has given up the defilements—corruptions that lead to future lives and are hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death—is not deluded, I say. MN 36:47.4For it’s giving up the defilements that makes you not deluded.

MN 36:47.5The Realized One has given up the defilements—corruptions that lead to future lives and are hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future. MN 36:47.6Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth, MN 36:47.7in the same way, the Realized One has given up the defilements so they are unable to arise in the future.”

MN 36:48.1BJ 10.592PTS-VP-PLI 1.251When he had spoken, Saccaka said to him, MN 36:48.10Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, MN 36:48.11and Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta in debate. MN 36:48.12They all dodged the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness. MN 36:48.13But when Master Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.

MN 36:48.14Well, now, Master Gotama, I must go. MN 36:48.15I have many duties, and much to do.”

MN 36:48.16“Please, Aggivessana, go at your convenience.”

MN 36:48.17Then Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat and left.

MN 36:48.2“It’s incredible, Master Gotama, it’s amazing! MN 36:48.3When Master Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.

MN 36:48.4I recall taking on Pūraṇa Kassapa in debate. MN 36:48.5He dodged the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness. MN 36:48.6But when Master Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.

MN 36:48.7I recall taking on Makkhali Gosāla, MN 36:48.8Ajita Kesakambala, MN 36:48.9Pakudha Kaccāyana,

MN 36:5.1BJ 10.562“But Aggivessana, what have you heard about the development of physical endurance?”

MN 36:5.2“Take, for example, MN 36:5.3Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and Makkhali Gosāla. MN 36:5.4They go naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on purpose for them, or an invitation for a meal. MN 36:5.5They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drink no beer. MN 36:5.6They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls. MN 36:5.7They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day. MN 36:5.8They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.”

MN 36:6.1“But Aggivessana, do they get by on so little?”

MN 36:6.2“No, Master Gotama. MN 36:6.3Sometimes they eat a variety of luxury foods and drink a variety of luxury beverages. MN 36:6.4They gather their body’s strength, build it up, and get fat.”

MN 36:6.5PTS-VP-PLI 1.239“What they earlier gave up, they later got back. That is how there is the increase and decrease of this body. MN 36:6.6But Aggivessana, what have you heard about development of the mind?” MN 36:6.7When Saccaka was questioned by the Buddha about development of the mind, he was stumped.

MN 36:7.1BJ 10.564So the Buddha said to Saccaka, MN 36:7.2“The development of physical endurance that you have described is not the legitimate development of physical endurance in the noble one’s training. MN 36:7.3And since you don’t even understand the development of physical endurance, how can you possibly understand the development of the mind? MN 36:7.4Still, as to how someone is undeveloped in physical endurance and mind, and how someone is developed in physical endurance and mind, MN 36:7.5listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 36:7.6“Yes, sir,” replied Saccaka. MN 36:7.7The Buddha said this:

MN 36:8.1“And how is someone undeveloped in physical endurance and mind? MN 36:8.2Take an uneducated ordinary person who has a pleasant feeling. MN 36:8.3When they experience pleasant feeling they become full of lust for it. MN 36:8.4Then that pleasant feeling ceases. MN 36:8.5And when it ceases, a painful feeling arises. MN 36:8.6When they suffer painful feeling, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. MN 36:8.7Because their physical endurance is undeveloped, pleasant feelings occupy the mind. And because their mind is undeveloped, painful feelings occupy the mind. MN 36:8.8Someone whose mind is occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is undeveloped in physical endurance and in mind.

MN 36:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.240And how is someone developed in physical endurance and mind? MN 36:9.2Take an educated noble disciple who has a pleasant feeling. MN 36:9.3When they experience pleasant feeling they don’t become full of lust for it. MN 36:9.4Then that pleasant feeling ceases. MN 36:9.5And when it ceases, painful feeling arises. MN 36:9.6When they suffer painful feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. MN 36:9.7Because their physical endurance is developed, pleasant feelings don’t occupy the mind. And because their mind is developed, painful feelings don’t occupy the mind. MN 36:9.8Someone whose mind is not occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is developed in physical endurance and in mind.”

MN 37:0.2The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

MN 37:1.1So I have heard. MN 37:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.

MN 37:10.1They were just like a daughter-in-law who is prudent and discreet when they see their father-in-law.

MN 37:10.3Then Sakka and Vessavaṇa encouraged Moggallāna to wander and explore the palace, saying, MN 37:10.4“See, in the palace, my good Moggallāna, this lovely thing! MN 37:10.5And that lovely thing!”

MN 37:10.6“That looks nice for Venerable Kosiya, just like for someone who has made merit in the past. MN 37:10.7Humans, when they see something lovely, also say: MN 37:10.8‘It looks nice enough for the Gods of the Thirty-Three!’ MN 37:10.9That looks nice for Venerable Kosiya, just like for someone who has made merit in the past.”

MN 37:11.1Then Moggallāna thought, MN 37:11.2“This spirit lives much too negligently. MN 37:11.3Why don’t I stir up a sense of urgency in him?”

MN 37:11.4Then Moggallāna used his psychic power to make the Palace of Victory shake and rock and tremble with his big toe. MN 37:11.5Then Sakka, Vessavaṇa, and the Gods of the Thirty-Three, their minds full of wonder and amazement, thought, MN 37:11.6“It’s incredible, it’s amazing! MN 37:11.7The ascetic has such power and might that he makes the god’s home shake and rock and tremble with his big toe!”

MN 37:12.1Knowing that Sakka was shocked and awestruck, Moggallāna said to him, MN 37:12.2“Kosiya, how did the Buddha briefly explain freedom through the ending of craving? MN 37:12.3Please share this talk with me so that I can also get to hear it.”

MN 37:12.4“My dear Moggallāna, I approached the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him, MN 37:12.5‘Sir, how do you briefly define a mendicant who is freed with the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans?’

MN 37:13.1BJ 10.598When I had spoken the Buddha said to me: MN 37:13.10They understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.” MN 37:13.11That’s how I briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans.’ MN 37:13.12That’s how the Buddha briefly explained freedom through the ending of craving to me.”

MN 37:13.2‘Lord of Gods, it’s when a mendicant has heard: MN 37:13.3“Nothing is worth insisting on” MN 37:13.4When a mendicant has heard that MN 37:13.5nothing is worth insisting on, MN 37:13.6they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Having completely understood all things, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—MN 37:13.7they meditate observing impermanence, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in those feelings. MN 37:13.8Meditating in this way, they don’t grasp at anything in the world. MN 37:13.9Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

MN 37:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.255Moggallāna approved and agreed with what Sakka said. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from among the Gods of the Thirty-Three and reappeared in the Eastern Monastery.

MN 37:14.2Soon after Moggallāna left, Sakka’s maids said to him, MN 37:14.3“Good sir, was that the Blessed One, your Teacher?”

MN 37:14.4“No, it was not. MN 37:14.5That was my spiritual companion Venerable Mahāmoggallāna.”

MN 37:14.6“You’re fortunate, good sir, so very fortunate, MN 37:14.7to have a spiritual companion of such power and might! MN 37:14.8We can’t believe that’s not the Blessed One, your Teacher!”

MN 37:15.1BJ 10.600Then Mahāmoggallāna went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, MN 37:15.17“That’s how I recall briefly explaining freedom through the ending of craving to Sakka, lord of gods.”

MN 37:15.18That is what the Buddha said. MN 37:15.19Satisfied, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 37:15.2“Sir, do you recall briefly explaining freedom through the ending of craving to a certain well-known and illustrious spirit?”

MN 37:15.3“I do, Moggallāna.” And the Buddha retold all that happened when Sakka came to visit him, adding:

MN 37:2.1And then Sakka, lord of gods, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:

MN 37:2.2“Sir, how do you briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans?”

MN 37:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.252“Lord of Gods, it’s when a mendicant has heard: MN 37:3.10That’s how I briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans.”

MN 37:3.2‘Nothing is worth insisting on.’ MN 37:3.3When a mendicant has heard that MN 37:3.4nothing is worth insisting on, MN 37:3.5they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Having completely understood all things, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—MN 37:3.6they meditate observing impermanence, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in those feelings. MN 37:3.7Meditating in this way, they don’t grasp at anything in the world. MN 37:3.8Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished. MN 37:3.9They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 37:4.1BJ 10.594Then Sakka, lord of gods, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

MN 37:5.1Now at that time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was sitting not far from the Buddha. MN 37:5.2He thought, MN 37:5.3“Did that spirit comprehend what the Buddha said when he agreed with him, or not? MN 37:5.4Why don’t I find out?”

MN 37:6.1And then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the Eastern Monastery and reappeared among the gods of the Thirty-Three. MN 37:7.1Now at that time Sakka was amusing himself in the Single Lotus Park, supplied and provided with a divine orchestra.

MN 37:7.2Seeing Mahāmoggallāna coming off in the distance, MN 37:7.3he dismissed the orchestra, approached Mahāmoggallāna, and said, MN 37:7.4“Come, my good Moggallāna! Welcome, good sir! MN 37:7.5It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here. MN 37:7.6Sit, my good Moggallāna, this seat is for you.” MN 37:7.7Mahāmoggallāna sat down on the seat spread out, MN 37:7.8while Sakka took a low seat and sat to one side.

MN 37:7.9Mahāmoggallāna said to him, MN 37:8.1“Kosiya, how did the Buddha briefly explain freedom through the ending of craving? MN 37:8.10Each tower has seven hundred chambers. MN 37:8.11Each chamber has seven nymphs. MN 37:8.12Each nymph has seven maids. MN 37:8.13Would you like to see the lovely Palace of Victory?” MN 37:8.14Mahāmoggallāna consented in silence.

MN 37:8.2Please share this talk with me so that I can also get to hear it.”

MN 37:8.3PTS-VP-PLI 1.253“My good Moggallāna, I have many duties, and much to do, MN 37:8.4not only for myself, but also for the Gods of the Thirty-Three. MN 37:8.5Besides, I quickly forget even things I’ve properly heard, learned, attended, and memorized. MN 37:8.6Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons. MN 37:8.7In that battle the gods won and the demons lost. MN 37:8.8When I returned from that battle as a conqueror, I created the Palace of Victory. MN 37:8.9The Palace of Victory has a hundred towers.

MN 37:9.1BJ 10.596PTS-VP-PLI 1.254Then, putting Venerable Mahāmoggallāna in front, Sakka, lord of gods, and Vessavaṇa, the Great King, went to the Palace of Victory. MN 37:9.2When they saw Moggallāna coming off in the distance, Sakka’s maids, MN 37:9.3being prudent and discreet, each went to her own bedroom.

MN 38:0.2The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

MN 38:1.1BJ 10.602PTS-VP-PLI 1.257So I have heard. MN 38:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 38:10.1“Does doubt arise when you’re uncertain whether or not this has come to be?”

MN 38:10.2“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:10.3“Does doubt arise when you’re uncertain whether or not this has originated with that as fuel?”

MN 38:10.4“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:10.5“Does doubt arise when you’re uncertain whether or not when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”

MN 38:10.6“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:11.1BJ 10.610“Is doubt given up in someone who truly sees with right understanding that this has come to be?”

MN 38:11.2“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:11.3“Is doubt given up in someone who truly sees with right understanding that this has originated with that as fuel?”

MN 38:11.4“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:11.5“Is doubt given up in someone who truly sees with right understanding that when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”

MN 38:11.6“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:12.1“Are you free of doubt as to whether this has come to be?”

MN 38:12.2“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:12.3“Are you free of doubt as to whether this has originated with that as fuel?”

MN 38:12.4“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:12.5“Are you free of doubt as to whether when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”

MN 38:12.6“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:13.1“Have you truly seen clearly with right understanding that this has come to be?”

MN 38:13.2“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:13.3“Have you truly seen clearly with right understanding that this has originated with that as fuel?”

MN 38:13.4“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:13.5“Have you truly seen clearly with right understanding that when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”

MN 38:13.6“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:14.1“Pure and bright as this view is, mendicants, if you cherish it, fancy it, treasure it, and treat it as your own, would you be understanding how the Dhamma is similar to a raft: for crossing over, not for holding on?”

MN 38:14.2“No, sir.”

MN 38:14.3PTS-VP-PLI 1.261“Pure and bright as this view is, mendicants, if you don’t cherish it, fancy it, treasure it, and treat it as your own, would you be understanding how the Dhamma is similar to a raft: for crossing over, not for holding on?”

MN 38:14.4“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:15.1“Mendicants, there are these four fuels. They maintain sentient beings that have been born and help those that are about to be born. MN 38:15.2What four? MN 38:15.3Solid food, whether coarse or fine; contact is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth.

MN 38:16.1What is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of these four fuels? MN 38:16.10Name and form.

MN 38:16.11And what is the source of name and form? MN 38:16.12Consciousness.

MN 38:16.13And what is the source of consciousness? MN 38:16.14Choices.

MN 38:16.15And what is the source of choices? MN 38:16.16Ignorance.

MN 38:16.2Craving.

MN 38:16.3And what is the source of craving? MN 38:16.4Feeling.

MN 38:16.5BJ 10.612And what is the source of feeling? MN 38:16.6Contact.

MN 38:16.7And what is the source of contact? MN 38:16.8The six sense fields.

MN 38:16.9And what is the source of the six sense fields?

MN 38:17.1So, ignorance is a condition for choices. MN 38:17.10Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. MN 38:17.11Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. MN 38:17.12That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

MN 38:17.2Choices are a condition for consciousness. MN 38:17.3Consciousness is a condition for name and form. MN 38:17.4Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields. MN 38:17.5The six sense fields are conditions for contact. MN 38:17.6Contact is a condition for feeling. MN 38:17.7Feeling is a condition for craving. MN 38:17.8Craving is a condition for grasping. MN 38:17.9Grasping is a condition for continued existence.

MN 38:18.1‘Rebirth is a condition for old age and death.’ That’s what I said. MN 38:18.2Is that how you see this or not?”

MN 38:18.4“That’s how we see it.”

MN 38:18.50BJ 10.616‘Ignorance is a condition for choices.’ That’s what I said. MN 38:18.51Is that how you see this or not?”

MN 38:18.53“That’s how we see it.”

MN 38:18.6PTS-VP-PLI 1.262“‘Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.’ …

MN 38:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.263“Good, mendicants! MN 38:19.10Feeling is a condition for craving. MN 38:19.11Craving is a condition for grasping. MN 38:19.12Grasping is a condition for continued existence. MN 38:19.13Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. MN 38:19.14Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. MN 38:19.15That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

MN 38:19.2So both you and I say this. MN 38:19.3When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises. That is: MN 38:19.4Ignorance is a condition for choices. MN 38:19.5Choices are a condition for consciousness. MN 38:19.6Consciousness is a condition for name and form. MN 38:19.7Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields. MN 38:19.8The six sense fields are conditions for contact. MN 38:19.9Contact is a condition for feeling.

MN 38:2.1Now at that time a mendicant called Sāti, the fisherman’s son, had the following harmful misconception: MN 38:2.2“As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”

MN 38:20.1When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease. MN 38:20.10When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. MN 38:20.11When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. MN 38:20.12That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

MN 38:20.2When choices cease, consciousness ceases. MN 38:20.3When consciousness ceases, name and form cease. MN 38:20.4When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease. MN 38:20.5When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases. MN 38:20.6When contact ceases, feeling ceases. MN 38:20.7When feeling ceases, craving ceases. MN 38:20.8When craving ceases, grasping ceases. MN 38:20.9When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

MN 38:21.1‘When rebirth ceases, old age and death cease.’ That’s what I said. MN 38:21.2Is that how you see this or not?”

MN 38:21.4“That’s how we see it.”

MN 38:21.51‘When ignorance ceases, choices cease.’ That’s what I said. MN 38:21.52Is that how you see this or not?”

MN 38:21.54“That’s how we see it.”

MN 38:21.6‘When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.’ …

MN 38:22.1“Good, mendicants! MN 38:22.10When feeling ceases, craving ceases. MN 38:22.11When craving ceases, grasping ceases. MN 38:22.12When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. MN 38:22.13When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. MN 38:22.14When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. MN 38:22.15That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

MN 38:22.2So both you and I say this. MN 38:22.3When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is: MN 38:22.4When ignorance ceases, choices cease. MN 38:22.5When choices cease, consciousness ceases. MN 38:22.6When consciousness ceases, name and form cease. MN 38:22.7When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease. MN 38:22.8When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases. MN 38:22.9When contact ceases, feeling ceases.

MN 38:23.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.265Knowing and seeing in this way, mendicants, would you turn back to the past, thinking, MN 38:23.2‘Did we exist in the past? Did we not exist in the past? What were we in the past? How were we in the past? After being what, what did we become in the past?’?”

MN 38:23.3“No, sir.”

MN 38:23.4“Knowing and seeing in this way, mendicants, would you turn forward to the future, thinking, MN 38:23.5‘Will we exist in the future? Will we not exist in the future? What will we be in the future? How will we be in the future? After being what, what will we become in the future?’?”

MN 38:23.6“No, sir.”

MN 38:24.1“Knowing and seeing in this way, mendicants, would you be undecided about the present, thinking,

MN 38:24.10“Knowing and seeing in this way, would you acknowledge another teacher?”

MN 38:24.11“No, sir.”

MN 38:24.12“Knowing and seeing in this way, would you believe that the observances and noisy, superstitious rites of the various ascetics and brahmins are the most important things?”

MN 38:24.13“No, sir.”

MN 38:24.14“Aren’t you speaking only of what you have known and seen and realized for yourselves?”

MN 38:24.15“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:24.2‘Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? This sentient being—where did it come from? And where will it go?’?”

MN 38:24.3“No, sir.”

MN 38:24.4BJ 10.622“Knowing and seeing in this way, would you say, MN 38:24.5‘Our teacher is respected. We speak like this out of respect for our teacher.’?”

MN 38:24.6“No, sir.”

MN 38:24.7“Knowing and seeing in this way, would you say, MN 38:24.8‘Our ascetic says this. It’s only because of him that we say this’?”

MN 38:24.9“No, sir.”

MN 38:25.1“Good, mendicants! You have been guided by me with this teaching that’s visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves. MN 38:25.2For when I said that this teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves, MN 38:25.3this is what I was referring to.

MN 38:26.1BJ 10.624PTS-VP-PLI 1.266Mendicants, when three things come together an embryo is conceived. MN 38:26.2In a case where the mother and father come together, but the mother is not in the fertile part of her menstrual cycle, and the spirit being reborn is not present, the embryo is not conceived. MN 38:26.3In a case where the mother and father come together, the mother is in the fertile part of her menstrual cycle, but the spirit being reborn is not present, the embryo is not conceived. MN 38:26.4But when these three things come together—the mother and father come together, the mother is in the fertile part of her menstrual cycle, and the spirit being reborn is present—an embryo is conceived.

MN 38:27.1The mother nurtures the embryo in her womb for nine or ten months at great risk to her heavy burden. MN 38:27.2When nine or ten months have passed, the mother gives birth at great risk to her heavy burden. MN 38:27.3When the infant is born she nourishes it with her own blood. MN 38:27.4For mother’s milk is regarded as blood in the training of the Noble One.

MN 38:28.1That boy grows up and his faculties mature. MN 38:28.2He accordingly plays childish games such as toy plows, tipcat, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, and toy bows.

MN 38:29.1That boy grows up and his faculties mature further. MN 38:29.2He accordingly amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 38:29.3Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

MN 38:29.4Sounds known by the ear …

MN 38:29.5Smells known by the nose …

MN 38:29.6Tastes known by the tongue …

MN 38:29.7Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

MN 38:3.1Several mendicants heard about this. MN 38:3.10In many ways the Buddha has said that consciousness is dependently originated, since without a cause, consciousness does not come to be.”

MN 38:3.11But even though the mendicants pressed him in this way, Sāti obstinately stuck to his misconception and insisted on stating it. MN 38:3.4They went up to Sāti and said to him, MN 38:3.5“Is it really true, Reverend Sāti, that you have such a harmful misconception: MN 38:3.6‘As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another’?”

MN 38:3.7“Absolutely, reverends. As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”

MN 38:3.8Then, wishing to dissuade Sāti from his view, the mendicants pursued, pressed, and grilled him, MN 38:3.9“Don’t say that, Sāti! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.

MN 38:30.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.267When they see a sight with their eyes, if it’s pleasant they desire it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart restricted.

MN 38:30.10When they feel a touch with their body …

MN 38:30.11When they know a thought with their mind, if it’s pleasant they desire it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart restricted. MN 38:30.12And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

MN 38:30.13Being so full of favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it. MN 38:30.14This gives rise to relishing. MN 38:30.15Relishing feelings is grasping. Their grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. MN 38:30.16That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

MN 38:30.2And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

MN 38:30.3Being so full of favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it. MN 38:30.4This gives rise to relishing. MN 38:30.5Relishing feelings is grasping. Their grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. MN 38:30.6That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

MN 38:30.7When they hear a sound with their ears …

MN 38:30.8When they smell an odor with their nose …

MN 38:30.9When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

MN 38:31.1BJ 10.626But consider when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. MN 38:31.2He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. MN 38:31.3He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing. MN 38:31.4He reveals an entirely full and pure spiritual life.

MN 38:32.1A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some good family. MN 38:32.2They gain faith in the Realized One, MN 38:32.3and reflect, MN 38:32.4‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open. MN 38:32.5It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell. MN 38:32.6Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?’ MN 38:32.7After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

MN 38:33.1Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.

MN 38:33.10They avoid dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows. MN 38:33.11They avoid beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, perfumes, and makeup. MN 38:33.12They avoid high and luxurious beds. MN 38:33.13They avoid receiving gold and money, MN 38:33.14raw grains, MN 38:33.15raw meat, MN 38:33.16women and girls, MN 38:33.17male and female bondservants, MN 38:33.18goats and sheep, MN 38:33.19chickens and pigs,

MN 38:33.2PTS-VP-PLI 1.268They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.

MN 38:33.20elephants, cows, horses, and mares, MN 38:33.21and fields and land. MN 38:33.22They avoid running errands and messages; MN 38:33.23buying and selling; MN 38:33.24falsifying weights, metals, or measures; MN 38:33.25bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; MN 38:33.26mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

MN 38:33.3They give up unchastity. They are celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.

MN 38:33.4They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words.

MN 38:33.5They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

MN 38:33.6They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

MN 38:33.7They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

MN 38:33.8BJ 10.628They avoid injuring plants and seeds. MN 38:33.9They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.

MN 38:34.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.269They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things. MN 38:34.2They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden. MN 38:34.3In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things. MN 38:34.4When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

MN 38:35.1When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 38:35.2If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

MN 38:35.3When they hear a sound with their ears …

MN 38:35.4When they smell an odor with their nose …

MN 38:35.5When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

MN 38:35.6When they feel a touch with their body …

MN 38:35.7When they know a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 38:35.8If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint. MN 38:35.9When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.

MN 38:36.1BJ 10.630They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

MN 38:37.1When they have this noble spectrum of ethics, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, MN 38:37.2they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

MN 38:38.1After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. MN 38:38.2Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire. MN 38:38.3Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will. MN 38:38.4Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness. MN 38:38.5Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse. MN 38:38.6Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

MN 38:39.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.270They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. MN 38:39.2Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 38:39.3Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption … MN 38:39.4third absorption … MN 38:39.5fourth absorption.

MN 38:4.1BJ 10.604When they weren’t able to dissuade Sāti from his view, the mendicants went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

MN 38:40.1BJ 10.632PTS-VP-PLI 1.271When they see a sight with their eyes, if it’s pleasant they don’t desire it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart. MN 38:40.2And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

MN 38:40.3Having given up favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to it. MN 38:40.4As a result, relishing of feelings ceases. MN 38:40.5When their relishing ceases, grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. MN 38:40.6That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

MN 38:41.1When they hear a sound with their ears …

MN 38:41.10That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

MN 38:41.11Mendicants, you should memorize that brief statement on freedom through the ending of craving. But the mendicant Sāti, the fisherman’s son, is caught in a vast net of craving, a tangle of craving.”

MN 38:41.12That is what the Buddha said. MN 38:41.13Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 38:5.1BJ 10.606PTS-VP-PLI 1.258So the Buddha addressed a certain monk,

MN 38:5.10“Sāti, what is that consciousness?”

MN 38:5.11“Sir, it is he who speaks and feels and experiences the results of good and bad deeds in all the different realms.”

MN 38:5.12“Silly man, who on earth have you ever known me to teach in that way? MN 38:5.13Haven’t I said in many ways that consciousness is dependently originated, since consciousness does not arise without a cause? MN 38:5.14But still you misrepresent me by your wrong grasp, harm yourself, and make much bad karma. MN 38:5.15This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”

MN 38:5.2“Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Sāti that MN 38:5.3the teacher summons him.”

MN 38:5.4“Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Sāti and said to him, MN 38:5.5“Reverend Sāti, the teacher summons you.”

MN 38:5.6“Yes, reverend,” Sāti replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him, MN 38:5.7“Is it really true, Sāti, that you have such a harmful misconception: MN 38:5.8‘As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another’?”

MN 38:5.9“Absolutely, sir. As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”

MN 38:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.259Then the Buddha said to the mendicants, MN 38:6.2“What do you think, mendicants? MN 38:6.3Has this mendicant Sāti kindled even a spark of wisdom in this teaching and training?”

MN 38:6.4“How could that be, sir? MN 38:6.5No, sir.” MN 38:6.6When this was said, Sāti sat silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

MN 38:6.7Knowing this, the Buddha said, MN 38:6.8“Silly man, you will be known by your own harmful misconception. MN 38:6.9I’ll question the mendicants about this.”

MN 38:7.1Then the Buddha said to the mendicants, MN 38:7.2“Mendicants, do you understand my teachings as Sāti does, when he misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and makes much bad karma?”

MN 38:7.3“No, sir. MN 38:7.4For in many ways the Buddha has told us that consciousness is dependently originated, since without a cause, consciousness does not come to be.”

MN 38:7.5“Good, good, mendicants! MN 38:7.6It’s good that you understand my teaching like this. MN 38:7.7For in many ways I have told you that consciousness is dependently originated, since without a cause, consciousness does not come to be.MN 38:7.8But still this Sāti misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and makes much bad karma. MN 38:7.9This will be for his lasting harm and suffering.

MN 38:8.1BJ 10.608Consciousness is reckoned according to the specific conditions dependent upon which it arises. MN 38:8.10A fire that burns dependent on twigs is reckoned as a twig fire. MN 38:8.11A fire that burns dependent on grass is reckoned as a grass fire. MN 38:8.12A fire that burns dependent on cow-dung is reckoned as a cow-dung fire. MN 38:8.13A fire that burns dependent on husks is reckoned as a husk fire. MN 38:8.14A fire that burns dependent on rubbish is reckoned as a rubbish fire.

MN 38:8.15In the same way, consciousness is reckoned according to the specific conditions dependent upon which it arises. … MN 38:8.2Consciousness that arises dependent on the eye and sights is reckoned as eye consciousness. MN 38:8.3Consciousness that arises dependent on the ear and sounds is reckoned as ear consciousness. MN 38:8.4Consciousness that arises dependent on the nose and smells is reckoned as nose consciousness. MN 38:8.5Consciousness that arises dependent on the tongue and tastes is reckoned as tongue consciousness. MN 38:8.6Consciousness that arises dependent on the body and touches is reckoned as body consciousness. MN 38:8.7Consciousness that arises dependent on the mind and thoughts is reckoned as mind consciousness.

MN 38:8.8PTS-VP-PLI 1.260It’s like fire, which is reckoned according to the specific conditions dependent upon which it burns. MN 38:8.9A fire that burns dependent on logs is reckoned as a log fire.

MN 38:9.1Mendicants, do you see that this has come to be?”

MN 38:9.2“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:9.3“Do you see that it originated with that as fuel?”

MN 38:9.4“Yes, sir.”

MN 38:9.5“Do you see that when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”

MN 38:9.6“Yes, sir.”

  • MN 39:0.1Middle Discourses 39

MN 39:0.2The Longer Discourse at Assapura

MN 39:1.1So I have heard. MN 39:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅgas, near the Aṅgan town named Assapura. MN 39:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 39:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 39:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 39:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 39:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.274What more is there to do? MN 39:10.2You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will be dedicated to wakefulness. When practicing walking and sitting meditation by day, we will purify our mind from obstacles. MN 39:10.3In the evening, we will continue to practice walking and sitting meditation. MN 39:10.4In the middle of the night, we will lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up. MN 39:10.5In the last part of the night, we will get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying our mind from obstacles.’ MN 39:10.6Now, mendicants, you might think, MN 39:10.7‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, our sense doors are restrained, we don’t eat too much, and we are dedicated to wakefulness. MN 39:10.8Just this much is enough …’

MN 39:11.1BJ 10.640What more is there to do? MN 39:11.2You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will have situational awareness and mindfulness. We will act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.’ MN 39:11.3Now, mendicants, you might think, MN 39:11.4‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, our sense doors are restrained, we don’t eat too much, we are dedicated to wakefulness, and we have mindfulness and situational awareness. MN 39:11.5Just this much is enough …’

MN 39:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.275What more is there to do? MN 39:12.2Take a mendicant who frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

MN 39:13.1After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. MN 39:13.2Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire. MN 39:13.3Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will. MN 39:13.4Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness. MN 39:13.5Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse. MN 39:13.6Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

MN 39:14.1Suppose a man who has gotten into debt were to apply himself to work, MN 39:14.10Thinking about this, MN 39:14.12they’d be filled with joy and happiness.

MN 39:14.13Suppose a person was imprisoned in a jail. MN 39:14.14But after some time they were released from jail, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth. MN 39:14.15Thinking about this, MN 39:14.17they’d be filled with joy and happiness.

MN 39:14.18BJ 10.642PTS-VP-PLI 1.276Suppose a person was a bondservant. They belonged to someone else and were unable to go where they wished. MN 39:14.19But after some time they’d be freed from servitude and become their own master, an emancipated individual able to go where they wished. MN 39:14.2and his efforts proved successful. MN 39:14.20Thinking about this, MN 39:14.22they’d be filled with joy and happiness.

MN 39:14.23Suppose there was a person with wealth and property who was traveling along a desert road. MN 39:14.24But after some time they crossed over the desert, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth. MN 39:14.25Thinking about this, MN 39:14.28they’d be filled with joy and happiness.

MN 39:14.29In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing. MN 39:14.3He would pay off the original loan and have enough left over to support his partner. MN 39:14.30But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and sanctuary.

MN 39:14.4Thinking about this, MN 39:14.7he’d be filled with joy and happiness.

MN 39:14.8Suppose a person was sick, suffering, and gravely ill. They’d lose their appetite and get physically weak. MN 39:14.9But after some time they’d recover from that illness, and regain their appetite and their strength.

MN 39:15.1They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. MN 39:15.2Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 39:15.3They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. MN 39:15.4It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.

MN 39:15.5In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.

MN 39:16.1BJ 10.644PTS-VP-PLI 1.277Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 39:16.2They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion. MN 39:16.3It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and no rainfall to replenish it from time to time. But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.

MN 39:16.4In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.

MN 39:17.1Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 39:17.2They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture. MN 39:17.3It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.

MN 39:17.4In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.

MN 39:18.1BJ 10.646PTS-VP-PLI 1.278Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 39:18.2They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind. MN 39:18.3It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.

MN 39:18.4In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.

MN 39:19.1When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives. MN 39:19.2They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details. MN 39:19.3Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village. They’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’

MN 39:19.4In the same way, a mendicant recollects their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

MN 39:2.1“Mendicants, people label you as ascetics. MN 39:2.2And when they ask you what you are, you claim to be ascetics.

MN 39:2.3Given this label and this claim, you should train like this: ‘We will undertake and follow the things that make one an ascetic and a brahmin. That way our label will be accurate and our claim correct. MN 39:2.4Any robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick that we use will be very fruitful and beneficial for the donor. And our going forth will not be wasted, but will be fruitful and fertile.’

MN 39:20.1BJ 10.648PTS-VP-PLI 1.279When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 39:20.2With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds. MN 39:20.3Suppose there were two houses with doors. A person with good eyesight standing in between them would see people entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.

MN 39:20.4In the same way, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

MN 39:21.1When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 39:21.10‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’

MN 39:21.11In the same way, a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ MN 39:21.12They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 39:21.2They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ MN 39:21.3They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’ MN 39:21.4Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 39:21.5When they’re freed, they know they’re freed. MN 39:21.6They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 39:21.7BJ 10.650PTS-VP-PLI 1.280Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with good eyesight standing on the bank would see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still. MN 39:21.9They’d think:

MN 39:22.1This mendicant is called an ‘ascetic’, a ‘brahmin’, a ‘bathed initiate’, a ‘knowledge master’, a ‘scholar’, a ‘noble one’, and a ‘perfected one’.

MN 39:23.1And how is a mendicant an ascetic? MN 39:23.2They have quelled the bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. MN 39:23.3That’s how a mendicant is an ascetic.

MN 39:24.1And how is a mendicant a brahmin? MN 39:24.2They have banished the bad, unskillful qualities. MN 39:24.3That’s how a mendicant is a brahmin.

MN 39:25.1And how is a mendicant a bathed initiate? MN 39:25.2They have bathed off the bad, unskillful qualities. MN 39:25.3That’s how a mendicant is a bathed initiate.

MN 39:26.1And how is a mendicant a knowledge master? MN 39:26.2They have known the bad, unskillful qualities. MN 39:26.3That’s how a mendicant is a knowledge master.

MN 39:27.1And how is a mendicant a scholar? MN 39:27.2They have scoured off the bad, unskillful qualities. MN 39:27.3That’s how a mendicant is a scholar.

MN 39:28.1And how is a mendicant a noble one? MN 39:28.2They are far away from the bad, unskillful qualities. MN 39:28.3That’s how a mendicant is a noble one.

MN 39:29.1And how is a mendicant a perfected one? MN 39:29.2They are far away from the bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. MN 39:29.3That’s how a mendicant is a perfected one.”

MN 39:29.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 39:29.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 39:3.1BJ 10.634And what are the things that make one an ascetic and a brahmin? MN 39:3.2You should train like this: ‘We will have conscience and prudence.’ MN 39:3.3Now, mendicants, you might think, MN 39:3.4‘We have conscience and prudence. Just this much is enough. We have achieved the goal of life as an ascetic. There is nothing more to do.’ And you might rest content with just that much. MN 39:3.5I declare this to you, mendicants, I announce this to you: MN 39:3.6‘You who seek to be true ascetics, do not lose sight of the goal of the ascetic life while there is still more to do.’

MN 39:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.272What more is there to do? MN 39:4.2You should train like this: ‘Our bodily behavior will be pure, clear, open, neither inconsistent nor secretive. MN 39:4.3And we won’t glorify ourselves or put others down on account of our pure bodily behavior.’ MN 39:4.4Now, mendicants, you might think, MN 39:4.5‘We have conscience and prudence, and our bodily behavior is pure. MN 39:4.6Just this much is enough …’ MN 39:4.7I declare this to you, mendicants, I announce this to you: MN 39:4.8‘You who seek to be true ascetics, do not lose sight of the goal of the ascetic life while there is still more to do.’

MN 39:5.1What more is there to do? MN 39:5.2You should train like this: ‘Our verbal behavior … MN 39:6.2mental behavior … MN 39:7.2livelihood will be pure, clear, open, neither inconsistent nor secretive. MN 39:7.3And we won’t glorify ourselves or put others down on account of our pure livelihood.’ MN 39:7.4Now, mendicants, you might think, MN 39:7.5‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, and our livelihood is pure. MN 39:7.6Just this much is enough. We have achieved the goal of life as an ascetic. There is nothing more to do.’ And you might rest content with just that much. MN 39:7.7I declare this to you, mendicants, I announce this to you: MN 39:7.8‘You who seek to be true ascetics, do not lose sight of the goal of the ascetic life while there is still more to do.’

MN 39:8.1What more is there to do? MN 39:8.10If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, we will practice restraint, we will protect the faculty of mind, and we will achieve its restraint.’ MN 39:8.11Now, mendicants, you might think, MN 39:8.12‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, and our sense doors are restrained. MN 39:8.13Just this much is enough …’ MN 39:8.2You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will restrain our sense doors. MN 39:8.3When we see a sight with our eyes, we won’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 39:8.4If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, we will practice restraint, we will protect the faculty of sight, and we will achieve its restraint. MN 39:8.5When we hear a sound with our ears … MN 39:8.6When we smell an odor with our nose … MN 39:8.7When we taste a flavor with our tongue … MN 39:8.8When we feel a touch with our body … MN 39:8.9When we know a thought with our mind, we won’t get caught up in the features and details.

MN 39:9.1BJ 10.638What more is there to do? MN 39:9.2You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will not eat too much. We will only eat after reflecting properly on our food. MN 39:9.3We will eat not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, we shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and we will live blamelessly and at ease.’ MN 39:9.4Now, mendicants, you might think, MN 39:9.5‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, our sense doors are restrained, and we don’t eat too much. MN 39:9.6Just this much is enough …’

MN 40:0.2The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

MN 40:1.1BJ 10.652PTS-VP-PLI 1.281So I have heard. MN 40:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅgas, near the Aṅgan town named Assapura. MN 40:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 40:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 40:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 40:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 40:10-12.1They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …

MN 40:10-12.2They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

MN 40:10-12.3They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

MN 40:13.1Suppose there was a lotus pond with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful. MN 40:13.2Then along comes a person—whether from the east, west, north, or south—struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. MN 40:13.3No matter what direction they come from, when they arrive at that lotus pond they would alleviate their thirst and heat exhaustion.

MN 40:13.4In the same way, suppose someone has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness—whether from a family of aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, or workers—and has arrived at the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One. Having developed love, compassion, rejoicing, and equanimity in this way they gain inner peace. MN 40:13.5Because of that inner peace they are practicing the way proper for an ascetic, I say.

MN 40:14.1BJ 10.660And suppose someone has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness—whether from a family of aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, or workers—MN 40:14.2and they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements. MN 40:14.3They’re an ascetic because of the ending of defilements.”

MN 40:14.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 40:14.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 40:2.1“Mendicants, people label you as ascetics. MN 40:2.2And when they ask you what you are, you claim to be ascetics.

MN 40:2.3Given this label and this claim, you should train like this: ‘We will practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic. That way our label will be accurate and our claim correct. MN 40:2.6Any robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick that we use will be very fruitful and beneficial for the donor. And our going forth will not be wasted, but will be fruitful and fertile.’

MN 40:3.1And how does a mendicant not practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic?

MN 40:3.2There are some mendicants who have not given up covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view. MN 40:3.3These stains, defects, and dregs of an ascetic are grounds for rebirth in places of loss, and are experienced in bad places. As long as they have not given these up, they do not practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic, I say. MN 40:4.1I say that such a mendicant’s going forth may be compared to the kind of weapon called ‘death-dealer’—double-edged, hardened, and keen—covered and wrapped in the outer robe.

MN 40:5.1BJ 10.654PTS-VP-PLI 1.282I say that you don’t deserve the label ‘outer robe wearer’ just because you wear an outer robe. MN 40:5.10You don’t deserve the label ‘matted-hair ascetic’ just because you have matted hair.

MN 40:5.2You don’t deserve the label ‘naked ascetic’ just because you go naked. MN 40:5.3You don’t deserve the label ‘dust and dirt wearer’ just because you’re caked in dust and dirt. MN 40:5.4You don’t deserve the label ‘water immerser’ just because you immerse yourself in water. MN 40:5.5You don’t deserve the label ‘tree root dweller’ just because you stay at the root of a tree. MN 40:5.6You don’t deserve the label ‘open air dweller’ just because you stay in the open air. MN 40:5.7You don’t deserve the label ‘stander’ just because you continually stand. MN 40:5.8You don’t deserve the label ‘interval eater’ just because you eat food at set intervals. MN 40:5.9You don’t deserve the label ‘reciter’ just because you recite scriptures.

MN 40:6.1Imagine that just by wearing an outer robe someone with covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view could give up these things. If that were the case, your friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would make you an outer robe wearer as soon as you were born. They’d encourage you: MN 40:6.10eating at set intervals … MN 40:6.11reciting scriptures … MN 40:6.12having matted hair someone with covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view could give up these things. If that were the case, your friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would make you a matted-hair ascetic as soon as you were born. They’d encourage you: MN 40:6.13‘Please, my dear, become a matted-hair ascetic! By doing so you will give up covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view.’ MN 40:6.14But sometimes I see someone with these bad qualities who is a matted-hair ascetic. That’s why I say that you don’t deserve the label ‘matted-hair ascetic’ just because you have matted hair.

MN 40:6.2‘Please, my dear, wear an outer robe! By doing so you will give up covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view.’ MN 40:6.3But sometimes I see someone with these bad qualities who is an outer robe wearer. That’s why I say that you don’t deserve the label ‘outer robe wearer’ just because you wear an outer robe.

MN 40:6.4BJ 10.656PTS-VP-PLI 1.283Imagine that just by going naked … MN 40:6.5wearing dust and dirt … MN 40:6.6immersing in water … MN 40:6.7staying at the root of a tree … MN 40:6.8staying in the open air … MN 40:6.9standing continually …

MN 40:7.1BJ 10.658And how does a mendicant practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic?

MN 40:7.2There are some mendicants who have given up covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view. MN 40:7.3These stains, defects, and dregs of an ascetic are grounds for rebirth in places of loss, and are experienced in bad places. When they have given these up, they are practicing in the way that is proper for an ascetic, I say.

MN 40:8.1They see themselves purified from all these bad, unskillful qualities. MN 40:8.2Seeing this, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

MN 40:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.284They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
