MN 41:0.2The People of Sālā

MN 41:1.1BJ 10.662PTS-VP-PLI 1.285So I have heard. MN 41:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Sālā.

MN 41:10.1BJ 10.666And how is unprincipled and immoral conduct threefold by way of mind? MN 41:10.2It's when a certain person is covetous. They covet the wealth and belongings of others: ‘Oh, if only their belongings were mine!’

MN 41:10.3They have ill will and malicious intentions: ‘May these sentient beings be killed, slaughtered, slain, destroyed, or annihilated!’

MN 41:10.4They have wrong view. Their perspective is distorted: MN 41:10.5‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no obligation to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’ MN 41:10.6This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of mind.

MN 41:10.7That’s how unprincipled and immoral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

MN 41:11.1Householders, principled and moral conduct is threefold by way of body, fourfold by way of speech, and threefold by way of mind.

MN 41:12.1And how is principled and moral conduct threefold by way of body? MN 41:12.2It’s when a certain person gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.

MN 41:12.3They give up stealing. They don’t, with the intention to commit theft, take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.

MN 41:12.4PTS-VP-PLI 1.288They give up sexual misconduct. They don’t have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They don’t have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal. MN 41:12.5This is how principled and moral conduct is threefold by way of body.

MN 41:13.1BJ 10.668And how is principled and moral conduct fourfold by way of speech? MN 41:13.2It’s when a certain person gives up lying. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, mister, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I see.’ So they don’t deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.

MN 41:13.3They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

MN 41:13.4They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable, and agreeable to the people.

MN 41:13.5They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial. MN 41:13.6This is how principled and moral conduct is fourfold by way of speech.

MN 41:14.1And how is principled and moral conduct threefold by way of mind? MN 41:14.2It's when a certain person is not covetous. They don’t covet the wealth and belongings of others: ‘Oh, if only their belongings were mine!’

MN 41:14.3They have a kind heart and loving intentions: ‘May these sentient beings live free of enmity and ill will, untroubled and happy!’

MN 41:14.4They have right view, an undistorted perspective: MN 41:14.5‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There is obligation to mother and father. There are beings reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are well attained and practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’ MN 41:14.6This is how principled and moral conduct is threefold by way of mind.

MN 41:14.7This is how principled and moral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

MN 41:15.1BJ 10.670PTS-VP-PLI 1.289A person of principled and moral conduct might wish: MN 41:15.2‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats!’ MN 41:15.3It’s possible that this might happen. MN 41:15.4Why is that? MN 41:15.5Because they have principled and moral conduct.

MN 41:16-17.1A person of principled and moral conduct might wish: MN 41:16-17.2‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do brahmins … MN 41:16-17.3well-to-do householders … MN 41:18-42.10the Gods Who Love to Create … MN 41:18-42.11the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others … MN 41:18-42.12the Gods of Brahmā’s Host … MN 41:18-42.17the Radiant Gods … MN 41:18-42.2the Gods of the Four Great Kings … MN 41:18-42.22the Gods of Limited Radiance … MN 41:18-42.23the Gods of Limitless Radiance … MN 41:18-42.24the Gods of Streaming Radiance … MN 41:18-42.25the Gods of Limited Glory … MN 41:18-42.26the Gods of Limitless Glory … MN 41:18-42.27the Gods Replete with Glory … MN 41:18-42.28the Gods of Abundant Fruit … MN 41:18-42.29the Gods of Aviha … MN 41:18-42.30the Gods of Atappa … MN 41:18-42.31the Gods Fair to See … MN 41:18-42.32the Fair Seeing Gods … MN 41:18-42.33the Gods of Akaniṭṭha … MN 41:18-42.34the gods of the dimension of infinite space … MN 41:18-42.35the gods of the dimension of infinite consciousness … MN 41:18-42.36the gods of the dimension of nothingness … MN 41:18-42.37the gods of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’ MN 41:18-42.38It’s possible that this might happen. MN 41:18-42.39Why is that? MN 41:18-42.40Because they have principled and moral conduct.

MN 41:18-42.7the Gods of the Thirty-Three … MN 41:18-42.8the Gods of Yama … MN 41:18-42.9the Joyful Gods …

MN 41:2.1The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard, MN 41:2.2“It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. MN 41:2.3He has this good reputation: MN 41:2.4‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ MN 41:2.5He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. MN 41:2.6He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing. MN 41:2.7He reveals an entirely full and pure spiritual life. MN 41:2.8It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

MN 41:3.1Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. Seated to one side they said to the Buddha:

MN 41:4.1“What is the cause, Master Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell? MN 41:4.2And what is the cause, Master Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm?”

MN 41:43.1BJ 10.672A person of principled and moral conduct might wish: MN 41:43.2‘If only I might realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’ MN 41:43.3It’s possible that this might happen. MN 41:43.4Why is that? MN 41:43.5Because they have principled and moral conduct.”

MN 41:44.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.290When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Sālā said to the Buddha, MN 41:44.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! MN 41:44.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways. MN 41:44.4We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 41:44.5From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

MN 41:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.286“Unprincipled and immoral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 41:5.2Principled and moral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

MN 41:6.1BJ 10.664“We don’t understand the detailed meaning of Master Gotama’s brief statement. MN 41:6.2Master Gotama, please teach us this matter in detail so we can understand the meaning.”

MN 41:6.3“Well then, householders, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 41:6.4“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 41:6.5The Buddha said this:

MN 41:7.1“Householders, unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of body, fourfold by way of speech, and threefold by way of mind.

MN 41:8.1And how is unprincipled and immoral conduct threefold by way of body? MN 41:8.2It’s when a certain person kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.

MN 41:8.3They steal. With the intention to commit theft, they take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.

MN 41:8.4They commit sexual misconduct. They have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal. MN 41:8.5This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of body.

MN 41:9.1And how is unprincipled and immoral conduct fourfold by way of speech? MN 41:9.2It’s when a certain person lies. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, mister, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ So they deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.

MN 41:9.3They speak divisively. They repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. And so they divide those who are harmonious, supporting division, delighting in division, loving division, speaking words that promote division.

MN 41:9.4PTS-VP-PLI 1.287They speak harshly. They use the kinds of words that are cruel, nasty, hurtful, offensive, bordering on anger, not leading to immersion.

MN 41:9.5They talk nonsense. Their speech is untimely, and is neither factual nor beneficial. It has nothing to do with the teaching or the training. Their words have no value, and are untimely, unreasonable, rambling, and pointless. MN 41:9.6This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is fourfold by way of speech.

  • MN 42:0.1Middle Discourses 42

MN 42:0.2The People of Verañja

MN 42:1.1So I have heard. MN 42:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 42:2.1Now at that time the brahmins and householders of Verañja were residing in Sāvatthī on some business. MN 42:2.2The brahmins and householders of Verañja heard:

MN 42:2.3“It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—is staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 42:2.4He has this good reputation …” …

MN 42:7.1“Householders, a person of unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of body, fourfold by way of speech, and threefold by way of mind. …” …

MN 42:8.1BJ 10.676(The remainder of this discourse is identical with MN 41.)

  • MN 43:0.1Middle Discourses 43

MN 43:0.2The Great Classification

MN 43:1.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.292So I have heard. MN 43:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 43:1.3Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 43:1.4When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Sāriputta:

MN 43:10.1“What can be known by purified mind consciousness released from the five senses?”

MN 43:10.2“Aware that ‘space is infinite’ it can know the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’ it can know the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’ it can know the dimension of nothingness.”

MN 43:11.1“How do you understand something that can be known?”

MN 43:11.2“You understand something that can be known with the eye of wisdom.”

MN 43:12.1“What is the purpose of wisdom?”

MN 43:12.2“The purpose of wisdom is direct knowledge, complete understanding, and giving up.”

MN 43:13.1BJ 10.690PTS-VP-PLI 1.294“How many conditions are there for the arising of right view?”

MN 43:13.2“There are two conditions for the arising of right view: MN 43:13.3the words of another and proper attention. MN 43:13.4These are the two conditions for the arising of right view.”

MN 43:14.1“When right view is supported by how many factors does it have freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit?”

MN 43:14.2“When right view is supported by five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit. MN 43:14.3It’s when right view is supported by ethics, learning, discussion, serenity, and discernment. MN 43:14.4When right view is supported by these five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.”

MN 43:15.1“How many states of existence are there?”

MN 43:15.2“Reverend, there are these three states of existence. MN 43:15.3Existence in the sensual realm, the realm of luminous form, and the formless realm.”

MN 43:16.1“But how is there rebirth into a new state of existence in the future?”

MN 43:16.2“It’s because of sentient beings—hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving—taking pleasure in various different realms. MN 43:16.3That’s how there is rebirth into a new state of existence in the future.”

MN 43:17.1“But how is there no rebirth into a new state of existence in the future?”

MN 43:17.2“It’s when ignorance fades away, knowledge arises, and craving ceases. MN 43:17.3That’s how there is no rebirth into a new state of existence in the future.”

MN 43:18.1“But what, reverend, is the first absorption?”

MN 43:18.2“Reverend, it’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 43:18.3This is called the first absorption.”

MN 43:19.1“But how many factors does the first absorption have?”

MN 43:19.2“The first absorption has five factors. MN 43:19.3When a mendicant has entered the first absorption, placing the mind, keeping it connected, rapture, bliss, and unification of mind are present. MN 43:19.4That’s how the first absorption has five factors.”

MN 43:2.1“Reverend, they speak of ‘a witless person’. MN 43:2.2How is a witless person defined?”

MN 43:2.3“Reverend, they’re called witless because they don’t understand. MN 43:2.4And what don’t they understand? MN 43:2.5They don’t understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ MN 43:2.6They’re called witless because they don’t understand.”

MN 43:2.7BJ 10.686Saying “Good, reverend,” Mahākoṭṭhita approved and agreed with what Sāriputta said. Then he asked another question:

MN 43:20.1BJ 10.692“But how many factors has the first absorption given up and how many does it possess?”

MN 43:20.2PTS-VP-PLI 1.295“The first absorption has given up five factors and possesses five factors. MN 43:20.3When a mendicant has entered the first absorption, sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt are given up. MN 43:20.4Placing the mind, keeping it connected, rapture, bliss, and unification of mind are present. MN 43:20.5That’s how the first absorption has given up five factors and possesses five factors.”

MN 43:21.1“Reverend, these five faculties have different scopes and different ranges, and don’t experience each others’ scope and range. That is, MN 43:21.2the faculties of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body. MN 43:21.3What do these five faculties, with their different scopes and ranges, have recourse to? What experiences their scopes and ranges?”

MN 43:21.6“These five faculties, with their different scopes and ranges, have recourse to the mind. And the mind experiences their scopes and ranges.”

MN 43:22.10“Warmth depends on life to continue.”

MN 43:22.11“Just now I understood you to say: MN 43:22.12‘Life depends on warmth to continue.’ MN 43:22.13But I also understood you to say: MN 43:22.14‘Warmth depends on life to continue.’ MN 43:22.15How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”

MN 43:22.16BJ 10.694“Well then, reverend, I shall give you a simile. MN 43:22.17For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said. MN 43:22.18Suppose there was an oil lamp burning. The light appears dependent on the flame, and the flame appears dependent on the light. MN 43:22.19In the same way, life depends on warmth to continue, and warmth depends on life to continue.”

MN 43:22.3“These five faculties depend on what to continue?”

MN 43:22.6“These five faculties depend on life to continue.”

MN 43:22.7“But what does life depend on to continue?”

MN 43:22.8“Life depends on warmth to continue.”

MN 43:22.9“But what does warmth depend on to continue?”

MN 43:23.1“Are the life forces the same things as the phenomena that are felt? Or are they different things?”

MN 43:23.2PTS-VP-PLI 1.296“The life forces are not the same things as the phenomena that are felt. MN 43:23.3For if the life forces and the phenomena that are felt were the same things, a mendicant who had attained the cessation of perception and feeling would not emerge from it. MN 43:23.4But because the life forces and the phenomena that are felt are different things, a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling can emerge from it.”

MN 43:24.1“How many things must this body lose before it lies forsaken, tossed aside like an insentient log?”

MN 43:24.2“This body must lose three things before it lies forsaken, tossed aside like an insentient log: vitality, warmth, and consciousness.”

MN 43:25.1“What’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling?”

MN 43:25.2“When someone dies, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled; their vitality is spent; their warmth is dissipated; and their faculties have disintegrated. MN 43:25.3When a mendicant has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled. But their vitality is not spent; their warmth is not dissipated; and their faculties are very clear. MN 43:25.4That’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling.”

MN 43:26.1“How many conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart?”

MN 43:26.2BJ 10.696“Four conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart. MN 43:26.3Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 43:26.4These four conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart.”

MN 43:27.1“How many conditions are necessary to attain the signless release of the heart?”

MN 43:27.2“Two conditions are necessary to attain the signless release of the heart: MN 43:27.3not focusing on any signs, and focusing on the signless. MN 43:27.4These two conditions are necessary to attain the signless release of the heart.”

MN 43:27.5“How many conditions are necessary to remain in the signless release of the heart?”

MN 43:28.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.297“Three conditions are necessary to remain in the signless release of the heart: MN 43:28.2not focusing on any signs, focusing on the signless, and a previous determination. MN 43:28.3These three conditions are necessary to remain in the signless release of the heart.”

MN 43:29.1“How many conditions are necessary to emerge from the signless release of the heart?”

MN 43:29.2“Two conditions are necessary to emerge from the signless release of the heart: MN 43:29.3focusing on all signs, and not focusing on the signless. MN 43:29.4These two conditions are necessary to emerge from the signless release of the heart.”

MN 43:29.5“The limitless release of the heart, and the release of the heart through nothingness, and the release of the heart through emptiness, and the signless release of the heart: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”

MN 43:3.1“They speak of ‘a wise person’. MN 43:3.2How is a wise person defined?”

MN 43:3.3“They’re called wise because they understand. MN 43:3.4And what do they understand? MN 43:3.5They understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ MN 43:3.6They’re called wise because they understand.”

MN 43:30.1BJ 10.698“There is a way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing. MN 43:30.2But there’s also a way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.

MN 43:31.1And what’s the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing?

MN 43:31.2Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will. MN 43:31.3They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion … MN 43:31.4They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing … MN 43:31.5They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will. MN 43:31.6This is called the limitless release of the heart.

MN 43:32.1And what is the release of the heart through nothingness? MN 43:32.2It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. MN 43:32.3This is called the heart’s release through nothingness.

MN 43:33.1And what is the release of the heart through emptiness? MN 43:33.2PTS-VP-PLI 1.298It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this: MN 43:33.3‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’ MN 43:33.4This is called the release of the heart through emptiness.

MN 43:34.1And what is the signless release of the heart? MN 43:34.2It’s when a mendicant, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart. MN 43:34.3This is called the signless release of the heart.

MN 43:34.4This is the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.

MN 43:35.1BJ 10.700And what’s the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?

MN 43:35.2Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of limits. MN 43:35.3A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future. MN 43:35.4The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of limitless release of the heart. MN 43:35.5That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.

MN 43:36.1Greed is something, hate is something, and delusion is something. MN 43:36.2A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future. MN 43:36.3The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of release of the heart through nothingness. MN 43:36.4That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.

MN 43:37.1Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of signs. MN 43:37.2A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future. MN 43:37.3The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of signless release of the heart. MN 43:37.4That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.

MN 43:37.5This is the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”

MN 43:37.6This is what Venerable Sāriputta said. MN 43:37.7Satisfied, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita was happy with what Sāriputta said.

MN 43:4.1“They speak of ‘consciousness’. MN 43:4.2How is consciousness defined?”

MN 43:4.3“It’s called consciousness because it cognizes. MN 43:4.4And what does it cognize? MN 43:4.5It cognizes ‘pleasure’ and ‘pain’ and ‘neutral’. MN 43:4.6It’s called consciousness because it cognizes.”

MN 43:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.293“Wisdom and consciousness—MN 43:5.2are these things mixed or separate? MN 43:5.3And can we completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them?”

MN 43:5.4“Wisdom and consciousness—MN 43:5.5these things are mixed, not separate. MN 43:5.6And you can never completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them. MN 43:5.7For you understand what you cognize, and you cognize what you understand. MN 43:5.8That’s why these things are mixed, not separate. MN 43:5.9And you can never completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them.”

MN 43:6.1“Wisdom and consciousness—MN 43:6.2what is the difference between these things that are mixed, not separate?”

MN 43:6.4“The difference between these things is that wisdom should be developed, while consciousness should be completely understood.”

MN 43:7.1“They speak of this thing called ‘feeling’. MN 43:7.2How is feeling defined?”

MN 43:7.3BJ 10.688“It’s called feeling because it feels. MN 43:7.4And what does it feel? MN 43:7.5It feels pleasure, pain, and neutral. MN 43:7.6It’s called feeling because it feels.”

MN 43:8.1“They speak of this thing called ‘perception’. MN 43:8.2How is perception defined?”

MN 43:8.3“It’s called perception because it perceives. MN 43:8.4And what does it perceive? MN 43:8.5It perceives blue, yellow, red, and white. MN 43:8.6It’s called perception because it perceives.”

MN 43:9.1“Feeling, perception, and consciousness—MN 43:9.2are these things mixed or separate? MN 43:9.3And can we completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them?”

MN 43:9.4“Feeling, perception, and consciousness—MN 43:9.5these things are mixed, not separate. MN 43:9.6And you can never completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them. MN 43:9.7For you perceive what you feel, and you cognize what you perceive. MN 43:9.8That’s why these things are mixed, not separate. MN 43:9.9And you can never completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them.”

  • MN 44:0.1Middle Discourses 44

MN 44:0.2The Shorter Classification

MN 44:1.1BJ 10.702PTS-VP-PLI 1.299So I have heard. MN 44:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

MN 44:1.3Then the layman Visākha went to see the nun Dhammadinnā, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to her:

MN 44:10.1“But ma’am, is the noble eightfold path conditioned or unconditioned?”

MN 44:10.2PTS-VP-PLI 1.301“The noble eightfold path is conditioned.”

MN 44:11.1“Are the three practice categories included in the noble eightfold path? Or is the noble eightfold path included in the three practice categories?”

MN 44:11.2“The three practice categories are not included in the noble eightfold path. Rather, the noble eightfold path is included in the three practice categories. MN 44:11.3Right speech, right action, and right livelihood: these things are included in the category of ethics. MN 44:11.4Right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion: these things are included in the category of immersion. MN 44:11.5Right view and right thought: these things are included in the category of wisdom.”

MN 44:12.1“But ma’am, what is immersion? What things are the foundations of immersion? What things are the prerequisites for immersion? What is the development of immersion?”

MN 44:12.2“Unification of the mind is immersion. MN 44:12.3The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the foundations of immersion. MN 44:12.4The four right efforts are the prerequisites for immersion. MN 44:12.5The cultivation, development, and making much of these very same things is the development of immersion.”

MN 44:13.1“How many processes are there?”

MN 44:13.2“There are these three processes. MN 44:13.3Physical, verbal, and mental processes.”

MN 44:14.1“But ma’am, what is the physical process? What’s the verbal process? What’s the mental process?”

MN 44:14.2“Breathing is a physical process. Placing the mind and keeping it connected are verbal processes. Perception and feeling are mental processes.”

MN 44:15.1BJ 10.708“But ma’am, why is breathing a physical process? Why are placing the mind and keeping it connected verbal processes? Why are perception and feeling mental processes?”

MN 44:15.2“Breathing is physical. It’s tied up with the body, that’s why breathing is a physical process. MN 44:15.3First you place the mind and keep it connected, then you break into speech. That’s why placing the mind and keeping it connected are verbal processes. MN 44:15.4Perception and feeling are mental. They’re tied up with the mind, that’s why perception and feeling are mental processes.”

MN 44:16.1“But ma’am, how does someone attain the cessation of perception and feeling?”

MN 44:16.2“A mendicant who is entering such an attainment does not think: MN 44:16.3‘I will enter the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I am entering the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I have entered the cessation of perception and feeling.’ MN 44:16.4Rather, their mind has been previously developed so as to lead to such a state.”

MN 44:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.302“But ma’am, which cease first for a mendicant who is entering the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental processes?”

MN 44:17.2“Verbal processes cease first, then physical, then mental.”

MN 44:18.1“But ma’am, how does someone emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling?”

MN 44:18.2“A mendicant who is emerging from such an attainment does not think: MN 44:18.3‘I will emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I am emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I have emerged from the cessation of perception and feeling.’ MN 44:18.4Rather, their mind has been previously developed so as to lead to such a state.”

MN 44:19.1BJ 10.710“But ma’am, which arise first for a mendicant who is emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental processes?”

MN 44:19.2“Mental processes arise first, then physical, then verbal.”

MN 44:2.1“Ma’am, they speak of this thing called ‘identity’. MN 44:2.2What is this identity that the Buddha spoke of?”

MN 44:2.3“Visākha, the Buddha said that these five grasping aggregates are identity. MN 44:2.4That is: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness. MN 44:2.5The Buddha said that these five grasping aggregates are identity.”

MN 44:2.6Saying “Good, ma’am,” Visākha approved and agreed with what Dhammadinnā said. Then he asked another question:

MN 44:20.1“But ma’am, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, how many kinds of contact do they experience?”

MN 44:20.2“They experience three kinds of contact: emptiness, signless, and undirected contacts.”

MN 44:21.1“But ma’am, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, what does their mind slant, slope, and incline to?”

MN 44:21.2“Their mind slants, slopes, and inclines to seclusion.”

MN 44:22.1“But ma’am, how many feelings are there?”

MN 44:22.2“There are three feelings: MN 44:22.3pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling.”

MN 44:23.1“What are these three feelings?”

MN 44:23.2PTS-VP-PLI 1.303“Anything felt physically or mentally as pleasant or enjoyable. MN 44:23.3This is pleasant feeling. MN 44:23.4Anything felt physically or mentally as painful or unpleasant. MN 44:23.5This is painful feeling. MN 44:23.6Anything felt physically or mentally as neither pleasurable nor painful. MN 44:23.7This is neutral feeling.”

MN 44:24.1“What is pleasant and what is painful in each of the three feelings?”

MN 44:24.2BJ 10.712“Pleasant feeling is pleasant when it remains and painful when it perishes. MN 44:24.3Painful feeling is painful when it remains and pleasant when it perishes. MN 44:24.4Neutral feeling is pleasant when there is knowledge, and painful when there is ignorance.”

MN 44:25.1“What underlying tendencies underlie each of the three feelings?”

MN 44:25.2“The underlying tendency for greed underlies pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency for repulsion underlies painful feeling. The underlying tendency for ignorance underlies neutral feeling.”

MN 44:26.1“Do these underlying tendencies always underlie these feelings?”

MN 44:26.2“No, they do not.”

MN 44:27.1“What should be given up in regard to each of these three feelings?”

MN 44:27.2“The underlying tendency to greed should be given up when it comes to pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency to repulsion should be given up when it comes to painful feeling. The underlying tendency to ignorance should be given up when it comes to neutral feeling.”

MN 44:28.1“Should these underlying tendencies be given up regarding all instances of these feelings?”

MN 44:28.10With this they give up ignorance, and the underlying tendency to ignorance does not lie within that.”

MN 44:28.2BJ 10.714PTS-VP-PLI 1.304“No, not in all instances. MN 44:28.3Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 44:28.4With this they give up greed, and the underlying tendency to greed does not lie within that. MN 44:28.5And take a mendicant who reflects: MN 44:28.6‘Oh, when will I enter and remain in the same dimension that the noble ones enter and remain in today?’ MN 44:28.7Nursing such a longing for the supreme liberations gives rise to sadness due to longing. MN 44:28.8With this they give up repulsion, and the underlying tendency to repulsion does not lie within that. MN 44:28.9Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

MN 44:29.1“But ma’am, what is the counterpart of pleasant feeling?”

MN 44:29.10“Freedom.”

MN 44:29.11“What is the counterpart of freedom?”

MN 44:29.12“Extinguishment.”

MN 44:29.13BJ 10.716“What is the counterpart of extinguishment?”

MN 44:29.14“Your question goes too far, Visākha. You couldn’t figure out the limit of questions. MN 44:29.15For extinguishment is the culmination, destination, and end of the spiritual life. MN 44:29.16If you wish, go to the Buddha and ask him this question. You should remember it in line with his answer.”

MN 44:29.2“Painful feeling.”

MN 44:29.3“What is the counterpart of painful feeling?”

MN 44:29.4“Pleasant feeling.”

MN 44:29.5“What is the counterpart of neutral feeling?”

MN 44:29.6“Ignorance.”

MN 44:29.7“What is the counterpart of ignorance?”

MN 44:29.8“Knowledge.”

MN 44:29.9“What is the counterpart of knowledge?”

MN 44:3.1“Ma’am, they speak of this thing called ‘the origin of identity’. MN 44:3.2What is the origin of identity that the Buddha spoke of?”

MN 44:3.3“It’s the craving that leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure in various different realms. That is, MN 44:3.4craving for sensual pleasures, craving to continue existence, and craving to end existence. MN 44:3.5The Buddha said that this is the origin of identity.”

MN 44:30.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.305And then the layman Visākha approved and agreed with what the nun Dhammadinnā said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled her, keeping her on his right. Then he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, MN 44:30.2and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.

MN 44:30.3When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him, MN 44:30.4“The nun Dhammadinnā is astute, Visākha, she has great wisdom. MN 44:30.5If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as the nun Dhammadinnā. MN 44:30.6That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”

MN 44:30.7That is what the Buddha said. MN 44:30.8Satisfied, the layman Visākha was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 44:4.1“Ma’am, they speak of this thing called ‘the cessation of identity’. MN 44:4.2What is the cessation of identity that the Buddha spoke of?”

MN 44:4.3“It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it. MN 44:4.4The Buddha said that this is the cessation of identity.”

MN 44:5.1“Ma’am, they speak of the practice that leads to the cessation of identity. MN 44:5.2What is the practice that leads to the cessation of identity that the Buddha spoke of?”

MN 44:5.3BJ 10.704“The practice that leads to the cessation of identity that the Buddha spoke of is simply this noble eightfold path, that is: MN 44:5.4right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.”

MN 44:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.300“But ma’am, is that grasping the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates? Or is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another?”

MN 44:6.2“That grasping is not the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates. Nor is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another. MN 44:6.3The desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates is the grasping there.”

MN 44:7.1“But ma’am, how does identity view come about?”

MN 44:7.2“It’s when an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 44:7.3They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form. MN 44:7.4They regard feeling … MN 44:7.5perception … MN 44:7.6choices … MN 44:7.7consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness. MN 44:7.8That’s how identity view comes about.”

MN 44:8.1“But ma’am, how does identity view not come about?”

MN 44:8.2“It’s when an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 44:8.3They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form. MN 44:8.4They don’t regard feeling … MN 44:8.5perception … MN 44:8.6choices … MN 44:8.7consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness. MN 44:8.8That’s how identity view does not come about.”

MN 44:9.1BJ 10.706“But ma’am, what is the noble eightfold path?”

MN 44:9.2“It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is: MN 44:9.3right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.”

  • MN 45:0.1Middle Discourses 45

MN 45:0.2The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

MN 45:1.1BJ 10.718So I have heard. MN 45:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 45:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 45:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 45:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 45:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 45:2.1“Mendicants, there are these four ways of taking up practices. MN 45:2.2What four? MN 45:2.3There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain. MN 45:2.4There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain. MN 45:2.5There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure. MN 45:2.6There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.

MN 45:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.306And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain? MN 45:3.10And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings. MN 45:3.11They say, MN 45:3.12‘This is that future danger that those ascetics and brahmins saw. For it is because of sensual pleasures that I’m feeling painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.’

MN 45:3.2There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 45:3.3‘There’s nothing wrong with sensual pleasures.’ MN 45:3.4They throw themselves into sensual pleasures, MN 45:3.5cavorting with female wanderers with fancy hair-dos. MN 45:3.6They say, MN 45:3.7‘What future danger do those ascetics and brahmins see in sensual pleasures that they speak of giving up sensual pleasures, and advocate the complete understanding of sensual pleasures? MN 45:3.8Pleasant is the touch of this female wanderer’s arm, tender, soft, and downy!’ And they throw themselves into sensual pleasures. MN 45:3.9When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

MN 45:4.1BJ 10.720PTS-VP-PLI 1.307Suppose that in the last month of summer a camel’s foot creeper pod were to burst open MN 45:4.10‘What future danger did my friends see when they said: MN 45:4.11‘Do not fear, sir, do not fear! MN 45:4.12Hopefully that seed will be swallowed by a peacock, or eaten by a deer, or burnt by a forest fire, or picked up by a lumberjack, or eaten by termites, or it may not even be fertile.’ MN 45:4.13Pleasant is the touch of this creeper’s tender, soft, and downy tendrils.’ MN 45:4.14Then the creeper enfolded the sal tree, MN 45:4.15made a canopy over it, MN 45:4.16draped a curtain around it, MN 45:4.17and split apart all the main branches. MN 45:4.18Then the deity thought, MN 45:4.19‘This is the future danger that my friends saw! MN 45:4.2and a seed were to fall at the root of a sal tree. MN 45:4.21It’s because of that camel’s foot creeper seed that I’m feeling painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.’

MN 45:4.22BJ 10.722In the same way, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: ‘There’s nothing wrong with sensual pleasures’ … MN 45:4.3Then the deity haunting that sal tree would become apprehensive and nervous. MN 45:4.34This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain.

MN 45:4.4But their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin—deities of the parks, forests, trees, and those who haunt the herbs, grass, and big trees—would come together to reassure them, MN 45:4.5‘Do not fear, sir, do not fear! MN 45:4.6Hopefully that seed will be swallowed by a peacock, or eaten by a deer, or burnt by a forest fire, or picked up by a lumberjack, or eaten by termites, or it may not even be fertile.’ MN 45:4.7But none of these things happened. And the seed was fertile, so that when the clouds soaked it with rain, it sprouted. MN 45:4.8And the creeper wound its tender, soft, and downy tendrils around that sal tree. MN 45:4.9Then the deity thought,

MN 45:5.1And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain? MN 45:5.10They stand forever, refusing seats. MN 45:5.11They squat, committed to persisting in the squatting position. MN 45:5.12They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed. MN 45:5.13They’re committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening. MN 45:5.14And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body. MN 45:5.15When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 45:5.16This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.

MN 45:5.2It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on purpose for them, or an invitation for a meal. MN 45:5.3They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drink no beer. MN 45:5.4They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls. MN 45:5.5They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day. MN 45:5.6They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.

MN 45:5.7BJ 10.724PTS-VP-PLI 1.308They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.

MN 45:5.8They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings. MN 45:5.9They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.

MN 45:6.1And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure? MN 45:6.2It’s when someone is ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They often feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring. MN 45:6.5They lead the full and pure spiritual life in pain and sadness, weeping, with tearful faces. MN 45:6.6When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 45:6.7This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure.

MN 45:7.1BJ 10.726PTS-VP-PLI 1.309And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure? MN 45:7.10This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure. MN 45:7.11These are the four ways of taking up practices.”

MN 45:7.12That is what the Buddha said. MN 45:7.13Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 45:7.2It’s when someone is not ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They rarely feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring. MN 45:7.5Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption … MN 45:7.6second absorption … MN 45:7.7third absorption … MN 45:7.8fourth absorption. MN 45:7.9When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

MN 46:0.2The Great Discourse on Taking Up Practices

MN 46:1.1BJ 10.728PTS-VP-PLI 1.310So I have heard. MN 46:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 46:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 46:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 46:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 46:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 46:10.1When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, a wise person, knowing this, truly understands: MN 46:10.2‘This is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.’ MN 46:10.3So instead of cultivating that practice, they avoid it. MN 46:10.4When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things increase. MN 46:10.5Why is that? MN 46:10.6Because that’s what it’s like for someone who knows.

MN 46:11.1When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pain, a wise person … MN 46:11.3doesn’t cultivate it … MN 46:11.4and agreeable things increase …

MN 46:12.1BJ 10.734When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pleasure, a wise person … MN 46:12.3cultivates it … MN 46:12.4and agreeable things increase …

MN 46:13.1When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure, a wise person, knowing this, truly understands: MN 46:13.2‘This is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.’ MN 46:13.3So instead of avoiding that practice, they cultivate it. MN 46:13.4When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things increase. MN 46:13.5Why is that? MN 46:13.6Because that’s what it’s like for someone who knows.

MN 46:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.313And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain? MN 46:14.12And when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 46:14.13This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.

MN 46:14.2It’s when someone in pain and sadness kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view. Because of these things they experience pain and sadness.

MN 46:15.1BJ 10.736PTS-VP-PLI 1.314And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain? MN 46:15.12But when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 46:15.13This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain.

MN 46:15.2It’s when someone with pleasure and happiness kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view. Because of these things they experience pleasure and happiness.

MN 46:16.1BJ 10.738PTS-VP-PLI 1.315And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure? MN 46:16.12But when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 46:16.13This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure.

MN 46:16.2It’s when someone in pain and sadness doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. Because of these things they experience pain and sadness.

MN 46:17.1And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure? MN 46:17.12And when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 46:17.13This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure. MN 46:17.14These are the four ways of taking up practices.

MN 46:17.2It’s when someone with pleasure and happiness doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. Because of these things they experience pleasure and happiness.

MN 46:18.1BJ 10.740PTS-VP-PLI 1.316Suppose there was some bitter gourd mixed with poison. MN 46:18.2Then a man would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. MN 46:18.3They’d say to him: MN 46:18.4‘Here, mister, this is bitter gourd mixed with poison. MN 46:18.5Drink it if you like. MN 46:18.6If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be unappetizing, and it will result in death or deadly pain.’ MN 46:18.7He wouldn’t reject it. Without reflection, he’d drink it. MN 46:18.8The color, aroma, and flavor would be unappetizing, and it would result in death or deadly pain. MN 46:18.9This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, I say.

MN 46:19.1Suppose there was a bronze cup of beverage that had a nice color, aroma, and flavor. MN 46:19.10The color, aroma, and flavor would be appetizing, but it would result in death or deadly pain. MN 46:19.11This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pain, I say.

MN 46:19.2But it was mixed with poison. MN 46:19.3Then a man would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. MN 46:19.4They’d say to him: MN 46:19.5‘Here, mister, this bronze cup of beverage has a nice color, aroma, and flavor. MN 46:19.6But it’s mixed with poison. MN 46:19.7Drink it if you like. MN 46:19.8If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be appetizing, but it will result in death or deadly pain.’ MN 46:19.9He wouldn’t reject it. Without reflection, he’d drink it.

MN 46:2.1“Mendicants, sentient beings typically have the wish, desire, and hope: MN 46:2.2‘Oh, if only unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things would decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things would increase!’ MN 46:2.3But exactly the opposite happens to them. MN 46:2.4What do you take to be the reason for this?”

MN 46:2.5“Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

MN 46:2.6“Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 46:2.7“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 46:2.8The Buddha said this:

MN 46:20.1Suppose there was some fermented urine mixed with different medicines. MN 46:20.2Then a man with jaundice would come along. MN 46:20.3They’d say to him: MN 46:20.4‘Here, mister, this is fermented urine mixed with different medicines. Drink it if you like. MN 46:20.5If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be unappetizing, but after drinking it you will be happy.’ MN 46:20.6He wouldn’t reject it. After appraisal, he’d drink it. MN 46:20.7The color, aroma, and flavor would be unappetizing, but after drinking it he would be happy. MN 46:20.8This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pleasure, I say.

MN 46:21.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.317Suppose there was some curds, honey, ghee, and molasses all mixed together. MN 46:21.2Then a man with dysentery would come along. MN 46:21.3They’d say to him: MN 46:21.4‘Here, mister, this is curds, honey, ghee, and molasses all mixed together. Drink it if you like. MN 46:21.5If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be appetizing, and after drinking it you will be happy.’ MN 46:21.6He wouldn’t reject it. After appraisal, he’d drink it. MN 46:21.7The color, aroma, and flavor would be appetizing, and after drinking it he would be happy. MN 46:21.8This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure, I say.

MN 46:22.1BJ 10.742It’s like the time after the rainy season when the sky is clear and cloudless. And when the sun rises, it dispels all the darkness from the sky as it shines and glows and radiates. MN 46:22.2In the same way, this way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure dispels the doctrines of the various other ascetics and brahmins as it shines and glows and radiates.”

MN 46:22.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 46:22.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 46:3.1“Take an uneducated ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 46:3.2They don’t know what practices they should cultivate and foster, and what practices they shouldn’t cultivate and foster. MN 46:3.3So they cultivate and foster practices they shouldn’t, and don’t cultivate and foster practices they should. MN 46:3.4When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things increase, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things decrease. MN 46:3.5Why is that? MN 46:3.6Because that’s what it’s like for someone who doesn’t know.

MN 46:4.1BJ 10.730But an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 46:4.2They know what practices they should cultivate and foster, and what practices they shouldn’t cultivate and foster. MN 46:4.3So they cultivate and foster practices they should, and don’t cultivate and foster practices they shouldn’t. MN 46:4.4When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things increase. MN 46:4.5Why is that? MN 46:4.6Because that’s what it’s like for someone who knows.

MN 46:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.311Mendicants, there are these four ways of taking up practices. MN 46:5.2What four? MN 46:5.3There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain. MN 46:5.4There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain. MN 46:5.5There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure. MN 46:5.6There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.

MN 46:6.1When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, an ignoramus, without knowing this, doesn’t truly understand: MN 46:6.2‘This is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.’ MN 46:6.3So instead of avoiding that practice, they cultivate it. MN 46:6.4When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things increase, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things decrease. MN 46:6.5Why is that? MN 47:0.2The Inquirer

MN 47:1.1BJ 10.744PTS-VP-PLI 1.318So I have heard. MN 47:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 47:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 47:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 47:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 47:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 47:10.1BJ 10.748If others should ask that mendicant, MN 47:10.2‘But what reason and evidence does the venerable have for saying this?’ MN 47:10.5Answering rightly, the mendicant should say, MN 47:10.6‘Because, whether that venerable is staying in a community or alone, some people there are in a good state or a sorry state, some instruct a group, and some indulge in material pleasures, while others remain unsullied. Yet that venerable doesn’t look down on them for that. MN 47:10.7Also, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 47:10.8“I am securely stopped, not insecurely stopped. The reason I don’t indulge in sensual pleasures is that I’m free of greed because greed has ended.”’

MN 47:11.1Next, they should ask the Realized One himself about this, MN 47:11.2‘Can anything corrupt be seen or heard in the Realized One or not?’ MN 47:11.3The Realized One would answer, MN 47:11.4‘Nothing corrupt can be seen or heard in the Realized One.’

MN 47:12.1‘Can anything mixed be seen or heard in the Realized One or not?’ MN 47:12.2The Realized One would answer, MN 47:12.3‘Nothing mixed can be seen or heard in the Realized One.’

MN 47:13.1‘Can anything clean be seen or heard in the Realized One or not?’ MN 47:13.2The Realized One would answer, MN 47:13.3‘Clean things can be seen and heard in the Realized One. MN 47:13.4I am that range and that territory, but I do not identify with that.’

MN 47:14.1BJ 10.750PTS-VP-PLI 1.320A disciple ought to approach a teacher who has such a doctrine in order to listen to the teaching. MN 47:14.2The teacher explains Dhamma with its higher and higher stages, with its better and better stages, with its dark and bright sides. MN 47:14.3When they directly know a certain principle of those teachings, in accordance with how they were taught, the mendicant comes to a conclusion about the teachings. They have confidence in the teacher: MN 47:14.4‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha! The teaching is well explained! The Saṅgha is practicing well!’

MN 47:15.1If others should ask that mendicant, MN 47:15.2‘But what reason and evidence does the venerable have for saying this?’ MN 47:15.4Answering rightly, the mendicant should say, MN 47:15.5‘Reverends, I approached the Buddha to listen to the teaching. MN 47:15.6He explained Dhamma with its higher and higher stages, with its better and better stages, with its dark and bright sides. MN 47:15.7When I directly knew a certain principle of those teachings, in accordance with how I was taught, I came to a conclusion about the teachings. I had confidence in the Teacher: MN 47:15.8“The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha! The teaching is well explained! The Saṅgha is practicing well!”’

MN 47:16.1When someone’s faith is settled, rooted, and planted in the Realized One in this manner, with these words and phrases, it’s said to be grounded faith that’s based on evidence. MN 47:16.2It is firm, and cannot be shifted by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world. MN 47:16.3This is how to scrutinize the Realized One’s qualities. MN 47:16.4But the Realized One has already been properly searched in this way by nature.”

MN 47:16.5That is what the Buddha said. MN 47:16.6Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 47:2.1“Mendicants, a mendicant who is an inquirer, unable to comprehend another’s mind, should scrutinize the Realized One to see whether he is a fully awakened Buddha or not.”

MN 47:3.1“Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

MN 47:3.2“Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 47:3.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 47:3.4The Buddha said this:

MN 47:4.1“Mendicants, a mendicant who is an inquirer, unable to comprehend another’s mind, should scrutinize the Realized One for two things—things that can be seen and heard: MN 47:4.2‘Can anything corrupt be seen or heard in the Realized One or not?’ MN 47:4.3Scrutinizing him they find that MN 47:4.4nothing corrupt can be seen or heard in the Realized One.

MN 47:5.2They scrutinize further: MN 47:5.3‘Can anything mixed be seen or heard in the Realized One or not?’ MN 47:5.4Scrutinizing him they find that MN 47:5.5nothing mixed can be seen or heard in the Realized One.

MN 47:6.2They scrutinize further: MN 47:6.3‘Can anything clean be seen or heard in the Realized One or not?’ MN 47:6.4Scrutinizing him they find that MN 47:6.5clean things can be seen and heard in the Realized One.

MN 47:7.2They scrutinize further: MN 47:7.3‘Did the venerable attain this skillful state a long time ago, or just recently?’ MN 47:7.4Scrutinizing him they find that MN 47:7.5the venerable attained this skillful state a long time ago, not just recently.

MN 47:8.2They scrutinize further: MN 47:8.3‘Are certain dangers found in that venerable mendicant who has achieved fame and renown?’ MN 47:8.4For, mendicants, so long as a mendicant has not achieved fame and renown, certain dangers are not found in them. MN 47:8.5But when they achieve fame and renown, those dangers appear. MN 47:8.6Scrutinizing him they find that MN 47:8.7those dangers are not found in that venerable mendicant who has achieved fame and renown.

MN 47:9.2They scrutinize further: MN 47:9.3‘Is this venerable securely stopped or insecurely stopped? MN 47:9.4Is the reason they don’t indulge in sensual pleasures that they’re free of greed because greed has ended?’ MN 47:9.5Scrutinizing him they find that MN 47:9.6that venerable is securely stopped, not insecurely stopped. MN 47:9.7The reason they don’t indulge in sensual pleasures is that they’re free of greed because greed has ended.
