MN 48:0.2The Mendicants of Kosambi

MN 48:1.1BJ 10.752PTS-VP-PLI 1.321So I have heard. MN 48:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

MN 48:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.324Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects, MN 48:10.2‘Are there any ascetics or brahmins outside of the Buddhist community who have the same kind of view that I have?’ MN 48:10.3They understand, MN 48:10.4‘There are no ascetics or brahmins outside of the Buddhist community who have the same kind of view that I have.’ MN 48:10.5This is their third knowledge …

MN 48:11.1BJ 10.760Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects, MN 48:11.10And having revealed it they restrain themselves in the future. MN 48:11.11They understand, MN 48:11.12‘I have the same nature as a person accomplished in view.’ MN 48:11.13This is their fourth knowledge …

MN 48:11.2‘Do I have the same nature as a person accomplished in view?’ MN 48:11.3And what, mendicants, is the nature of a person accomplished in view? MN 48:11.4This is the nature of a person accomplished in view. MN 48:11.5Though they may fall into a kind of offense for which rehabilitation has been laid down, they quickly disclose, clarify, and reveal it to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion. MN 48:11.6And having revealed it they restrain themselves in the future. MN 48:11.7Suppose there was a little baby boy. If he puts his hand or foot on a burning coal, he quickly pulls it back. MN 48:11.8In the same way, this is the nature of a person accomplished in view. MN 48:11.9Though they may still fall into a kind of offense for which rehabilitation has been laid down, they quickly reveal it to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion.

MN 48:12.1Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects, MN 48:12.10‘I have the same nature as a person accomplished in view.’ MN 48:12.11This is their fifth knowledge …

MN 48:12.2‘Do I have the same nature as a person accomplished in view?’ MN 48:12.3And what, mendicants, is the nature of a person accomplished in view? MN 48:12.4This is the nature of a person accomplished in view. MN 48:12.5Though they might manage a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, they still feel a keen regard for the training in higher ethics, higher mind, and higher wisdom. MN 48:12.6Suppose there was a cow with a baby calf. She keeps the calf close as she grazes. MN 48:12.7In the same way, this is the nature of a person accomplished in view. MN 48:12.8Though they might manage a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, they still feel a keen regard for the training in higher ethics, higher mind, and higher wisdom. MN 48:12.9They understand,

MN 48:13.1BJ 10.762PTS-VP-PLI 1.325Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects, MN 48:13.2‘Do I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view?’ MN 48:13.3And what, mendicants, is the strength of a person accomplished in view? MN 48:13.4The strength of a person accomplished in view is that, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, they pay heed, pay attention, engage wholeheartedly, and lend an ear. MN 48:13.5They understand, MN 48:13.6‘I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view.’ MN 48:13.7This is their sixth knowledge …

MN 48:14.1Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects, MN 48:14.2‘Do I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view?’ MN 48:14.3And what, mendicants, is the strength of a person accomplished in view? MN 48:14.4The strength of a person accomplished in view is that, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching. MN 48:14.5They understand, MN 48:14.6‘I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view.’ MN 48:14.7This is the seventh knowledge they have achieved that is noble and transcendent, and is not shared with ordinary people.

MN 48:15.1When a noble disciple has these seven factors, they have properly investigated their own nature with respect to the realization of the fruit of stream-entry. MN 48:15.2A noble disciple with these seven factors has the fruit of stream-entry.”

MN 48:15.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 48:15.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 48:2.1Now at that time the mendicants of Kosambi were arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words. MN 48:2.2They couldn’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor could they convince each other or be convinced.

MN 48:3.1Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.

MN 48:4.1BJ 10.754PTS-VP-PLI 1.322So the Buddha addressed a certain monk, MN 48:4.2“Please, monk, in my name tell those mendicants that MN 48:4.3the teacher summons them.

MN 48:4.4“Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those monks and said, MN 48:4.5“Venerables, the teacher summons you.”

MN 48:4.6“Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them,

MN 48:4.7“Is it really true, mendicants, that you have been arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words? MN 48:4.8And that you can’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor can you convince each other or be convinced?”

MN 48:4.9“Yes, sir,” they said.

MN 48:5.1“What do you think, mendicants? MN 48:5.2When you’re arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words, are you treating your spiritual companions with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private?”

MN 48:5.3“No, sir.”

MN 48:5.4“So it seems that when you’re arguing you are not treating each other with kindness. MN 48:5.5So what exactly do you know and see, you foolish men, that you behave in such a way? MN 48:5.6This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”

MN 48:6.1Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

MN 48:6.10Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material possessions they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions …

MN 48:6.12BJ 10.756Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion. …

MN 48:6.14Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. MN 48:6.15This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

MN 48:6.16PTS-VP-PLI 1.323These six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

MN 48:6.2“Mendicants, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling. MN 48:6.3What six? MN 48:6.4Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private. MN 48:6.5This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

MN 48:6.6Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness …

MN 48:6.8Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness …

MN 48:7.1Of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. It holds and binds everything together. MN 48:7.2It’s like a bungalow. The roof-peak is the chief point, which holds and binds everything together. MN 48:7.3In the same way, of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. It holds and binds everything together.

MN 48:8.1BJ 10.758And how does the view that is noble and emancipating lead one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering? MN 48:8.10pursuing speculation about the next world, MN 48:8.11or arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding others with barbed words, it’s their mind that’s overcome. MN 48:8.12They understand, MN 48:8.13‘There is nothing that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see. MN 48:8.14My mind is properly disposed for awakening to the truths.’ MN 48:8.15This is the first knowledge they have achieved that is noble and transcendent, and is not shared with ordinary people.

MN 48:8.2It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this, MN 48:8.3‘Is there anything that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see?’ MN 48:8.4If a mendicant is overcome with sensual desire, it’s their mind that’s overcome. MN 48:8.5If a mendicant is overcome with ill will, MN 48:8.6dullness and drowsiness, MN 48:8.7restlessness and remorse, MN 48:8.8doubt, MN 48:8.9pursuing speculation about this world,

MN 48:9.1Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects, MN 48:9.2‘When I develop, cultivate, and make much of this view, do I personally gain serenity and quenching?’ MN 48:9.3They understand, MN 48:9.4‘When I develop, cultivate, and make much of this view, I personally gain serenity and quenching.’ MN 48:9.5This is their second knowledge …

  • MN 49:0.1Middle Discourses 49

MN 49:0.2On the Invitation of Brahmā

MN 49:1.1BJ 10.764PTS-VP-PLI 1.326So I have heard. MN 49:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 49:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 49:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 49:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 49:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 49:10.1BJ 10.770But there is another realm that you don’t know or see. MN 49:10.10So Brahmā, I am not your equal in knowledge, still less your inferior. MN 49:10.11Rather, I know more than you.

MN 49:10.2But I know it and see it. MN 49:10.3There is the realm named after the gods of streaming radiance. You passed away from there and were reborn here. MN 49:10.4You’ve dwelt here so long that you’ve forgotten about that, so you don’t know it or see it. MN 49:10.5But I know it and see it. MN 49:10.6So Brahmā, I am not your equal in knowledge, still less your inferior. MN 49:10.7Rather, I know more than you.

MN 49:10.8There is the realm named after the gods replete with glory … the realm named after the gods of abundant fruit … the realm named after the Overlord, which you don’t know or see. MN 49:10.9But I know it and see it.

MN 49:11.1Having directly known earth as earth, and having directly known that which does not fall within the scope of experience based on earth, I did not identify with earth, I did not identify regarding earth, I did not identify as earth, I did not identify ‘earth is mine’, I did not enjoy earth. MN 49:11.2So Brahmā, I am not your equal in knowledge, still less your inferior. MN 49:11.3Rather, I know more than you.

MN 49:12.1Having directly known water … MN 49:13.1fire … MN 49:14.1air … MN 49:15.1creatures … MN 49:16.1gods … MN 49:17.1the Creator … MN 49:18.1Brahmā … MN 49:19.1the gods of streaming radiance …

MN 49:2.1“At one time, mendicants, I was staying near Ukkaṭṭhā, in the Subhaga Forest at the root of a magnificent sal tree. MN 49:2.2Now at that time Baka the Brahmā had the following harmful misconception: MN 49:2.3‘This is permanent, this is everlasting, this is eternal, this is whole, this is imperishable. For this is where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn. And there’s no other escape beyond this.’

MN 49:20.1the gods replete with glory … MN 49:21.1the gods of abundant fruit … MN 49:22.1the Overlord … MN 49:23.1Having directly known all as all, and having directly known that which does not fall within the scope of experience based on all, I did not identify with all, I did not identify regarding all, I did not identify as all, I did not identify ‘all is mine’, I did not enjoy all. MN 49:23.2So Brahmā, I am not your equal in knowledge, still less your inferior. MN 49:23.3Rather, I know more than you.’

MN 49:24.1‘Well, good sir, if you have directly known that which is not within the scope of experience based on all, may your words not turn out to be void and hollow!

MN 49:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.330Consciousness that is invisible, infinite, entirely given up—that’s what is not within the scope of experience based on earth, water, fire, air, creatures, gods, the Creator, Brahmā, the gods of streaming radiance, the gods replete with glory, the gods of abundant fruit, the Overlord, and the all.

MN 49:26.1BJ 10.772Well look now, good sir, I will vanish from you!’

MN 49:26.10And while invisible I recited this verse:

MN 49:26.2‘All right, then, Brahmā, vanish from me—if you can.’

MN 49:26.3Then Baka the Brahmā said, MN 49:26.4‘I will vanish from the ascetic Gotama! I will vanish from the ascetic Gotama!’ But he was unable to vanish from me.

MN 49:26.5So I said to him, MN 49:26.6‘Well look now, Brahmā, I will vanish from you!’

MN 49:26.7‘All right, then, good sir, vanish from me—if you can.’

MN 49:26.8Then I used my psychic power to will that MN 49:26.9my voice would extend so that Brahmā, his assembly, and his retinue would hear me, but they would not see me.

MN 49:27.1‘Seeing the danger in continued existence—MN 49:27.2that life in any existence will cease to be—MN 49:27.3I didn’t welcome any kind of existence, MN 49:27.4and didn’t grasp at relishing.’

MN 49:28.1Then Brahmā, his assembly, and his retinue, their minds full of wonder and amazement, thought, MN 49:28.2‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing! MN 49:28.3The ascetic Gotama has such psychic power and might! We’ve never before seen or heard of any other ascetic or brahmin with psychic power and might like the ascetic Gotama, who has gone forth from the Sakyan clan. MN 49:28.4Though people enjoy continued existence, loving it so much, he has extracted it, root and all.’

MN 49:29.1BJ 10.774PTS-VP-PLI 1.331Then Māra the Wicked took possession of a member of Brahmā’s retinue and said this to me, MN 49:29.10When their bodies broke up and their breath was cut off they were reborn in a higher realm.

MN 49:29.11So, mendicant, I tell you this: MN 49:29.12please, good sir, remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life, for this is better left unsaid. Good sir, do not instruct others.’

MN 49:29.2‘If such is your understanding, good sir, do not present it to your disciples or those gone forth! MN 49:29.3Do not teach this Dhamma to your disciples or those gone forth! MN 49:29.4Do not wish this for your disciples or those gone forth!

MN 49:29.5There have been ascetics and brahmins before you, mendicant, who claimed to be perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas. MN 49:29.6They presented, taught, and wished this for their disciples and those gone forth. MN 49:29.7When their bodies broke up and their breath was cut off they were reborn in a lower realm.

MN 49:29.8But there have also been other ascetics and brahmins before you, mendicant, who claimed to be perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas. MN 49:29.9They did not present, teach, or wish this for their disciples and those gone forth.

MN 49:3.1Then I knew what Baka the Brahmā was thinking. MN 49:3.2As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, I vanished from the Subhaga Forest and reappeared in that Brahmā realm.

MN 49:3.3Baka saw me coming off in the distance MN 49:3.4and said, MN 49:3.5‘Come, good sir! Welcome, good sir! MN 49:3.6It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here. MN 49:3.7For this is permanent, this is everlasting, this is eternal, this is complete, this is imperishable. For this is where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn. And there’s no other escape beyond this.’

MN 49:30.1When he had spoken, I said to Māra, MN 49:30.10But I am. MN 49:30.11The Realized One remains as such whether or not he teaches disciples. MN 49:30.12The Realized One remains as such whether or not he presents the teaching to disciples. MN 49:30.13Why is that? MN 49:30.14Because the Realized One has given up the defilements—corruptions that lead to future lives and are hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. MN 49:30.15He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future. MN 49:30.16Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth, MN 49:30.17the Realized One has given up the defilements—corruptions that lead to future lives and are hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. MN 49:30.18He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future.’”

MN 49:30.2‘I know you, Wicked One. Do not think, MN 49:30.3“He doesn’t know me.” MN 49:30.4You are Māra the Wicked. MN 49:30.5You don’t speak to me like this out of compassion, MN 49:30.6but with no compassion. MN 49:30.7For you think, MN 49:30.8“Those who the ascetic Gotama teaches will go beyond my reach.”

MN 49:30.9Those who formerly claimed to be fully awakened Buddhas were not in fact fully awakened Buddhas.

MN 49:31.1And so, because of the silencing of Māra, and because of the invitation of Brahmā, the name of this discussion is “On the Invitation of Brahmā”.

MN 49:4.1When he had spoken, I said to him, MN 49:4.2‘Alas, Baka the Brahmā is lost in ignorance! Alas, Baka the Brahmā is lost in ignorance! MN 49:4.3Because what is actually impermanent, not lasting, transient, incomplete, and perishable, he says is permanent, everlasting, eternal, complete, and imperishable. MN 49:4.4And where there is being born, growing old, dying, passing away, and being reborn, he says that MN 49:4.5there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn. MN 49:4.6And although there is another escape beyond this, he says that there’s no other escape beyond this.’

MN 49:5.1BJ 10.766PTS-VP-PLI 1.327Then Māra the Wicked took possession of a member of Brahmā’s retinue and said this to me, MN 49:5.10Please, dear sir, do exactly what Brahmā says. Don’t go beyond the word of Brahmā. MN 49:5.11Do you not see the assembly of Brahmā gathered here?’

MN 49:5.12And that is how Māra the Wicked presented the assembly of Brahmā to me as an example.

MN 49:5.2‘Mendicant, mendicant! Don’t attack this one! Don’t attack this one! For this is Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Undefeated, the Champion, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, the Lord God, the Maker, the Author, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.

MN 49:5.3There have been ascetics and brahmins before you, mendicant, who criticized and loathed earth, water, air, fire, creatures, gods, the Creator, and Brahmā. MN 49:5.4When their bodies broke up and their breath was cut off they were reborn in a lower realm.

MN 49:5.5There have been ascetics and brahmins before you, mendicant, who praised and approved earth, water, air, fire, creatures, gods, the Creator, and Brahmā. MN 49:5.6When their bodies broke up and their breath was cut off they were reborn in a higher realm.

MN 49:5.7So, mendicant, I tell you this: MN 49:5.8please, good sir, do exactly what Brahmā says. Don’t go beyond the word of Brahmā. MN 49:5.9If you do, then the consequence for you will be like that of a person who, when Lady Luck approaches, wards her off with a staff, or someone who shoves away the ground as they fall down the abyss into hell.

MN 49:6.1When he had spoken, I said to Māra, MN 49:6.2‘I know you, Wicked One. Do not think, MN 49:6.3“He does not know me.” MN 49:6.4You are Māra the Wicked. MN 49:6.5And Brahmā, Brahmā’s assembly, and Brahmā’s retinue have all fallen into your hands; they’re under your sway. MN 49:6.6And you think, MN 49:6.7“Maybe this one, too, has fallen into my hands; maybe he’s under my sway!” MN 49:6.8But I haven’t fallen into your hands; I’m not under your sway.’

MN 49:7.1BJ 10.768PTS-VP-PLI 1.328When I had spoken, Baka the Brahmā said to me, MN 49:7.10If you attach to water … MN 49:7.11fire … MN 49:7.12air … MN 49:7.13creatures … MN 49:7.14gods … MN 49:7.15the Creator … MN 49:7.16Brahmā, you will lie close to me, in my domain, vulnerable and expendable.’

MN 49:7.2‘But, good sir, what I say is permanent, everlasting, eternal, complete, and imperishable is in fact permanent, everlasting, eternal, complete, and imperishable. And where I say there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn there is in fact MN 49:7.3no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn. MN 49:7.4And when I say there’s no other escape beyond this there is in fact no other escape beyond this. MN 49:7.5There have been ascetics and brahmins in the world before you, mendicant, whose self-mortification lasted as long as your entire life. MN 49:7.6When there was another escape beyond this they knew it, and when there was no other escape beyond this, they knew it. MN 49:7.7So, mendicant, I tell you this: MN 49:7.8you will never find another escape beyond this, and you will eventually get weary and frustrated. MN 49:7.9If you attach to earth, you will lie close to me, in my domain, vulnerable and expendable.

MN 49:8.1‘Brahmā, I too know that MN 49:8.10“That’s how powerful is Baka the Brahmā, how illustrious and mighty.”’

MN 49:8.11‘But in what way do you understand my range and my light?’ MN 49:8.2if I attach to earth, I will lie close to you, in your domain, vulnerable and expendable. MN 49:8.3If I attach to water … MN 49:8.4fire … MN 49:8.5air … MN 49:8.6creatures … MN 49:8.7gods … MN 49:8.8the Creator … MN 49:8.9Brahmā, I will lie close to you, in your domain, vulnerable and expendable. And in addition, Brahmā, I understand your range and your light:

MN 49:9.1‘A galaxy extends a thousand times as far MN 49:9.2as the moon and sun revolve MN 49:9.3and the shining ones light up the quarters. MN 49:9.4And there you wield your power.

MN 49:9.5You know the high and low, MN 49:9.6the passionate and dispassionate, MN 49:9.7and the coming and going of sentient beings MN 49:9.8from this realm to another.

MN 49:9.9PTS-VP-PLI 1.329That’s how I understand your range and your light.

MN 50:0.2The Rebuke of Māra

MN 50:1.1BJ 10.776PTS-VP-PLI 1.332So I have heard. MN 50:1.2At one time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was staying in the land of the Bhaggas on Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

MN 50:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.334But when Venerable Sañjīva had gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he easily attained the cessation of perception and feeling. MN 50:10.2Once upon a time, Sañjīva was sitting at the root of a certain tree having attained the cessation of perception and feeling. MN 50:10.3Some cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him sitting there MN 50:10.4and said, MN 50:10.5‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing! MN 50:10.6This ascetic passed away while sitting. MN 50:10.7We should cremate him.’ MN 50:10.8They collected grass, wood, and cow-dung, heaped it all on Sañjīva’s body, set it on fire, and left.

MN 50:11.1Then, when the night had passed, Sañjīva emerged from that attainment, shook out his robes, and, since it was morning, he robed up and entered the village for alms. MN 50:11.2Those cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him wandering for alms MN 50:11.3and said, MN 50:11.4‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing! MN 50:11.5This ascetic passed away while sitting, and now he has come back to life!’ MN 50:11.6And that’s how he came to be known as Sañjīva.

MN 50:12.1BJ 10.780Then it occurred to Māra Dūsī, MN 50:12.2‘I don’t know the course of rebirth of these ethical mendicants of good character. MN 50:12.3Why don’t I take possession of these brahmins and householders and say, MN 50:12.4“Come, all of you, abuse, attack, harass, and trouble the ethical mendicants of good character. MN 50:12.5Hopefully by doing this we can upset their minds so that Māra Dūsī can find a vulnerability.”’ MN 50:12.6And that’s exactly what he did.

MN 50:13.1Then those brahmins and householders abused, attacked, harassed, and troubled the ethical mendicants of good character: MN 50:13.10In the same way, these shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman, say, “We practice absorption meditation! We practice absorption meditation!” Slouching, downcast, and dopey, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.’

MN 50:13.11Most of the people who died at that time—when their body broke up, after death—were reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

MN 50:13.2‘These shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman, say, “We practice absorption meditation! We practice absorption meditation!” Slouching, downcast, and dopey, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate. MN 50:13.3They’re just like an owl on a branch, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a mouse. MN 50:13.5They’re just like a jackal on a river-bank, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a fish. MN 50:13.7They’re just like a cat by an alley or a drain or a dustbin, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a mouse. MN 50:13.9They’re just like an unladen donkey by an alley or a drain or a dustbin, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates.

MN 50:14.1BJ 10.782PTS-VP-PLI 1.335Then Kakusandha the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, addressed the mendicants: MN 50:14.2‘Mendicants, the brahmins and householders have been possessed by Māra Dūsī. MN 50:14.3He told them to abuse you in the hope of upsetting your minds so that he can find a vulnerability. MN 50:14.4Come, all of you mendicants, meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will. MN 50:14.5Meditate spreading a heart full of compassion … MN 50:14.6Meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing … MN 50:14.7Meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’

MN 50:15.1When those mendicants were instructed and advised by the Buddha Kakusandha in this way, they went to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, where they meditated spreading a heart full of love … MN 50:15.2compassion … MN 50:15.3rejoicing … MN 50:15.4equanimity.

MN 50:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.336Then it occurred to Māra Dūsī, MN 50:16.2‘Even when I do this I don’t know the course of rebirth of these ethical mendicants of good character. Why don’t I take possession of these brahmins and householders and say, MN 50:16.3“Come, all of you, honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the ethical mendicants of good character. MN 50:16.4Hopefully by doing this we can upset their minds so that Māra Dūsī can find a vulnerability.”’

MN 50:17.1BJ 10.784And that’s exactly what he did. MN 50:17.4Then those brahmins and householders honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated the ethical mendicants of good character.

MN 50:17.5Most of the people who died at that time—when their body broke up, after death—were reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

MN 51:0.2With Kandaraka

MN 51:1.1BJ 11.2PTS-VP-PLI 1.339So I have heard. MN 51:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

MN 51:1.3Then Pessa the elephant driver’s son and Kandaraka the wanderer went to see the Buddha. When they had approached, Pessa bowed and sat down to one side. MN 51:1.4But the wanderer Kandaraka exchanged greetings with the Buddha and stood to one side. MN 51:1.5He looked around the mendicant Saṅgha, who were so very silent, and said to the Buddha:

MN 51:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.344And what person mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others? MN 51:10.2It’s when a person is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin. MN 51:10.3He has a new temple built to the east of the city. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the temple with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest. MN 51:10.4There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass. MN 51:10.5The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the remainder. MN 51:10.6He says: MN 51:10.7‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’ MN 51:10.8His bondservants, employees, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces. MN 51:10.9This is called a person who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

MN 51:11.1BJ 11.12PTS-VP-PLI 1.345And what person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, but lives without wishes, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves?

MN 51:12.1It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. MN 51:12.2He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. MN 51:12.3He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

MN 51:13.1A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some clan. MN 51:13.2They gain faith in the Realized One, MN 51:13.3and reflect: MN 51:13.4‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open. MN 51:13.5It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell. MN 51:13.6Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’ MN 51:13.7After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

MN 51:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.346Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings. MN 51:14.10They avoid dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows. MN 51:14.11They avoid beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, perfumes, and makeup. MN 51:14.12They avoid high and luxurious beds. MN 51:14.13They avoid receiving gold and money, MN 51:14.14raw grains, MN 51:14.15raw meat, MN 51:14.16women and girls, MN 51:14.17male and female bondservants, MN 51:14.18goats and sheep, MN 51:14.19chickens and pigs, MN 51:14.2They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving. MN 51:14.20elephants, cows, horses, and mares, MN 51:14.21and fields and land. MN 51:14.22They avoid running errands and messages; MN 51:14.23buying and selling; MN 51:14.24falsifying weights, metals, or measures; MN 51:14.25bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; MN 51:14.26mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

MN 51:14.3They give up unchastity. They are celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex. MN 51:14.4They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words. MN 51:14.5They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony. MN 51:14.6They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people. MN 51:14.7They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial. MN 51:14.8They avoid injuring plants and seeds. MN 51:14.9They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.

MN 51:15.1BJ 11.14They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things. MN 51:15.2They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden. MN 51:15.3In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things. MN 51:15.4When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

MN 51:16.1When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 51:16.2If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint. MN 51:16.3When they hear a sound with their ears … MN 51:16.4When they smell an odor with their nose … MN 51:16.5When they taste a flavor with their tongue … MN 51:16.6When they feel a touch with their body … MN 51:16.7When they know a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 51:16.8If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint. MN 51:16.9When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.

MN 51:17.1They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

MN 51:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.347When they have this noble spectrum of ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, MN 51:18.2they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

MN 51:19.1After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. MN 51:19.2Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire. MN 51:19.3Giving up ill will, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will and malevolence. MN 51:19.4Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness. MN 51:19.5Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse. MN 51:19.6Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

MN 51:2.1“It’s incredible, Master Gotama, it’s amazing! MN 51:2.2How the mendicant Saṅgha has been led to practice properly by Master Gotama! MN 51:2.3All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly will at best do so MN 51:2.4like Master Gotama does in the present.”

MN 51:20.1BJ 11.16They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. MN 51:20.2Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

MN 51:21.1As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

MN 51:22.1And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

MN 51:23.1Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

MN 51:24.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.348When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives. MN 51:24.2They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

MN 51:25.1When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 51:25.2With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

MN 51:26.1BJ 11.18PTS-VP-PLI 1.349When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 51:26.2They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

MN 51:27.1They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’. MN 51:27.2Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 51:27.3When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

MN 51:27.4They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 51:28.1This is called a person who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others. MN 51:28.2They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.”

MN 51:28.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 51:28.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 51:3.1“That’s so true, Kandaraka! That’s so true!

MN 51:3.10It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 51:3.11They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 51:3.12They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 51:3.13They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.”

MN 51:3.2All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly will at best do so MN 51:3.3like I do in the present.

MN 51:3.6BJ 11.4PTS-VP-PLI 1.340For in this mendicant Saṅgha there are perfected mendicants, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. MN 51:3.7And in this mendicant Saṅgha there are trainee mendicants who are consistently ethical, living consistently, alert, living alertly. MN 51:3.8They meditate with their minds firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. MN 51:3.9What four?

MN 51:4.1When he had spoken, Pessa said to the Buddha:

MN 51:4.10How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though people continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky. MN 51:4.11For human beings are shady, sir, MN 51:4.12while the animal is obvious. MN 51:4.13For I can drive an elephant in training, MN 51:4.14and while going back and forth in Campā it’ll try all the tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints that it can. MN 51:4.15But my bondservants, employees, and workers behave one way by body, another by speech, and their minds another. MN 51:4.16It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! MN 51:4.17How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though people continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky. MN 51:4.18For human beings are shady, sir, MN 51:4.19while the animal is obvious.”

MN 51:4.2“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing, MN 51:4.3how much the Buddha has clearly described the four kinds of mindfulness meditation! They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to end the cycle of suffering, and to realize extinguishment. MN 51:4.4For we white-clothed laypeople also from time to time meditate with our minds well established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. MN 51:4.5We meditate observing an aspect of the body … MN 51:4.6feelings … MN 51:4.7mind … MN 51:4.8principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

MN 51:4.9It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!

MN 51:5.1BJ 11.6PTS-VP-PLI 1.341“That’s so true, Pessa! That’s so true! MN 51:5.10They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.

MN 51:5.11Which one of these four people do you like the sound of?”

MN 51:5.12“Sir, I don’t like the sound of the first three people. MN 51:5.16I only like the sound of the last person, who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others.”

MN 51:5.2For human beings are shady, MN 51:5.3while the animal is obvious. MN 51:5.4Pessa, these four people are found in the world. MN 51:5.5What four?

  1. MN 51:5.6One person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
  2. MN 51:5.7One person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
  3. MN 51:5.8One person mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
  4. MN 51:5.9One person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.

    MN 51:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.342“But why don’t you like the sound of those three people?”

    MN 51:6.10That’s why I like the sound of that person. MN 51:6.11Well, now, sir, I must go. MN 51:6.12I have many duties, and much to do.”

    MN 51:6.13“Please, Pessa, go at your convenience.” MN 51:6.14And then Pessa the elephant driver’s son approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

    MN 51:6.2“Sir, the person who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain. MN 51:6.3That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person. MN 51:6.4The person who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain. MN 51:6.5That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person. MN 51:6.6The person who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain. MN 51:6.7That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person. MN 51:6.8The person who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain.

    MN 51:7.1BJ 11.8Then, not long after he had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants: MN 51:7.10The Buddha said this:

    MN 51:7.2“Mendicants, Pessa the elephant driver’s son is astute. MN 51:7.3He has great wisdom. MN 51:7.4If he had sat here a little longer so that I could have analyzed these four people in detail, he would have greatly benefited. MN 51:7.5Still, even with this much he has already greatly benefited.”

    MN 51:7.6“Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One! MN 51:7.7May the Buddha analyze these four people in detail. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

    MN 51:7.8“Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

    MN 51:7.9“Yes, sir,” they replied.

    MN 51:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.343“And what person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves? It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared for them, or an invitation for a meal. MN 51:8.10They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting. MN 51:8.11They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed. MN 51:8.12They’re committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening. MN 51:8.13And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body. MN 51:8.14This is called a person who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

    MN 51:8.2They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drink no beer. MN 51:8.3They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls. MN 51:8.4They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day. MN 51:8.5They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.

    MN 51:8.6They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.

    MN 51:8.7They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings. MN 51:8.8They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice. MN 51:8.9They constantly stand, refusing seats.

    MN 51:9.1BJ 11.10And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others? MN 51:9.2It’s when a person is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, or poultry, a hunter or trapper, a fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher, a jailer, or someone with some other kind of cruel livelihood. MN 51:9.3This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.

    MN 52:0.2The Man From the City of Aṭṭhaka

    MN 52:1.1BJ 11.20So I have heard. MN 52:1.2At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Vesālī in the little village of Beluva.

    MN 52:1.3Now at that time the householder Dasama from the city of Aṭṭhaka had arrived at Pāṭaliputta on some business. MN 52:10.1rejoicing … MN 52:11.1equanimity …

    MN 52:12.1Furthermore, householder, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space. MN 52:12.2Then they reflect: MN 52:12.3‘Even this attainment of the dimension of infinite space is produced by choices and intentions.’ MN 52:12.4They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ …

    MN 52:13.1Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …

    MN 52:14.1Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. MN 52:14.2Then they reflect: MN 52:14.3‘Even this attainment of the dimension of nothingness is produced by choices and intentions.’ MN 52:14.4They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ MN 52:14.5Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements. MN 52:14.6If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. MN 52:14.7This too is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary.”

    MN 52:15.1BJ 11.26PTS-VP-PLI 1.353When he said this, the householder Dasama said to Venerable Ānanda, MN 52:15.2“Sir, suppose a person was looking for an entrance to a hidden treasure. And all at once they’d come across eleven entrances! MN 52:15.3In the same way, I was searching for the door to the deathless. And all at once I got to hear of eleven doors to the deathless. MN 52:15.4Suppose a person had a house with eleven doors. If the house caught fire they’d be able to flee to safety through any one of those doors. MN 52:15.5In the same way, I’m able to flee to safety through any one of these eleven doors to the deathless. MN 52:15.6Sir, those who follow other paths seek a fee for the teacher. Why shouldn’t I make an offering to Venerable Ānanda?”

    MN 52:16.1Then the householder Dasama, having assembled the Saṅgha from Vesālī and Pāṭaliputta, served and satisfied them with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods. MN 52:16.2He clothed each and every mendicant in a pair of garments, with a set of three robes for Ānanda. And he had a dwelling worth five hundred built for Ānanda.

    MN 52:2.1He went to the Chicken Monastery, approached a certain mendicant, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, MN 52:2.2“Sir, where is Venerable Ānanda now staying? MN 52:2.3For I want to see him.”

    MN 52:2.4“Householder, Venerable Ānanda is staying near Vesālī in the little village of Beluva.”

    MN 52:3.1Then the householder Dasama, having concluded his business there, went to the little village of Beluva in Vesālī to see Ānanda. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Ānanda:

    MN 52:3.2“Sir, Ānanda, is there one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary?”

    MN 52:3.3PTS-VP-PLI 1.350“There is, householder.”

    MN 52:3.4“And what is that one thing?”

    MN 52:4.1BJ 11.22“Householder, it’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 52:4.2Then they reflect: MN 52:4.3‘Even this first absorption is produced by choices and intentions.’ MN 52:4.4They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ MN 52:4.5Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements. MN 52:4.6If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. MN 52:4.7This is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary.

    MN 52:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.351Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption … MN 52:6.1third absorption … MN 52:7.1fourth absorption …

    MN 52:8.1Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will. MN 52:8.2Then they reflect: MN 52:8.3‘Even this heart’s release by love is produced by choices and intentions.’ MN 52:8.4They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ …

    MN 52:9.1BJ 11.24PTS-VP-PLI 1.352Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …

    • MN 53:0.1Middle Discourses 53

    MN 53:0.2A Trainee

    MN 53:1.1BJ 11.28PTS-VP-PLI 1.354So I have heard. MN 53:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

    MN 53:10.1And how is a noble disciple dedicated to wakefulness? MN 53:10.2It’s when a noble disciple practices walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying their mind from obstacles. MN 53:10.3In the evening, they continue to practice walking and sitting meditation. MN 53:10.4In the middle of the night, they lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up. MN 53:10.5In the last part of the night, they get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying their mind from obstacles. MN 53:10.6That’s how a noble disciple is dedicated to wakefulness.

    MN 53:11.1BJ 11.32PTS-VP-PLI 1.356And how does a noble disciple have seven good qualities? MN 53:11.2It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening: MN 53:11.3‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

    MN 53:12.1They have a conscience. They’re conscientious about bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and conscientious about having any bad, unskillful qualities.

    MN 53:13.1They exercise prudence. They’re prudent when it comes to bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and prudent when it comes to acquiring any bad, unskillful qualities.

    MN 53:14.1They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.

    MN 53:15.1They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

    MN 53:16.1They’re mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

    MN 53:17.1They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. MN 53:17.2That’s how a noble disciple has seven good qualities.

    MN 53:18.1And how does a noble disciple get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty? MN 53:18.2It’s when a noble disciple, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption … MN 53:18.3second absorption … MN 53:18.4third absorption … MN 53:18.5fourth absorption. MN 53:18.6That’s how a noble disciple gets the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

    MN 53:19.1BJ 11.34PTS-VP-PLI 1.357When a noble disciple is accomplished in ethics, guards the sense doors, eats in moderation, and is dedicated to wakefulness; and they have seven good qualities, and they get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty, they are called a noble disciple who is a practicing trainee. Their eggs are unspoiled, and they are capable of breaking out of their shell, becoming awakened, and achieving the supreme sanctuary. MN 53:19.2Suppose there was a chicken with eight or ten or twelve eggs. And she properly sat on them to keep them warm and incubated. Even if that chicken doesn’t wish, MN 53:19.3‘If only my chicks could break out of the eggshell with their claws and beak and hatch safely!’ MN 53:19.4Still they can break out and hatch safely.

    MN 53:19.5In the same way, when a noble disciple is practicing all these things they are called a noble disciple who is a practicing trainee. Their eggs are unspoiled, and they are capable of breaking out of their shell, becoming awakened, and achieving the supreme sanctuary.

    MN 53:2.1Now at that time a new town hall had recently been constructed for the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu. It had not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any person at all. MN 53:2.2Then the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

    MN 53:2.3“Sir, a new town hall has recently been constructed for the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu. It has not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any person at all. MN 53:2.4May the Buddha be the first to use it, and only then will the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu use it. MN 53:2.5That would be for the lasting welfare and happiness of the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu.”

    MN 53:20.1Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple recollects their many kinds of past lives. MN 53:20.2That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. MN 53:20.3This is their first breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.

    MN 53:21.1Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. … They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds. MN 53:21.2This is their second breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.

    MN 53:22.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.358Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements. MN 53:22.2This is their third breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.

    MN 53:23.1A noble disciple’s conduct includes the following: being accomplished in ethics, MN 53:23.2guarding the sense doors, MN 53:23.3moderation in eating, MN 53:23.4being dedicated to wakefulness, MN 53:23.5having seven good qualities, MN 53:23.6and getting the four absorptions when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

    MN 53:24.1BJ 11.36A noble disciple’s knowledge includes the following: recollecting their past lives, MN 53:24.2clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, MN 53:24.3and realizing the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life due to the ending of defilements.

    MN 53:25.1This noble disciple is said to be ‘accomplished in knowledge’, and also ‘accomplished in conduct’, and also ‘accomplished in knowledge and conduct’.

    MN 53:25.2And Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra also spoke this verse:

    MN 53:25.3‘The aristocrat is first among people MN 53:25.4who take clan as the standard. MN 53:25.5But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct MN 53:25.6is first among gods and humans.’

    MN 53:25.7And that verse was well sung by Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra, not poorly sung; well spoken, not poorly spoken, beneficial, not harmful, and it was approved by the Buddha.”

    MN 53:26.1Then the Buddha got up and said to Venerable Ānanda, MN 53:26.2“Good, good, Ānanda! MN 53:26.3It’s good that you spoke to the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu about the practicing trainee.”

    MN 53:26.4PTS-VP-PLI 1.359This is what Venerable Ānanda said, MN 53:26.5and the teacher approved. MN 53:26.6Satisfied, the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu were happy with what Venerable Ānanda said.

    MN 53:3.1The Buddha consented in silence.

    MN 53:3.2Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, the Sakyans got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went to the new town hall, where they spread carpets all over, prepared seats, set up a water jar, and placed a lamp. Then they went back to the Buddha, MN 53:3.3bowed, stood to one side, MN 53:3.4and told him of their preparations, saying, MN 53:3.6“Please, sir, come at your convenience.”

    MN 53:4.1Then the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the new town hall together with the Saṅgha of mendicants. Having washed his feet he entered the town hall and sat against the central column facing east. MN 53:4.2The Saṅgha of mendicants also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the west wall facing east, with the Buddha right in front of them. MN 53:4.3The Sakyans of Kapilavatthu also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the east wall facing west, with the Buddha right in front of them.

    MN 53:5.1The Buddha spent most of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the Sakyans with a Dhamma talk. Then he addressed Venerable Ānanda, MN 53:5.2“Ānanda, speak about the practicing trainee to the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu as you feel inspired. MN 53:5.3My back is sore, MN 53:5.4I’ll stretch it.”

    MN 53:5.5“Yes, sir,” Ānanda replied. MN 53:5.6And then the Buddha spread out his outer robe folded in four and laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.

    MN 53:6.1BJ 11.30Then Ānanda addressed Mahānāma the Sakyan:

    MN 53:6.2“Mahānāma, a noble disciple is accomplished in ethics, guards the sense doors, eats in moderation, and is dedicated to wakefulness. They have seven good qualities, and they get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

    MN 53:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.355And how is a noble disciple accomplished in ethics? MN 53:7.2It’s when a noble disciple is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. MN 53:7.3That’s how a noble disciple is ethical.

    MN 53:8.1And how does a noble disciple guard the sense doors? MN 53:8.10That’s how a noble disciple guards the sense doors.

    MN 53:8.2When a noble disciple sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 53:8.3If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint. MN 53:8.4When they hear a sound with their ears … MN 53:8.5When they smell an odor with their nose … MN 53:8.6When they taste a flavor with their tongue … MN 53:8.7When they feel a touch with their body … MN 53:8.8When they know a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 53:8.9If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

    MN 53:9.1And how does a noble disciple eat in moderation? MN 53:9.2It’s when a noble disciple reflects properly on the food that they eat: MN 53:9.3‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will live blamelessly and at ease.’ MN 53:9.4That’s how a noble disciple eats in moderation.
