    MN 54:0.2With Potaliya the Householder

    MN 54:1.1BJ 11.38So I have heard. MN 54:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Northern Āpaṇas, near the town of theirs named Āpaṇa.

    MN 54:10.1greed and lust … MN 54:11.1BJ 11.44PTS-VP-PLI 1.363blaming and insulting … MN 54:12.1anger and distress …

    MN 54:13.1Arrogance should be given up, relying on not being arrogant.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 54:13.2It’s when a noble disciple reflects: MN 54:13.3‘I am practicing to give up and cut off the fetters that might cause me to be arrogant. MN 54:13.4But if I were to be arrogant, because of that I would reprimand myself; sensible people, after examination, would criticize me; and when my body breaks up, after death, I could expect to be reborn in a bad place. MN 54:13.5And arrogance is itself a fetter and a hindrance. MN 54:13.6The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of arrogance do not occur in someone who is not arrogant.’ MN 54:13.7‘Arrogance should be given up by not being arrogant.’ MN 54:13.8That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

    MN 54:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.364These are the eight things—stated in brief and analyzed in detail—that lead to the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training. MN 54:14.2But just this much does not constitute the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training.”

    MN 54:14.3“But, sir, how is there the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training? MN 54:14.4Sir, please teach me this.”

    MN 54:14.5“Well then, householder, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

    MN 54:14.6“Yes, sir,” said Potaliya. MN 54:14.7The Buddha said this:

    MN 54:15.01. The Dangers of Sensual Pleasures

    MN 54:15.1BJ 11.46“Householder, suppose a dog weak with hunger was hanging around a butcher’s shop. MN 54:15.10‘With the simile of a skeleton the Buddha said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’ MN 54:15.11Having truly seen this with right understanding, they reject equanimity based on diversity and develop only the equanimity based on unity, where all kinds of grasping to the world’s material delights cease without anything left over.

    MN 54:15.2Then a deft butcher or their apprentice would toss them a skeleton scraped clean of flesh and smeared in blood. MN 54:15.3What do you think, householder? MN 54:15.4Gnawing on such a fleshless skeleton, would that dog still get rid of its hunger?”

    MN 54:15.5“No, sir. MN 54:15.6Why not? MN 54:15.7Because that skeleton is scraped clean of flesh and smeared in blood. MN 54:15.8That dog will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

    MN 54:15.9“In the same way, a noble disciple reflects:

    MN 54:16.1Suppose a vulture or a crow or a hawk was to grab a lump of meat and fly away. MN 54:16.2Other vultures, crows, and hawks would keep chasing it, pecking and clawing. MN 54:16.3What do you think, householder? MN 54:16.4If that vulture, crow, or hawk doesn’t quickly let go of that lump of meat, wouldn’t that result in death or deadly suffering for them?”

    MN 54:16.5“Yes, sir.” …

    MN 54:17.1“Suppose a person carrying a blazing grass torch was to walk against the wind. MN 54:17.2What do you think, householder? MN 54:17.3If that person doesn’t quickly let go of that blazing grass torch, wouldn’t they burn their hands or arm or other limb, resulting in death or deadly suffering for them?”

    MN 54:17.4“Yes, sir.” …

    MN 54:18.1BJ 11.48“Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, full of glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked. MN 54:18.2Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. MN 54:18.3Then two strong men would grab them by the arms and drag them towards the pit of glowing coals. MN 54:18.4What do you think, householder? MN 54:18.5Wouldn’t that person writhe and struggle to and fro?”

    MN 54:18.6“Yes, sir. MN 54:18.7Why is that? MN 54:18.8For that person knows: ‘If I fall in that pit of glowing coals, that’d result in my death or deadly pain.’” …

    MN 54:19.1“Suppose a person was to see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds in a dream. MN 54:19.2But when they woke they couldn’t see them at all. …

    MN 54:2.1Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms. MN 54:2.2He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation. MN 54:2.3Having plunged deep into it, he sat at the root of a certain tree for the day’s meditation.

    MN 54:20.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.366Suppose a man had borrowed some goods—a gentleman’s carriage and fine jewelled earrings—MN 54:20.2and preceded and surrounded by these he proceeded through the middle of Āpaṇa. MN 54:20.3When people saw him they’d say: MN 54:20.4‘This must be a wealthy man! For that’s how the wealthy enjoy their wealth.’ MN 54:20.5But when the owners saw him, they’d take back what was theirs. MN 54:20.6What do you think? Would that be enough for that man to get upset?”

    MN 54:20.7“Yes, sir. MN 54:20.8Why is that? MN 54:20.9Because the owners took back what was theirs.” …

    MN 54:21.1BJ 11.50PTS-VP-PLI 1.367“Suppose there was a dark forest grove not far from a town or village. MN 54:21.10And along would come a second person in need of fruit, wandering in search of fruit, carrying a sharp axe. MN 54:21.11Having plunged deep into that forest grove, they’d see that tree laden with fruit. MN 54:21.12They’d think: MN 54:21.13‘That tree is laden with fruit, yet none of the fruit has fallen to the ground. MN 54:21.14But I don’t know how to climb a tree. MN 54:21.15Why don’t I chop this tree down at the root, eat as much as I like, then fill my pouch?’ MN 54:21.16And so they’d chop the tree down at the root. MN 54:21.17What do you think, householder? MN 54:21.18If the first person, who climbed the tree, doesn’t quickly come down, when that tree fell wouldn’t they break their hand or arm or other limb, resulting in death or deadly suffering for them?”

    MN 54:21.19“Yes, sir.”

    MN 54:21.2And there was a tree laden with fruit, yet none of the fruit had fallen to the ground.

    MN 54:21.20“In the same way, a noble disciple reflects: MN 54:21.21‘With the simile of the fruit tree the Buddha said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’ MN 54:21.22Having truly seen this with right understanding, they reject equanimity based on diversity and develop only the equanimity based on unity, where all kinds of grasping to the world’s material delights cease without anything left over.

    MN 54:21.3And along came a person in need of fruit, wandering in search of fruit. MN 54:21.4Having plunged deep into that forest grove, they’d see that tree laden with fruit. MN 54:21.5They’d think: MN 54:21.6‘That tree is laden with fruit, yet none of the fruit has fallen to the ground. MN 54:21.7But I know how to climb a tree. MN 54:21.8Why don’t I climb the tree, eat as much as I like, then fill my pouch?’ MN 54:21.9And that’s what they’d do.

    MN 54:22.1Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple recollects their many kinds of past lives. MN 54:22.2That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

    MN 54:23.1Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. … They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

    MN 54:24.1Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

    MN 54:25.1That’s how there is the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training.

    MN 54:25.10The Buddha has inspired me to have love, confidence, and respect for ascetics!

    MN 54:25.2BJ 11.52PTS-VP-PLI 1.368What do you think, householder? MN 54:25.3Do you regard yourself as having cut off judgments in a way comparable to the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?”

    MN 54:25.4“Who am I compared to one who has cut off judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training? MN 54:25.5I am far from that. MN 54:25.6Sir, I used to think that the wanderers following other paths were thoroughbreds, and I fed them and treated them accordingly, but they were not actually thoroughbreds. MN 54:25.7I thought that the mendicants were not thoroughbreds, and I fed them and treated them accordingly, but they actually were thoroughbreds. MN 54:25.8But now I shall understand that the wanderers following other paths are not actually thoroughbreds, and I will feed them and treat them accordingly. MN 54:25.9And I shall understand that the mendicants actually are thoroughbreds, and I will feed them and treat them accordingly.

    MN 54:26.1Excellent, sir! Excellent! MN 54:26.2As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways. MN 54:26.3I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 54:26.4From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

    MN 54:3.1Potaliya the householder also approached that forest grove while going for a walk. He was well dressed in a cloak and sarong, with parasol and sandals. Having plunged deep into it, he went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

    MN 54:3.10“Well, householder, you have the features, attributes, and signs of a householder.”

    MN 54:3.11“Master Gotama, it’s because I have refused all work and cut off all judgments.”

    MN 54:3.12“Householder, in what way have you refused all work and cut off all judgments?”

    MN 54:3.13“Master Gotama, all the money, grain, gold, and silver I used to have has been handed over to my children as their inheritance. And in this matter I do not advise or reprimand them, but live with nothing more than food and clothes. MN 54:3.14That’s how I have refused all work and cut off all judgments.”

    MN 54:3.15“The cutting off of judgments as you describe it is one thing, householder, but the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training is quite different.”

    MN 54:3.16“But what, sir, is cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training? MN 54:3.17Sir, please teach me this.”

    MN 54:3.18“Well then, householder, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

    MN 54:3.19“Yes, sir,” said Potaliya.

    MN 54:3.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side, and the Buddha said to him, MN 54:3.3“There are seats, householder. Please sit if you wish.”

    MN 54:3.5BJ 11.40PTS-VP-PLI 1.360For a second time … MN 54:3.6and a third time the Buddha said to him, MN 54:3.7“There are seats, householder. Please sit if you wish.”

    MN 54:4.1The Buddha said this:

    MN 54:4.10Anger and distress should be given up, relying on not being angry and distressed. MN 54:4.11Arrogance should be given up, relying on not being arrogant. MN 54:4.12These are the eight things—stated in brief without being analyzed in detail—that lead to the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training.”

    MN 54:4.2“Householder, these eight things lead to the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training. MN 54:4.3What eight? MN 54:4.4Killing living creatures should be given up, relying on not killing living creatures. MN 54:4.5Stealing should be given up, relying on not stealing. MN 54:4.6Lying should be given up, relying on speaking the truth. MN 54:4.7Divisive speech should be given up, relying on speech that isn’t divisive. MN 54:4.8Greed and lust should be given up, relying on not being greedy and lustful. MN 54:4.9Blaming and insulting should be given up, relying on not blaming and not insulting.

    MN 54:5.1“Sir, please teach me these eight things in detail out of compassion.”

    MN 54:5.2“Well then, householder, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

    MN 54:5.3“Yes, sir,” said Potaliya. MN 54:5.4The Buddha said this:

    MN 54:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.361“‘Killing living creatures should be given up, relying on not killing living creatures.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 54:6.2It’s when a noble disciple reflects: MN 54:6.3‘I am practicing to give up and cut off the fetters that might cause me to kill living creatures. MN 54:6.4But if I were to kill living creatures, because of that I would reprimand myself; sensible people, after examination, would criticize me; and when my body breaks up, after death, I could expect to be reborn in a bad place. MN 54:6.5And killing living creatures is itself a fetter and a hindrance. MN 54:6.6The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of killing living creatures do not occur in someone who does not kill living creatures.’ MN 54:6.7‘Killing living creatures should be given up, relying on not killing living creatures.’ MN 54:6.8That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

    MN 57:0.2The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

    MN 57:1.1BJ 11.84So I have heard. MN 57:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Koliyans, where they have a town named Haliddavasana.

    MN 57:10.1And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results? MN 57:10.10These are called dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.

    MN 57:10.2It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 57:10.3Having made these choices, they are reborn in a world that is both hurtful and pleasing, MN 57:10.4where hurtful and pleasing contacts strike them. MN 57:10.5Touched by both hurtful and pleasing contacts, they experience both hurtful and pleasing feelings that are a mixture of pleasure and pain—like humans, some gods, and some beings in the underworld. MN 57:10.6This is how a being is born from a being. MN 57:10.7For what you do brings about your rebirth, MN 57:10.8and when you’re reborn contacts strike you. MN 57:10.9This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.

    MN 57:11.1BJ 11.90PTS-VP-PLI 1.391And what are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds? MN 57:11.2It’s the intention to give up dark deeds with dark results, bright deeds with bright results, and both dark and bright deeds with both dark and bright results. MN 57:11.3These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

    MN 57:11.4These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

    MN 57:12.1When he had spoken, Puṇṇa Koliyaputta the observer of cow behavior said to the Buddha, MN 57:12.2“Excellent, sir! Excellent! … MN 57:12.4From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

    MN 57:13.1And Seniya the naked dog ascetic said to the Buddha, MN 57:13.2“Excellent, sir! Excellent! … MN 57:13.4I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 57:13.5Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

    MN 57:14.1“Seniya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood. MN 57:14.2However, I have recognized individual differences in this matter.”

    MN 57:14.3“Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”

    MN 57:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.392And the naked dog ascetic Seniya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence. MN 57:15.2Not long after his ordination, Venerable Seniya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

    MN 57:15.3He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.” MN 57:15.4And Venerable Seniya became one of the perfected.

    MN 57:2.1Then Puṇṇa Koliyaputta, who had taken a vow to behave like a cow, and Seniya, a naked ascetic who had taken a vow to behave like a dog, went to see the Buddha. Puṇṇa bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side, while Seniya exchanged greetings and polite conversation with him before sitting down to one side curled up like a dog.

    MN 57:2.10For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a dog. MN 57:2.11Where will he be reborn in his next life?”

    MN 57:2.12BJ 11.86PTS-VP-PLI 1.388“Clearly, Puṇṇa, I’m not getting through to you when I say: MN 57:2.13‘Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’ MN 57:2.14Nevertheless, I will answer you.

    MN 57:2.2Puṇṇa said to the Buddha, MN 57:2.3“Sir, this naked dog ascetic Seniya does a hard thing: he eats food placed on the ground. MN 57:2.4For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a dog. MN 57:2.5Where will he be reborn in his next life?”

    MN 57:2.6“Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”

    MN 57:2.7For a second time … MN 57:2.8and a third time, Puṇṇa said to the Buddha, MN 57:2.9“Sir, this naked dog ascetic Seniya does a hard thing: he eats food placed on the ground.

    MN 57:3.1Take someone who develops the dog observance fully and uninterruptedly. They develop a dog’s ethics, a dog’s mentality, and a dog’s behavior fully and uninterruptedly. MN 57:3.2When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of dogs. MN 57:3.3But if they have such a view: ‘By this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’ This is their wrong view. MN 57:3.4An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say: hell or the animal realm. MN 57:3.5So if the dog observance succeeds it leads to rebirth in the company of dogs, but if it fails it leads to hell.”

    MN 57:4.1When he said this, Seniya cried and burst out in tears.

    MN 57:4.10“Enough, Seniya, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”

    MN 57:4.11For a second time … MN 57:4.12and a third time Seniya said to the Buddha, MN 57:4.13“Sir, this Puṇṇa has taken a vow to behave like a cow. MN 57:4.14For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a cow. MN 57:4.15Where will he be reborn in his next life?”

    MN 57:4.16PTS-VP-PLI 1.389“Clearly, Seniya, I’m not getting through to you when I say: MN 57:4.17‘Enough, Seniya, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’ MN 57:4.18Nevertheless, I will answer you.

    MN 57:4.2The Buddha said to Puṇṇa, MN 57:4.3“This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said: MN 57:4.4‘Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”

    MN 57:4.5“Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said. MN 57:4.6But, sir, for a long time I have undertaken this observance to behave like a dog. MN 57:4.7Sir, this Puṇṇa has taken a vow to behave like a cow. MN 57:4.8For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a cow. MN 57:4.9Where will he be reborn in his next life?”

    MN 57:5.1Take someone who develops the cow observance fully and uninterruptedly. They develop a cow’s ethics, a cow’s mentality, and a cow’s behavior fully and uninterruptedly. MN 57:5.2When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of cows. MN 57:5.3But if they have such a view: ‘By this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’ This is their wrong view. MN 57:5.4An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say: hell or the animal realm. MN 57:5.5So if the cow observance succeeds it leads to rebirth in the company of cows, but if it fails it leads to hell.”

    MN 57:6.1When he said this, Puṇṇa cried and burst out in tears.

    MN 57:6.10“Yes, sir,” he replied. MN 57:6.11The Buddha said this:

    MN 57:6.2The Buddha said to Seniya, MN 57:6.3“This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said: MN 57:6.4‘Enough, Seniya, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”

    MN 57:6.5“Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said. MN 57:6.6But, sir, for a long time I have undertaken this observance to behave like a cow. MN 57:6.7I am quite confident that the Buddha MN 57:6.8is capable of teaching me so that I can give up this cow observance, and the naked ascetic Seniya can give up that dog observance.”

    MN 57:6.9“Well then, Puṇṇa, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

    MN 57:7.1“Puṇṇa, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight. MN 57:7.2What four?

    1. MN 57:7.3There are dark deeds with dark results;
    2. MN 57:7.4bright deeds with bright results;
    3. MN 57:7.5dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results; and
    4. MN 57:7.6neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

    MN 57:8.1BJ 11.88PTS-VP-PLI 1.390And what are dark deeds with dark results? MN 57:8.10These are called dark deeds with dark results.

    MN 57:8.2It’s when someone makes hurtful choices by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 57:8.3Having made these choices, they’re reborn in a hurtful world, MN 57:8.4where hurtful contacts strike them. MN 57:8.5Touched by hurtful contacts, they experience hurtful feelings that are exclusively painful—like the beings in hell. MN 57:8.6This is how a being is born from a being. MN 57:8.7For your deeds determine your rebirth, MN 57:8.8and when you’re reborn contacts strike you. MN 57:8.9This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.

    MN 57:9.1And what are bright deeds with bright results? MN 57:9.10These are called bright deeds with bright results.

    MN 57:9.2It’s when someone makes pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 57:9.3Having made these choices, they are reborn in a pleasing world, MN 57:9.4where pleasing contacts strike them. MN 57:9.5Touched by pleasing contacts, they experience pleasing feelings that are exclusively happy—like the gods replete with glory. MN 57:9.6This is how a being is born from a being. MN 57:9.7For your deeds determine your rebirth, MN 57:9.8and when you’re reborn contacts strike you. MN 57:9.9This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.
    • MN 58:0.1Middle Discourses 58

    MN 58:0.2With Prince Abhaya

    MN 58:1.1BJ 11.92PTS-VP-PLI 1.393So I have heard. MN 58:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

    MN 58:10.1“Well then, prince, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like. MN 58:10.10All the parts are well-known to me. MN 58:10.11The answer just appears to me on the spot.”

    MN 58:10.2What do you think, prince? MN 58:10.3Are you skilled in the various parts of a chariot?”

    MN 58:10.4“I am, sir.”

    MN 58:10.5PTS-VP-PLI 1.396“What do you think, prince? MN 58:10.6When they come to you and ask: MN 58:10.7‘What’s the name of this chariot part?’ MN 58:10.8Do you think beforehand that if they ask you like this, you’ll answer like that, or does the answer appear to you on the spot?”

    MN 58:10.9“Sir, I’m well-known as a charioteer skilled in a chariot’s parts.

    MN 58:11.1BJ 11.98“In the same way, when clever aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics come to see me with a question already planned, the answer just appears to me on the spot. MN 58:11.2Why is that? MN 58:11.3Because the Realized One has clearly comprehended the principle of the teachings, so that the answer just appears to him on the spot.”

    MN 58:12.1When he had spoken, Prince Abhaya said to the Buddha, MN 58:12.2“Excellent, sir! Excellent! … MN 58:12.3From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

    MN 58:2.1Then Prince Abhaya went up to Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, bowed, and sat down to one side. Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta said to him, MN 58:3.1“Come, prince, refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine. MN 58:3.10For even an ordinary person might utter speech that is disliked by others.’ MN 58:3.11But if he answers, MN 58:3.12‘He would not, prince,’ say this to him: MN 58:3.13‘Then, sir, why exactly did you declare of Devadatta: MN 58:3.14“Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable”? MN 58:3.15Devadatta was angry and upset with what you said.’

    MN 58:3.16When you put this dilemma to him, the Buddha won’t be able to either spit it out or swallow it down. MN 58:3.17He’ll be like a man with an iron cross stuck in his throat, unable to either spit it out or swallow it down.” MN 58:3.2Then you will get a good reputation: MN 58:3.3‘Prince Abhaya refuted the doctrine of the ascetic Gotama, so mighty and powerful!’”

    MN 58:3.4“But sir, how am I to do this?”

    MN 58:3.5“Here, prince, go to the ascetic Gotama and say to him: MN 58:3.6‘Sir, might the Realized One utter speech that is disliked by others?’ MN 58:3.7When he’s asked this, if he answers: MN 58:3.8‘He might, prince,’ say this to him, MN 58:3.9‘Then, sir, what exactly is the difference between you and an ordinary person?

    MN 58:4.1“Yes, sir,” replied Abhaya. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, keeping him on his right. Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

    MN 58:4.2BJ 11.94Then he looked up at the sun and thought, MN 58:4.3“It’s too late to refute the Buddha’s doctrine today. MN 58:4.4I shall refute his doctrine in my own home tomorrow.” He said to the Buddha, MN 58:4.5“Sir, may the Buddha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me, together with three other monks.” MN 58:4.6The Buddha consented in silence.

    MN 58:5.1Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Abhaya got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

    MN 58:5.2Then when the night had passed, the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Abhaya’s home, and sat down on the seat spread out. MN 58:5.3Then Abhaya served and satisfied the Buddha with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods.

    MN 58:5.4When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Abhaya took a low seat, sat to one side, MN 58:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.394and said to him, MN 58:6.2“Sir, might the Realized One utter speech that is disliked by others?”

    MN 58:6.3“This is no simple matter, prince.”

    MN 58:6.4“Then the Jains have lost in this, sir.”

    MN 58:6.5“But prince, why do you say that MN 58:6.6the Jains have lost in this?”

    MN 58:6.7Then Abhaya told the Buddha all that had happened.

    MN 58:7.1BJ 11.96PTS-VP-PLI 1.395Now at that time a little baby boy was sitting in Prince Abhaya’s lap. MN 58:7.2Then the Buddha said to Abhaya, MN 58:7.3“What do you think, prince? MN 58:7.4If—because of your negligence or his nurse’s negligence—your boy was to put a stick or stone in his mouth, what would you do to him?”

    MN 58:7.5“I’d try to take it out, sir. MN 58:7.6If that didn’t work, I’d hold his head with my left hand, and take it out using a hooked finger of my right hand, even if it drew blood. MN 58:7.7Why is that? MN 58:7.8Because I have compassion for the boy, sir.”

    MN 58:8.1“In the same way, prince, the Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be untrue, false, and harmful, and which is disliked by others. MN 58:8.2The Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be true and substantive, but which is harmful and disliked by others. MN 58:8.3The Realized One knows the right time to speak so as to explain what he knows to be true, substantive, and beneficial, but which is disliked by others. MN 58:8.4The Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be untrue, false, and harmful, but which is liked by others. MN 58:8.5The Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be true and substantive, but which is harmful, even if it is liked by others. MN 58:8.6The Realized One knows the right time to speak so as to explain what he knows to be true, substantive, and beneficial, and which is liked by others. MN 58:8.7Why is that? MN 58:8.8Because the Realized One has compassion for sentient beings.”

    MN 58:9.1“Sir, there are clever aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics who come to see you with a question already planned. MN 58:9.2Do you think beforehand that if they ask you like this, you’ll answer like that, or does the answer just appear to you on the spot?”

    • MN 59:0.1Middle Discourses 59

    MN 59:0.2The Many Kinds of Feeling

    MN 59:1.1BJ 11.100PTS-VP-PLI 1.397So I have heard. MN 59:1.10He’s spoken of two feelings: MN 59:1.11pleasant and painful. MN 59:1.12The Buddha said that neutral feeling is included as a peaceful and subtle kind of pleasure.”

    MN 59:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

    MN 59:1.3Then the master builder Pañcakaṅga went up to Venerable Udāyī, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, MN 59:1.4“Sir, how many feelings has the Buddha spoken of?”

    MN 59:1.5“Master builder, the Buddha has spoken of three feelings: MN 59:1.6pleasant, painful, and neutral. MN 59:1.7The Buddha has spoken of these three feelings.”

    MN 59:1.8When he said this, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī, MN 59:1.9“Sir, Udāyī, the Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings. MN 59:10.2There is another pleasure that is finer than that. MN 59:10.3And what is that pleasure? MN 59:10.4It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. … MN 59:11.2There is another pleasure that is finer than that. MN 59:11.3And what is that pleasure? MN 59:11.4It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space. … MN 59:12.2There is another pleasure that is finer than that. MN 59:12.3And what is that pleasure? MN 59:12.4It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. … MN 59:13.2There is another pleasure that is finer than that. MN 59:13.3And what is that pleasure? MN 59:13.4It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. … MN 59:14.2There is another pleasure that is finer than that. MN 59:14.3And what is that pleasure? MN 59:14.4It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 59:14.5This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

    MN 59:15.1There are those who would say that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience. But I don’t grant them that. MN 59:15.2Why is that? MN 59:15.3Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that. MN 59:15.4And what is that pleasure? MN 59:15.5It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. MN 59:15.6This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

    MN 59:16.1BJ 11.106It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say, MN 59:16.2‘The ascetic Gotama spoke of the cessation of perception and feeling, and he includes it in happiness. MN 59:16.3What’s up with that?’

    MN 59:16.4When wanderers who follow other paths say this, you should say to them, MN 59:16.5‘Reverends, when the Buddha describes what’s included in happiness, he’s not just referring to pleasant feeling. MN 59:16.6The Realized One describes pleasure as included in happiness wherever it’s found, and in whatever context.’”

    MN 59:16.7That is what the Buddha said. MN 59:16.8Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 59:2.1For a second time, Udāyī said to Pañcakaṅga, MN 59:2.2“The Buddha hasn’t spoken of two feelings, MN 59:2.3he’s spoken of three.” MN 59:2.6For a second time, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī, MN 59:2.7“The Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings, MN 59:2.8he’s spoken of two.”

    MN 59:3.1And for a third time, Udāyī said to Pañcakaṅga,

    MN 59:3.11But neither was able to persuade the other.

    MN 59:3.2“The Buddha hasn’t spoken of two feelings, MN 59:3.3he’s spoken of three.”

    MN 59:3.6And for a third time, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī, MN 59:3.7“The Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings, MN 59:3.8he’s spoken of two.”

    MN 59:4.1BJ 11.102PTS-VP-PLI 1.398Venerable Ānanda heard this discussion between Udāyī and Pañcakaṅga. MN 59:4.2Then he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, MN 59:4.3and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed. MN 59:4.4When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,

    MN 59:5.1“Ānanda, the explanation by the mendicant Udāyī, which the master builder Pañcakaṅga didn’t agree with, was quite correct. But the explanation by Pañcakaṅga, which Udāyī didn’t agree with, was also quite correct. MN 59:5.2In one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings. MN 59:5.3I’ve explained the teaching in all these different ways. MN 59:5.4This being so, you can expect that those who don’t concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will argue, quarrel, and fight, continually wounding each other with barbed words. MN 59:5.5I’ve explained the teaching in all these different ways. MN 59:5.6This being so, you can expect that those who do concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.

    MN 59:6.1There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 59:6.2What five? MN 59:6.3Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 59:6.4Sounds known by the ear … MN 59:6.5Smells known by the nose … MN 59:6.6Tastes known by the tongue … MN 59:6.7Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 59:6.8These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 59:6.9The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure.

    MN 59:7.1There are those who would say that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience. But I don’t grant them that. MN 59:7.2Why is that? MN 59:7.3Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that. MN 59:7.4And what is that pleasure? MN 59:7.5It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 59:7.6This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

    MN 59:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.399There are those who would say that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience. But I don’t grant them that. MN 59:8.2Why is that? MN 59:8.3Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that. MN 59:8.4And what is that pleasure? MN 59:8.5It’s when, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. … MN 59:9.2There is another pleasure that is finer than that. MN 59:9.3And what is that pleasure? MN 59:9.4It’s when, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ …

    • MN 60:0.1Middle Discourses 60

    MN 60:0.2Guaranteed

    MN 60:1.1BJ 11.108PTS-VP-PLI 1.401So I have heard. MN 60:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Sālā.

    MN 60:10.1BJ 11.112PTS-VP-PLI 1.404Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that MN 60:10.2there is meaning in giving, etc. MN 60:10.3You can expect that they will reject bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and undertake and implement good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 60:10.4Why is that? MN 60:10.5Because those ascetics and brahmins see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, sordidness, and corruption, and that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.

    MN 60:11.1Moreover, since there actually is another world, their view that there is another world is right view. MN 60:11.2Since there actually is another world, their thought that there is another world is right thought. MN 60:11.3Since there actually is another world, their speech that there is another world is right speech. MN 60:11.4Since there actually is another world, in saying that there is another world they don’t contradict those perfected ones who know the other world. MN 60:11.5Since there actually is another world, in convincing another that there is another world they are convincing them to accept a true teaching. MN 60:11.6And on account of that they don’t glorify themselves or put others down. MN 60:11.7So they give up their former unethical conduct and are established in ethical conduct. MN 60:11.8And that is how right view gives rise to these many skillful qualities—right view, right thought, right speech, not contradicting the noble ones, convincing others to accept true teachings, and not glorifying oneself or putting others down.

    MN 60:12.1A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way: MN 60:12.2‘If there is another world, when this individual’s body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 60:12.3But let’s assume that those who say that there is no other world are correct. MN 60:12.4Regardless, that individual is still praised by sensible people in the present life as being a moral individual of right view, who affirms a positive teaching.’ MN 60:12.5So if there really is another world, they win on both counts. MN 60:12.6For they are praised by sensible people in the present life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 60:12.7They have rightly undertaken this guaranteed teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of both sides, leaving out the unskillful premise.

    MN 60:13.1BJ 11.114PTS-VP-PLI 1.405There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 60:13.2‘The one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do nothing wrong when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie. MN 60:13.3If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil. MN 60:13.4If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil. MN 60:13.5If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit. MN 60:13.6In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’

    MN 60:14.1And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this. They say: MN 60:14.2‘The one who acts does a bad deed when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do a bad deed when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie. MN 60:14.3If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, evil comes of that, and an outcome of evil. MN 60:14.4If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, evil comes of that, and an outcome of evil. MN 60:14.5If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, merit comes of that, and an outcome of merit. MN 60:14.6In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is merit and outcome of merit.’

    MN 60:14.7What do you think, householders? MN 60:14.8Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”

    MN 60:14.9“Yes, sir.”

    MN 60:15.1BJ 11.116PTS-VP-PLI 1.406“Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that MN 60:15.2the one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, etc. MN 60:15.5You can expect that they will reject good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and undertake and implement bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 60:15.6Why is that? MN 60:15.7Because those ascetics and brahmins don’t see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, sordidness, and corruption, or that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.

    MN 60:16.1Moreover, since action actually does have an effect, their view that action is ineffective is wrong view. MN 60:16.2Since action actually does have an effect, their thought that action is ineffective is wrong thought. MN 60:16.3Since action actually does have an effect, their speech that action is ineffective is wrong speech. MN 60:16.4Since action actually does have an effect, in saying that action is ineffective they contradict those perfected ones who teach that action is effective. MN 60:16.5Since action actually does have an effect, in convincing another that action is ineffective they are convincing them to accept an untrue teaching. MN 60:16.6And on account of that they glorify themselves and put others down. MN 60:16.7So they give up their former ethical conduct and are established in unethical conduct. MN 60:16.8And that is how wrong view gives rise to these many bad, unskillful qualities—wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, contradicting the noble ones, convincing others to accept untrue teachings, and glorifying oneself and putting others down.

    MN 60:17.1A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way: MN 60:17.2‘If there is no effective action, when this individual’s body breaks up they will keep themselves safe. MN 60:17.3And if there is effective action, when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 60:17.4But let’s assume that those who say that there is no effective action are correct. MN 60:17.5Regardless, that individual is still criticized by sensible people in the present life as being an immoral individual of wrong view, one who denies the efficacy of action.’ MN 60:17.6But if there really is effective action, they lose on both counts. MN 60:17.7For they are criticized by sensible people in the present life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 60:17.8They have wrongly undertaken this guaranteed teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of one side only, leaving out the skillful premise.

    MN 60:18.1BJ 11.118PTS-VP-PLI 1.407Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that MN 60:18.2the one who acts does a bad deed when they punish, etc. MN 60:18.6You can expect that they will reject bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and undertake and implement good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 60:18.7Why is that? MN 60:18.8Because those ascetics and brahmins see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, sordidness, and corruption, and that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.

    MN 60:19.1Moreover, since action actually does have an effect, their view that action is effective is right view. MN 60:19.2Since action actually does have an effect, their thought that action is effective is right thought. MN 60:19.3Since action actually does have an effect, their speech that action is effective is right speech. MN 60:19.4Since action actually does have an effect, in saying that action is effective they don’t contradict those perfected ones who teach that action is effective. MN 60:19.5Since action actually does have an effect, in convincing another that action is effective they are convincing them to accept a true teaching. MN 60:19.6And on account of that they don’t glorify themselves or put others down. MN 60:19.7So they give up their former unethical conduct and are established in ethical conduct. MN 60:19.8And that is how right view gives rise to these many skillful qualities—right view, right thought, right speech, not contradicting the noble ones, convincing others to accept true teachings, and not glorifying oneself or putting others down.

    MN 60:2.1The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard:

    MN 60:2.2“It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. MN 60:2.3He has this good reputation: MN 60:2.4‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ MN 60:2.5He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. MN 60:2.6He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. MN 60:2.7It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

    MN 60:20.1A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way: MN 60:20.2‘If there is effective action, when this individual’s body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 60:20.3But let’s assume that those who say that there is no effective action are correct. MN 60:20.4Regardless, that individual is still praised by sensible people in the present life as being a moral individual of right view, who affirms the efficacy of action.’ MN 60:20.5So if there really is effective action, they win on both counts. MN 60:20.6For they are praised by sensible people in the present life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 60:20.7They have rightly undertaken this guaranteed teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of both sides, leaving out the unskillful premise.

    MN 60:21.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.408There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 60:21.2‘There is no cause or condition for the corruption of sentient beings. MN 60:21.3Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason. MN 60:21.4There’s no cause or condition for the purification of sentient beings. MN 60:21.5Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason. MN 60:21.6There is no power, no energy, no human strength or vigor. MN 60:21.7All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.’

    MN 60:22.1And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this. MN 60:22.10Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”

    MN 60:22.11“Yes, sir.”

    MN 60:22.2They say: MN 60:22.3‘There is a cause and condition for the corruption of sentient beings. MN 60:22.4Sentient beings are corrupted with cause and reason. MN 60:22.5There is a cause and condition for the purification of sentient beings. MN 60:22.6Sentient beings are purified with cause and reason. MN 60:22.7There is power, energy, human strength and vigor. MN 60:22.8It is not the case that all sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy, or that, molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.’

    MN 60:22.9What do you think, householders?

    MN 60:23.1BJ 11.120“Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that MN 60:23.2there’s no cause or condition for the corruption of sentient beings, etc. MN 60:23.7You can expect that they will reject good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and undertake and implement bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 60:23.8Why is that? MN 60:23.9Because those ascetics and brahmins don’t see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, sordidness, and corruption, or that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.

    MN 60:24.1Moreover, since there actually is causality, their view that there is no causality is wrong view. MN 60:24.2Since there actually is causality, their thought that there is no causality is wrong thought. MN 60:24.3Since there actually is causality, their speech that there is no causality is wrong speech. MN 60:24.4Since there actually is causality, in saying that there is no causality they contradict those perfected ones who teach that there is causality. MN 60:24.5Since there actually is causality, in convincing another that there is no causality they are convincing them to accept an untrue teaching. MN 60:24.6And on account of that they glorify themselves and put others down. MN 60:24.7So they give up their former ethical conduct and are established in unethical conduct. MN 60:24.8And that is how wrong view gives rise to these many bad, unskillful qualities—wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, contradicting the noble ones, convincing others to accept untrue teachings, and glorifying oneself and putting others down.

    MN 60:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.409A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way: MN 60:25.2‘If there is no causality, when this individual’s body breaks up they will keep themselves safe.     MN 60:3.1Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha.     MN 60:31.1“A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way: MN 60:31.10that I will be guaranteed rebirth among the gods who possess form and made of mind. MN 60:31.11If those ascetics and brahmins who say that MN 60:31.12there are totally formless meditations are correct, it is possible MN 60:31.13that I will be guaranteed rebirth among the gods who are formless and made of perception. MN 60:31.14Now, owing to form, bad things are seen: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, and disputes, accusations, divisive speech, and lies. MN 60:31.15But those things don’t exist where it is totally formless.’ MN 60:31.16Reflecting like this, they simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding forms.

MN 60:31.4Some ascetics and brahmins say that MN 60:31.5there are totally formless meditations, but I have not known that.     MN 60:34.1“A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way: MN 60:34.10that I will be guaranteed rebirth among the gods who are formless and made of perception.     MN 60:35.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.412Householders, these four people are found in the world. MN 60:35.2What four?

    1. MN 60:35.3One person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
    2. MN 60:35.4One person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
    3. MN 60:35.5One person mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
    4. MN 60:35.6One person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others. MN 60:35.7They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.

    MN 60:36.1BJ 11.126And what person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves? MN 60:36.2It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. … MN 60:36.3And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body. MN 60:36.4This is called a person who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

    MN 60:37.1And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others? MN 60:37.2It’s when a person is a butcher of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood. MN 60:37.3This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.

    MN 60:38.1And what person mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others? MN 60:38.2It’s when a person is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin. … MN 60:38.3His bondservants, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping, with tearful faces. MN 60:38.4This is called a person who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

    MN 60:39.1And what person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others, MN 60:39.2living without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves?

    MN 60:4.1“So, householders, is there some other teacher you’re happy with, in whom you have acquired grounded faith?”

    MN 60:4.2“No, sir.”

    MN 60:4.3“Since you haven’t found a teacher you’re happy with, you should undertake and implement this guaranteed teaching. MN 60:4.4For when the guaranteed teaching is undertaken, it will be for your lasting welfare and happiness. MN 60:4.5And what is the guaranteed teaching?

    MN 60:40-54.1It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha … MN 60:40-54.2A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some good family. … MN 60:40-54.3They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. MN 60:40-54.4Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption … MN 60:40-54.5second absorption … MN 60:40-54.6third absorption … MN 60:40-54.7fourth absorption.

    MN 60:5.1BJ 11.110PTS-VP-PLI 1.402There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 60:5.2‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no obligation to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

    MN 60:55.1BJ 11.128PTS-VP-PLI 1.413When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives. …

    MN 60:55.10They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’

    MN 60:55.2They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

    MN 60:55.3When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 60:55.4With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. … They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

    MN 60:55.5When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 60:55.6They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. MN 60:55.7They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’. MN 60:55.8Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 60:55.9When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

    MN 60:56.1This is called a person who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others. MN 60:56.2They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.”

    MN 60:57.1When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Sālā said to the Buddha, MN 60:57.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! MN 60:57.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways. MN 60:57.4We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 60:57.5From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

    MN 60:6.1And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this. MN 60:6.2They say: MN 60:6.3‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings.     MN 60:6.4What do you think, householders? MN 60:6.5Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”
