    MN 61:0.2Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

    MN 61:1.1BJ 11.130PTS-VP-PLI 1.414So I have heard. MN 61:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

    MN 61:10.1While you are acting with the body, you should check on that same act: MN 61:10.2‘Does this act with the body that I am doing lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both? MN 61:10.3Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’ MN 61:10.4If, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:10.5‘This act with the body that I am doing leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. MN 61:10.6It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should desist from such a deed. MN 61:10.7But if, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:10.8‘This act with the body that I am doing doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. MN 61:10.9It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should continue doing such a deed.

    MN 61:11.1BJ 11.134PTS-VP-PLI 1.417After you have acted with the body, you should check on that same act: MN 61:11.10It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should live in rapture and joy because of this, training day and night in skillful qualities.

    MN 61:11.2‘Does this act with the body that I have done lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both? MN 61:11.3Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’ MN 61:11.4If, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:11.5‘This act with the body that I have done leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. MN 61:11.6It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should confess, reveal, and clarify such a deed to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion. MN 61:11.7And having revealed it you should restrain yourself in future. MN 61:11.8But if, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:11.9‘This act with the body that I have done doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.

    MN 61:12.1When you want to act with speech, you should check on that same deed: MN 61:12.2‘Does this act of speech that I want to do lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both? …’ … MN 61:14.10It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should live in rapture and joy because of this, training day and night in skillful qualities.

    MN 61:14.4If, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:14.5‘This act of speech that I have done leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. MN 61:14.6It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should confess, reveal, and clarify such a deed to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion. MN 61:14.7And having revealed it you should restrain yourself in future. MN 61:14.8But if, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:14.9‘This act of speech that I have done doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.

    MN 61:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.419When you want to act with the mind, you should check on that same deed: MN 61:15.2‘Does this act of mind that I want to do lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both? …’ … MN 61:17.10It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should live in rapture and joy because of this, training day and night in skillful qualities.

    MN 61:17.4If, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:17.5‘This act of mind that I have done leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. MN 61:17.6It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should be horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that deed. MN 61:17.7And being repelled, you should restrain yourself in future. MN 61:17.8But if, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:17.9‘This act with the mind that I have done doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.

    MN 61:18.1BJ 11.140PTS-VP-PLI 1.420All the ascetics and brahmins of the past, future, and present who purify their physical, verbal, and mental actions do so after repeatedly checking. MN 61:18.4So Rāhula, you should train yourself like this: ‘I will purify my physical, verbal, and mental actions after repeatedly checking.’”

    MN 61:18.6That is what the Buddha said. MN 61:18.7Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula was happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 61:2.1Now at that time Venerable Rāhula was staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā. MN 61:2.2Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Ambalaṭṭhika to see Venerable Rāhula. MN 61:2.3Rāhula saw the Buddha coming off in the distance. MN 61:2.4He spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet. MN 61:2.5The Buddha sat on the seat spread out, MN 61:2.6and washed his feet. MN 61:2.7Rāhula bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

    MN 61:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.415Then the Buddha, leaving a little water in the pot, addressed Rāhula, MN 61:3.2“Rāhula, do you see this little bit of water left in the pot?”

    MN 61:3.3“Yes, sir.”

    MN 61:3.4“That’s how little of the ascetic’s nature is left in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”

    MN 61:4.1Then the Buddha, tossing away what little water was left in the pot, said to Rāhula, MN 61:4.2“Do you see this little bit of water that was tossed away?”

    MN 61:4.3“Yes, sir.”

    MN 61:4.4“That’s how the ascetic’s nature is tossed away in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”

    MN 61:5.1Then the Buddha, turning the pot upside down, said to Rāhula, MN 61:5.2“Do you see how this pot is turned upside down?”

    MN 61:5.3“Yes, sir.”

    MN 61:5.4“That’s how the ascetic’s nature is turned upside down in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”

    MN 61:6.1Then the Buddha, turning the pot right side up, said to Rāhula, MN 61:6.2“Do you see how this pot is vacant and hollow?”

    MN 61:6.3“Yes, sir.”

    MN 61:6.4“That’s how vacant and hollow the ascetic’s nature is in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.

    MN 61:7.1Suppose there was a royal bull elephant with tusks like chariot-poles, able to draw a heavy load, pedigree and battle-hardened. In battle it uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, but it still protects its trunk. MN 61:7.10So you should train like this: ‘I will not tell a lie, even for a joke.’ MN 61:7.2So its rider thinks: MN 61:7.3‘This royal bull elephant still protects its trunk. MN 61:7.4It has not yet given its life.’ MN 61:7.5BJ 11.132But when that royal bull elephant … in battle uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, and its trunk, its rider thinks: MN 61:7.6‘This royal bull elephant … in battle uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, and its trunk. MN 61:7.7It has given its life. MN 61:7.8Now there is nothing that royal bull elephant would not do.’

    MN 61:7.9In the same way, when someone is not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie, there is no bad deed they would not do, I say.

    MN 61:8.1What do you think, Rāhula? MN 61:8.2What is the purpose of a mirror?”

    MN 61:8.3“It’s for checking your reflection, sir.”

    MN 61:8.4PTS-VP-PLI 1.416“In the same way, deeds of body, speech, and mind should be done only after repeated checking.

    MN 61:9.1When you want to act with the body, you should check on that same deed: MN 61:9.2‘Does this act with the body that I want to do lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both? MN 61:9.3Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’ MN 61:9.4If, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:9.5‘This act with the body that I want to do leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. MN 61:9.6It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ To the best of your ability, Rāhula, you should not do such a deed. MN 61:9.7But if, while checking in this way, you know: MN 61:9.8‘This act with the body that I want to do doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. MN 61:9.9It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should do such a deed.

    • MN 62:0.1Middle Discourses 62

    MN 62:0.2The Longer Advice to Rāhula

    MN 62:1.1BJ 11.142PTS-VP-PLI 1.421So I have heard. MN 62:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

    MN 62:10.1And what is the fire element? MN 62:10.2The fire element may be interior or exterior. MN 62:10.3And what is the interior fire element? MN 62:10.4Anything that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes: MN 62:10.5that which warms, that which ages, that which heats you up when feverish, that which properly digests food and drink, or anything else that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 62:10.6This is called the interior fire element. MN 62:10.7The interior fire element and the exterior fire element are just the fire element. MN 62:10.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 62:10.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the fire element, detaching the mind from the fire element.

    MN 62:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.423And what is the air element? MN 62:11.2The air element may be interior or exterior. MN 62:11.3And what is the interior air element? MN 62:11.4Anything that’s wind, windy, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes: MN 62:11.5winds that go up or down, winds in the belly or the bowels, winds that flow through the limbs, in-breaths and out-breaths, or anything else that’s air, airy, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 62:11.6This is called the interior air element. MN 62:11.7The interior air element and the exterior air element are just the air element. MN 62:11.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 62:11.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the air element, detaching the mind from the air element.

    MN 62:12.1BJ 11.146And what is the space element? MN 62:12.2The space element may be interior or exterior. MN 62:12.3And what is the interior space element? MN 62:12.4Anything that’s space, spacious, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes: MN 62:12.5the ear canals, nostrils, and mouth; and the space for swallowing what is eaten and drunk, the space where it stays, and the space for excreting it from the nether regions. MN 62:12.6This is called the interior space element. MN 62:12.7The interior space element and the exterior space element are just the space element. MN 62:12.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 62:12.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the space element, detaching the mind from the space element.

    MN 62:13.1Rāhula, meditate like the earth. MN 62:13.2For when you meditate like the earth, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind. MN 62:13.3Suppose they were to toss both clean and unclean things on the earth, like feces, urine, spit, pus, and blood. The earth isn’t horrified, repelled, and disgusted because of this. MN 62:13.4In the same way, meditate like the earth. MN 62:13.5For when you meditate like the earth, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.

    MN 62:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.424Meditate like water. MN 62:14.2For when you meditate like water, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind. MN 62:14.3Suppose they were to wash both clean and unclean things in the water, like feces, urine, spit, pus, and blood. The water isn’t horrified, repelled, and disgusted because of this. MN 62:14.4In the same way, meditate like water. MN 62:14.5For when you meditate like water, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.

    MN 62:15.1Meditate like fire. MN 62:15.2For when you meditate like fire, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind. MN 62:15.3Suppose a fire were to burn both clean and unclean things, like feces, urine, spit, pus, and blood. The fire isn’t horrified, repelled, and disgusted because of this. MN 62:15.4In the same way, meditate like fire. MN 62:15.5For when you meditate like fire, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.

    MN 62:16.1Meditate like wind. MN 62:16.2For when you meditate like wind, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind. MN 62:16.3Suppose the wind were to blow on both clean and unclean things, like feces, urine, spit, pus, and blood. The wind isn’t horrified, repelled, and disgusted because of this. MN 62:16.4In the same way, meditate like the wind. MN 62:16.5For when you meditate like wind, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.

    MN 62:17.1Meditate like space. MN 62:17.2For when you meditate like space, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind. MN 62:17.3Just as space is not established anywhere, MN 62:17.4in the same way, meditate like space. MN 62:17.5For when you meditate like space, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.

    MN 62:18.1BJ 11.148PTS-VP-PLI 1.425Meditate on love. MN 62:18.2For when you meditate on love any ill will will be given up.

    MN 62:19.1Meditate on compassion. MN 62:19.2For when you meditate on compassion any cruelty will be given up.

    MN 62:2.1Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms. MN 62:2.2And Venerable Rāhula also robed up and followed behind the Buddha.

    MN 62:20.1Meditate on rejoicing. MN 62:20.2For when you meditate on rejoicing any discontent will be given up. MN 62:20.3Meditate on equanimity.

    MN 62:21.1For when you meditate on equanimity any repulsion will be given up.

    MN 62:22.1Meditate on ugliness. MN 62:22.2For when you meditate on ugliness any lust will be given up.

    MN 62:23.1Meditate on impermanence. MN 62:23.2For when you meditate on impermanence any conceit ‘I am’ will be given up.

    MN 62:24.1Develop mindfulness of breathing. MN 62:24.2When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. MN 62:24.3And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?

    MN 62:25.1It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, with their body straight, and establishes mindfulness right there. MN 62:25.2Just mindful, they breath in. Mindful, they breath out.

    MN 62:26.1When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’ MN 62:26.2When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ When breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’ MN 62:26.3They practice breathing in experiencing the whole body. They practice breathing out experiencing the whole body. MN 62:26.4They practice breathing in stilling the body’s motion. They practice breathing out stilling the body’s motion.

    MN 62:27.1They practice breathing in experiencing rapture. They practice breathing out experiencing rapture. MN 62:27.2They practice breathing in experiencing bliss. They practice breathing out experiencing bliss. MN 62:27.3They practice breathing in experiencing these emotions. They practice breathing out experiencing these emotions. MN 62:27.4They practice breathing in stilling these emotions. They practice breathing out stilling these emotions.

    MN 62:28.1BJ 11.150They practice breathing in experiencing the mind. They practice breathing out experiencing the mind. MN 62:28.2They practice breathing in gladdening the mind. They practice breathing out gladdening the mind. MN 62:28.3They practice breathing in immersing the mind. They practice breathing out immersing the mind. MN 62:28.4They practice breathing in freeing the mind. They practice breathing out freeing the mind.

    MN 62:29.1They practice breathing in observing impermanence. They practice breathing out observing impermanence. MN 62:29.2They practice breathing in observing fading away. They practice breathing out observing fading away. MN 62:29.3They practice breathing in observing cessation. They practice breathing out observing cessation. MN 62:29.4They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.

    MN 62:3.1Then the Buddha looked back at Rāhula and said, MN 62:3.2“Rāhula, you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’”

    MN 62:3.3“Only form, Blessed One? Only form, Holy One?”

    MN 62:3.4“Form, Rāhula, as well as feeling and perception and choices and consciousness.”

    MN 62:30.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.426Mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial. MN 62:30.2When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated in this way, even when the final breaths in and out cease, they are known, not unknown.”

    MN 62:30.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 62:30.4Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula was happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 62:4.1Then Rāhula thought, “Who would go to the village for alms today after being advised directly by the Buddha?” Turning back, he sat down at the root of a certain tree cross-legged, with his body straight, and established mindfulness right there.

    MN 62:5.1Venerable Sāriputta saw him sitting there, MN 62:5.2and addressed him, MN 62:5.3“Rāhula, develop mindfulness of breathing. MN 62:5.4When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.”

    MN 62:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.422Then in the late afternoon, Rāhula came out of retreat, went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

    MN 62:7.1“Sir, how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?”

    MN 62:8.1“Rāhula, the interior earth element is said to be anything hard, solid, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes: MN 62:8.2head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, or anything else hard, solid, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 62:8.3This is called the interior earth element. MN 62:8.4The interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element. MN 62:8.5This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 62:8.6When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.

    MN 62:9.1BJ 11.144And what is the water element? MN 62:9.2The water element may be interior or exterior. MN 62:9.3And what is the interior water element? MN 62:9.4Anything that’s water, watery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes: MN 62:9.5bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine, or anything else that’s water, watery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 62:9.6This is called the interior water element. MN 62:9.7The interior water element and the exterior water element are just the water element. MN 62:9.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 62:9.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the water element, detaching the mind from the water element.

    MN 63:0.2The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkya

    MN 63:1.1BJ 11.152So I have heard. MN 63:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

    MN 63:10.1And why have I declared these things? MN 63:10.2Because they are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. MN 63:10.3That’s why I have declared them. MN 63:10.4So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared, MN 63:10.5and what I have declared as declared.”

    MN 63:10.6That is what the Buddha said. MN 63:10.7Satisfied, Venerable Māluṅkyaputta was happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 63:2.1Then as Venerable Māluṅkya was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:

    MN 63:2.10I will lead the spiritual life under him. MN 63:2.11If he does not give me a straight answer on any of these points, MN 63:2.14I shall resign the training and return to a lesser life.”

    MN 63:2.2“There are several convictions that the Buddha has left undeclared; he has set them aside and refused to comment on them. MN 63:2.3For example: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist. MN 63:2.4The Buddha does not give me a straight answer on these points. MN 63:2.5I don’t like that, and do not accept it. MN 63:2.6I’ll go to him and ask him about this. MN 63:2.7If he gives me a straight answer on any of these points,

    MN 63:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.427Then in the late afternoon, Māluṅkya came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha of his thoughts. He then continued:

    MN 63:3.17“If the Buddha knows MN 63:3.18that the cosmos is eternal, please tell me. MN 63:3.19If you know MN 63:3.20that the cosmos is not eternal, tell me. MN 63:3.21If you don’t know MN 63:3.22whether the cosmos is eternal or not, then it is straightforward to simply say: MN 63:3.23‘I neither know nor see.’ MN 63:3.24If you know MN 63:3.25that the world is finite, or infinite; that the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; that after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist, please tell me. MN 63:3.49If you don’t know MN 63:3.50any of these things, then it is straightforward to simply say: MN 63:3.51‘I neither know nor see.’”

    MN 63:4.1“What, Māluṅkyaputta, did I ever say to you: MN 63:4.10‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, lead the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you.’ MN 63:4.13And you never said to me: MN 63:4.14‘Sir, I will lead the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me.’ MN 63:4.17In that case, you silly man, are you really in a position to be abandoning anything?

    MN 63:4.2‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, lead the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you’?”

    MN 63:4.4“No, sir.”

    MN 63:4.5“Or did you ever say to me: MN 63:4.6‘Sir, I will lead the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me’?”

    MN 63:4.8“No, sir.”

    MN 63:4.9BJ 11.156“So it seems that I did not say to you:

    MN 63:5.1BJ 11.158PTS-VP-PLI 1.429Suppose someone were to say this: MN 63:5.10He’d say: MN 63:5.11‘I won’t pull out this arrow as long as I don’t know the following things about the man who wounded me: his name and clan; MN 63:5.13whether he’s tall, short, or medium; MN 63:5.15whether his skin is black, brown, or tawny; MN 63:5.17and what village, town, or city he comes from. MN 63:5.19I won’t pull out this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the bow that wounded me is made of wood or cane; MN 63:5.2‘I will not lead the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me MN 63:5.21whether the bow-string is made of swallow-wort fibre, sunn hemp fibre, sinew, sanseveria fibre, or spurge fibre; MN 63:5.23whether the shaft is made from a bush or a plantation tree; MN 63:5.25whether the shaft was fitted with feathers from a vulture, a heron, a hawk, a peacock, or a stork; MN 63:5.27whether the shaft was bound with sinews of a cow, a buffalo, a swamp deer, or a gibbon; MN 63:5.29and whether the arrowhead was spiked, razor-tipped, barbed, made of iron or a calf’s tooth, or lancet-shaped.’ MN 63:5.3that the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal … MN 63:5.30That man would still not have learned these things, and meanwhile they’d die.

    MN 63:5.31In the same way, suppose someone was to say: MN 63:5.32‘I will not lead the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me MN 63:5.33that the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal … MN 63:5.34or that after death a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist.’ MN 63:5.35That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that person would die.

    MN 63:5.4or that after death a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist.’ MN 63:5.5That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that person would die.

    MN 63:5.6Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison. MN 63:5.7His friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a field surgeon to treat him. MN 63:5.8But the man would say: MN 63:5.9‘I won’t pull out this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the man who wounded me was an aristocrat, a brahmin, a merchant, or a worker.’

    MN 63:6.1BJ 11.160PTS-VP-PLI 1.431It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life. MN 63:6.10‘the soul and the body are different things’ … MN 63:6.13‘a Realized One exists after death’ … MN 63:6.14‘a Realized One doesn’t exist after death’ … MN 63:6.17‘a Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death’ … MN 63:6.18‘a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death’ there would be the living of the spiritual life. MN 63:6.19When there are any of these views there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. MN 63:6.2It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is not eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life. MN 63:6.20And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate.

    MN 63:6.3When there is the view that the cosmos is eternal or that the cosmos is not eternal, there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. MN 63:6.4And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate. MN 63:6.5It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the world is finite’ … MN 63:6.6‘the world is infinite’ … MN 63:6.9‘the soul and the body are the same thing’ …

    MN 63:7.1BJ 11.162PTS-VP-PLI 1.432So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared, MN 63:7.11‘the soul and the body are the same thing,’ MN 63:7.13‘the soul and the body are different things,’ MN 63:7.15‘a Realized One exists after death,’ MN 63:7.17‘a Realized One doesn’t exist after death,’ MN 63:7.19‘a Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death,’ MN 63:7.2and what I have declared as declared. MN 63:7.21‘a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death.’ MN 63:7.3And what have I not declared? MN 63:7.4I have not declared the following: ‘the cosmos is eternal,’ MN 63:7.5‘the cosmos is not eternal,’ MN 63:7.7‘the world is finite,’ MN 63:7.9‘the world is infinite,’

    MN 63:8.1And why haven’t I declared these things? MN 63:8.2Because they aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. MN 63:8.3That’s why I haven’t declared them.

    MN 63:9.1And what have I declared? MN 63:9.2I have declared the following: ‘this is suffering,’ MN 63:9.3‘this is the origin of suffering,’ MN 63:9.5‘this is the cessation of suffering,’ MN 63:9.7‘this is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

    • MN 64:0.1Middle Discourses 64

    MN 64:0.2The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

    MN 64:1.1BJ 11.164So I have heard. MN 64:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 64:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 64:1.4“Mendicants!”

    MN 64:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 64:1.6The Buddha said this:

    MN 64:10-12.1Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption … MN 64:10-12.2third absorption … MN 64:10-12.3fourth absorption. MN 64:10-12.4They contemplate the phenomena there as impermanent … MN 64:10-12.5They turn their mind away from those things … MN 64:10-12.6If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, they’re reborn spontaneously … and are not liable to return from that world. MN 64:10-12.7This too is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.

    MN 64:13.1Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space. MN 64:13.2They contemplate the phenomena there as impermanent … MN 64:13.3They turn their mind away from those things … MN 64:13.4If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, they’re reborn spontaneously … and are not liable to return from that world. MN 64:13.5This too is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.

    MN 64:14.1Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. MN 64:14.2They contemplate the phenomena there as impermanent … MN 64:14.3They turn their mind away from those things … MN 64:14.4If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, they’re reborn spontaneously … and are not liable to return from that world. MN 64:14.5This too is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.

    MN 64:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.437Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. MN 64:15.2They contemplate the phenomena there as impermanent … MN 64:15.3They turn their mind away from those things … MN 64:15.4If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, they’re reborn spontaneously … and are not liable to return from that world. MN 64:15.5This too is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.”

    MN 64:16.1BJ 11.172“Sir, if this is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters, how come some mendicants here are released in heart while others are released by wisdom?”

    MN 64:16.2“In that case, I say it is the diversity of their faculties.”

    MN 64:16.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 64:16.4Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 64:2.1“Mendicants, do you remember the five lower fetters that I taught?”

    MN 64:2.10That’s how I remember the five lower fetters taught by the Buddha.”

    MN 64:2.2When he said this, Venerable Māluṅkyaputta said to him, MN 64:2.3“Sir, I remember them.”

    MN 64:2.4“But how do you remember them?”

    MN 64:2.5“I remember the lower fetters taught by the Buddha as follows: identity view, MN 64:2.6doubt, MN 64:2.7misapprehension of precepts and observances, MN 64:2.8sensual desire, MN 64:2.9and ill will.

    MN 64:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.433“Who on earth do you remember being taught the five lower fetters in that way? MN 64:3.10Yet the underlying tendency to sensual desire still lies within them. MN 64:3.11A little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘sentient beings’, so how could ill will for sentient beings possibly arise in them? MN 64:3.12Yet the underlying tendency to ill will still lies within them. MN 64:3.13Wouldn’t the wanderers who follow other paths fault you using the simile of the infant?”

    MN 64:3.2Wouldn’t the wanderers who follow other paths fault you using the simile of the infant? MN 64:3.3For a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘identity’, so how could identity view possibly arise in them? MN 64:3.4Yet the underlying tendency to identity view still lies within them. MN 64:3.5A little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘teachings’, so how could doubt about the teachings possibly arise in them? MN 64:3.6Yet the underlying tendency to doubt still lies within them. MN 64:3.7A little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘precepts’, so how could misapprehension of precepts and observances possibly arise in them? MN 64:3.8Yet the underlying tendency to misapprehension of precepts and observances still lies within them. MN 64:3.9A little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘sensual pleasures’, so how could desire for sensual pleasures possibly arise in them?

    MN 64:4.1BJ 11.166When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha, MN 64:4.2“Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One! MN 64:4.3May the Buddha teach the five lower fetters. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

    MN 64:4.4“Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

    MN 64:4.5“Yes, sir,” Ānanda replied. MN 64:4.6The Buddha said this:

    MN 64:5.1“Ānanda, take an uneducated ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 64:5.10That misapprehension of precepts and observances is reinforced in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.

    MN 64:5.11PTS-VP-PLI 1.434Their heart is overcome and mired in sensual desire, MN 64:5.12and they don’t truly understand the escape from sensual desire that has arisen. MN 64:5.13That sensual desire is reinforced in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.

    MN 64:5.14Their heart is overcome and mired in ill will, MN 64:5.15and they don’t truly understand the escape from ill will that has arisen. MN 64:5.16That ill will is reinforced in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.

    MN 64:5.2Their heart is overcome and mired in identity view, MN 64:5.3and they don’t truly understand the escape from identity view that has arisen. MN 64:5.4That identity view is reinforced in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.

    MN 64:5.5Their heart is overcome and mired in doubt, MN 64:5.6and they don’t truly understand the escape from doubt that has arisen. MN 64:5.7That doubt is reinforced in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.

    MN 64:5.8Their heart is overcome and mired in misapprehension of precepts and observances, MN 64:5.9and they don’t truly understand the escape from misapprehension of precepts and observances that has arisen.

    MN 64:6.1But an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons. Their heart is not overcome and mired in identity view,

    MN 64:6.10Their heart is not overcome and mired in sensual desire, MN 64:6.11and they truly understand the escape from sensual desire that has arisen. MN 64:6.12That sensual desire, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.

    MN 64:6.13Their heart is not overcome and mired in ill will, MN 64:6.14and they truly understand the escape from ill will that has arisen. MN 64:6.15That ill will, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.

    MN 64:6.16BJ 11.168There is a path and a practice for giving up the five lower fetters. It’s not possible to know or see or give up the five lower fetters without relying on that path and that practice. MN 64:6.17Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood. It’s not possible to cut out the heartwood without having cut through the bark and the softwood. MN 64:6.19In the same way, there is a path and a practice for giving up the five lower fetters. It’s not possible to know or see or give up the five lower fetters without relying on that path and that practice.

    MN 64:6.2and they truly understand the escape from identity view that has arisen. MN 64:6.3That identity view, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.

    MN 64:6.4Their heart is not overcome and mired in doubt, MN 64:6.5and they truly understand the escape from doubt that has arisen. MN 64:6.6That doubt, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.

    MN 64:6.7Their heart is not overcome and mired in misapprehension of precepts and observances, MN 64:6.8and they truly understand the escape from misapprehension of precepts and observances that has arisen. MN 64:6.9That misapprehension of precepts and observances, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.

    MN 64:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.435There is a path and a practice for giving up the five lower fetters. It is possible to know and see and give up the five lower fetters by relying on that path and that practice.

    MN 64:8.1Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood. It is possible to cut out the heartwood after having cut through the bark and the softwood. MN 64:8.10Then along comes a strong person, who thinks: MN 64:8.11‘By swimming with my arms I’ll safely cross over to the far shore of the Ganges.’ MN 64:8.12And they are able to do so.

    MN 64:8.13In the same way, when the Dhamma is being taught for the cessation of identity view, someone whose mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided MN 64:8.14should be regarded as being like that strong person.

    MN 64:8.2In the same way, there is a path and a practice for giving up the five lower fetters. It is possible to know and see and give up the five lower fetters by relying on that path and that practice. MN 64:8.3Suppose the river Ganges was full to the brim so a crow could drink from it. MN 64:8.4Then along comes a feeble person, who thinks: MN 64:8.5‘By swimming with my arms I’ll safely cross over to the far shore of the Ganges.’ MN 64:8.6But they’re not able to do so. MN 64:8.7In the same way, when the Dhamma is being taught for the cessation of identity view, someone whose mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided MN 64:8.8should be regarded as being like that feeble person. MN 64:8.9Suppose the river Ganges was full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.

    MN 64:9.1BJ 11.170PTS-VP-PLI 1.436And what, Ānanda, is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters? MN 64:9.2It’s when a mendicant—due to the seclusion from attachments, the giving up of unskillful qualities, and the complete settling of physical discomfort—quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 64:9.3They contemplate the phenomena there—included in form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self. MN 64:9.4They turn their mind away from those things, MN 64:9.5and apply it to the deathless element: MN 64:9.6‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, cessation, extinguishment.’ MN 64:9.7Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements. MN 64:9.8If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. MN 64:9.9This is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.

    MN 65:0.2With Bhaddāli

    MN 65:1.1BJ 11.174So I have heard. MN 65:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 65:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 65:1.4“Mendicants!”

    MN 65:10.1“I made a mistake, sir.     MN 65:10.3“Indeed, Bhaddāli, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you that, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, you announced you would not try to keep it.

    MN 65:11.13“No, sir.”

    MN 65:11.2Suppose I was to say this to a mendicant who is freed both ways: MN 65:11.3‘Please, mendicant, be a bridge for me to cross over the mud.’ Would they cross over themselves, or struggle to get out of it, or just say no?”

    MN 65:11.4“No, sir.”

    MN 65:11.5“What do you think, Bhaddāli? MN 65:11.6Suppose I was to say the same thing to a mendicant who is freed by wisdom, MN 65:11.7or a personal witness, MN 65:11.8or attained to view, MN 65:11.9or freed by faith,

    MN 65:12.4“Weren’t you void, hollow, and mistaken?”

    MN 65:13.1“Yes, sir.”

    MN 65:13.2“I made a mistake, sir. … MN 65:13.3Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”

MN 65:13.6For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.

    MN 65:14.1BJ 11.180Bhaddāli, take a mendicant who doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions. MN 65:14.2They think, MN 65:14.3‘Why don’t I frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw. MN 65:14.4Hopefully I’ll realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.’ MN 65:14.5So they frequent a secluded lodging. MN 65:14.6While they’re living withdrawn, they’re reprimanded by the Teacher, by sensible spiritual companions after examination, by deities, and by themselves. MN 65:14.7Being reprimanded in this way, they don’t realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones. MN 65:14.8Why is that? MN 65:14.9Because that’s how it is when someone doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.

    MN 65:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.441But take a mendicant who does fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions. MN 65:15.2They think, MN 65:15.3‘Why don’t I frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.     MN 65:16.1Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 65:16.2Why is that? MN 65:16.3Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.

    MN 65:17.1Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 65:17.2Why is that? MN 65:17.3Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.

    MN 65:17.4Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 65:17.5Why is that? MN 65:17.6Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.

    MN 65:17.7Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 65:17.8Why is that? MN 65:17.9Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.

    MN 65:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.442When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives. MN 65:18.2They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. MN 65:18.3Why is that? MN 65:18.4Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.

    MN 65:19.1BJ 11.182When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.     MN 66:0.2The Simile of the Quail

    MN 66:1.1BJ 11.190PTS-VP-PLI 1.448So I have heard. MN 66:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Northern Āpaṇas, near the town of theirs named Āpaṇa.

    MN 66:10.1Suppose there was a royal bull elephant with tusks like chariot-poles, able to draw a heavy load, pedigree and battle-hardened. And it was bound with a strong harness. But just by twisting its body a little, it would break apart its bonds and go wherever it wants. MN 66:10.10and when the mendicants who want to train have given that up, they live relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer. MN 66:10.11For them, that bond is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.

    MN 66:10.2Would it be right to say that, MN 66:10.3for that bull elephant, that strong harness is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke?”

    MN 66:10.5“No, sir. MN 66:10.6For that bull elephant, that strong harness is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.”

    MN 66:10.7BJ 11.196“In the same way, when some gentlemen are told by me to give something up, they say, MN 66:10.8‘What, we just have to give up such a trivial, insignificant thing as this, when the Blessed One tells us to give it up, the Holy One tells us to let it go?’ MN 66:10.9They give it up, and they don’t nurse bitterness towards me;

    MN 66:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.451Suppose there was a poor man, with few possessions and little wealth. MN 66:11.10those bonds are weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial?”

    MN 66:11.12“No, sir. MN 66:11.13For that man, MN 66:11.14they are a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.”

    MN 66:11.15“In the same way, when some foolish people are told by me to give something up, they say, MN 66:11.16‘What, such a trivial, insignificant thing as this?     MN 66:11.2He had a single broken-down hovel open to the crows, not the best sort; a single broken-down couch, not the best sort; a single pot for storing grain, not the best sort; and a single wifey, not the best sort.     MN 66:12.1BJ 11.198PTS-VP-PLI 1.452Suppose there was a rich man, affluent, and wealthy. He had a vast amount of gold coin, grain, fields, lands, wives, and male and female bondservants.

    MN 66:12.10PTS-VP-PLI 1.453“No, sir. MN 66:12.11For that man, MN 66:12.12those bonds are weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.”

    MN 66:13.1Udāyī, these four people are found in the world. MN 66:13.2What four?

    MN 66:14.1Take a certain person practicing to give up and let go of attachments. MN 66:14.2As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them. MN 66:14.3They tolerate them and don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them. MN 66:14.4I call this person ‘fettered’, not ‘detached’. MN 66:14.5Why is that? MN 66:14.6Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.

    MN 66:15.1BJ 11.200Take another person practicing to give up and let go of attachments. MN 66:15.2As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them. MN 66:15.3They don’t tolerate them, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them. MN 66:15.4I call this person ‘fettered’, not ‘detached’. MN 66:15.5Why is that? MN 66:15.6Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.

    MN 66:16.1Take another person practicing to give up and let go of attachments. MN 66:16.10but they quickly give them up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts. MN 66:16.11I also call this person ‘fettered’, not ‘detached’. MN 66:16.12Why is that? MN 66:16.13Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.

    MN 66:16.2As they do so, every so often they lose mindfulness, and memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them. MN 66:16.3Their mindfulness is slow to come up, MN 66:16.4but they quickly give up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts. MN 66:16.5Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day, and a person let two or three drops of water fall onto it. MN 66:16.6The drops would be slow to fall, but they’d quickly dry up and evaporate.

    MN 66:16.7PTS-VP-PLI 1.454In the same way, take a person practicing to give up and let go of attachments. MN 66:16.8As they do so, every so often they lose mindfulness, and memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them. MN 66:16.9Their mindfulness is slow to come up,

    MN 66:17.1Take another person who, understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, MN 66:17.2is freed with the ending of attachments. MN 66:17.3I call this person ‘detached’, not ‘fettered’. MN 66:17.4Why is that? MN 66:17.5Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person. MN 66:17.6These are the four people found in the world.

    MN 66:18.1Udāyī, these are the five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 66:18.2What five? MN 66:18.3Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 66:18.4Sounds known by the ear … MN 66:18.5Smells known by the nose … MN 66:18.6Tastes known by the tongue … MN 66:18.7Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 66:18.8These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

    MN 66:19.1The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, ordinary, ignoble pleasure. Such pleasure should not be cultivated or developed, but should be feared, I say.

    MN 66:2.1Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms. MN 66:2.2He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. MN 66:2.3Having plunged deep into it, he sat at the root of a certain tree for the day’s meditation.

    MN 66:20.1Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption … MN 66:20.2second absorption … MN 66:20.3third absorption … MN 66:20.4fourth absorption.

    MN 66:21.1This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening. Such pleasure should be cultivated and developed, and should not be feared, I say.

    MN 66:22.1BJ 11.202PTS-VP-PLI 1.455Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption. MN 66:22.2This belongs to the perturbable, I say. MN 66:22.3And what there belongs to the perturbable? MN 66:22.4Whatever placing of the mind and keeping it connected has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.

    MN 66:23.1Take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption. MN 66:23.2This belongs to the perturbable, I say. MN 66:23.3And what there belongs to the perturbable? MN 66:23.4Whatever rapture and bliss has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.

    MN 66:24.1Take a mendicant who, with the fading away of rapture, enters and remains in the third absorption. MN 66:24.2This belongs to the perturbable. MN 66:24.3And what there belongs to the perturbable? MN 66:24.4Whatever equanimous bliss has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.

    MN 66:25.1Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, enters and remains in the fourth absorption. MN 66:25.2This belongs to the imperturbable.

    MN 66:26.1BJ 11.204PTS-VP-PLI 1.456Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption. MN 66:26.2But this is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it. MN 66:26.3And what goes beyond it?

    MN 66:27.1Take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption. That goes beyond it. MN 66:27.2But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it. MN 66:27.3And what goes beyond it?

    MN 66:28.1Take a mendicant who, with the fading away of rapture, enters and remains in the third absorption. That goes beyond it. MN 66:28.2But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it. MN 66:28.3And what goes beyond it?

    MN 66:29.1Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, enters and remains in the fourth absorption. That goes beyond it. MN 66:29.2But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it. MN 66:29.3And what goes beyond it?

    MN 66:3.1Venerable Udāyī also robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms. MN 66:3.2He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa.     MN 66:30.1Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.     MN 66:34.4“No, sir.”

    MN 66:34.5That is what the Buddha said. MN 66:34.6Satisfied, Venerable Udāyī was happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 66:4.1“The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness! MN 66:4.2He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!”

    MN 66:5.1BJ 11.192PTS-VP-PLI 1.449Then in the late afternoon, Udāyī came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

    MN 66:6.1“Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind: MN 66:6.10Then we ate in the evening and the morning.

    MN 66:6.11But then there came a time when the Buddha addressed the mendicants, saying, MN 66:6.12‘Please, mendicants, give up that meal at the wrong time of night.’ MN 66:6.13At that, sir, we became sad and upset, MN 66:6.14‘But that’s considered the more delicious of the two meals. He said, MN 66:6.16‘Come, let’s set this aside; we’ll enjoy it together this evening.’ MN 66:6.17Nearly all meals are prepared at night, only a few in the day. MN 66:6.18But when we considered our love and respect for the Buddha, and our sense of conscience and prudence, we gave up that meal at the wrong time of night.

    MN 66:6.19In the past, mendicants went wandering for alms in the dark of the night.     MN 66:6.2‘The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!

    MN 66:6.20Once it so happened that I wandered for alms in the dark of the night. MN 66:6.21A woman washing a pot saw me by a flash of lightning. MN 66:6.22Startled, she cried out, MN 66:6.23‘Bloody hell! A goblin’s upon me!’

    MN 66:6.27‘Then it’s a mendicant whose ma died and pa died! MN 66:6.28You’d be better off having your belly sliced open with a meat cleaver than to wander for alms in the dark of night for the sake of your belly.’

    MN 66:6.4For we used to eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.     MN 66:7.1BJ 11.194“This is exactly what happens when some foolish people are told by me to give something up. They say, MN 66:7.2‘What, such a trivial, insignificant thing as this?     MN 66:8.2Would it be right to say that, MN 66:8.3for that quail, that vine is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial?”

    MN 66:8.5“No, sir. MN 66:8.6For that quail, that vine is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.”

    MN 67:0.2At Cātumā

    MN 67:1.1BJ 11.206PTS-VP-PLI 1.457So I have heard. MN 67:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Cātumā in a myrobalan grove.

    MN 67:10.1BJ 11.210The Sakyans of Cātumā and Brahmā Sahampati were able to restore the Buddha’s confidence with the similes of the seedlings and the calf.

    MN 67:11.1Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants, MN 67:11.2“Get up, reverends, and pick up your bowls and robes. MN 67:11.3The Buddha’s confidence has been restored by the Sakyans of Cātumā and Brahmā Sahampati with the similes of the seedlings and the calf.”

    MN 67:12.1“Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and, taking their bowls and robes, went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to Venerable Sāriputta, MN 67:12.2“Sāriputta, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”

    MN 67:12.3“Sir, I thought this: MN 67:12.4‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 67:12.5Now he will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life, and so will we.’”

    MN 67:12.6“Hold on, Sāriputta, hold on! Don’t you ever think such a thing again!”

    MN 67:13.1Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, MN 67:13.2“Moggallāna, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”

    MN 67:13.3“Sir, I thought this: MN 67:13.4‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 67:13.5Now he will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life. Meanwhile, Venerable Sāriputta and I will lead the mendicant Saṅgha.’”

    MN 67:13.6“Good, good, Moggallāna! MN 67:13.7For either I should lead the mendicant Saṅgha, or else Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”

    MN 67:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.460Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

    MN 67:14.2“Mendicants, when you go into the water you should anticipate four dangers. MN 67:14.3What four? MN 67:14.4The dangers of waves, crocodiles, whirlpools, and sharks. MN 67:14.5These are the four dangers that anyone who enters the water should anticipate.

    MN 67:15.1In the same way, a gentleman who goes forth from the lay life to homelessness in this teaching and training should anticipate four dangers. MN 67:15.2What four? MN 67:15.3The dangers of waves, crocodiles, whirlpools, and sharks.

    MN 67:16.1BJ 11.212And what, mendicants, is the danger of waves? MN 67:16.10They resign the training and return to a lesser life. MN 67:16.11This is called one who resigns the training and returns to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of waves. MN 67:16.12‘Danger of waves’ is a term for anger and distress.

    MN 67:16.2It’s when a gentleman has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking: MN 67:16.3‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. MN 67:16.4Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’ MN 67:16.5When they’ve gone forth, their spiritual companions advise and instruct them: MN 67:16.6‘You should go out like this, and come back like that. You should look to the front like this, and to the side like that. You should contract your limbs like this, and extend them like that. This is how you should bear your outer robe, bowl, and robes.’ MN 67:16.7They think: MN 67:16.8‘Formerly, as laypeople, we advised and instructed others. MN 67:16.9And now these mendicants—who you’d think were our children or grandchildren—imagine they can advise and instruct us!’

    MN 67:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.461And what, mendicants, is the danger of crocodiles? MN 67:17.10They resign the training and return to a lesser life. MN 67:17.11This is called one who resigns the training and returns to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of crocodiles. MN 67:17.12‘Danger of crocodiles’ is a term for gluttony.

    MN 67:17.2It’s when a gentleman has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking: MN 67:17.3‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. MN 67:17.4Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’ MN 67:17.5When they’ve gone forth, their spiritual companions advise and instruct them: MN 67:17.6‘You may eat, consume, taste, and drink these things, but not those. You may eat what’s allowable, but not what’s unallowable. You may eat at the right time, but not at the wrong time.’ MN 67:17.7They think: ‘Formerly, as laypeople, we used to eat, consume, taste, and drink what we wanted, not what we didn’t want. MN 67:17.8We ate and drank both allowable and unallowable things, at the right time and the wrong time. MN 67:17.9And these faithful householders give us a variety of delicious foods at the wrong time of day. But these mendicants imagine they can gag our mouths!’

    MN 67:18.1BJ 11.214And what, mendicants, is the danger of whirlpools? MN 67:18.10I can both enjoy my wealth and make merit.’ MN 67:18.11They resign the training and return to a lesser life. MN 67:18.12This is called one who resigns the training and returns to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of whirlpools. MN 67:18.13‘Danger of whirlpools’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

    MN 67:18.2It’s when a gentleman has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking: MN 67:18.3‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. MN 67:18.4Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’ MN 67:18.5When they’ve gone forth, they robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties. MN 67:18.6There they see a householder or their child amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 67:18.7They think: MN 67:18.8‘Formerly, as laypeople, we amused ourselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 67:18.9And it’s true that my family is wealthy.

    MN 67:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.462And what, mendicants, is the danger of sharks? MN 67:19.10‘Danger of sharks’ is a term for females.

    MN 67:19.2It’s when a gentleman has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking: MN 67:19.3‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. MN 67:19.4Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’ MN 67:19.5When they’ve gone forth, they robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties. MN 67:19.6There they see a female scantily clad, with revealing clothes. MN 67:19.7Lust infects their mind, MN 67:19.8so they resign the training and return to a lesser life. MN 67:19.9This is called one who resigns the training and returns to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of sharks.

    MN 67:2.1Now at that time around five hundred mendicants headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna arrived at Cātumā to see the Buddha. MN 67:2.2And the visiting mendicants, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.

    MN 67:20.1These are the four dangers that a gentleman who goes forth from the lay life to homelessness in this teaching and training should anticipate.”

    MN 67:20.2That is what the Buddha said. MN 67:20.3Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 67:3.1Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda, MN 67:3.2“Ānanda, who’s making that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”

    MN 67:3.3And Ānanda told him what had happened.

    MN 67:4.1“Well then, Ānanda, in my name tell those mendicants that MN 67:4.2the teacher summons them.”

    MN 67:4.3“Yes, sir,” Ānanda replied. He went to those mendicants and said, MN 67:4.4“Venerables, the teacher summons you.”

    MN 67:4.5“Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:

    MN 67:4.6“Mendicants, what’s with that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”

    MN 67:4.7And they told him what had happened.

    MN 67:5.1“Go away, mendicants, I dismiss you. You are not to stay in my presence.”

    MN 67:5.2“Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. They set their lodgings in order and left, taking their bowls and robes.

    MN 67:6.1BJ 11.208PTS-VP-PLI 1.458Now at that time the Sakyans of Cātumā were sitting together at the meeting hall on some business. MN 67:6.2Seeing those mendicants coming off in the distance, MN 67:6.3they went up to them and said, MN 67:6.4“Hello venerables, where are you going?”

    MN 67:6.5“Sirs, the mendicant Saṅgha has been dismissed by the Buddha.”

    MN 67:6.7“Yes, sirs,” replied the mendicants.

    MN 67:7.1Then the Sakyans of Cātumā went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

    MN 67:7.10In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart. MN 67:7.11May the Buddha approve of the mendicant Saṅgha! MN 67:7.12May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha! MN 67:7.13May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!”

    MN 67:7.2“May the Buddha approve of the mendicant Saṅgha! MN 67:7.3May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha! MN 67:7.4May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past! MN 67:7.5There are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. MN 67:7.6If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart. MN 67:7.7If young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart. MN 67:7.8In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart. MN 67:7.9If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart.

    MN 67:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.459Then Brahmā Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the Brahmā realm and reappeared in front of the Buddha. MN 67:8.2He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

    MN 67:9.1“May the Buddha approve of the mendicant Saṅgha! MN 67:9.10May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha! MN 67:9.11May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!”

    MN 67:9.2May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha! MN 67:9.3May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past! MN 67:9.4There are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart. MN 67:9.5If young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart. … MN 67:9.7If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart. MN 67:9.8In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart. MN 67:9.9May the Buddha approve of the mendicant Saṅgha!

    MN 68:10.1Take a monk who hears this: MN 68:10.2‘The monk named so-and-so has passed away.     MN 68:24.1So it’s not for the sake of deceiving people or flattering them, nor for the benefit of possessions, honor, or popularity, nor thinking, ‘So let people know about me!’ that the Realized One declares the rebirth of his disciples who have passed away: MN 68:24.2‘This one is reborn here, while that one is reborn there.’ MN 68:24.3Rather, there are gentlemen of faith who are full of joy and gladness. MN 68:24.4When they hear that, they apply their minds to that end. MN 68:24.5That is for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

    MN 68:24.6That is what the Buddha said. MN 68:24.7Satisfied, Venerable Anuruddha and friends were happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 68:3.1Now at that time the Buddha was sitting in the open, surrounded by the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 68:3.10For a third time, the mendicants kept silent.

    MN 68:3.2Then the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about those gentlemen: MN 68:3.3“Mendicants, those gentlemen who have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith in me—I trust they’re satisfied with the spiritual life?” MN 68:3.4When this was said, the mendicants kept silent.

    MN 68:3.5For a second and a third time the Buddha asked the same question.

    MN 68:4.1Then it occurred to the Buddha, MN 68:4.2“Why don’t I question just those gentlemen?” MN 68:4.3Then the Buddha said to Venerable Anuruddha, MN 68:4.4“Anuruddha and friends, I hope you’re satisfied with the spiritual life?”

    MN 68:4.5“Indeed, sir, we are satisfied with the spiritual life.”

    MN 68:5.1“Good, good, Anuruddha and friends! MN 68:5.2It’s appropriate for gentlemen like yourselves, who have gone forth in faith from the lay life to homelessness, to be satisfied with the spiritual life. MN 68:5.3Since you’re blessed with youth, in the prime of life, black-haired, you could have enjoyed sensual pleasures; yet you have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness. MN 68:5.4But you didn’t go forth because you were forced to by kings or bandits, or because you’re in debt or threatened, or to earn a living. MN 68:5.5Rather, didn’t you go forth thinking: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. MN 68:5.6Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering’?”

    MN 68:5.8“Yes, sir.”

    MN 68:6.1BJ 11.218PTS-VP-PLI 1.464“But, Anuruddha and friends, when a gentleman has gone forth like this, what should he do? MN 68:6.2Take someone who doesn’t achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that. Their mind is still occupied by desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, doubt, discontent, and sloth. MN 68:6.3That’s someone who doesn’t achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that.

    MN 68:6.4Take someone who does achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that. Their mind is not occupied by desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, doubt, discontent, and sloth. MN 68:6.5That’s someone who does achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that.

    MN 68:7.1Is this what you think of me?

    MN 68:7.10“Good, good, Anuruddha and friends! MN 68:7.11The Realized One has given up the defilements, the corruptions that lead to future lives and are hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future. MN 68:7.12Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth, MN 68:7.13in the same way, the Realized One has given up the defilements so they are unable to arise in the future. MN 68:7.14That’s why, after appraisal, he uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.

    MN 68:7.2‘The Realized One has not given up the defilements, the corruptions that lead to future lives and are hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. MN 68:7.3That’s why, after appraisal, he uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.’”

    MN 68:7.4“No sir, we don’t think of you that way. MN 68:7.7We think of you this way: MN 68:7.8‘The Realized One has given up the defilements, the corruptions that lead to future lives and are hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. MN 68:7.9That’s why, after appraisal, he uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.’”

    MN 68:8.1BJ 11.220What do you think, Anuruddha and friends? MN 68:8.2What advantage does the Realized One see in declaring the rebirth of his disciples who have passed away: MN 68:8.3‘This one is reborn here, while that one is reborn there’?”

    MN 68:8.4PTS-VP-PLI 1.465“Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

    MN 68:9.1“The Realized One does not declare such things for the sake of deceiving people or flattering them, nor for the benefit of possessions, honor, or popularity, nor thinking, ‘So let people know about me!’ MN 68:9.3Rather, there are gentlemen of faith who are full of sublime joy and gladness. MN 68:9.4When they hear that, they apply their minds to that end. MN 68:9.5That is for their lasting welfare and happiness.
