    MN 69:0.2With Gulissāni

    MN 69:1.1BJ 11.228PTS-VP-PLI 1.469So I have heard. MN 69:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

    MN 69:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.471A wilderness monk should guard the sense doors. MN 69:10.2If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:10.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he doesn’t guard the sense doors?’ MN 69:10.5That’s why a wilderness monk should guard the sense doors.

    MN 69:11.1BJ 11.232A wilderness monk should eat in moderation. MN 69:11.2If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:11.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he eats too much?’ MN 69:11.5That’s why a wilderness monk should eat in moderation.

    MN 69:12.1A wilderness monk should be committed to wakefulness. MN 69:12.2If he isn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:12.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he’s not committed to wakefulness?’ MN 69:12.5That’s why a wilderness monk should be committed to wakefulness.

    MN 69:13.1A wilderness monk should be energetic. MN 69:13.2If he isn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:13.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he’s not energetic?’ MN 69:13.5That’s why a wilderness monk should be energetic.

    MN 69:14.1A wilderness monk should be mindful. MN 69:14.2If he isn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:14.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he’s not mindful?’ MN 69:14.5That’s why a wilderness monk should be mindful.

    MN 69:15.1A wilderness monk should have immersion. MN 69:15.2If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:15.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he doesn’t have immersion?’ MN 69:15.5That’s why a wilderness monk should have immersion.

    MN 69:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.472A wilderness monk should be wise. MN 69:16.2If he isn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:16.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he’s not wise?’ MN 69:16.5That’s why a wilderness monk should be wise.

    MN 69:17.1A wilderness monk should make an effort to learn the teaching and training. MN 69:17.2There are those who will question a wilderness monk about the teaching and training. MN 69:17.3If he is stumped, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:17.4‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he is stumped by a question about the teaching and training?’ MN 69:17.6That’s why a wilderness monk should make an effort to learn the teaching and training.

    MN 69:18.1BJ 11.234A wilderness monk should practice meditation to realize the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. MN 69:18.2There are those who will question a wilderness monk regarding the formless liberations. MN 69:18.3If he is stumped, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:18.4‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he is stumped by a question about the formless liberations?’ MN 69:18.6That’s why a wilderness monk should practice meditation to realize the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form.

    MN 69:19.1A wilderness monk should practice meditation to realize the superhuman state. MN 69:19.2There are those who will question a wilderness monk about the superhuman state. MN 69:19.3If he is stumped, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:19.4‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he doesn’t know the goal for which he went forth?’ MN 69:19.6That’s why a wilderness monk should practice meditation to realize the superhuman state.”

    MN 69:19.7PTS-VP-PLI 1.473When Venerable Sāriputta said this, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said to him, MN 69:19.8“Reverend Sāriputta, should these things be undertaken and followed only by wilderness monks, or by those who live within a village as well?”

    MN 69:19.9“Reverend Moggallāna, these things should be undertaken and followed by wilderness monks, and still more by those who live within a village.”

    MN 69:2.1Now at that time a wilderness mendicant of lax behavior named Gulissāni had come down to the midst of the Saṅgha on some business. MN 69:2.2There Venerable Sāriputta spoke to the mendicants about Gulissāni:

    MN 69:3.1“Reverends, a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should have respect and reverence for his spiritual companions. MN 69:3.2If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:3.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he has no respect and reverence for his spiritual companions?’ MN 69:3.5That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should have respect and reverence for his spiritual companions.

    MN 69:4.1A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should be careful where he sits, thinking: MN 69:4.11That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should know even the supplementary regulations.

    MN 69:4.2‘I shall sit so that I don’t intrude on the senior monks and I don’t block the junior monks from a seat.’ MN 69:4.3If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:4.4‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he’s not careful where he sits?’ MN 69:4.6That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should be careful where he sits.

    MN 69:4.7A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should know even the supplementary regulations. MN 69:4.8If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:4.9‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he doesn’t even know the supplementary regulations?’

    MN 69:5.1A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t enter the village too early or return too late in the day. MN 69:5.2If he does so, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:5.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he enters the village too early or returns too late in the day?’ MN 69:5.5That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t enter the village too early or return too late in the day.

    MN 69:6.1BJ 11.230PTS-VP-PLI 1.470A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t socialize with families before or after the meal. MN 69:6.2If he does so, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:6.3‘This wilderness venerable, staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, must be used to wandering about at the wrong time, since he behaves like this when he’s come to the Saṅgha.’ MN 69:6.5That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t socialize with families before or after the meal.

    MN 69:7.1A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t be restless and fickle. MN 69:7.2If he is, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:7.3‘This wilderness venerable, staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, must be used to being restless and fickle, since he behaves like this when he’s come to the Saṅgha.’ MN 69:7.5That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t be restless and fickle.

    MN 69:8.1A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t be scurrilous and loose-tongued. MN 69:8.2If he is, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:8.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he’s scurrilous and loose-tongued?’ MN 69:8.5That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t be scurrilous and loose-tongued.

    MN 69:9.1A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should be easy to admonish, with good friends. MN 69:9.2If he’s hard to admonish, with bad friends, there’ll be some who say: MN 69:9.3‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he’s hard to admonish, with bad friends?’ MN 69:9.5That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should be easy to admonish, with good friends.

    • MN 70:0.1Middle Discourses 70

    MN 70:0.2At Kīṭāgiri

    MN 70:1.1BJ 11.236So I have heard. MN 70:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kāsīs together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. MN 70:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

    MN 70:10.1Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

    MN 70:10.10“No, sir.”

    MN 70:10.2‘When someone feels this kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ MN 70:10.3Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should give up this kind of neutral feeling’?”

    MN 70:10.4“No, sir.”

    MN 70:10.5BJ 11.242“But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:10.6‘When someone feels this kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should give up this kind of neutral feeling.’ MN 70:10.7Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:10.8‘When someone feels that kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ MN 70:10.9Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of neutral feeling’?”

    MN 70:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.477“But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:11.2‘When someone feels that kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of neutral feeling.’

    MN 70:12.1Mendicants, I don’t say that all these mendicants still have work to do with diligence. MN 70:12.2Nor do I say that all these mendicants have no work to do with diligence. MN 70:12.3I say that mendicants don’t have work to do with diligence if they are perfected, with defilements ended, having completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and become rightly freed through enlightenment. MN 70:12.4Why is that? MN 70:12.5They’ve done their work with diligence. MN 70:12.6They’re incapable of being negligent.

    MN 70:13.1I say that mendicants still have work to do with diligence if they are trainees, who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary. MN 70:13.2Why is that? Thinking: MN 70:13.3‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties. MN 70:13.4Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’ MN 70:13.5Seeing this fruit of diligence for those mendicants, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

    MN 70:14.1Mendicants, these seven people are found in the world. MN 70:14.2What seven? MN 70:14.3One freed both ways, one freed by wisdom, a personal witness, one attained to view, one freed by faith, a follower of the teachings, and a follower by faith.

    MN 70:15.1And what person is freed both ways? MN 70:15.2It’s a person who has direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements have come to an end. MN 70:15.3This person is called freed both ways. MN 70:15.4And I say that this mendicant has no work to do with diligence. MN 70:15.5Why is that? MN 70:15.6They’ve done their work with diligence. MN 70:15.7They’re incapable of being negligent.

    MN 70:16.1BJ 11.244PTS-VP-PLI 1.478And what person is freed by wisdom? MN 70:16.2It’s a person who does not have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. Nevertheless, having seen with wisdom, their defilements have come to an end. MN 70:16.3This person is called freed by wisdom. MN 70:16.4I say that this mendicant has no work to do with diligence. MN 70:16.5Why is that? MN 70:16.6They’ve done their work with diligence. MN 70:16.7They’re incapable of being negligent.

    MN 70:17.1And what person is a personal witness? MN 70:17.2It’s a person who has direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. And, having seen with wisdom, some of their defilements have come to an end. MN 70:17.3This person is called a personal witness. MN 70:17.4I say that this mendicant still has work to do with diligence. MN 70:17.5Why is that? Thinking: MN 70:17.6‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties. MN 70:17.7Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’ MN 70:17.8Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

    MN 70:18.1And what person is attained to view? MN 70:18.2It’s a person who doesn’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. Nevertheless, having seen with wisdom, some of their defilements have come to an end. And they have clearly seen and clearly contemplated with wisdom the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One. MN 70:18.3This person is called attained to view. MN 70:18.4I say that this mendicant also still has work to do with diligence. MN 70:18.5Why is that? Thinking: MN 70:18.6‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties. MN 70:18.7Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’ MN 70:18.8Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

    MN 70:19.1BJ 11.246PTS-VP-PLI 1.479And what person is freed by faith? MN 70:19.2It’s a person who doesn’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. Nevertheless, having seen with wisdom, some of their defilements have come to an end. And their faith is settled, rooted, and planted in the Realized One. MN 70:19.3This person is called freed by faith. MN 70:19.4I say that this mendicant also still has work to do with diligence. MN 70:19.5Why is that? Thinking: MN 70:19.6‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties. MN 70:19.7Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’ MN 70:19.8Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

    MN 70:2.1“Mendicants, I abstain from eating at night. MN 70:2.2Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably. MN 70:2.3You too should abstain from eating at night. MN 70:2.4Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”

    MN 70:2.5“Yes, sir,” they replied.

    MN 70:20.1And what person is a follower of the teachings? MN 70:20.2It’s a person who doesn’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. Nevertheless, having seen with wisdom, some of their defilements have come to an end. And they accept the teachings proclaimed by the Realized One after considering them with a degree of wisdom. And they have the following qualities: MN 70:20.3the faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom. MN 70:20.4This person is called a follower of the teachings. MN 70:20.5I say that this mendicant also still has work to do with diligence. MN 70:20.6Why is that? Thinking: MN 70:20.7‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties. MN 70:20.8Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’ MN 70:20.9Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

    MN 70:21.1And what person is a follower by faith? MN 70:21.2It’s a person who doesn’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. Nevertheless, having seen with wisdom, some of their defilements have come to an end. And they have a degree of faith and love for the Realized One. And they have the following qualities: MN 70:21.3the faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom. MN 70:21.4This person is called a follower by faith. MN 70:21.5I say that this mendicant also still has work to do with diligence. MN 70:21.6Why is that? Thinking: MN 70:21.7‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties. MN 70:21.8Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’ MN 70:21.9Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

    MN 70:22.1BJ 11.248PTS-VP-PLI 1.480Mendicants, I don’t say that enlightenment is achieved right away. MN 70:22.2Rather, enlightenment is achieved by gradual training, progress, and practice.

    MN 70:23.1And how is enlightenment achieved by gradual training, progress, and practice? MN 70:23.2It’s when someone in whom faith has arisen approaches a teacher. They pay homage, lend an ear, hear the teachings, remember the teachings, reflect on their meaning, and accept them after consideration. Then enthusiasm springs up; they make an effort, weigh up, and persevere. Persevering, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.

    MN 70:24.1Mendicants, there has not been that faith, MN 70:24.10that making an effort, MN 70:24.11that weighing up, MN 70:24.12or that striving. MN 70:24.13You’ve lost the way, mendicants! You’re practicing the wrong way! MN 70:24.14Just how far have these foolish people strayed from this teaching and training!

    MN 70:24.2that approaching, MN 70:24.3that paying homage, MN 70:24.4that listening, MN 70:24.5that hearing the teachings, MN 70:24.6that remembering the teachings, MN 70:24.7that reflecting on their meaning, MN 70:24.8that acceptance after consideration, MN 70:24.9that enthusiasm,

    MN 70:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.481There is an exposition in four parts, which a sensible person would quickly understand when it is recited. MN 70:25.2I shall recite it for you, mendicants. Try to understand it.”

    MN 70:25.3“Sir, who are we to be counted alongside those who understand the teaching?”

    MN 70:26.1“Even with a teacher who values material things, is an heir in material things, who lives caught up in material things, you wouldn’t get into such haggling: MN 70:26.2‘If we get this, we’ll do that. If we don’t get this, we won’t do it.’ What then of the Realized One, who lives utterly detached from material things?

    MN 70:27.1For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, this is in line with the teaching: MN 70:27.10Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 70:27.2‘The Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple. MN 70:27.3The Buddha knows, I do not know.’ MN 70:27.4For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, the Teacher’s instructions are nourishing and nutritious. MN 70:27.5For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, this is in line with the teaching: MN 70:27.6‘Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not relax my energy until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’ MN 70:27.7A faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions can expect one of two results: MN 70:27.8enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

    MN 70:27.9BJ 11.250That is what the Buddha said.

    MN 70:3.1Then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the land of the Kāsīs, arrived at a town of the Kāsīs named Kīṭāgiri, MN 70:3.2and stayed there.

    MN 70:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.474Now at that time the mendicants who followed Assaji and Punabbasuka were residing at Kīṭāgiri. MN 70:4.10Why should we give up what is visible in the present to chase after what takes effect over time? MN 70:4.11We shall eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.”

    MN 70:4.2Then several mendicants went up to them and said, MN 70:4.3“Reverends, the Buddha abstains from eating at night, and so does the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 70:4.4Doing so, they find that they’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably. MN 70:4.5You too should abstain from eating at night. MN 70:4.6Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”

    MN 70:4.7When they said this, the mendicants who followed Assaji and Punabbasuka said to them, MN 70:4.8“Reverends, we eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day. MN 70:4.9Doing so, we find that we’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

    MN 70:5.1Since those mendicants were unable to persuade the mendicants who were followers of Assaji and Punabbasuka, they approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

    MN 70:6.1BJ 11.238PTS-VP-PLI 1.475So the Buddha addressed a certain monk, MN 70:6.10You too should abstain from eating at night. MN 70:6.11Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’ MN 70:6.12When they said this, did you really say to them: MN 70:6.13‘Reverends, we eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day. MN 70:6.14Doing so, we find that we’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably. MN 70:6.15Why should we give up what is visible in the present to chase after what takes effect over time? MN 70:6.16We shall eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.’”

    MN 70:6.17“Yes, sir.”

    MN 70:6.18“Mendicants, have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma like this: no matter what this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—their unskillful qualities decline and their skillful qualities grow?”

    MN 70:6.19“No, sir.”

    MN 70:6.2“Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicants who follow Assaji and Punabbasuka that MN 70:6.3the teacher summons them.”

    MN 70:6.4“Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those mendicants and said, MN 70:6.5“Venerables, the teacher summons you.”

    MN 70:6.6“Yes, reverend,” those mendicants replied. They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

    MN 70:6.7The Buddha said to them, “Is it really true, mendicants, that several mendicants went to you and said: MN 70:6.8‘Reverends, the Buddha abstains from eating at night, and so does the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 70:6.9Doing so, they find that they’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

    MN 70:7.1“Haven’t you known me to teach the Dhamma like this: ‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. When someone feels this kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow’?”

    MN 70:7.2“Yes, sir.”

    MN 70:8.1BJ 11.240“Good, mendicants! MN 70:8.10Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of pleasant feeling’?”

    MN 70:8.11“No, sir.”

    MN 70:8.12“But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:8.13‘When someone feels that kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of pleasant feeling.’

    MN 70:8.14Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:8.15‘When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ MN 70:8.16Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should give up this kind of painful feeling’?”

    MN 70:8.17“No, sir.”

    MN 70:8.2Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:8.3‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ MN 70:8.4Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should give up this kind of pleasant feeling’?”

    MN 70:8.5“No, sir.”

    MN 70:8.6PTS-VP-PLI 1.476“But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:8.7‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should give up this kind of pleasant feeling.’ MN 70:8.8Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:8.9‘When someone feels that kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’

    MN 70:9.1“But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:9.2‘When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should give up this kind of painful feeling.’ MN 70:9.3Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:9.4‘When someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ MN 70:9.5Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of painful feeling’?”

    MN 70:9.6“No, sir.”

    MN 70:9.7“But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom: MN 70:9.8‘When someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of painful feeling.’

    • MN 71:0.1Middle Discourses 71

    MN 71:0.2To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

    MN 71:1.1BJ 11.252So I have heard. MN 71:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

    MN 71:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.483‘The ascetic Gotama has the three knowledges.’ Answering like this you would repeat what I have said, and not misrepresent me with an untruth. You would explain in line with my teaching, and there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism.”

    MN 71:11.1When he said this, the wanderer Vacchagotta said to the Buddha, MN 71:11.2“Master Gotama, are there any laypeople who, without giving up the fetter of lay life, make an end of suffering when the body breaks up?”

    MN 71:11.3“No, Vaccha.”

    MN 71:12.1“But are there any laypeople who, without giving up the fetter of lay life, go to heaven when the body breaks up?”

    MN 71:12.2“There’s not just one hundred laypeople, Vaccha, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that who, without giving up the fetter of lay life, go to heaven when the body breaks up.”

    MN 71:13.1“Master Gotama, are there any Ājīvaka ascetics who make an end of suffering when the body breaks up?”

    MN 71:13.2“No, Vaccha.”

    MN 71:14.1“But are there any Ājīvaka ascetics who go to heaven when the body breaks up?”

    MN 71:14.2“Vaccha, when I recollect the past ninety-one eons, I can’t find any Ājīvaka ascetics who have gone to heaven, except one; MN 71:14.3and he taught the efficacy of deeds and action.”

    MN 71:15.1“In that case, Master Gotama, the sectarian tenets are empty even of the chance to go to heaven.”

    MN 71:15.2“Yes, Vaccha, the sectarian tenets are empty even of the chance to go to heaven.”

    MN 71:15.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 71:15.4Satisfied, the wanderer Vacchagotta was happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 71:2.1Now at that time the wanderer Vacchagotta was residing in the Single Lotus Monastery of the wanderers.

    MN 71:3.1Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms. MN 71:3.2Then it occurred to him, MN 71:3.3“It’s too early to wander for alms in Vesālī. MN 71:3.4Why don’t I visit the wanderer Vacchagotta at the Single Lotus Monastery?” MN 71:3.5So that’s what he did.

    MN 71:4.1Vacchagotta saw the Buddha coming off in the distance, MN 71:4.2and said to him, MN 71:4.3PTS-VP-PLI 1.482“Come, Blessed One! MN 71:4.4Welcome, Blessed One! MN 71:4.5It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here. MN 71:4.6Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”

    MN 71:4.7The Buddha sat on the seat spread out, MN 71:4.8while Vacchagotta took a low seat and sat to one side. MN 71:4.9Then Vacchagotta said to the Buddha:

    MN 71:5.1“Sir, I have heard this: MN 71:5.2‘The ascetic Gotama claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus: MN 71:5.3“Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”’ MN 71:5.4I trust that those who say this repeat what the Buddha has said, and do not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?”

    MN 71:5.5“Vaccha, those who say this do not repeat what I have said. They misrepresent me with what is false and untrue.”

    MN 71:6.1“So how should we answer so as to repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? How should we explain in line with his teaching, with no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?”

    MN 71:6.2BJ 11.254“‘The ascetic Gotama has the three knowledges.’ Answering like this you would repeat what I have said, and not misrepresent me with an untruth. You would explain in line with my teaching, and there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism.

    MN 71:7.1For, Vaccha, whenever I want, I recollect my many kinds of past lives. MN 71:7.2That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. I remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

    MN 71:8.1And whenever I want, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

    MN 71:9.1And I have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. I live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.

    • MN 72:0.1Middle Discourses 72

    MN 72:0.2With Vacchagotta on Fire

    MN 72:1.1BJ 11.256PTS-VP-PLI 1.484So I have heard. MN 72:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

    MN 72:10.1BJ 11.258“Then is this your view: ‘A Realized One doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly’?”

    MN 72:10.3“That’s not my view, Vaccha.”

    MN 72:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.485“Then is this your view: ‘A Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly’?”

    MN 72:11.3“That’s not my view, Vaccha.”

    MN 72:12.1“Then is this your view: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly’?”

    MN 72:12.3“That’s not my view, Vaccha.”

    MN 72:13.1BJ 11.260“Master Gotama, when asked these ten questions, you say: ‘That’s not my view.’ MN 72:13.31Seeing what drawback do you avoid all these convictions?”

    MN 72:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.486“Each of these ten convictions is the thicket of views, the desert of views, the trick of views, the evasiveness of views, the fetter of views. They’re beset with anguish, distress, and fever. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. MN 72:14.11Seeing this drawback I avoid all these convictions.”

    MN 72:15.1“But does Master Gotama have any convictions at all?”

    MN 72:15.2“The Realized One has done away with convictions. MN 72:15.3For the Realized One has seen: MN 72:15.4‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form. MN 72:15.5Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling. MN 72:15.6Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception. MN 72:15.7Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices. MN 72:15.8Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’ MN 72:15.9That’s why the Realized One is freed with the ending, fading away, cessation, giving up, and letting go of all identifying, all worries, and all ego, possessiveness, or underlying tendency to conceit, I say.”

    MN 72:16.1BJ 11.262“But Master Gotama, when a mendicant’s mind is freed like this, where are they reborn?”

    MN 72:16.2“‘They’re reborn’ doesn’t apply, Vaccha.”

    MN 72:16.3“Well then, are they not reborn?”

    MN 72:16.4“‘They’re not reborn’ doesn’t apply, Vaccha.”

    MN 72:16.5“Well then, are they both reborn and not reborn?”

    MN 72:16.6“‘They’re both reborn and not reborn’ doesn’t apply, Vaccha.”

    MN 72:16.7“Well then, are they neither reborn nor not reborn?”

    MN 72:16.8“‘They’re neither reborn nor not reborn’ doesn’t apply, Vaccha.”

    MN 72:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.487“Master Gotama, when asked all these questions, you say: ‘It doesn’t apply.’ MN 72:17.5I fail to understand this point, Master Gotama; I’ve fallen into confusion. MN 72:17.6And I’ve now lost even the degree of clarity I had from previous discussions with Master Gotama.”

    MN 72:18.1“No wonder you don’t understand, Vaccha, no wonder you’re confused. MN 72:18.2For this principle is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute. MN 72:18.3It’s hard for you to understand, since you have a different view, creed, preference, practice, and tradition.

    MN 72:18.4Well then, Vaccha, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

    MN 72:19.1What do you think, Vaccha? MN 72:19.10‘This fire burning in front of me burns in dependence on grass and logs as fuel.’”

    MN 72:19.11“Suppose that fire burning in front of you was extinguished. Would you know: MN 72:19.12‘This fire in front of me is extinguished’?”

    MN 72:19.13“Yes, I would, Master Gotama.”

    MN 72:19.15“But Vaccha, suppose they were to ask you: MN 72:19.16‘This fire in front of you that is extinguished: in what direction did it go—MN 72:19.17east, south, west, or north?’ How would you answer?”

    MN 76:10.1Furthermore, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view: MN 76:10.2‘Nothing bad is done by the doer when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. Nothing bad is done when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie. MN 76:10.3If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil. MN 76:10.4If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil. MN 76:10.5If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit. MN 76:10.6In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’

    MN 76:11.1BJ 11.314A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way: MN 76:11.10What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher? MN 76:11.11This negates the spiritual life.’ MN 76:11.12Realizing this, they leave disappointed.

    MN 76:11.2‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view. MN 76:11.7If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it MN 76:11.8have attained exactly the same level. MN 76:11.9But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go naked, shaven, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.

    MN 76:12.1This is the second way that negates the spiritual life.

    MN 76:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 1.517Furthermore, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view: MN 76:13.2‘There is no cause or condition for the corruption of sentient beings.     MN 76:16.1BJ 11.318PTS-VP-PLI 1.518Furthermore, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view: MN 76:16.10The sword simply passes through the gap between the seven substances. MN 76:16.11There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600. There are 500 deeds, and five, and three. There are deeds and half-deeds. There are 62 paths, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life. There are 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 naked ascetics. There are 2,000 faculties, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dust. There are seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, and seven embryos without attachments. There are seven gods, seven humans, and seven goblins. There are seven lakes, seven winds, seven cliffs, and 700 cliffs. There are seven dreams and 700 dreams. There are 8.4 million great eons through which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering. MN 76:16.12And here there is no such thing as this: “By this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life I shall force unripened deeds to bear their fruit, or eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little”—for that cannot be. MN 76:16.13Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse. MN 76:16.14It’s like how, when you toss a ball of string, it rolls away unraveling. MN 76:16.15In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’

    MN 76:16.2‘There are these seven substances that are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. MN 76:16.3They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or neutral feeling to each other. MN 76:16.4What seven? MN 76:16.5The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh. MN 76:16.6These seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. MN 76:16.7They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or neutral feeling to each other. MN 76:16.8And here there is no-one who kills or who makes others kill; no-one who learns or who educates others; no-one who understands or who helps others understand.     MN 76:7.1“Sandaka, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view: MN 76:7.10Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and they don’t exist after death.’

    MN 76:7.2‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no obligation to mother and father. MN 76:7.3This person is made up of the four primary elements. When they die, the earth in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of earth. The water in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of water. The fire in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of fire. The air in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of air. The faculties are transferred to space. MN 76:7.4Four men with a bier carry away the corpse. MN 76:7.5Their footprints show the way to the cemetery. MN 76:7.6The bones become bleached. MN 76:7.7Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes. MN 76:7.8Giving is a doctrine for morons. MN 76:7.9When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just hollow, false nonsense.

    MN 77:0.2The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

    MN 77:1.1BJ 11.332PTS-VP-PLI 2.1So I have heard. MN 77:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

    MN 77:10.1There are five other qualities because of which my disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate me; and after honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me. MN 77:10.2What five?

    MN 77:10.3Firstly, my disciples esteem me for the higher ethics: MN 77:10.4‘The ascetic Gotama is ethical. He possesses the entire spectrum of ethical conduct to the highest degree.’ MN 77:11.1Since this is so, MN 77:11.2this is the first quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.

    MN 77:12.1BJ 11.346PTS-VP-PLI 2.10Furthermore, my disciples esteem me for my excellent knowledge and vision: MN 77:12.12this is the second quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.

    MN 77:12.2‘The ascetic Gotama only claims to know when he does in fact know. MN 77:12.3He only claims to see when he really does see. MN 77:12.4He teaches based on direct knowledge, not without direct knowledge. MN 77:12.5He teaches based on reason, not without reason. MN 77:12.6He teaches with a demonstrable basis, not without it.’ MN 77:12.7Since this is so,

    MN 77:13.1Furthermore, my disciples esteem me for my higher wisdom: MN 77:13.13this is the third quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.

    MN 77:13.2‘The ascetic Gotama is wise. He possesses the entire spectrum of wisdom to the highest degree. MN 77:13.3It’s not possible that he would fail to foresee grounds for future criticism, or to legitimately and completely refute the doctrines of others that come up.’ MN 77:13.4What do you think, Udāyī? MN 77:13.5Would my disciples, knowing and seeing this, break in and interrupt me?”

    MN 77:13.6“No, sir.”

    MN 77:13.7“That’s because I don’t expect to be instructed by my disciples. MN 77:13.8Invariably, my disciples expect instruction from me.

    MN 77:13.9Since this is so,

    MN 77:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.11Furthermore, my disciples come to me and ask how the noble truth of suffering applies to the suffering in which they are swamped and mired. And I provide them with a satisfying answer to their question. MN 77:14.11this is the fourth quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.

    MN 77:14.2They ask how the noble truths of the origin of suffering, MN 77:14.3the cessation of suffering, MN 77:14.4and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering apply to the suffering that has overwhelmed them and brought them low.     MN 77:15.1BJ 11.348Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. MN 77:15.2It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 77:15.3They meditate observing an aspect of feelings … MN 77:15.4mind … MN 77:15.5principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 77:15.6And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.

    MN 77:16.1Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the four right efforts. MN 77:16.2It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise. MN 77:16.3They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up. MN 77:16.4They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise. MN 77:16.5They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development. MN 77:16.6And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.

    MN 77:17.1Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the four bases of psychic power. MN 77:17.2It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort. MN 77:17.3They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort. MN 77:17.4They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort. MN 77:17.5They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort. MN 77:17.6And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.

MN 77:19.7And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.

    MN 77:2.1Now at that time several very well-known wanderers were residing in the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground. MN 77:2.2They included Annabhāra, Varadhara, Sakuludāyī, and other very well-known wanderers.

    MN 77:22.1BJ 11.350PTS-VP-PLI 2.13Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the eight liberations.

    MN 77:22.10Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness. MN 77:22.11This is the fifth liberation.
