MN 77:6.63That large crowd is poised on the edge of their seats, thinking, MN 77:6.64“Whatever the Buddha teaches, we shall listen to it.” MN 77:6.65It’s like when there’s a person at the crossroads pressing out pure manuka honey, MN 77:6.66and a large crowd is poised on the edge of their seats. MN 77:6.67In the same way, while the ascetic Gotama is teaching an assembly of many hundreds, there is no sound of his disciples coughing or clearing their throats. MN 77:6.68That large crowd is poised on the edge of their seats, thinking, MN 77:6.69“Whatever the Buddha teaches, we shall listen to it.” MN 77:6.70Even when a disciple of the ascetic Gotama resigns the training and returns to a lesser life, having been overly attached to their spiritual companions, they speak only praise of the teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha. They blame only themselves, not others: “We were unlucky, we had little merit. For even after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training we weren’t able to practice for life the perfectly full and pure spiritual life.” MN 77:6.71They become monastery workers or lay followers, and they proceed having undertaken the five precepts. MN 77:6.72That’s how the ascetic Gotama is honored, respected, revered, and venerated by his disciples. And that’s how his disciples, honoring and respecting him, remain loyal to him.’”

    MN 77:6.8Makkhali Gosāla, MN 77:6.9Ajita Kesakambala,

    MN 77:7.1“But Udāyī, how many qualities do you see in me, because of which my disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate me; and after honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me?”

    MN 77:8.1“Sir, I see five such qualities in the Buddha. MN 77:8.10This is the fourth such quality I see in the Buddha.

    MN 77:8.11Furthermore, the Buddha is secluded, and praises seclusion. MN 77:8.12This is the fifth such quality I see in the Buddha.

    MN 77:8.13These are the five qualities I see in the Buddha, because of which his disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate him; and after honoring and respecting him, they remain loyal to him.”

    MN 77:8.2What five?

    MN 77:8.3The Buddha eats little and praises eating little. MN 77:8.4This is the first such quality I see in the Buddha.

    MN 77:8.5PTS-VP-PLI 2.6Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment. MN 77:8.6This is the second such quality I see in the Buddha.

    MN 77:8.7BJ 11.340Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of almsfood, and praises such contentment. MN 77:8.8This is the third such quality I see in the Buddha.

    MN 77:8.9Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of lodging, and praises such contentment.

    MN 77:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.7“Suppose, Udāyī, my disciples were loyal to me because I eat little. Well, there are disciples of mine who eat a cupful of food, or half a cupful; they eat a wood apple, or half a wood apple.

    MN 77:9.10Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of lodging. Well, there are disciples of mine who stay at the root of a tree, in the open air. For eight months they don’t go under a roof. MN 77:9.11But sometimes I even stay in bungalows, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with latches fastened and windows shuttered. MN 77:9.12So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of lodging, then those disciples who stay at the root of a tree would not be loyal to me.

    MN 77:9.13BJ 11.344PTS-VP-PLI 2.9Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m secluded and I praise seclusion. Well, there are disciples of mine who live in the wilderness, in remote lodgings. Having ventured deep into remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest, they live there, coming down to the midst of the Saṅgha each fortnight for the recitation of the monastic code. MN 77:9.14But sometimes I live crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and teachers of other paths and their disciples. MN 77:9.15So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m secluded and praise seclusion, then those disciples who live in the wilderness would not be loyal to me.

    MN 77:9.16So, Udāyī, it’s not because of these five qualities that my disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate me; and after honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me.

    MN 77:9.2But sometimes I even eat this bowl full to the brim, or even more. MN 77:9.3So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I eat little, then those disciples who eat even less would not be loyal to me.

    MN 77:9.4BJ 11.342Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of robe. Well, there are disciples of mine who have rag robes, wearing shabby robes. They gather scraps from charnel grounds, rubbish dumps, and shops, make them into a patchwork robe and wear it. MN 77:9.5But sometimes I wear robes offered by householders that are strong, yet next to which bottle-gourd down is coarse. MN 77:9.6So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of robe, then those disciples who wear rag robes would not be loyal to me.

    MN 77:9.7PTS-VP-PLI 2.8Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of almsfood. Well, there are disciples of mine who eat only almsfood, wander indiscriminately for almsfood, happy to eat whatever they glean. When they’ve entered an inhabited area, they don’t consent when invited to sit down. MN 77:9.8But sometimes I even eat by invitation boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces. MN 77:9.9So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of almsfood, then those disciples who eat only almsfood would not be loyal to me.

    • MN 78:0.1Middle Discourses 78

    MN 78:0.2With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamuṇḍika

    MN 78:1.1BJ 11.366PTS-VP-PLI 2.23So I have heard. MN 78:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

    MN 78:1.3Now at that time the wanderer Uggāhamāna Samaṇamuṇḍikāputta was residing together with around three hundred wanderers in Mallikā’s single-halled monastery for group debates, set among the flaking pale-moon ebony trees.

    MN 78:10.1And what, master builder, are unskillful behaviors?

    MN 78:10.10BJ 11.372And where do these unskillful behaviors cease without anything left over? MN 78:10.11Their cessation has also been stated. MN 78:10.12It’s when a mendicant gives up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and develops good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind; they give up wrong livelihood and earn a living by right livelihood. MN 78:10.13This is where these unskillful behaviors cease without anything left over.

    MN 78:10.14PTS-VP-PLI 2.27And how is someone practicing for the cessation of unskillful behaviors? MN 78:10.15It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise. MN 78:10.16They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up. MN 78:10.17They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise. MN 78:10.18They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development. MN 78:10.19Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of unskillful behaviors.

    MN 78:10.2Unskillful deeds by way of body and speech, and bad livelihood. MN 78:10.3These are called unskillful behaviors.

    MN 78:10.4And where do these unskillful behaviors stem from? MN 78:10.5Where they stem from has been stated. MN 78:10.6You should say that they stem from the mind. MN 78:10.7What mind? MN 78:10.8The mind takes many and diverse forms. MN 78:10.9But unskillful behaviors stem from a mind that has greed, hate, and delusion.

    MN 78:11.1And what are skillful behaviors?

    MN 78:11.10And where do these skillful behaviors cease without anything left over? MN 78:11.11Their cessation has also been stated. MN 78:11.12It’s when a mendicant behaves ethically, but they don’t identify with their ethical behavior. MN 78:11.13And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where these skillful behaviors cease without anything left over.

    MN 78:11.14And how is someone practicing for the cessation of skillful behaviors? MN 78:11.15It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise … MN 78:11.16so that unskillful qualities are given up … MN 78:11.17so that skillful qualities arise … MN 78:11.18so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development. MN 78:11.19Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of skillful behaviors.

    MN 78:11.2Skillful deeds by way of body and speech, and purified livelihood are included in behavior, I say. MN 78:11.3These are called skillful behaviors.

    MN 78:11.4And where do these skillful behaviors stem from? MN 78:11.5Where they stem from has been stated. MN 78:11.6You should say that they stem from the mind. MN 78:11.7What mind? MN 78:11.8The mind takes many and diverse forms. MN 78:11.9But skillful behaviors stem from a mind that is free from greed, hate, and delusion.

    MN 78:12.1And what are unskillful thoughts? MN 78:12.10unskillful thoughts stem from this.

    MN 78:12.11PTS-VP-PLI 2.28And where do these unskillful thoughts cease without anything left over? MN 78:12.12Their cessation has also been stated. MN 78:12.13It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 78:12.14This is where these unskillful thoughts cease without anything left over.

    MN 78:12.15And how is someone practicing for the cessation of unskillful thoughts? MN 78:12.16It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise … MN 78:12.17so that unskillful qualities are given up … MN 78:12.18so that skillful qualities arise … MN 78:12.19so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development. MN 78:12.2Thoughts of sensuality, of malice, and of cruelty. MN 78:12.20Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of unskillful thoughts.

    MN 78:12.3These are called unskillful thoughts.

    MN 78:12.4And where do these unskillful thoughts stem from? MN 78:12.5Where they stem from has been stated. MN 78:12.6You should say that they stem from perception. MN 78:12.7What perception? MN 78:12.8Perception takes many and diverse forms. MN 78:12.9Perceptions of sensuality, malice, and cruelty—

    MN 78:13.1BJ 11.374And what are skillful thoughts? MN 78:13.10skillful thoughts stem from this.

    MN 78:13.11And where do these skillful thoughts cease without anything left over? MN 78:13.12Their cessation has also been stated. MN 78:13.13It’s when, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 78:13.14This is where these skillful thoughts cease without anything left over.

    MN 78:13.15And how is someone practicing for the cessation of skillful thoughts? MN 78:13.16It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise … MN 78:13.17so that unskillful qualities are given up … MN 78:13.18so that skillful qualities arise … MN 78:13.19so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development. MN 78:13.2Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness. MN 78:13.20Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of skillful thoughts.

    MN 78:13.3These are called skillful thoughts.

    MN 78:13.4And where do these skillful thoughts stem from? MN 78:13.5Where they stem from has been stated. MN 78:13.6You should say that they stem from perception. MN 78:13.7What perception? MN 78:13.8Perception takes many and diverse forms. MN 78:13.9Perceptions of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness—

    MN 78:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.29Master builder, when an individual has what ten qualities do I describe them as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment? MN 78:14.2It’s when a mendicant has an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom. MN 78:14.3When an individual has these ten qualities, I describe them as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.”

    MN 78:14.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 78:14.5Satisfied, Pañcakaṅga the master builder was happy with what the Buddha said.

    MN 78:2.1Then the master builder Pañcakaṅga left Sāvatthī in the middle of the day to see the Buddha. MN 78:2.2It occurred to him, MN 78:2.3“It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha, MN 78:2.4as he’s in retreat. MN 78:2.5And it’s the wrong time to see the esteemed mendicants, MN 78:2.6as they’re in retreat. MN 78:2.7Why don’t I go to Mallikā’s monastery to visit the wanderer Uggāhamāna?” MN 78:2.8So that’s what he did.

    MN 78:3.1Now at that time, Uggāhamāna was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of unworthy talk, such as MN 78:3.10Then those wanderers fell silent.

    MN 78:3.2talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.

    MN 78:3.3Uggāhamāna saw Pañcakaṅga coming off in the distance, MN 78:3.4and hushed his own assembly, MN 78:3.5“Be quiet, good sirs, don’t make a sound. MN 78:3.6Here comes Pañcakaṅga, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama. MN 78:3.7He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing in Sāvatthī. MN 78:3.8Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet. MN 78:3.9Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”

    MN 78:4.1BJ 11.368PTS-VP-PLI 2.24Then Pañcakaṅga approached Uggāhamāna, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 78:4.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. Uggāhamāna said to him:

    MN 78:5.1“Householder, when an individual has four qualities I describe them as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment. MN 78:5.2What four? MN 78:5.3It’s when they do no bad deeds with their body; speak no bad words; think no bad thoughts; and don’t earn a living by bad livelihood. MN 78:5.4When an individual has these four qualities I describe them as an invincible ascetic.”

    MN 78:6.1Then Pañcakaṅga neither approved nor dismissed that mendicant’s statement. MN 78:6.2He got up from his seat, thinking, MN 78:6.3“I will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”

    MN 78:7.1Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, MN 78:7.2and informed the Buddha of all that had been discussed.

    MN 78:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.25When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him, MN 78:8.10It’s when they do no bad deeds with their body; speak no bad words; think no bad thoughts; and don’t earn a living by bad livelihood. MN 78:8.11When an individual has these four qualities I describe them, not as an invincible ascetic, but as having achieved the same level as a little baby.

    MN 78:8.2“Master builder, if what Uggāhamāna says is true, a little baby boy is an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment. MN 78:8.3For a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘a body’, so how could they possibly do a bad deed with their body, apart from just wriggling? MN 78:8.4And a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘speech’, so how could they possibly speak bad words, apart from just crying? MN 78:8.5And a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘thought’, so how could they possibly think bad thoughts, apart from just whimpering? MN 78:8.6And a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘livelihood’, so how could they possibly earn a living by bad livelihood, apart from their mother’s breast? MN 78:8.7If what Uggāhamāna says is true, a little baby boy is an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.

    MN 78:8.8When an individual has four qualities I describe them, not as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment—but as having achieved the same level as a little baby. MN 78:8.9What four?

    MN 78:9.1BJ 11.370When an individual has ten qualities, master builder, I describe them as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.

    MN 78:9.10‘These are skillful behaviors.’ MN 78:9.12‘Skillful behaviors stem from this.’ MN 78:9.14‘Here skillful behaviors cease without anything left over.’ MN 78:9.16‘Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of skillful behaviors.’

    MN 78:9.18PTS-VP-PLI 2.26‘These are unskillful thoughts.’

    MN 78:9.2But certain things must first be understood, I say. ‘These are unskillful behaviors.’ MN 78:9.20‘Unskillful thoughts stem from this.’ MN 78:9.22‘Here unskillful thoughts cease without anything left over.’ MN 78:9.24‘Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of unskillful thoughts.’

    MN 78:9.26‘These are skillful thoughts.’ MN 78:9.28‘Skillful thoughts stem from this.’ MN 78:9.30‘Here skillful thoughts cease without anything left over.’ MN 78:9.32‘Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of skillful thoughts.’ MN 78:9.4‘Unskillful behaviors stem from this.’ MN 78:9.6‘Here unskillful behaviors cease without anything left over.’ MN 78:9.8‘Someone practicing like this is practicing for the cessation of unskillful behaviors.’

    • MN 79:0.1Middle Discourses 79

    MN 79:0.2The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

    MN 79:1.1BJ 11.376So I have heard. MN 79:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground. MN 79:1.3Now at that time the wanderer Sakuludāyī was residing together with a large assembly of wanderers in the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground.

    MN 79:10.1“Udāyī, you could draw this out for a long time. MN 79:10.10Asked this, he’d say, ‘No.’ MN 79:10.11They’d say to him, MN 79:10.12‘Mister, do you desire someone who you’ve never even known or seen?’ MN 79:10.13Asked this, he’d say, ‘Yes.’

    MN 79:10.14BJ 11.382What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:10.15This being so, doesn’t that man’s statement turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”

    MN 79:10.16“Clearly that’s the case, sir.”

    MN 79:10.17“In the same way, you say, ‘The ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ But you don’t describe that splendor.”

    MN 79:10.2You say, ‘The ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ But you don’t describe that splendor. MN 79:10.3Suppose a man was to say, MN 79:10.4‘Whoever the finest lady in the land is, it is her that I want, her I desire!’ MN 79:10.5They’d say to him, MN 79:10.6‘Mister, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know whether she’s an aristocrat, a brahmin, a merchant, or a worker?’ MN 79:10.7Asked this, he’d say, ‘No.’ MN 79:10.8They’d say to him, MN 79:10.9‘Mister, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know her name or clan? Whether she’s tall or short or medium? Whether her skin is black, brown, or tawny? What village, town, or city she comes from?’

    MN 79:11.1“Sir, suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate. Such is the splendor of the self that is well after death.”

    MN 79:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.34“What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:12.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: such a beryl gem, or a firefly in the dark of night?”

    MN 79:12.3“A firefly in the dark of night, sir.”

    MN 79:13.1“What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:13.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: a firefly in the dark of night, or an oil lamp in the dark of night?”

    MN 79:13.3“An oil lamp in the dark of night, sir.”

    MN 79:14.1“What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:14.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: an oil lamp in the dark of night, or a bonfire in the dark of night?”

    MN 79:14.3“A bonfire in the dark of night, sir.”

    MN 79:15.1“What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:15.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: a bonfire in the dark of night, or the Morning Star in a clear and cloudless sky at the crack of dawn?”

    MN 79:15.3“The Morning Star in a clear and cloudless sky at the crack of dawn, sir.”

    MN 79:16.1BJ 11.384“What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:16.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: the Morning Star in a clear and cloudless sky at the crack of dawn, or the full moon at midnight in a clear and cloudless sky on the fifteenth day sabbath?”

    MN 79:16.3“The full moon at midnight in a clear and cloudless sky on the fifteenth day sabbath, sir.”

    MN 79:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.35“What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:17.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: the full moon at midnight in a clear and cloudless sky on the fifteenth day sabbath, or the sun at midday in a clear and cloudless sky in the last month of the rainy season?”

    MN 79:17.3“The sun at midday in a clear and cloudless sky in the last month of the rainy season, sir.”

    MN 79:18.1“Beyond this, Udāyī, I know very many gods on whom the light of the sun and moon make no impression. MN 79:18.2Nevertheless, I do not say: MN 79:18.3‘The splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ MN 79:18.4But of the splendor inferior to a firefly you say, ‘This is the ultimate splendor.’ And you don’t describe that splendor.”

    MN 79:19.1“The Blessed One has cut short the discussion! The Holy One has cut short the discussion!”

    MN 79:19.2“But Udāyī, why do you say this?”

    MN 79:19.4“Sir, it says this in our own teacher’s doctrine: MN 79:19.5‘This is the ultimate splendor, this is the ultimate splendor.’ MN 79:19.6But when pursued, pressed, and grilled on our own teacher’s doctrine, we turned out to be void, hollow, and mistaken.”

    MN 79:2.1Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms. MN 79:2.2Then it occurred to him, MN 79:2.3“It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha. MN 79:2.4Why don’t I visit the wanderer Sakuludāyī at the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground?” MN 79:2.5Then the Buddha went to the monastery of the wanderers.

    MN 79:20.1“But Udāyī, is there a world of perfect happiness? And is there a grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness?”

    MN 79:20.2“Sir, it says this in our own teacher’s doctrine: MN 79:20.3‘There is a world of perfect happiness. And there is a grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness.’”

    MN 79:21.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.36“Well, what is that grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness?”

    MN 79:21.2“Sir, it’s when someone gives up killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, and lying. And they proceed having undertaken some kind of mortification. MN 79:21.3This is the grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness.”

    MN 79:22.1BJ 11.386“What do you think, Udāyī?

    MN 79:22.10“It has both pleasure and pain.”

    MN 79:22.11“What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:22.12On an occasion when someone undertakes and follows some kind of mortification, is their self perfectly happy at that time, or does it have both pleasure and pain?”

    MN 79:22.13“It has both pleasure and pain.”

    MN 79:22.14“What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:22.15Is a perfectly happy world realized by relying on a practice of mixed pleasure and pain?”

    MN 79:22.2On an occasion when someone refrains from killing living creatures, is their self perfectly happy at that time, or does it have both pleasure and pain?”

    MN 79:22.3“It has both pleasure and pain.”

    MN 79:22.4“What do you think, Udāyī? MN 79:22.5On an occasion when someone refrains from stealing … MN 79:22.7sexual misconduct … MN 79:22.9lying, is their self perfectly happy at that time, or does it have both pleasure and pain?”

    MN 79:23.1“The Blessed One has cut short the discussion! The Holy One has cut short the discussion!”

    MN 79:23.2“But Udāyī, why do you say this?”

    MN 79:23.4“Sir, it says this in our own teacher’s doctrine: MN 79:23.5‘There is a world of perfect happiness. And there is a grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness.’ MN 79:23.6But when pursued, pressed, and grilled on our own teacher’s doctrine, we turned out to be void, hollow, and mistaken.

    MN 79:23.7PTS-VP-PLI 2.37But sir, is there a world of perfect happiness? And is there a grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness?”

    MN 79:24.1“There is a world of perfect happiness, Udāyī. And there is a grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness.”

    MN 79:24.2BJ 11.388“Well sir, what is that grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness?”

    MN 79:25.1“It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption. MN 79:25.2As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption. MN 79:25.3With the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption. MN 79:25.4This is the grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness.”

    MN 79:25.5“Sir, that’s not the grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness. At that point a perfectly happy world has already been realized.”

    MN 79:25.6“No, Udāyī, at that point a perfectly happy world has not been realized. MN 79:25.7This is the grounded path for realizing a world of perfect happiness.”

    MN 79:26.1When he said this, Sakuludāyī’s assembly made an uproar, a dreadful racket, MN 79:26.2“In that case, we’re lost, and so are our teacher’s doctrines! We’re lost, and so are our teacher’s doctrines! MN 79:26.3We know nothing higher than this!”

    MN 79:26.4Then Sakuludāyī, having quieted those wanderers, said to the Buddha, MN 79:27.1“Well sir, at what point is a perfectly happy world realized?”

    MN 79:27.2“It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption. MN 79:27.3There are deities who have been reborn in a perfectly happy world. That mendicant associates with them, converses, and engages in discussion. MN 79:27.4It’s at this point that a perfectly happy world has been realized.”

    MN 79:28.1“Surely the mendicants must lead the spiritual life under the Buddha for the sake of realizing this perfectly happy world?”

    MN 79:28.2“No, Udāyī, the mendicants don’t lead the spiritual life under me for the sake of realizing this perfectly happy world. MN 79:28.3There are other things that are finer, for the sake of which the mendicants lead the spiritual life under me.”

    MN 79:28.4PTS-VP-PLI 2.38“But what are those finer things?”

    MN 79:29-36.1“It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. …

    MN 79:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.30Now at that time, Sakuludāyī was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of unworthy talk, such as MN 79:3.2talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.

    MN 79:3.3Sakuludāyī saw the Buddha coming off in the distance, MN 79:3.4and hushed his own assembly, MN 79:3.5“Be quiet, good sirs, don’t make a sound. MN 79:3.6Here comes the ascetic Gotama. MN 79:3.7The venerable likes quiet and praises quiet. MN 79:3.8Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.” MN 79:3.9Then those wanderers fell silent.

    MN 79:37.1They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. MN 79:37.2Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption. MN 79:37.3This is one of the finer things for the sake of which the mendicants lead the spiritual life under me.

    MN 79:38-40.1BJ 11.390Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption … MN 79:38-40.2third absorption … MN 79:38-40.3fourth absorption. MN 79:38-40.4This too is one of the finer things.

    MN 79:4.1BJ 11.378PTS-VP-PLI 2.31Then the Buddha approached Sakuludāyī, MN 79:4.10The Buddha said to him, MN 79:4.11“Udāyī, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”

    MN 79:4.2who said to him, MN 79:4.3“Come, Blessed One! MN 79:4.4Welcome, Blessed One! MN 79:4.5It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here. MN 79:4.6Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.” MN 79:4.8The Buddha sat on the seat spread out, MN 79:4.9while Sakuludāyī took a low seat and sat to one side.

    MN 79:41.1When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives. MN 79:41.2They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. MN 79:41.3This too is one of the finer things.

    MN 79:42.1When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 79:42.2With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds. MN 79:42.3This too is one of the finer things.

    MN 79:43.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.39When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 79:43.2They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. MN 79:43.3They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

    MN 79:44.1Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 79:44.2When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

    MN 79:44.3They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’ MN 79:44.4This too is one of the finer things. MN 79:44.5These are the finer things for the sake of which the mendicants lead the spiritual life under me.”

    MN 79:45.1When he had spoken, Sakuludāyī said to the Buddha, MN 79:45.2“Excellent, sir! Excellent! MN 79:45.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways. MN 79:45.4I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 79:45.5Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

    MN 79:46.1BJ 11.392When he said this, Sakuludāyī’s assembly said to him, MN 79:46.2“Master Udāyī, don’t lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama. MN 79:46.3You have been a teacher; don’t live as a student. MN 79:46.4The consequence for you will be as if a water jar were to become a water jug. MN 79:46.5Master Udāyī, don’t lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama. MN 79:46.6You have been a teacher; don’t live as a student.” MN 79:46.7And that’s how the wanderer Sakuludāyī’s own assembly prevented him from leading the spiritual life under the Buddha.

    MN 79:5.1“Sir, leave aside what we were sitting talking about just now. MN 79:5.2It won’t be hard for you to hear about that later. MN 79:5.3When I don’t come to the assembly, they sit and engage in all kinds of unworthy talk. MN 79:5.4But when I have come to the assembly, they sit gazing up at my face alone, thinking, MN 79:5.5‘Whatever the ascetic Udāyī teaches, we shall listen to it.’ MN 79:5.6But when the Buddha has come to the assembly, both myself and the assembly sit gazing up at your face, thinking, MN 79:5.7‘Whatever the Buddha teaches, we shall listen to it.’”

    MN 79:6.1“Well then, Udāyī, suggest something for me to talk about.”

    MN 79:6.2“Master Gotama, a few days ago someone was claiming to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus: ‘Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’ MN 79:6.3When I asked them a question about the past, they dodged the issue, distracted the discussion with irrelevant points, and displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness. MN 79:6.4That reminded me of the Buddha: MN 79:6.5‘Surely it must be the Blessed One, the Holy One who is so skilled in such matters.’”

    MN 79:6.6“But Udāyī, who was it that made such a claim and behaved in such a way?”

    MN 79:6.7“It was Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, sir.”

    MN 79:7.1“Udāyī, someone who can recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details, might ask me a question about the past, or I might ask them a question about the past. MN 79:7.2And they might satisfy me with their answer, or I might satisfy them with my answer.

    MN 79:7.3PTS-VP-PLI 2.32Someone who, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds might ask me a question about the future, or I might ask them a question about the future. MN 79:7.4And they might satisfy me with their answer, or I might satisfy them with my answer.

    MN 79:7.5Nevertheless, Udāyī, leave aside the past and the future. MN 79:7.6I shall teach you the Dhamma: MN 79:7.7‘When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises. MN 79:7.8When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases.’”

    MN 79:8.1BJ 11.380“Well sir, I can’t even recall with features and details what I’ve undergone in this incarnation. MN 79:8.10Perhaps I might satisfy the Buddha by answering a question about my own teacher’s doctrine.”

    MN 79:8.2How should I possibly recollect my many kinds of past lives with features and details, like the Buddha? MN 79:8.3For I can’t even see a mud-goblin right now. MN 79:8.4How should I possibly, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, see sentient beings passing away and being reborn, like the Buddha? MN 79:8.5But then the Buddha told me, MN 79:8.6‘Nevertheless, Udāyī, leave aside the past and the future. MN 79:8.7I shall teach you the Dhamma:

    MN 79:8.8“When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises. MN 79:8.9When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases.”’ But that is even more unclear to me.

    MN 79:9.1“But Udāyī, what is your own teacher’s doctrine?”

    MN 79:9.2“Sir, it’s this: MN 79:9.3‘This is the ultimate splendor, this is the ultimate splendor.’”

    MN 79:9.4“But what is that ultimate splendor?”

    MN 79:9.6“Sir, the ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.”

    MN 79:9.7PTS-VP-PLI 2.33“But what is that ultimate splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer?”

    MN 79:9.8“Sir, the ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.”

    • MN 80:0.1Middle Discourses 80

    MN 80:0.2With Vekhanasa

    MN 80:1.1BJ 11.394PTS-VP-PLI 2.40So I have heard. MN 80:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

    MN 80:10.1“What do you think, Kaccāna? MN 80:10.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: the full moon at midnight in a clear and cloudless sky on the fifteenth day sabbath, or the sun at midday in a clear and cloudless sky in the last month of the rainy season?”

    MN 80:10.3“The sun at midday in a clear and cloudless sky in the last month of the rainy season.”

    MN 80:11.1“Beyond this, Kaccāna, I know very many gods on whom the light of the sun and moon make no impression. MN 80:11.2Nevertheless, I do not say: MN 80:11.3‘The splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ MN 80:11.4But of the splendor inferior to a firefly you say, ‘This is the ultimate splendor.’ And you don’t describe that splendor.

    MN 80:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.43Kaccāna, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 80:12.2What five? MN 80:12.3Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 80:12.4Sounds known by the ear … MN 80:12.5Smells known by the nose … MN 80:12.6Tastes known by the tongue … MN 80:12.7Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 80:12.8These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

    MN 80:13.1The pleasure and happiness that arises from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure. MN 80:13.2So there is the saying: ‘From the senses comes sensual pleasure. From sensual pleasure comes the best kind of sensual pleasure, which is said to be the best thing there.’”

    MN 80:14.1BJ 11.400When he said this, Vekhanasa said to the Buddha, MN 80:14.2“It’s incredible, Master Gotama, it’s amazing! MN 80:14.3How well said this was by Master Gotama! MN 80:14.4‘From the senses comes sensual pleasure. From sensual pleasure comes the best kind of sensual pleasure, which is said to be the best thing there.’ MN 80:14.5Master Gotama, from the senses comes sensual pleasure. From sensual pleasure comes the best kind of sensual pleasure, which is said to be the best thing there.”

    MN 80:14.6“Kaccāna, it’s hard for you, who has a different view, creed, preference, practice, and teacher’s doctrine, to understand MN 80:14.7the senses, sensual pleasure, and the best kind of sensual pleasure. MN 80:14.8There are mendicants who are perfected, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. They can understand MN 80:14.9the senses, sensual pleasure, and the best kind of sensual pleasure.”

    MN 80:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.44When he said this, Vekhanasa became angry and upset. He even attacked and badmouthed the Buddha himself, saying, MN 80:15.2“The ascetic Gotama will be worsted!” He said to the Buddha, MN 80:15.3“This is exactly what happens with some ascetics and brahmins. Not knowing the past or seeing the future, they nevertheless claim: MN 80:15.4‘We understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’” MN 80:15.5Their statement turns out to be a joke—mere words, void and hollow.”

    MN 80:16.1“Kaccāna, there are some ascetics and brahmins who, not knowing the past or seeing the future, nevertheless claim: MN 80:16.10They’d know ‘I’m released,’ and there would be no more bonds.

    MN 80:16.11In the same way, let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them. MN 80:16.12Practicing as instructed they will soon know and see for themselves, MN 80:16.13‘So this is how to be rightly released from the bond, that is, the bond of ignorance.’”

    MN 80:16.2‘We understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’” MN 80:16.3There is a legitimate refutation of them. MN 80:16.4Nevertheless, Kaccāna, leave aside the past and the future. MN 80:16.5Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them. MN 80:16.6Practicing as instructed they will soon know and see for themselves, MN 80:16.7‘So this is how to be rightly released from the bond, that is, the bond of ignorance.’ MN 80:16.8Suppose there was a little baby bound with swaddling up to the neck. MN 80:16.9As they grow up and their senses mature, they’re accordingly released from those bonds.

    MN 80:17.1BJ 11.402When he said this, Vekhanasa said to the Buddha, MN 80:17.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! … MN 80:17.3From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

    MN 80:2.1Then the wanderer Vekhanasa went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

    MN 80:2.10“Master Gotama, the ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.”

    MN 80:2.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side, MN 80:2.3and expressed this heartfelt sentiment: MN 80:2.4“This is the ultimate splendor, this is the ultimate splendor.”

    MN 80:2.5“But Kaccāna, why do you say: MN 80:2.6‘This is the ultimate splendor, this is the ultimate splendor.’ MN 80:2.7What is that ultimate splendor?”

    MN 80:2.8“Master Gotama, the ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.”

    MN 80:2.9“But what is that ultimate splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer?”

    MN 80:3.1“Kaccāna, you could draw this out for a long time.

    MN 80:3.10Asked this, he’d say, ‘No.’

    MN 80:3.11They’d say to him, MN 80:3.12‘Mister, do you desire someone who you’ve never even known or seen?’

    MN 80:3.13Asked this, he’d say, ‘Yes.’

    MN 80:3.14BJ 11.396PTS-VP-PLI 2.41What do you think, Kaccāna? MN 80:3.15This being so, doesn’t that man’s statement turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”

    MN 80:3.16“Clearly that’s the case, sir.”

    MN 80:3.17“In the same way, you say, ‘The ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ But you don’t describe that splendor.”

    MN 80:3.2You say, ‘The ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ But you don’t describe that splendor.

    MN 80:3.3Suppose a man was to say, MN 80:3.4‘Whoever the finest lady in the land is, it is her that I want, her I desire!’

    MN 80:3.5They’d say to him, MN 80:3.6‘Mister, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know whether she’s an aristocrat, a brahmin, a merchant, or a worker?’

    MN 80:3.7Asked this, he’d say, ‘No.’

    MN 80:3.8They’d say to him, MN 80:3.9‘Mister, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know her name or clan? Whether she’s tall or short or medium? Whether her skin is black, brown, or tawny? What village, town, or city she comes from?’

    MN 80:4.1“Master Gotama, suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate. Such is the splendor of the self that is well after death.”

    MN 80:5.1“What do you think, Kaccāna? MN 80:5.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: such a beryl gem, or a firefly in the dark of night?”

    MN 80:5.3“A firefly in the dark of night.”

    MN 80:6.1“What do you think, Kaccāna? MN 80:6.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: a firefly in the dark of night, or an oil lamp in the dark of night?”

    MN 80:6.3“An oil lamp in the dark of night.”

    MN 80:7.1“What do you think, Kaccāna? MN 80:7.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: an oil lamp in the dark of night, or a bonfire in the dark of night?”

    MN 80:7.3“A bonfire in the dark of night.”

    MN 80:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.42“What do you think, Kaccāna? MN 80:8.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: a bonfire in the dark of night, or the Morning Star in a clear and cloudless sky at the crack of dawn?”

    MN 80:8.3“The Morning Star in a clear and cloudless sky at the crack of dawn.”

    MN 80:9.1BJ 11.398“What do you think, Kaccāna? MN 80:9.2Which of these two has a finer splendor: the Morning Star in a clear and cloudless sky at the crack of dawn, or the full moon at midnight in a clear and cloudless sky on the fifteenth day sabbath?”

    MN 80:9.3“The full moon at midnight in a clear and cloudless sky on the fifteenth day sabbath.”

    • MN 81:0.1Middle Discourses 81

    MN 81:0.2With Ghaṭikāra

    MN 81:1.1BJ 11.404PTS-VP-PLI 2.45So I have heard. MN 81:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

    MN 81:10.1Then Ghaṭīkāra the potter and Jotipāla the brahmin student went to the Buddha Kassapa. Ghaṭīkāra bowed and sat down to one side, but Jotipāla exchanged greetings with the Buddha and sat down to one side.

    MN 81:10.2Ghaṭīkāra said to the Buddha Kassapa, MN 81:10.3‘Sir, this is my dear friend Jotipāla, a brahmin student. MN 81:10.4Please teach him the Dhamma.’ MN 81:10.5Then the Buddha Kassapa educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Ghaṭikāra and Jotipāla with a Dhamma talk. MN 81:10.6Then they got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha Kassapa, keeping him on their right, before leaving.

    MN 81:11.1BJ 11.410PTS-VP-PLI 2.49Then Jotipāla said to Ghatīkāra, MN 81:11.2‘Dear Ghaṭīkāra, you have heard this teaching, so why don’t you go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

    MN 81:11.3‘Don’t you know, dear Jotipāla, that I look after my blind old parents?’

    MN 81:11.4‘Well then, dear Ghaṭīkāra, I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

    MN 81:12.1Then Ghaṭīkāra and Jotipāla went to the Buddha Kassapa, bowed and sat down to one side. MN 81:12.3Please give him the going forth.’ MN 81:12.4And Jotipāla the brahmin student received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

    MN 81:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.50Not long after Jotipāla’s ordination, a fortnight later, the Buddha Kassapa—having stayed in Vebhaliṅga as long as he wished—set out for Benares. MN 81:13.2Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Benares, MN 81:13.3where he stayed near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana. MN 81:14.1King Kikī of Kāsi heard that he had arrived. MN 81:14.2He had the finest carriages harnessed. He then mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Benares to see the Buddha Kassapa. MN 81:14.3He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha Kassapa on foot. He bowed and sat down to one side. MN 81:14.4The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.

    MN 81:14.5Then King Kikī said to the Buddha, MN 81:14.6‘Sir, would the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?’ MN 81:14.7The Buddha Kassapa consented in silence.

    MN 81:15.1Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, King Kikī got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving. MN 81:16.1And when the night had passed, King Kikī had a variety of delicious foods prepared in his own home—soft saffron rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces.     MN 81:17.1BJ 11.412PTS-VP-PLI 2.51Then Kassapa Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of King Kikī, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants. MN 81:17.10and a third time King Kikī said to the Buddha Kassapa, MN 81:17.11‘Sir, may the Buddha please accept my invitation to reside in Benares for the rainy season. MN 81:17.12The Saṅgha will be looked after in the same style.’

    MN 81:17.13‘Enough, Great King. MN 81:17.14I have already accepted an invitation for the rains residence.’

    MN 81:17.15Then King Kikī, thinking, ‘The Buddha does not accept my invitation to reside for the rains in Benares,’ became sad and upset. MN 81:17.16Then King Kikī said to the Buddha Kassapa, MN 81:17.17‘Sir, do you have another supporter better than me?’

    MN 81:17.2Then King Kikī served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods.

    MN 81:17.3When the Buddha Kassapa had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, King Kikī took a low seat and sat to one side. MN 81:17.4There he said to the Buddha Kassapa, MN 81:17.5‘Sir, may the Buddha please accept my invitation to reside in Benares for the rainy season. MN 81:17.6The Saṅgha will be looked after in the same style.’

    MN 81:17.7‘Enough, great king. MN 81:17.8I have already accepted an invitation for the rains residence.’

    MN 81:17.9For a second time …

    MN 81:18.1BJ 11.414PTS-VP-PLI 2.52‘Great king, there is a market town named Vebhaliṅga, MN 81:18.10He eats in one part of the day; he’s celibate, ethical, and of good character. MN 81:18.11He has set aside gems and gold, and rejected gold and money. MN 81:18.12He’s put down the shovel and doesn’t dig the earth with his own hands. MN 81:18.13He takes what has crumbled off by a riverbank or been dug up by mice, and brings it back in a carrier. When he has made a pot, he says, MN 81:18.14“Anyone may leave bagged sesame, mung beans, or chickpeas here and take what they wish.” MN 81:18.15He looks after his blind old parents. MN 81:18.16And since he has ended the five lower fetters, Ghaṭīkāra will be reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

    MN 81:18.2where there’s a potter named Ghaṭīkāra. MN 81:18.3He is my chief supporter. MN 81:18.4Now, great king, you thought, “The Buddha does not accept my invitation to reside for the rains in Benares,” and you became sad and upset. MN 81:18.5But Ghaṭīkāra doesn’t get upset, nor will he.

    MN 81:18.6Ghaṭīkāra has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha. MN 81:18.7He doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or take alcoholic drinks that cause negligence. MN 81:18.8He has experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and has the ethics loved by the noble ones. MN 81:18.9He is free of doubt regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

    MN 81:19.1This one time, great king, I was staying near the market town of Vebhaliṅga. MN 81:19.10“I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate, MN 81:19.11in that the Buddha Kassapa trusts me so much!” MN 81:19.12Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.

    MN 81:19.2Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, went to the home of Ghaṭīkāra’s parents, where I said to them, MN 81:19.3“Excuse me, where has Bhaggava gone?”

    MN 81:19.4“Your supporter has gone out, sir. But take rice from the pot and sauce from the pan and eat.” MN 81:19.5So that’s what I did. And after eating I got up from my seat and left.

    MN 81:19.6Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said, MN 81:19.7“Who took rice from the pot and sauce from the pan, ate it, and left?”

    MN 81:19.8“It was the Buddha Kassapa, my dear.”

    MN 81:19.9Then Ghaṭīkāra thought, MN 81:2.1Then the Buddha left the road, and at a certain spot he smiled.

    MN 81:2.2Then Venerable Ānanda thought, MN 81:2.3“What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled? MN 81:2.4Realized Ones do not smile for no reason.”

    MN 82:1.1BJ 11.420PTS-VP-PLI 2.55So I have heard. MN 82:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kurus together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Kurus named Thullakoṭṭhita.

    MN 82:10.1BJ 11.426PTS-VP-PLI 2.59Then Raṭṭhapāla’s friends went to him and said, MN 82:10.10So how can they allow you to go forth while you’re still alive?”

    MN 82:10.11When they said this, Raṭṭhapāla kept silent.

    MN 82:10.12For a second time, MN 82:10.13and a third time, Raṭṭhapāla’s friends made the same request. MN 82:10.19And for a third time, Raṭṭhapāla kept silent.

    MN 82:10.2“Our friend Raṭṭhapāla, you are your parents’ only child. Youʼre dear to them and they love you. You’re dainty and raised in comfort. MN 82:10.3You know nothing of suffering. MN 82:10.4When you die your parents will lose you against their wishes. MN 82:10.5So how can they allow you to go forth while you’re still alive? MN 82:10.6Get up, Raṭṭhapāla! Eat, drink, and amuse yourself. MN 82:10.7While enjoying sensual pleasures, delight in making merit. MN 82:10.8Your parents will not allow you to go forth. MN 82:10.9When you die your parents will lose you against their wishes.

    MN 82:11.1BJ 11.428PTS-VP-PLI 2.60Then Raṭṭhapāla’s friends went to his parents and said,

    MN 82:11.2“Mum and dad, Raṭṭhapāla is lying there on the bare ground saying: MN 82:11.3‘I’ll either die right here or go forth.’ MN 82:11.4If you donʼt allow him to go forth, he’ll die there. MN 82:11.5But if you do allow him to go forth, you’ll see him again afterwards. MN 82:11.6And if he doesnʼt enjoy the renunciate life, where else will he have to go? He’ll come right back here. MN 82:11.7Please give Raṭṭhapāla permission to go forth.”

    MN 82:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.61Raṭṭhapāla got up and regained his strength. He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, MN 82:12.2“Sir, I have my parentsʼ permission to go forth from the lay life to homelessness. MN 82:12.3May the Buddha please give me the going forth.”

    MN 82:13.1And Raṭṭhapāla received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence. MN 82:13.2Not long after Venerable Raṭṭhapāla’s ordination, a fortnight later, the Buddha—having stayed in Thullakoṭṭhita as long as he wished—set out for Sāvatthī. MN 82:13.3Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sāvatthī, MN 82:13.4where he stayed in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

    MN 82:14.1Then Venerable Raṭṭhapāla, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

    MN 82:14.2He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.” MN 82:14.3And Venerable Raṭṭhapāla became one of the perfected.

    MN 82:15.1BJ 11.430PTS-VP-PLI 2.62Then he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, MN 82:15.2“Sir, I’d like to visit my parents, if the Buddha allows it.”

    MN 82:29.1“Master Raṭṭhapāla, there are these four kinds of decay. MN 82:29.3Decay due to old age, decay due to sickness, decay of wealth, and decay of relatives.

    MN 82:3.1Then the brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhita went up to the Buddha. MN 82:3.2When they were seated, the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.

    MN 82:30.1And what is decay due to old age? MN 82:30.10You have no decay due to old age. MN 82:30.11So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?

    MN 82:30.2It’s when someone is old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life. MN 82:30.3They reflect: MN 82:30.4‘I’m now old, elderly, and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life. MN 82:30.5It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired. MN 82:30.6Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’ MN 82:30.7So because of that decay due to old age they go forth. MN 82:30.8This is called decay due to old age. MN 82:30.9But Master Raṭṭhapāla is now a youth, young, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life.

    MN 82:31.1BJ 11.438PTS-VP-PLI 2.67And what is decay due to sickness? MN 82:31.10You have no decay due to sickness. MN 82:31.11So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?

    MN 82:31.2It’s when someone is sick, suffering, gravely ill. MN 82:31.3They reflect: MN 82:31.4‘I’m now sick, suffering, gravely ill. MN 82:31.5It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired. MN 82:31.6Why don’t I go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’ MN 82:31.7So because of that decay due to sickness they go forth. MN 82:31.8This is called decay due to sickness. MN 82:31.9But Master Raṭṭhapāla is now rarely ill or unwell. Your stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold.

    MN 82:32.1And what is decay of wealth? MN 82:32.10This is called decay of wealth. MN 82:32.11But Master Raṭṭhapāla is the son of the leading clan here in Thullakoṭṭhita. MN 82:32.12You have no decay of wealth. MN 82:32.13So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?

MN 86:0.2With Aṅgulimāla

MN 86:1.1BJ 11.516PTS-VP-PLI 2.98So I have heard. MN 86:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 86:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.103Then Venerable Aṅgulimāla robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms. MN 88:0.2The Imported Cloth

MN 88:1.1BJ 11.540So I have heard. MN 88:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 88:10.1But sir, what kind of bodily behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?”

MN 88:10.10“Bodily behavior that leads to hurting yourself, hurting others, and hurting both, MN 88:10.11and which makes unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline. MN 88:10.12That kind of bodily behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

MN 88:10.2“Unskillful behavior.”

MN 88:10.3“But what kind of bodily behavior is unskillful?”

MN 88:10.4“Blameworthy behavior.”

MN 88:10.5“But what kind of bodily behavior is blameworthy?”

MN 88:10.6“Hurtful behavior.”

MN 88:10.7“But what kind of bodily behavior is hurtful?”

MN 88:10.8“Behavior that results in suffering.”

MN 88:10.9BJ 11.544“But what kind of bodily behavior results in suffering?”

MN 88:11.1“But what kind of verbal behavior … MN 88:11.2mental behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?” …

MN 88:12.4“Mental behavior that leads to hurting yourself, hurting others, and hurting both, MN 88:12.5and which makes unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline. MN 88:12.6That kind of mental behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

MN 88:13.1“Sir, does the Buddha praise giving up all these unskillful things?”

MN 88:13.2“Great king, the Realized One has given up all unskillful things and possesses skillful things.”

MN 88:14.1“But sir, what kind of bodily behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?”

MN 88:14.10“Bodily behavior that leads to pleasing yourself, pleasing others, and pleasing both, MN 88:14.11and which makes unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow. MN 88:14.12That kind of bodily behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

MN 88:14.2“Skillful behavior.”

MN 88:14.3“But what kind of bodily behavior is skillful?”

MN 88:14.4“Blameless behavior.”

MN 88:14.5“But what kind of bodily behavior is blameless?”

MN 88:14.6“Pleasing behavior.”

MN 88:14.7“But what kind of bodily behavior is pleasing?”

MN 88:14.8“Behavior that results in happiness.”

MN 88:14.9BJ 11.546“But what kind of bodily behavior results in happiness?”

MN 88:15.1“But what kind of verbal behavior … MN 88:15.2mental behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?” …

MN 88:16.6“Mental behavior that leads to pleasing yourself, pleasing others, and pleasing both, MN 88:16.7and which makes unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow. MN 88:16.8That kind of mental behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

MN 88:17.1“Sir, does the Buddha praise embracing all these skillful things?”

MN 88:17.2“Great king, the Realized One has given up all unskillful things and possesses skillful things.”

MN 88:18.1BJ 11.548“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! MN 88:18.10This imported cloth was sent to me by King Ajātasattu Vedehiputta of Magadha packed in a parasol case. It’s exactly sixteen measures long and eight wide. MN 88:18.11May Venerable Ānanda please accept it out of compassion.”

MN 88:18.12“Enough, great king. My three robes are complete.”

MN 88:18.2How well this was said by Venerable Ānanda! MN 88:18.3I’m delighted and satisfied with what you’ve expressed so well. MN 88:18.4So much so that MN 88:18.5if an elephant-treasure was suitable for you, I would give you one. MN 88:18.6If a horse-treasure was suitable for you, I would give you one. MN 88:18.7If a prize village was suitable for you, I would give you one. MN 88:18.8But, sir, I know that MN 88:18.9these things are not suitable for you.

MN 88:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.117“Sir, we have both seen this river Aciravatī MN 88:19.2when it has rained heavily in the mountains, and the river overflows both its banks. MN 88:19.3In the same way, Venerable Ānanda can make a set of three robes for himself from this imported cloak. MN 88:19.4And you can share your old robes with your fellow monks. MN 88:19.5In this way my religious donation will come to overflow, it seems to me. MN 88:19.6Please accept the imported cloth.”

MN 88:2.1Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms. MN 88:2.2He wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother, for the day’s meditation.

MN 88:20.1So Ānanda accepted it.

MN 88:20.2Then King Pasenadi said to him, MN 88:20.3“Well, now, sir, I must go. MN 88:20.4I have many duties, and much to do.”

MN 88:20.5“Please, great king, go at your convenience.” MN 88:20.6Then King Pasenadi approved and agreed with what Ānanda said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Ānanda, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

MN 88:21.1Soon after he left, Ānanda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, MN 88:21.2and told him what had happened. MN 88:21.3He presented the cloth to the Buddha.

MN 88:22.1Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

MN 88:22.2“Mendicants, King Pasenadi is lucky, so very lucky, MN 88:22.3to get to see Ānanda and pay homage to him.”

MN 88:22.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 88:22.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 88:3.1Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala mounted the Single Lotus Elephant and drove out from Sāvatthī in the middle of the day. MN 88:3.2He saw Ānanda coming off in the distance MN 88:3.3and said to the minister Sirivaḍḍha, MN 88:3.4“My dear Sirivaḍḍha, isn’t that Venerable Ānanda?”

MN 88:3.5“Indeed it is, great king.”

MN 88:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.113Then King Pasenadi addressed a man, MN 88:4.2“Please, mister, go to Venerable Ānanda, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him: MN 88:4.3‘Sir, King Pasenadi of Kosala bows with his head at your feet.’ MN 88:4.4And then say: MN 88:4.5‘Sir, if you have no urgent business, please wait a moment out of compassion.’”

MN 88:5.1“Yes, Your Majesty,” that man replied. He did as the king asked.

MN 88:6.1Ānanda consented in silence.

MN 88:6.2Then King Pasenadi rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Ānanda on foot. MN 88:7.1Ānanda consented in silence.

MN 88:8.1So the king sat down on the seat spread out, MN 88:8.2and said, MN 88:8.3“Sir, might the Buddha engage in the sort of behavior—by way of body, speech, or mind—that is faulted by ascetics and brahmins?”

MN 88:8.4“No, great king, the Buddha would not engage in the sort of behavior that is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”

MN 88:9.1“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! MN 88:9.2For I couldn’t fully express the question, but Ānanda’s answer completed it for me. MN 88:9.3I don’t believe that praise or criticism of others spoken by incompetent fools, without examining or scrutinizing, is the most important thing. MN 88:9.4Rather, I believe that praise or criticism of others spoken by competent and intelligent people after examining and scrutinizing is the most important thing.

MN 89:0.2Shrines to the Teaching

MN 89:1.1BJ 11.550PTS-VP-PLI 2.118So I have heard. MN 89:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near the Sakyan town named Medaḷumpa.

MN 89:10.1“Sir, I infer about the Buddha from the teaching: MN 89:10.2‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’ MN 89:10.3It happens, sir, that I see some ascetics and brahmins leading the spiritual life only for a limited period: ten, twenty, thirty, or forty years. MN 89:10.4Some time later—nicely bathed and anointed, with hair and beard dressed—they amuse themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 89:10.5But here I see the mendicants leading the spiritual life entirely full and pure as long as they live, to their last breath. MN 89:10.6I don’t see any other spiritual life elsewhere so full and pure. MN 89:10.7That’s why I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching: MN 89:10.8‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

MN 89:11.1BJ 11.554PTS-VP-PLI 2.121Furthermore, kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend. MN 89:11.2But here I see the mendicants living in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes. MN 89:11.3I don’t see any other assembly elsewhere so harmonious. MN 89:11.4So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching: MN 89:11.5‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

MN 89:12.1Furthermore, I have walked and wandered from monastery to monastery and from park to park. MN 89:12.10But here I see mendicants always smiling and joyful, obviously happy, with cheerful faces, living relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer. MN 89:12.11It occurred to me: MN 89:12.12‘Clearly these venerables have realized a higher distinction in the Buddha’s instructions than they had before. MN 89:12.13That’s why these venerables are always smiling and joyful, obviously happy, with cheerful faces, living relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer.’ MN 89:12.14So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching: MN 89:12.15‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

MN 89:12.2There I’ve seen some ascetics and brahmins who are thin, haggard, pale, and veiny—hardly a captivating sight, you’d think. MN 89:12.3It occurred to me: MN 89:12.4‘Clearly these venerables lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, or they’re hiding some bad deed they’ve done. MN 89:12.5That’s why they’re thin, haggard, pale, and veiny—hardly a captivating sight, you’d think.’ MN 89:12.6I went up to them and said: MN 89:12.7‘Venerables, why are you so thin, haggard, pale, and veiny—hardly a captivating sight, you’d think?’ MN 89:12.8They say: MN 89:12.9‘We have jaundice, great king.’

MN 89:13.1BJ 11.556PTS-VP-PLI 2.122Furthermore, as an anointed aristocratic king MN 89:13.10Then one of his disciples cleared their throat. MN 89:13.11And one of their spiritual companions nudged them with their knee, to indicate: MN 89:13.12‘Hush, venerable, don’t make a sound! Our teacher, the Blessed One, is teaching!’ MN 89:13.13It occurred to me: MN 89:13.14‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing, MN 89:13.15how an assembly can be so well trained without rod or sword!’ MN 89:13.16I don’t see any other assembly elsewhere so well trained. MN 89:13.17So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching: MN 89:13.18‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

MN 89:13.2I am able to execute, fine, or banish those who are guilty. MN 89:13.3Yet when I’m sitting in judgment they interrupt me. MN 89:13.4And I can’t get them MN 89:13.5to stop interrupting me and wait until I’ve finished speaking. MN 89:13.7But here I’ve seen the mendicants MN 89:13.8while the Buddha is teaching an assembly of many hundreds, and there is no sound of his disciples coughing or clearing their throats. MN 89:13.9Once it so happened that the Buddha was teaching an assembly of many hundreds.

MN 89:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.123Furthermore, I’ve seen some clever aristocrats who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. You’d think they live to demolish convictions with their intellect. MN 89:14.10they approach him. MN 89:14.11The Buddha educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires them with a Dhamma talk. MN 89:14.12They don’t even get around to asking their question to the Buddha, so how could they refute his answer? MN 89:14.13Invariably, they become his disciples. MN 89:14.14So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching: MN 89:14.15‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

MN 89:14.2They hear: MN 89:14.3‘So, gentlemen, that ascetic Gotama will come down to such and such village or town.’ MN 89:14.4They formulate a question, thinking: MN 89:14.5‘We’ll approach the ascetic Gotama and ask him this question. MN 89:14.6If he answers like this, we’ll refute him like that; MN 89:14.7and if he answers like that, we’ll refute him like this.’ MN 89:14.8When they hear that MN 89:14.9he has come down

MN 89:15.1BJ 11.558Furthermore, I see some clever brahmins … MN 89:16.1some clever householders … MN 89:17.1some clever ascetics who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. … MN 89:17.12They don’t even get around to asking their question to the Buddha, so how could they refute his answer? MN 89:17.13Invariably, they ask the ascetic Gotama for the chance to go forth. MN 89:17.14And he gives them the going-forth. MN 89:17.15Soon after going forth, living withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, they realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. They live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness. MN 89:17.16They say: MN 89:17.17‘We were almost lost! We almost perished! MN 89:17.18For we used to claim that we were ascetics, brahmins, and perfected ones, but we were none of these things. MN 89:17.19But now we really are ascetics, brahmins, and perfected ones!’ MN 89:17.20So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching: MN 89:17.21‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

MN 89:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.124Furthermore, these chamberlains Isidatta and Purāṇa share my meals and my carriages. I give them a livelihood and bring them renown. MN 89:18.10So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching: MN 89:18.11‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

MN 89:18.2And yet they don’t show me the same level of devotion that they show to the Buddha. MN 89:18.3Once it so happened that while I was leading a military campaign and testing Isidatta and Purāṇa I took up residence in a cramped house. MN 89:18.4They spent most of the night discussing the teaching, then they lay down with their heads towards where the Buddha was and their feet towards me. MN 89:18.5It occurred to me: MN 89:18.6‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing! MN 89:18.7These chamberlains Isidatta and Purāṇa share my meals and my carriages. I give them a livelihood and bring them renown. MN 89:18.8And yet they don’t show me the same level of devotion that they show to the Buddha. MN 89:18.9Clearly these venerables have realized a higher distinction in the Buddha’s instructions than they had before.’

MN 89:19.1Furthermore, the Buddha is an aristocrat, and so am I. MN 89:19.2The Buddha is Kosalan, and so am I. MN 89:19.3The Buddha is eighty years old, and so am I. MN 89:19.4Since this is so, MN 89:19.5it’s proper for me to show the Buddha such utmost devotion and demonstrate such friendship.

MN 89:2.1Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala had arrived at Townsville on some business.

MN 89:2.2Then he addressed Dīgha Kārāyana, MN 89:2.3“My good Kārāyana, harness the finest chariots. We will go to a park and see the scenery.”

MN 89:2.4“Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Dīgha Kārāyana. He harnessed the chariots and informed the king, MN 89:2.5“Sire, the finest chariots are harnessed. MN 89:2.6Please go at your convenience.”

MN 89:20.1Well, now, sir, I must go. MN 89:20.2I have many duties, and much to do.”

MN 89:20.3“Please, great king, go at your convenience.” MN 89:20.4Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

MN 89:21.1BJ 11.560PTS-VP-PLI 2.125Soon after the king had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants: MN 89:21.2“Mendicants, before he got up and left, King Pasenadi spoke shrines to the teaching. MN 89:21.7That is what the Buddha said. MN 89:21.8Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 89:3.1Then King Pasenadi mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Townsville, MN 89:3.2heading for the park grounds. MN 89:3.3He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the park on foot.

MN 89:4.1As he was going for a walk in the park he saw roots of trees that were impressive and inspiring, quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat. MN 89:4.2The sight reminded him right away of the Buddha: MN 89:4.3“These roots of trees, so impressive and inspiring, are like those where we used to pay homage to the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”

MN 89:4.4He addressed Dīgha Kārāyana, MN 89:4.5“These roots of trees, so impressive and inspiring, are like those where we used to pay homage to the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. MN 89:4.6My good Kārāyana, where is that Buddha at present?”

MN 89:5.1BJ 11.552PTS-VP-PLI 2.119“Great king, there is a Sakyan town named Medaḷumpa. MN 89:5.10Please go at your convenience.”

MN 89:5.2That’s where the Buddha is now staying.”

MN 89:5.3“But how far away is that town?”

MN 89:5.4“Not far, great king, MN 89:5.5it’s three leagues. MN 89:5.6We can get there while it’s still light.”

MN 89:5.8“Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Dīgha Kārāyana. He harnessed the chariots and informed the king, MN 89:5.9“Sire, the finest chariots are harnessed.

MN 89:6.2He reached the town while it was still light MN 89:6.3and headed for the park grounds. MN 89:6.4He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot.

MN 89:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.120At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air. MN 89:7.2King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to them and said, MN 89:7.3“Sirs, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha? MN 89:7.4For I want to see him.”

MN 89:9.4“But great king, for what reason do you demonstrate such utmost devotion for this body, conveying your manifest love?”
