MN 90:0.2At Kaṇṇakatthala

MN 90:1.1BJ 11.562So I have heard. MN 90:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Ujuñña, in the deer park at Kaṇṇakatthala.

MN 90:10.1“Sir, I am not asking you about the present life, MN 90:10.10They are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation. MN 90:10.11They’re not devious or deceitful. They reveal themselves honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions. MN 90:10.12They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities. MN 90:10.13They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. MN 90:10.14These are the five factors that support meditation. MN 90:10.15There are these four classes: MN 90:10.16aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers. MN 90:10.17If they had these five factors that support meditation, MN 90:10.18that would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

MN 90:10.2but about the life to come.”

MN 90:10.6BJ 11.568PTS-VP-PLI 2.129“Great king, there are these five factors that support meditation. MN 90:10.7What five? MN 90:10.8It’s when a mendicant has faith in the Realized One’s awakening: MN 90:10.9‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

MN 90:11.1“Sir, there are these four classes:

MN 90:11.10“But would the pair that was not tamed and trained perform the tasks of the tamed and reach the level of the tamed, just like the tamed pair?”

MN 90:11.11“No, sir.”

MN 90:11.12“In the same way, there are things that must be attained by someone with faith, health, integrity, energy, and wisdom. It’s not possible for a faithless, unhealthy, deceitful, lazy, witless person to attain them.”

MN 90:11.2aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers. MN 90:11.3If they had these five factors that support meditation, MN 90:11.4would there be any difference between them?”

MN 90:11.5“In that case, I say it is the diversity of their efforts in meditation. MN 90:11.6Suppose there was a pair of elephants or horses or oxen in training who were well tamed and well trained. And there was a pair who were not tamed or trained. MN 90:11.7What do you think, great king? MN 90:11.8Wouldn’t the pair that was well tamed and well trained perform the tasks of the tamed, and reach the level of the tamed?”

MN 90:11.9“Yes, sir.”

MN 90:12.1BJ 11.570PTS-VP-PLI 2.130“What the Buddha says appears reasonable. MN 90:12.10while another used wood of the cluster fig. MN 90:12.11What do you think, great king? MN 90:12.12Would there be any difference between the fires produced by these different kinds of wood, that is, in the flame, color, or light?”

MN 90:12.13“No, sir.”

MN 90:12.14“In the same way, when fire has been kindled by energy and produced by effort, I say that there is no difference between the freedom of one and the freedom of the other.”

MN 90:12.2Sir, there are these four classes: MN 90:12.3aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers. MN 90:12.4If they had these five factors that support meditation, and if they practiced rightly, MN 90:12.5would there be any difference between them?”

MN 90:12.6“In that case, I say that there is no difference between the freedom of one and the freedom of the other. MN 90:12.7Suppose a person took dry teak wood and lit a fire and produced heat. MN 90:12.8Then another person did the same using sāl wood, MN 90:12.9another used mango wood,

MN 90:13.1“What the Buddha says appears reasonable. MN 90:13.2But sir, do gods absolutely exist?”

MN 90:13.3“But what exactly are you asking?”

MN 90:13.5“Whether those gods come back to this state of existence or not.”

MN 90:13.6“Those gods who are subject to affliction come back to this state of existence, but those free of affliction do not come back.”

MN 90:14.1When he said this, General Viḍūḍabha said to the Buddha, MN 90:14.10As far as the dominion of King Pasenadi of Kosala extends, where he rules as sovereign lord, can he topple or expel from that place any ascetic or brahmin, regardless of whether they are good or bad, or whether or not they are genuine spiritual practitioners?”

MN 90:14.11“He can, mister.”

MN 90:14.12“What do you think, general? MN 90:14.13As far as the dominion of King Pasenadi does not extend, where he does not rule as sovereign lord, can he topple or expel from that place any ascetic or brahmin, regardless of whether they are good or bad, or whether or not they are genuine spiritual practitioners?”

MN 90:14.14“He cannot, mister.”

MN 90:14.15BJ 11.572“What do you think, general? MN 90:14.16Have you heard of the gods of the Thirty-Three?”

MN 90:14.17“Yes, mister, MN 90:14.18I’ve heard of them, MN 90:14.19and so has the good King Pasenadi.”

MN 90:14.2“Sir, will the gods subject to affliction topple or expel from their place the gods who are free of affliction?”

MN 90:14.20“What do you think, general? MN 90:14.21Can King Pasenadi topple or expel from their place the gods of the Thirty-Three?”

MN 90:14.22“King Pasenadi can’t even see the gods of the Thirty-Three, so how could he possibly topple or expel them from their place?”

MN 90:14.23“In the same way, general, the gods subject to affliction can’t even see the gods who are free of affliction, so how could they possibly topple or expel them from their place?”

MN 90:14.3PTS-VP-PLI 2.131Then Venerable Ānanda thought, MN 90:14.4“This General Viḍūḍabha is King Pasenadi’s son, MN 90:14.5and I am the Buddha’s son. MN 90:14.6Now is the time for one son to confer with another.” MN 90:14.7So Ānanda addressed General Viḍūḍabha, MN 90:14.8“Well then, general, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like. MN 90:14.9What do you think, general?

MN 90:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.132Then the king said to the Buddha,

MN 90:15.10“Any Brahmā who is subject to affliction comes back to this state of existence, but those free of affliction do not come back.”

MN 90:15.2“Sir, what is this mendicant’s name?”

MN 91:0.2With Brahmāyu

MN 91:1.1BJ 11.576So I have heard. MN 91:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Videhans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.

MN 91:10.1BJ 11.584PTS-VP-PLI 2.138When he’s walking he takes the first step with the right foot. MN 91:10.2He doesn’t lift his foot too far or place it too near. MN 91:10.3He doesn’t walk too slow or too fast. MN 91:10.4He walks without knocking his knees or ankles together. MN 91:10.5When he’s walking he keeps his thighs neither too straight nor too bent, neither too tight nor too loose. MN 91:10.6When he walks, only the lower half of his body moves, and he walks effortlessly. MN 91:10.7When he turns to look he does so with the whole body. MN 91:10.8He doesn’t look directly up or down. MN 91:10.9He doesn’t look all around while walking, but focuses a plough’s length in front. Beyond that he has unhindered knowledge and vision.

MN 91:11.1When entering an inhabited area he keeps his body neither too straight nor too bent, neither too tight nor too loose.

MN 91:12.1He turns around neither too far nor too close to the seat. He doesn’t lean on his hand when sitting down. And he doesn’t just plonk his body down on the seat. MN 91:12.2When sitting in inhabited areas he doesn’t fidget with his hands or feet. MN 91:12.3He doesn’t sit with his knees or ankles crossed. MN 91:12.4He doesn’t sit with his hand holding his chin. MN 91:12.5When sitting in inhabited areas he doesn’t shake, tremble, quake, or get nervous, and so he is not nervous at all. MN 91:12.6When sitting in inhabited areas he still practices seclusion.

MN 91:13.1When receiving water for rinsing the bowl, he holds the bowl neither too straight nor too bent, neither too tight nor too loose.

MN 91:14.1He receives neither too little nor too much water. MN 91:14.10He eats experiencing the taste, but without experiencing greed for the taste.

MN 91:14.11BJ 11.586PTS-VP-PLI 2.139He eats food thinking of eight reasons: MN 91:14.12‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will live blamelessly and at ease.’

MN 91:14.2He rinses the bowl without making a sloshing noise, or spinning it around. He doesn’t put the bowl on the ground to rinse his hands; his hands and bowl are rinsed at the same time. MN 91:14.3He doesn’t throw the bowl rinsing water away too far or too near, or splash it about. MN 91:14.4When receiving rice, he holds the bowl neither too straight nor too bent, neither too close nor too loose. MN 91:14.5He receives neither too little nor too much rice. MN 91:14.6He eats sauce in a moderate proportion, and doesn’t spend too much time saucing his portions. MN 91:14.7He chews over each portion two or three times before swallowing. MN 91:14.8But no grain of rice enters his body unchewed, and none remain in his mouth. MN 91:14.9Only then does he raise another portion to his lips.

MN 91:15.1After eating, when receiving water for washing the bowl, he holds the bowl neither too straight nor too bent, neither too tight nor too loose. MN 91:15.2He receives neither too little nor too much water. MN 91:15.3He washes the bowl without making a sloshing noise, or spinning it around. He doesn’t put the bowl on the ground to wash his hands; his hands and bowl are washed at the same time. MN 91:15.4He doesn’t throw the bowl washing water away too far or too near, or splash it about.

MN 91:16.1After eating he doesn’t put the bowl on the ground too far away or too close. He’s not careless with his bowl, nor does he spend too much time on it.

MN 91:17.1After eating he sits for a while in silence, but doesn’t wait too long to give the verses of appreciation. MN 91:17.2After eating he expresses appreciation without criticizing the meal or expecting another one. MN 91:17.3Invariably, he educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires that assembly with a Dhamma talk. MN 91:17.4Then he gets up from his seat and leaves.

MN 91:18.1He walks neither too fast nor too slow, without wanting to get out of there.

MN 91:19.1He wears his robe on his body neither too high nor too low, neither too tight nor too loose. MN 91:19.2The wind doesn’t blow his robe off his body. MN 91:19.3And dust and dirt don’t stick to his body.

MN 91:2.1Now at that time the brahmin Brahmāyu was residing in Mithilā. He was old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, having reached the final stage of life; he was a hundred and twenty years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies, ritual, phonology and etymology, and the testament as fifth. He knew philology and grammar, and was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.

MN 91:20.1When he has gone to the monastery he sits on a seat spread out and washes his feet. MN 91:20.2But he doesn’t waste time with pedicures. MN 91:20.3When he has washed his feet, he sits down cross-legged, with his body straight, and establishes mindfulness right there. MN 91:20.4He has no intention to hurt himself, hurt others, or hurt both. MN 91:20.5He only wishes for the welfare of himself, of others, of both, and of the whole world. MN 91:21.1In the monastery when he teaches Dhamma to an assembly, he neither flatters them nor rebukes them. MN 91:21.2Invariably, he educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires that assembly with a Dhamma talk.

MN 91:21.3His voice has eight qualities: MN 91:21.4it is clear, comprehensible, charming, audible, rounded, undistorted, deep, and resonant. MN 91:21.5He makes sure his voice is intelligible as far as the assembly goes, but it doesn’t extend outside the assembly. MN 91:21.6And when they’ve been inspired with a Dhamma talk by Master Gotama they get up from their seats and leave looking back at him alone, and not forgetting their lesson.

MN 91:22.1I have seen Master Gotama walking and standing; entering inhabited areas, and sitting and eating there; sitting silently after eating, and expressing appreciation; going to the monastery, sitting silently there, and teaching Dhamma to an assembly there. MN 91:22.2Such is Master Gotama; such he is and more than that.”

MN 91:23.1When he had spoken, the brahmin Brahmāyu got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and uttered this aphorism three times:

MN 91:23.2“Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

MN 91:23.3Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

MN 91:23.4Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

MN 91:23.5Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet him, and we can have a discussion.”

MN 91:24.1BJ 11.588PTS-VP-PLI 2.141And then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the Videhan lands, arrived at Mithilā, MN 91:24.2where he stayed in the Makhādeva Mango Grove.

MN 91:24.5He has this good reputation: MN 91:24.6‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ MN 91:24.7He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. MN 91:9.13He has delicate skin, so delicate that dust and dirt don’t stick to his body.

MN 91:9.14His hairs grow one per pore.

MN 91:9.16His body is as straight as Brahmā’s.

MN 91:9.17He has bulging muscles in seven places.

MN 91:9.18His chest is like that of a lion.

MN 91:9.19The gap between the shoulder-blades is filled in.

MN 91:9.20He has the proportional circumference of a banyan tree: the span of his arms equals the height of his body.

MN 91:9.21BJ 11.582His torso is cylindrical.

MN 91:9.22He has an excellent sense of taste.

MN 91:9.23PTS-VP-PLI 2.137His jaw is like that of a lion.

MN 91:9.24He has forty teeth.

MN 91:9.25His teeth are even.

MN 91:9.26His teeth have no gaps.

MN 91:9.27His teeth are perfectly white.

MN 91:9.28He has a large tongue.

MN 91:9.29He has the voice of Brahmā, like a cuckoo’s call.

MN 91:9.3On the soles of his feet there are thousand-spoked wheels, with rims and hubs, complete in every detail.

MN 91:9.30His eyes are deep blue.

MN 91:9.31He has eyelashes like a cow’s.

MN 91:9.32Between his eyebrows there grows a tuft, soft and white like cotton-wool.

MN 91:9.33His head is shaped like a turban.

MN 91:9.34These are the thirty-two marks of a great man possessed by Master Gotama.

MN 91:9.4He has projecting heels.

MN 91:9.5He has long fingers.

MN 91:9.6His hands and feet are tender.

MN 91:9.8His feet are arched.

MN 91:9.9His calves are like those of an antelope.

MN 93:3.2Then those brahmins thought, MN 93:3.4“This Assalāyana is capable of having a dialogue with the ascetic Gotama about this.”

MN 93:4.1So they approached Assalāyana and said to him, MN 93:4.10Please, Mister Assalāyana, have a dialogue with the ascetic Gotama about this. MN 93:4.11For you have lived as a wanderer.” MN 93:4.12And for a second time, Assalāyana refused.

MN 93:4.16For a third time, those brahmins said to him, MN 93:4.17“This ascetic Gotama advocates purification for all four classes. MN 93:4.18Please, Mister Assalāyana, have a dialogue with the ascetic Gotama about this. MN 93:4.19For you have lived as a wanderer. MN 93:4.2“This ascetic Gotama advocates purification for all four classes. MN 93:4.20Don’t admit defeat before going into battle!”

MN 93:4.21BJ 11.612When they said this, Assalāyana said to them, MN 93:4.22“Clearly, gentlemen, I’m not getting through to you when I say: MN 93:4.23‘They say that the ascetic Gotama is a speaker of principle. MN 93:4.24But speakers of principle are hard to have a dialogue with. MN 93:4.25I’m not capable of having a dialogue with the ascetic Gotama about this.’ MN 93:4.26Nevertheless, I shall go at your bidding.”

MN 93:4.3Please, Mister Assalāyana, have a dialogue with the ascetic Gotama about this.”

MN 93:4.4When they said this, Assalāyana said to them, MN 93:4.5“They say that the ascetic Gotama is a speaker of principle. MN 93:4.6But speakers of principle are hard to have a dialogue with. MN 93:4.7I’m not capable of having a dialogue with the ascetic Gotama about this.”

MN 93:4.8PTS-VP-PLI 2.148For a second time, those brahmins said to him MN 93:4.9“This ascetic Gotama advocates purification for all four classes.

MN 93:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.149Then Assalāyana together with a large group of brahmins went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him. MN 93:5.10Yet even though they’re born from a brahmin womb they say: MN 93:5.11‘Only brahmins are the highest caste; other castes are inferior. MN 93:5.12Only brahmins are the light caste; other castes are dark. MN 93:5.13Only brahmins are purified, not others. MN 93:5.14Only brahmins are Brahmā’s rightful sons, born of his mouth, born of Brahmā, created by Brahmā, heirs of Brahmā.’”

MN 93:5.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

MN 93:5.3“Master Gotama, the brahmins say: MN 93:5.4‘Only brahmins are the highest caste; other castes are inferior. MN 93:5.5Only brahmins are the light caste; other castes are dark. MN 93:5.6Only brahmins are purified, not others. MN 93:5.7Only brahmins are Brahmā’s rightful sons, born of his mouth, born of Brahmā, created by Brahmā, heirs of Brahmā.’ MN 93:5.8What do you say about this?”

MN 93:5.9“But Assalāyana, brahmin women are seen menstruating, being pregnant, giving birth, and breastfeeding.

MN 93:6.1“Even though you say this, still the brahmins maintain their belief.”

MN 93:6.4“What do you think, Assalāyana? MN 93:6.5Have you heard that in Greece and Persia and other foreign lands there are only two classes, masters and bonded servants; and that masters may become servants, and servants masters?”

MN 93:6.6“Yes, I have heard that.”

MN 93:6.7“Then what is the source of the brahmins’ self-confidence and forcefulness in this matter that they make this claim?”

MN 93:7.1“Even though you say this, still the brahmins maintain their belief.” MN 93:7.13For if any of the four classes were to kill living creatures, steal, and commit sexual misconduct; to use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and to be covetous, malicious, with wrong view, then, when their body breaks up, after death, they’d be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.”

MN 93:7.14“Then what is the source of the brahmins’ self-confidence and forcefulness in this matter that they make this claim?”

MN 93:7.4BJ 11.614PTS-VP-PLI 2.150“What do you think, Assalāyana? MN 93:7.5Suppose an aristocrat were to kill living creatures, steal, and commit sexual misconduct; to use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and to be covetous, malicious, with wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’d be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. Would this happen only to an aristocrat, and not to a brahmin? MN 93:7.6Or suppose a merchant, MN 93:7.7or a worker were to act in the same way. Would that result befall only a merchant or a worker, and not to a brahmin?”

MN 93:7.8“No, Master Gotama. MN 93:7.9If they acted the same way, the same result would befall an aristocrat, a brahmin, a merchant, or a worker.

MN 93:8.1“Even though you say this, still the brahmins maintain their belief.” MN 93:8.11For if any of the four classes were to refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct; from using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and from covetousness, malice, and wrong view, then, when their body breaks up, after death, they’d be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

MN 93:8.12“Then what is the source of the brahmins’ self-confidence and forcefulness in this matter that they make this claim?”

MN 93:8.4PTS-VP-PLI 2.151“What do you think, Assalāyana? MN 93:8.5Suppose a brahmin were to refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct; from using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and from covetousness, malice, and wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’d be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. Would this happen only to an brahmin, and not to an aristocrat, a merchant, or a worker?”

MN 93:8.6“No, Master Gotama. MN 93:8.7If they acted the same way, the same result would befall an aristocrat, a brahmin, a merchant, or a worker.

MN 93:9.1“Even though you say this, still the brahmins maintain their belief.” MN 93:9.11For all four classes are capable of developing a heart of love, free of enmity and ill will for this region.”

MN 93:9.12“Then what is the source of the brahmins’ self-confidence and forcefulness in this matter that they make this claim?”

MN 93:9.4BJ 11.616“What do you think, Assalāyana? MN 93:9.5Is only a brahmin capable of developing a heart of love, free of enmity and ill will for this region, and not an aristocrat, merchant, or worker?”

MN 93:9.6“No, Master Gotama. MN 93:9.7Aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers can all do so.

  • MN 94:0.1Middle Discourses 94

MN 94:0.2With Ghoṭamukha

MN 94:1.1BJ 11.628PTS-VP-PLI 2.158So I have heard. MN 94:1.2At one time Venerable Udena was staying near Benares in the Khemiya Mango Grove.

MN 94:10.1BJ 11.634PTS-VP-PLI 2.162“What person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves? MN 94:10.10They constantly stand, refusing seats. MN 94:10.11They squat, committed to persisting in the squatting position. MN 94:10.12They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed. MN 94:10.13They’re committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening. MN 94:10.14And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body. MN 94:10.15This is called a person who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

MN 94:10.2It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on purpose for them, or an invitation for a meal. MN 94:10.3They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drink no beer. MN 94:10.4They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls. MN 94:10.5They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day. MN 94:10.6They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals. MN 94:10.7They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit. MN 94:10.8They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings. MN 94:10.9They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.

MN 94:11.1And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others? MN 94:11.2It’s when a person is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood. MN 94:11.3This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.

MN 94:12.1BJ 11.636And what person mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others? MN 94:12.2It’s when a person is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin. MN 94:12.3He has a new temple built to the east of the city. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the temple with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest. MN 94:12.4There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass. MN 94:12.5The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the remainder. MN 94:12.6He says: MN 94:12.7‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’ MN 94:12.8His bondservants, employees, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces. MN 94:12.9This is called a person who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

MN 94:13.1BJ 11.638And what person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others, MN 94:13.2living without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves?

MN 94:14.1It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. MN 94:14.2He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. MN 94:14.3He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

MN 94:15.1A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some clan. MN 94:15.2They gain faith in the Realized One, MN 94:15.3and reflect: MN 94:15.4‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open. MN 94:15.5It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell. MN 94:15.6Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’ MN 94:15.7After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness. MN 94:15.8Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.

MN 94:16.1They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.

MN 94:16.10They avoid beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, perfumes, and makeup. MN 94:16.11They avoid high and luxurious beds. MN 94:16.12They avoid receiving gold and money, MN 94:16.13raw grains, MN 94:16.14raw meat, MN 94:16.15women and girls, MN 94:16.16male and female bondservants, MN 94:16.17goats and sheep, MN 94:16.18chickens and pigs, MN 94:16.19elephants, cows, horses, and mares,

MN 94:16.2They give up unchastity. They are celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.

MN 94:16.20and fields and land. MN 94:16.21They avoid running errands and messages; MN 94:16.22buying and selling; MN 94:16.23falsifying weights, metals, or measures; MN 94:16.24bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; MN 94:16.25mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

MN 94:16.3They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words.

MN 94:16.4They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

MN 94:16.5They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

MN 94:16.6They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

MN 94:16.7They avoid injuring plants and seeds. MN 94:16.8They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time. MN 94:16.9They avoid dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows.

MN 94:17.1They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things. MN 94:17.2They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden. MN 94:17.3In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things. MN 94:17.4When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

MN 94:18.1When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 94:18.2If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint. MN 94:18.3When they hear a sound with their ears … MN 94:18.4When they smell an odor with their nose … MN 94:18.5When they taste a flavor with their tongue … MN 94:18.6When they feel a touch with their body … MN 94:18.7When they know a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 94:18.8If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint. MN 94:18.9When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.

MN 94:19.1BJ 11.640They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

MN 94:2.1Now at that time the brahmin Ghoṭamukha had arrived at Benares on some business. MN 94:2.2Then as he was going for a walk he went to the Khemiya Mango Grove. MN 94:2.3At that time Venerable Udena was walking mindfully in the open air. MN 94:2.4Ghoṭamukha approached and exchanged greetings with him.

MN 94:2.5Walking alongside Udena, he said, MN 94:2.6“Mister ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life; MN 94:2.7that’s what I think. MN 94:2.8And that’s without seeing gentlemen such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”

MN 94:20.1When they have this noble spectrum of ethics, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, MN 94:20.2they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

MN 94:21.1After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. MN 94:21.2Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire. MN 94:21.3Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will. MN 94:21.4Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness. MN 94:21.5Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse. MN 94:21.6Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

MN 94:22.1They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. MN 94:22.2Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

MN 94:23.1As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

MN 94:24.1And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

MN 94:25.1Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

MN 94:26.1When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives. MN 94:26.2They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

MN 94:27.1BJ 11.642When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 94:27.2With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

MN 94:28.1When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 94:28.2They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. MN 94:28.3They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

MN 94:29.1Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 94:29.2When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

MN 94:29.3They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 94:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.159When he said this, Udena stepped down from the walking path, entered his dwelling, and sat down on the seat spread out. MN 94:3.2Ghoṭamukha also stepped down from the walking path and entered the dwelling, where he stood to one side. MN 94:3.3Udena said to him, MN 94:3.4“There are seats, brahmin. MN 94:3.5Please sit if you wish.”

MN 94:3.6“I was just waiting for you to sit down. MN 94:3.7For how could one such as I presume to sit first without being invited?”

MN 94:30.1This is called a person who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others. MN 94:30.2They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.”

MN 94:31.1When he had spoken, Ghoṭamukha said to him, MN 94:31.2“Excellent, Master Udena! Excellent! MN 94:31.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Udena has made the teaching clear in many ways. MN 94:31.4I go for refuge to Master Udena, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 94:31.5From this day forth, may Master Udena remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

MN 94:32.1“Brahmin, don’t go for refuge to me.

MN 94:32.11But since the Buddha has become fully extinguished, I go for refuge to that fully extinguished Buddha, to the teaching, and to the Saṅgha. MN 94:32.12From this day forth, may Master Udena remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life. MN 94:32.2You should go for refuge to that same Blessed One to whom I have gone for refuge.”

MN 94:32.3“But Master Udena, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

MN 94:32.4“Brahmin, the Buddha has already become fully extinguished.”

MN 94:32.5BJ 11.644PTS-VP-PLI 2.163“Master Udena, if I heard that the Buddha was within ten leagues, or twenty, or even up to a hundred leagues away, I’d go a hundred leagues to see him. MN 94:33.1Master Udena, the king of Aṅga gives me a regular daily allowance. I will give you one portion of that.”

MN 94:33.10And these days it’s called the “Ghoṭamukhī”.

MN 94:33.2“But brahmin, what does the king of Aṅga give you as a regular daily allowance?”

MN 94:33.3“Five hundred dollars.”

MN 94:33.4“It’s not proper for us to receive gold and money.”

MN 94:33.5“If that’s not proper, I will have a dwelling built for Master Udena.”

MN 94:33.6“If you want to build me a dwelling, then build an assembly hall for the Saṅgha at Pāṭaliputta.”

MN 94:33.7“Now I’m even more delighted and satisfied with Master Udena, since he encourages me to give to the Saṅgha. MN 94:33.8So with this allowance and another one I will have an assembly hall built for the Saṅgha at Pāṭaliputta.”

MN 94:33.9And so he had that hall built.

MN 94:4.1Then he took a low seat and sat to one side, MN 94:4.2where he said, MN 94:4.3“Mister ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life; MN 94:4.4that’s what I think. MN 94:4.5And that’s without seeing gentlemen such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”

MN 94:4.6“Brahmin, we can discuss this. But only if you allow what should be allowed, and reject what should be rejected. And if you ask me the meaning of anything you don’t understand, saying: MN 94:4.7‘Sir, why is this? What does that mean?’”

MN 94:4.8“Let us discuss this. I will do as you say.”

MN 94:5.1BJ 11.630“Brahmin, these four people are found in the world. MN 94:5.13I only like the sound of the last person, who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others.”

MN 94:5.2What four?

  1. MN 94:5.3One person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
  2. MN 94:5.4One person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
  3. MN 94:5.5One person mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
  4. MN 94:5.6One person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others. MN 94:5.7They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.

MN 94:5.8Which one of these four people do you like the sound of?”

MN 94:5.9“Sir, I don’t like the sound of the first three people.

MN 94:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.160“But why don’t you like the sound of those three people?”

MN 94:6.2“Sir, the person who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain. MN 94:6.3That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person. MN 94:6.4The person who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain. MN 94:6.5That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person. MN 94:6.6The person who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain. MN 94:6.7That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person. MN 94:6.8The person who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain. MN 94:6.9That’s why I like the sound of that person.”

MN 94:7.1BJ 11.632“There are, brahmin, these two groups of people. MN 94:7.10the group that has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

MN 94:7.2What two? MN 94:7.3There’s one group of people who, being infatuated with jeweled earrings, seeks partners and children, male and female bondservants, fields and lands, and gold and money.

MN 94:7.4And there’s another group of people who, not being infatuated with jeweled earrings, has given up partner and children, male and female bondservants, fields and lands, and gold and money, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness.

MN 95:13.3this is the only truth, other ideas are silly’?”

MN 95:14.1“The brahmins don’t just honor this because of faith, but also because of oral transmission.”

MN 95:14.10something may be accurately transmitted … MN 95:14.11something may be well contemplated … MN 95:14.12something may be well considered, it may be void, hollow, and false. MN 95:14.13And even if something is not well considered, it may be true and real, not otherwise. MN 95:14.14For a sensible person who is preserving truth this is not sufficient to come to the definite conclusion: MN 95:14.15‘This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’”

MN 95:14.2“First you relied on faith, now you speak of oral tradition. MN 95:14.3These five things can be seen to turn out in two different ways. MN 95:14.4What five? MN 95:14.7Even though you have full faith in something, it may be void, hollow, and false. MN 95:14.8And even if you don’t have full faith in something, it may be true and real, not otherwise. MN 95:15.1BJ 11.658“But Master Gotama, how do you define the preservation of truth?” MN 95:15.10or has accepted a view after contemplation, MN 95:15.11they preserve truth by saying, ‘Such is the view I have accepted after contemplation.’ MN 95:15.12But they don’t yet come to the definite conclusion: MN 95:15.13‘This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’ MN 95:15.14That’s how the preservation of truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. MN 95:17.1“Bhāradvāja, take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village. MN 95:17.11Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without greed. MN 95:17.12And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute. MN 95:2.1Now at that time the brahmin Caṅkī was living in Opāsāda. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal endowment of the highest quality.

MN 95:20.1Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that promote delusion. MN 95:20.2Next, they place faith in them. When faith has arisen they approach the teacher. MN 95:20.3That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the awakening to truth as defined in this way. MN 95:20.4But this is not yet the arrival at the truth.”

MN 95:21.1BJ 11.662PTS-VP-PLI 2.174“That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, Master Gotama. I regard the awakening to truth as defined in this way. MN 95:21.2But Master Gotama, how do you define the arrival at the truth?”

MN 96:1.1BJ 11.668PTS-VP-PLI 2.178So I have heard. MN 96:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 96:10.1BJ 11.672When he had spoken, Esukārī said to him:

MN 96:10.2“Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe four kinds of wealth: MN 96:10.3for a brahmin, an aristocrat, a merchant, and a worker. MN 96:10.4The wealth they prescribe for a brahmin is living on alms. MN 96:10.5A brahmin who scorns his own wealth, living on alms, fails in his duty like a guard who steals. MN 96:10.7The wealth they prescribe for an aristocrat is the bow and quiver. MN 96:10.8An aristocrat who scorns his own wealth, the bow and quiver, fails in his duty like a guard who steals.

MN 96:11.1BJ 11.674PTS-VP-PLI 2.181“But brahmin, did the whole world authorize the brahmins to prescribe these four kinds of wealth?”

MN 96:11.2“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 96:11.3“It’s as if they were to force a steak on a poor, penniless person, telling them they must eat it and then pay for it.

MN 96:11.4In the same way, the brahmins have prescribed these four kinds of wealth without the consent of these ascetics and brahmins.

MN 96:12.1I declare that a person’s own wealth is the noble, transcendent teaching. MN 96:12.10A fire that burns dependent on grass is reckoned as a grass fire. MN 96:12.11A fire that burns dependent on cow-dung is reckoned as a cow-dung fire.

MN 96:12.12In the same way, I declare that a person’s own wealth is the noble, transcendent teaching. MN 96:12.13But they are reckoned by recollecting the traditional family lineage of their mother and father wherever they are incarnated.

MN 96:12.2But they are reckoned by recollecting the traditional family lineage of their mother and father wherever they are incarnated. MN 96:12.3If they incarnate in a family of aristocrats they are reckoned as an aristocrat. MN 96:12.4If they incarnate in a family of brahmins they are reckoned as a brahmin. MN 96:12.5If they incarnate in a family of merchants they are reckoned as a merchant. MN 96:12.6If they incarnate in a family of workers they are reckoned as a worker.

MN 96:12.7It’s like fire, which is reckoned according to the specific conditions dependent upon which it burns. MN 96:12.8A fire that burns dependent on logs is reckoned as a log fire. MN 96:12.9A fire that burns dependent on twigs is reckoned as a twig fire.

MN 96:13.1Suppose someone from a family of aristocrats goes forth from the lay life to homelessness. Relying on the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One they refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and sex. They refrain from using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re not covetous or malicious, and they have right view. They succeed in the procedure of the skillful teaching.

MN 96:13.2PTS-VP-PLI 2.182Suppose someone from a family of brahmins … MN 96:13.3merchants … MN 96:13.4workers goes forth from the lay life to homelessness. Relying on the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One … they succeed in the procedure of the skillful teaching.

MN 96:14.1What do you think, brahmin? MN 96:14.10BJ 11.676brahmins, MN 96:14.11merchants, MN 96:14.12or workers goes forth from the lay life to homelessness. Relying on the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One … they succeed in the procedure of the skillful teaching.

MN 96:14.2Is only a brahmin capable of developing a heart of love free of enmity and ill will for this region, and not an aristocrat, merchant, or worker?”

MN 96:14.3“No, Master Gotama. MN 96:14.4Aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers can all do so. MN 96:14.8For all four classes are capable of developing a heart of love free of enmity and ill will for this region.”

MN 96:14.9“In the same way, suppose someone from a family of aristocrats,

MN 96:15.9“In the same way, suppose someone from a family of aristocrats,

MN 96:16.12“In the same way, suppose someone from a family of aristocrats, MN 96:16.13brahmins, MN 96:16.14merchants, MN 96:16.15or workers goes forth from the lay life to homelessness. Relying on the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One they refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and sex. They refrain from using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re not covetous or malicious, and they have right view. MN 96:16.2Suppose an anointed aristocratic king were to gather a hundred people born in different castes and say to them: MN 96:16.3‘Please gentlemen, let anyone here who was born in a family of aristocrats, brahmins, or chieftains take a drill-stick made of teak, sal, frankincense wood, sandalwood, or cherry wood, light a fire and produce heat. MN 96:16.5BJ 11.678PTS-VP-PLI 2.184What do you think, brahmin? MN 96:16.6Would only the fire produced by the high class people with good quality wood have flames, color, and radiance, and be usable as fire, MN 96:16.7and not the fire produced by the low class people with poor quality wood?”

MN 96:16.8“No, Master Gotama. MN 96:16.9The fire produced by the high class people with good quality wood would have flames, color, and radiance, and be usable as fire,

MN 96:2.1Then Esukārī the brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 96:2.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

MN 96:3.1“Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe four kinds of service: MN 96:3.10‘A merchant or a worker may serve a merchant.’ MN 96:3.12This is the service they prescribe for a worker: MN 96:3.13‘Only a worker may serve a worker. MN 96:3.14For who else will serve a worker?’ MN 96:3.16These are the four kinds of service that the brahmins prescribe. MN 96:3.17What do you say about this?”

MN 96:3.2for a brahmin, an aristocrat, a merchant, and a worker. MN 96:3.3This is the service they prescribe for a brahmin: MN 96:3.4‘A brahmin, an aristocrat, a merchant, and a worker may all serve a brahmin.’ MN 96:3.6This is the service they prescribe for an aristocrat: MN 96:3.7‘An aristocrat, a merchant, and a worker may all serve an aristocrat.’ MN 96:3.9This is the service they prescribe for a merchant:

MN 96:4.1BJ 11.670PTS-VP-PLI 2.179“But brahmin, did the whole world authorize the brahmins to prescribe these four kinds of service?”

MN 96:4.2“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 96:4.3“It’s as if they were to force a steak on a poor, penniless person, telling them they must eat it and then pay for it. MN 96:4.4In the same way, the brahmins have prescribed these four kinds of service without the consent of these ascetics and brahmins.

MN 96:5.1Brahmin, I don’t say that you should serve everyone, nor do I say that you shouldn’t serve anyone. MN 96:5.2I say that you shouldn’t serve someone if serving them makes you worse, not better. MN 96:5.3And I say that you should serve someone if serving them makes you better, not worse.

MN 96:6.1If they were to ask an aristocrat this, MN 96:6.2‘Who should you serve? Someone in whose service you get worse, or someone in whose service you get better?’ MN 96:6.3Answering rightly, an aristocrat would say, MN 96:6.4‘Someone in whose service I get better.’

MN 96:7.1If they were to ask a brahmin … MN 96:7.2a merchant … MN 96:7.3or a worker this, MN 96:7.4‘Who should you serve? Someone in whose service you get worse, or someone in whose service you get better?’ MN 96:7.5Answering rightly, a worker would say, MN 96:7.6‘Someone in whose service I get better.’

MN 96:7.7Brahmin, I don’t say that coming from an eminent family makes you a better or worse person. MN 96:7.8I don’t say that being very beautiful makes you a better or worse person. MN 96:7.9I don’t say that being very wealthy makes you a better or worse person.

MN 96:8.1For some people from eminent families kill living creatures, steal, and commit sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view. MN 96:8.10That’s why I don’t say that any of these things makes you a better or worse person. MN 96:8.2That’s why I don’t say that coming from an eminent family makes you a better person.

MN 96:8.3But some people from eminent families also refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct. They refrain from using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re not covetous or malicious, and they have right view. MN 96:8.4That’s why I don’t say that coming from an eminent family makes you a worse person.

MN 96:8.5PTS-VP-PLI 2.180People who are very beautiful, MN 96:8.6or not very beautiful, MN 96:8.7who are very wealthy, MN 96:8.8or not very wealthy, MN 96:8.9may also behave in the same ways.

MN 96:9.1Brahmin, I don’t say that you should serve everyone, nor do I say that you shouldn’t serve anyone. MN 96:9.2And I say that you should serve someone if serving them makes you grow in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. MN 96:9.3I say that you shouldn’t serve someone if serving them doesn’t make you grow in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.”

MN 99:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.201When he said this, Subha became angry and upset with the Buddha because of the simile of the queue of blind men. He even attacked and badmouthed the Buddha himself, saying, MN 99:10.2“The ascetic Gotama will be worsted!” He said to the Buddha:

MN 99:12.14PTS-VP-PLI 2.202“No, Master Gotama. MN 99:12.15There are such things as dark and bright sights, and one who sees them. MN 99:24.1“And what is a path to companionship with Brahmā? MN 99:24.2Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. MN 99:24.3When the heart’s release by love has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there. MN 99:24.4Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four directions. MN 99:24.5In the same way, when the heart’s release by love has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there. MN 99:5.2‘Since the work of the lay life has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings it is very fruitful. MN 99:5.3But since the work of the renunciate has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings it is not very fruitful.’ MN 99:5.4What do you say about this?”

MN 99:5.5BJ 11.714PTS-VP-PLI 2.198“On this point, too, I speak after analyzing the question, MN 99:5.6not definitively. MN 99:5.7Some work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful. MN 99:5.8Some work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful. MN 99:5.9Some work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful.

MN 99:6.1And what work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful? MN 99:6.2Farming. MN 99:6.3And what work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful? MN 99:6.4Again, it is farming. MN 99:6.5And what work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful? MN 99:6.6Trade. MN 99:6.7And what work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful? MN 99:6.8Again, it’s trade.

MN 99:7.1BJ 11.716PTS-VP-PLI 2.199The lay life is like farming in that it’s work with many requirements and when it fails it’s not very fruitful; MN 99:7.3but when it succeeds it is very fruitful. MN 99:7.5The renunciate life is like trade in that it’s work with few requirements and when it fails it’s not very fruitful; MN 99:7.7but when it succeeds it is very fruitful.”

MN 99:8.1“Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe five things for making merit and succeeding in the skillful.”

MN 99:8.3“If you don’t mind, MN 99:8.4please explain these in this assembly.”

MN 99:8.5“It’s no trouble when gentlemen such as yourself are sitting here.”

MN 99:8.6“Well, speak then, student.”

MN 99:9.1“Master Gotama, truth is the first thing.

MN 99:9.10“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 99:9.11“Well, is there even a single teacher of the brahmins, or a teacher’s teacher, or anyone back to the seventh generation of teachers, who says this: MN 99:9.12‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight’?”

MN 99:9.13“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 99:9.14“Well, what of the ancient hermits of the brahmins, namely Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu? They were the authors and propagators of the hymns. Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught. MN 99:9.15Did even they say: MN 99:9.16‘We declare the result of these five things after realizing it with our own insight’?”

MN 99:9.17“No, Master Gotama.”

MN 99:9.18“So, student, it seems that there is not a single one of the brahmins, MN 99:9.2Austerity is the second thing. MN 99:9.20not even anyone back to the seventh generation of teachers, MN 99:9.22nor even the ancient hermits of the brahmins MN 99:9.23who says: MN 99:9.24‘We declare the result of these five things after realizing it with our own insight.’

MN 99:9.25Suppose there was a queue of blind men, each holding the one in front: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see. MN 99:9.26In the same way, it seems to me that the brahmins’ statement turns out to be comparable to a queue of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.”

MN 99:9.3Celibacy is the third thing. MN 99:9.4Recitation is the fourth thing. MN 99:9.5Generosity is the fifth thing. MN 99:9.6These are the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful. MN 99:9.7What do you say about this?”

MN 99:9.8BJ 11.718PTS-VP-PLI 2.200“Well, student, is there even a single one of the brahmins who says this: MN 99:9.9‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight’?”

MN 100:1.1BJ 11.736So I have heard. MN 100:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

MN 100:10.1BJ 11.742So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him: MN 100:10.10Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Āḷāra Kālāma says he has realized with his own insight?’ MN 100:10.11I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.

MN 100:10.12So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him, MN 100:10.13‘Reverend Kālāma, have you realized this teaching with your own insight up to this point, and declare having achieved it?’

MN 100:10.14‘I have, reverend.’

MN 100:10.15‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’

MN 100:10.16‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate MN 100:10.17to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions! MN 100:10.19The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and live having achieved it, I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it. MN 100:10.2‘Reverend Kālāma, to what extent do you say you’ve realized this teaching with your own insight?’ MN 100:10.20So the teaching that I know, you know, and the teaching you know, I know. MN 100:10.21I am like you and you are like me. MN 100:10.22Come now, reverend! We should both lead this community together.’

MN 100:10.23And that is how my teacher Āḷāra Kālāma placed me, his student, on the same position as him, and honored me with lofty praise.

MN 100:10.24Then it occurred to me, MN 100:10.25‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. MN 100:10.3When I said this, he declared the dimension of nothingness.

MN 100:11.1I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Uddaka, son of Rāma, and said to him, MN 100:11.10Surely he meditated knowing and seeing this teaching.’

MN 100:11.11So I approached Uddaka, son of Rāma, and said to him, MN 100:11.12‘Reverend, to what extent did Rāma say he’d realized this teaching with his own insight?’ MN 100:11.13When I said this, Uddaka, son of Rāma, declared the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

MN 100:11.14Then it occurred to me, MN 100:11.15‘It’s not just Rāma who had faith, MN 100:11.16energy, MN 100:11.17mindfulness, MN 100:11.18immersion, MN 100:11.19and wisdom; I too have these things. MN 100:11.2‘Reverend, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’

MN 100:11.20Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Rāma said he had realized with his own insight?’ MN 100:11.21I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.

MN 100:11.3Uddaka replied, MN 100:11.4‘Stay, venerable. MN 100:11.5This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own teacher’s doctrine with their own insight and live having achieved it.’

MN 100:11.6I quickly memorized that teaching. MN 100:11.7So far as lip-recital and oral recitation were concerned, I spoke with knowledge and the authority of the elders. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.

MN 100:11.8Then it occurred to me, MN 100:11.9‘It is not solely by mere faith that Rāma declared: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”

MN 100:12.1BJ 11.744So I approached Uddaka, son of Rāma, and said to him, MN 100:12.10Rāma was like you and you are like Rāma. MN 100:12.11Come now, reverend! MN 100:13.1I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. Traveling stage by stage in the Magadhan lands, I arrived at Senanigama near Uruvelā. MN 100:13.2There I saw a delightful park, a lovely grove with a flowing river that was clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby was a village for alms. MN 100:13.3Then it occurred to me, MN 100:13.4‘This park is truly delightful, a lovely grove with a flowing river that’s clean and charming, with smooth banks. MN 100:13.5This is good enough for a gentleman who wishes to put forth effort in meditation.’ MN 100:13.6So I sat down right there, thinking: MN 100:13.7‘This is good enough for meditation.’

MN 100:14.1And then these three examples, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me. MN 100:14.10That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

MN 100:14.11“In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. They haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening. MN 100:14.12This was the first example that occurred to me.

MN 100:14.2BJ 11.746Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying in water. MN 100:14.3Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking MN 100:14.4to light a fire and produce heat. MN 100:14.5What do you think, Bhāradvāja? MN 100:14.6By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log lying in water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

MN 100:14.7“No, Master Gotama. MN 100:14.8Why is that? MN 100:14.9Because it’s a green, sappy log, and it’s lying in the water.

MN 100:15.1Then a second example occurred to me. MN 100:15.10That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.” “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. MN 100:15.11This was the second example that occurred to me.

MN 100:15.2Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water. MN 100:16.1BJ 11.748Then a third example occurred to me.

MN 100:16.11This was the third example that occurred to me. MN 100:16.12These are the three examples, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, that occurred to me.

MN 100:16.2Suppose there was a dried up, withered log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water. MN 100:17.1Then it occurred to me, MN 100:17.2‘Why don’t I, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, squeeze, squash, and torture mind with mind.’ MN 100:17.3So that’s what I did, MN 100:17.4until sweat ran from my armpits. MN 100:17.5It was like when a strong man grabs a weaker man by the head or throat or shoulder and squeezes, squashes, and tortures them. MN 100:17.6In the same way, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, I squeezed, squashed, and tortured mind with mind until sweat ran from my armpits. MN 100:17.7My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

MN 100:18.1Then it occurred to me, MN 100:18.2‘Why don’t I practice the breathless absorption?’ MN 100:18.3So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose. MN 100:23.1Then some deities saw me and said, MN 100:23.2‘The ascetic Gotama is dead.’ MN 100:23.3Others said, MN 100:23.4‘He’s not dead, but he’s dying.’ MN 100:23.5Others said, MN 100:23.6‘He’s not dead or dying. The ascetic Gotama is a perfected one, for that is how the perfected ones live.’

MN 100:24.1Then it occurred to me, MN 100:24.10So I dismissed those deities, saying, ‘There’s no need.’

MN 100:24.2‘Why don’t I practice completely cutting off food?’

MN 100:24.3But deities came to me and said, MN 100:24.4‘Good sir, don’t practice totally cutting off food. MN 100:24.5If you do, we’ll infuse divine nectar into your pores and you will live on that.’

MN 100:24.7Then it occurred to me, MN 100:24.8‘If I claim to be completely fasting while these deities are infusing divine nectar in my pores, that would be a lie on my part.’

MN 100:25.1BJ 11.754Then it occurred to me, MN 100:25.10Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun. MN 100:25.11Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly. MN 100:25.12Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there. MN 100:25.13Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.

MN 100:25.2‘Why don’t I just take a little bit of food each time, a cup of broth made from mung beans, lentils, chickpeas, or green gram.’ MN 100:25.3So that’s what I did, MN 100:25.4until my body became extremely emaciated. MN 100:25.5Due to eating so little, my limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a corpse, MN 100:25.6my bottom became like a camel’s hoof, MN 100:25.7my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string, MN 100:25.8and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn. MN 100:25.9Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.

MN 100:26.1Then some people saw me and said: ‘The ascetic Gotama is black.’ MN 100:26.2Some said: ‘He’s not black, he’s brown.’ MN 100:26.3Some said: ‘He’s neither black nor brown. The ascetic Gotama has tawny skin.’ MN 100:26.4That’s how far the pure, bright complexion of my skin had been ruined by taking so little food.

MN 100:27.1Then it occurred to me, MN 100:27.2‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this. MN 100:27.5But I have not achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by this severe, grueling work. MN 100:27.6Could there be another path to awakening?’

MN 100:28.1Then it occurred to me, MN 100:28.2‘I recall sitting in the cool shade of the rose-apple tree while my father the Sakyan was off working. MN 100:28.3Could that be the path to awakening?’ MN 100:28.4Stemming from that memory came the realization: MN 100:28.5‘That is the path to awakening!’

MN 100:3.1Now at that time the brahmin student Saṅgārava was residing in Caṇḍalakappa. He was young, newly tonsured; he was sixteen years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies, ritual, phonology and etymology, and the testament as fifth. MN 100:3.2Hearing Dhanañjānī’s exclamation, MN 100:3.3he said to her, MN 100:3.4“The brahmin lady named Dhanañjānī is a disgrace! Though brahmins who are proficient in the three Vedas are found, she praises that shaveling, that fake ascetic.”

MN 100:3.7“Well then, ma’am, let me know when the Buddha arrives in Caṇḍalakappa.”

MN 100:30.1BJ 11.756Then it occurred to me, MN 100:30.2‘I can’t achieve that pleasure with a body so excessively emaciated. Why don’t I eat some solid food, some rice and porridge?’ MN 100:30.4So I ate some solid food.

MN 100:30.5Now at that time the five mendicants were attending on me, thinking, MN 100:30.6‘The ascetic Gotama will tell us of any truth that he realizes.’ MN 100:30.7But when I ate some solid food, they left disappointed in me, saying, MN 100:30.8‘The ascetic Gotama has become indulgent; he has strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.’

MN 100:34.1When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives. MN 100:34.2I recollected many past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

MN 100:35.1This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night. MN 100:35.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

MN 100:36-38.1When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 100:36-38.2With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. MN 100:36-38.3This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night. MN 100:36-38.4Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

MN 100:39.1BJ 11.758When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 100:39.2I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. MN 100:39.3I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

MN 100:4.1BJ 11.738And then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the Kosalan lands, arrived at Caṇḍalakappa, MN 100:4.2where he stayed in the mango grove of the Todeyya brahmins.

MN 100:40.1Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 100:40.2When it was freed, I knew it was freed.

MN 100:40.3I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 100:41.1This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night. MN 100:41.2Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.”

MN 100:42.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.213When he had spoken, Saṅgārava said to the Buddha, MN 100:42.10a sensible person would come to the definite conclusion that MN 100:42.11gods exist.”

MN 100:42.12“But why didn’t you say that in the first place?”

MN 100:42.2“Master Gotama’s effort was steadfast and appropriate for a good person, MN 100:42.3since he is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha. MN 100:42.4But Master Gotama, do gods absolutely exist?”

MN 100:42.5“I’ve understood the existence of gods in terms of causes.”

MN 100:42.7“But Master Gotama, when asked ‘Do gods exist?’ why did you say that you have understood the existence of gods in terms of causes? MN 100:42.8If that’s the case, isn’t it a hollow lie?”

MN 100:42.9“When asked ‘Do gods exist’, whether you reply ‘Gods exist’ or ‘I’ve understood it in terms of causes’

MN 100:43.1BJ 11.760When he had spoken, Saṅgārava said to the Buddha, MN 100:43.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! MN 100:43.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways. MN 100:43.4I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 100:43.5From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

MN 100:5.1Dhanañjānī heard that he had arrived. MN 100:5.2So she went to Saṅgārava and told him, adding, MN 100:5.4“Please, my little dear, go at your convenience.”

MN 100:5.5PTS-VP-PLI 2.211“Yes, ma’am,” replied Saṅgārava. He went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him. MN 100:5.6When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

MN 100:6.1“Master Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life having attained perfection and consummation of insight in the present life. MN 100:6.2Where do you stand regarding these?”

MN 100:7.1“I say there is a diversity among those who claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life having attained perfection and consummation of insight in the present life. MN 100:7.2There are some ascetics and brahmins who are oral transmitters. MN 100:7.3Through oral transmission they claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life. MN 100:7.4For example, the brahmins who are proficient in the three Vedas. MN 100:7.5There are some ascetics and brahmins who solely by mere faith claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life. MN 100:7.6For example, those who rely on logic and inquiry. MN 100:7.7There are some ascetics and brahmins who, having directly known for themselves the principle regarding teachings not learned before from another, claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life. MN 100:7.8I am one of those. MN 100:8.1And here’s a way to understand that I am one of them.

MN 100:9.1BJ 11.740PTS-VP-PLI 2.212Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought: MN 100:9.10This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own teacher’s doctrine with their own insight and live having achieved it.’

MN 100:9.11I quickly memorized that teaching. MN 100:9.12So far as lip-recital and oral recitation were concerned, I spoke with knowledge and the authority of the elders. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.

MN 100:9.13Then it occurred to me, MN 100:9.14‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.” MN 100:9.15Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’

MN 100:9.2‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open. MN 100:9.3It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell. MN 100:9.4Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’ MN 100:9.5Some time later, while still black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

MN 100:9.6Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him, MN 100:9.7‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’

MN 100:9.8Āḷāra Kālāma replied, MN 100:9.9‘Stay, venerable.
