MN 101:0.2At Devadaha

MN 101:1.1BJ 12.2PTS-VP-PLI 2.214So I have heard. MN 101:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near the Sakyan town named Devadaha. MN 101:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

MN 101:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.218When I said this, those Jain ascetics said to me, MN 101:10.2‘Reverend, the Jain leader Nāṭaputta claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus: MN 101:10.3“Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”

MN 101:10.4He says: MN 101:10.5“O reverend Jain ascetics, you have done bad deeds in a past life. Wear them away with these severe and grueling austerities. MN 101:10.6And when you refrain from such deeds in the present by way of body, speech, and mind, you’re not doing any bad deeds for the future. MN 101:10.7So, due to eliminating past deeds by mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future. MN 101:10.8With nothing to come up in the future, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.” MN 101:10.9We like and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.’

MN 101:11.1When they said this, I said to them, MN 101:11.2‘These five things can be seen to turn out in two different ways. MN 101:11.3What five? MN 101:11.4Faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, and acceptance of a view after consideration. MN 101:11.5These are the five things that can be seen to turn out in two different ways. MN 101:11.6In this case, what faith in your teacher do you have when it comes to the past? What preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration?’ MN 101:11.7When I said this, I did not see any legitimate defense of their doctrine from the Jains.

MN 101:12.1BJ 12.10PTS-VP-PLI 2.219Furthermore, I said to those Jain ascetics, MN 101:12.2‘What do you think, reverends? MN 101:12.3At a time of intense exertion and striving do you suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion? MN 101:12.4Whereas at a time without intense exertion and striving do you not suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?’

MN 101:12.5‘Reverend Gotama, at a time of intense exertion we suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion, MN 101:12.6not without intense exertion.’

MN 101:13.1‘So it seems that only at a time of intense exertion do you suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion, MN 101:13.2not without intense exertion. MN 101:13.3In that case, it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare: MN 101:13.4“Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. …”

MN 101:14.1If at a time of intense exertion you did not suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion, MN 101:14.2and if without intense exertion you did experience such feelings, MN 101:14.3it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.

MN 101:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.220But since this is not the case, MN 101:15.3aren’t you experiencing painful, sharp feelings due only to your own exertion, which out of ignorance, unknowing, and confusion you misconstrue to imply: MN 101:15.4“Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. …”?’ MN 101:15.7When I said this, I did not see any legitimate defense of their doctrine from the Jains.

MN 101:16.1Furthermore, I said to those Jain ascetics, MN 101:16.2‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced in this life, can exertion make it be experienced in lives to come?’

MN 101:16.3‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:16.4BJ 12.12‘But if a deed is to be experienced in lives to come, can exertion make it be experienced in this life?’

MN 101:16.5‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:17.1‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced as pleasure, can exertion make it be experienced as pain?’

MN 101:17.2‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:17.3‘But if a deed is to be experienced as pain, can exertion make it be experienced as pleasure?’

MN 101:17.4‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:18.1‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced when fully ripened, can exertion make it be experienced when not fully ripened?’

MN 101:18.2‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:18.3‘But if a deed is to be experienced when not fully ripened, can exertion make it be experienced when fully ripened?’

MN 101:18.4‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.221‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced strongly, can exertion make it be experienced weakly?’

MN 101:19.2‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:19.3‘But if a deed is to be experienced weakly, can exertion make it be experienced strongly?’

MN 101:19.4‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:2.1“Mendicants!”

MN 101:2.2“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 101:2.3The Buddha said this:

MN 101:2.4“Mendicants, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: MN 101:2.5‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. MN 101:2.6So, due to eliminating past deeds by mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future. MN 101:2.7With nothing to come up in the future, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.’ MN 101:2.8Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.

MN 101:20.1‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced, can exertion make it not be experienced?’

MN 101:20.2‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:20.3‘But if a deed is not to be experienced, can exertion make it be experienced?’

MN 101:20.4‘No, reverend.’

MN 101:21.1BJ 12.14PTS-VP-PLI 2.222‘So it seems that exertion cannot change the way deeds are experienced in any of these ways. MN 101:21.2This being so, your exertion and striving are fruitless.’

MN 101:22.1Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics. MN 101:22.10clearly the Jains have been reborn in a bad class, since they now experience such intense pain. MN 101:22.11If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in the present, MN 101:22.12clearly the Jains exert themselves badly in the present, since they now experience such intense pain.

MN 101:22.13BJ 12.16PTS-VP-PLI 2.223The Jains deserve criticism whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds, MN 101:22.15or the Lord God’s creation, MN 101:22.17or circumstance and nature, MN 101:22.19or class of rebirth, MN 101:22.2Saying this, the Jain ascetics deserve rebuke and criticism on ten legitimate grounds.

MN 101:22.21or exertion in the present. MN 101:22.23Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics. MN 101:22.24The Jain ascetics who say this deserve rebuke and criticism on these ten legitimate grounds. MN 101:22.25That’s how exertion and striving is fruitless.

MN 101:22.3If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds, MN 101:22.4clearly the Jains have done bad deeds in the past, since they now experience such intense pain. MN 101:22.5If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the Lord God’s creation, MN 101:22.6clearly the Jains were created by a bad God, since they now experience such intense pain. MN 101:22.7If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature, MN 101:22.8clearly the Jains arise from bad circumstances, since they now experience such intense pain. MN 101:22.9If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth,

MN 101:23.1And how is exertion and striving fruitful? MN 101:23.10and so that suffering is worn away.

MN 101:23.2It’s when a mendicant doesn’t bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t give up legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure. MN 101:23.3They understand: MN 101:23.4‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’ MN 101:23.5So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate. MN 101:23.7Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering, MN 101:23.8and so that suffering is worn away. MN 101:23.9Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering,

MN 101:24.1BJ 12.18PTS-VP-PLI 2.224Suppose a man is in love with a woman, full of intense desire and lust. MN 101:24.2Then he sees her standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing.

MN 101:24.3What do you think, mendicants? MN 101:24.4Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?”

MN 101:24.5“Yes, sir. MN 101:24.6Why is that? MN 101:24.7Because that man is in love that woman, full of intense desire and lust.”

MN 101:25.1“Then that man might think: MN 101:25.10Why is that? MN 101:25.11Because he no longer desires that woman.” MN 101:25.2‘I’m in love with that woman, full of intense desire and lust. MN 101:25.3When I saw her standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing, it gave rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for me. MN 101:25.4Why don’t I give up that desire and lust for that woman?’ MN 101:25.5So that’s what he did. MN 101:25.6Some time later he sees her again standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing.

MN 101:25.7What do you think, mendicants? MN 101:25.8Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?”

MN 101:25.9“No, sir.

MN 101:26.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.225“In the same way, a mendicant doesn’t bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t give up legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure. MN 101:26.10That’s how exertion and striving is fruitful.

MN 101:26.2They understand: MN 101:26.3‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’ MN 101:26.4So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate. MN 101:26.6Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering, MN 101:26.7and so that suffering is worn away. MN 101:26.8Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering, MN 101:26.9and so that suffering is worn away.

MN 101:27.1Furthermore, a mendicant reflects: MN 101:27.2‘When I live as I please, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. MN 101:27.3But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. MN 101:27.4Why don’t I strive painfully?’ MN 101:27.5So that’s what they do, MN 101:27.6and as they do so unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. MN 101:27.7After some time, they no longer strive painfully. MN 101:27.8Why is that? MN 101:27.9Because they have accomplished the goal for which they strived painfully.

MN 101:28.1BJ 12.20PTS-VP-PLI 2.226Suppose an arrowsmith was heating an arrow shaft between two firebrands, making it straight and fit for use. MN 101:29.1After it’s been made straight and fit for use, they’d no longer heat it to make it straight and fit for use. MN 101:29.14After some time, they no longer strive painfully. MN 101:29.15That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

MN 101:29.2Why is that? MN 101:29.3Because they have accomplished the goal for which they heated it.

MN 101:29.5In the same way, a mendicant reflects: MN 101:29.6‘When I live as I please, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. MN 101:29.7But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. MN 101:29.8Why don’t I strive painfully?’ …

MN 101:3.1I’ve gone up to the Jain ascetics who say this and said, MN 101:3.2‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’ MN 101:3.6They admitted that it is.

MN 101:30.1Furthermore, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. MN 101:30.2He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. MN 101:30.3He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

MN 101:31.1A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some clan. MN 101:31.2They gain faith in the Realized One, MN 101:31.3and reflect: MN 101:31.4‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open. MN 101:31.5It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell. MN 101:31.6Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’ MN 101:31.7After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

MN 101:32.1BJ 12.22Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings. MN 101:32.10They avoid dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows. MN 101:32.11They avoid beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, perfumes, and makeup. MN 101:32.12They avoid high and luxurious beds. MN 101:32.13They avoid receiving gold and money, MN 101:32.14raw grains, MN 101:32.15raw meat, MN 101:32.16women and girls, MN 101:32.17male and female bondservants, MN 101:32.18goats and sheep, MN 101:32.19chickens and pigs, MN 101:32.2They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving. MN 101:32.20elephants, cows, horses, and mares, MN 101:32.21and fields and land. MN 101:32.22They avoid running errands and messages; MN 101:32.23buying and selling; MN 101:32.24falsifying weights, metals, or measures; MN 101:32.25bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; MN 101:32.26mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

MN 101:32.3They give up unchastity. They are celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex. MN 101:32.4They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words. MN 101:32.5They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony. MN 101:32.6They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people. MN 101:32.7They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial. MN 101:32.8They avoid injuring plants and seeds. MN 101:32.9They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.

MN 101:33.1They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things. MN 101:33.2They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden. MN 101:33.3In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things. MN 101:33.4When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

MN 101:34.1When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 101:34.2If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint. MN 101:34.3When they hear a sound with their ears … MN 101:34.4When they smell an odor with their nose … MN 101:34.5When they taste a flavor with their tongue … MN 101:34.6When they feel a touch with their body … MN 101:34.7When they know a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 101:34.8If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint. MN 101:34.9When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.

MN 101:35.1They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

MN 101:36.1BJ 12.24When they have this noble spectrum of ethics, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, MN 101:36.2they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw. MN 101:36.3After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there.

MN 101:37.1Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire. MN 101:37.2Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will. MN 101:37.3Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness. MN 101:37.4Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse. MN 101:37.5Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

MN 101:38.1They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. MN 101:38.2Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 101:38.3That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

MN 101:39.1Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 101:39.2That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

MN 101:40.1Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 101:40.2That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

MN 101:41.1Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 101:41.2That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

MN 101:42.1When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives. MN 101:42.2They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. MN 101:42.3That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

MN 101:43.1BJ 12.26When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings. MN 101:43.2With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds. MN 101:43.3That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

MN 101:44.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.227When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 101:44.2They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. MN 101:44.3They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

MN 101:45.1Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 101:45.2When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

MN 101:45.3They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’ MN 101:45.4That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful. MN 101:46.1Such is the doctrine of the Realized One. MN 101:46.10clearly the Realized One was reborn in a good class, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure. MN 101:46.11If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in the present, MN 101:46.12clearly the Realized One exerts himself well in the present, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.

MN 101:46.13BJ 12.28PTS-VP-PLI 2.228The Realized One deserves praise whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds, MN 101:46.15or the Lord God’s creation, MN 101:46.17or circumstance and nature, MN 101:46.19or class of rebirth, MN 101:46.2Saying this, the Realized One deserves praise on ten legitimate grounds.

MN 101:46.22or exertion in the present. MN 101:46.23Such is the doctrine of the Realized One. MN 101:46.24Saying this, the Realized One deserves praise on these ten legitimate grounds.”

MN 101:46.25That is what the Buddha said. MN 101:46.26Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 101:46.3If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds, MN 101:46.4clearly the Realized One has done good deeds in the past, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure. MN 101:46.5If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the Lord God’s creation, MN 101:46.6clearly the Realized One was created by a good God, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure. MN 101:46.7If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature, MN 101:46.8clearly the Realized One arises from good circumstances, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure. MN 101:46.9If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth,

MN 101:5.1‘So it seems that you don’t know any of these things. MN 101:5.7In that case, it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.

MN 101:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.216Now, supposing you did know these things. MN 101:6.7In that case, it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.

MN 101:7.1BJ 12.6PTS-VP-PLI 2.217Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison, MN 101:7.10They’d apply cauterizing medicine to the wound, MN 101:7.11causing painful feelings, sharp and severe. MN 101:7.12After some time that wound would be healed and the skin regrown. They’d be healthy, happy, autonomous, master of themselves, able to go where they wanted.

MN 101:7.13They’d think, MN 101:7.14“Earlier I was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison, MN 101:7.15causing painful feelings, sharp and severe. MN 101:7.16My friends and colleagues, relatives and kin got a field surgeon to treat me. MN 101:7.17At each step, the treatment was painful. MN 101:7.2causing painful feelings, sharp and severe. MN 101:7.25But these days that wound is healed and the skin regrown. I’m healthy, happy, autonomous, my own master, able to go where I want.”

MN 101:7.3Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a field surgeon to treat them. MN 101:7.4The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel, MN 101:7.5causing painful feelings, sharp and severe. MN 101:7.6They’d probe for the arrow, MN 101:7.7causing painful feelings, sharp and severe. MN 101:7.8They’d extract the arrow, MN 101:7.9causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.

MN 101:8.1In the same way, reverends, if you knew about these things, MN 101:8.7it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.

MN 101:9.1BJ 12.8But since you don’t know any of these things, MN 101:9.7it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.’

MN 102:0.2The Five and Three

MN 102:1.1BJ 12.30So I have heard. MN 102:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 102:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 102:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 102:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 102:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 102:10.1The Realized One understands this as follows. MN 102:10.2There are ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is neither percipient nor non-percipient and well after death, describing it as having form, or being formless, or both having form and being formless, or neither having form nor being formless. MN 102:10.3Some ascetics or brahmins assert the embracing of that dimension merely through the conditioned phenomena of what is seen, heard, thought, and known. But that is said to be a disastrous approach. MN 102:10.4For that dimension is said to be not attainable by means of conditioned phenomena, MN 102:10.5but only with a residue of conditioned phenomena. MN 102:10.6‘All that is conditioned and coarse. But there is the cessation of conditions—that is real.’ MN 102:10.7Understanding this and seeing the escape from it, the Realized One has gone beyond all that.

MN 102:11.1BJ 12.36PTS-VP-PLI 2.233Now, the ascetics and brahmins who assert the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of an existing being reject those who assert a self that is well after death, whether percipient or non-percipient or neither percipient non-percipient. MN 102:11.2Why is that? MN 102:11.3Because all of those ascetics and brahmins only assert their attachment to heading upstream: MN 102:11.4‘After death we shall be like this! After death we shall be like that!’

MN 102:12.1Suppose a trader was going to market, thinking: MN 102:12.10Understanding this and seeing the escape from it, the Realized One has gone beyond all that.

MN 102:12.2‘With this, that shall be mine! This way, I shall get that!’ MN 102:12.3In the same way, those ascetics and brahmins seem to be like traders when they say: MN 102:12.4‘After death we shall be like this! After death we shall be like that!’ MN 102:12.5The Realized One understands this as follows. MN 102:12.6The ascetics and brahmins who assert the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of an existing being; from fear and disgust with identity, they just keep running and circling around identity. MN 102:12.7Suppose a dog on a leash was tethered to a strong post or pillar. It would just keeping running and circling around that post or pillar. MN 102:12.8In the same way, those ascetics and brahmins, from fear and disgust with identity, just keep running and circling around identity. MN 102:12.9‘All that is conditioned and coarse. But there is the cessation of conditions—that is real.’

MN 102:13.1Whatever ascetics and brahmins theorize about the future, and propose various hypotheses concerning the future, all of them propose one or other of these five theses.

MN 102:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.234There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the past, and propose various hypotheses concerning the past. They propose the following, each insisting that theirs is the only truth and that everything else is wrong. MN 102:14.10‘The self and the cosmos are unified in perception.’ MN 102:14.11‘The self and the cosmos are diverse in perception.’ MN 102:14.12‘The self and the cosmos have limited perception.’ MN 102:14.13‘The self and the cosmos have limitless perception.’ MN 102:14.14‘The self and the cosmos experience nothing but happiness.’ MN 102:14.15‘The self and the cosmos experience nothing but suffering.’ MN 102:14.16‘The self and the cosmos experience both happiness and suffering.’ MN 102:14.17‘The self and the cosmos experience neither happiness nor suffering.’ MN 102:14.2‘The self and the cosmos are eternal.’ MN 102:14.3‘The self and the cosmos are not eternal.’ MN 102:14.4‘The self and the cosmos are both eternal and not eternal.’ MN 102:14.5‘The self and the cosmos are neither eternal nor not eternal.’ MN 102:14.6‘The self and the cosmos are finite.’ MN 102:14.7‘The self and the cosmos are infinite.’ MN 102:14.8‘The self and the cosmos are both finite and infinite.’ MN 102:14.9‘The self and the cosmos are neither finite nor infinite.’

MN 102:15.1BJ 12.38Now, consider the ascetics and brahmins whose view is as follows. MN 102:15.2‘The self and the cosmos are eternal. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’ It’s simply not possible for them to have purified and clear personal knowledge of this, apart from faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration. MN 102:15.3And in the absence of such knowledge, even the partial knowledge that they are clear about is said to be grasping on their part. MN 102:15.4‘All that is conditioned and coarse. But there is the cessation of conditions—that is real.’ MN 102:15.5Understanding this and seeing the escape from it, the Realized One has gone beyond all that.

MN 102:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.235Now, consider the ascetics and brahmins whose view is as follows. MN 102:16.10or of diverse perception, MN 102:16.11or of limited perception, MN 102:16.12or of limitless perception, MN 102:16.13or experience nothing but happiness, MN 102:16.14or experience nothing but suffering, MN 102:16.15or experience both happiness and suffering, MN 102:16.16or experience neither happiness nor suffering. It’s simply not possible for them to have purified and clear personal knowledge of this, apart from faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration. MN 102:16.17And in the absence of such knowledge, even the partial knowledge that they are clear about is said to be grasping on their part. MN 102:16.18‘All that is conditioned and coarse. But there is the cessation of conditions—that is real.’ MN 102:16.19Understanding this and seeing the escape from it, the Realized One has gone beyond all that.

MN 102:16.2The self and the cosmos are not eternal, MN 102:16.3or both eternal and not eternal, MN 102:16.4or neither eternal nor not-eternal, MN 102:16.5or finite, MN 102:16.6or infinite, MN 102:16.7or both finite and infinite, MN 102:16.8or neither finite nor infinite, MN 102:16.9or of unified perception,

MN 102:17.1BJ 12.40Now, some ascetics and brahmins, letting go of theories about the past and the future, shedding the fetters of sensuality, enter and remain in the rapture of seclusion: MN 102:17.2‘This is peaceful, this is sublime, that is, entering and remaining in the rapture of seclusion.’ MN 102:17.3But that rapture of seclusion of theirs ceases. MN 102:17.4When the rapture of seclusion ceases, sadness arises; and when sadness ceases, the rapture of seclusion arises.

MN 102:18.1It’s like how the sunlight fills the space when the shadow leaves, or the shadow fills the space when the sunshine leaves. MN 102:18.2In the same way, when the rapture of seclusion ceases, sadness arises; and when sadness ceases, the rapture of seclusion arises. MN 102:18.3The Realized One understands this as follows. MN 102:18.4This good ascetic or brahmin, letting go of theories about the past and the future, shedding the fetters of sensuality, enters and remains in the rapture of seclusion: MN 102:18.5‘This is peaceful, this is sublime, that is, entering and remaining in the rapture of seclusion.’ MN 102:18.6But that rapture of seclusion of theirs ceases. MN 102:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.236Now, some ascetics and brahmins, letting go of theories about the past and the future, shedding the fetters of sensuality, going beyond the rapture of seclusion, enter and remain in spiritual bliss. MN 102:19.4When spiritual bliss ceases, the rapture of seclusion arises; and when the rapture of seclusion ceases, spiritual bliss arises.

MN 102:2.1“Mendicants, there are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the future, and assert various hypotheses concerning the future. MN 102:2.10In this way five become three, and three become five. MN 102:2.11This is the passage for recitation of the five and three.

MN 102:2.2Some propose this: ‘The self is percipient and is well after death.’ MN 102:2.4Some propose this: ‘The self is non-percipient and is well after death.’ MN 102:2.6Some propose this: ‘The self is neither percipient nor non-percipient and is well after death.’ MN 102:2.8But some assert the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of an existing being, while others propose extinguishment in the present life. MN 102:23.1BJ 12.42Now, some ascetics and brahmins, letting go of theories about the past and the future, shedding the fetters of sensuality, go beyond the rapture of seclusion, spiritual bliss, and neutral feeling. MN 102:25.1But the Realized One has awakened to the supreme state of sublime peace, that is, MN 102:25.2liberation by not grasping after truly understanding these six sense fields’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.”

MN 102:3.1BJ 12.32PTS-VP-PLI 2.229Now, the ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is percipient and well after death describe it as having form, or being formless, or both having form and being formless, or neither having form nor being formless. Or they describe it as of unified perception, or of diverse perception, or of limited perception, or of limitless perception. MN 102:4.1The Realized One understands this as follows. MN 102:4.2There are ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is percipient and well after death, describing it as having form, or being formless, or both having form and being formless, or neither having form nor being formless. MN 102:4.4Or some, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, propose the dimension of nothingness, limitless and imperturbable. MN 102:4.5‘All that is conditioned and coarse. MN 102:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.231Now, the ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is non-percipient and well after death describe it as having form, or being formless, or both having form and being formless, or neither having form nor being formless.

MN 102:6.1So they reject those who assert a self that is percipient and well after death. MN 102:6.2Why is that? MN 102:6.3Because they believe that perception is a disease, a boil, a dart, and that the state of non-perception is peaceful and sublime.

MN 102:7.1The Realized One understands this as follows. MN 102:7.2There are ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is non-percipient and well after death, describing it as having form, or being formless, or both having form and being formless, or neither having form nor being formless. MN 102:7.6‘All that is conditioned and coarse. MN 102:8.1BJ 12.34PTS-VP-PLI 2.232Now, the ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is neither percipient nor non-percipient and well after death describe it as having form, or being formless, or both having form and being formless, or neither having form nor being formless.

MN 103:0.2Is This What You Think Of Me?

MN 103:1.1BJ 12.44So I have heard. MN 103:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusināra, in the Forest of Offerings. MN 103:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 103:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 103:10.1In such a case, you should not be in a hurry to accuse them. The individual should be examined like this: MN 103:10.2‘I won’t be troubled and the other individual won’t be hurt, for they’re not irritable and hostile. They don’t hold fast to their views, but let them go easily. I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’ MN 103:10.3If that’s what you think, then it’s appropriate to speak to them.

MN 103:11.1But suppose you think this: MN 103:11.2‘I will be troubled and the other individual will be hurt, for they’re irritable and hostile. MN 103:11.3But for the other individual to get hurt is a minor matter. MN 103:11.4It’s more important MN 103:11.5that I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’ MN 103:11.6If that’s what you think, then it’s appropriate to speak to them.

MN 103:12.3But for me to be troubled is a minor matter. MN 104:1.1BJ 12.52PTS-VP-PLI 2.244So I have heard. MN 104:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying among the Sakyans near the village of Sāma.

MN 104:12.1There are four kinds of disciplinary issues. MN 104:12.2What four? MN 104:12.3Disciplinary issues due to disputes, accusations, offenses, or proceedings. MN 104:12.4These are the four kinds of disciplinary issues. MN 104:13.1There are seven methods for the settlement of any disciplinary issues that might arise. MN 104:13.2Removal in the presence of those concerned is applicable. Removal by accurate recollection is applicable. Removal due to recovery from madness is applicable. The offense should be acknowledged. The decision of a majority. A verdict of aggravated misconduct. Covering over with grass.

MN 104:14.1And how is there removal in the presence of those concerned? MN 104:14.2It’s when mendicants are disputing: ‘This is the teaching,’ ‘This is not the teaching,’ ‘This is the monastic law,’ ‘This is not the monastic law.’ MN 104:14.3Those mendicants should all sit together in harmony MN 104:14.4and thoroughly go over the guidelines of the teaching. MN 104:14.5They should settle that disciplinary issue in agreement with the guidelines. MN 104:14.6That’s how there is removal in the presence of those concerned. MN 104:14.7And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is, MN 104:14.8by removal in the presence of those concerned.

MN 104:15.1And how is there the decision of a majority? MN 104:15.2If those mendicants are not able to settle that issue in that monastery, MN 104:15.3they should go to another monastery with more mendicants. MN 104:15.4There they should all sit together in harmony MN 104:15.5and thoroughly go over the guidelines of the teaching. MN 104:15.6They should settle that disciplinary issue in agreement with the guidelines. MN 104:15.7That’s how there is the decision of a majority. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is, MN 104:15.8by decision of a majority.

MN 104:16.1BJ 12.58PTS-VP-PLI 2.248And how is there removal by accurate recollection? MN 104:16.2It’s when mendicants accuse a mendicant of a serious offense; one entailing expulsion, or close to it: MN 104:16.3‘Venerable, do you recall committing the kind of serious offense that entails expulsion or close to it?’ MN 104:16.4They say: MN 104:16.5‘No, reverends, I don’t recall committing such an offense.’ MN 104:16.6The removal by accurate recollection is applicable to them. MN 104:16.7That’s how there is the removal by accurate recollection. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is, MN 104:16.8by removal by accurate recollection.

MN 104:17.1And how is there removal by recovery from madness? MN 104:17.10And while I was mad I did and said many things that are not proper for an ascetic. MN 104:17.11I don’t remember any of that, MN 104:17.12I was mad when I did it.’ MN 104:17.13The removal by recovery from madness is applicable to them. MN 104:17.14That’s how there is the removal by recovery from madness. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is, MN 104:17.15by recovery from madness.

MN 104:17.2It’s when mendicants accuse a mendicant of the kind of serious offense that entails expulsion, or close to it: MN 104:17.3‘Venerable, do you recall committing the kind of serious offense that entails expulsion or close to it?’ MN 104:17.4They say: MN 104:17.5‘No, reverends, I don’t recall committing such an offense.’ MN 104:17.6But though they try to get out of it, the mendicants pursue the issue: MN 104:17.7‘Surely the venerable must know perfectly well if you recall committing an offense that entails expulsion or close to it!’ MN 104:17.8They say: MN 104:17.9‘Reverends, I had gone mad, I was out of my mind.

MN 104:18.1And how is there the acknowledging of an offense? MN 104:18.10That’s how there is the acknowledging of an offense. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is, MN 104:18.11by acknowledging an offense.

MN 104:18.2It’s when a mendicant, whether accused or not, recalls an offense and clarifies it and reveals it. MN 104:18.3After approaching a more senior mendicant, that mendicant should arrange his robe over one shoulder, bow to that mendicant’s feet, squat on their heels, raise their joined palms, and say: MN 104:18.4‘Sir, I have fallen into such-and-such an offense. MN 104:19.1BJ 12.60PTS-VP-PLI 2.249And how is there a verdict of aggravated misconduct? MN 104:19.10But I do recall committing a light offense.’ MN 104:19.11But though they try to get out of it, the mendicants pursue the issue: MN 104:19.12‘Surely the venerable must know perfectly well if you recall committing an offense that entails expulsion or close to it!’ MN 104:19.13They say: MN 104:19.14‘Reverends, I’ll go so far as to acknowledge this light offense even when not asked. MN 104:19.15Why wouldn’t I acknowledge a serious offense when asked?’ MN 104:19.16They say: MN 104:19.17‘You wouldn’t have acknowledged that light offense without being asked, so why would you acknowledge a serious offense? MN 104:2.1Now at that time the Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta had recently passed away at Pāvā. MN 104:2.2With his passing the Jain ascetics split, dividing into two factions, arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words: MN 104:2.3“You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!” MN 104:2.4You’d think there was nothing but slaughter going on among the Jain ascetics. MN 104:2.5And the Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta’s white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics. They were equally disappointed with a teaching and training so poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha, with broken monument and without a refuge.

MN 104:20.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.250And how is there the covering over with grass? MN 104:21.1Ānanda, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling. MN 104:21.10This too is a warm-hearted quality.

MN 104:21.11Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. MN 104:21.13Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. MN 104:21.14This too is a warm-hearted quality.

MN 106:0.2Conducive to the Imperturbable

MN 106:1.1BJ 12.82So I have heard. MN 106:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma. MN 106:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 106:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 106:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 106:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 106:10.1BJ 12.88PTS-VP-PLI 2.265When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha: MN 106:10.10In this way they gain equanimity. MN 106:10.11They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to that equanimity. MN 106:10.12Their consciousness relies on that and grasps it. MN 106:10.13A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.”

MN 106:10.2“Sir, take a mendicant who practices like this: MN 106:10.3‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’ MN 106:10.4In this way they gain equanimity. MN 106:10.5Would that mendicant become extinguished or not?”

MN 106:10.6“One such mendicant might become extinguished, Ānanda, while another might not.”

MN 106:10.7“What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for this?”

MN 106:10.8“Ānanda, take a mendicant who practices like this: MN 106:10.9‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’

MN 106:11.1“But sir, what is that mendicant grasping?”

MN 106:11.2“The dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”

MN 106:11.3“Sir, it seems that mendicant is grasping the best thing to grasp!”

MN 106:11.4“Indeed, Ānanda. MN 106:11.5For the best thing to grasp is MN 106:11.6the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

MN 106:12.1Take a mendicant who practices like this: MN 106:12.2‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’ MN 106:12.3In this way they gain equanimity. MN 106:12.4They don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to that equanimity. MN 106:12.5So their consciousness doesn’t rely on that and grasp it. MN 106:12.6A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.”

MN 106:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.266“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! MN 106:13.10that is identity as far as identity extends. MN 106:13.11This is the deathless, namely the liberation of the mind through not grasping.

MN 106:13.2The Buddha has explained to us how to cross over the flood by relying on one support or the other. MN 106:13.3But sir, what is noble liberation?”

MN 106:13.4“Ananda, it’s when a mendicant reflects like this: MN 106:13.5‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:13.6sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:13.7visions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:13.8perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:13.9perceptions of the imperturbable, perceptions of the dimension of nothingness, perceptions of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception;

MN 106:14.1So, Ānanda, I have taught the ways of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable, the dimension of nothingness, and the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. I have taught how to cross the flood by relying on one support or the other, and I have taught noble liberation.

MN 106:15.1Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples. MN 106:15.2Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Ānanda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”

MN 106:15.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 106:15.4Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 106:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.262“Mendicants, sensual pleasures are impermanent, hollow, false, and deceptive, MN 106:2.2made by illusion, cooed over by fools. MN 106:2.3Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:2.4sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come; MN 106:2.5both of these are Māra’s domain, Māra’s realm, and Māra’s territory. MN 106:2.6They conduce to bad, unskillful qualities such as desire, ill will, and aggression. MN 106:2.7And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here.

MN 106:3.1A noble disciple reflects on this:

MN 106:3.10Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension. MN 106:3.11Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom. MN 106:3.12When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that the consciousness headed that way will be reborn in the imperturbable. MN 106:3.13This is said to be the first way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.

MN 106:3.2‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:3.3sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come; MN 106:3.4both of these are Māra’s domain, Māra’s realm, and Māra’s territory. MN 106:3.5They conduce to bad, unskillful qualities such as desire, ill will, and aggression. MN 106:3.6And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here. MN 106:3.7Why don’t I meditate with an abundant, expansive heart, having mastered the world and stabilized the mind? MN 106:3.8Then I will have no more bad, unskillful qualities such as desire, ill will, and aggression. MN 106:3.9And by giving them up my mind, no longer limited, will become limitless and well developed.’

MN 106:4.1BJ 12.84Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects: MN 106:4.2‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:4.3sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come; MN 106:4.4whatever is form, all form is the four primary elements, or form derived from the four primary elements.’ MN 106:4.5Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension. MN 106:4.6Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom. MN 106:4.7When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that the consciousness headed that way will be reborn in the imperturbable. MN 106:4.8This is said to be the second way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.

MN 106:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 2.263Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects: MN 106:5.10When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that the consciousness headed that way will be reborn in the imperturbable. MN 106:5.11This is said to be the third way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.

MN 106:5.2‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:5.3sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:5.4visions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:5.5perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come; MN 106:5.6all of these are impermanent. MN 106:5.7And what’s impermanent is not worth approving, welcoming, or clinging to.’ MN 106:5.8Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension. MN 106:5.9Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom.

MN 106:6.1Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects: MN 106:6.10Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension. MN 106:6.11Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom. MN 106:6.12When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that the consciousness headed that way will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness. MN 106:6.13This is said to be the first way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.

MN 106:6.2‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:6.3sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:6.4visions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:6.5perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:6.6and perceptions of the imperturbable; MN 106:6.7all are perceptions. MN 106:6.8Where they cease without anything left over, that is peaceful, that is sublime, MN 106:6.9namely the dimension of nothingness.’

MN 106:7.1Furthermore, a noble disciple has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this: MN 106:7.2‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’ MN 106:7.3Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension. MN 106:7.4Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom. MN 106:7.5When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that the consciousness headed that way will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness. MN 106:7.6This is said to be the second way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.

MN 106:8.1BJ 12.86PTS-VP-PLI 2.264Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects: MN 106:8.2‘I don’t belong to anyone anywhere! And nothing belongs to me anywhere!’ MN 106:8.3Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension. MN 106:8.4Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom. MN 106:8.5When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that the consciousness headed that way will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness. MN 106:8.6This is said to be the third way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.

MN 106:9.1Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects: MN 106:9.10Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension. MN 106:9.11Being confident, they either attain the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception now, or are freed by wisdom. MN 106:9.12When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that the consciousness headed that way will be reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 106:9.13This is said to be the way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”

MN 106:9.2‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:9.3sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:9.4visions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:9.5perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come, MN 106:9.6perceptions of the imperturbable, and perceptions of the dimension of nothingness; MN 106:9.7all are perceptions. MN 106:9.8Where they cease without anything left over, that is peaceful, that is sublime, MN 106:9.9namely the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

MN 107:0.2With Moggallāna the Accountant

MN 107:1.1BJ 12.90PTS-VP-PLI 3.1So I have heard. MN 107:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother. MN 107:1.3Then the brahmin Moggallāna the Accountant went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 107:1.4When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

MN 107:10.1BJ 12.94PTS-VP-PLI 3.4They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. MN 107:10.2Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 107:10.3As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 107:10.4And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 107:10.5Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

MN 107:11.1That’s how I instruct the mendicants who are trainees—who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary. MN 107:11.2But for those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and are rightly freed through enlightenment—these things lead to blissful meditation in the present life, and to mindfulness and awareness.”

MN 107:12.1When he had spoken, Moggallāna the Accountant said to the Buddha, MN 107:12.2“When his disciples are instructed and advised like this by Master Gotama, do all of them achieve the ultimate goal, extinguishment, or do some of them fail?”

MN 107:12.3“Some succeed, while others fail.”

MN 107:13.1“What is the cause, Master Gotama, what is the reason why, though extinguishment is present, the path leading to extinguishment is present, and Master Gotama is present to encourage them, MN 107:13.2still some succeed while others fail?”

MN 107:14.1BJ 12.96PTS-VP-PLI 3.5“Well then, brahmin, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like. MN 107:14.10Then you’d say to them: MN 107:14.11‘Here, mister, this road goes to Rājagaha. MN 107:14.12Go along it for a while, and you’ll see a certain village. Go along a while further, and you’ll see a certain town. MN 107:14.13Go along a while further and you’ll see Rājagaha with its delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds.’ MN 107:14.14Instructed like this by you, they might still take the wrong road, heading west. MN 107:14.15But a second person might come with the same question and receive the same instructions. MN 107:14.2What do you think, brahmin? MN 107:14.24Instructed by you, they might safely arrive at Rājagaha. MN 107:14.25What is the cause, brahmin, what is the reason why, though Rājagaha is present, the path leading to Rājagaha is present, and you are there to encourage them, MN 107:14.26one person takes the wrong path and heads west, while another arrives safely at Rājagaha?”

MN 107:14.27“What can I do about that, Master Gotama? MN 107:14.28I am the one who shows the way.”

MN 107:14.29“In the same way, though extinguishment is present, the path leading to extinguishment is present, and I am present to encourage them, MN 107:14.3Are you skilled in the road to Rājagaha?”

MN 107:14.30still some of my disciples, instructed and advised like this, achieve the ultimate goal, extinguishment, while some of them fail. MN 107:14.31What can I do about that, brahmin? MN 107:14.32The Realized One is the one who shows the way.”

MN 107:14.4“Yes, I am.”

MN 107:14.5“What do you think, brahmin? MN 107:14.6Suppose a person was to come along who wanted to go to Rājagaha. MN 107:14.7He’d approach you and say: MN 107:14.8‘Sir, I wish to go to Rājagaha. MN 107:14.9Please point out the road to Rājagaha.’

MN 107:15.1When he had spoken, Moggallāna the Accountant said to the Buddha, MN 107:15.2“Master Gotama, there are those faithless people who went forth from the lay life to homelessness not out of faith but to earn a livelihood. They’re devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They do not guard their sense doors or eat in moderation, and they are not committed to wakefulness. They don’t care about the ascetic life, and don’t keenly respect the training. They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, lazy, and lacking energy. They’re unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds, witless and stupid. Master Gotama doesn’t live together with these.

MN 107:15.3But there are those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith. They’re not devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re not restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They guard their sense doors and eat in moderation, and they are committed to wakefulness. They care about the ascetic life, and keenly respect the training. They’re not indulgent or slack, nor are they leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. They’re energetic and determined. They’re mindful, with situational awareness, immersion, and unified minds; wise, not stupid. Master Gotama does live together with these.

MN 107:16.1BJ 12.98PTS-VP-PLI 3.7Of all kinds of fragrant root, spikenard is said to be the best. MN 107:16.2Of all kinds of fragrant heartwood, red sandalwood is said to be the best. MN 107:16.3Of all kinds of fragrant flower, jasmine is said to be the best. MN 107:16.4In the same way, Master Gotama’s advice is the best of contemporary teachings.

MN 107:17.1Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! MN 107:17.2As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways. MN 107:17.3I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 107:17.4From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

MN 107:2.1“Master Gotama, in this stilt longhouse we can see gradual progress MN 107:2.10‘One one, two twos, three threes, four fours, five fives, six sixes, seven sevens, eight eights, nine nines, ten tens.’ MN 107:2.11We even make them count up to a hundred. MN 107:2.12Is it possible to similarly describe a gradual training, gradual progress, and gradual practice in this teaching and training?”

MN 107:2.2down to the last step of the staircase. MN 107:2.3Among the brahmins we can see gradual progress MN 107:2.4in learning the chants. MN 107:2.5Among archers we can see gradual progress MN 107:2.6in archery. MN 107:2.7Among us accountants, who earn a living by accounting, we can see gradual progress MN 107:2.8in mathematics. MN 107:2.9For when we get an apprentice we first make them count:

MN 107:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.2“It is possible, brahmin. MN 107:3.2Suppose a deft horse trainer were to obtain a fine thoroughbred. First of all he’d make it get used to wearing the bit. MN 107:3.3In the same way, when the Realized One gets a person for training they first guide them like this: MN 107:3.4‘Come, mendicant, be ethical and restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourself well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.’

MN 107:4.1When they have ethical conduct, the Realized One guides them further: MN 107:4.2‘Come, mendicant, guard your sense doors. When you see a sight with your eyes, don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 107:4.3If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, practice restraint, protect the faculty of sight, and achieve restraint over it. MN 107:4.4When you hear a sound with your ears … MN 107:4.5When you smell an odor with your nose … MN 107:4.6When you taste a flavor with your tongue … MN 107:4.7When you feel a touch with your body … MN 107:4.8When you know a thought with your mind, don’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 107:4.9If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, practice restraint, protect the faculty of mind, and achieve its restraint.’

MN 107:5.1BJ 12.92When they guard their sense doors, the Realized One guides them further: MN 107:5.2‘Come, mendicant, eat in moderation. MN 107:5.3Reflect properly on the food that you eat: MN 107:5.4‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will live blamelessly and at ease.’

MN 107:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.3When they eat in moderation, the Realized One guides them further: MN 107:6.2‘Come, mendicant, be committed to wakefulness. Practice walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying your mind from obstacles. In the evening, continue to practice walking and sitting meditation. In the middle of the night, lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up. In the last part of the night, get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying your mind from obstacles.’

MN 107:7.1When they are committed to wakefulness, the Realized One guides them further: MN 107:7.2‘Come, mendicant, have mindfulness and situational awareness. Act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.’

MN 107:8.1When they have mindfulness and situational awareness, the Realized One guides them further: MN 107:8.2‘Come, mendicant, frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.’ MN 107:9.1And they do so.

MN 107:9.2After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. MN 107:9.3Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire. MN 107:9.4Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will. MN 107:9.5Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness. MN 107:9.6Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse. MN 107:9.7Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

MN 108:0.2With Moggallāna the Guardian

MN 108:1.1BJ 12.100So I have heard. MN 108:1.2At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground. It was not long after the Buddha had become fully extinguished.

MN 108:10.1BJ 12.104PTS-VP-PLI 3.10“But Master Ānanda, when asked whether there was even a single mendicant—either appointed by the Buddha, MN 108:10.10But you say that the reason for your harmony is that you have MN 108:10.12the teaching as a refuge. MN 108:10.13How should I see the meaning of this statement?”

MN 108:10.14“The Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha laid down training rules and recited the monastic code for the mendicants. MN 108:10.15On the day of the sabbath all of us who live in dependence on one village district gather together as one. MN 108:10.16We invite one who has freshly rehearsed the code to recite it. MN 108:10.17If anyone remembers an offense or transgression while they’re reciting, we make them act in line with the teachings and in line with the instructions. MN 108:10.18It’s not the venerables that make us act, MN 108:10.19it’s the teaching that makes us act.”

MN 108:10.5or elected by the Saṅgha and appointed by several senior mendicants—MN 108:10.6who serves as your refuge after the Buddha passed away, to whom you now turn, MN 108:10.7you replied, ‘No, there is not.’

MN 108:11.1“Master Ānanda, is there even a single mendicant who you honor, respect, revere, venerate, and rely on?”

MN 108:11.2“There is, brahmin.”

MN 108:11.3BJ 12.106PTS-VP-PLI 3.11“But Master Ānanda, when asked whether there was even a single mendicant—either appointed by the Buddha, MN 108:12.2or elected by the Saṅgha and appointed by several senior mendicants—MN 108:12.3who serves as your refuge after the Buddha passed away, to whom you now turn, MN 108:12.4you replied, ‘No, there is not.’ MN 108:12.6But when asked whether there is even a single mendicant who you honor, respect, revere, venerate, and rely on, MN 108:12.7you replied, ‘There is.’ MN 108:12.8How should I see the meaning of this statement?”

MN 108:13.1“There are ten inspiring things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. MN 108:13.2We honor anyone in whom these things are found. MN 108:13.3What ten?

MN 108:14.1It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

MN 108:15.1They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. MN 108:15.2These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.

MN 108:16.1They’re content with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

MN 108:17.1They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

MN 108:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.12They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unimpeded through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. They control the body as far as the Brahmā realm.

MN 108:19.1BJ 12.108With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.

MN 108:2.1Now at that time King Ajātasattu Vedehiputta of Magadha, being suspicious of King Pajjota, was having Rājagaha fortified.

MN 108:20.1They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind.MN 108:20.10expansive mind …MN 108:20.11unexpansive mind …MN 108:20.12mind that is not supreme …MN 108:20.13mind that is supreme …MN 108:20.14mind immersed in samādhi …MN 108:20.15mind not immersed in samādhi …MN 108:20.16freed mind …MN 108:20.17They understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.

MN 108:20.2They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,MN 108:20.3and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’.MN 108:20.4They understand mind with hate …MN 108:20.5mind without hate …MN 108:20.6mind with delusion …MN 108:20.7mind without delusion …MN 108:20.8constricted mind …MN 108:20.9scattered mind …

MN 108:21.1They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

MN 108:22.1With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

MN 108:23.1They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

MN 108:23.2These are the ten inspiring things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. MN 108:23.3We honor anyone in whom these things are found, and rely on them.”

MN 108:24.1BJ 12.110PTS-VP-PLI 3.13When he had spoken, Vassakāra addressed General Upananda, MN 108:24.2“What do you think, general? MN 108:24.3Do these venerables honor, respect, revere, and venerate those who are worthy?”

MN 108:24.4“Indeed they do. MN 108:24.5For if these venerables were not to honor, respect, revere, and venerate such a person, MN 108:24.6then who exactly would they honor?”

MN 108:25.1Then Vassakāra said to Ānanda, MN 108:25.10And there he spoke about meditation in many ways. MN 108:25.11He meditated, and made a habit of meditating. MN 108:25.12And he praised all kinds of meditation.”

MN 108:25.2“Where are you staying at present?”

MN 108:25.3“In the Bamboo Grove, brahmin.”

MN 108:25.4“I hope the Bamboo Grove is delightful, quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat?”

MN 108:25.6“Surely, Master Ānanda, it is owing to the venerables who meditate, making a habit of meditating. MN 108:25.7For the venerables do in fact meditate and make a habit of meditating.

MN 108:25.8This one time, Master Ānanda, Master Gotama was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof. MN 108:25.9So I went there to see him.

MN 108:26.1BJ 12.112PTS-VP-PLI 3.14“No, brahmin, the Buddha did not praise all kinds of meditation, nor did he dispraise all kinds of meditation. MN 108:26.11doubt, and they don’t truly know and see the escape from doubt that has arisen. MN 108:26.12Harboring doubt within they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate. MN 108:26.13The Buddha didn’t praise this kind of meditation.

MN 108:26.2And what kind of meditation did he not praise? MN 108:26.3It’s when someone’s heart is overcome and mired in sensual desire, and they don’t truly understand the escape from sensual desire that has arisen. MN 108:26.4Harboring sensual desire within they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate. MN 108:26.5Their heart is overcome and mired in ill will … MN 108:26.7dullness and drowsiness … MN 108:26.9restlessness and remorse …

MN 108:27.1And what kind of meditation did he praise? MN 108:27.2It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 108:27.3As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 108:27.4And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 108:27.5Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 108:27.6The Buddha praised this kind of meditation.”

MN 108:28.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.15“Well, Master Ānanda, it seems that Master Gotama criticized the kind of meditation that deserves criticism and praised that deserving of praise. MN 108:28.2Well, now, Master Ānanda, I must go. MN 108:28.3I have many duties, and much to do.”

MN 108:28.4“Please, brahmin, go at your convenience.”

MN 108:28.5Then Vassakāra the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what Venerable Ānanda said, got up from his seat and left.

MN 108:29.1BJ 12.114Soon after he had left, Moggallāna the Guardian said to Ānanda, MN 108:29.2“Master Ānanda, you still haven’t answered my question.”

MN 108:29.3“But brahmin, didn’t I say: MN 108:29.4‘There is no single mendicant who has all the same qualities in each and every way as possessed by Master Gotama, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. MN 108:29.5For the Blessed One gave rise to the unarisen path, gave birth to the unborn path, explained the unexplained path. He was the knower of the path, the discoverer of the path, the expert on the path. MN 108:29.6And now the disciples live following the path; they acquire it later.’”

MN 108:3.1Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.

MN 108:3.2Then it occurred to him, MN 108:3.3“It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha. MN 108:3.4Why don’t I go to see the brahmin Moggallāna the Guardian at his place of work?”

MN 108:4.1BJ 12.102PTS-VP-PLI 3.8So that’s what he did. MN 108:4.6It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here. MN 108:4.7Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”

MN 108:4.8Ānanda sat down on the seat spread out, MN 108:4.9while Moggallāna took a low seat and sat to one side.
