MN 108:6.1But this conversation between Ānanda and Moggallāna the Guardian was left unfinished.

MN 108:6.2PTS-VP-PLI 3.9For just then the brahmin Vassakāra, a chief minister of Magadha, while supervising the work at Rājagaha, approached Ānanda at Moggallāna’s place of work and exchanged greetings with him. MN 108:6.3When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda, MN 108:6.4“Master Ānanda, what were you sitting talking about just now? MN 108:9.2“We don’t lack a refuge, brahmin, MN 108:9.3we have a refuge. MN 108:9.4The teaching is our refuge.”

MN 109:0.2The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

MN 109:1.1BJ 12.116So I have heard. MN 109:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.

MN 109:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.18“But sir, how does identity view come about?”

MN 109:10.2“It’s when an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 109:10.3They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form. MN 109:10.4They regard feeling as self, self as having feeling, feeling in self, or self in feeling. MN 109:10.5They regard perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception. MN 109:10.6They regard choices as self, self as having choices, choices in self, or self in choices. MN 109:10.7They regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness. MN 109:10.8That’s how identity view comes about.”

MN 109:11.1BJ 12.120“But sir, how does identity view not come about?”

MN 109:11.4They don’t regard feeling as self, self as having feeling, feeling in self, or self in feeling. MN 109:11.5They don’t regard perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception. MN 109:12.1“Sir, what’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form, MN 109:12.10perception … MN 109:12.11choices … MN 109:12.12consciousness: this is its gratification. MN 109:12.2feeling, MN 109:12.3perception, MN 109:12.4choices, MN 109:12.5and consciousness?”

MN 109:12.8Removing and giving up desire and greed for form: this is its escape. MN 109:12.9The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling …

MN 109:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.19“Sir, how does one know and see so that there’s no ego, possessiveness, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and all external stimuli?”

MN 109:13.2“One truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 109:13.3One truly sees any kind of feeling … MN 109:13.4perception … MN 109:13.5choices … MN 109:13.6consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 109:13.7That’s how to know and see so that there’s no ego, possessiveness, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and all external stimuli.”

MN 109:14.1BJ 12.122Now at that time one of the mendicants had the thought, MN 109:14.2“So it seems, good sir, that form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self. MN 109:14.3Then what self will the deeds done by not-self affect?”

MN 109:14.4But the Buddha, knowing what that monk was thinking, addressed the mendicants: MN 109:14.5“It’s possible that some foolish person here—unknowing and ignorant, their mind dominated by craving—thinks they can overstep the teacher’s instructions. MN 109:14.7Then what self will the deeds done by not-self affect?’ MN 109:14.8Now, mendicants, you have been educated by me in questioning with regard to all these things in all such cases.

MN 109:15.1BJ 12.124PTS-VP-PLI 3.20What do you think, mendicants? MN 109:15.2Is form permanent or impermanent?”

MN 109:15.3“Impermanent, sir.”

MN 109:15.4“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

MN 109:15.5“Suffering, sir.”

MN 109:15.6“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: MN 109:15.7‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

MN 109:15.8“No, sir.”

MN 109:16.1“What do you think, mendicants? MN 109:16.10‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

MN 109:16.11“No, sir.”

MN 109:16.12“So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

MN 109:16.2Is feeling … MN 109:16.3perception … MN 109:16.4choices … MN 109:16.5consciousness permanent or impermanent?”

MN 109:16.6“Impermanent, sir.”

MN 109:16.7“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

MN 109:16.8“Suffering, sir.”

MN 109:16.9“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

MN 109:17.1You should truly see any kind of feeling … MN 109:17.2perception … MN 109:17.3choices … MN 109:17.4consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

MN 109:17.5Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

MN 109:18.1Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

MN 109:18.2They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”

MN 109:18.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 109:18.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said. MN 109:18.5And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.

MN 109:2.1Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.

MN 109:3.1Then one of the mendicants got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, raised their joined palms toward the Buddha, and said, MN 109:3.2“I’d like to ask the Buddha about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”

MN 109:3.3“Well then, mendicant, take your own seat and ask what you wish.”

MN 109:3.4PTS-VP-PLI 3.16That mendicant took his seat and said to the Buddha:

MN 109:4.1“Sir, are these the five grasping aggregates: MN 109:4.2form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”

MN 109:4.3“Yes, they are,” replied the Buddha.

MN 109:4.5Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:

MN 109:5.1“But sir, what is the root of these five grasping aggregates?”

MN 109:5.2“These five grasping aggregates are rooted in desire.”

MN 109:6.1“But sir, is that grasping the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates? Or is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another?”

MN 109:6.2“Neither. MN 109:6.3Rather, the desire and greed for them is the grasping there.”

MN 109:7.1BJ 12.118“But sir, can there be different kinds of desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates?”

MN 109:7.2“There can,” said the Buddha. MN 109:7.3“It’s when someone thinks: MN 109:7.4‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’ MN 109:7.5That’s how there can be different kinds of desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates.”

MN 109:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.17“Sir, what is the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates?”

MN 109:8.2“Any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of form. MN 109:8.3Any kind of feeling at all … MN 109:8.4Any kind of perception at all … MN 109:8.5Any kind of choices at all … MN 109:8.6Any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of consciousness. MN 109:8.7That’s the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates.”

MN 109:9.1“What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why the aggregate of form is found? MN 109:9.10Name and form are the reasons why the aggregate of consciousness is found.”

MN 109:9.2What is the cause, what is the reason why the aggregate of feeling … MN 109:9.3perception … MN 109:9.4choices … MN 109:9.5consciousness is found?”

MN 109:9.6“The four primary elements are the reason why the aggregate of form is found. MN 109:9.7Contact is the reason why the aggregates of feeling … MN 109:9.8perception … MN 109:9.9and choices are found.

MN 110:0.2The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

MN 110:1.1BJ 12.126PTS-VP-PLI 3.21So I have heard. MN 110:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.

MN 110:10.1And how does a bad person have the action of a bad person? MN 110:10.2It’s when a bad person kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. MN 110:10.3That’s how a bad person has the actions of a bad person.

MN 110:11.1And how does a bad person have the view of a bad person? MN 110:11.2It’s when a bad person has such a view: MN 110:11.3‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no obligation to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’ MN 110:11.4That’s how a bad person has the view of a bad person.

MN 110:12.1And how does a bad person give the gifts of a bad person? MN 110:12.2It’s when a bad person gives a gift carelessly, not with their own hand, and thoughtlessly. They give the dregs, and they give without consideration for consequences. MN 110:12.3That’s how a bad person gives the gifts of a bad person.

MN 110:13.1That bad person—who has such bad qualities, frequents bad people, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of a bad person— MN 110:13.2when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the place where bad people are reborn. MN 110:13.3And what is the place where bad people are reborn? MN 110:13.4Hell or the animal realm.

MN 110:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.23Mendicants, could a good person know of a good person: MN 110:14.2‘This fellow is a good person’?”

MN 110:14.3“Yes, sir.”

MN 110:14.4BJ 12.130“Good, mendicants! MN 110:14.5It is possible that a good person could know of a good person: MN 110:14.6‘This fellow is a good person.’ MN 110:14.7But could a good person know of a bad person: MN 110:14.8‘This fellow is a bad person’?”

MN 110:14.9“Yes, sir.”

MN 110:15.1“Good, mendicants! MN 110:15.2That too is possible. MN 110:15.4A good person has good qualities, associates with good people, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of a good person.

MN 110:16.1And how does a good person have good qualities? MN 110:16.2It’s when a good person is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise. MN 110:16.3That’s how a good person has good qualities.

MN 110:17.1And how does a good person associate with good people? MN 110:17.2It’s when a good person is a friend and companion of ascetics and brahmins who are faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise. MN 110:17.3That’s how a good person associates with good people.

MN 110:18.1And how does a good person have the intentions of a good person? MN 110:18.2It’s when a good person doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. MN 110:18.3That’s how a good person has the intentions of a good person.

MN 110:19.1And how does a good person offer the counsel of a good person? MN 110:19.2It’s when a good person offers counsel that doesn’t hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. MN 110:19.3That’s how a good person offers the counsel of a good person.

MN 110:2.1Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks. MN 110:2.2Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were so very silent. He addressed them,

MN 110:20.1And how does a good person have the speech of a good person? MN 110:20.2It’s when a good person refrains from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. MN 110:20.3That’s how a good person has the speech of a good person.

MN 110:21.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.24And how does a good person have the action of a good person? MN 110:21.2It’s when a good person refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct. MN 110:21.3That’s how a good person has the action of a good person.

MN 110:22.1BJ 12.132And how does a good person have the view of a good person? MN 110:22.2It’s when a good person has such a view: MN 110:22.3‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are duties to mother and father. There are beings reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are well attained and practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’ MN 110:22.4That’s how a good person has the view of a good person.

MN 110:23.1And how does a good person give the gifts of a good person? MN 110:23.2It’s when a good person gives a gift carefully, with their own hand, and thoughtfully. They don’t give the dregs, and they give with consideration for consequences. MN 110:23.3That’s how a good person gives the gifts of a good person.

MN 110:24.1That good person—who has such good qualities, associates with good people, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of a good person— MN 110:24.2when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the place where good people are reborn. MN 110:24.3And what is the place where good people are reborn? MN 110:24.4A state of greatness among gods or humans.”

MN 110:25.1That is what the Buddha said. MN 110:25.2Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 110:3.1“Mendicants, could a bad person know of a bad person:

MN 110:3.10“Good, mendicants! MN 110:3.11That too is impossible. MN 110:3.2‘This fellow is a bad person’?”

MN 110:3.3“No, sir.”

MN 110:3.4“Good, mendicants! MN 110:3.5It’s impossible, it can’t happen, that a bad person could know of a bad person: MN 110:3.6‘This fellow is a bad person.’ MN 110:3.7But could a bad person know of a good person: MN 110:3.8‘This fellow is a good person’?”

MN 110:3.9“No, sir.”

MN 110:4.1A bad person has bad qualities, associates with bad people, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of a bad person.

MN 110:5.1And how does a bad person have bad qualities? MN 110:5.2It’s when a bad person is faithless, shameless, imprudent, uneducated, lazy, unmindful, and witless. MN 110:5.3That’s how a bad person has bad qualities.

MN 110:6.1And how does a bad person associate with bad people? MN 110:6.2It’s when a bad person is a friend and companion of ascetics and brahmins who are faithless, shameless, imprudent, uneducated, lazy, unmindful, and witless. MN 110:6.3That’s how a bad person associates with bad people.

MN 110:7.1BJ 12.128And how does a bad person have the intentions of a bad person? MN 110:7.2It’s when a bad person intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. MN 110:7.3That’s how a bad person has the intentions of a bad person.

MN 110:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.22And how does a bad person offer the counsel of a bad person? MN 110:8.2It’s when a bad person offers counsel that hurts themselves, hurts others, and hurts both. MN 110:8.3That’s how a bad person offers the counsel of a bad person.

MN 110:9.1And how does a bad person have the speech of a bad person? MN 110:9.2It’s when a bad person uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, and nonsensical. MN 110:9.3That’s how a bad person has the speech of a bad person.

MN 111:0.2One by One

MN 111:1.1BJ 12.134PTS-VP-PLI 3.25So I have heard. MN 111:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 111:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 111:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 111:10.1And he distinguished the phenomena in the fourth absorption one by one: equanimity and neutral feeling and mental unconcern due to tranquility and pure mindfulness and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and attention. MN 111:10.2He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away. MN 111:10.3He understood: MN 111:10.4‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’ MN 111:10.5And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits. MN 111:10.6He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’ MN 111:10.7And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.

MN 111:11.1BJ 12.138Furthermore, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, he entered and remained in the dimension of infinite space.

MN 111:12.1And he distinguished the phenomena in the dimension of infinite space one by one: the perception of the dimension of infinite space and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and attention. MN 111:12.3He understood: MN 111:12.4‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’ MN 111:12.5And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits. MN 111:12.6He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’ MN 111:12.7And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.

MN 111:13.1Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, he entered and remained in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

MN 111:14.1And he distinguished the phenomena in the dimension of infinite consciousness one by one: the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and attention. MN 111:14.2He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away. MN 111:14.3He understood: MN 111:14.4‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’ MN 111:14.5And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits. MN 111:14.6He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’ MN 111:14.7And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.

MN 111:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.28Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, he entered and remained in the dimension of nothingness.

MN 111:16.1And he distinguished the phenomena in the dimension of nothingness one by one: the perception of the dimension of nothingness and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and attention. MN 111:16.2He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away. MN 111:16.6He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’ MN 111:16.7And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.

MN 111:17.1Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, he entered and remained in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

MN 111:18.1And he emerged from that attainment with mindfulness. MN 111:18.2Then he contemplated the phenomena in that attainment that had passed, ceased, and perished: MN 111:18.3‘So it seems that these phenomena, not having been, come to be; and having come to be, they flit away.’ MN 111:18.4And he meditated without attraction or repulsion for those phenomena; independent, untied, liberated, detached, his mind free of limits. MN 111:18.5He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’ MN 111:18.6And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.

MN 111:19.1BJ 12.140Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, he entered and remained in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, his defilements came to an end.

MN 111:2.1“Sāriputta is astute, mendicants. MN 111:2.2He has great wisdom, MN 111:2.3widespread wisdom, MN 111:2.4laughing wisdom, MN 111:2.5swift wisdom, MN 111:2.6sharp wisdom, MN 111:2.7and penetrating wisdom. MN 111:2.8For a fortnight he practiced discernment of phenomena one by one. MN 111:2.9And this is how he did it.

MN 111:20.1And he emerged from that attainment with mindfulness. MN 111:20.5He understood: ‘There is no escape beyond.’ MN 111:20.6And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is not.

MN 111:21.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.29And if there’s anyone of whom it may be rightly said that MN 111:21.2they have attained mastery and perfection in noble ethics, immersion, wisdom, and freedom, it’s Sāriputta.

MN 111:22.1And if there’s anyone of whom it may be rightly said that MN 111:22.2they’re the Buddha’s true-born child, born from his mouth, born of the teaching, created by the teaching, heir to the teaching, not the heir in material things, it’s Sāriputta.

MN 111:23.1Sāriputta rightly keeps rolling the supreme Wheel of Dhamma that was rolled forth by the Realized One.”

MN 111:23.2That is what the Buddha said. MN 111:23.3Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 111:3.1Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 111:6.1And he distinguished the phenomena in the second absorption one by one: internal confidence and rapture and bliss and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and attention. MN 111:6.2He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away. MN 111:6.6He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’ MN 111:6.7And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.

MN 111:7.1Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, he entered and remained in the third absorption, where he meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

MN 111:8.6He understood: ‘There is an escape beyond.’ MN 111:8.7And by repeated practice he knew for sure that there is.

MN 111:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.27Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, he entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

MN 112:0.2The Sixfold Purification

MN 112:1.1BJ 12.142So I have heard. MN 112:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 112:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 112:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 112:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 112:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 112:10.1For a mendicant with defilements ended it is in line with the teaching to answer: MN 112:10.2‘I understand that my mind is freed through the ending, fading away, cessation, giving away, and letting go of desire and greed and relishing and craving; attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendency for the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness. MN 112:10.3I understand that my mind is freed through the ending of desire for the ear … MN 112:10.4nose … MN 112:10.5tongue … MN 112:10.6body … MN 112:10.7mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness. MN 112:10.8That is how I know and see regarding these six interior and exterior sense fields so that my mind is freed from defilements by not grasping.’

MN 112:11.1Saying ‘Good!’ you should applaud and cheer that mendicant’s statement, MN 112:11.2then ask a further question:

MN 112:11.3‘Sir, how does the venerable know and see so that he has eradicated ego, possessiveness, and underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and all external stimuli?’

MN 112:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.33For a mendicant with defilements ended it is in line with the teaching to answer: MN 112:12.2‘Formerly, reverends, when I was still a layperson, I was ignorant. MN 112:12.3Then the Realized One or one of his disciples taught me the Dhamma. MN 112:12.4I gained faith in the Realized One, MN 112:12.5and reflected:

MN 112:12.6“Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open. MN 112:12.7It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell. MN 112:12.8Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”

MN 112:13.1BJ 12.148PTS-VP-PLI 3.34After some time I gave up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. I shaved off hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness. MN 112:13.2Once I had gone forth, I took up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. I gave up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. I was scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings. MN 112:13.3I gave up stealing. I took only what’s given, and expected only what’s given. I kept myself clean by not thieving. MN 112:13.4I gave up unchastity. I became celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex. MN 112:13.5I gave up lying. I spoke the truth and stuck to the truth. I was honest and trustworthy, not tricking the world with my words. MN 112:13.6I gave up divisive speech. I didn’t repeat in one place what I heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, I reconciled those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony. MN 112:13.7I gave up harsh speech. I spoke in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people. MN 112:13.8I gave up talking nonsense. My words were timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. I said things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

MN 112:14.1I avoided injuring plants and seeds. I ate in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time. MN 112:14.10goats and sheep, MN 112:14.11chicken and pigs, MN 112:14.12elephants, cows, horses, and mares, MN 112:14.13and fields and land. MN 112:14.14I avoided running errands and messages; MN 112:14.15buying and selling; MN 112:14.16falsifying weights, metals, or measures; MN 112:14.17bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; MN 112:14.18mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

MN 112:14.19I became content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever I went, I set out taking only these things. MN 112:14.2I avoided dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows. MN 112:14.20Like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden. MN 112:14.21In the same way, I became content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever I went, I set out taking only these things. MN 112:14.22When I had this entire spectrum of noble ethics, I experienced a blameless happiness inside myself.

MN 112:14.3I avoided beautifying and adorning myself with garlands, perfumes, and makeup. MN 112:14.4I avoided high and luxurious beds. MN 112:14.5I avoided receiving gold and money, MN 112:14.6raw grains, MN 112:14.7raw meat, MN 112:14.8women and girls, MN 112:14.9male and female bondservants,

MN 112:15.1BJ 12.150PTS-VP-PLI 3.35When I saw a sight with my eyes, I didn’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 112:15.2If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, I practiced restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint. MN 112:15.3When I heard a sound with my ears … MN 112:15.4When I smelled an odor with my nose … MN 112:15.5When I tasted a flavor with my tongue … MN 112:15.6When I felt a touch with my body … MN 112:15.7When I knew a thought with my mind, I didn’t get caught up in the features and details. MN 112:15.8If the faculty of the mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, I practiced restraint, protecting the faculty of the mind, and achieving its restraint. MN 112:15.9When I had this noble sense restraint, I experienced an unsullied bliss inside myself.

MN 112:16.1I acted with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

MN 112:16.2When I had this noble spectrum of ethics, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, MN 112:16.3I frequented a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw. MN 112:16.4After the meal, I returned from almsround, sat down cross-legged with my body straight, and established mindfulness right there.

MN 112:17.1Giving up desire for the world, I meditated with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire. MN 112:17.2Giving up ill will and malevolence, I meditated with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will. MN 112:17.3Giving up dullness and drowsiness, I meditated with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness. MN 112:17.4Giving up restlessness and remorse, I meditated without restlessness, my mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse. MN 112:17.5Giving up doubt, I meditated having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

MN 112:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.36I gave up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. MN 112:18.2Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 112:18.3As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption … MN 112:18.4third absorption … MN 112:18.5fourth absorption.

MN 112:19.1BJ 12.152PTS-VP-PLI 3.37When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements. MN 112:19.2I truly understood: “This is suffering” … “This is the origin of suffering” … “This is the cessation of suffering” … “This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering”. MN 112:19.3I truly understood: “These are defilements”… “This is the origin of defilements” … “This is the cessation of defilements” … “This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements”.

MN 112:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.30“Take a mendicant who declares enlightenment: MN 112:2.2‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’

MN 112:20.1Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 112:20.2When it was freed, I knew it was freed. MN 112:20.3I understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.” MN 112:20.4That is how I know and see so that I have eradicated ego, possessiveness, and underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and all external stimuli.’

MN 112:21.1Saying ‘Good!’ you should applaud and cheer that mendicant’s statement, MN 112:21.2and then say to them: MN 112:21.3‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate MN 112:21.4to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!’”

MN 112:21.5That is what the Buddha said. MN 112:21.6Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 112:3.1You should neither approve nor dismiss that mendicant’s statement. MN 112:3.2Rather, you should question them: MN 112:3.3‘Reverend, these four kinds of expression have been rightly explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. MN 112:3.4What four? MN 112:3.5One speaks of the seen as seen, the heard as heard, the thought as thought, and the known as known. MN 112:3.6These are the four kinds of expression rightly explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. MN 112:3.7How does the venerable know and see regarding these four kinds of expression so that your mind is freed from defilements by not grasping?’

MN 112:4.1For a mendicant with defilements ended—who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—it is in line with the teaching to answer: MN 112:4.2‘Reverends, I live without attraction or repulsion for what is seen; independent, untied, liberated, detached, my mind free of limits. MN 112:4.3I live without attraction or repulsion for what is heard … MN 112:4.4thought … MN 112:4.5or known; independent, untied, liberated, detached, my mind free of limits. MN 112:4.6That is how I know and see regarding these four kinds of expression so that my mind is freed from defilements by not grasping.’

MN 112:5.1Saying ‘Good!’ you should applaud and cheer that mendicant’s statement, MN 112:5.2then ask a further question:

MN 112:5.3BJ 12.144‘Reverend, these five grasping aggregates have been rightly explained by the Buddha. MN 112:5.4What five? MN 112:5.5That is: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness. MN 112:5.6These are the five grasping aggregates that have been rightly explained by the Buddha. MN 112:5.7How does the venerable know and see regarding these five grasping aggregates so that your mind is freed from defilements by not grasping?’

MN 112:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.31For a mendicant with defilements ended it is in line with the teaching to answer: MN 112:6.2‘Reverends, knowing that form is powerless, fading, and unreliable, I understand that my mind is freed through the ending, fading away, cessation, giving away, and letting go of attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendency for form. MN 112:6.3Knowing that feeling … MN 112:6.4perception … MN 112:6.5choices … MN 112:6.6consciousness is powerless, fading, and unreliable, I understand that my mind is freed through the ending, fading away, cessation, giving away, and letting go of attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendency for consciousness. MN 112:6.7That is how I know and see regarding these five grasping aggregates so that my mind is freed from defilements by not grasping.’

MN 112:7.1Saying ‘Good!’ you should applaud and cheer that mendicant’s statement, MN 112:7.2then ask a further question:

MN 112:7.3‘Reverend, these six elements have been rightly explained by the Buddha. MN 112:7.4What six? MN 112:7.5The elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness. MN 112:7.6These are the six elements that have been rightly explained by the Buddha. MN 112:7.7How does the venerable know and see regarding these six elements so that your mind is freed from defilements by not grasping?’

MN 112:8.1BJ 12.146PTS-VP-PLI 3.32For a mendicant with defilements ended it is in line with the teaching to answer: MN 112:8.10That is how I know and see regarding these six elements so that my mind is freed from defilements by not grasping.’

MN 112:8.2‘Reverends, I’ve not taken the earth element as self, nor is there a self based on the earth element. MN 112:8.3And I understand that my mind is freed through the ending, fading away, cessation, giving away, and letting go of attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendency based on the earth element. MN 112:8.4I’ve not taken the water element … MN 112:8.5fire element … MN 112:8.6air element … MN 112:8.7space element … MN 112:8.8consciousness element as self, nor is there a self based on the consciousness element. MN 112:8.9And I understand that my mind is freed through the ending of attraction based on the consciousness element.

MN 112:9.1Saying ‘Good!’ you should applaud and cheer that mendicant’s statement, MN 112:9.2then ask a further question:

MN 112:9.3‘Reverend, these six interior and exterior sense fields have been rightly explained by the Buddha. MN 112:9.4What six? MN 112:9.5The eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, and the mind and thoughts. MN 112:9.6These are the six interior and exterior sense fields that have been rightly explained by the Buddha. MN 112:9.7How does the venerable know and see regarding these six interior and exterior sense fields so that your mind is freed from defilements by not grasping?’

MN 113:0.2A Good Person

MN 113:1.1BJ 12.154So I have heard. MN 113:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 113:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 113:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 113:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 113:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 113:10.1BJ 12.158PTS-VP-PLI 3.40who is an expert in the monastic law … MN 113:11.1who is a Dhamma teacher … MN 113:12.1who dwells in the wilderness … MN 113:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.41who is a rag robe wearer … MN 113:14.1BJ 12.160who eats only almsfood … MN 113:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.42who stays at the root of a tree … MN 113:16-20.1who stays in a charnel ground … MN 113:16-20.10A good person reflects: MN 113:16-20.11‘It’s not because of eating in one sitting per day that thoughts of greed, hate, or delusion come to an end. MN 113:16-20.12Even if someone eats in more than one sitting per day, MN 113:16-20.13if they practice in line with the teaching, practice properly, and live in line with the teaching, they are worthy of honor and praise for that.’ MN 113:16-20.14Keeping only the practice close to their heart, they don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of their eating in one sitting per day. MN 113:16-20.15This too is a quality of a good person.

MN 113:16-20.2who stays in the open air … MN 113:16-20.3who never lies down … MN 113:16-20.4who sleeps wherever they lay their mat … MN 113:16-20.5who eats in one sitting per day. MN 113:16-20.6They reflect: MN 113:16-20.7‘I eat in one sitting per day, unlike these other mendicants.’ MN 113:16-20.8And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that. MN 113:16-20.9This too is a quality of a bad person.

MN 114:0.2What Should and Should Not Be Cultivated

MN 114:1.1BJ 12.166So I have heard. MN 114:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 114:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 114:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 114:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 114:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 114:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.52‘I say that there are two ways of acquiring views: MN 114:10.10‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There are no duties to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’ MN 114:10.11That way of acquiring views causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

MN 114:10.12And what way of acquiring views causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow? MN 114:10.13It’s when someone has such a view: MN 114:10.14‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are duties to mother and father. There are beings reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are well attained and practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’ MN 114:10.15That way of acquiring views causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow. MN 114:10.16‘I say that there are two ways of acquiring views: MN 114:10.17that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate. MN 114:10.18And each of these is a way of acquiring views.’ MN 114:10.19That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

MN 114:10.2that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate. MN 114:10.3And each of these is a way of acquiring views.’ MN 114:10.4That’s what the Buddha said, MN 114:10.5but why did he say it? MN 114:10.6You should not cultivate the way of acquiring views which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline. MN 114:10.7And you should cultivate the way of acquiring views which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

MN 114:10.8BJ 12.176And what way of acquiring views causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline? MN 114:10.9It’s when someone has such a view:

MN 114:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.53‘I say that there are two ways of reincarnating:

MN 114:11.10And what way of reincarnating causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline? MN 114:11.11Generating rebirth in a hurtful reincarnation, which because of its unpreparedness causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline. MN 114:11.12And what way of reincarnating causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow? Generating rebirth in a pleasing reincarnation, which because of its preparedness causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow. MN 114:11.13‘I say that there are two ways of reincarnating: MN 114:11.14that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate. MN 114:11.15And each of these is a way of reincarnating.’ MN 114:11.16That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

MN 114:11.2that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate. MN 114:11.3And each of these is a way of reincarnating.’ MN 114:11.4That’s what the Buddha said, MN 114:11.5but why did he say it? MN 114:11.6The way of reincarnating that causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline: MN 114:11.7you should not cultivate that way of reincarnating. MN 114:11.8The way of reincarnating that causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow: MN 114:11.9you should cultivate that way of reincarnating.

MN 114:12.1Sir, that’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

MN 114:13.1“Good, good, Sāriputta! MN 114:13.2It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of my brief statement in this way.”

MN 114:6.1‘I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior: MN 114:6.10They speak divisively. They repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. And so they divide those who are harmonious, supporting division, delighting in division, loving division, speaking words that promote division. MN 114:6.11They speak harshly. They use the kinds of words that are cruel, nasty, hurtful, offensive, bordering on anger, not leading to immersion. MN 114:6.12They talk nonsense. Their speech is untimely, and is neither factual nor beneficial. It has nothing to do with the teaching or the training. Their words have no value, and are untimely, unreasonable, rambling, and pointless. MN 114:6.13That kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

MN 114:6.14BJ 12.172PTS-VP-PLI 3.49And what kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow? MN 114:6.15It’s when a certain person gives up lying. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, mister, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I see.’ So they don’t deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason. MN 114:6.16They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony. MN 114:6.17They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people. MN 114:6.18They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial. MN 114:6.19That kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow. MN 114:6.2that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate. MN 114:8.8BJ 12.174And what way of giving rise to a thought causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline? MN 114:8.9It’s when someone is covetous, and lives with their heart full of covetousness.

MN 114:9.1‘I say that there are two ways of acquiring perception: MN 114:9.10They are malicious, and live with their perception full of ill will. MN 114:9.11They’re hurtful, and live with their perception intent on harm. MN 114:9.12That way of acquiring perception causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

MN 114:9.13And what way of acquiring perception causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow? MN 114:9.14It’s when someone is content, and lives with their perception full of contentment. MN 114:9.15They have good will, and live with their perception full of good will. MN 114:9.16They’re kind, and live with their perception full of kindness. MN 114:9.17That way of acquiring perception causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow. MN 114:9.18‘I say that there are two ways of acquiring perception: MN 114:9.19that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate. MN 114:9.2that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate. MN 114:9.20And each of these is a way of acquiring perception.’ MN 114:9.21That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

MN 114:9.3And each of these is a way of acquiring perception.’ MN 114:9.4That’s what the Buddha said, MN 114:9.5but why did he say it? MN 114:9.6You should not cultivate the way of acquiring perception which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline. MN 114:9.7And you should cultivate the way of acquiring perception which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

MN 114:9.8And what way of acquiring perception causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline? MN 114:9.9It’s when someone is covetous, and lives with their perception full of covetousness.

  • MN 115:0.1Middle Discourses 115

MN 115:0.2Many Elements

MN 115:1.1BJ 12.194So I have heard. MN 115:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 115:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 115:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 115:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 115:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 115:10.1“But sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘skilled in the sense fields’?”

MN 115:10.2“There are these six interior and exterior sense fields: MN 115:10.3the eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, and the mind and thoughts. MN 115:10.4When a mendicant knows and sees these six interior and exterior sense fields, MN 115:10.5they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the sense fields’.”

MN 115:11.1BJ 12.198PTS-VP-PLI 3.64“But sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘skilled in dependent origination’?”

MN 115:11.10Contact is a condition for feeling. MN 115:11.11Feeling is a condition for craving. MN 115:11.12Craving is a condition for grasping. MN 115:11.13Grasping is a condition for continued existence. MN 115:11.14Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. MN 115:11.15Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. MN 115:11.16That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. MN 115:11.17When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease. MN 115:11.18When choices cease, consciousness ceases. MN 115:11.19When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.

MN 115:11.2“It’s when a mendicant understands: MN 115:11.20When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease. MN 115:11.21When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases. MN 115:11.22When contact ceases, feeling ceases. MN 115:11.23When feeling ceases, craving ceases. MN 115:11.24When craving ceases, grasping ceases. MN 115:11.25When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. MN 115:11.26When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. MN 115:11.27When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. MN 115:11.28That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’ MN 115:11.29That’s how a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in dependent origination’.”

MN 115:11.3‘When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises. MN 115:11.4When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is: MN 115:11.5ignorance is a condition for choices. MN 115:11.6Choices are conditions for consciousness. MN 115:11.7Consciousness is a condition for name and form. MN 115:11.8Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields. MN 115:11.9The six sense fields are conditions for contact.

MN 115:12.1“But sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘skilled in the possible and impossible’?”

MN 115:12.2“It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘It’s impossible for a person accomplished in view to take any condition as permanent. That is not possible. MN 115:12.3But it’s possible for an ordinary person to take some condition as permanent. That is possible.’ MN 115:12.4They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a person accomplished in view to take any condition as pleasant. MN 115:12.5But it’s possible for an ordinary person to take some condition as pleasant.’ MN 115:12.6They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a person accomplished in view to take anything as self. MN 115:12.7But it’s possible for an ordinary person to take something as self.’

MN 115:13.1BJ 12.200PTS-VP-PLI 3.65They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a person accomplished in view to murder their mother. MN 115:13.10But it’s possible for an ordinary person to acknowledge another teacher.’

MN 115:13.2But it’s possible for an ordinary person to murder their mother.’ MN 115:13.3They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a person accomplished in view to murder their father … or murder a perfected one. MN 115:13.4But it’s possible for an ordinary person to murder their father … or a perfected one.’ MN 115:13.5They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a person accomplished in view to injure a Realized One with malicious intent. MN 115:13.6But it’s possible for an ordinary person to injure a Realized One with malicious intent.’ MN 115:13.7They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a person accomplished in view to cause a schism in the Saṅgha. MN 115:13.8But it’s possible for an ordinary person to cause a schism in the Saṅgha.’ MN 115:13.9They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a person accomplished in view to acknowledge another teacher.

MN 115:14.1They understand: ‘It’s impossible for two perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas to arise in the same solar system at the same time. MN 115:14.2But it is possible for just one perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, to arise in one solar system.’ MN 115:14.3They understand: ‘It’s impossible for two wheel-turning monarchs to arise in the same solar system at the same time. MN 115:14.4But it is possible for just one wheel-turning monarch to arise in one solar system.’

MN 115:15.1BJ 12.202PTS-VP-PLI 3.66They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a woman to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha. MN 115:15.2But it is possible for a man to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.’ MN 115:15.3They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a woman to be a wheel-turning monarch. MN 115:15.4But it is possible for a man to be a wheel-turning monarch.’ MN 115:15.5They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a woman to perform the role of Sakka, Māra, or Brahmā. MN 115:15.6But it is possible for a man to perform the role of Sakka, Māra, or Brahmā.’

MN 115:16.1They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a likable, desirable, agreeable result to come from bad conduct of body, speech, and mind. MN 115:16.2But it is possible for an unlikable, undesirable, disagreeable result to come from bad conduct of body, speech, and mind.’

MN 115:17.1They understand: ‘It’s impossible for an unlikable, undesirable, disagreeable result to come from good conduct of body, speech, and mind. MN 115:17.2But it is possible for a likable, desirable, agreeable result to come from good conduct of body, speech, and mind.’

MN 115:18.1BJ 12.204PTS-VP-PLI 3.67They understand: ‘It’s impossible that someone who has engaged in bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, could for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 115:18.2But it is possible that someone who has engaged in bad conduct of body, speech, and mind could, for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’

MN 115:19.11That’s how a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the possible and impossible’.”

MN 115:19.5They understand: ‘It’s impossible that someone who has engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind could, for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a place of loss, the underworld, a lower realm, hell. MN 115:19.6But it is possible that someone who has engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind could, for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’

MN 115:2.1“Whatever dangers there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute. MN 115:2.10The fool is hazardous, but the astute person is not. MN 115:2.11There’s no danger, peril, or hazard that comes from the astute. MN 115:2.12So you should train like this: ‘We shall be astute, we shall be inquirers.’” MN 115:2.2Whatever perils there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute. MN 115:2.3Whatever hazards there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute. MN 115:2.4It’s like a fire that spreads from a hut made of reeds or grass, and burns down even a bungalow, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with latches fastened and windows shuttered. MN 115:2.5In the same way, whatever dangers there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute. MN 115:2.6Whatever perils there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute. MN 115:2.7Whatever hazards there are, all come from the foolish, not from the astute. MN 115:2.8So, the fool is dangerous, but the astute person is safe. MN 115:2.9The fool is perilous, but the astute person is not.

MN 115:20.1When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha, MN 115:20.2“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! MN 115:20.3What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

MN 115:20.4“In that case, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Many Elements’, or else ‘The Four Cycles’, or else ‘The Mirror of the Teaching’, or else ‘The Drum of the Deathless’, or else ‘The Supreme Victory in Battle’.”

MN 115:20.5That is what the Buddha said. MN 115:20.6Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 115:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.62When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha, MN 115:3.2“Sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘astute, an inquirer’?”

MN 115:3.3“Ānanda, it’s when a mendicant is skilled in the elements, in the sense fields, in dependent origination, and in the possible and the impossible. MN 115:3.4That’s how a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘astute, an inquirer’.”

MN 115:4.1“But sir, how is a mendicant qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

MN 115:4.10they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

MN 115:4.2“There are, Ānanda, these eighteen elements: MN 115:4.3the elements of the eye, sights, and eye consciousness; MN 115:4.4the ear, sounds, and ear consciousness; MN 115:4.5the nose, smells, and nose consciousness; MN 115:4.6the tongue, tastes, and tongue consciousness; MN 115:4.7the body, touches, and body consciousness; MN 115:4.8the mind, thoughts, and mind consciousness. MN 115:4.9When a mendicant knows and sees these eighteen elements,

MN 115:5.1BJ 12.196“But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

MN 115:5.2“There could, Ānanda. MN 115:5.3There are these six elements: MN 115:5.4the elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness. MN 115:5.5When a mendicant knows and sees these six elements, MN 115:5.6they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

MN 115:6.1“But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

MN 115:6.2“There could, Ānanda. MN 115:6.3There are these six elements: MN 115:6.4the elements of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, equanimity, and ignorance. MN 115:6.5When a mendicant knows and sees these six elements, MN 115:6.6they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

MN 115:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.63“But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

MN 115:7.2“There could, Ānanda. MN 115:7.3There are these six elements: MN 115:7.4the elements of sensuality and renunciation, malice and good will, and cruelty and harmlessness. MN 115:7.5When a mendicant knows and sees these six elements, MN 115:7.6they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

MN 115:8.1“But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

MN 115:8.2“There could, Ānanda. MN 115:8.3There are these three elements: MN 115:8.4the elements of the sensual realm, the realm of luminous form, and the formless realm. MN 115:8.5When a mendicant knows and sees these three elements, MN 115:8.6they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

MN 115:9.1“But sir, could there be another way in which a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’?”

MN 115:9.2“There could, Ānanda. MN 115:9.3There are these two elements: MN 115:9.4the conditioned element and the unconditioned element. MN 115:9.5When a mendicant knows and sees these two elements, MN 115:9.6they’re qualified to be called ‘skilled in the elements’.”

MN 116:0.2At Isigili

MN 116:1.1BJ 12.206PTS-VP-PLI 3.68So I have heard. MN 116:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Isigili Mountain. MN 116:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 116:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 116:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 116:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 116:2.1“Mendicants, do you see that Mount Vebhāra?”

MN 116:2.10Do you see that Mount Vulture’s Peak?”

MN 116:2.11“Yes, sir.”

MN 116:2.12“It too used to have a different label and description. MN 116:2.13Do you see that Mount Isigili?”

MN 116:2.14“Yes, sir.”

MN 116:2.2“Yes, sir.”

MN 116:2.3“It used to have a different label and description. MN 116:2.4Do you see that Mount Paṇḍava?”

MN 116:2.5“Yes, sir.”

MN 116:2.6“It too used to have a different label and description. MN 116:2.7Do you see that Mount Vepulla?”

MN 116:2.8“Yes, sir.”

MN 116:2.9“It too used to have a different label and description.

MN 116:3.1“It used to have exactly the same label and description.

MN 116:3.10Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 116:3.11“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 116:3.12The Buddha said this:

MN 116:3.2BJ 12.208PTS-VP-PLI 3.69Once upon a time, five hundred Buddhas awakened for themselves dwelt for a long time on this Isigili. MN 116:3.3They were seen entering the mountain, but after entering were seen no more. MN 116:3.4When people noticed this they said: MN 116:3.5‘That mountain swallows these hermits!’ MN 116:3.6That’s how it came to be known as Isigili.

MN 116:3.7I shall declare the names of the Buddhas awakened for themselves; MN 116:3.8I shall extol the names of the Buddhas awakened for themselves; MN 116:3.9I shall teach the names of the Buddhas awakened for themselves.

MN 116:4.1“The Buddhas awakened for themselves who dwelt for a long time on this Isigili were named Ariṭṭha, MN 116:4.10Nītha, MN 116:4.11Tatha, MN 116:4.12Sutavā, MN 116:4.13and Bhāvitatta.

MN 116:4.2Upariṭṭha, MN 116:4.3Tagarasikhin, MN 116:4.4Yasassin, MN 116:4.5Sudassana, MN 116:4.6Piyadassin, MN 116:4.7Gandhāra, MN 116:4.8Piṇḍola, MN 116:4.9Upāsabha,

MN 116:5.1Those saintly beings, untroubled, with no need for hope, MN 116:5.2who each achieved awakening by themselves; MN 116:5.3hear me extol their names, MN 116:5.4the supreme persons, free of thorns.

MN 116:5.5Ariṭṭha, Upariṭṭha, Tagarasikhin, Yasassin, MN 116:5.6Sudassana, and Piyadassin the awakened; MN 116:5.7Gandhāra, Piṇḍola, and Upāsabha, MN 116:5.8Nītha, Tatha, Sutavā, and Bhāvitatta.

MN 116:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.70Sumbha, Subha, Methula, and Aṭṭhama, MN 116:6.10Aṅga and Paṅga, and Guttijita too; MN 116:6.11Passin gave up attachment, suffering’s root, MN 116:6.12while Aparājita defeated Māra’s power.

MN 116:6.13Satthar, Pavattar, Sarabhaṅga, Lomahaṁsa, MN 116:6.14Uccaṅgamāya, Asita, Anāsava, MN 116:6.15Manomaya, and Bandhumant the cutter of conceit, MN 116:6.16and Tadādhimutta the immaculate and resplendent.

MN 116:6.17Ketumbarāga, Mātaṅga, and Ariya, MN 116:6.18then Accuta, Accutagāma, and Byāmaka, MN 116:6.19Sumaṅgala, Dabbila, Supatiṭṭhita, MN 116:6.2and Assumegha, Anīgha, and Sudāṭha, MN 116:6.20Asayha, Khemābhirata, and Sorata.

MN 116:6.21Durannaya, Saṅgha, and also Ujjaya, MN 116:6.22another sage, Sayha of peerless effort. MN 116:6.23There are twelve Ānandas, Nandas, and Upanandas, MN 116:6.24and Bhāradvāja, bearing his final body.

MN 116:6.25Bodhi, also Mahānāma the supreme, MN 116:6.26Kesin, Sikhin, Sundara, and Bhāradvāja, MN 116:6.27Tissa and Upatissa, who’ve both cut the bonds to rebirth, MN 116:6.28Upasīdarin and Sīdarin, who’ve both cut off craving.

MN 116:6.29Maṅgala was awakened, free of greed, MN 116:6.3awakened for themselves, enders of the attachment to rebirth. MN 116:6.30Usabha cut the net, the root of suffering, MN 116:6.31Upanīta who attained the state of peace, MN 116:6.32Uposatha, Sundara, and Saccanāma.

MN 116:6.33PTS-VP-PLI 3.71Jeta, Jayanta, Paduma, and Uppala; MN 116:6.34Padumuttara, Rakkhita, and Pabbata, MN 116:6.35Mānatthaddha, beautiful and free of greed, MN 116:6.36and the Buddha Kaṇha, his mind well freed.

MN 116:6.4Hiṅgū, and Hiṅga the mighty.

MN 116:6.5Two sages named Jāli, and Aṭṭhaka. MN 116:6.6Then the Buddha Kosala and Subāhu; MN 116:6.7Upanemi, Nemi, and Santacitta, MN 116:6.8right and true, stainless and astute.

MN 116:6.9BJ 12.210Kāḷa and Upakāḷa, Vijita and Jita,

MN 116:7.1These and other mighty ones awakened for themselves, MN 116:7.2enders of the attachment to rebirth—MN 116:7.3honor these great hermits who are fully extinguished, MN 116:7.4having slipped all chains, limitless.”
