MN 117:0.2The Great Forty

MN 117:1.1BJ 12.212So I have heard. MN 117:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 117:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 117:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 117:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 117:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 117:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.73In this context, right view comes first. MN 117:10.2And how does right view come first? MN 117:10.3When you understand wrong thought as wrong thought and right thought as right thought, that’s your right view.

MN 117:11.1And what is wrong thought? MN 117:11.2Thoughts of sensuality, of malice, and of cruelty. MN 117:11.3This is wrong thought.

MN 117:12.1And what is right thought? MN 117:12.2Right thought is twofold, I say. MN 117:12.3There is right thought that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment. MN 117:12.4And there is right thought that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.

MN 117:13.1And what is right thought that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment? MN 117:13.2Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness. MN 117:13.3This is right thought that is accompanied by defilements.

MN 117:14.1And what is right thought that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path? MN 117:14.2It’s the thinking—the placing of the mind, thought, applying, application, implanting of the mind, verbal processes—in one of noble mind and undefiled mind, who possesses the noble path and develops the noble path. MN 117:14.3This is right thought that is noble.

MN 117:15.1They make an effort to give up wrong thought and embrace right thought: that’s their right effort. MN 117:15.2Mindfully they give up wrong thought and take up right thought: that’s their right mindfulness. MN 117:15.3So these three things keep running and circling around right thought, namely: right view, right effort, and right mindfulness.

MN 117:16.1BJ 12.216PTS-VP-PLI 3.74In this context, right view comes first. MN 117:16.2And how does right view come first? MN 117:16.3When you understand wrong speech as wrong speech and right speech as right speech, that’s your right view.

MN 117:17.1And what is wrong speech? MN 117:17.2Speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. MN 117:17.3This is wrong speech.

MN 117:18.1And what is right speech? MN 117:18.2Right speech is twofold, I say. MN 117:18.3There is right speech that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment. MN 117:18.4And there is right speech that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.

MN 117:19.1And what is right speech that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment? MN 117:19.2The refraining from lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and talking nonsense. MN 117:19.3This is right speech that is accompanied by defilements.

MN 117:2.1“Mendicants, I will teach you noble right immersion with its vital conditions and its prerequisites. MN 117:2.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 117:2.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 117:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 117:20.1And what is right speech that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path? MN 117:20.2It’s the desisting, abstaining, abstinence, and refraining from the four kinds of bad verbal conduct in one of noble mind and undefiled mind, who possesses the noble path and develops the noble path. MN 117:20.3This is right speech that is noble.

MN 117:21.1They make an effort to give up wrong speech and embrace right speech: that’s their right effort. MN 117:21.2Mindfully they give up wrong speech and take up right speech: that’s their right mindfulness. MN 117:21.3So these three things keep running and circling around right speech, namely: right view, right effort, and right mindfulness.

MN 117:22.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.75In this context, right view comes first. MN 117:22.2And how does right view come first? MN 117:22.3When you understand wrong action as wrong action and right action as right action, that’s your right view.

MN 117:23.1And what is wrong action? MN 117:23.2Killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct. MN 117:23.3This is wrong action.

MN 117:24.1And what is right action? MN 117:24.2Right action is twofold, I say. MN 117:24.3There is right action that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment. MN 117:24.4And there is right action that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.

MN 117:25.1And what is right action that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment? MN 117:25.2Refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct. MN 117:25.3This is right action that is accompanied by defilements.

MN 117:26.1And what is right action that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path? MN 117:26.2It’s the desisting, abstaining, abstinence, and refraining from the three kinds of bad bodily conduct in one of noble mind and undefiled mind, who possesses the noble path and develops the noble path. MN 117:26.3This is right action that is noble.

MN 117:27.1They make an effort to give up wrong action and embrace right action: that’s their right effort. MN 117:27.2Mindfully they give up wrong action and take up right action: that’s their right mindfulness. MN 117:27.3So these three things keep running and circling around right action, namely: right view, right effort, and right mindfulness.

MN 117:28.1BJ 12.218In this context, right view comes first. MN 117:28.2And how does right view come first? MN 117:28.3When you understand wrong livelihood as wrong livelihood and right livelihood as right livelihood, that’s your right view.

MN 117:29.1And what is wrong livelihood? MN 117:29.2Deceit, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material possessions to chase after other material possessions. MN 117:29.3This is wrong livelihood.

MN 117:3.1“And what is noble right immersion with its vital conditions and its prerequisites? MN 117:3.2They are: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, and right mindfulness. MN 117:3.3Unification of mind with these seven factors as prerequisites MN 117:3.4is called noble right immersion with its vital conditions and also with its prerequisites.

MN 117:30.1And what is right livelihood? MN 117:30.2Right livelihood is twofold, I say. MN 117:30.3There is right livelihood that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment. MN 117:30.4And there is right livelihood that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.

MN 117:31.1And what is right livelihood that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment? MN 117:31.2It’s when a noble disciple gives up wrong livelihood and earns a living by right livelihood. MN 117:31.3This is right livelihood that is accompanied by defilements.

MN 117:32.1And what is right livelihood that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path? MN 117:32.2It’s the desisting, abstaining, abstinence, and refraining from wrong livelihood in one of noble mind and undefiled mind, who possesses the noble path and develops the noble path. MN 117:32.3This is right livelihood that is noble.

MN 117:33.1They make an effort to give up wrong livelihood and embrace right livelihood: that’s their right effort. MN 117:33.2Mindfully they give up wrong livelihood and take up right livelihood: that’s their right mindfulness. MN 117:33.3So these three things keep running and circling around right livelihood, namely: right view, right effort, and right mindfulness.

MN 117:34.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.76In this context, right view comes first. MN 117:34.2And how does right view come first? MN 117:34.3Right view gives rise to right thought. Right thought gives rise to right speech. Right speech gives rise to right action. Right action gives rise to right livelihood. Right livelihood gives rise to right effort. Right effort gives rise to right mindfulness. Right mindfulness gives rise to right immersion. Right immersion gives rise to right knowledge. Right knowledge gives rise to right freedom. MN 117:34.4So the trainee has eight factors, while the perfected one has ten factors. MN 117:34.5And here too, the eradication of many bad, unskillful qualities is fully developed due to right knowledge.

MN 117:35.1BJ 12.220PTS-VP-PLI 3.77In this context, right view comes first. MN 117:35.10For one of right effort, wrong effort is worn away. … MN 117:35.11For one of right mindfulness, wrong mindfulness is worn away. … MN 117:35.12For one of right immersion, wrong immersion is worn away. … MN 117:35.13For one of right knowledge, wrong knowledge is worn away. … MN 117:35.14For one of right freedom, wrong freedom is worn away. MN 117:35.15And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong freedom are worn away. MN 117:35.16And because of right freedom, many skillful qualities are fully developed.

MN 117:35.2And how does right view come first? MN 117:35.3For one of right view, wrong view is worn away. MN 117:35.4And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong view are worn away. MN 117:35.5And because of right view, many skillful qualities are fully developed. MN 117:35.6For one of right thought, wrong thought is worn away. … MN 117:35.7For one of right speech, wrong speech is worn away. … MN 117:35.8For one of right action, wrong action is worn away. … MN 117:35.9For one of right livelihood, wrong livelihood is worn away. …

MN 117:36.1So there are twenty on the side of the skillful, and twenty on the side of the unskillful. MN 117:36.2This exposition of the teaching on the Great Forty has been rolled forth. And it cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.

MN 117:37.1BJ 12.222PTS-VP-PLI 3.78If any ascetic or brahmin imagines they can criticize and reject the exposition of the teaching on the Great Forty, they deserve rebuke and criticism on ten legitimate grounds in the present life. MN 117:37.10right knowledge … MN 117:37.11right freedom, they praise and honor the ascetics and brahmins who have wrong freedom. MN 117:37.12If any ascetic or brahmin imagines they can criticize and reject the exposition of the teaching on the Great Forty, they deserve rebuke and criticism on these ten legitimate grounds in the present life.

MN 117:37.2If such a gentleman criticizes right view, they praise and honor the ascetics and brahmins who have wrong view. MN 117:37.3If they criticize right thought … MN 117:37.4right speech … MN 117:37.5right action … MN 117:37.6right livelihood … MN 117:37.7right effort … MN 117:37.8right mindfulness … MN 117:37.9right immersion …

MN 117:38.1Even those wanderers of the past, Vassa and Bhañña of Ukkalā, who taught the doctrines of no-cause, inaction, and nihilism, didn’t imagine that the Great Forty should be criticized or rejected. MN 117:38.2Why is that? MN 117:38.3For fear of blame, attack, and condemnation.”

MN 117:38.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 117:38.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 117:4.1In this context, right view comes first. MN 117:4.2And how does right view come first? MN 117:4.3When you understand wrong view as wrong view and right view as right view, that’s your right view.

MN 117:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.72And what is wrong view? MN 117:5.2‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There are no duties to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’ MN 117:5.3This is wrong view.

MN 117:6.1And what is right view? MN 117:6.2Right view is twofold, I say. MN 117:6.3There is right view that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment. MN 117:6.4And there is right view that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.

MN 117:7.1And what is right view that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment? MN 117:7.2‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are duties to mother and father. There are beings reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are well attained and practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’ MN 117:7.3This is right view that is accompanied by defilements, has the attributes of good deeds, and ripens in attachment.

MN 117:8.1BJ 12.214And what is right view that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path? MN 117:8.2It’s the wisdom—the faculty of wisdom, the power of wisdom, the awakening factor of investigation of principles, and right view as a factor of the path—in one of noble mind and undefiled mind, who possesses the noble path and develops the noble path. MN 117:8.3This is called right view that is noble, undefiled, transcendent, a factor of the path.

MN 117:9.1They make an effort to give up wrong view and embrace right view: that’s their right effort. MN 117:9.2Mindfully they give up wrong view and take up right view: that’s their right mindfulness. MN 117:9.3So these three things keep running and circling around right view, namely: right view, right effort, and right mindfulness.

  • MN 118:0.1Middle Discourses 118

MN 118:0.2Mindfulness of Breathing

MN 118:1.1BJ 12.224PTS-VP-PLI 3.79So I have heard. MN 118:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother, together with several well-known senior disciples, such as MN 118:1.3the venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, Mahākassapa, Mahākaccāna, Mahākoṭṭhita, Mahākappina, Mahācunda, Anuruddha, Revata, Ānanda, and others.

MN 118:10.1In this Saṅgha there are mendicants who, with the ending of the five lower fetters are reborn spontaneously. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. MN 118:10.2There are such mendicants in this Saṅgha.

MN 118:11.1In this Saṅgha there are mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, are once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. MN 118:11.2There are such mendicants in this Saṅgha.

MN 118:12.1In this Saṅgha there are mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening. MN 118:12.2There are such mendicants in this Saṅgha.

MN 118:13.1BJ 12.228PTS-VP-PLI 3.82In this Saṅgha there are mendicants who are committed to developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation … MN 118:14.1the four right efforts … MN 118:14.10rejoicing … MN 118:14.11equanimity … MN 118:14.12ugliness … MN 118:14.13impermanence. MN 118:14.14There are such mendicants in this Saṅgha. MN 118:14.15In this Saṅgha there are mendicants who are committed to developing the meditation on mindfulness of breathing.

MN 118:14.2the four bases of psychic power … MN 118:14.3the five faculties … MN 118:14.4the five powers … MN 118:14.5the seven awakening factors … MN 118:14.6the noble eightfold path. MN 118:14.7There are such mendicants in this Saṅgha. MN 118:14.8In this Saṅgha there are mendicants who are committed to developing the meditation on love … MN 118:14.9compassion …

MN 118:15.1Mendicants, when mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it is very fruitful and beneficial. MN 118:15.2Mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, fulfills the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. MN 118:15.3The four kinds of mindfulness meditation, when developed and cultivated, fulfill the seven awakening factors. MN 118:15.4And the seven awakening factors, when developed and cultivated, fulfill knowledge and freedom.

MN 118:16.1And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?

MN 118:17.1It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut. They sit down cross-legged, with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. MN 118:17.2Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.

MN 118:18.1When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’ MN 118:18.2When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ When breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’ MN 118:18.3They practice breathing in experiencing the whole body. They practice breathing out experiencing the whole body. MN 118:18.4They practice breathing in stilling the body’s motion. They practice breathing out stilling the body’s motion.

MN 118:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.83They practice breathing in experiencing rapture. They practice breathing out experiencing rapture. MN 118:19.2They practice breathing in experiencing bliss. They practice breathing out experiencing bliss. MN 118:19.3They practice breathing in experiencing these emotions. They practice breathing out experiencing these emotions. MN 118:19.4They practice breathing in stilling these emotions. They practice breathing out stilling these emotions.

MN 118:2.1Now at that time the senior mendicants were advising and instructing the junior mendicants. MN 118:2.2Some senior mendicants instructed ten mendicants, while some instructed twenty, thirty, or forty. MN 118:2.3Being instructed by the senior mendicants, the junior mendicants realized a higher distinction than they had before.

MN 118:20.1They practice breathing in experiencing the mind. They practice breathing out experiencing the mind. MN 118:20.2They practice breathing in gladdening the mind. They practice breathing out gladdening the mind. MN 118:20.3They practice breathing in immersing the mind in samādhi. They practice breathing out immersing the mind in samādhi. MN 118:20.4They practice breathing in freeing the mind. They practice breathing out freeing the mind.

MN 118:21.1BJ 12.230They practice breathing in observing impermanence. They practice breathing out observing impermanence. MN 118:21.2They practice breathing in observing fading away. They practice breathing out observing fading away. MN 118:21.3They practice breathing in observing cessation. They practice breathing out observing cessation. MN 118:21.4They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.

MN 118:22.1Mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial.

MN 118:23.1And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?

MN 118:24.1Whenever a mendicant knows that they breathe heavily, MN 118:24.2or lightly, MN 118:24.3or experiencing the whole body, MN 118:24.4or stilling the body’s motion—MN 118:24.5at that time they’re meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 118:24.6For I say that the in-breaths and out-breaths are an aspect of the body. MN 118:24.7That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

MN 118:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.84Whenever a mendicant practices breathing while experiencing rapture, MN 118:25.2or experiencing bliss, MN 118:25.3or experiencing these emotions, MN 118:25.4or stilling these emotions—MN 118:25.5at that time they meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 118:25.6For I say that close attention to the in-breaths and out-breaths is an aspect of feelings. MN 118:25.7That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

MN 118:26.1Whenever a mendicant practices breathing while experiencing the mind, MN 118:26.2or gladdening the mind, MN 118:26.3or immersing the mind in samādhi, MN 118:26.4or freeing the mind—MN 118:26.5at that time they meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 118:26.6There is no development of mindfulness of breathing for someone who is unmindful and lacks awareness, I say. MN 118:26.7That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

MN 118:27.1BJ 12.232PTS-VP-PLI 3.85Whenever a mendicant practices breathing while observing impermanence, MN 118:27.2or observing fading away, MN 118:27.3or observing cessation, MN 118:27.4or observing letting go—MN 118:27.5at that time they meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 118:27.6Having seen with wisdom the giving up of desire and aversion, they watch over closely with equanimity. MN 118:27.7That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

MN 118:28.1That’s how mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, fulfills the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

MN 118:29.1And how are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the seven awakening factors?

MN 118:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.80Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks for the invitation to admonish. MN 118:3.2Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were so very silent. He addressed them:

MN 118:30.1Whenever a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, at that time their mindfulness is established and lucid. MN 118:30.2At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of mindfulness; they develop it and perfect it.

MN 118:31.1As they live mindfully in this way they investigate, explore, and inquire into that principle with wisdom. MN 118:31.2At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of investigation of principles; they develop it and perfect it.

MN 118:32.1As they investigate principles with wisdom in this way their energy is roused up and unflagging. MN 118:32.2At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of energy; they develop it and perfect it.

MN 118:33.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.86When they’re energetic, spiritual rapture arises. MN 118:33.2At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of rapture; they develop it and perfect it.

MN 118:34.1BJ 12.234When the mind is full of rapture, the body and mind become tranquil. MN 118:34.2At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of tranquility; they develop it and perfect it.

MN 118:35.1When the body is tranquil and they feel bliss, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 118:35.2At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of immersion; they develop it and perfect it.

MN 118:36.1They closely watch over that mind immersed in samādhi. MN 118:36.2At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of equanimity; they develop it and perfect it.

MN 118:37.1Whenever a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of feelings … MN 118:38.1mind … MN 118:38.11tranquility … MN 118:38.13immersion … MN 118:38.2principles, at that time their mindfulness is established and lucid. MN 118:38.3At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of mindfulness … MN 118:38.5investigation of principles … MN 118:38.7energy … MN 118:38.9rapture … MN 118:39.2equanimity.

MN 118:4.1“I am satisfied, mendicants, with this practice. MN 118:4.2My heart is satisfied with this practice. MN 118:4.3So you should rouse up even more energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized. MN 118:4.4I will wait here in Sāvatthī for the Komudi full moon of the fourth month.”

MN 118:40.1That’s how the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, when developed and cultivated, fulfill the seven awakening factors.

MN 118:41.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.88And how are the seven awakening factors developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom?

MN 118:42.1It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness, MN 118:42.2investigation of principles, MN 118:42.3energy, MN 118:42.4rapture, MN 118:42.5tranquility, MN 118:42.6immersion,

MN 118:42.7and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

MN 118:43.1That’s how the seven awakening factors, when developed and cultivated, fulfill knowledge and freedom.”

MN 118:43.2That is what the Buddha said. MN 118:43.3Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 118:5.1Mendicants from around the country heard about this, MN 118:5.3and came down to Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.

MN 118:6.1And those senior mendicants instructed the junior mendicants even more. MN 118:6.2Some senior mendicants instructed ten mendicants, while some instructed twenty, thirty, or forty. MN 118:6.3Being instructed by the senior mendicants, the junior mendicants realized a higher distinction than they had before.

MN 118:7.1BJ 12.226Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the Komudi full moon on the fifteenth day of the fourth month—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks. MN 118:7.2Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were so very silent. He addressed them:

MN 118:8.1“This assembly has no nonsense, mendicants, it’s free of nonsense. It consists purely of the essential core. MN 118:8.2Such is this Saṅgha of monks, such is this assembly! MN 118:8.3An assembly such as this is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world. MN 118:8.4Such is this Saṅgha of monks, such is this assembly! MN 118:8.5Even a small gift to an assembly such as this is fruitful, while giving more is even more fruitful. MN 118:8.6Such is this Saṅgha of monks, such is this assembly! MN 118:8.7An assembly such as this is rarely seen in the world. MN 118:8.8Such is this Saṅgha of monks, such is this assembly! MN 118:8.9An assembly such as this is worth traveling many leagues to see, even if you have to carry your own provisions in a shoulder bag.

MN 118:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.81For in this Saṅgha there are perfected mendicants, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. MN 118:9.2There are such mendicants in this Saṅgha.

  • MN 119:0.1Middle Discourses 119

MN 119:0.2Mindfulness of the Body

MN 119:1.1BJ 12.238PTS-VP-PLI 3.89So I have heard. MN 119:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 119:10.1Or suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures. MN 119:10.2They’d compare it with their own body: MN 119:10.3‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’ MN 119:10.5That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:11-14.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.92Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews … MN 119:11-14.2A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews … MN 119:11-14.3A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews … MN 119:11-14.4Bones without sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here a shin-bone, there a thigh-bone, here a hip-bone, there a rib-bone, here a back-bone, there an arm-bone, here a neck-bone, there a jaw-bone, here a tooth, there the skull … MN 119:15-17.2White bones, the color of shells … MN 119:15-17.3Decrepit bones, heaped in a pile … MN 119:15-17.4Bones rotted and crumbled to powder. MN 119:15-17.5They’d compare it with their own body: MN 119:15-17.6‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’ MN 119:15-17.7As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts of the lay life are given up. MN 119:15-17.8Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 119:15-17.9That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.93Furthermore, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 119:18.2They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. MN 119:18.3It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out. MN 119:18.4In the same way, they drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. MN 119:18.5As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts of the lay life are given up. MN 119:18.6Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 119:18.7That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:19.1Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 119:19.2They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion. MN 119:19.3It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and no rainfall to replenish it from time to time. But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water. MN 119:19.4In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion. MN 119:19.6That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:2.1Then after the meal, on return from almsround, several senior mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them.

MN 119:2.2“It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing, MN 119:2.3how the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha has said that mindfulness of the body, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.”

MN 119:2.4But their conversation was left unfinished. Then the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the pavilion. He sat on the seat spread out MN 119:2.5and addressed the mendicants, MN 119:2.6“Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”

MN 119:2.7So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about. The Buddha said:

MN 119:20.1BJ 12.246PTS-VP-PLI 3.94Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 119:20.2They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture. MN 119:20.3It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water. MN 119:20.4In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture. MN 119:20.6That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:21.1Furthermore, a mendicant, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 119:21.2They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not filled with pure bright mind. MN 119:21.3It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth. MN 119:21.4In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not filled with pure bright mind. MN 119:21.5As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts of the lay life are given up. MN 119:21.6Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 119:21.7That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:22.1Anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization. MN 119:22.2Anyone who brings into their mind the great ocean includes all of the streams that run down into it. MN 119:22.3In the same way, anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization.

MN 119:23.1BJ 12.248PTS-VP-PLI 3.95When a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them. MN 119:23.2Suppose a person were to throw a heavy stone ball on a mound of wet clay.

MN 119:23.3What do you think, mendicants? MN 119:23.4Would that heavy stone ball find an entry into that mound of wet clay?”

MN 119:23.5“Yes, sir.”

MN 119:23.6“In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.

MN 119:24.1Suppose there was a dried up, withered log. MN 119:24.2Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking MN 119:24.3to light a fire and produce heat.

MN 119:24.4What do you think, mendicants? MN 119:24.5By drilling the stick against that dried up, withered log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

MN 119:24.6“Yes, sir.”

MN 119:24.7“In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.

MN 119:25.1Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, empty and hollow. MN 119:25.2Then a person comes along with a load of water.

MN 119:25.3What do you think, mendicants? MN 119:25.4Could that person pour water into the jar?”

MN 119:25.5“Yes, sir.”

MN 119:25.6“In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.

MN 119:26.1BJ 12.250PTS-VP-PLI 3.96When a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get hold of them.

MN 119:26.2Suppose a person were to throw a light ball of string at a door-panel made entirely of hardwood.

MN 119:26.3What do you think, mendicants? MN 119:26.4Would that light ball of string find an entry into that door-panel made entirely of hardwood?”

MN 119:26.5“No, sir.”

MN 119:26.6“In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get hold of them.

MN 119:27.1Suppose there was a green, sappy log. MN 119:27.2Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking MN 119:27.3to light a fire and produce heat.

MN 119:27.4What do you think, mendicants? MN 119:27.5By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

MN 119:27.6“No, sir.”

MN 119:27.7“In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get hold of them. MN 119:28.1Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it. MN 119:28.2Then a person comes along with a load of water.

MN 119:28.3What do you think, mendicants? MN 119:28.4Could that person pour water into the jar?”

MN 119:28.5“No, sir.”

MN 119:28.6“In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get hold of them.

MN 119:29.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.97When a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.

MN 119:29.2Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it. MN 119:29.3If a strong man was to pour it on any side, would water pour out?”

MN 119:29.4“Yes, sir.”

MN 119:29.5“In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.

MN 119:3.1“And how, mendicants, is mindfulness of the body developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?

MN 119:30.1Suppose there was a square, walled lotus pond on level ground, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it. MN 119:30.2If a strong man was to open the wall on any side, would water pour out?”

MN 119:30.3“Yes, sir.”

MN 119:30.4“In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case. MN 119:31.1Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready. MN 119:31.2Then a deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes. MN 119:31.3In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.

MN 119:32.1BJ 12.252You can expect ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.

MN 119:33.1They prevail over desire and discontent, and live having mastered desire and discontent whenever they arose.

MN 119:34.1They prevail over fear and dread, and live having mastered fear and dread whenever they arose.

MN 119:35.1They endure cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.

MN 119:36.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.98They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

MN 119:37.1They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again … They control the body as far as the Brahmā realm.

MN 119:38.1With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far. …

MN 119:39.1They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind. …

MN 119:4.1It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut. They sit down cross-legged, with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. MN 119:4.2Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out. MN 119:4.3When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’ MN 119:4.4When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ When breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’ MN 119:4.5They practice breathing in experiencing the whole body. They practice breathing out experiencing the whole body. MN 119:4.6They practice breathing in stilling the body’s motion. They practice breathing out stilling the body’s motion. MN 119:4.7As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts of the lay life are given up. MN 119:4.8Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 119:4.9That’s how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:40.1BJ 12.254PTS-VP-PLI 3.99They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

MN 119:41.1With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

MN 119:42.1They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

MN 119:43.1You can expect these ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.”

MN 119:43.2That is what the Buddha said. MN 119:43.3Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 119:5.1BJ 12.240Furthermore, when a mendicant is walking they know ‘I am walking’. When standing they know ‘I am standing’. When sitting they know ‘I am sitting’. And when lying down they know ‘I am lying down’. MN 119:5.2Whatever posture their body is in, they know it. MN 119:5.3As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts of the lay life are given up. MN 119:5.4Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 119:5.5That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.90Furthermore, a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent. MN 119:6.2As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts of the lay life are given up. MN 119:6.3Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 119:6.4That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:7.1Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth. MN 119:7.10Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 119:7.11That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:7.2‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’

MN 119:7.3It’s as if there were a bag with openings at both ends, filled with various kinds of grains, such as MN 119:7.4fine rice, wheat, mung beans, peas, sesame, and ordinary rice. MN 119:7.5And someone with good eyesight were to open it and examine the contents: MN 119:7.6‘These grains are fine rice, these are wheat, these are mung beans, these are peas, these are sesame, and these are ordinary rice.’ MN 119:7.7In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth. … MN 119:7.9As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts of the lay life are given up.

MN 119:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.91Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements: MN 119:8.2‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’

MN 119:8.3BJ 12.242It’s as if a deft butcher or butcher’s apprentice were to kill a cow and sit down at the crossroads with the meat cut into portions. MN 119:8.4In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements: MN 119:8.5‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’ MN 119:8.6As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts of the lay life are given up. MN 119:8.7Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 119:8.8That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 119:9.1Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering. MN 119:9.2They’d compare it with their own body: MN 119:9.3‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’ MN 119:9.4As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts of the lay life are given up. MN 119:9.5Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi. MN 119:9.6That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

MN 121:0.2The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

MN 121:1.1BJ 12.264PTS-VP-PLI 3.104So I have heard. MN 121:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.

MN 121:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.108Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the dimension of nothingness and the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception—focuses on the oneness dependent on the signless immersion of the heart. MN 121:10.2Their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided in that signless immersion of the heart. MN 121:10.3They understand: MN 121:10.4‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of the dimension of nothingness or the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 121:10.5There is only this modicum of stress, namely that associated with the six sense fields dependent on this body and conditioned by life.’ MN 121:10.6They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the dimension of nothingness. It is empty of the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 121:10.7There is only this that is not emptiness, namely that associated with the six sense fields dependent on this body and conditioned by life.’ MN 121:10.8And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present. MN 121:10.9That’s how emptiness is born in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

MN 121:11.1BJ 12.270PTS-VP-PLI 3.109Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the dimension of nothingness and the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception—focuses on the oneness dependent on the signless immersion of the heart. MN 121:11.2Their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided in that signless immersion of the heart. MN 121:11.3They understand: MN 121:11.4‘Even this signless immersion of the heart is produced by choices and intentions.’ MN 121:11.5They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ MN 121:11.6Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 121:11.7When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

MN 121:11.8They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 121:12.1They understand: MN 121:12.2‘Here there is no stress due to the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, or ignorance. MN 121:12.3There is only this modicum of stress, namely that associated with the six sense fields dependent on this body and conditioned by life.’ MN 121:12.4They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. MN 121:12.5There is only this that is not emptiness, namely that associated with the six sense fields dependent on this body and conditioned by life.’ MN 121:12.6And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present. MN 121:12.7That’s how emptiness is born in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

MN 121:13.1Whatever ascetics and brahmins enter and remain in the pure, ultimate, supreme emptiness—whether in the past, future, or present—all of them enter and remain in this same pure, ultimate, supreme emptiness. MN 121:13.4So, Ānanda, you should train like this: ‘We will enter and remain in the pure, ultimate, supreme emptiness.’ MN 121:13.5That’s how you should train.”

MN 121:13.6That is what the Buddha said. MN 121:13.7Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 121:2.1Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Ānanda came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

MN 121:3.1“Sir, this one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans where they have a town named Townsville. MN 121:3.2There I heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 121:3.3‘Ānanda, these days I usually practice the meditation on emptiness.’ MN 121:3.4I trust I properly heard, learned, attended, and remembered that from the Buddha?”

MN 121:3.5PTS-VP-PLI 3.105“Indeed, Ānanda, you properly heard, learned, attended, and remembered that. MN 121:3.6Now, as before, I usually practice the meditation on emptiness.

MN 121:4.1Consider this stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother. It’s empty of elephants, cows, horses, and mares; of gold and money; and of gatherings of men and women. MN 121:4.10And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present. MN 121:4.11That’s how emptiness is born in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

MN 121:4.2There is only this that is not emptiness, namely, the oneness dependent on the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 121:4.3In the same way, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the village and the perception of people—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of wilderness. MN 121:4.4Their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided in that perception of wilderness. MN 121:4.5They understand: MN 121:4.6‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of village or the perception of people. MN 121:4.7There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of wilderness.’ MN 121:4.8They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the village. It is empty of the perception of people. MN 121:4.9There is only this that is not emptiness, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of wilderness.’

MN 121:5.1BJ 12.266Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of people and the perception of wilderness—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of earth. MN 121:5.10There is only this that is not emptiness, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of earth.’ MN 121:5.11And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present. MN 121:5.12That’s how emptiness is born in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

MN 121:5.2Their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided in that perception of earth. MN 121:5.3As a bull’s hide is rid of folds when fully stretched out by a hundred pegs, MN 121:5.4so too, ignoring the hilly terrain, inaccessible riverlands, stumps and thorns, and rugged mountains, they focus on the oneness dependent on the perception of earth. MN 121:5.5Their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided in that perception of earth. MN 121:5.6They understand: MN 121:5.7‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of people or the perception of wilderness. MN 121:5.8There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of earth.’ MN 121:5.9They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of people. It is empty of the perception of wilderness.

MN 121:6.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.106Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of wilderness and the perception of earth—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite space. MN 121:6.2Their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided in that perception of the dimension of infinite space. MN 121:6.3They understand: MN 121:6.4‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of wilderness or the perception of earth. MN 121:6.5There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite space.’ MN 121:6.6They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of wilderness. MN 121:6.7There is only this that is not emptiness, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite space.’ MN 121:6.8And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present. MN 121:6.9That’s how emptiness is born in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

MN 121:7.1Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of earth and the perception of the dimension of infinite space—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness. MN 121:7.2Their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided in that perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness. MN 121:7.3They understand: MN 121:7.4‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of earth or the perception of the dimension of infinite space. MN 121:7.5There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.’ MN 121:7.6They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of earth. It is empty of the perception of the dimension of infinite space. MN 121:7.7There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.’ MN 121:7.8And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present. MN 121:7.9That’s how emptiness is born in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

MN 121:8.1BJ 12.268PTS-VP-PLI 3.107Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the dimension of infinite space and the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of nothingness. MN 121:8.2Their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided in that perception of the dimension of nothingness. MN 121:8.3They understand: MN 121:8.4‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of the dimension of infinite space or the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness. MN 121:8.5There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of nothingness.’ MN 121:8.6They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the dimension of infinite space. MN 121:8.9That’s how emptiness is born in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

MN 121:9.1Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness and the perception of the dimension of nothingness—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 121:9.2Their mind becomes eager, confident, settled, and decided in that perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 122:1.1BJ 12.272PTS-VP-PLI 3.110So I have heard. MN 122:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

MN 122:12.1While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to talking, they think: MN 122:12.2‘I will not engage in the kind of speech that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such speech doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. Namely: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.’ MN 122:12.3In this way they are aware of the situation. MN 122:12.4‘But I will take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.’ MN 122:12.5In this way they are aware of the situation.

MN 122:13.1BJ 12.278PTS-VP-PLI 3.114While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to thinking, they think: MN 122:13.2‘I will not think the kind of thought that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such thoughts don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.’ MN 122:13.3In this way they are aware of the situation. MN 122:13.4‘But I will think the kind of thought that is noble and emancipating, and brings one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. That is, thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.’ MN 122:13.5In this way they are aware of the situation.

MN 122:14.1There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 122:14.2What five? MN 122:14.3Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 122:14.4Sounds known by the ear … MN 122:14.5Smells known by the nose … MN 122:14.6Tastes known by the tongue … MN 122:14.7Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 122:14.8These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

MN 122:15.1So you should regularly check your own mind: MN 122:15.10In that case, they understand: MN 122:15.11‘I have given up desire and greed for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.’ MN 122:15.12In this way they are aware of the situation.

MN 122:15.2‘Does my mind take an interest in any of these five kinds of sensual stimulation?’ MN 122:15.3Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this: MN 122:15.4‘My mind does take an interest.’ MN 122:15.5In that case, they understand: MN 122:15.6‘I have not given up desire and greed for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.’ MN 122:15.7In this way they are aware of the situation. MN 122:15.8But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this: MN 122:15.9‘My mind does not take an interest.’

MN 122:16.1BJ 12.280PTS-VP-PLI 3.115A mendicant should meditate observing rise and fall in these five grasping aggregates: MN 122:16.2‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form. MN 122:16.3Such is feeling … MN 122:16.4Such is perception … MN 122:16.5Such are choices … MN 122:16.6Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

MN 122:17.1As they do so, they give up the conceit ‘I am’ regarding the five grasping aggregates. MN 122:17.2In that case, they understand: MN 122:17.3‘I have given up the conceit “I am” regarding the five grasping aggregates.’ MN 122:17.4In this way they are aware of the situation.

MN 122:18.1These principles are entirely skillful, with skillful outcomes; they are noble, transcendent, and inaccessible to the Wicked One.

MN 122:19.1What do you think, Ānanda? MN 122:19.2For what reason would a disciple value following the Teacher, even if sent away?”

MN 122:19.3“Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

MN 122:2.1Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms. MN 122:2.10and said to Venerable Ānanda, MN 122:2.11“Many resting places have been spread out at Kāḷakhemaka’s dwelling; MN 122:2.12are many mendicants living there?”

MN 122:2.14“Indeed there are, sir. MN 122:2.15It’s currently the time for making robes.”

MN 122:2.2He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the dwelling of Kāḷakhemaka the Sakyan for the day’s meditation.

MN 122:2.3Now at that time many resting places had been spread out at Kāḷakhemaka’s dwelling. MN 122:2.4The Buddha saw this, MN 122:2.5and wondered, MN 122:2.6“Many resting places have been spread out; MN 122:2.7are there many mendicants living here?”

MN 122:20.1“A disciple should not value following the Teacher for the sake of statements, songs, or discussions. MN 122:20.2Why is that? MN 122:20.3Because for a long time you have learned the teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically. MN 122:20.4But a disciple should value following the Teacher, even if asked to go away, for the sake of talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

MN 122:21.1This being so, Ānanda, there is a peril for the teacher, a peril for the student, and a peril for a spiritual practitioner.

MN 122:22.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.116And how is there a peril for the teacher? MN 122:22.2It’s when some teacher frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw. MN 122:22.3While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country. MN 122:22.4When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence. MN 122:22.5This teacher is said to be imperiled by the teacher’s peril. MN 122:22.6They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. MN 122:22.7That’s how there is a peril for the teacher.

MN 122:23.1And how is there a peril for the student? MN 122:23.2It’s when the student of a teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion, MN 122:23.3frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw. MN 122:23.4While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country. MN 122:23.5When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence. MN 122:23.6This student is said to be imperiled by the student’s peril. MN 122:23.7They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. MN 122:23.8That’s how there is a peril for the student.

MN 122:24.1BJ 12.282PTS-VP-PLI 3.117And how is there a peril for a spiritual practitioner? MN 122:24.10This spiritual practitioner is said to be imperiled by the spiritual practitioner’s peril. MN 122:24.11They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. MN 122:24.12That’s how there is a peril for the spiritual practitioner.

MN 122:24.13And in this context, Ānanda, as compared to the peril of the teacher or the student, the peril of the spiritual practitioner has more painful, bitter results, and even leads to the underworld.

MN 122:24.2It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. MN 122:24.3He frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw. MN 122:24.4While meditating withdrawn, he’s visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country. MN 122:24.5When this happens, he doesn’t enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence. MN 122:24.6But a disciple of this teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion, MN 122:24.7frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw. MN 122:24.8While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country. MN 122:24.9When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.

MN 122:25.1So, Ānanda, treat me as a friend, not as an enemy. MN 122:25.2That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.

MN 122:25.3And how do disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not a friend? MN 122:25.4It’s when the Teacher teaches the Dhamma out of kindness and compassion: MN 122:25.5‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’ MN 122:25.6But their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t pay attention or apply their minds to understand. They proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction. MN 122:25.7That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not a friend.

MN 122:26.1BJ 12.284And how do disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy? MN 122:26.2It’s when the Teacher teaches the Dhamma out of kindness and compassion: MN 122:26.3‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’ MN 122:26.4And their disciples want to listen. They pay attention and apply their minds to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction. MN 122:26.5That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy.

MN 122:26.6PTS-VP-PLI 3.118So, Ānanda, treat me as a friend, not as an enemy. MN 122:26.7That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness. MN 122:27.1I shall not mollycoddle you like a potter with their damp, unfired pots. MN 122:27.2I shall speak, correcting you again and again, MN 122:27.3pressing you again and again. MN 122:27.4The core will stand the test.”

MN 122:27.5That is what the Buddha said. MN 122:27.6Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 122:3.1“Ānanda, a mendicant doesn’t shine who enjoys company and groups, who loves them and likes to enjoy them. MN 122:3.2It’s simply not possible that such a mendicant will get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty. MN 122:3.3But you should expect that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group, will get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is possible.

MN 122:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.111Indeed, Ānanda, it is not possible that a mendicant who enjoys company will enter and remain in the freedom of heart—either that which is temporary and pleasant, or that which is irreversible and unshakable. MN 122:4.2But it is possible that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group will enter and remain in the freedom of heart—either that which is temporary and pleasant, or that which is irreversible and unshakable.

MN 122:5.1BJ 12.274Ānanda, I do not see even a single sight which, with its decay and perishing, would not give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in someone who has desire and lust for it.

MN 122:6.1But the Realized One woke up to this meditation, namely MN 122:6.2to enter and remain in emptiness internally by not focusing on any signs. MN 122:6.4In that case, with a mind slanting, sloping, and inclining to seclusion, withdrawn, and loving renunciation, he invariably gives each of them a talk emphasizing the topic of dismissal.

MN 122:7.1Therefore, if a mendicant might wish: MN 122:7.2‘May I enter and remain in emptiness internally!’ So they should still, settle, unify, and immerse their mind in samādhi internally.

MN 123:0.2Incredible and Amazing

MN 123:1.1BJ 12.286PTS-VP-PLI 3.119So I have heard. MN 123:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 123:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.121I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:10.2‘When the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, she no longer feels sexual desire for men, and she cannot be violated by a man of lustful intent.’ MN 123:10.3This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:11.1I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:11.2‘When the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, she obtains the five kinds of sensual stimulation and amuses herself, supplied and provided with them.’ MN 123:11.3This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:12.1I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:12.2‘When the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, no afflictions beset her. She’s happy and free of bodily fatigue. And she sees the being intent on awakening in her womb, complete with all his various parts, not deficient in any faculty. MN 123:12.3Suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked. And it was strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown. MN 123:12.4And someone with good eyesight were to take it in their hand and examine it: “This beryl gem is naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked. And it’s strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.”

MN 123:12.5In the same way, when the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, no afflictions beset her. She’s happy and free of bodily fatigue. And she sees the being intent on awakening in her womb, complete with all his various parts, not deficient in any faculty.’ MN 123:12.6This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.122I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:13.2‘Seven days after the being intent on awakening is born, his mother passes away and is reborn in the host of Joyful Gods.’ MN 123:13.3This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:14.1I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:14.2‘Other women carry the infant in the womb for nine or ten months before giving birth. Not so the mother of the being intent on awakening. She gives birth after exactly ten months.’ MN 123:14.3This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:15.1BJ 12.292I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:15.2‘Other women give birth while sitting or lying down. Not so the mother of the being intent on awakening. She only gives birth standing up.’ MN 123:15.3This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:16.1I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:16.2‘When the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, gods receive him first, then humans.’ MN 123:16.3This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:17.1I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:17.2‘When the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, before he reaches the ground, four deities receive him and place him before his mother, saying: “Rejoice, O Queen! An illustrious son is born to you.”’ MN 123:17.3This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.123I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:18.2‘When the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, he emerges already clean, unsoiled by waters, mucus, blood, or any other kind of impurity, pure and clean. MN 123:18.3Suppose a jewel-treasure was placed on a cloth from Kāsī. The jewel would not soil the cloth, nor would the cloth soil the jewel. MN 123:18.4Why is that? MN 123:18.5Because of the cleanliness of them both.

MN 123:18.6In the same way, when the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, he emerges already clean, unsoiled by waters, mucus, blood, or any other kind of impurity, pure and clean.’ MN 123:18.7This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:19.1I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:19.2‘When the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, two streams of water appear in the sky, one cool, one warm, for bathing the being intent on awakening and his mother.’ MN 123:19.3This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:2.1Then after the meal, on return from almsround, several senior mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them:

MN 123:2.10and addressed the mendicants: MN 123:2.11“Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”

MN 123:2.12So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about. The Buddha said, MN 123:2.19“Well then, Ānanda, say some more about the incredible and amazing qualities of the Realized One.”

MN 123:2.2“It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing, the power and might of a Realized One! MN 123:2.3For he is able to know the Buddhas of the past who have become completely extinguished, cut off proliferation, cut off the track, finished off the cycle, and transcended suffering. MN 123:2.4He knows the caste they were born in, and also their names, clans, conduct, teaching, wisdom, meditation, and freedom.”

MN 123:2.5When they said this, Venerable Ānanda said, MN 123:2.6“The Realized Ones are incredible, reverends, and they have incredible qualities. MN 123:2.7They’re amazing, and they have amazing qualities.” MN 123:2.8But this conversation among those mendicants was left unfinished.

MN 123:2.9Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall, sat down on the seat spread out,

MN 123:20.1I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:20.2‘As soon as he’s born, the being intent on awakening stands firm with his own feet on the ground. Facing north, he takes seven strides with a white parasol held above him, surveys all quarters, and makes this dramatic proclamation: “I am the foremost in the world! I am the eldest in the world! I am the first in the world! This is my last rebirth. Now there are no more future lives.”’ MN 123:20.3This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

MN 123:21.1BJ 12.294PTS-VP-PLI 3.124I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha: MN 123:21.2‘When the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, then—in this world with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—an immeasurable, magnificent light appears, surpassing the glory of the gods. MN 123:21.3Even in the boundless desolation of interstellar space—so utterly dark that even the light of the moon and the sun, so mighty and powerful, makes no impression—an immeasurable, magnificent light appears, surpassing the glory of the gods. MN 123:21.4And the sentient beings reborn there recognize each other by that light: “So, it seems other sentient beings have been reborn here!” MN 123:21.5And this galaxy shakes and rocks and trembles. And an immeasurable, magnificent light appears in the world, surpassing the glory of the gods.’ MN 123:21.6This too I remember as an incredible and amazing quality of the Buddha.”

MN 123:22.1“Well then, Ānanda, you should also remember this as an incredible and amazing quality of the Realized One. MN 123:22.2It’s that the Realized One knows feelings as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away. MN 123:22.3He knows perceptions as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away. MN 123:22.4He knows thoughts as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away. MN 123:22.5This too you should remember as an incredible and amazing quality of the Realized One.”

MN 123:23.1“Sir, the Buddha knows feelings as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away. MN 123:23.2He knows perceptions as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away. MN 125:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.134In the same way, Aggivessana, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. MN 127:10.1BJ 12.336PTS-VP-PLI 3.148There comes a time, householder, when the deities gather together as one. When they do so, a difference in their color is evident, but not in their radiance. MN 127:12.1It’s not that those deities think, MN 127:12.2‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those deities cling, that’s where they take pleasure. MN 127:12.3It’s like when flies are being carried along on a carrying-pole or basket. MN 127:12.5In the same way, it’s not that those deities think, MN 127:12.6‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those deities cling, that’s where they take pleasure.”

MN 128:16.1BJ 12.352PTS-VP-PLI 3.158“Well, you should work out the reason for that. MN 128:29.2or I perceived limitless light and saw limitless forms. MN 128:29.3And this went on for a whole night, a whole day, even a whole night and day.
