MN 128:3.1Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and told him what was happening, adding: MN 128:3.3“Please, sir go to those mendicants out of compassion.” MN 128:3.4The Buddha consented in silence.

MN 128:30.1BJ 12.358PTS-VP-PLI 3.162After understanding that doubt, MN 128:30.10perception of diversity, MN 128:30.11and excessive concentration on forms are corruptions of the mind, I had given them up.MN 128:30.2loss of focus, MN 128:30.3dullness and drowsiness, MN 128:30.4terror, MN 128:30.5excitement, MN 128:30.6discomfort, MN 128:30.7excessive energy, MN 128:30.8overly lax energy, MN 128:30.9longing,

MN 128:32.1When I had developed immersion in these ways, MN 128:32.2the knowledge and vision arose in me: MN 128:32.3‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there are no more future lives.’”

MN 128:5.1BJ 12.346Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kosambi for alms. MN 128:5.2After the meal, on his return from almsround, he set his lodgings in order. Taking his bowl and robe, he recited these verses while standing right there:

MN 128:6.3While the Saṅgha’s being split,

MN 128:6.9“They abused me, they hit me!

MN 129:0.2The Foolish and the Astute

MN 129:1.1BJ 12.360PTS-VP-PLI 3.163So I have heard. MN 129:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 129:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 129:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 129:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 129:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 129:10.1BJ 12.366PTS-VP-PLI 3.167The wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion. MN 129:10.2They drive red-hot stakes through the hands and feet, and another in the middle of the chest. MN 129:10.3And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

MN 129:11.1The wardens of hell throw them down and hack them with axes. …

MN 129:12.1They hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets. …

MN 129:13.1They harness them to a chariot, and drive them back and forth across burning ground, blazing and glowing. …

MN 129:14.1They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …

MN 129:15.1The wardens of hell turn them upside down and throw them into a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing. MN 129:15.3There they’re seared in boiling scum, and they’re swept up and down and round and round. MN 129:15.4And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

MN 129:16.1The wardens of hell toss them in the Great Hell. MN 129:16.10a hundred leagues around.’

MN 129:16.2Now, about that Great Hell:

MN 129:16.3‘Four are its corners, four its doors, MN 129:16.4neatly divided in equal parts. MN 129:16.5Surrounded by an iron wall, MN 129:16.6of iron is its roof.

MN 129:16.7The ground is even made of iron, MN 129:16.8it burns with fierce fire. MN 129:16.9The heat forever radiates

MN 129:17.1I could tell you many different things about hell. MN 129:17.2So much so that it’s not easy to completely describe the suffering in hell.

MN 129:18.1BJ 12.368There are, mendicants, animals that feed on grass. MN 129:18.2They eat by cropping fresh or dried grass with their teeth. MN 129:18.3And what animals feed on grass? MN 129:18.4Elephants, horses, cattle, donkeys, goats, deer, and various others. MN 129:18.5A fool who used to be a glutton here and did bad deeds here, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of those sentient beings who feed on grass.

MN 129:19.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.168There are animals that feed on dung. MN 129:19.10Chickens, pigs, dogs, jackals, and various others. MN 129:19.11A fool who used to be a glutton here and did bad deeds here, after death is reborn in the company of those sentient beings who feed on dung.

MN 129:19.2When they catch a whiff of dung they run to it, thinking, MN 129:19.3‘There we’ll eat! There we’ll eat!’ MN 129:19.4It’s like when brahmins smell a burnt offering, they run to it, thinking, MN 129:19.5‘There we’ll eat! There we’ll eat!’ MN 129:19.9And what animals feed on dung?

MN 129:2.1“These are the three characteristics, signs, and manifestations of a fool. MN 129:2.2What three? MN 129:2.3A fool thinks poorly, speaks poorly, and acts poorly. MN 129:2.4If a fool didn’t think poorly, speak poorly, and act poorly, then how would the astute know of them, MN 129:2.5‘This fellow is a fool, a bad person’? MN 129:2.6But since a fool does think poorly, speak poorly, and act poorly, then the astute do know of them, MN 129:2.7‘This fellow is a fool, a bad person’.

MN 129:20.1There are animals who are born, live, and die in darkness. MN 129:20.2And what animals are born, live, and die in darkness? MN 129:20.3Moths, maggots, earthworms, and various others. MN 129:20.4A fool who used to be a glutton here and did bad deeds here, after death is reborn in the company of those sentient beings who are born, live, and die in darkness.

MN 129:23.1BJ 12.370I could tell you many different things about the animal realm. MN 129:23.2So much so that it’s not easy to completely describe the suffering in the animal realm.

MN 129:24.1Mendicants, suppose a person were to throw a yoke with a single hole into the ocean. MN 129:24.10Because in that place there’s no principled or moral conduct, and no doing what is good and skillful. MN 129:24.11There they just prey on each other, preying on the weak.

MN 129:24.2The east wind wafts it west; the west wind wafts it east; the north wind wafts it south; and the south wind wafts it north. MN 129:24.3And there was a one-eyed turtle who popped up once every hundred years.

MN 129:24.4What do you think, mendicants? MN 129:24.5Would that one-eyed turtle still poke its neck through the hole in that yoke?”

MN 129:24.6“No, sir. MN 129:24.7Only after a very long time, sir, if ever.”

MN 129:24.8“That one-eyed turtle would poke its neck through the hole in that yoke sooner than a fool who has fallen to the underworld would be reborn as a human being, I say. MN 129:24.9Why is that?

MN 129:25.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.170And suppose that fool, after a very long time, returned to the human realm. MN 129:25.2They’d be reborn in a low class family—a family of outcastes, hunters, bamboo-workers, chariot-makers, or waste-collectors. MN 129:25.3Such families are poor, with little to eat or drink, where life is tough, and food and shelter are hard to find. MN 129:25.4And they’d be ugly, unsightly, deformed, chronically ill—one-eyed, crippled, lame, or half-paralyzed. They don’t get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, perfumes, and makeup; or bed, house, and lighting. MN 129:25.5And they do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 129:25.6When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

MN 129:26.1Suppose a gambler on the first unlucky throw were to lose his wife and child, all his property, and then get thrown in jail. MN 129:26.2But such an unlucky throw is trivial compared to MN 129:26.3the unlucky throw whereby a fool, having done bad things by way of body, speech, and mind, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 129:26.4This is the total fulfillment of the fool’s level.

MN 129:27.1BJ 12.372PTS-VP-PLI 3.171There are these three characteristics, signs, and manifestations of an astute person. MN 129:27.2What three? MN 129:27.3An astute person thinks well, speaks well, and acts well. MN 129:27.4If an astute person didn’t think well, speak well, and act well, then how would the astute know of them, MN 129:27.5‘This fellow is astute, a good person’?

MN 129:28.1But since an astute person does think well, speak well, and act well, then the astute do know of them, MN 129:28.10This is the first kind of pleasure and happiness that an astute person experiences in the present life.

MN 129:28.2‘This fellow is astute, a good person’. MN 129:28.3An astute person experiences three kinds of pleasure and happiness in the present life. MN 129:28.4Suppose an astute person is sitting in a council hall, a street, or a crossroad, MN 129:28.5where people are discussing about what is proper and fitting. MN 129:28.6And suppose that astute person is someone who refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, committing sexual misconduct, lying, and alcoholic drinks that cause negligence. MN 129:28.7Then that astute person thinks, MN 129:28.8‘These people are discussing what is proper and fitting. MN 129:28.9And those good things are found in me and I am seen in them.’

MN 129:29.1Furthermore, an astute person sees that the kings have arrested a bandit, a criminal, and subjected them to various punishments—MN 129:29.2whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘demon’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘grass blades’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded. MN 129:29.3Then that astute person thinks, MN 129:29.4‘The kinds of deeds for which the kings inflict such punishments—those things are not found in me and I am not seen in them!’ MN 129:29.5This is the second kind of pleasure and happiness that an astute person experiences in the present life.

MN 129:3.1A fool experiences three kinds of suffering and sadness in the present life.

MN 129:3.2Suppose a fool is sitting in a council hall, a street, or a crossroad, MN 129:3.3where people are discussing what is proper and fitting. MN 129:3.4And suppose that fool is someone who kills living creatures, steals, commits sexual misconduct, lies, and uses alcoholic drinks that cause negligence. MN 129:3.5Then that fool thinks, MN 129:3.6‘These people are discussing what is proper and fitting. MN 129:3.7But those bad things are found in me and I am seen in them!’ MN 129:3.8This is the first kind of suffering and sadness that a fool experiences in the present life.

MN 129:30.1Furthermore, when an astute person is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past good deeds—good conduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them. MN 129:30.2It is like the shadow of a great mountain peak in the evening as it settles down, rests down, and lays down upon the earth. MN 129:30.3In the same way, when an astute person is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past good deeds—good conduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them. MN 129:30.4Then that astute person thinks, MN 129:30.5‘Well, I haven’t done bad, violent, and depraved things. MN 129:30.6And I have done good and skillful deeds that keep me safe. MN 129:30.7When I pass away, I’ll go to the place where people who’ve done such things go.’ MN 129:30.8So they don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. MN 129:30.9This is the third kind of pleasure and happiness that an astute person experiences in the present life.

MN 129:31.1BJ 12.374PTS-VP-PLI 3.172When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

MN 129:32.1And if there’s anything of which it may be rightly said that MN 129:32.2it is utterly likable, desirable, and agreeable, it is of heaven that this should be said. MN 129:32.4So much so that it’s not easy to give a simile for how pleasurable heaven is.”

MN 129:33.1“It’s possible,” said the Buddha.

MN 129:33.2“Suppose there was a king, a wheel-turning monarch who possessed seven treasures and four blessings, and experienced pleasure and happiness because of them.

MN 129:34.1What seven? MN 129:34.2It’s when, on the fifteenth day sabbath, an anointed aristocratic king has bathed his head and gone upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath. MN 129:35.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.173Then the anointed aristocratic king, taking a ceremonial vase in his left hand, besprinkled the wheel-treasure with his right hand, saying, MN 129:35.10Having plunged into the southern ocean and emerged again, it rolls towards the west. … MN 129:35.11Having plunged into the western ocean and emerged again, it rolls towards the north, followed by the king together with his army of four divisions. MN 129:41.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.176Next, the counselor-treasure appears to the wheel-turning monarch. MN 129:41.2He is astute, competent, intelligent, and capable of getting the king to appoint who should be appointed, dismiss who should be dismissed, and retain who should be retained. MN 129:41.3He approaches the wheel-turning monarch and says, MN 129:41.4‘Relax, sire. I shall issue instructions.’ MN 129:41.5Such is the counselor-treasure that appears to the wheel-turning monarch. MN 129:41.6These are the seven treasures possessed by a wheel-turning monarch.

MN 129:42.1And what are the four blessings?

MN 129:42.2A wheel-turning monarch is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty, more so than other people. MN 129:42.3This is the first blessing.

MN 129:43.1BJ 12.380Furthermore, he is long-lived, more so than other people. MN 129:43.2This is the second blessing.

MN 129:44.1Furthermore, he is rarely ill or unwell, and his stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, more so than other people. MN 129:44.2This is the third blessing.

MN 129:45.1Furthermore, a wheel-turning monarch is as dear and beloved to the brahmins and householders MN 129:45.10And the king addressed his charioteer, MN 129:45.11‘Drive slowly, charioteer, so I can see the brahmins and householders longer!’ MN 129:45.12This is the fourth blessing.

MN 129:45.13These are the four blessings possessed by a wheel-turning monarch.

MN 129:45.2as a father is to his children. MN 129:45.4And the brahmins and householders are as dear to the wheel-turning monarch MN 129:45.5as children are to their father.

MN 129:45.7PTS-VP-PLI 3.177Once it so happened that a wheel-turning monarch went with his army of four divisions to visit a park. MN 129:45.8Then the brahmins and householders went up to him and said, MN 129:45.9‘Slow down, Your Majesty, so we may see you longer!’

MN 129:46.1What do you think, mendicants? MN 129:46.2Would a wheel-turning monarch who possessed these seven treasures and these four blessings experience pleasure and happiness because of them?”

MN 129:46.3“Sir, a wheel-turning monarch who possessed even a single one of these treasures would experience pleasure and happiness because of that, let alone all seven treasures and four blessings!”

MN 129:47.1Then the Buddha, picking up a stone the size of his palm, addressed the mendicants, MN 129:47.2“What do you think, mendicants? MN 129:47.3Which is bigger: the stone the size of my palm that I’ve picked up, or the Himalayas, the king of mountains?”

MN 129:47.4“Sir, the stone you’ve picked up is tiny. Compared to the Himalayas, it doesn’t count, it’s not worth a fraction, there’s no comparison.”

MN 129:47.5“In the same way, compared to the happiness of heaven, the pleasure and happiness experienced by a wheel-turning monarch due to those seven treasures and those four blessings doesn’t even count, it’s not even a fraction, there’s no comparison.

MN 129:48.1BJ 12.382PTS-VP-PLI 3.178And suppose that astute person, after a very long time, returned to the human realm. MN 129:48.2They’d be reborn in a well-to-do family of aristocrats, brahmins, or householders—rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain. MN 129:48.3And they’d be attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. They’d get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, perfumes, and makeup; and a bed, house, and lighting. MN 129:48.4And they do good things by way of body, speech, and mind. MN 129:48.5When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

MN 129:49.1Suppose a gambler on the first lucky throw was to win a big pile of money. MN 129:49.2But such a lucky throw is trivial compared to MN 129:49.3the lucky throw whereby an astute person, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 129:49.4This is the total fulfillment of the astute person’s level.”

MN 129:49.5That is what the Buddha said. MN 129:49.6Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 129:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.165Furthermore, when a fool is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past bad deeds—misconduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them. MN 129:5.2It is like the shadow of a great mountain peak in the evening as it settles down, rests down, and lays down upon the earth. MN 129:5.3In the same way, when a fool is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past bad deeds—misconduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them. MN 129:5.4Then that fool thinks, MN 129:5.5‘Well, I haven’t done good and skillful things that keep me safe. MN 129:5.6And I have done bad, violent, and depraved things. MN 129:5.7When I depart, I’ll go to the place where people who’ve done such things go.’ MN 129:5.8They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breasts and falling into confusion. MN 129:5.9This is the third kind of suffering and sadness that a fool experiences in the present life.

MN 129:6.1BJ 12.364Having done bad things by way of body, speech, and mind, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

MN 129:7.1And if there’s anything of which it may be rightly said that MN 129:7.2it is utterly unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable, it is of hell that this should be said. MN 129:7.4So much so that it’s not easy to give a simile for how painful hell is.”

MN 129:7.5PTS-VP-PLI 3.166When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha, MN 129:7.6“But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”

MN 129:8.1“It’s possible,” said the Buddha.

MN 129:8.10The king would say, MN 129:8.11‘Go, my men, and strike this man in the midday with a hundred spears!’ MN 129:8.12The king’s men did as they were told. MN 129:8.13Then late in the afternoon the king would say, MN 129:8.14‘My men, how is that man?’ MN 129:8.15‘He’s still alive, Your Majesty.’ MN 129:8.16The king would say, MN 129:8.17‘Go, my men, and strike this man in the late afternoon with a hundred spears!’ MN 129:8.18The king’s men did as they were told.

MN 130:0.2Messengers of the Gods

MN 130:1.1BJ 12.384So I have heard. MN 130:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 130:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 130:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 130:10.1Then the wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion. MN 130:10.2They drive red-hot stakes through the hands and feet, and another in the middle of the chest. MN 130:10.3And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

MN 130:11.1Then the wardens of hell throw them down and hack them with axes. …

MN 130:12.1They hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets. …

MN 130:13.1They harness them to a chariot, and drive them back and forth across burning ground, blazing and glowing. …

MN 130:14.1They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …

MN 130:15.1Then the wardens of hell turn them upside down and throw them in a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing. MN 130:15.3There they’re seared in boiling scum, and they’re swept up and down and round and round. MN 130:15.4And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

MN 130:16.1Then the wardens of hell toss them into the Great Hell. MN 130:16.10a hundred leagues around.’

MN 130:16.2Now, about that Great Hell:

MN 130:16.3‘Four are its corners, four its doors, MN 130:16.4neatly divided in equal parts. MN 130:16.5Surrounded by an iron wall, MN 130:16.6of iron is its roof.

MN 130:16.7The ground is even made of iron, MN 130:16.8it burns with fierce fire. MN 130:16.9The heat forever radiates

MN 130:17.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.184Now in the Great Hell, flames surge out of the walls and crash into the opposite wall: from east to west, from west to east, from north to south, from south to north, from bottom to top, from top to bottom. MN 130:17.2And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

MN 130:18.1There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, the eastern gate of the Great Hell is opened. MN 130:18.10And as they run, their outer skin, inner skin, flesh, and sinews burn and even their bones smoke. MN 130:18.12And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

MN 130:18.2So they run there as fast as they can. MN 130:18.3And as they run, their outer skin, inner skin, flesh, and sinews burn and even their bones smoke. MN 130:2.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.179“Mendicants, suppose there were two houses with doors. A person with good eyesight standing in between them would see people entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.

MN 130:2.2In the same way, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, or among humans. These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the ghost realm, the animal realm, or in a lower realm, a bad destination, a world of misery, hell.’

MN 130:20.1BJ 12.394PTS-VP-PLI 3.185Immediately adjacent to the Great Hell is the vast Dung Hell. MN 130:20.2And that’s where they fall. MN 130:20.4And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

MN 130:22.1Immediately adjacent to the Hell of Hot Coals is the vast Hell of the Red Silk-Cotton Wood. It’s a league high, full of sixteen-inch thorns, burning, blazing, and glowing. MN 131:0.2One Fine Night

MN 131:1.1BJ 12.398So I have heard. MN 131:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 131:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 131:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 131:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 131:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 131:10.1Don’t run back to the past, MN 131:10.10who knows, tomorrow may bring death! MN 131:10.11For there is no bargain to be struck MN 131:10.12with Death and his mighty hordes.

MN 131:10.13The peaceful sage explained it’s those MN 131:10.14who keenly meditate like this, MN 131:10.15tireless all night and day, MN 131:10.16who truly have that one fine night.

MN 131:10.2don’t hope for the future. MN 131:10.3What’s past is left behind; MN 131:10.4the future has not arrived;

MN 131:10.5and phenomena in the present MN 131:10.6are clearly seen in every case. MN 131:10.7Knowing this, foster it—MN 131:10.8unfaltering, unshakable.

MN 131:10.9BJ 12.402Today’s the day to keenly work—

MN 131:11.1And that’s what I meant when I said: ‘I shall teach you the passage for recitation and the analysis of One Fine Night.’”

MN 131:11.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 131:11.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 131:2.1“I shall teach you the passage for recitation and the analysis of One Fine Night. MN 131:2.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 131:2.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 131:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 131:3.1“Don’t run back to the past, MN 131:3.10who knows, tomorrow may bring death! MN 131:3.11For there is no bargain to be struck MN 131:3.12with Death and his mighty hordes.

MN 131:3.13The peaceful sage explained it’s those MN 131:3.14who keenly meditate like this, MN 131:3.15tireless all night and day, MN 131:3.16who truly have that one fine night.

MN 131:3.2don’t hope for the future. MN 131:3.3What’s past is left behind; MN 131:3.4the future has not arrived;

MN 131:3.5and phenomena in the present MN 131:3.6are clearly seen in every case. MN 131:3.7Knowing this, foster it—MN 131:3.8unfaltering, unshakable.

MN 131:3.9Today’s the day to keenly work—

MN 131:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.188And how do you run back to the past? MN 131:4.2You muster delight there, thinking: ‘I had such form in the past.’ … ‘I had such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the past.’ MN 131:4.3That’s how you run back to the past.

MN 131:5.1And how do you not run back to the past? MN 131:5.2You don’t muster delight there, thinking: ‘I had such form in the past.’ … ‘I had such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the past.’ MN 131:5.3That’s how you don’t run back to the past.

MN 131:6.1BJ 12.400And how do you hope for the future? MN 131:6.2You muster delight there, thinking: ‘May I have such form in the future.’ … ‘May I have such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the future.’ MN 131:6.3That’s how you hope for the future.

MN 131:7.1And how do you not hope for the future? MN 131:7.2You don’t muster delight there, thinking: ‘May I have such form in the future.’ … ‘May I have such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the future.’ MN 131:7.3That’s how you don’t hope for the future.

MN 131:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.189And how do you falter amid presently arisen phenomena? MN 131:8.2It’s when an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 131:8.3They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form. MN 131:8.4They regard feeling … MN 131:8.5perception … MN 131:8.6choices … MN 131:8.7consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness. MN 131:8.8That’s how you falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

MN 131:9.1And how do you not falter amid presently arisen phenomena? MN 131:9.2It’s when an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 131:9.3They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form. MN 131:9.4They don’t regard feeling … MN 131:9.5perception … MN 131:9.6choices … MN 131:9.7consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness. MN 131:9.8That’s how you don’t falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

MN 133:0.2Mahākaccāna and One Fine Night

MN 133:1.1BJ 12.410PTS-VP-PLI 3.192So I have heard. MN 133:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Hot Springs Monastery.

MN 133:1.3Then Venerable Samiddhi rose at the crack of dawn and went to the hot springs to bathe. MN 133:1.4When he had bathed and emerged from the water he stood in one robe drying himself.

MN 133:1.5Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire hot springs, went up to Samiddhi, stood to one side, and said to Samiddhi:

MN 133:10.1“Certainly he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is supreme. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One. MN 133:10.2That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter. MN 133:10.3We should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer. MN 133:10.4Still, Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. MN 133:10.5He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha. MN 133:10.6Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”

MN 133:11.1“Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 133:11.2“Yes, reverend,” they replied. MN 133:11.3Venerable Mahākaccāna said this:

MN 133:12.1“Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:

MN 133:12.2‘Don’t run back to the past … MN 133:12.4not slacking off by night or day, MN 133:12.5who truly have that one fine night.’

MN 133:12.6And this is how I understand the detailed meaning of this passage for recitation.

MN 133:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.196And how do you run back to the past? MN 133:13.10That’s how you run back to the past.

MN 133:13.2Consciousness gets tied up there with desire and lust, thinking: ‘In the past I had such eyes and such sights.’ MN 133:13.3So you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you run back to the past.

MN 133:13.4Consciousness gets tied up there with desire and lust, thinking: ‘In the past I had such ears and such sounds … MN 133:13.5such a nose and such smells … MN 133:13.6such a tongue and such tastes … MN 133:13.7such a body and such touches … MN 133:13.8such a mind and such thoughts.’ MN 133:13.9So you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you run back to the past.

MN 133:14.1BJ 12.418And how do you not run back to the past? MN 133:14.10That’s how you don’t run back to the past.

MN 133:14.2Consciousness doesn’t get tied up there with desire and lust, thinking: ‘In the past I had such eyes and such sights.’ MN 133:14.3So you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer run back to the past.

MN 133:14.4Consciousness doesn’t get tied up there with desire and lust, thinking: ‘In the past I had such ears and such sounds … MN 133:14.5such a nose and such smells … MN 133:14.6such a tongue and such tastes … MN 133:14.7such a body and such touches … MN 133:14.8such a mind and such thoughts.’ MN 133:14.9So you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer run back to the past.

MN 133:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.197And how do you hope for the future? MN 133:15.10That’s how you hope for the future.

MN 133:15.2The heart is set on getting what it does not have, thinking: ‘May I have such eyes and such sights in the future.’ MN 133:15.3So you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you hope for the future. MN 133:15.4The heart is set on getting what it does not have, thinking: ‘May I have such ears and such sounds … MN 133:15.5such a nose and such smells … MN 133:15.6such a tongue and such tastes … MN 133:15.7such a body and such touches … MN 133:15.8such a mind and such thoughts in the future.’ MN 133:15.9So you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you hope for the future.

MN 133:16.1And how do you not hope for the future? MN 133:16.10That’s how you don’t hope for the future.

MN 133:16.2The heart is not set on getting what it does not have, thinking: ‘May I have such eyes and such sights in the future.’ MN 133:16.3So you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer hope for the future. MN 133:16.4The heart is not set on getting what it does not have, thinking: ‘May I have such ears and such sounds … MN 133:16.5such a nose and such smells … MN 133:16.6such a tongue and such tastes … MN 133:16.7such a body and such touches … MN 133:16.8such a mind and such thoughts in the future.’ MN 133:16.9So you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer hope for the future.

MN 133:17.1BJ 12.420And how do you falter amid presently arisen phenomena? MN 133:17.10are presently arisen. MN 133:17.11If consciousness gets tied up there in the present with desire and lust, you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you falter amid presently arisen phenomena. MN 133:17.12That’s how you falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

MN 133:17.2Both the eye and sights MN 133:17.3are presently arisen. MN 133:17.4If consciousness gets tied up there in the present with desire and lust, you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you falter amid presently arisen phenomena. MN 133:17.5Both the ear and sounds … MN 133:17.6nose and smells … MN 133:17.7tongue and tastes … MN 133:17.8body and touches … MN 133:17.9mind and thoughts

MN 133:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.198And how do you not falter amid presently arisen phenomena? MN 133:18.10are presently arisen. MN 133:18.11If consciousness doesn’t get tied up there in the present with desire and lust, you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer falter amid presently arisen phenomena. MN 133:18.12That’s how you don’t falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

MN 133:18.2Both the eye and sights MN 133:18.3are presently arisen. MN 133:18.4If consciousness doesn’t get tied up there in the present with desire and lust, you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer falter amid presently arisen phenomena. MN 133:18.5Both the ear and sounds … MN 133:18.6nose and smells … MN 133:18.7tongue and tastes … MN 133:18.8body and touches … MN 133:18.9mind and thoughts

MN 133:19.1This is how I understand the detailed meaning of that brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.

MN 133:19.7If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this. MN 133:19.8You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

MN 133:2.1“Mendicant, do you remember the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night?”

MN 133:2.10memorize it, MN 133:2.11and remember it. MN 133:2.12It is beneficial and relates to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”

MN 133:2.13That’s what that deity said, MN 133:2.14before vanishing right there.

MN 133:2.2“No, reverend, I do not. MN 133:2.3Do you?”

MN 133:2.4“I also do not. MN 133:2.5But do you remember just the verses on One Fine Night?”

MN 133:2.6“I do not. MN 133:2.7Do you?”

MN 133:2.8“I also do not. MN 133:2.9Learn the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night, mendicant,

MN 133:20.1“Yes, reverend,” said those mendicants, approving and agreeing with what Mahākaccāna said. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, adding: MN 133:20.31“Mahākaccāna clearly explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”

MN 133:21.1“Mahākaccāna is astute, mendicants, he has great wisdom. MN 133:21.2If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Mahākaccāna. MN 133:21.3That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”

MN 133:21.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 133:21.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 133:3.1Then, when the night had passed, Samiddhi went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he added:

MN 133:4.15“Sir, please teach me the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine night.”

MN 133:4.16“Well then, mendicant, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 133:4.17“Yes, sir,” Samiddhi replied. MN 133:4.18The Buddha said this:

MN 133:5.1“Don’t run back to the past, MN 133:5.10who knows, tomorrow may bring death! MN 133:5.11For there is no bargain to be struck MN 133:5.12with Death and his mighty hordes.

MN 133:5.13The peaceful sage explained it’s those MN 133:5.14who keenly meditate like this, MN 133:5.15tireless all night and day, MN 133:5.16who truly have that one fine night.”

MN 133:5.2don’t hope for the future. MN 133:5.3What’s past is left behind; MN 133:5.4the future has not arrived;

MN 133:5.5and phenomena in the present MN 133:5.6are clearly seen in every case. MN 133:5.7Knowing this, foster it—MN 133:5.8unfaltering, unshakable.

MN 133:5.9Today’s the day to keenly work—

MN 133:6.1That is what the Buddha said. MN 133:6.2When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

MN 133:7.1Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered,

MN 133:7.19Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary given by the Buddha?”

MN 133:7.2“The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. …

MN 133:7.20PTS-VP-PLI 3.194Then those mendicants thought:

MN 133:7.21“This Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. MN 133:7.22He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha. MN 133:7.23Let’s go to him, and ask him about this matter.”

MN 133:7.24Then those mendicants went to Mahākaccāna, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 133:7.25When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. They told him what had happened, and said: MN 133:8.6“May Venerable Mahākaccāna please explain this.”

MN 133:9.1BJ 12.416PTS-VP-PLI 3.195“Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But he’d pass over the roots and trunk, imagining that the heartwood should be sought in the branches and leaves. MN 133:9.2Such is the consequence for the venerables. Though you were face to face with the Buddha, you overlooked him, imagining that you should ask me about this matter. MN 133:9.3For he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is supreme. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One. MN 133:9.4That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter. You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

MN 135:0.2The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

MN 135:1.1BJ 12.432So I have heard. MN 135:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 135:10.1BJ 12.436But take some woman or man who isn’t irritable and bad-tempered. MN 135:10.2Even when heavily criticized, they don’t lose their temper, become annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness. MN 135:10.3Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm … MN 135:10.4or if they return to the human realm, they’re lovely …

MN 135:11.1Take some woman or man who is jealous. MN 135:11.2They envy, resent, and begrudge the possessions, honor, respect, reverence, homage, and veneration given to others. MN 135:11.3Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss … MN 135:11.4or if they return to the human realm, they’re insignificant …

MN 135:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.205But take some woman or man who is not jealous … MN 135:12.3Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm … MN 135:12.4or if they return to the human realm, they’re illustrious …

MN 135:13.1Take some woman or man who doesn’t give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, perfumes, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting. MN 135:13.2Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss … MN 135:13.3or if they return to the human realm, they’re poor …

MN 135:14.1BJ 12.438But take some woman or man who does give to ascetics or brahmins … MN 135:14.2Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm … MN 135:14.3or if they return to the human realm, they’re rich …

MN 135:15.1Take some woman or man who is obstinate and vain. MN 135:15.2They don’t bow to those they should bow to. They don’t rise up for them, offer them a seat, make way for them, or honor, respect, esteem, or venerate those who are worthy of such. MN 135:15.3Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss … MN 135:15.4or if they return to the human realm, they’re reborn in a low class family …

MN 135:16.1But take some woman or man who is not obstinate and vain … MN 135:16.3Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm … MN 135:16.4or if they return to the human realm, they’re reborn in an eminent family …

MN 135:17.1BJ 12.440Take some woman or man who doesn’t approach an ascetic or brahmin to ask: MN 135:17.2‘Sir, what is skillful and what is unskillful? MN 135:17.3What is blameworthy and what is blameless? MN 135:17.4What should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated? MN 135:17.5What kind of action will lead to my lasting harm and suffering? Or what kind of action will lead to my lasting welfare and happiness?’ MN 135:17.6Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss … MN 135:17.7or if they return to the human realm, they’re witless …

MN 135:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.206But take some woman or man who does approach an ascetic or brahmin to ask: MN 135:18.2‘Sir, what is skillful and what is unskillful? MN 135:18.3What is blameworthy and what is blameless? MN 135:18.4What should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated? MN 135:18.5What kind of action will lead to my lasting harm and suffering? Or what kind of action will lead to my lasting welfare and happiness?’ MN 135:18.6Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 135:18.7If they’re not reborn in a heavenly realm, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re very wise. MN 135:18.8For asking questions of ascetics or brahmins is the path leading to wisdom.

MN 135:19.1So it is the way people live that makes them how they are, whether short-lived or long-lived, MN 135:19.2sickly or healthy, MN 135:19.3ugly or lovely, MN 135:19.4insignificant or illustrious, MN 135:19.5poor or rich, MN 135:19.6in a low class or eminent family, MN 135:19.7or witless or wise.

MN 135:2.1Then the brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 135:2.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

MN 135:20.1Sentient beings are the owners of their deeds and heir to their deeds. Deeds are their womb, their relative, and their refuge. MN 135:20.2It is deeds that divide beings into MN 135:20.3inferior and superior.”

MN 135:21.1BJ 12.442When he had spoken, Subha said to him, MN 135:21.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! MN 135:21.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways. MN 135:21.4I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 135:21.5From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

MN 135:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.203“What is the cause, Master Gotama, what is the reason why even among those who are human beings some are seen to be inferior and superior? MN 135:3.2For people are seen who are short-lived and long-lived, MN 135:3.3sickly and healthy, MN 135:3.4ugly and beautiful, MN 135:3.5insignificant and illustrious, MN 135:3.6poor and rich, MN 135:3.7from low and eminent families, MN 135:3.8witless and wise. MN 135:3.9What is the reason why even among those who are human beings some are seen to be inferior and superior?”

MN 135:4.1“Student, sentient beings are the owners of their deeds and heir to their deeds. Deeds are their womb, their relative, and their refuge. MN 135:4.2It is deeds that divide beings into MN 135:4.3inferior and superior.”

MN 135:4.4“I don’t understand the meaning of what Master Gotama has said in brief, without explaining the details. MN 135:4.5Master Gotama, please teach me this matter in detail so I can understand the meaning.”

MN 135:4.6“Well then, student, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 135:4.7“Yes, sir,” replied Subha. MN 135:4.8The Buddha said this:

MN 135:5.1“Take some woman or man who kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings. MN 135:5.2Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 135:5.3If they’re not reborn in a place of loss, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re short-lived. MN 135:5.4For killing living creatures is the path leading to a short lifespan.

MN 135:6.1BJ 12.434PTS-VP-PLI 3.204But take some woman or man who gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings. MN 135:6.2Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. MN 135:6.3If they’re not reborn in a heavenly realm, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re long-lived. MN 135:6.4For not killing living creatures is the path leading to a long lifespan.

MN 135:7.1Take some woman or man who habitually hurts living creatures with a fist, stone, rod, or sword. MN 135:7.2Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss … MN 135:7.3or if they return to the human realm, they’re sickly …

MN 135:8.1But take some woman or man who does not habitually hurt living creatures with a fist, stone, rod, or sword. MN 135:8.2Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm … MN 135:8.3or if they return to the human realm, they’re healthy …

MN 135:9.1Take some woman or man who is irritable and bad-tempered. MN 135:9.2Even when lightly criticized they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness. MN 135:9.3Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss … MN 135:9.4or if they return to the human realm, they’re ugly …

MN 136:0.2The Longer Analysis of Deeds

MN 136:1.1BJ 12.444PTS-VP-PLI 3.207So I have heard. MN 136:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

MN 136:10.1BJ 12.450PTS-VP-PLI 3.211But some other ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that it gives rise to clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman. MN 136:13.1In this case, when an ascetic or brahmin says this: MN 136:13.10Why is that? MN 136:13.11Because the Realized One’s knowledge of the great analysis of deeds is otherwise.

MN 136:13.7And when they say: MN 136:13.8‘Those who know this are right. Those who know something else are wrong,’ I also don’t grant them that. MN 136:13.9And when they obstinately stick to what they have known, seen, and understood for themselves, insisting that: ‘This is the only truth, other ideas are silly,’ I also don’t grant them that.

MN 136:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.213In this case, when an ascetic or brahmin says this: MN 136:14.11Because the Realized One’s knowledge of the great analysis of deeds is otherwise.

MN 136:14.5But when they say: MN 136:14.6‘It seems that everyone who kills living creatures … and has wrong view is reborn in a heavenly realm,’ I don’t grant them that. …

MN 136:17.1Now, Ānanda, take the case of the person here who killed living creatures … and had wrong view, and who, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 136:17.2They must have done a bad deed to be experienced as painful either previously or later, or else at the time of death they undertook wrong view. MN 136:17.3And that’s why, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 136:17.4But anyone here who kills living creatures … and has wrong view experiences the result of that in the present life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.

MN 136:18.1BJ 12.456Now, Ānanda, take the case of the person here who killed living creatures … and had wrong view, and who is reborn in a heavenly realm. MN 136:2.1Now at that time Venerable Samiddhi was staying in a wilderness hut.

MN 136:2.10“Reverend Samiddhi, how long has it been since you went forth?”

MN 136:2.11“Not long, reverend: three years.”

MN 136:2.12“Well now, what are we to say to the senior mendicants, when even such a junior mendicant imagines their Teacher needs defending? MN 136:2.13After doing an intentional deed by way of body, speech, or mind, reverend, what does one feel?”

MN 136:2.14“After doing an intentional deed by way of body, speech, or mind, reverend, one feels suffering.” MN 136:2.15Then, neither approving nor dismissing Samiddhi’s statement, Potaliputta MN 136:2.16got up from his seat and left.

MN 136:2.2Then as the wanderer Potaliputta was going for a walk he came up to Venerable Samiddhi and exchanged greetings with him. MN 136:2.3When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to him:

MN 136:2.4“Reverend Samiddhi, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the ascetic Gotama: MN 136:2.5‘Deeds by way of body and speech are done in vain. Only mental deeds are real.’ MN 136:2.6And: ‘There is such an attainment where the one who enters it does not feel anything at all.’”

MN 136:2.7“Don’t say that, Reverend Potaliputta, don’t say that! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say this. MN 136:2.9But, reverend, there is such an attainment where the one who enters it does not feel anything at all.”

MN 136:20.1Now, Ānanda, take the case of the person here who refrained from killing living creatures … and had right view, and who is reborn in hell. MN 136:20.2They must have done a bad deed to be experienced as painful either previously or later, or else at the time of death they undertook wrong view. MN 136:20.3And that’s why, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. MN 136:20.4But anyone here who refrains from killing living creatures … and has right view experiences the result of that in the present life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.

MN 136:21.1So, Ānanda, there are deeds that are ineffective and appear ineffective. There are deeds that are ineffective but appear effective. There are deeds that are effective and appear effective. And there are deeds that are effective but appear ineffective.”

MN 136:21.2That is what the Buddha said. MN 136:21.3Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 136:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.208Soon after he had left, Venerable Samiddhi went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 136:3.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, MN 136:3.3and informed Ānanda of all they had discussed.

MN 136:3.4BJ 12.446When he had spoken, Ānanda said to him, MN 136:3.5“Reverend Samiddhi, we should see the Buddha about this matter. MN 136:3.6Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this. MN 136:3.7As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”

MN 136:3.8“Yes, reverend,” Samiddhi replied.

MN 136:4.1Then Ānanda and Samiddhi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, MN 136:4.2and told him what had happened.

MN 136:5.1When they had spoken, the Buddha said to Ānanda, MN 136:5.2“I don’t recall even seeing the wanderer Potaliputta, Ānanda, so how could we have had such a discussion? MN 136:5.3The wanderer Potaliputta’s question should have been answered after analyzing it, but this foolish person answered definitively.”

MN 136:6.1When he said this, Venerable Udāyī said to him, MN 136:6.10‘After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as pleasant by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels pleasure. MN 136:6.11After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as painful by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels pain. MN 136:6.12After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as neutral by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels neutral.’ MN 136:6.13Answering in this way, Samiddhi would have rightly answered Potaliputta.

MN 136:6.14Still, who are those foolish and incompetent wanderers who follow other paths to understand the Realized One’s great analysis of deeds? MN 136:6.15Ānanda, if only you would all listen to the Realized One’s explanation of the great analysis of deeds.”

MN 136:6.2“But perhaps, sir, Venerable Samiddhi spoke in reference to the statement: MN 136:6.3‘Suffering includes whatever is felt.’”

MN 136:6.4PTS-VP-PLI 3.209But the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda, MN 136:6.5“See how this foolish person Udāyī comes up with an idea? MN 136:6.6I knew that MN 136:6.7he was going to come up with such an irrational idea. MN 136:6.8Right from the start Potaliputta asked about the three feelings. MN 136:6.9Suppose the foolish person Samiddhi had answered the wanderer Potaliputta’s question like this:

MN 136:7.1“Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One! MN 136:7.2Let the Buddha explain the great analysis of deeds. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

MN 136:7.3“Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 136:7.4“Yes, sir,” Ānanda replied. MN 136:7.5The Buddha said this:

MN 136:8.1“Ānanda, these four people are found in the world. MN 136:8.10When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

MN 136:8.2What four? MN 136:8.3Some person here kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. MN 136:8.9But some other person here refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, committing sexual misconduct, or using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view.

MN 136:9.1Now, some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that it gives rise to clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman. MN 137:0.2The Analysis of the Six Sense Fields

MN 137:1.1BJ 12.458So I have heard. MN 137:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 137:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 137:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 137:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 137:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 137:10.1And in this context what are the six kinds of lay happiness? MN 137:10.10These are the six kinds of lay happiness.

MN 137:10.2There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasing, connected with the world’s material delights. Happiness arises when you regard it as a gain to obtain such sights, or when you recollect sights you formerly obtained that have passed, ceased, and perished. MN 137:10.3Such happiness is called lay happiness. MN 137:10.4There are sounds known by the ear … MN 137:10.5Smells known by the nose … MN 137:10.6Tastes known by the tongue … MN 137:10.7Touches known by the body … MN 137:10.8Thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasing, connected with the world’s material delights. Happiness arises when you regard it as a gain to obtain such thoughts, or when you recollect thoughts you formerly obtained that have passed, ceased, and perished. MN 137:10.9Such happiness is called lay happiness.

MN 137:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.218And in this context what are the six kinds of renunciate happiness? MN 137:11.10These are the six kinds of renunciate happiness.

MN 137:11.2When you’ve understood the impermanence of sights—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—happiness arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those sights are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. MN 137:11.3Such happiness is called renunciate happiness. MN 137:11.4When you’ve understood the impermanence of sounds … MN 137:11.5smells … MN 137:11.6tastes … MN 137:11.7touches … MN 137:11.8thoughts—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—happiness arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those thoughts are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. MN 137:11.9Such happiness is called renunciate happiness.

MN 137:12.1BJ 12.462And in this context what are the six kinds of lay sadness? MN 137:12.10These are the six kinds of lay sadness.

MN 137:12.2There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasing, connected with the world’s material delights. Sadness arises when you regard it as a loss to lose such sights, or when you recollect sights you formerly lost that have passed, ceased, and perished. MN 137:12.3Such sadness is called lay sadness. MN 137:12.4There are sounds known by the ear … MN 137:12.5There are smells known by the nose … MN 137:12.6There are tastes known by the tongue … MN 137:12.7There are touches known by the body … MN 137:12.8There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasing, connected with the world’s material delights. Sadness arises when you regard it as a loss to lose such thoughts, or when you recollect thoughts you formerly lost that have passed, ceased, and perished. MN 137:12.9Such sadness is called lay sadness.

MN 137:13.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.219And in this context what are the six kinds of renunciate sadness? MN 137:13.10‘Oh, when will I enter and remain in the same dimension that the noble ones enter and remain in today?’ When you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations like this, sadness arises because of the yearning. MN 137:13.11Such sadness is called renunciate sadness. MN 137:13.12These are the six kinds of renunciate sadness.

MN 137:13.2When you’ve understood the impermanence of sights—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those sights are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Upon seeing this, you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations: MN 137:13.3‘Oh, when will I enter and remain in the same dimension that the noble ones enter and remain in today?’ When you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations like this, sadness arises because of the yearning. MN 137:13.4Such sadness is called renunciate sadness. MN 137:13.5When you’ve understood the impermanence of sounds … MN 137:13.6smells … MN 137:13.7tastes … MN 137:13.8touches … MN 137:13.9thoughts—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those thoughts are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Upon seeing this, you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations:

MN 137:14.1And in this context what are the six kinds of lay equanimity? MN 137:14.10Such equanimity does not transcend the thought. MN 137:14.11That’s why it’s called lay equanimity. MN 137:14.12These are the six kinds of lay equanimity.

MN 137:14.2When seeing a sight with the eye, equanimity arises for the uneducated ordinary person—a foolish ordinary person who has not overcome their limitations and the results of deeds, and is blind to the drawbacks. MN 137:14.3Such equanimity does not transcend the sight. MN 137:14.4That’s why it’s called lay equanimity. MN 137:14.5When hearing a sound with the ear … MN 137:14.6When smelling an odor with the nose … MN 137:14.7When tasting a flavor with the tongue … MN 137:14.8When feeling a touch with the body … MN 137:14.9When knowing a thought with the mind, equanimity arises for the uneducated ordinary person—a foolish ordinary person who has not overcome their limitations and the results of deeds, and is blind to the drawbacks.

MN 137:15.1BJ 12.464And in this context what are the six kinds of renunciate equanimity? MN 137:15.10Such equanimity transcends the thought. MN 137:15.11That’s why it’s called renunciate equanimity. MN 137:15.12These are the six kinds of renunciate equanimity. MN 137:15.13‘The thirty-six positions of sentient beings should be understood.’ MN 137:15.14That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 137:15.2When you’ve understood the impermanence of sights—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—equanimity arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those sights are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. MN 137:15.3Such equanimity transcends the sight. MN 137:15.4That’s why it’s called renunciate equanimity. MN 137:15.5When you’ve understood the impermanence of sounds … MN 137:15.6smells … MN 137:15.7tastes … MN 137:15.8touches … MN 137:15.9thoughts—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—equanimity arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those thoughts are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.

MN 137:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.220‘Therein, relying on this, give up that.’ MN 137:16.10That’s how they are given up.

MN 137:16.11Therein, by relying on the six kinds of renunciate equanimity, give up the six kinds of renunciate happiness. MN 137:16.12That’s how they are given up.

MN 137:16.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

MN 137:16.3Therein, by relying and depending on the six kinds of renunciate happiness, give up and go beyond the six kinds of lay happiness. MN 137:16.4That’s how they are given up.

MN 137:16.5Therein, by relying on the six kinds of renunciate sadness, give up the six kinds of lay sadness. MN 137:16.6That’s how they are given up.

MN 137:16.7Therein, by relying on the six kinds of renunciate equanimity, give up the six kinds of lay equanimity. MN 137:16.8That’s how they are given up.

MN 137:16.9Therein, by relying on the six kinds of renunciate happiness, give up the six kinds of renunciate sadness.

MN 137:17.1BJ 12.466There is equanimity that is diversified, based on diversity, and equanimity that is unified, based on unity.

MN 137:18.1And what is equanimity based on diversity? MN 137:18.2There is equanimity towards sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches. MN 137:18.3This is equanimity based on diversity.

MN 137:19.1And what is equanimity based on unity? MN 137:19.2There is equanimity based on the dimensions of infinite space, infinite consciousness, nothingness, and neither perception nor non-perception. MN 137:19.3This is equanimity based on unity.

MN 137:2.1“Mendicants, I shall teach you the analysis of the six sense fields. MN 137:2.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 137:2.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 137:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 137:20.1Therein, relying on equanimity based on unity, give up equanimity based on diversity. MN 137:20.2That’s how it is given up.

MN 137:20.3PTS-VP-PLI 3.221Relying on non-identification, give up equanimity based on unity. MN 137:20.4That’s how it is given up. MN 137:20.5‘Therein, relying on this, give up that.’ MN 137:20.6That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 137:21.1‘The Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness in three cases, by virtue of which they are a Teacher worthy to instruct a group.’ MN 137:21.2That’s what I said, MN 137:21.3but why did I say it?

MN 137:22.1The first case is when the Teacher teaches the Dhamma out of kindness and compassion: MN 137:22.2‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’ MN 137:22.3But their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t pay attention or apply their minds to understand. They proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction. MN 137:22.4In this case the Realized One is not displeased, he does not feel displeasure. He remains unaffected, mindful and aware. MN 137:22.5This is the first case in which the Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness.

MN 137:23.1The next case is when the Teacher teaches the Dhamma out of kindness and compassion: MN 137:23.2‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’ MN 137:23.3And some of their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t pay attention or apply their minds to understand. They proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction. MN 137:23.4But some of their disciples do want to listen. They pay attention and apply their minds to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction. MN 137:23.5In this case the Realized One is not displeased, MN 137:23.6nor is he pleased. MN 137:23.8Rejecting both displeasure and pleasure, he remains equanimous, mindful and aware. MN 137:23.9This is the second case in which the Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness.

MN 137:24.1BJ 12.468PTS-VP-PLI 3.222The next case is when the Teacher teaches the Dhamma out of kindness and compassion: MN 137:24.2‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’ MN 137:24.3And their disciples want to listen. They pay attention and apply their minds to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction. MN 137:24.4In this case the Realized One is not pleased, he does not feel pleasure. He remains unaffected, mindful and aware. MN 137:24.5This is the third case in which the Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness. MN 137:24.6‘The Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness in three cases, by virtue of which they are a Teacher worthy to instruct a group.’ MN 137:24.7That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 137:25.1‘Of all meditation teachers, it is he that is called the supreme guide for those who wish to train.’ MN 137:25.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 137:25.3Driven by an elephant trainer, an elephant in training proceeds in just one direction: MN 137:25.4east, west, north, or south.

MN 137:26.1Driven by a horse trainer, a horse in training proceeds in just one direction: MN 137:26.2east, west, north, or south. MN 137:26.3Driven by an ox trainer, an ox in training proceeds in just one direction: MN 137:26.4east, west, north, or south. MN 137:26.5But driven by the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, a person in training proceeds in eight directions:

MN 137:27.1Having physical form, they see visions. MN 137:27.10This is the fifth direction. MN 137:27.11Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness. MN 137:27.12This is the sixth direction. MN 137:27.13Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. MN 137:27.14This is the seventh direction. MN 137:27.15Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling. MN 137:27.16This is the eighth direction. MN 137:27.17Driven by the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, a person in training proceeds in these eight directions.

MN 137:27.2This is the first direction. MN 137:27.3Not perceiving physical form internally, they see visions externally. MN 137:27.4This is the second direction. MN 137:27.5They’re focused only on beauty. MN 137:27.6This is the third direction. MN 137:27.7Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space. MN 137:27.8This is the fourth direction. MN 137:27.9Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

MN 137:28.1‘Of all meditation teachers, it is he that is called the supreme guide for those who wish to train.’ MN 137:28.2That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

MN 137:28.3That is what the Buddha said. MN 137:28.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 137:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.216“‘The six interior sense fields should be understood. The six exterior sense fields should be understood. The six classes of consciousness should be understood. The six classes of contact should be understood. The eighteen mental preoccupations should be understood. The thirty-six positions of sentient beings should be understood. Therein, relying on this, give up that. The Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness in three cases, by virtue of which they are a Teacher worthy to instruct a group. Of all meditation teachers, it is he that is called the supreme guide for those who wish to train.’ MN 137:3.2This is the recitation passage for the analysis of the six sense fields.

MN 137:4.1‘The six interior sense fields should be understood.’ MN 137:4.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 137:4.3There are the sense fields of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. MN 137:4.4‘The six interior sense fields should be understood.’ MN 137:4.5That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 137:5.1‘The six exterior sense fields should be understood.’ MN 137:5.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 137:5.3There are the sense fields of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts. MN 137:5.4‘The six exterior sense fields should be understood.’ MN 137:5.5That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 137:6.1‘The six classes of consciousness should be understood.’ MN 137:6.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 137:6.3There are eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness. MN 137:6.4‘The six classes of consciousness should be understood.’ MN 137:6.5That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 137:7.1‘The six classes of contact should be understood.’ MN 137:7.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 137:7.3There is contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. MN 137:7.4‘The six classes of contact should be understood.’ MN 137:7.5That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 137:8.1BJ 12.460PTS-VP-PLI 3.217‘The eighteen mental preoccupations should be understood.’ MN 137:8.10That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 137:8.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 137:8.3Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity. MN 137:8.4Hearing a sound with the ear … MN 137:8.5Smelling an odor with the nose … MN 137:8.6Tasting a flavor with the tongue …

MN 137:8.7Feeling a touch with the body … MN 137:8.8Becoming conscious of a thought with the mind, one is preoccupied with a thought that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity. MN 137:8.9So there are six preoccupations with happiness, six preoccupations with sadness, and six preoccupations with equanimity. ‘The eighteen mental preoccupations should be understood.’

MN 137:9.1‘The thirty-six positions of sentient beings should be understood.’ MN 137:9.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 137:9.3There are six kinds of lay happiness and six kinds of renunciate happiness. There are six kinds of lay sadness and six kinds of renunciate sadness. There are six kinds of lay equanimity and six kinds of renunciate equanimity.
