MN 138:0.2The Analysis of a Recitation Passage

MN 138:1.1BJ 12.470PTS-VP-PLI 3.223So I have heard. MN 138:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 138:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 138:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 138:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 138:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 138:10.1And how is consciousness scattered and diffused externally? MN 138:10.2Take a mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes. Their consciousness follows after the features of that sight, tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in its features. So their consciousness is said to be scattered and diffused externally. MN 138:10.3When they hear a sound with their ears … MN 138:10.4When they smell an odor with their nose … MN 138:10.5When they taste a flavor with their tongue … MN 138:10.6When they feel a touch with their body … MN 138:10.7When they know a thought with their mind, their consciousness follows after the features of that thought, tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in its features. So their consciousness is said to be scattered and diffused externally. MN 138:10.8That’s how consciousness is scattered and diffused externally.

MN 138:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.226And how is consciousness not scattered and diffused externally? MN 138:11.2Take a mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes. Their consciousness doesn’t follow after the features of that sight, and is not tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in its features. So their consciousness is said to be not scattered and diffused externally. MN 138:11.3When they hear a sound with their ears … MN 138:11.4When they smell an odor with their nose … MN 138:11.5When they taste a flavor with their tongue … MN 138:11.6When they feel a touch with their body … MN 138:11.7When they know a thought with their mind, their consciousness doesn’t follow after the features of that thought, and is not tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in its features. So their consciousness is said to be not scattered and diffused externally. MN 138:11.8That’s how consciousness is not scattered and diffused externally.

MN 138:12.1BJ 12.476And how is their consciousness stuck internally? MN 138:12.2Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 138:12.3Their consciousness follows after that rapture and bliss born of seclusion, tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in that rapture and bliss born of seclusion. So their mind is said to be stuck internally.

MN 138:13.1Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 138:13.2Their consciousness follows after that rapture and bliss born of immersion, tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in that rapture and bliss born of immersion. So their mind is said to be stuck internally.

MN 138:14.1Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 138:14.2Their consciousness follows after that equanimity, tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in that equanimous bliss. So their mind is said to be stuck internally.

MN 138:15.1Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 138:15.2Their consciousness follows after that neutral feeling, tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in that neutral feeling. So their mind is said to be stuck internally. MN 138:15.3That’s how their consciousness is stuck internally.

MN 138:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.227And how is their consciousness not stuck internally? MN 138:16.2It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 138:16.3Their consciousness doesn’t follow after that rapture and bliss born of seclusion, and is not tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in that rapture and bliss born of seclusion. So their mind is said to be not stuck internally.

MN 138:17.1Furthermore, they enter the second absorption … MN 138:17.2Their consciousness doesn’t follow after that rapture and bliss born of immersion …

MN 138:18.1Furthermore, they enter and remain in the third absorption … MN 138:18.2Their consciousness doesn’t follow after that equanimity, and is not tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in that equanimous bliss. So their mind is said to be not stuck internally.

MN 138:19.1BJ 12.478Furthermore, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption … MN 138:19.2Their consciousness doesn’t follow after that neutral feeling, and is not tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in that neutral feeling. So their mind is said to be not stuck internally. MN 138:19.3That’s how their consciousness is not stuck internally.

MN 138:2.1“Mendicants, I shall teach you the analysis of a recitation passage. MN 138:2.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 138:2.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 138:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 138:20.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.228And how are they anxious because of grasping? MN 138:20.10choices … MN 138:20.11consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness. MN 138:20.12But that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes, MN 138:20.13and consciousness latches on to the perishing of consciousness. MN 138:20.14Anxieties occupy their mind, born of latching on to the perishing of consciousness, and originating in accordance with natural principles. MN 138:20.15So they become frightened, worried, concerned, and anxious because of grasping. MN 138:20.16That’s how they are anxious because of grasping.

MN 138:20.2It’s when an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 138:20.3They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form. MN 138:20.4But that form of theirs decays and perishes, MN 138:20.5and consciousness latches on to the perishing of form. MN 138:20.6Anxieties occupy their mind, born of latching on to the perishing of form, and originating in accordance with natural principles. MN 138:20.7So they become frightened, worried, concerned, and anxious because of grasping. MN 138:20.8They regard feeling … MN 138:20.9perception …

MN 138:21.1And how are they not anxious because of grasping? MN 138:21.10choices … MN 138:21.11consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness. MN 138:21.12When that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes, MN 138:21.13consciousness doesn’t latch on to the perishing of consciousness. MN 138:21.14Anxieties—born of latching on to the perishing of consciousness and originating in accordance with natural principles—don’t occupy their mind. MN 138:21.15So they don’t become frightened, worried, concerned, or anxious because of grasping. MN 138:21.16That’s how they are not anxious because of grasping.

MN 138:21.2It’s when an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons. MN 138:21.3They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form. MN 138:21.4When that form of theirs decays and perishes, MN 138:21.5consciousness doesn’t latch on to the perishing of form. MN 138:21.6Anxieties—born of latching on to the perishing of form and originating in accordance with natural principles—don’t occupy their mind. MN 138:21.7So they don’t become frightened, worried, concerned, or anxious because of grasping. MN 138:21.8They don’t regard feeling … MN 138:21.9perception …

MN 138:22.1BJ 12.480PTS-VP-PLI 3.229The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail: MN 138:22.2‘A mendicant should examine in any such a way that their consciousness is neither scattered and diffused externally nor stuck internally, and they are not anxious because of grasping. MN 138:22.3When this is the case and they are no longer anxious, there is for them no coming to be of the origin of suffering—of rebirth, old age, and death in the future.’ MN 138:22.4And this is how I understand the detailed meaning of this passage for recitation. MN 138:22.5If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this. MN 138:22.6You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

MN 138:23.1“Yes, reverend,” said those mendicants, approving and agreeing with what Mahākaccāna said. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, saying:

MN 138:23.15“Mahākaccāna clearly explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”

MN 138:24.1“Mahākaccāna is astute, mendicants, he has great wisdom. MN 138:24.2If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Mahākaccāna. MN 138:24.3That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”

MN 138:24.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 138:24.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 138:3.1“A mendicant should examine in any such a way that their consciousness is neither scattered and diffused externally nor stuck internally, and they are not anxious because of grasping. MN 138:3.2When this is the case and they are no longer anxious, there is for them no coming to be of the origin of suffering—of rebirth, old age, and death in the future.”

MN 138:4.1That is what the Buddha said. MN 138:4.2When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

MN 138:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.224Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered, MN 138:5.2“The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. MN 138:5.5Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha?”

MN 138:5.6Then those mendicants thought, MN 138:5.7“This Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. MN 138:5.8He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha. MN 138:5.9Let’s go to him, and ask him about this matter.”

MN 138:6.1Then those mendicants went to Mahākaccāna, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 138:6.15“May Venerable Mahākaccāna please explain this.”

MN 138:6.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. They told him what had happened, and said,

MN 138:7.1BJ 12.474PTS-VP-PLI 3.225“Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But he’d pass over the roots and trunk, imagining that the heartwood should be sought in the branches and leaves. MN 138:7.2Such is the consequence for the venerables. Though you were face to face with the Buddha, you overlooked him, imagining that you should ask me about this matter. MN 138:7.3For he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is supreme. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One. MN 138:7.4That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter. MN 138:7.5You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

MN 138:8.1“Certainly he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is supreme. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One. MN 138:8.2That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter. MN 138:8.3We should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer. MN 138:8.4Still, Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. MN 138:8.5He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha. MN 138:8.6Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”

MN 138:9.1“Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 138:9.2“Yes, reverend,” they replied. MN 138:9.3Venerable Mahākaccāna said this:

MN 138:9.4“Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail: MN 138:9.5‘A mendicant should examine in any such a way that their consciousness is neither scattered and diffused externally nor stuck internally, and they are not anxious because of grasping. When this is the case and they are no longer anxious, there is for them no coming to be of the origin of suffering—of rebirth, old age, and death in the future.’ MN 138:9.6And this is how I understand the detailed meaning of this passage for recitation.

MN 139:0.2The Analysis of Non-Conflict

MN 139:1.1BJ 12.484PTS-VP-PLI 3.230So I have heard. MN 139:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 139:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 139:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 139:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 139:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 139:10.1‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’ MN 139:10.10‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’ MN 139:10.11That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 139:10.2That’s what I said, MN 139:10.3but why did I say it? MN 139:10.4When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is untrue, false, and harmful, then if at all possible you should not speak. MN 139:10.5When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true and correct, but harmful, then you should train yourself not to speak. MN 139:10.6When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak. MN 139:10.7When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are untrue, false, and harmful, then if at all possible you should not speak. MN 139:10.8When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true and correct, but harmful, then you should train yourself not to speak. MN 139:10.9When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak.

MN 139:11.1‘Don’t speak hurriedly.’ MN 139:11.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 139:11.3When speaking hurriedly, your body gets tired, your mind gets stressed, your voice gets stressed, your throat gets sore, and your words become unclear and hard to understand. MN 139:11.4When not speaking hurriedly, your body doesn’t get tired, your mind doesn’t get stressed, your voice doesn’t get stressed, your throat doesn’t get sore, and your words are clear and easy to understand. MN 139:11.5‘Don’t speak hurriedly.’ MN 139:11.6That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 139:12.1BJ 12.492PTS-VP-PLI 3.235‘Don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.’ MN 139:12.10And however it is known in those various localities, you speak accordingly, thinking: ‘It seems that the venerables are referring to this.’ MN 139:12.11That’s how you don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage. MN 139:12.12‘Don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.’ MN 139:12.13That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 139:12.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 139:12.3And how do you insist on local terminology and override normal usage? MN 139:12.4It’s when in different localities the same thing is known as a ‘plate’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘cup’, a ‘dish’, a ‘basin’, a ‘tureen’, or a ‘porringer’. MN 139:12.5And however it is known in those various localities, you speak accordingly, obstinately sticking to that and insisting: MN 139:12.6‘This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’ MN 139:12.7That’s how you insist on local terminology and override normal usage.

MN 139:12.8And how do you not insist on local terminology and not override normal usage? MN 139:12.9It’s when in different localities the same thing is known as a ‘plate’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘cup’, a ‘dish’, a ‘basin’, a ‘tureen’, or a ‘porringer’.

MN 139:13.1Now, mendicants, pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Indulging in such happiness is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.10Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:13.12That’s why this is a principle free of conflict.

MN 139:13.13PTS-VP-PLI 3.236The middle way of practice by which the Realized One was awakened gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment. It is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:13.15That’s why this is a principle free of conflict.

MN 139:13.16Flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.18That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict. MN 139:13.19Neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:13.21That’s why this is a principle free of conflict.

MN 139:13.22Sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure—is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.24That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict. MN 139:13.25The pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:13.27That’s why this is a principle free of conflict.

MN 139:13.28BJ 12.494Saying untrue, false, and harmful things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.3That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict. MN 139:13.30That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict. MN 139:13.31Saying true and correct, but harmful things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.33That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict. MN 139:13.34Saying true, correct, and beneficial things behind someone’s back is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:13.36That’s why this is a principle free of conflict.

MN 139:13.37PTS-VP-PLI 3.237Saying untrue, false, and harmful things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.39That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict. MN 139:13.4Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:13.40Saying true and correct, but harmful things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.42That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict. MN 139:13.43Saying true, correct, and beneficial things in someone’s presence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:13.45That’s why this is a principle free of conflict.

MN 139:13.46Speaking hurriedly is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.48That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict. MN 139:13.49Speaking unhurriedly is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:13.51That’s why this is a principle free of conflict.

MN 139:13.52Insisting on local terminology and overriding normal usage is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.54That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict. MN 139:13.55Not insisting on local terminology and not overriding normal usage is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:13.57That’s why this is a principle free of conflict.

MN 139:13.6That’s why this is a principle free of conflict.

MN 139:13.7Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:13.9That’s why this is a principle beset by conflict.

MN 139:14.1So you should train like this: ‘We shall know the principles beset by conflict and the principles free of conflict. MN 139:14.2Knowing this, we will practice the way free of conflict.’

MN 139:14.3And, mendicants, Subhūti, the gentleman, practices the way of non-conflict.”

MN 139:14.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 139:14.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 139:2.1“Mendicants, I shall teach you the analysis of non-conflict. MN 139:2.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 139:2.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 139:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 139:3.1“Don’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless. MN 139:3.10This is the recitation passage for the analysis of non-conflict.

MN 139:3.2Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One woke up by understanding the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment. MN 139:3.3Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke. MN 139:3.4Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma. MN 139:3.5Know how to assess different kinds of pleasure. MN 139:3.6Knowing this, pursue inner bliss. MN 139:3.7Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence. MN 139:3.8Don’t speak hurriedly. MN 139:3.9Don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.

MN 139:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.231‘Don’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.’ MN 139:4.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 139:4.3Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Indulging in such happiness is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:4.4Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:4.5Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. MN 139:4.6Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. MN 139:4.7‘Don’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.’ MN 139:4.8That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 139:5.1BJ 12.486‘Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One woke up by understanding the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.’ MN 139:5.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 139:5.3It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is: MN 139:5.4right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. MN 139:5.5‘Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One woke up by understanding the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.’ MN 139:5.6That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 139:6.1‘Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke. MN 139:6.2Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.’ MN 139:6.3That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

MN 139:7.1And how is there flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma?

MN 139:7.10In speaking like this, some are rebuked: ‘All those who have not given up the fetters of rebirth are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

MN 139:7.12In speaking like this, some are flattered: ‘All those who have given up the fetters of rebirth are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ MN 139:7.14That’s how there is flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma.

MN 139:7.2In speaking like this, some are rebuked: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in such happiness are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

MN 139:7.4In speaking like this, some are flattered: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’

MN 139:7.6PTS-VP-PLI 3.232In speaking like this, some are rebuked: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in it are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

MN 139:7.8In speaking like this, some are flattered: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’

MN 139:8.1And how is there neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma?

MN 139:8.12You don’t say: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in it are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’ MN 139:8.13Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma: MN 139:8.14‘The indulgence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.’

MN 139:8.17You don’t say: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ MN 139:8.18Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma: MN 139:8.19‘Breaking off the indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.’ MN 139:8.2You don’t say: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in such happiness are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

MN 139:8.22PTS-VP-PLI 3.233You don’t say: ‘All those who have not given up the fetters of rebirth are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’ MN 139:8.23Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma: MN 139:8.24‘When the fetter of rebirth is not given up, rebirth is also not given up.’

MN 139:8.26You don’t say: ‘All those who have given up the fetters of rebirth are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ MN 139:8.27Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma: MN 139:8.28‘When the fetter of rebirth is given up, rebirth is also given up.’ MN 139:8.3Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma: MN 139:8.30That’s how there is neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma. MN 139:8.31‘Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke. MN 139:8.32Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.’ MN 139:8.33That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 139:8.4‘The indulgence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.’

MN 139:8.7BJ 12.488You don’t say: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ MN 139:8.8Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma: MN 139:8.9‘Breaking off the indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.’

MN 139:9.1BJ 12.490PTS-VP-PLI 3.234‘Know how to assess different kinds of pleasure. MN 139:9.10Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 139:9.11These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 139:9.12The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure. MN 139:9.13Such pleasure should not be cultivated or developed, but should be feared, I say. MN 139:9.14Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 139:9.15As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption … MN 139:9.16third absorption … MN 139:9.17fourth absorption. MN 139:9.18This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening. MN 139:9.19Such pleasure should be cultivated and developed, and should not be feared, I say. MN 139:9.2Knowing this, pursue inner bliss.’ MN 139:9.20‘Know how to assess different kinds of pleasure. MN 139:9.21Knowing this, pursue inner bliss.’ MN 139:9.22That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 139:9.3That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 139:9.4There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation. MN 139:9.5What five? MN 139:9.6Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 139:9.7Sounds known by the ear … MN 139:9.8Smells known by the nose … MN 139:9.9Tastes known by the tongue …
  • MN 140:0.1Middle Discourses 140

MN 140:0.2The Analysis of the Elements

MN 140:1.1BJ 12.496So I have heard. MN 140:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the Magadhan lands when he arrived at Rājagaha. MN 140:1.3He went to see Bhaggava the potter, and said,

MN 140:10.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.240‘This person has eighteen mental preoccupations.’ MN 140:10.10‘This person has eighteen mental preoccupations.’ MN 140:10.11That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 140:10.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 140:10.3Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity. MN 140:10.4Hearing a sound with the ear … MN 140:10.5Smelling an odor with the nose … MN 140:10.6Tasting a flavor with the tongue …

MN 140:10.7Feeling a touch with the body … MN 140:10.8Becoming conscious of a thought with the mind, one is preoccupied with a thought that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity. MN 140:10.9So there are six preoccupations with happiness, six preoccupations with sadness, and six preoccupations with equanimity.

MN 140:11.1‘This person has four foundations.’ MN 140:11.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 140:11.3The foundations of wisdom, truth, generosity, and peace. MN 140:11.4‘This person has four foundations.’ MN 140:11.5That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 140:12.1BJ 12.500‘Don’t neglect wisdom, preserve truth, foster generosity, and train only for peace.’ MN 140:12.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

MN 140:13.1And how does one not neglect wisdom? MN 140:13.2There are these six elements: MN 140:13.3the elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.

MN 140:14.1And what is the earth element? MN 140:14.2The earth element may be interior or exterior. MN 140:14.3And what is the interior earth element? MN 140:14.4Anything hard, solid, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes MN 140:14.5head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, or anything else hard, solid, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 140:14.6This is called the interior earth element. MN 140:14.7The interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element. MN 140:14.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 140:14.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.

MN 140:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.241And what is the water element? MN 140:15.2The water element may be interior or exterior. MN 140:15.3And what is the interior water element? MN 140:15.4Anything that’s water, watery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes MN 140:15.5bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine, or anything else that’s water, watery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 140:15.6This is called the interior water element. MN 140:15.7The interior water element and the exterior water element are just the water element. MN 140:15.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 140:15.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the water element, detaching the mind from the water element.

MN 140:16.1And what is the fire element? MN 140:16.2The fire element may be interior or exterior. MN 140:16.3And what is the interior fire element? MN 140:16.4Anything that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes MN 140:16.5that which warms, that which ages, that which heats you up when feverish, that which properly digests food and drink, or anything else that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 140:16.6This is called the interior fire element. MN 140:16.7The interior fire element and the exterior fire element are just the fire element. MN 140:16.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 140:16.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the fire element, detaching the mind from the fire element.

MN 140:17.1BJ 12.502And what is the air element? MN 140:17.2The air element may be interior or exterior. MN 140:17.3And what is the interior air element? MN 140:17.4Anything that’s air, airy, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes MN 140:17.5winds that go up or down, winds in the belly or the bowels, winds that flow through the limbs, in-breaths and out-breaths, or anything else that’s air, airy, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. MN 140:17.6This is called the interior air element. MN 140:17.7The interior air element and the exterior air element are just the air element. MN 140:17.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 140:17.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the air element, detaching the mind from the air element.

MN 140:18.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.242And what is the space element? MN 140:18.2The space element may be interior or exterior. MN 140:18.3And what is the interior space element? MN 140:18.4Anything that’s space, spacious, and appropriated that’s internal, pertaining to an individual. This includes MN 140:18.5the ear canals, nostrils, and mouth; and the space for swallowing what is eaten and drunk, the space where it stays, and the space for excreting it from the nether regions. MN 140:18.6This is called the interior space element. MN 140:18.7The interior space element and the exterior space element are just the space element. MN 140:18.8This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 140:18.9When you truly see with right understanding, you reject the space element, detaching the mind from the space element.

MN 140:19.1There remains only consciousness, pure and bright.

MN 140:19.10Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral. MN 140:19.11When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’ MN 140:19.12They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.’

MN 140:19.13BJ 12.504PTS-VP-PLI 3.243When you rub two sticks together, heat is generated and fire is produced. But when you part the sticks and lay them aside, any corresponding heat ceases and stops. MN 140:19.14In the same way, pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant. … MN 140:19.2And what does that consciousness know? MN 140:19.22They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.’

MN 140:19.3It knows ‘pleasure’ and ‘pain’ and ‘neutral’. MN 140:19.4Pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant. MN 140:19.5When they feel a pleasant feeling, they know: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling.’ MN 140:19.6They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, the corresponding pleasant feeling ceases and stops.’

MN 140:19.7Painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful. MN 140:19.8When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’ MN 140:19.9They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, the corresponding painful feeling ceases and stops.’

MN 140:2.1“Bhaggava, if it is no trouble, I’d like to spend a single night in your workshop.”

MN 140:2.2“It’s no trouble, sir. MN 140:2.3But there’s a renunciate already staying there. MN 140:2.4If he allows it, sir, you may stay as long as you like.”

MN 140:20.1There remains only equanimity, pure, bright, pliable, workable, and radiant. MN 140:20.2It’s like when a goldsmith or a goldsmith’s apprentice prepares a forge, fires the crucible, picks up some gold with tongs and puts it in the crucible. From time to time they fan it, from time to time they sprinkle water on it, and from time to time they just watch over it. That gold becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and is ready to be worked. Then the goldsmith can successfully create any kind of ornament they want, whether a bracelet, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland. MN 140:20.3In the same way, there remains only equanimity, pure, bright, pliable, workable, and radiant.

MN 140:21.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.244They understand: MN 140:21.2‘If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite space, my mind would develop accordingly. MN 140:21.3And this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time. MN 140:21.4If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite consciousness, my mind would develop accordingly. MN 140:21.5And this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time. MN 140:21.6If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of nothingness, my mind would develop accordingly. MN 140:21.7And this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time. MN 140:21.8If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, my mind would develop accordingly. MN 140:21.9And this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time.’

MN 140:22.1BJ 12.506They understand:

MN 140:22.10They neither make a choice nor form an intention to continue existence or to end existence. MN 140:22.11Because of this, they don’t grasp at anything in the world. MN 140:22.12Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

MN 140:22.13They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’

MN 140:22.2‘If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite space, my mind would develop accordingly. MN 140:22.3But that is conditioned. MN 140:22.4If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite consciousness … MN 140:22.6nothingness … MN 140:22.8neither perception nor non-perception, my mind would develop accordingly. MN 140:22.9But that is conditioned.’

MN 140:23.1If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it. MN 140:23.2If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it. MN 140:23.3If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

MN 140:24.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.245If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached. MN 140:24.2If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached. MN 140:24.3If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached. MN 140:24.4Feeling the end of the body approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’ Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’ MN 140:24.5They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’

MN 140:24.6Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn. MN 140:24.7As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to lack of fuel. MN 140:24.8In the same way, feeling the end of the body approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’ Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’ MN 140:24.9They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’

MN 140:25.1Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of wisdom. MN 140:25.2For this is the ultimate noble wisdom, namely, MN 140:25.3the knowledge of the ending of suffering.

MN 140:26.1Their freedom, being founded on truth, is unshakable. MN 140:26.2For that which is false has a deceptive nature, while that which is true has an undeceptive nature—extinguishment. MN 140:26.3Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of truth. MN 140:26.4For this is the ultimate noble truth, namely, MN 140:26.5that which has an undeceptive nature—extinguishment.

MN 140:27.1BJ 12.508In their ignorance, they used to acquire attachments. MN 140:27.2Those have been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so they are unable to arise in the future. MN 140:27.3Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of generosity. MN 140:27.4For this is the ultimate noble generosity, namely, MN 140:27.5letting go of all attachments.

MN 140:28.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.246In their ignorance, they used to be covetous, full of desire and lust. MN 140:28.2That has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so it’s unable to arise in the future. MN 140:28.3In their ignorance, they used to be contemptuous, full of ill will and malevolence. MN 140:28.4That has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so it’s unable to arise in the future. MN 140:28.5In their ignorance, they used to be ignorant, full of delusion. MN 140:28.6That has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so it’s unable to arise in the future. MN 140:28.7Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of peace. MN 140:28.8For this is the ultimate noble peace, namely, MN 140:28.9the pacification of greed, hate, and delusion.

MN 140:29.1‘Don’t neglect wisdom, preserve truth, foster generosity, and train only for peace.’ MN 140:29.2That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 140:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.238Now at that time a gentleman named Pukkusāti had gone forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith in the Buddha. MN 140:3.2And it was he who had first taken up residence in the workshop. MN 140:3.3Then the Buddha approached Venerable Pukkusāti and said, MN 140:3.4“Mendicant, if it is no trouble, I’d like to spend a single night in the workshop.”

MN 140:3.5“The potter’s workshop is spacious, reverend. MN 140:3.6Please stay as long as you like.”

MN 140:30.1‘They have four foundations, standing on which the streams of identification don’t flow. And when the streams of identification don’t flow, they’re called a sage at peace.’ MN 140:30.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

MN 140:31.1These are all forms of identifying: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’ MN 140:31.2Identification is a disease, a boil, a dart. MN 140:31.3Having gone beyond all identification, one is called a sage at peace. MN 140:31.4The sage at peace is not reborn, does not grow old, and does not die. They are not shaken, and do not yearn. MN 140:31.5For they have nothing which would cause them to be reborn. Not being reborn, how could they grow old? Not growing old, how could they die? Not dying, how could they be shaken? Not shaking, for what could they yearn?

MN 140:32.1‘They have four foundations, standing on which the streams of identification don’t flow. And when the streams of identification don’t flow, they’re called a sage at peace.’ MN 140:32.2That’s what I said, and this is why I said it. MN 140:32.3Mendicant, you should remember this brief analysis of the six elements.”

MN 140:33.1BJ 12.510PTS-VP-PLI 3.247Then Venerable Pukkusāti thought, MN 140:33.2“It seems the Teacher has come to me! The Holy One has come to me! The fully awakened Buddha has come to me!” He got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, bowed with his head to the Buddha’s feet, and said, MN 140:33.3“I have made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to presume to address the Buddha as ‘reverend’. MN 140:33.4Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”

MN 140:33.5“Indeed, mendicant, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to act in that way. MN 140:33.6But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it. MN 140:33.7For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”

MN 140:34.1“Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

MN 140:34.2“But mendicant, are your bowl and robes complete?”

MN 140:34.3“No, sir, they are not.”

MN 140:34.4“The Realized Ones do not ordain those whose bowl and robes are incomplete.”

MN 140:35.1And then Venerable Pukkusāti approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

MN 140:35.2But while he was wandering in search of a bowl and robes, a stray cow took his life.

MN 140:36.1Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, MN 140:36.2“Sir, the gentleman named Pukkusāti, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away. MN 140:36.3Where has he been reborn in his next life?”

MN 140:36.4“Mendicants, Pukkusāti was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings. MN 140:36.5With the ending of the five lower fetters, he’s been reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.”

MN 140:36.6That is what the Buddha said. MN 140:36.7Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 140:4.1Then the Buddha entered the workshop and spread out a grass mat to one side. He sat down cross-legged, with his body straight, and established mindfulness right there. MN 140:4.2He spent most of the night sitting meditation, MN 140:4.3and so did Pukkusāti.

MN 140:4.4BJ 12.498PTS-VP-PLI 3.239Then it occurred to the Buddha, MN 140:4.5“This gentleman’s conduct is impressive. MN 140:4.6Why don’t I question him?”

MN 140:4.7So the Buddha said to Pukkusāti, MN 140:5.1“In whose name have you gone forth, reverend? Who is your Teacher? Whose teaching do you believe in?”

MN 140:5.10There the Blessed One is now staying, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”

MN 140:5.11“But have you ever seen that Buddha? MN 140:5.12Would you recognize him if you saw him?”

MN 140:5.13“No, I’ve never seen him, MN 140:5.14and I wouldn’t recognize him if I did.”

MN 140:5.2“Reverend, there is the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family. MN 140:5.3He has this good reputation: MN 140:5.4‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ MN 140:5.5I’ve gone forth in his name. MN 140:5.6That Blessed One is my Teacher, MN 140:5.7and I believe in his teaching.”

MN 140:5.8“But mendicant, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

MN 140:5.9“In the northern lands there is a city called Sāvatthī.

MN 140:6.1Then it occurred to the Buddha, MN 140:6.2“This gentleman has gone forth in my name. MN 140:6.3Why don’t I teach him the Dhamma?”

MN 140:6.4So the Buddha said to Pukkusāti, MN 140:6.5“Mendicant, I shall teach you the Dhamma. MN 140:6.6Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 140:6.7“Yes, reverend,” replied Pukkusāti. MN 140:6.8The Buddha said this:

MN 140:7.1“‘This person has six elements, six fields of contact, and eighteen mental preoccupations. MN 140:7.2They have four foundations, standing on which the streams of identification don’t flow. And when the streams of identification don’t flow, they’re called a sage at peace. MN 140:7.3Don’t neglect wisdom, preserve truth, foster generosity, and train only for peace.’ MN 140:7.4This is the recitation passage for the analysis of the elements.

MN 140:8.1‘This person has six elements.’ MN 140:8.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 140:8.3There are these six elements: MN 140:8.4the elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness. MN 140:8.5‘This person has six elements.’ MN 140:8.6That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 140:9.1‘This person has six fields of contact.’ MN 140:9.2That’s what I said, but why did I say it? MN 140:9.3The fields of contact of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. MN 140:9.4‘This person has six fields of contact.’ MN 140:9.5That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

MN 141:0.2The Analysis of the Truths

MN 141:1.1BJ 12.512PTS-VP-PLI 3.248So I have heard. MN 141:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana. MN 141:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 141:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 141:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 141:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 141:10.1And what is the noble truth of suffering? MN 141:10.2Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.

MN 141:11.1And what is rebirth? MN 141:11.2The rebirth, inception, conception, reincarnation, manifestation of the aggregates, and acquisition of the sense fields of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings. MN 141:11.3This is called rebirth.

MN 141:12.1And what is old age? MN 141:12.2The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings. MN 141:12.3This is called old age.

MN 141:13.1And what is death? MN 141:13.2The passing away, perishing, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, laying to rest of the corpse, and cutting off of the life faculty of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings. MN 141:13.3This is called death.

MN 141:14.1And what is sorrow? MN 141:14.2The sorrow, sorrowing, state of sorrow, inner sorrow, inner deep sorrow in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering. MN 141:14.3This is called sorrow.

MN 141:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.250And what is lamentation? MN 141:15.2The wail, lament, wailing, lamenting, state of wailing and lamentation in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering. MN 141:15.3This is called lamentation.

MN 141:16.1And what is pain? MN 141:16.2Physical pain, physical displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact. MN 141:16.3This is called pain.

MN 141:17.1And what is sadness? MN 141:17.2Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact. MN 141:17.3This is called sadness.

MN 141:18.1BJ 12.516And what is distress? MN 141:18.2The stress, distress, state of stress and distress in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering. MN 141:18.3This is called distress.

MN 141:19.1And what is ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering’? MN 141:19.10‘Oh, if only we were not liable to experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress! If only sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress would not come to us!’ MN 141:19.11But you can’t get that by wishing. MN 141:19.12This is: ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’

MN 141:19.2In sentient beings who are liable to be reborn, such a wish arises: MN 141:19.3‘Oh, if only we were not liable to be reborn! If only rebirth would not come to us!’ MN 141:19.4But you can’t get that by wishing. MN 141:19.5This is: ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’ MN 141:19.6In sentient beings who are liable to grow old … MN 141:19.7fall ill … MN 141:19.8die … MN 141:19.9experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, such a wish arises:

MN 141:2.1“Near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world. MN 141:2.2It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths. MN 141:2.3What four?

MN 141:20.1And what is ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’? MN 141:20.2They are the grasping aggregates that consist of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness. MN 141:20.3This is called ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.’ MN 141:20.4This is called the noble truth of suffering.

MN 141:21.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.251And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering? MN 141:21.2It’s the craving that leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, looking for enjoyment in various different realms. That is, MN 141:21.3craving for sensual pleasures, craving to continue existence, and craving to end existence. MN 141:21.4This is called the noble truth of the origin of suffering.

MN 141:22.1And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering? MN 141:22.2It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it. MN 141:22.3This is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.

MN 141:23.1And what is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering? MN 141:23.2It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is: MN 141:23.3right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

MN 141:24.1And what is right view? MN 141:24.2Knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. MN 141:24.3This is called right view.

MN 141:25.1And what is right thought? MN 141:25.2Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness. MN 141:25.3This is called right thought.

MN 141:26.1And what is right speech? MN 141:26.2Refraining from lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and talking nonsense. MN 141:26.3This is called right speech.

MN 141:27.1BJ 12.518And what is right action? MN 141:27.2Refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct. MN 141:27.3This is called right action.

MN 141:28.1And what is right livelihood? MN 141:28.2It’s when a noble disciple gives up wrong livelihood and earns a living by right livelihood. MN 141:28.3This is called right livelihood.

MN 141:29.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.252And what is right effort? MN 141:29.2It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise. MN 141:29.3They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up. MN 141:29.4They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise. MN 141:29.5They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development. MN 141:29.6This is called right effort.

MN 141:3.1The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

MN 141:30.1And what is right mindfulness? MN 141:30.2It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 141:30.3They meditate observing an aspect of feelings … MN 141:30.4mind … MN 141:30.5principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world. MN 141:30.6This is called right mindfulness.

MN 141:31.1And what is right immersion? MN 141:31.2It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 141:31.3As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. MN 141:31.4And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ MN 141:31.5Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. MN 141:31.6This is called right immersion. MN 141:31.7This is called the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

MN 141:32.1Near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world. MN 141:32.2It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.”

MN 141:32.3That’s what Venerable Sāriputta said. MN 141:32.4Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Sāriputta said.

MN 141:4.1Near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world. MN 141:4.2It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.

MN 141:5.1Mendicants, you should cultivate friendship with Sāriputta and Moggallāna. MN 141:5.2You should associate with Sāriputta and Moggallāna. MN 141:5.3They’re astute, and they support their spiritual companions. MN 141:5.4Sāriputta is just like the mother who gives birth, MN 141:5.5while Moggallāna is like the one who raises the child. MN 141:5.6Sāriputta guides people to the fruit of stream-entry, Moggallāna to the highest goal. MN 141:5.7Sāriputta is able to explain, teach, assert, establish, clarify, analyze, and reveal the four noble truths in detail.”

MN 141:6.1That is what the Buddha said. MN 141:6.2When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

MN 141:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.249Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the mendicants, MN 141:7.2“Reverends, mendicants!”

MN 141:7.3“Reverend,” they replied. MN 141:7.4Sāriputta said this:

MN 141:8.1BJ 12.514“Near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world. MN 141:8.2It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths. MN 141:8.3What four?

MN 141:9.1The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

MN 142:0.2The Analysis of Religious Donations

MN 142:1.1BJ 12.520PTS-VP-PLI 3.253So I have heard. MN 142:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

MN 142:10.1And how is a religious donation purified by the giver, not the recipient? MN 142:10.2It’s when the giver is ethical, of good character, but the recipient is unethical, of bad character.

MN 142:11.1And how is a religious donation purified by the recipient, not the giver? MN 142:11.2It’s when the giver is unethical, of bad character, but the recipient is ethical, of good character.

MN 142:12.1And how is a religious donation purified by neither the giver nor the recipient? MN 142:12.2It’s when both the giver and the recipient are unethical, of bad character.

MN 142:13.1BJ 12.526PTS-VP-PLI 3.257And how is a religious donation purified by both the giver and the recipient? MN 142:13.2It’s when both the giver and the recipient are ethical, of good character. MN 142:13.4These are the four ways of purifying a religious donation.”

MN 142:14.1That is what the Buddha said. MN 142:14.10that offering is purified by the receivers.

MN 142:14.11When an unethical and untrusting person, MN 142:14.12gives an improper gift to unethical persons, MN 142:14.13not trusting in the ample fruit of deeds, MN 142:14.14I declare that gift is not very fruitful.

MN 142:14.15When an ethical person with trusting heart MN 142:14.16gives a proper gift to ethical persons, MN 142:14.17trusting in the ample fruit of deeds, MN 142:14.18I declare that gift is abundantly fruitful.

MN 142:14.19But when a passionless one gives to the passionless MN 142:14.2Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

MN 142:14.20a proper gift with trusting heart, MN 142:14.21trusting in the ample fruit of deeds, MN 142:14.22that’s truly the best of material gifts.”

MN 142:14.3“When an ethical person with trusting heart MN 142:14.4gives a proper gift to unethical persons, MN 142:14.5trusting in the ample fruit of deeds, MN 142:14.6that offering is purified by the giver.

MN 142:14.7When an unethical and untrusting person, MN 142:14.8gives an improper gift to ethical persons, MN 142:14.9not trusting in the ample fruit of deeds,

MN 142:2.1Then Mahāpajāpati Gotamī approached the Buddha bringing a new pair of garments. She bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha,

MN 142:2.13For a third time, Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī said to the Buddha, MN 142:2.14“Sir, I have spun and woven this new pair of garments specially for the Buddha. MN 142:2.15May the Buddha please accept this from me out of compassion.”

MN 142:2.16And for a third time, the Buddha said to her, MN 142:2.17“Give it to the Saṅgha, Gotamī. MN 142:2.18When you give to the Saṅgha, both the Saṅgha and I will be honored.”

MN 142:2.2“Sir, I have spun and woven this new pair of garments specially for the Buddha. MN 142:2.3May the Buddha please accept this from me out of compassion.”

MN 142:2.4When she said this, the Buddha said to her, MN 142:2.5“Give it to the Saṅgha, Gotamī. MN 142:2.6When you give to the Saṅgha, both the Saṅgha and I will be honored.”

MN 142:2.7For a second time …

MN 142:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.254When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha, MN 142:3.10The Buddha has been very helpful to Mahāpajāpatī.”

MN 142:3.2“Sir, please accept the new pair of garments from Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī. MN 142:3.3Sir, Mahāpajāpatī was very helpful to the Buddha. As his aunt, she raised him, nurtured him, and gave him her milk. MN 142:3.4When the Buddha’s birth mother passed away, she nurtured him at her own breast.

MN 142:3.5And the Buddha has been very helpful to Mahāpajāpatī. MN 142:3.6It is owing to the Buddha that Mahāpajāpatī has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha. MN 142:3.7It’s owing to the Buddha that she refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, committing sexual misconduct, lying, and taking alcoholic drinks that cause negligence. MN 142:3.8It’s owing to the Buddha that she has experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and has the ethics loved by the noble ones. MN 142:3.9It’s owing to the Buddha that she is free of doubt regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

MN 142:4.1BJ 12.522“That’s so true, Ānanda. MN 142:4.2When someone has enabled you to go for refuge, it’s not easy to repay them MN 142:4.3by bowing down to them, rising up for them, greeting them with joined palms, and observing proper etiquette for them; or by providing them with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

MN 142:4.4When someone has enabled you to refrain from killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and alcoholic drinks that cause negligence, it’s not easy to repay them …

MN 142:4.6When someone has enabled you to have experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and the ethics loved by the noble ones, it’s not easy to repay them …

MN 142:4.8When someone has enabled you to be free of doubt regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation, it’s not easy to repay them MN 142:4.9by bowing down to them, rising up for them, greeting them with joined palms, and observing proper etiquette for them; or by providing them with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

MN 142:5.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.255Ānanda, there are these fourteen religious donations to individuals. MN 142:5.10This is the fourth religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.11One gives a gift to a non-returner. MN 142:5.12This is the fifth religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.13One gives a gift to someone practicing to realize the fruit of non-return. MN 142:5.14This is the sixth religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.15One gives a gift to a once-returner. MN 142:5.16This is the seventh religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.17One gives a gift to someone practicing to realize the fruit of once-return. MN 142:5.18This is the eighth religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.19One gives a gift to a stream-enterer. MN 142:5.2What fourteen? MN 142:5.20This is the ninth religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.21One gives a gift to someone practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry. MN 142:5.22This is the tenth religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.23One gives a gift to an outsider who is free of sensual desire. MN 142:5.24This is the eleventh religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.25One gives a gift to an ordinary person who has good ethical conduct. MN 142:5.26This is the twelfth religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.27One gives a gift to an ordinary person who has bad ethical conduct. MN 142:5.28This is the thirteenth religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.29One gives a gift to an animal. MN 142:5.3One gives a gift to the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. MN 142:5.30This is the fourteenth religious donation to an individual.

MN 142:5.4This is the first religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.5One gives a gift to a Buddha awakened for themselves. MN 142:5.6This is the second religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.7One gives a gift to a perfected one. MN 142:5.8This is the third religious donation to an individual. MN 142:5.9One gives a gift to someone practicing to realize the fruit of perfection.

MN 142:6.1BJ 12.524Now, Ānanda, gifts to the following persons may be expected to yield the following returns. To an animal, a hundred times. To an unethical ordinary person, a thousand. To an ethical ordinary person, a hundred thousand. To an outsider free of sensual desire, 10,000,000,000. But a gift to someone practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry may be expected to yield incalculable, immeasurable returns. How much more so a gift to a stream-enterer, someone practicing to realize the fruit of once-return, a once-returner, someone practicing to realize the fruit of non-return, a non-returner, someone practicing to realize the fruit of perfection, a perfected one, or a Buddha awakened for themselves? How much more so a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha?

MN 142:7.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.256But there are, Ānanda, seven religious donations bestowed on a Saṅgha. MN 142:7.10This is the fourth religious donation bestowed on a Saṅgha. MN 142:7.11One gives a gift, thinking: ‘Appoint this many monks and nuns for me from the Saṅgha.’ MN 142:7.12This is the fifth religious donation bestowed on a Saṅgha. MN 142:7.13One gives a gift, thinking: ‘Appoint this many monks for me from the Saṅgha.’ MN 142:7.14This is the sixth religious donation bestowed on a Saṅgha. MN 142:7.15One gives a gift, thinking: ‘Appoint this many nuns for me from the Saṅgha.’ MN 142:7.16This is the seventh religious donation bestowed on a Saṅgha.

MN 142:7.2What seven? MN 142:7.3One gives a gift to the communities of both monks and nuns headed by the Buddha. MN 142:7.4This is the first religious donation bestowed on a Saṅgha. MN 142:7.5One gives a gift to the communities of both monks and nuns after the Buddha has finally become extinguished. MN 142:7.6This is the second religious donation bestowed on a Saṅgha. MN 142:7.7One gives a gift to the Saṅgha of monks. MN 142:7.8This is the third religious donation bestowed on a Saṅgha. MN 142:7.9One gives a gift to the Saṅgha of nuns.

MN 142:8.1In times to come there will be members of the spiritual family merely by virtue of wearing ocher cloth around their necks; but they are unethical and of bad character. MN 142:8.2People will give gifts to those unethical people in the name of the Saṅgha. MN 142:8.3Even then, I say, a religious donation bestowed on the Saṅgha is incalculable and immeasurable. MN 142:8.4But I say that there is no way a personal offering can be more fruitful than one bestowed on a Saṅgha.

MN 142:9.1Ānanda, there are these four ways of purifying a religious donation. MN 142:9.2What four? MN 142:9.3There’s a religious donation that’s purified by the giver, not the recipient. MN 142:9.4There’s a religious donation that’s purified by the recipient, not the giver. MN 142:9.5There’s a religious donation that’s purified by neither the giver nor the recipient. MN 142:9.6There’s a religious donation that’s purified by both the giver and the recipient.

MN 143:0.2Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

MN 143:1.1BJ 12.528PTS-VP-PLI 3.258So I have heard. MN 143:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 143:10.1You should train like this: MN 143:10.10That’s how you should train.

MN 143:10.2‘I shall not grasp the earth element … MN 143:10.5water element … MN 143:10.6fire element … MN 143:10.7air element … MN 143:10.8space element … MN 143:10.9consciousness element, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the consciousness element.’

MN 143:11.1You should train like this: MN 143:11.2‘I shall not grasp form … MN 143:11.5feeling … MN 143:11.6perception … MN 143:11.7choices … MN 143:11.8consciousness, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on consciousness.’ MN 143:11.9That’s how you should train.

MN 143:12.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.261You should train like this: MN 143:12.2‘I shall not grasp the dimension of infinite space … MN 143:12.5the dimension of infinite consciousness … MN 143:12.6the dimension of nothingness … MN 143:12.7the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’ MN 143:12.8That’s how you should train.

MN 143:13.1BJ 12.534You should train like this: MN 143:13.2‘I shall not grasp this world, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on this world.’ MN 143:13.3That’s how you should train.

MN 143:14.1You should train like this: MN 143:14.2‘I shall not grasp the other world, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the other world.’ MN 143:14.3That’s how you should train. MN 143:14.4You should train like this: MN 143:14.5‘I shall not grasp whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by my mind, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on that.’ MN 143:14.6That’s how you should train.”

MN 143:15.1When he said this, Anāthapiṇḍika cried and burst out in tears. MN 143:15.10There are gentlemen with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching. MN 143:15.11There will be those who understand the teaching!”

MN 143:15.2Venerable Ānanda said to him, MN 143:15.3“Are you failing, householder? Are you fading, householder?”

MN 143:15.4“No, sir. MN 143:15.5But for a long time I have paid homage to the Buddha and the esteemed mendicants. MN 143:15.6Yet I have never before heard such a Dhamma talk.”

MN 143:15.7“Householder, it does not occur to us to teach such a Dhamma talk to white-clothed laypeople. MN 143:15.8Rather, we teach like this to those gone forth.”

MN 143:15.9“Well then, Master Sāriputta, let it occur to you to teach such a Dhamma talk to white-clothed laypeople as well!

MN 143:16.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.262And when the venerables Sāriputta and Ānanda had given the householder Anāthapiṇḍika this advice they got up from their seat and left. MN 143:16.2Not long after they had left, Anāthapiṇḍika passed away and was reborn in the host of Joyful Gods.

MN 143:17.1Then, late at night, the glorious god Anāthapiṇḍika, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, MN 143:17.10not by clan or wealth.

MN 143:17.11BJ 12.536That’s why an astute person, MN 143:17.12seeing what’s good for themselves, MN 143:17.13would examine the teaching rationally, MN 143:17.14and thus be purified in it.

MN 143:17.15Sāriputta has true wisdom, MN 143:17.16ethics, and also peace. MN 143:17.17Any mendicant who has crossed over MN 143:17.18can at best equal him.”

MN 143:17.2and addressed the Buddha in verse:

MN 143:17.3“This is indeed that Jeta’s Grove, MN 143:17.4frequented by the Saṅgha of hermits, MN 143:17.5where the King of Dhamma stayed: MN 143:17.6it brings me joy!

MN 143:17.7Deeds, knowledge, and principle; MN 143:17.8ethical conduct, an excellent livelihood; MN 143:17.9by these are mortals purified,

MN 143:18.1This is what the god Anāthapiṇḍika said, MN 143:18.2and the teacher approved. MN 143:18.3Then the god Anāthapiṇḍika, MN 143:18.4knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

MN 143:19.1Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.

MN 143:2.1Now at that time the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, suffering, gravely ill. MN 143:2.10‘Sir, please visit him at his home out of compassion.’”

MN 143:2.11“Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Anāthapiṇḍika asked. MN 143:2.19Sāriputta consented in silence.

MN 143:2.2Then he addressed a man, MN 143:2.3“Please, mister, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him: MN 143:2.4‘Sir, the householder Anāthapiṇḍika is sick, suffering, gravely ill. MN 143:2.5He bows with his head to your feet.’ MN 143:2.6Then go to Venerable Sāriputta, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. MN 143:20.2“Sir, that god must surely have been Anāthapiṇḍika. MN 143:20.3For the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was devoted to Venerable Sāriputta.”

MN 143:20.4“Good, good, Ānanda. MN 143:20.5You’ve reached the logical conclusion, as far as logic goes. MN 143:20.6For that was indeed the god Anāthapiṇḍika.”

MN 143:20.7That is what the Buddha said. MN 143:20.8Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 143:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.259Then Venerable Sāriputta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went with Venerable Ānanda as his second monk to Anāthapiṇḍika’s home. MN 143:4.1BJ 12.530“I’m not keeping well, Master Sāriputta, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing, not its fading, is evident. MN 143:4.2The winds piercing my head are so severe, it feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point. MN 143:4.6The winds piercing my belly are so severe, it feels like a deft butcher or their apprentice is slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver. MN 143:4.8The burning in my body is so severe, it feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals. MN 143:5.1“That’s why, householder, you should train like this: MN 143:5.11‘I shall not grasp the tongue, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the tongue.’ … MN 143:5.14‘I shall not grasp the body, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the body.’ … MN 143:5.17‘I shall not grasp the mind, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the mind.’ MN 143:5.18That’s how you should train.
