MN 144:0.2Advice to Channa

MN 144:1.1BJ 12.538So I have heard. MN 144:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

MN 144:10.1BJ 12.542“Reverend Channa, what have you seen, what have you directly known in these things that you regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”

MN 144:10.7PTS-VP-PLI 3.266“Reverend Sāriputta, after seeing cessation, after directly knowing cessation in these things I regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’.”

MN 144:11.1When he said this, Venerable Mahācunda said to Venerable Channa:

MN 144:11.10And when the venerables Sāriputta and Mahācunda had given Venerable Channa this advice they got up from their seat and left.

MN 144:11.2“So, Reverend Channa, you should pay close attention to this instruction of the Buddha whenever you can: MN 144:11.3‘For the dependent there is agitation. For the independent there’s no agitation. MN 144:11.4When there’s no agitation there is tranquility. MN 144:11.5When there is tranquility there’s no inclination. MN 144:11.6When there’s no inclination there’s no coming and going. MN 144:11.7When there’s no coming and going there’s no passing away and reappearing. MN 144:11.8When there’s no passing away and reappearing there’s no this world or world beyond or between the two. MN 144:11.9Just this is the end of suffering.’”

MN 144:12.1BJ 12.544Not long after those venerables had left, Venerable Channa slit his wrists.

MN 144:13.1Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, MN 144:13.10But the mendicant Channa did no such thing. MN 144:13.11You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa slit his wrists blamelessly.’”

MN 144:13.12That is what the Buddha said. MN 144:13.13Satisfied, Venerable Sāriputta was happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 144:13.2“Sir, Venerable Channa has slit his wrists. MN 144:13.3Where has he been reborn in his next life?”

MN 144:13.4“Sāriputta, didn’t the mendicant Channa declare his blamelessness to you personally?”

MN 144:13.5“Sir, there is a Vajjian village named Pubbavijjhana MN 144:13.6where Channa had families with whom he was friendly, intimate, and familiar.”

MN 144:13.7“The mendicant Channa did indeed have such families. MN 144:13.8But this is not enough for me to call someone ‘blameworthy’. MN 144:13.9When someone lays down this body and takes up another body, I call them ‘blameworthy’.

MN 144:2.1Now at that time the venerables Sāriputta, Mahācunda, and Channa were staying on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

MN 144:3.1Now at that time Venerable Channa was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

MN 144:3.2Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahācunda and said to him, MN 144:3.3“Come, Reverend Cunda, let’s go to see Venerable Channa and ask about his illness.”

MN 144:3.4“Yes, reverend,” replied Mahācunda.

MN 144:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.264And then Sāriputta and Mahācunda went to see Channa and exchanged greetings with him. MN 144:4.2When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

MN 144:5.1BJ 12.540“Reverend Sāriputta, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading. MN 144:5.10Reverend Sāriputta, I will slit my wrists. I don’t wish to live.”

MN 144:5.2The winds piercing my head are so severe, it feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point. MN 144:5.4The pain in my head is so severe, it feels like a strong man tightening a tough leather strap around my head. MN 144:5.6The winds piercing my belly are so severe, it feels like a deft butcher or their apprentice is slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver. MN 144:5.8The burning in my body is so severe, it feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals. MN 144:5.9I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.

MN 144:6.1“Please don’t slit your wrists! MN 144:6.2Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going. MN 144:6.3If you don’t have any suitable food, we’ll find it for you. MN 144:6.4If you don’t have suitable medicine, we’ll find it for you. MN 144:6.5If you don’t have a capable carer, we’ll find one for you. MN 144:6.6Please don’t slit your wrists! MN 144:6.7Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going.”

MN 144:7.1“Reverend Sāriputta, it’s not that I don’t have suitable food, MN 144:7.2or suitable medicine, MN 144:7.3or a capable carer. MN 144:7.4Moreover, for a long time now I have served the Teacher with love, not without love. MN 144:7.5For it is proper for a disciple to serve the Teacher with love, not without love. MN 144:7.6You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa slit his wrists blamelessly.’”

MN 144:8.1“I’d like to ask you about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”

MN 144:8.2“Ask, Reverend Sāriputta. When I’ve heard it I’ll know.”

MN 144:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.265“Reverend Channa, do you regard the eye, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness in this way: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’? MN 145:0.2Advice to Puṇṇa

MN 145:1.1BJ 12.546PTS-VP-PLI 3.267So I have heard. MN 145:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 145:1.3Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Puṇṇa came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha, MN 145:2.1“Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

MN 145:2.2“Well then, Puṇṇa, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 145:2.3“Yes, sir,” replied Puṇṇa. MN 145:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 145:3.1“Puṇṇa, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 145:3.10If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them, MN 145:3.11this gives rise to relishing. MN 145:3.12Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.

MN 145:3.2If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them, MN 145:3.3this gives rise to relishing. MN 145:3.4Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.

MN 145:3.5There are sounds known by the ear … MN 145:3.6smells known by the nose … MN 145:3.7tastes known by the tongue … MN 145:3.8touches known by the body … MN 145:3.9thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

MN 145:4.1There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. MN 145:4.10If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, MN 145:4.11relishing ceases. MN 145:4.12When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.

MN 145:4.2If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, MN 145:4.3relishing ceases. MN 145:4.4When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.

MN 145:4.5PTS-VP-PLI 3.268There are sounds known by the ear … MN 145:4.6smells known by the nose … MN 145:4.7tastes known by the tongue … MN 145:4.8touches known by the body … MN 145:4.9thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

MN 145:5.1BJ 12.548Puṇṇa, now that I’ve given you this brief advice, what country will you live in?”

MN 145:5.10“But if they do hit you with their fists, what will you think of them then?”

MN 145:5.11“If they hit me with their fists, I’ll think: MN 145:5.12‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t throw stones at me.’ MN 145:5.13That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One. MN 145:5.14That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”

MN 145:5.15“But if they do throw stones at you, what will you think of them then?”

MN 145:5.16“If they throw stones at me, I’ll think: MN 145:5.17‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t beat me with a club.’ MN 145:5.18That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One. MN 145:5.19That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”

MN 145:5.2“Sir, there’s a country named Sunāparanta. I shall live there.”

MN 145:5.20PTS-VP-PLI 3.269“But if they do beat you with a club, what will you think of them then?”

MN 145:5.21“If they beat me with a club, I’ll think: MN 145:5.22‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t stab me with a knife.’ MN 145:5.23That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One. MN 145:5.24That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”

MN 145:5.25“But if they do stab you with a knife, what will you think of them then?”

MN 145:5.26“If they stab me with a knife, I’ll think: MN 145:5.27‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t take my life with a sharp knife.’ MN 145:5.28That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One. MN 145:5.29That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”

MN 145:5.3“The people of Sunāparanta are wild and rough, Puṇṇa.

MN 145:5.30BJ 12.550“But if they do take your life with a sharp knife, what will you think of them then?”

MN 145:5.31“If they take my life with a sharp knife, I’ll think: MN 145:5.32‘There are disciples of the Buddha who looked for someone to assist with slitting their wrists because they were horrified, repelled, and disgusted with the body and with life. And I have found this without looking!’ MN 145:5.33That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One. MN 145:5.34That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”

MN 145:5.5If they abuse and insult you, what will you think of them?”

MN 145:5.6“If they abuse and insult me, I will think: MN 145:5.7‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t hit me with their fists.’ MN 145:5.8That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One. MN 145:5.9That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”

MN 145:6.1“Good, good Puṇṇa! MN 145:6.2Having such self-control and peacefulness, you will be quite capable of living in Sunāparanta. MN 145:6.3Now, Puṇṇa, go at your convenience.”

MN 145:7.1And then Puṇṇa welcomed and agreed with the Buddha’s words. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sunāparanta. MN 145:7.2Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sunāparanta, MN 145:7.3and stayed there. MN 145:7.4Within that rainy season he confirmed around five hundred male and five hundred female lay followers. And within that same rainy season he realized the three knowledges. MN 145:7.5Some time later he became fully extinguished.

MN 145:8.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.270Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him, MN 145:8.2“Sir, the gentleman named Puṇṇa, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away. MN 145:8.3Where has he been reborn in his next life?”

MN 145:8.4“Mendicants, Puṇṇa was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings. MN 145:8.5Puṇṇa has become completely extinguished.”

MN 145:8.6That is what the Buddha said. MN 145:8.7Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 146:0.2Advice from Nandaka

MN 146:1.1BJ 12.552So I have heard. MN 146:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

MN 146:10.1BJ 12.560Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood. The roots, trunk, branches and leaves, and shadow were all impermanent and perishable. MN 146:10.10‘These six exterior sense fields are impermanent. MN 146:10.11But the feeling—whether pleasant, painful, or neutral—that I experience due to these six exterior sense fields is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’ MN 146:10.12Would they be speaking rightly?”

MN 146:10.13“No, sir. MN 146:10.14Why is that? MN 146:10.15Because each kind of feeling arises dependent on the corresponding condition. MN 146:10.16When the corresponding condition ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”

MN 146:10.17“Good, good, sisters! MN 146:10.18That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.

MN 146:10.2Now, suppose someone was to say: MN 146:10.3‘There’s a large tree standing with heartwood. The roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable. But the shadow is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’ MN 146:10.4Would they be speaking rightly?”

MN 146:10.5“No, sir. MN 146:10.6Why is that? MN 146:10.7Because that large tree’s roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable, MN 146:10.8let alone the shadow.”

MN 146:10.9“In the same way, suppose someone was to say:

MN 146:11.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.275Suppose a deft butcher or their apprentice was to kill a cow and carve it with a sharp meat cleaver. Without damaging the flesh inside or the hide outside, MN 146:11.10Because even if they wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say: MN 146:11.11‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before,’ MN 146:11.12still that cow is not joined to that hide.”

MN 146:11.2they’d cut, carve, sever, and slice through the connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments, MN 146:11.3and then peel off the outer hide. Then they’d wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say: MN 146:11.4‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before.’ MN 146:11.5Would they be speaking rightly?”

MN 146:11.6“No, sir. MN 146:11.7Why is that?

MN 146:12.1“I’ve made up this simile to make a point. MN 146:12.2And this is the point. MN 146:12.3‘The inner flesh’ is a term for the six interior sense fields. MN 146:12.4‘The outer hide’ is a term for the six exterior sense fields. MN 146:12.5‘The connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments’ is a term for greed and relishing. MN 146:12.6‘A sharp meat cleaver’ is a term for noble wisdom. MN 146:12.7And it is that noble wisdom which cuts, carves, severs, and slices the connecting corruption, fetter, and bond.

MN 146:13.1BJ 12.562Sisters, by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements. MN 146:13.10It is by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors that a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

MN 146:13.2What seven? MN 146:13.3It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness, MN 146:13.4investigation of principles, MN 146:13.5energy, MN 146:13.6rapture, MN 146:13.7tranquility, MN 146:13.8immersion, MN 146:13.9and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

MN 146:14.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.276Then after giving this advice to the nuns, Nandaka dismissed them, saying, MN 146:14.2“Go, sisters, it is time.”

MN 146:14.3And then those nuns approved and agreed with what Nandaka had said. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled him, keeping him on their right. Then they went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side. The Buddha said to them, MN 146:14.4“Go, nuns, it is time.”

MN 146:14.5Then those nuns bowed to the Buddha respectfully circled him, keeping him on their right, before departing.

MN 146:15.1Soon after those nuns had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants: MN 146:15.2“Suppose, mendicants, it was the sabbath of the fourteenth day. You wouldn’t get lots of people MN 146:15.3wondering whether the moon is full or not, since it is obviously not full.

MN 146:15.4In the same way, those nuns were uplifted by Nandaka’s Dhamma teaching, but they still haven’t found what they’re looking for.”

MN 146:16.1BJ 12.564PTS-VP-PLI 3.277Then the Buddha said to Nandaka, MN 146:16.2“Well then, Nandaka, tomorrow you should give those nuns the same advice again.”

MN 146:16.3“Yes, sir,” Nandaka replied. MN 146:16.4And the next day he went to those nuns, and all unfolded just like the previous day.

MN 146:2.1Then Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī together with around five hundred nuns approached the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him, MN 146:2.2“Sir, may the Buddha please advise MN 146:2.3and instruct the nuns. MN 146:2.4Please give the nuns a Dhamma talk.”

MN 146:27.1Soon after those nuns had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants: MN 146:27.2“Suppose, mendicants, it was the sabbath of the fifteenth day. You wouldn’t get lots of people MN 146:27.3wondering whether the moon is full or not, since it is obviously full. MN 146:27.4In the same way, those nuns were uplifted by Nandaka’s Dhamma teaching, and they found what they’re looking for. MN 146:27.5Even the last of these five hundred nuns is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”

MN 146:27.6That is what the Buddha said. MN 146:27.7Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 146:3.1Now at that time the senior monks were taking turns to advise the nuns. MN 146:3.2But Venerable Nandaka didn’t want to take his turn.

MN 146:3.3Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda, MN 146:3.4“Ānanda, whose turn is it to advise the nuns today?”

MN 146:3.5“It’s Nandaka’s turn, sir, MN 146:3.6but he doesn’t want to do it.”

MN 146:4.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.271Then the Buddha said to Nandaka, MN 146:4.10and washed his feet. MN 146:4.11Those nuns bowed, and sat down to one side.

MN 146:4.12Nandaka said to them, MN 146:4.2“Nandaka, please advise MN 146:4.3and instruct the nuns. MN 146:4.4Please, brahmin, give the nuns a Dhamma talk.”

MN 146:4.5“Yes, sir,” replied Nandaka. Then, in the morning, he robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms. MN 146:4.6He wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Royal Monastery with a companion. MN 146:4.7Those nuns saw him coming off in the distance, MN 146:4.8so they spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet. MN 146:4.9Nandaka sat down on the seat spread out, MN 146:5.1“Sisters, this talk shall be in the form of questions. MN 146:5.2When you understand, say so. When you don’t understand, say so. MN 146:5.3If anyone has a doubt or uncertainty, ask me about it: MN 146:5.4‘Why, sir, does it say this? What does that mean?’”

MN 146:5.5“We’re already delighted and satisfied with Venerable Nandaka, since he invites us like this.”

MN 146:6.1BJ 12.554PTS-VP-PLI 3.272“What do you think, sisters? MN 146:6.10Is the ear … MN 146:6.12nose … MN 146:6.14tongue … MN 146:6.16body … MN 146:6.18mind permanent or impermanent?”

MN 146:6.19“Impermanent, sir.”

MN 146:6.2Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

MN 146:6.20“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

MN 146:6.21“Suffering, sir.”

MN 146:6.22“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: MN 146:6.23‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

MN 146:6.24“No, sir. MN 146:6.25Why is that? MN 146:6.26Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom: MN 146:6.27‘So these six interior sense fields are impermanent.’”

MN 146:6.28“Good, good, sisters! MN 146:6.29That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.

MN 146:6.3“Impermanent, sir.”

MN 146:6.4“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

MN 146:6.5“Suffering, sir.”

MN 146:6.6“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: MN 146:6.7‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

MN 146:6.8“No, sir.”

MN 146:9.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.274Suppose there was an oil lamp burning. The oil, wick, flame, and light were all impermanent and perishable.

MN 148:0.2Six By Six

MN 148:1.1BJ 12.582So I have heard. MN 148:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 148:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 148:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 148:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 148:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 148:10.1If anyone says, ‘the eye is self,’ that is not tenable. MN 148:10.10That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that MN 148:10.11sights are self. MN 148:10.12So the eye is not self and sights are not self.

MN 148:10.13BJ 12.586If anyone says, ‘eye consciousness is self,’ that is not tenable. MN 148:10.14The arising and vanishing of eye consciousness is evident, MN 148:10.15so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes. MN 148:10.16That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that MN 148:10.17eye consciousness is self. MN 148:10.18So the eye, sights, and eye consciousness are not self.

MN 148:10.19If anyone says, ‘eye contact is self,’ that is not tenable. MN 148:10.2The arising and vanishing of the eye is evident, MN 148:10.20The arising and vanishing of eye contact is evident, MN 148:10.21so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes. MN 148:10.22That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that MN 148:10.23eye contact is self. MN 148:10.24So the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are not self.

MN 148:10.25PTS-VP-PLI 3.283If anyone says, ‘feeling is self,’ that is not tenable. MN 148:10.26The arising and vanishing of feeling is evident, MN 148:10.27so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes. MN 148:10.28That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that MN 148:10.29feeling is self. MN 148:10.3so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes. MN 148:10.30So the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and feeling are not self.

MN 148:10.31If anyone says, ‘craving is self,’ that is not tenable. MN 148:10.32The arising and vanishing of craving is evident, MN 148:10.33so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes. MN 148:10.34That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that MN 148:10.35craving is self. MN 148:10.36So the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, feeling, and craving are not self.

MN 148:10.4That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that MN 148:10.5the eye is self. MN 148:10.6So the eye is not self.

MN 148:10.7If anyone says, ‘sights are self,’ that is not tenable. MN 148:10.8The arising and vanishing of sights is evident, MN 148:10.9so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

MN 148:11.1If anyone says, ‘the ear is self’ … MN 148:11.10So the mind is not self.

MN 148:11.2‘the nose is self’ … MN 148:11.3‘the tongue is self’ … MN 148:11.4‘the body is self’ … MN 148:11.5‘the mind is self,’ that is not tenable. MN 148:11.6The arising and vanishing of the mind is evident, MN 148:11.7so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes. MN 148:11.8That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that MN 148:11.9the mind is self.

MN 148:12.1If anyone says, ‘thoughts are self’ … MN 148:13.1‘mind consciousness is self’ … MN 148:14.1BJ 12.588‘mind contact is self’ … MN 148:15.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.284‘feeling is self’ … MN 148:15.10That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that MN 148:15.11craving is self. MN 148:15.12So the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, mind contact, feeling, and craving are not self.

MN 148:15.7‘craving is self,’ that is not tenable. MN 148:15.8The arising and vanishing of craving is evident, MN 148:15.9so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

MN 148:16.1Now, mendicants, this is the way that leads to the origin of identity. MN 148:16.2You regard the eye like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

MN 148:17-21.1You regard sights … MN 148:17-21.10mind … thoughts … mind consciousness … mind contact … feeling … craving like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

MN 148:17-21.2eye consciousness … MN 148:17-21.3eye contact … MN 148:17-21.4feeling … MN 148:17-21.5craving like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’ MN 148:17-21.6You regard the ear … MN 148:17-21.7nose … MN 148:17-21.8tongue … MN 148:17-21.9body …

MN 148:2.1“Mendicants, I shall teach you the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And I shall reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure, namely, MN 148:2.2the six sets of six. MN 148:2.3Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 148:2.4“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 148:2.5The Buddha said this:

MN 148:22.1BJ 12.590PTS-VP-PLI 3.285But this is the way that leads to the cessation of identity. MN 148:22.2You regard the eye like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

MN 148:23-27.1You regard sights … MN 148:23-27.10mind like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 148:23-27.11You regard thoughts … MN 148:23-27.12mind consciousness … MN 148:23-27.13mind contact … MN 148:23-27.14feeling … MN 148:23-27.15craving like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

MN 148:23-27.2eye consciousness … MN 148:23-27.3eye contact … MN 148:23-27.4feeling … MN 148:23-27.5craving like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ MN 148:23-27.6You regard the ear … MN 148:23-27.7nose … MN 148:23-27.8tongue … MN 148:23-27.9body …

MN 148:28.1Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for the arising of what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral. MN 148:28.2When you experience a pleasant feeling, if you approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it, MN 148:28.3the underlying tendency to greed underlies that. MN 148:28.4When you experience a painful feeling, if you sorrow and wail and lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion, MN 148:28.5the underlying tendency to repulsion underlies that. MN 148:28.6When you experience a neutral feeling, if you don’t truly understand that feeling’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape, MN 148:28.7the underlying tendency to ignorance underlies that. MN 148:28.8Mendicants, without giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, without dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, without eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, without giving up ignorance and without giving rise to knowledge, it’s simply impossible to make an end of suffering in the present life.

MN 148:29-33.1Ear consciousness … MN 148:29-33.10When you experience a neutral feeling, if you don’t truly understand that feeling’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape, MN 148:29-33.11the underlying tendency to ignorance underlies that. MN 148:29-33.12Mendicants, without giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, without dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, without eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, without giving up ignorance and without giving rise to knowledge, it’s simply impossible to make an end of suffering in the present life.

MN 148:29-33.2Nose consciousness … MN 148:29-33.3Tongue consciousness … MN 148:29-33.4Body consciousness … MN 148:29-33.5Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for the arising of what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral. MN 148:29-33.6When you experience a pleasant feeling, if you approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it, MN 148:29-33.7the underlying tendency to greed underlies that. MN 148:29-33.8When you experience a painful feeling, if you sorrow and wail and lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion, MN 148:29-33.9the underlying tendency to repulsion underlies that.

MN 148:3.1“The six interior sense fields should be understood. The six exterior sense fields should be understood. The six classes of consciousness should be understood. The six classes of contact should be understood. The six classes of feeling should be understood. The six classes of craving should be understood.

MN 148:34.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.286Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. MN 149:0.2The Great Discourse on the Six Sense Fields

MN 149:1.1BJ 12.594So I have heard. MN 149:1.2At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. MN 149:1.3There the Buddha addressed the mendicants, MN 149:1.4“Mendicants!”

MN 149:1.5“Venerable sir,” they replied. MN 149:1.6The Buddha said this:

MN 149:10.1The view of such a person is right view. MN 149:10.10serenity and discernment. MN 149:10.11They completely understand by direct knowledge those things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge. MN 149:10.12They give up by direct knowledge those things that should be given up by direct knowledge. MN 149:10.13They develop by direct knowledge those things that should be developed by direct knowledge. MN 149:10.14They realize by direct knowledge those things that should be realized by direct knowledge.

MN 149:10.2Their intention is right intention, MN 149:10.3their effort is right effort, MN 149:10.4their mindfulness is right mindfulness, MN 149:10.5and their immersion is right immersion. MN 149:10.6And their actions of body and speech have already been fully purified before. MN 149:10.7So this noble eightfold path is fully developed.

MN 149:10.8When the noble eightfold path is developed, the following are fully developed: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, and the seven awakening factors.

MN 149:10.9And these two qualities proceed in conjunction:

MN 149:11.1And what are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge? MN 149:11.10These are the things that should be developed by direct knowledge.

MN 149:11.11PTS-VP-PLI 3.290And what are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge? MN 149:11.12Knowledge and freedom. MN 149:11.13These are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge.

MN 149:11.2You should say: ‘The five grasping aggregates.’ MN 149:11.3That is: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness. MN 149:11.4These are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.

MN 149:11.5BJ 12.598And what are the things that should be given up by direct knowledge? MN 149:11.6Ignorance and craving for continued existence. MN 149:11.7These are the things that should be given up by direct knowledge.

MN 149:11.8And what are the things that should be developed by direct knowledge? MN 149:11.9Serenity and discernment.

MN 149:12-18.1When you truly know and see the ear … MN 149:12-18.2nose … MN 149:12-18.3tongue … MN 149:12-18.4body … MN 149:12-18.5mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, mind contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises conditioned by mind contact, you are not aroused by desire for these things. …

MN 149:2.1“Mendicants, I shall teach you the great discourse on the six sense fields. MN 149:2.2Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

MN 149:2.3“Yes, sir,” they replied. MN 149:2.4The Buddha said this:

MN 149:26.3These are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge.”

MN 149:26.4That is what the Buddha said. MN 149:26.5Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

MN 149:3.1“Mendicants, when you don’t truly know and see the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises conditioned by eye contact, you’re aroused by desire for these things.

MN 149:3.2PTS-VP-PLI 3.288Someone who lives aroused like this—fettered, confused, concentrating on gratification—accumulates the five grasping aggregates for themselves in the future. MN 149:3.3And their craving—which leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, looking for enjoyment in various different realms—grows. MN 149:3.4Their physical and mental stress, MN 149:3.5torment, MN 149:3.6and fever grow. MN 149:3.7And they experience physical and mental suffering.

MN 149:4-7.1When you don’t truly know and see the ear … MN 149:4-7.2nose … MN 149:4-7.3tongue … MN 149:4-7.4body … MN 149:4-7.5mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, mind contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises conditioned by mind contact, you’re aroused by desire for these things.

MN 149:8.1BJ 12.596Someone who lives aroused like this—fettered, confused, concentrating on gratification—accumulates the five grasping aggregates for themselves in the future. MN 149:8.2And their craving—which leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, looking for enjoyment in various different realms—grows. MN 149:8.3Their physical and mental stress, MN 149:8.4torment, MN 149:8.5and fever grow. MN 149:8.6And they experience physical and mental suffering.

MN 149:9.1When you do truly know and see the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises conditioned by eye contact, you’re not aroused by desire for these things.

MN 149:9.2PTS-VP-PLI 3.289Someone who lives unaroused like this—unfettered, unconfused, concentrating on drawbacks—disperses the the five grasping aggregates for themselves in the future. MN 149:9.3And their craving—which leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, looking for enjoyment in various different realms—is given up. MN 149:9.4Their physical and mental stress, MN 149:9.5torment, MN 149:9.6and fever are given up. MN 149:9.7And they experience physical and mental pleasure.

MN 150:0.2With the People of Nagaravinda

MN 150:1.1BJ 12.602PTS-VP-PLI 3.291So I have heard. MN 150:1.2At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Nagaravinda.

MN 150:2.1The brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda heard, MN 150:2.2“It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Nagaravinda, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. MN 150:2.3He has this good reputation: MN 150:2.4‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ MN 150:2.5He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others. MN 150:2.6He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. MN 150:2.7It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

MN 150:3.1Then the brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. The Buddha said to them:

MN 150:4.1BJ 12.604PTS-VP-PLI 3.292“Householders, if wanderers who follow another path were to ask you: MN 150:4.10tastes known by the tongue… MN 150:4.11touches known by the body … MN 150:4.12thoughts known by the mind, who are not peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves badly among the good by way of body, speech, and mind. They don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration. MN 150:4.13Why is that? MN 150:4.14Because we ourselves are not free of these things, so we do not see that they have any higher good conduct than us. MN 150:4.15That’s why they don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.’ MN 150:4.16When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them.

MN 150:4.2‘What kind of ascetic or brahmin doesn’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration?’ MN 150:4.3You should answer them: MN 150:4.4‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are not free of greed, hate, and delusion for sights known by the eye, who are not peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves badly among the good by way of body, speech, and mind. They don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration. MN 150:4.5Why is that? MN 150:4.6Because we ourselves are not free of these things, so we do not see that they have any higher good conduct than us. MN 150:4.7That’s why they don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration. MN 150:4.8There are ascetics and brahmins who are not free of greed, hate, and delusion for sounds known by the ear … MN 150:4.9smells known by the nose …

MN 150:5.1If wanderers who follow other paths were to ask you: MN 150:5.10tastes known by the tongue … MN 150:5.11touches known by the body … MN 150:5.12thoughts known by the mind, who are peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves well by way of body, speech, and mind. They deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration. MN 150:5.13Why is that? MN 150:5.14Because we ourselves are not free of these things, but we see that they have a higher good conduct than us. MN 150:5.15That’s why they deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration. MN 150:5.16When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them.

MN 150:5.2‘What kind of ascetic or brahmin deserves honor, respect, reverence, and veneration?’ MN 150:5.3You should answer them: MN 150:5.4‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are free of greed, hate, and delusion for sights known by the eye, who are peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves well by way of body, speech, and mind. They deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration. MN 150:5.5Why is that? MN 150:5.6Because we ourselves are not free of these things, but we see that they have a higher good conduct than us. MN 150:5.7That’s why they deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration. MN 150:5.8There are ascetics and brahmins who are free of greed, hate, and delusion for sounds known by the ear … MN 150:5.9smells known by the nose …

MN 150:6.1BJ 12.606PTS-VP-PLI 3.293If wanderers who follow other paths were to ask you: MN 150:6.2‘But what reasons and evidence do you have regarding those venerables that justifies saying, MN 150:6.3“Clearly those venerables are free of greed, hate, and delusion, or practicing to be free of them”?’ MN 150:6.4You should answer them: MN 150:6.5‘It’s because those venerables frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. MN 150:6.6In such places there are no sights known by the eye to see and enjoy, there are no sounds known by the ear to hear and enjoy, no odors known by the nose to smell and enjoy, no flavors known by the tongue to taste and enjoy, and no touches known by the body to feel and enjoy. MN 150:6.7These are the reasons and evidence that you have regarding those venerables that justifies saying, MN 150:6.8“Clearly those venerables are free of greed, hate, and delusion, or practicing to be free of them”.’ MN 150:6.9When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them.”

MN 150:7.1When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda said to the Buddha, MN 150:7.2“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! MN 150:7.3As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways. MN 150:7.4We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha. MN 150:7.5From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

MN 152:2.1Then the brahmin student Uttara, a pupil of the brahmin Pārāsariya, approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. MN 152:3.1PTS-VP-PLI 3.299Knowing this, the Buddha addressed Venerable Ānanda, MN 152:3.2“Ānanda, the development of the faculties taught by Pārāsariya is quite different from the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One.”

MN 152:4.1BJ 12.618“And how, Ānanda, is there the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One? MN 152:4.10It’s like how a person with good sight might open their eyes then shut them; or might shut their eyes then open them. MN 152:4.11Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which any liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking at all that came up in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized. MN 152:4.12In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding sights known by the eye.

MN 152:8.2They understand: MN 152:8.3‘Liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking have come up in me. MN 152:8.4That’s conditioned, coarse, and dependently originated. MN 152:8.5But this is peaceful and sublime, namely MN 152:8.6equanimity.’ MN 152:8.7Then the liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking that came up in them cease, MN 152:8.8and equanimity becomes stabilized. MN 152:8.9It’s like how a strong person can extend or contract their arm.

MN 152:9.1Furthermore, when a mendicant knows a thought with their mind, liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking come up in them. MN 152:9.10The drops would be slow to fall, but they’d quickly dry up and evaporate. MN 152:9.11Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which any liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking at all that came up in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized. MN 152:9.12In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding thoughts known by the mind. MN 152:9.13That’s how there is the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One.

MN 152:9.2They understand: MN 152:9.3‘Liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking have come up in me. MN 152:9.4That’s conditioned, coarse, and dependently originated. MN 152:9.5But this is peaceful and sublime, namely MN 152:9.6equanimity.’ MN 152:9.7Then the liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking that came up in them cease, MN 152:9.8and equanimity becomes stabilized. MN 152:9.9It’s like how a strong person could let two or three drops of water fall onto an iron cauldron that had been heated all day.
